headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 8 at Iraqi Market
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber on Saturday attacked a group of Iraqi soldiers at an entrance of a large market in the northern city of Mosul, killing 5 soldiers and 3 other people and wounding 19, according to an Iraqi security official.

headline: Sushi and Asian Fusion, Infinitely Varied
text: XAGA combines two restaurant trends that show no signs of slowing: sushi and Asian fusion. The full name of this six-month-old restaurant in Merrick is, in fact, Xaga Sushi Asian Fusion. It has an older sibling with the same name in Hewlett.

headline: A Cheerful Brasserie, With Sweet Accents
text: THE BRASSERIE is a cheerful, attractive French restaurant within walking distance of the Fairfield train station. It has loads of character: exposed brick walls and a large blackboard listing handwritten specials. Tables are comfortably spaced, and the single-page menu offers a variety of appealing choices — French and not-so-French — like tapas, burgers, frog’s legs, bouillabaisse and short ribs. But as I watched the restaurant fill almost to capacity on a recent Saturday evening, I wondered if the rest of the room knew something I didn’t.

headline: Levee Breach Moves One Step Closer
text: CAIRO, Ill. — Chugging north along the Mississippi River, twin barges laden with more than 250 tons of explosive material were ordered to dock at a final staging area on Saturday in an apparent sign that the Army Corps of Engineers was making further preparations to breach a nearby levee, inundating roughly 130,000 acres of Missouri farmland to relieve pressure on the groaning levee system upstream.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Only Missing Ingredient Is a Bit of Quiet
text: I HAVE one word of advice for Larry Fishman, owner of the Rail House 1449: textiles.

headline: Baked Goods, Nothing Added
text: Susan O’Keefe was looking for a commercial kitchen to expand her wholesale baking business when she came across a sunny retail space in Croton-on-Hudson that changed her perspective. Home to a series of pizza parlors, the storefront is now redolent with the smell of baking cookies, cakes and muffins.

headline: Where the Diners Linger
text: Kathy West, co-owner of the Mockingbird Cafe, calls herself “my own worst promoter.” But the charming 40-seat cafe she and her husband, Tom, opened in August does a pretty good job of promoting itself.

headline: Coming Together Amid the Wreckage
text: The tornadoes that ripped through the South last week have been the deadliest natural disaster on American soil since Hurricane Katrina.

headline: A Bakery That Loves Butter
text: Don’t judge La Brioche French Bakery by its décor. The pine wainscoting, orange and red walls and linoleum floor all date to a previous era, when the building was occupied by the Boston Bakery. It is the delectable spread of breads and pastries that most clearly reflects the abilities of the current tenant, Colette Berube.

headline: Thank You for Taking Our Team’s Call. Now Please Hold.
text: They pipe music through Radio City Music Hall between picks at the N.F.L. draft. But the real background noise accompanying the three-day restocking for future seasons was provided by the legal maneuvering surrounding the lockout that threatens the start of the next one.

headline: Police Look Into Complaint by Walcott After Traffic Stop
text: A New York police official said on Saturday that an internal departmental investigation had been initiated into the treatment of the city’s schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, by two plainclothes police officers during a traffic stop in Queens on Thursday night.

headline: Blushing Newcomer
text: Rosato di Refosco hardly sounds like a wine from the East End. But it is the fourth and latest rosato — rosé in Italian — at the innovative Channing Daughters Winery in Bridgehampton. This newcomer is a winner.

headline: How Happy Are You? A Census Wants to Know
text: SOMERVILLE, Mass. — When they filled out the city’s census forms this spring, the people of Somerville got a new question. On a scale of 1 to 10, they were asked, “How happy do you feel right now?”

headline: A Couple’s Offerings of Film, Theater and Music
text: ARMONK, N.Y.

headline: Celebrating a Few Fertile Years in the Hamptons
text: In 1953, Conrad Marca-Relli, an artist associated with the Abstract Expressionists, left Manhattan, with all its distractions, for a cottage in Springs, a quiet hamlet in the town of East Hampton. His new home — “in terrible shape,” as he wrote years later — was next to the property of the painters Jackson Pollock and his wife, Lee Krasner.

headline: To Sell First Novel, Putting That Marketing Degree to Use
text: GREENLAWN, N.Y.

headline: Central Florida to Review Recruiting
text: Central Florida is taking allegations of potential N.C.A.A. violations raised in a New York Times article “very seriously,” according to a statement released by the university. A highly rated recruit, Kevin Ware, said that Central Florida used an intermediary, Kenneth Caldwell, to help recruit him, even arranging three-way telephone calls with Coach Donnie Jones when coaches were prohibited from contact with recruits. Caldwell has an extensive criminal record and ties to a prominent sport agent, though Caldwell denies working for an agent.

headline: The Joys and the Perils of Parenthood, Set to Music
text: “RATED P,” a new musical being staged May 5 to 8 at the South Orange Performing Arts Center, is about parenthood — “the whole thing, from the time you find out you’re pregnant all the way until the time you send them off to college,” said the writer, Sandy Rustin, of Maplewood.

headline: When Twin Towers Were a Dream
text: Matt Schatz, a versatile playwright-lyricist-composer, could have written a drama about a serious subject like the Iraq war or a frivolous musical with singing nuns or clueless Mormon missionaries. Those are the sorts of things that are big on Broadway this year. But Mr. Schatz chose to write a play about the relatively unpromising topic of the World Trade Center’s structural design.

headline: In Tornado Zone, Many Ask, ‘How Can We Help?’
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — So many contractors showed up at a high school gymnasium here on Saturday that they could not all fit. Even though the death count continued its grim climb upward in what is now the worst tornado disaster in the country since 1925, here at the epicenter people know that the rebuilding has to begin, and quickly.

headline: Vows: Jill & Guy
text: Jill Kaufman, a New Yorker, and Guy Tallent of Tennessee were going through divorces when they first met. They have since integrated two families — three kids under eight — into a new one.

headline: Gatlin Looking to Outrun Competition and Suspicions
text: PHILADELPHIA

headline: After Disaster, Skater Brings ‘a Little Smile to the People of Japan’
text: MOSCOW — If all had gone according to plan, the dateline on this story from the world figure skating championships would have been Tokyo. But the national tragedy that began with a powerful earthquake in the Pacific Ocean changed all that for Japan, just as it has disrupted so many plans and lives since March 11.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Romney Catches Himself on ‘Hang’ Metaphor
text: Mitt Romney, like many politicians, is no stranger to embarrassing statements: just a few months into his presidential run in 2008 he had already made so many gaffes that Time magazine put together a Top 10 list.

headline: Curves of the City
text: The domes and arches built by the Guastavino Company are everywhere, but you have to look for them.

headline: A Panoramic View of Guastavino
text: Some of the best work by Rafael Guastavino y Moreno and his son, Rafael Guastavino y Esposito, is out of the public eye.

headline: In These Portraits, a Challenge to Labels of ‘Sitter’ and ‘Artist’
text: The people have spoken, and the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum listened. Research conducted by the museum found that community members would like to see more exhibitions linked together by a common theme. And while giving the people what they want is not always a successful strategy — either for increasing museum attendance, or for art in general — it works well in the first exhibitions under the new plan, a group of six solo projects by contemporary artists titled “Portraiture at the Aldrich Contemporary Museum.”

headline: Evoking Jazz, Through Film
text: CAN one art form evoke another? The filmmakers Paul Bernays and Oren Jacoby think so. Working independently, some 15 years apart, each made a documentary about jazz that he hoped would mirror the music itself. The films will be shown at “Jazz Sessions: The Greats on Camera 2011” at the Jacob Burns Film Center  in Pleasantville.

headline: Lottery Numbers
text: April 30, 2011

headline: For Want of a Draw, a Player Loses the U.S. Title
text: Yury Shulman forgot the old saying that a tie is better than a loss during his quest to win the United States Chess Championship last week. And that opened the door for Gata Kamsky to capture his second straight title.

headline: Obama Zings Trump at White House Correspondents’ Dinner
text: Joe Biden. Michele Bachmann. Tim Pawlenty. Donald Trump.

headline: At N.F.L. Draft, Jets Collect a Rogues’ Gallery of Talent
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — In two seasons under Coach Rex Ryan, the Jets have operated as if no player is too risky, no background too questionable, no reputation too sullied. They have welcomed all types of questionable characters, as if starting an N.F.L. halfway house, and with consecutive trips to the A.F.C. title game, this strategy has worked, for the most part.

text: The Metropolitan Museum unveils its newly renovated medieval gallery and, in the adjacent sculpture hall, “Choirs of Angels,” a sumptuous little holiday show.

text: Photos of some of Liza Minnelli’s performances on stage and screen.

text: A highlight of the day’s sporting including gold medals, Rugby break-aways, and the Warrior Dash obstacle race.

headline: Job Losses in November
text: The nation’s employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.

headline: New York Through a Looking Glass
text: At the “Holiday Train Show” at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, electric trains run in loops around botanical versions of city landmarks.

headline: The Faces of the Unemployed
text: A portfolio of images from across the country as the ranks of the unemployed grow.

headline: Walking a Tightrope Between Nationalist and Populist
text: Ollanta Humala, the front-runner in Peru’s coming presidential election, has distanced himself from the far-left leanings of his 2006 bid in favor of a more populist approach, but transforming voters’ doubts into support is proving difficult.

headline: Costly Afghanistan Road Project Is Marred by Unsavory Alliances
text: GARDEZ, Afghanistan — When construction crews faced attacks while working on a major American-financed highway here in southeastern Afghanistan, Western contractors turned to a powerful local figure named simply Arafat, who was suspected to have links to Afghanistan’s insurgents.

headline: SAC’s Cohen’s Tells of ‘Rough Six Months’
text: Editor’s note: This post refers to an 2010 article in Vanity Fair. It was published in error.

headline: Prague’s Answer to Oktoberfest
text: The Czech Beer Festival is Prague’s answer to Oktoberfest.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 1
text: With Congress gearing up for a debate over the debt ceiling, discussion of federal spending and the budget dominates the Sunday talk shows. But following President Obama’s announcement of sanctions on Syrian officials and another week of Republican presidential posturing, the Middle East and the 2012 election are also on the agenda.

headline: Giants’ Picks in 2011 N.F.L. Draft
text: The Giants continued to shore up defensive positions on the third day of the draft, grabbing a safety and two linebackers, including the all-American Greg Jones in the sixth round.

headline: 7 Tips for Great Wedding Pictures
text: If the Royal Wedding hasn’t yet made you aware of just how mundane wedding photos can be, June is coming soon with fresh opportunities for clichéd group shots (“Smile! Smile, everybody! Smile!”)

headline: Jets’ Picks in 2011 N.F.L. Draft
text: The Jets focused on defensive linemen in the early rounds of the draft, but turned their attention to offense Saturday, including trading up in the fifth round to get T.C.U. receiver Jeremy Kerley. Their last two picks, Greg McElroy and Scotty McKnight, have known Mark Sanchez for years.

headline: ESPN, Mark Ingram and a Make-Him-Cry Moment
text: Not long after Alabama running back Mark Ingram was selected by the Saints with the 28th overall pick in the draft on Thursday, Suzy Kolber interviewed him for ESPN. After an initial question and response, Kolber read him an e-mail from Mark Ingram Sr., his father, who is in prison.

headline: Stone House by the Sea
text: Behind the scenes at the home of Alexandre de Betak in Majorca.

headline: John Paul II Beatified at Vatican Mass
text: VATICAN CITY — Lauding John Paul II as a giant of 20th-century history as well as a hero of the church, Pope Benedict XVI moved his towering predecessor one step closer to sainthood on Sunday in a celebratory Mass that drew more than a million people to Rome.

text: I encourage you to read John Tierney’s article, “How Happy Are You? In a Boston Suburb, It’s a Census Question.” Here’s the nut of the story, which speaks of an interesting effort in Somerville, Mass., to follow the lead of Bhutan and other countries testing new ways to gauge progress:

headline: Israel Holds Palestinian Funds as Deal Nears
text: JERUSALEM — Israel said Sunday that it was delaying the transfer of almost $90 million in tax revenue owed to the Palestinian Authority in a move against the emerging reconciliation between Fatah, the party that dominates the authority, and its Islamic rival, Hamas.

headline: One Fish, Two Fish, False-ish, True-ish
text: Two University of Washington scientists have just published a study in the journal Conservation Biology in collaboration with colleagues from Rutgers University and Dalhousie University arguing that the gloomiest predictions about the world’s fisheries are significantly exaggerated.

headline: Fiscalization and Hellenization
text: Kevin O’Rourke leads us to a good complaint by Colm McCarthy about the ECB’s handling of the eurozone crisis. McCarthy tells us that

headline: Finding the Drama in What Life Has Left Behind
text: It is not often you see a couple of characters dashing around the Bronx dressed in Kiplingesque explorers’ outfits. But last summer, two actors named Joey Rizzolo and Christopher Borg pulled on their aviator goggles and straightened their bow ties and set off on an expedition.

headline: Reaction to NATO Strike
text: Libyans react to the NATO airstrike late Saturday night that Libyan officials said killed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's youngest son, Seif al-Arab Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Mixed TV Ratings for the Royal Wedding
text: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. Still, it amounted to a record ratings day for some television channels.

headline: Mixed TV Ratings for the Royal Wedding
text: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. Still, it amounted to a record ratings day for some television channels.

headline: The Beatification of John Paul II
text: Lauding John Paul II as a giant of 20th century history, Pope Benedict XVI moved his predecessor one step closer to sainthood in a celebratory Mass on Sunday.

headline: Allies Defending Actions in Libya After Airstrike
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — NATO officials and Western leaders defended the increasingly aggressive airstrikes in Libya on Sunday after the Libyan government said one barrage had killed four members of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s family, raising criticism that the attacks exceeded the Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force.

headline: Money Talks, Regulation Walks
text: The Times editorial page is outraged at the proposal to exempt foreign-exchange swaps from regulation — and rightly so. Have we learned nothing from the crisis?

headline: Key Piece of Air France Data Recorder Is Found
text: PARIS — French accident investigators said Sunday that they had retrieved a key component from one of the flight recorders of an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic almost two years ago, reviving hopes that it could help explain why the plane went down.

headline: Granderson’s New Swing Continues To Pay Off
text: Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson hit another home run Sunday, his 22nd since last Aug. 14, or about the time Kevin Long, the team’s hitting coach, helped Granderson simplify his swing. Granderson apparently hit the refresh button on his mental approach then, too.

headline: A Canadian Party Gains Strength
text: OTTAWA — When Canada’s government collapsed in March, setting in motion a federal election to be held Monday, the timing looked especially bleak for the New Democrats, the perennial third-place party.

headline: Four Ensembles Unite for a Contemporary Composer’s Big Birthday
text: Steve Reich is in the enviable position, for a living composer, of not having to wait for milestone birthday celebrations to hear his music performed. Certain seminal works — “Drumming” (1971), Music for 18 Musicians (1976) and “Different Trains” (1988) — are heard at least once a season, and new scores are added immediately to his expansive Nonesuch discography. So when those birthdays do come — like Mr. Reich’s 75th birthday, on Oct. 3 — the stakes are raised: How do you make a concert of a composer’s works seem special when the music is heard all the time?

headline: Sensual Spanish Accent Arrives by Way of Quebec
text: Lots of shows do their best to break down the fourth wall, but tango productions tend to rely on it. There the audience members are, seated demurely in their rows of chairs, while on stage the dancers and musicians, dressed to the glittery nines, evoke sultry encounters in romantic, far-flung locales. The whole point is to be transported to another place.

headline: Roger Cohen Reports From Libya
text: From Ajdabiya, the Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen urges NATO to keep up pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his supporters.

headline: An Underworld Rescue With Dancers and Chorus
text: A renewed sense of loss is inevitable when the Metropolitan Opera revives the Mark Morris production of Gluck’s “Orfeo ed Euridice,” which was originally conceived for the superb mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died in 2006, 10 months before it was first performed. That sense became even more acute when the production returned on Friday evening, just a week after the death of Hunt Lieberson’s husband, the composer Peter Lieberson, also from cancer.

headline: A Viola and a Piano in Search of Common Ground
text: One may be the loneliest number, but two can be the most revealing. More than other ensembles, musical duos suggest narratives: rival siblings, say, or a blissful romance. But at a duet recital on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, the image that came to mind was of a couple out to dinner, each partner talking intently on his cellphone.

headline: Stage Where the Blood Is Real and Freshly Drawn
text: On Friday night a recording of Ivo Dimchev’s voice preceded his appearance in “Som Faves” with some words about the performance to follow: “My body will lose energy”; “We are all going to lose time”; and “Somebody will even lose his own blood.”

headline: Tunes for the Swank Who’d Rather Cha-Cha
text: The Copacabana, the Latin Quarter, El Morocco, the Stork Club, the Blue Angel and on and on: nowadays these fabled names tend to dissolve into a hazy, undifferentiated fantasy of glamour, cafe society and Manhattan nightlife before television arrived to change everything. And on Saturday evening the mists shrouding a world that is remembered largely by word of mouth and vintage live recordings were dissipated at the 92nd St. Y’s new Lyrics & Lyricists show, “The Crowd’s at El Morocco: The Heyday of the New York Nightclubs.”

headline: Songs of America, With Beauty and Gusto
text: Sarcasm is the prevailing mode in contemporary music about the American experience. Since many talented composers are dubious about the country and its history, their well-meaning attempts to grapple with them musically can easily slide into self-righteous critique. It may not be wrong, but it’s not interesting.

headline: German Politics Faces Grass-Roots Threat
text: KLEINMACHNOW, GERMANY — They are called “Wutbürger.” And they have become the bane of every political party in Germany.

headline: A Depression-Era Protest Ripped From the Headlines
text: “That’s socialism!” an angry character shouts in “One-Third of a Nation,” a play written during the Depression and now revived by the Metropolitan Playhouse. “It’s unconstitutional!” yells another, the president of a mortgage company.

headline: A Wry Eye on Problems of the Future
text: In his most recent film, “Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World,” Albert Brooks can be seen as a stand-up comic trying to entertain an audience in India. He tells a few jokes. Nobody laughs. He wonders why. Then he has the bright idea that maybe the crowd simply can’t follow him. How many people in the auditorium understand English, he asks? Every person in the audience raises a hand.

headline: Revisiting a Brash 2010 Slam
text: The Cavendish Invitational tournament starts on Wednesday in Henderson, Nev., on the outskirts of Las Vegas. The first two days feature the John Roberts Teams, won last year by Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son), Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness.

text: Johann Hari on Donald Trump and the GOP:

headline: Maryland, My Maryland
text: April 27 – May 4, 1861

headline: Beethoven Devotee Makes Some Keyboard Time for Schubert
text: There is nothing flashy or even very charismatic about the shy-looking, bushy-haired English pianist Paul Lewis. Still Mr. Lewis, 38, has steadily gained a well-deserved reputation as an accomplished and exceptionally thoughtful artist. So a sizable audience turned out for his recital on Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: New Series to Honor Duke Ellington
text: Duke Ellington, above, brought dance, music and variety shows to the Cotton Club in Harlem in the 1920s and ’30s. This year City Center’s Encores! series and Jazz at Lincoln Center will present “Cotton Club Parade,” a tribute to Ellington’s performances there, and the first in a new series of musical theater and jazz collaborations from the organizations. “Cotton Club Parade” will have six performances at City Center, Nov. 18 to 22, directed by Warren Carlyle (“Finian’s Rainbow”), with musical direction by Wynton Marsalis and featuring the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. The series will run every two years, with the next production scheduled at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center during its 2013-14 season. Tickets for “Cotton Club Parade” can be purchased through City Center beginning Aug. 15.

headline: Footnotes
text: “Mike Birbiglia’s My Girlfriend’s Boyfriend” has extended its run at the Barrow Street Theater. The sad but humorous love life of Mr. Birbiglia, below, a “This American Life” and “Moth” favorite, will play through June 25. Mr. Birbiglia’s 2008 show, “Sleepwalk With Me,” ran for eight months at the Bleecker Street Theater, was turned into a book and CD, and is being made into a movie. ... Branden Jacobs-Jenkins has been named the winner of the Paula Vogel playwriting award, the Vineyard Theater said. Ms. Vogel will present the award, which includes a residency at the Vineyard as well as a prize of $3,000, to Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins at a luncheon on June 9. Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins is the author of “Neighbors,” which played at the Public Theater last spring, and “The Octoroon: An Adaptation of The Octoroon Based on The Octoroon,” which was produced at Performance Space 122 last summer.

headline: ‘Fast Five’ Vrooms to No. 1 at Box Office
text: The North American box office came roaring back to life over the weekend as “Fast Five” (Universal Pictures), with Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson, from left above, opened in first place to an estimated $83.6 million in ticket sales. An animated holdover, 20th Century Fox’s “Rio,” was second with $14.4 million for a three-week total of $103.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. “Tyler Perry’s Madea’s Big Happy Family” (Lionsgate) was third with $10.5 million, for a two-week total of $41.1 million. “Water for Elephants” (Fox) was fourth, selling $9.1 million for a two-week total of $32.3 million. “Prom,” a low-budget comedy from Walt Disney Studios, failed to gain traction in its opening weekend, placing fifth with about $5 million.

headline: Ferguson to Direct Film About WikiLeaks Founder
text: Charles Ferguson has taken on his first nondocumentary project with HBO Films, directing a movie about Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Mr. Ferguson won an Oscar this year for his documentary “Inside Job,” about the origins of the 2008 financial crisis, and received a nomination for his 2007 film “No End In Sight,” about the American occupation in Iraq. Mr. Assange has been embroiled in controversy since November, when WikiLeaks made public confidential diplomatic cables from the State Department. Shortly afterward, he was arrested in Britain on charges of sexual abuse in Sweden; he has appealed a decision allowing his extradition to Sweden. He is also under investigation by the United States Justice Department. Other films about Mr. Assange, below, and WikiLeaks are in the works, The Los Angeles Times reported. DreamWorks has optioned several memoirs about Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks; Universal has a documentary by Alex Gibney (“Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room”) in production; and Annapurna Productions has said it is financing a film to be produced, and possibly written by, Mark Boal, whose “Hurt Locker” won him two Oscars in 2009, for original screenplay and best film.

headline: On Not Reading Keynes
text: I’ve been staying out of the truly stupid debate about whether Keynes advocated central planning; folks, this is not an issue to be settled by trawling his works for gotcha quotes. Keynes had a model, laid out at length in his General Theory; it was a model of how an otherwise workable market economy can suffer from inadequate demand, and how government can play a useful role by pumping up demand to achieve full employment. This model is, as Keynes himself said, moderately conservative in its implications.

headline: Mixed Television Ratings for the Royal Wedding
text: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. The Nielsen Company said that an average of 22.7 million viewers at home in the United States watched the wedding live (between 6 a.m. and 7:15 a.m. Eastern daylight time). That figure, encompassing viewers of 11 channels, reaffirmed pre-wedding polls that found only lukewarm interest in the nuptials among most Americans. Still, millions did tune in, leading to a record ratings day for some television channels. Between 4 a.m. and 10 a.m., when the wedding coverage was at its peak, CNN had an average of 1.66 million viewers, its biggest audience since the day after the presidential election in 2008. Between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. NBC’s “Today” had an average of more than 9.6 million viewers, its biggest audience since the day after the presidential election in 2000. “Good Morning America” on ABC had an average of 8.65 million viewers, its biggest audience in at least 20 years. CBS’s “Early Show” averaged 3.91 million viewers. The Nielsen ratings count only viewers at home, so it is unknown how many wedding aficionados gathered for viewing parties.

headline: R.L. Stine’s Lastest Book to Be a Feature Film
text: The latest book from R. L. Stine, the author of the “Goosebumps” children’s books, will be turned into a family-adventure feature film. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Gotham Group, a management and production company, has optioned the rights to the book, “It’s the First Day of School ... Forever,” about a 12-year-old boy whose first, horrible day of school keeps repeating itself. The book won’t be released until July, and a writer and studio have not been determined for the film. Mr. Stine’s “Goosebumps” and “Haunting Hour” series have already been adapted for television; in an interview with moviefone.com Mr. Stine said that his adult novel “The Sitter” was also being developed as a feature film under the title “The Au Pair,” to be produced by Sam Raimi’s Ghost House Pictures.

headline: Tribeca Audience Chooses Philippine Documentary
text: Moviegoers at the Tribeca Film Festival chose “Give Up Tomorrow” as the winner of the Heineken Audience Award for best feature film at a ceremony in New York on Saturday night. The film’s director, Michael Collins, an alumnus of the Tribeca Film Institute’s All Access program, which supports filmmakers from underrepresented groups, will receive $25,000 as part of the prize. “Give Up Tomorrow” is a documentary that follows the case of Paco Larranaga, who was arrested in 1997 and accused of killing two teenage sisters on the island of Cebu in the Philippines, despite overwhelming evidence of his innocence.

headline: Duerson Findings Could Shape Debate
text: The question of whether the former Chicago Bear Dave Duerson had football-related brain damage when he killed himself in February will be answered Monday morning, when Boston University researchers announce autopsy results.

headline: From Southern Africa to American Tracks
text: Philadelphia

headline: Monday: Mysterious Saucer
text: Administrivial Access Alert: The New York Times is aware that some people are having trouble accessing the PDF and still others are having trouble accessing the Across Lite version of the puzzle. While the problems are being resolved, here is a link to both versions. Sincere thanks to Jim Horne for his technical expertise, as well as for housing these links.

headline: Beneath the Greasepaint, the Roar of ‘Fam-i-ly!’
text: When Violent J, the alter ego assumed by the husky Detroit native Joseph Bruce when he performs in the rap duo Insane Clown Posse, arrived at the Skyport Marina on East 23rd Street in Manhattan, it was just after midnight on Saturday morning, and he was still wearing the greasepaint that makes him look like a demented distant relative of Emmett Kelly.

headline: From Starry-Eyed to Star

This is the single most important success the United States has had in its war against Al Qaeda.

headline: The Ghost, and Cult, of ‘Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip’
text: Back in 2006, “Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip” made its debut on NBC, and the show was intriguing for several reasons. One, it was created by arguably TV’s most revered auteur at the time, Aaron Sorkin, who was more-or-less fresh off “The West Wing,” a paragon of snappy-pattered, makes-you-feel-smart-just-for-watching television. Two, “Studio 60″ was about comedy: specifically, late-night comedy and, presumably, “Saturday Night Live.” (“Studio 60″ was the name of a fictional, live, late-night sketch-comedy show produced out of Los Angeles.) Third, in a weird coincidence, “Studio 60″ premiered the same year, on the same network, as the similarly numerically titled “30 Rock,” which is also sort-of about “Saturday Night Live” and is written by the ex-“S.N.L.” head writer Tina Fey.

headline: How Hot Will the Arab Summer Be?
text: There was a nice piece by Asef Bayat in Foreign Affairs last week on “The Post-Islamist Revolutions.” Bayat — born and raised in Iran, educated in Britain, professor at Leiden then the University of Illinois — makes the first convincing (rather than wishful) argument I’ve seen that the Arab Spring is likely to usher in relatively liberal, though religiously inflected, societies. The article makes a nice pairing with another recent Foreign Affairs piece by Michael Scott Doran, which takes Iran and Syria seriously as a kind of “anticolonialist” bloc single-mindedly focused on undermining the United States. It is perhaps a slightly paranoid or excited piece, but it is paranoid about something that the United States, as a noncolonial and indeed anticolonial power, habitually underestimates in its foreign policy, namely the enduring political power of anticolonial feeling in a post-colonial world.

headline: The Thing That Scared Us
text: The thing that scared us most about Osama bin Laden, I think, was what seemed to be his — and many of his acolytes’ — rational mega-murderousness. In American action thrillers, the bad guys sometimes used what appeared to be blind terrifying terrorism as a guise for merely felonious behavior. (The “Die Hard” franchise nearly always centered on that construction.) But here were engineers and others with advanced degrees whose obsession was an end to modernism and a return to primal law.

headline: Case Study | Building a Better Mixer
text: When you entreat a conscientious bartender to make you a gimlet these days, he frequently does something that is at once resolutely incorrect and completely forgivable: he makes you a drink containing gin, simple syrup and fresh lime juice. I’ve done it many times myself. Depending on whom you talk to, that might be a type of sour or it might be a type of fix, but it almost certainly is not a gimlet. A proper gimlet is made with lime cordial. And what most of the world knows as lime cordial is Rose’s, that dusty, fluorescent yellow-green bottle in the drinks section of your supermarket. I am willing to bet that at some point in its very long history Mr. Lauchlin Rose’s Cordial Mixer Lime Juice may have been a bracing product, redolent of the fruit that it promises. Sadly, its current incarnation is to limes as Spam is to steak. It tastes of the high-fructose corn syrup, stabilizers and various chemicals that give it its cesium-like shelf life, which is all fine for Cadbury, which has owned the brand since 1981, but is bitter gruel for someone trying to tap into the sublimity of a true gimlet. For that, as for many such rich rewards, you’ve got to make your own.

headline: A Mix of Emotion Stored for a Decade
text: Finally, the sworn enemy of this American generation had been cornered and killed by our determined special forces over there, ending a decade-long hunt for the villain who had altered our way of life. Here, it seemed, was our moment to plant a celebratory kiss on a nurse or soldier in Times Square, to chant “U.S.A., U.S.A., U.S.A.” until dawn — to see the faint outline of a better tomorrow.

headline: In Florida, Do-Tell Motels
text: American roadside motels – those metastasized ranch houses with parking spaces right outside each room entrance, are the opposite of chic. But staying at them was just about the only way I could hope to keep lodging down to my $60-a-night budget during my jaunt down the Atlantic coast of north Florida. In five nights, I stayed in four motels, three of which turned out to be comfortable and clean enough to satisfy any budget traveler. A dose of lost-in-time real America was just a bonus.

headline: Linked In | Hoorsenbuhs
text: When the 1941 Quonset hut that housed Hoorsenbuhs’s Santa Monica atelier was scheduled for demolition, the first reaction of the fine jewelry line’s founders, Robert Keith and Kether Parker, was resistance; after all, the iron structure’s rustic feel was the perfect complement to Keith’s opulent industrial designs, favored by style savvy celebs like David Beckham, Katie Holmes, Mary Kate Olsen and Rihanna. But soon the two men, who became fast friends on a Malibu beach 20 years ago and started Hoorsenbuhs in 2005, decided that an upgrade was in order. The new private showroom opened this week in a former bungalow on Santa Monica’s Main Street, with fittings from the old space, like dark wood sliding doors, industrial lamps and jewelry cases offset with heavy maritime chains. (The Hoorsenbuhs name comes from a Dutch trading ship sailed by Keith’s ancestors.). The new space is an airy, light-filled room that will soon open to an outdoor area with a fire pit.

headline: Osama’s Long Goodbye
text: Did you grow up with the notion that you should never cheer at the death of a person, even a tyrant? I did. I suppose it has to do with that very subtle business of distinguishing yourself from your enemies. So I felt some slight ambivalence when a force that was much stronger than my ambivalence took me into my daughter’s bedroom this morning to wake her and show her the local newspaper, then on the same errand into my son’s room, waiting while he rubbed the sleep out of his eyes and focused on the Page 1 headline in great, black type: BIN LADEN DEAD. I exult in the death of my enemy.

headline: Tune In for the Tony Nominations
text: Will “Catch Me If You Can” be nominated for the best musical Tony Award, after being left out of that category by the Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle award nominators last week? Which of these five Broadway plays — “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo,” “Good People,” “Jerusalem,” “The —————— with the Hat,” or “War Horse” — will not be in the running for best play when all of the Tony nominees are announced Tuesday morning? Will the two male stars of “Catch Me” and the two in “The Book of Mormon” take up four of the five nominations for best actor in a musical? And who will make the cut for the five spots in another competitive performance category this year, best actor in a play? Broadway veterans like Brian Bedford (“The Importance of Being Earnest”) and Joe Mantello (“The Normal Heart”); movies stars like James Earl Jones (“Driving Miss Daisy”), Al Pacino (“The Merchant of Venice”), and Robin Williams (“Bengal Tiger”); and widely admired actors Bobby Cannavale (“Hat”) and Mark Rylance (“Jerusalem,” “La Bête”) are all more-than-plausible as nominees. To that end, will Mr. Rylance be competing against himself at the Tonys ceremony? And which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed?

headline: Obscura Cool
text: One pleasure of the sixth floor — right now I mean the offices, not the blog — is getting to walk past the prints of some of the photos we’ve published in the magazine over the years. They’re big, and they’re full of fun or beauty or mystery or some mix of all these and other qualities. I’m no art critic — I know, shocking, right? — but one in particular has struck me as subtler than the rest, harder to “read” at a glance, easier to pass by on a daily basis without fully seeing what’s going on. That’s how it has been for me, anyway. The photo is a black-and-white camera obscura image of Times Square by Abelardo Morell. It ran in the magazine in 1997, and is reproduced above.

headline: Patterns: An Omega-3 Fatty Acid Shows a Risky Side
text: Omega-3 fatty acids have anti-inflammatory effects that may help protect against heart disease, studies have shown. But men with high blood levels of the omega-3 fat docosahexaenoic acid, or D.H.A., were at significantly greater risk for aggressive prostate cancer, a large study has found.

headline: Journey and Legacy of Obama’s Mother
text: Pieces of the story of Ann Dunham, the mother of Barack Obama, we know already. A “white woman from Kansas,” as he referred to her at the Democratic convention in 2008, who married an African intellectual and had a son with him. A strict mother who roused that son before dawn to study. An anthropologist who spent years studying in Indonesian villages, several of those years without her son. A 52-year-old woman whose last year before succumbing to cancer was spent in part trying to convince the Cigna insurance company that she should not be disqualified from benefits by virtue of a “pre-existing condition.” These are the parts of her life that resonate with our cultural anxieties about good mothering, access to health care and, of course, race.

headline: Chief Photography Curator Retiring From MoMA
text: Peter Galassi, the chief curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, will retire in July, the museum announced. Mr. Galassi, 60, who first worked for the museum as a curatorial intern in 1974, will leave to devote time to other projects, including writing, according to a statement from the museum. He joined MoMA’s photography department as a staff member in 1981 and was made chief curator 10 years later. Under his direction the museum expanded its exhibition style to include not just documentary but also post-modern works.

They planned to include all rites associated with Muslim burials, the official added.

headline: A Poetic Job That Invites Conversation
text: I TRAVEL quite a bit, which raises the question, Why does a poet have to travel? Here’s how it works. You write a poem and you make zero dollars. You write a book of poems, and you make slightly more than zero dollars. But if someone calls you to give a poetry reading, all of a sudden you actually make some money. I bet people didn’t know poetry involved such high stakes.

headline: Researchers Defend Study Finding Plankton Decline
text: A new study in Nature Climate Change, “Revaluating ocean warming impacts on global phytoplankton,” has shown that the method used to calculate phytoplankton loss in the 2010 research greatly overstated plankton losses because of a missing vital factor. Read New Scientist for the details.

headline: The Webster Sends T Packing
text: Laure Heriard Dubreuil and Frederic Dechnik, founders of the Webster Miami, have a penchant for sun, and lots of it. It’s reflected in what they buy for their store but also in their personal itineraries, which have them jet-setting from Egypt and Greece to St. Tropez and Mallorca. Come June the duo will head to Venice (for the Art Biennale) and to Mexico’s Costa Careyes for the wild beaches, Las Alamandas resort and the banana forest. With their astute knowledge of all climates — and immaculate taste — The Moment put Dubreul and Dechnik to work to send T’s editors packing. “I guess it’s very French, but August is off,” Dechnik says. “I will never compromise.” We can dream.

headline: The Clout of Air Alliances

headline: Monkeys’ Memories Can Stretch Beyond What’s in Front of Them

headline: Forget Straws: Hummingbirds Sip With Forks

headline: Screening: An Autism Questionnaire at Checkup Time
text: A questionnaire that parents can fill out in five minutes while waiting for the pediatrician can detect autism and other delays in 1-year-olds, a new study has found. But the test has a high false-positive rate that may cause unnecessary alarm.

headline: Second Thoughts About Obama and Bin Laden: It’s Not Just the Economy, Stupid
text: When I first heard the news about the American military operation that killed Osama bin Laden, I was pretty certain that the popular press was going to overstate its impact on Barack Obama’s re-election chances. I wrote an article to that effect last night.

headline: Consumer Reports Offers New Comparison Tool
text: Consumer Reports has long offered rankings and comparisons of products as diverse as cars, vacuum cleaners and televisions. Now the magazine’s online counterpart, consumerreports.org, has teamed up with the bill comparison site Billshrink.com to help shoppers evaluate the services that go along with some of those products.

text: On Monday afternoon, Michael D. Shear, the chief correspondent for The Caucus, participated in a live chat on The Times’s Facebook page, responding to comments and questions about Osama bin Laden’s death and its political ramifications. The following is a transcript of the questions Mr. Shear addressed and the answers he posted on Facebook. Thanks to everyone who participated; we hope to bring you more Facebook chats like this in the future.

headline: An Orphan’s Adventures, Ripe for the Telling

headline: Classical Music Finds Ways to Reach (Way) Out

He accompanied the female inmates as they rehearsed a musical show based on their life experiences, as part of the C.S.O.’s program to reach communities far from Symphony Center.

headline: Tugging at Threads to Unspool Stories of Torture
text: AMMAN, Jordan — The first time the Iraqi Army arrested him, he said, soldiers burst into his shop in Baghdad, dragged him out in handcuffs and a blindfold, and took him to a filthy, overcrowded prison. Beatings, rape, hunger and disease were rampant, and he expected at any moment to be killed. He was held for four months, until December 2008.

headline: Worldwide Travel Alert

headline: Who’s Over-leveraged Now?
text: When I wrote the first edition of The Return of Depression Economics, I was reacting in large part to the Asian financial crisis, which I thought could presage similarly difficult crises here in America. Sadly, I was right.

headline: Police Step Up Efforts on News of Bin Laden’s Death
text: As New Yorkers made their way through the city on Monday, they were greeted with an increased police presence in the city’s transit system, at the area’s bridges and tunnels and at other key sites like Times Square and the financial district — part of a coordinated security plan put in place as soon as Osama bin Laden’s death was reported by President Obama.

headline: Drumbeat of Nuclear Fallout Fear Doesn’t Resound With Experts

headline: Bin Laden’s Likely Heir Is Viewed as Organizer, Not as Inspiring Figure

headline: What Will the N.R.C. Learn From Fukushima?

headline: Bluebird Coffee’s Owners Move on
text: Bluebird Coffee Shop’s owners have sold the store. I first set foot in the tiny coffee shop in the East Village early last year, when I was researching an article on where you could (finally) get a cappuccino or brewed-to-order coffee in New York on par with what you find in San Francisco or Portland, Ore. The coffee at Bluebird Coffee Shop was great, and when the head barista, Katie Duris, was on her game, it could be exquisite. I named it as one of the 10 “most notable” establishments in the city. For diehard coffee nuts, it was a place of pilgrimage. For the neighborhood, it was the next-door beauty who just happened to be a star.

headline: Supplies Squeezed, Rare Earth Prices Surge

headline: Bin Laden News Gives CNN a Ratings Victory

headline: Live Blog: New York Reacts to Bin Laden’s Death

headline: Lara Logan Interview Leads Sunday Ratings
text: CBS’s interview with its correspondent Lara Logan on “60 Minutes” in which she recounted details of her sexual assault in Cairo topped the Nielsen ratings on Sunday. The program drew 10.6 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour, lifting CBS to No. 1 for the night, according to preliminary estimates, which were somewhat imprecise because of interruptions in Western time zones for President Obama’s announcement of the death of Osama bin Laden. Although CBS also appeared to lead the 8 p.m. time slot with “The Amazing Race” (9.7 million), at 9 and 10, CBS’s “Undercover Boss” (8.8 million) and “CSI: Miami” (9 million) lagged slightly behind ABC’s “Desperate Housewives” (10.1 million) and the second half of NBC’s two-hour installment of “Celebrity Apprentice” (9.1 million). ABC ranked second for the night over all, garnering 9.6 million viewers in the 8 o’clock hour for “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition.” NBC was third with “Dateline” at 7 (5.5 million) and “America’s Next Great Restaurant” at 8 (6 million). Fox finished in fourth place with mostly reruns.

headline: In Syria, Reports of Arrests Proliferate

headline: The Magazine on Osama bin Laden
text: What did we say about Osama bin Laden? The magazine exhaustively covered 9/11 and the wars that followed — the wars, especially, with in-depth reports from Iraq and Afghanistan as well as coverage of policy debates in Washington and leading trends in South Asia and what the State Department calls MENA (Middle East/North Africa). But Bin Laden only occasionally wafted into view. In the first few months after 9/11, he was omnipresent — Andrew Sullivan, for example, filed an article late that month that talked about how it was a mistake to deny that the conflict we were in was “about religion.” His main evidence was the statements of Osama bin laden, which were then forthcoming in abundance.

headline: The Morning Line: Slow, Slower, Slowest

headline: Media React: Al Jazeera on Bin Laden’s Death
text: By midday the headline on Al Jazeera’s English-language Web site read “Osama bin Laden killed by US forces” and all 10 of the most-viewed headlines on the Web site were about the killing of Bin Laden. The network live-streamed its broadcast on the Web site, including interviews with heads of state from around the world and a live press conference from the White House.

headline: An Antarctic Buffet Where Whales Gather to Feast
text: Scientists doing observations in the Wilhelmina Bay in the western Antarctic have found an estimated two million tons of krill, and more than 300 humpback whales feeding on them. It is the densest population of these whales ever recorded, more than 15 per square mile.

headline: Media React: Le Monde Notes History’s Timing
text: PARIS — “Chance sometimes does things well,”  Le Monde, widely viewed as France’s newspaper of record, wrote in an editorial. “The man who embodied international jihadism dies at the moment when the ‘Arab spring’ has just given a blow to this totalitarian fantasy. As soon as Arab peoples revolted in the name of democracy and not Islamism or the return to the caliphate preached by Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden was politically moribund.”

headline: Job Description Grows for Our Utility Hormone

headline: Violinists Wander Into Bartok, and Well Off the Beaten Path

headline: Building on the Mastery of What Came Before
text: BOSTON — The stage, washed in white light, looks enormous when the curtain goes up on William Forsythe’s “Second Detail,” the opening piece on the Boston Ballet triple bill at the opera house here. Twelve dancers, dressed in the palest gray leotards and tights — some facing the audience, some with their backs to us — are arrayed in lines and diagonals, their bodies etched against the space with cut-glass clarity. Thom Willem’s electronic score offers a hesitant, knocking rhythm, and then a 13th dancer, a woman, walks on quietly and takes her place in a line.

Its terrorist prowess was never more evident than on that horrible day of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Ideas and Theory: The Political Difference
text: The last of the 200 comments to my previous column declaring the political impotence of the everything-is-socially-constructed thesis accuses me of assuming that “ideas have no consequences.” Nothing could be further from the truth. “Women have long been marginalized and suppressed by a dominant male culture” is an idea. “Gays have been denied the rights that are theirs as citizens” is an idea. Each of these ideas has been enormously consequential; and each has been the basis of concerted action that altered our political and cultural landscape.

headline: Vatican: Bishop Who Broached New Rules for Priests Is Ousted
text: The Vatican ousted an Australian bishop on Monday who had called on the church to consider ordaining women and married men. In a statement, the Vatican said that it had “removed from pastoral care” Bishop William Morris, left, the bishop of Toowoomba, Australia. The statement was particularly strong; normally the Vatican urges bishops to resign and then announces that it has accepted their resignation. Australian media reported that Bishop Morris had recently published an open letter saying that he was being removed for having argued in 2006 that the church should consider ordaining women and married men in order to fight a shortage of priests, prompting Pope Benedict XVI to open an investigation into his diocese. In the letter, Bishop Morris said he that he refused to resign, but would take early retirement because the pope had decided “that the diocese would be better served by the leadership of a new bishop.”

headline: The End of the Jihadist Dream
text: TO the Qaeda members I interrogated at Guantánamo Bay and elsewhere in the aftermath of 9/11, Osama bin Laden was never just the founder and leader of the group, but also an idea. He embodied the belief that their version of Islam was correct, that terrorism was the right weapon, and that they would ultimately be victorious. Bin Laden’s death did not kill that idea, but did deal it a mortal blow.

headline: The Long-Awaited News
text: The news that Osama bin Laden had been tracked and killed by American forces filled us, and all Americans, with a great sense of relief. But our reaction was strongly tinged with sadness. Nearly a decade after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the horror has not faded, nor has the knowledge of how profoundly our lives were changed.

headline: Shots Heard ‘Round the World
text: Three hearses, flag-draped and drawn by horses, rolled through the colonial streets of Boston on May 1. The men of the Sixth Massachusetts — the “noble sons who have given their life’s blood in defense of the laws and maintenance of their country’s honor,” in the words of the next morning’s newspaper — had come home. The cortège, accompanied by Gov. John A. Andrew and by militia cadets marching with their muskets reversed, drew up at last before the staid 18th-century portico of King’s Chapel on Tremont Street. Slowly, the chapel’s great bell, cast long ago in bronze by Paul Revere himself, tolled a dirge.

But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope.

headline: Nevada: House Race Is Thrown Open to All
text: A special election to replace Representative Dean Heller, a Republican about to be appointed to the United States Senate, should be open to all candidates, not just those selected by the two major political parties, Nevada’s secretary of state ruled on Monday. The decision improves the prospects of Sharron Angle, the Tea Party-backed Republican who ran for Senate last year and whom state Republicans had signaled that they did not want to run for this seat. The secretary of state, Ross J. Miller, a Democrat, ruled against an interpretation of the law that would limit the ballot to just candidates chosen by the major parties. “Pleased to announce an open-ballot-access election,” Mr. Miller posted on his Twitter account. “Freedom for all to run; let the people decide rather than politically elite power brokers.” Mr. Heller’s Second Congressional District is, normally, solidly Republican; the decision appears to put the Sept. 13 election in flux. Mr. Heller would replace John Ensign, a Republican, whose resignation is effective today.

headline: Media React: Haaretz Weighs In
text: The Web site for the Israeli publication Haaretz led its coverage with a map of the compound where Osama bin Laden was found, with the headline: “U.S. Had No Choice but to Kill Bin Laden, Says U.S. Defense Official.” Other content on the home page included a slide show of Americans celebrating the killing and an article featuring the results of a survey conducted by the Pew Research Center Global Attitudes Project. According to the article, the data found that support for Bin Laden had declined among Muslims worldwide. While the publication’s lead editorial focused on the commemoration of Holocaust Martyrs and Heroes Day, an editorial titled “The Road to Bin Laden Ran Through Guantánamo Bay,” by Yossi Melman, extolled the merits of the United States’ war on terror, including the cost to American taxpayers. “It turned out that it was worth every cent.”

headline: Slogging on the Home Front

headline: A Real, Unnecessary Crisis for Families
text: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, made a strong argument for good early childhood care. In a speech in New York City, he argued that the value can be especially high for disadvantaged children with a strong payoff for the economy. These programs can increase high school graduation rates, and graduates earn more, pay more taxes, and rely less on state-provided health care.

headline: An Art-Themed Block Party in Paris
text: Every spring art galleries in the Saint-Germain-des-Pres neighborhood, long famed as home to artists, writers and musicians, open their doors to the public, in a block party called Art Saint-Germain-des-Pres. With what might be the highest concentration of galleries in the world, it’s an ideal area to find a variety of art, from primitive to contemporary and sculpture and painting to photography, jewelry and antiques. This year’s event, from May 19 to 22, will include at least 60 galleries. As an example of the event’s breadth, La Galerie Artco-France will show works by the Surrealist René Magritte and La Galerie Frédéric Got Fine Art photographs by Elliott Erwitt.

headline: On the Ground with a ‘Gap Year’
text: I’ve periodically recommended that high school students take a “gap year” after graduation, by deferring college entrance for one year. Most colleges encourage students to take a gap year, partly because students then arrive a little more mature, a little more ready to study, a little more worldly. It’s becoming a bit more common, and Princeton now pays for some kids to travel during their gap year, but most people are still wary of the idea. In fact, almost every kid I’ve talked to who has taken a gap year raves about the idea, so I thought I’d commission a guest column from my eldest son, Gregory, who is currently taking a gap year in China. He spent most of the year studying Chinese at Tsinghua University and then at a language school in Dalian, and soon he’s going to finish up the year studying Spanish in Peru. On the side, he worked and volunteered. Here’s his take:

headline: Now Renting | Traveling Coffee Bar
text: The quest for the perfect cup of organic fair-trade Sumatran coffee can take you far afield (or at least off the island of Manhattan). But why travel when Melissa Knott of Grounded Coffee Catering will bring her coffee bar to you? Knott will journey anywhere in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania where there’s a dedicated electrical outlet and “four clear feet of space” for her folding table and portable Pasquini espresso machine. Along with filter coffee and espresso drinks — including a fantastic decaf — Knott offers loose-leaf black and herbal teas, hot chocolate (made with dairy, soy or coconut milk) and Italian sodas, all organic and fair-trade. She works with a local roaster to create custom blends and has them specially roasted for each event she caters. Since founding her business three and a half years ago, Knott has pulled shots and poured cups everywhere from suburban pool parties to the set of a slasher film on Governors Island. Her dedication to coffee — she wrote her thesis on it — is such that she even checks the water quality of an area before heading out. “I actually prefer to bring my own,” she says. “If the water’s too hard or too soft it really affects the taste of the coffee.” For more on Grounded Coffee Catering, including information on the farmers’ markets where Knott sells her custom roasted beans, go to groundedcatering.com.

headline: Rights Group Urges Prosecutions in Thai Violence

headline: More Reasons to Say “Eeh” When You Learn About the ECB

headline: The Tony Nominations: Who Got Snubbed This Year?
text: Somewhere, Lord Voldemort is surely smiling while “Harry Potter” fans are heartbroken: Daniel Radcliffe leveraged his years as the star of that boy-wizard franchise to play J. Pierrepont Finch in the current Broadway revival of “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” and spent months in vocal and dance training to get up to speed for the role. Yet he couldn’t conjure up enough magic to secure a Tony nomination on Tuesday for a performance that excited many theatergoers and critics, making him one of the most glaring snubs of the morning. Did Tony nominators agree with Ben Brantley, who wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Radcliffe “is clearly not to the musical manner born.” Or was Mr. Radcliffe simply the victim of an evil spell cast by Severus Snape? We may never know.

text: As I explain in today’s Well column, “Adding Food and Subtracting Calories, “ researchers at Penn State University found that adding vegetable purée to various recipes didn’t change the flavor much but did lead to big reductions in the amount of calories consumed. The result was that diners felt full after eating fewer calories, allowing the vegetable purée mixtures to act as natural appetite suppressants.

headline: Was Big D Wise to Pursue Small Customers?
text: Last week, we published a case study that explored whether Big D Custom Screen Printing could become profitable by specializing in small T-shirt orders. After a year in business, the company had sales of $325,000 on which it suffered a nominal loss. Big D’s co-founder, Darren Robbins, and his partner disagreed as to the best way to turn things around. His partner wanted to focus on large corporate accounts. Mr. Robbins believed Big D could thrive by targeting customers with small orders — as small as one T-shirt. The partners split (amicably) over the issue.

headline: This Time, The Tonys Grow Up and Get It Right
text: What’s this? A full slate of real, original plays – and I mean plays, like mom and dad used to dress up for and would talk about over martinis afterward. Though the Tony nominations announced Tuesday morning didn’t offer many surprises (the hearty, 12-nomination celebration of “Scottsboro Boys” was the only mild shocker), it did confirm some good news. Legitimate dramas are still being written, and they’re being written well.

headline: Harold Garfinkel, a Common-Sense Sociologist, Dies at 93
text: Harold Garfinkel, an innovative sociologist who turned the study of common sense into a dense and arcane discipline, creating one of his field’s most challenging and fruitful branches of inquiry, died April 21 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 93.

headline: The Making of a Cover
text: Our cover story on Sunday was about the American soldiers accused of murdering Afghan civilians. Some reports have depicted them as a rogue unit, but our story goes deeper into the psyche of the American soldier and questions whether the killings are symptoms of a much larger issue. Being a weekly, time was a factor, so we executed some staff-produced, alternate versions of the magazine’s cover, two days before it had to ship. We started with a graphic approach, experimenting with every font in our arsenal. We did more than can be featured in this blog post, but the following is a curated depiction of our process for developing a cover.

headline: You Say Man Cave, I Say Good Taste
text: If Bravo is the network devoted to baroque expressions of coastal affluence, TLC exists as its spirit cousin and opposition: a cable channel committed to the ostensibly bizarre habits of non-elites. Producers take us from Pennsylvania to Arkansas to Utah and to other places that are neither West Hollywood nor East Hampton to uncover overbreeders (“19 Kids and Counting,” “Kate Plus 8”), polygamists (“Sister Wives”), addicts of household flotsam (“Hoarding: Buried Alive”) and the strange people who submit their young children to spray tans (“Toddlers & Tiaras”). Bravo ridicules the world of the well to do; TLC, instead, implicitly makes fun of the idea that those hoping to avoid encounters with creepiness or bad taste are safe beyond the realm of four-ply cashmere.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ’12:08 East of Bucharest’
text: This week, A. O. Scott looks at a film from Corneliu Porumboiu, one of the directors who has emerged out of the new wave of Romanian cinema. His film, “12:08 East of Bucharest,” looks back at the Romanian revolution of 1989 and asks what the revolution meant to the country and how such a dynamic moment could quickly fade into history. In the film, three characters gather in a drab television studio to commemorate the revolution and to also question whether or not it really happened. Mr. Scott says that one of the elements that makes the film stand out is its “sly, deadpan, understated wit.” Have you seen “12:08 East of Bucharest” or other films from the Romanian new wave? Please share your thoughts.

headline: ‘The Big Thirst': The Future of Water
text: Charles Fishman, a longtime writer for Fast Company magazine, is the author of “The Big Thirst,” a new book on water. He previously wrote “The Wal-Mart Effect,” which was an Economist “book of the year” in 2006 and a finalist in The Financial Times’s awards for best business book. Our conversation follows.

headline: U.N. Forecasts 10.1 Billion People by Century’s End
text: The population of the world, long expected to stabilize just above 9 billion in the middle of the century, will instead keep growing and may hit 10.1 billion by the year 2100, the United Nations projected in a report released Tuesday.

headline: Peter Bergen to Write Book on Bin Laden Manhunt
text: Less than 48 hours after Osama bin Laden’s death, the book deals have begun. Peter Bergen will write the “definitive” book on the hunt for Bin Laden, his publisher said on Tuesday. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said it had acquired a new book by Mr. Bergen that it described as “an immersive, definitive account of the operation that killed the world’s most wanted man.”

headline: Let Them Eat Choux
text: Popelini, the pastry shop Lauren Koumetz opened this month in Paris’s Marais neighborhood, is devoted exclusively to choux à la crème, or cream puffs, the bite-size flavor shots that offer a sugar lover an alternative to France’s superstar macaron. On any given day, the choux are lined up in a half dozen flavors including dark chocolate, lemon praline, salted butter caramel, Madagascar vanilla and rose; some have an additional confit filling of passion fruit or raspberry. And then there’s the choux du jour, dreamed up by the pastry chef Alice Barday, which might be strawberry-litchi, Earl Grey tea, pear, or tiramisu, inspired by the Italian dessert with whipped cream, almonds and crunchy chocolate sprinkles.

headline: Troubled Employers and Your Company Charge Card

headline: Russian Is Charged in Absentia With Betraying Spies in U.S.
text: MOSCOW — After a group of Russian sleeper agents were arrested in the United States last summer, an angry Vladimir V. Putin, Russia’s prime minister, promised to punish the person who betrayed them.

headline: Canadian Leader Celebrates Victory Over Opposition
text: OTTAWA — It was a different Prime Minister Stephen Harper who appeared on Tuesday for his first news conference after his Conservative Party’s resounding victory in Canada’s federal election.

headline: May Day
text: Now that Osama bin Laden is dead, I imagine many historians will be taking out their chisels and stones in an attempt to capture the moment within the historical record. Most military histories hyphenate years of conflict and inscribe them on a tombstone formed by parentheses. When we walk through history’s graveyard, for example, we find: World War I (1914-1918) and World War II (1939-1945) among the many rows of markers annotating warfare.

headline: The Up Side of Population (Projections)
text: Rumors of an impending human population crash are not borne out by the latest United Nations projections, offering further proof that human beings are the least certain factor in efforts to project the course of events on this planet in this century.

headline: Mood Spending
text: Term used to describe emotional (and ill-considered) purchasing – illustrated by ticket applications for the 2012 London Olympics.

headline: Colonie
text: THE lack of good restaurants in Brooklyn Heights has been a topic of discussion along the neighborhood’s leafy sidewalks at least since the first white-shoe lawyers crossed the Brooklyn Bridge to settle there.

headline: Reviewing Colonie
Teenager Questioned in Death of Baby
text: Updated, 9:35 p.m. | The police are questioning a 17-year-old in connection with the death of a baby who died on Tuesday while in his care, a law enforcement official said.

headline: Inequality Rising Across the Developed World
text: America isn’t the only rich country dealing with a rise in inequality. Most of the developed world is, too.

headline: Icahn Gets Backing From I.S.S. on Mentor Graphics
text: Carl C. Icahn’s slate of candidates for the board of Mentor Graphics has received support from the influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services.

headline: Obama to Observe 9/11 Anniversary in New York
text: President Obama will travel to New York City this September to observe the 10-year anniversary of 9/11 and the opening of a memorial at ground zero, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday.

headline: Checking In | W Hotel, London
text: Centuries ago, Leicester Square was a genteel patch, but now it is brash and loud, bordered by an all-night Chinatown and ringed by West End theaters, carousels and street stalls. On weekend evenings, gaggles of young women soused on Magners or caffeinated tonic wine don dangerously short skirts (even in frigid temperatures) and stumble around the hucksters, buskers and neophyte tourists who’ve been sucked in, mothlike, by all that neon. There are good movie theaters here, great soup dumplings, and the square is convenient to just about everything in London. But it is not a traditionally desirable neighborhood for a hotel.

headline: Congress Dedicates Statue of President Ford in Rotunda
text: Presidents Andrew Jackson and Ronald Reagan have new company: On Tuesday, a bronze statue of President Gerald R. Ford was dedicated in the Rotunda of the United States Capitol by Congressional leaders.

headline: Six Tips on Taking Outside Investors
text: Having a great idea for a company is one thing. Getting the money to get it moving and growing is quite another — especially when you’ve got an unconventional product or business model that your average investor isn’t likely to recognize as an obvious winner.

headline: By the Numbers, an Uninspiring Derby Field
text: How fast are this year’s Kentucky Derby horses? Judging by the comments of Andrew Beyer, who developed Beyer Speed Figures, and Len Friedman of The Sheets, the field is anything but fast. John Scheinman at Kentucky Confidential talked to Beyer and Friedman:

headline: Rick Riordan’s Favorite Childhood Books
text: Today marks the publication date of “The Throne of Fire,” the second in Rick Riordan’s latest mega-series, “The Kane Chronicles,” for which Disney has announced an initial print run of 1.5 million copies. Mr. Riordan is probably best known for his #1 best-selling “Percy Jackson and the Olympians,” also for middle grade readers, though he writes novels for adults as well.

headline: Hermès Is Selling Its Stake in Gaultier’s Fashion House
text: Jean Paul Gaultier, the French designer whose fashion house has been in partnership with Hermès since 1999, said Tuesday that the Puig Beauty and Fashion Group, a Spanish company whose primary focus is perfumes, was acquiring a controlling 60 percent share of the company.

headline: How Should We Think of the Civil War?
text: Via Brad DeLong, Ta-Nehisi Coates argues that the Civil War wasn’t tragic in the way it’s so often portrayed. The human losses were terrible — but the war marked the end of the far greater horror of slavery.

headline: Obama to Give ’60 Minutes’ Details on Bin Laden
text: President Obama will give his first extensive comments on the raid that killed Osama bin Laden in an interview with CBS News’s Steve Kroft that airs Sunday night on “60 Minutes.”

headline: Scene City: Inside the Met Gala
text: A glamorous and celebrity-studded crowd celebrated Alexander McQueen at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s annual Costume Institute gala.

headline: Forstmann Is Said to Be Undergoing Treatment for Brain Cancer
text: Theodore J. Forstmann, one of Wall Street’s original leveraged buyout barons, has received a diagnosis of a malignant brain tumor, according to a person close to him.

headline: Teach for America Equalizes Health Costs for Domestic Partners
text: Teach for America is the latest organization to ensure that its employees with same-sex partners get the same treatment as opposite-sex married couples when it comes to health care costs.

headline: White House Corrects Bin Laden Narrative
text: White House officials on Tuesday sought to correct the official account of the raid in Pakistan that ended in the killing of Osama bin Laden, saying that the Qaeda leader was not armed and that his wife was not killed. But they added that Bin Laden resisted when confronted during the raid.

headline: Europe Leads in Pushing for Privacy of User Data
text: BRUSSELS — As pressure grows for technology companies like Apple and Google to adjust how their phones and devices gather data, Europe seems to be where the new rules are being determined.

headline: How Credit Card Data Is Stolen and Sold
text: Last week, after the Sony PlayStation Network was attacked by a group of unknown hackers, Sony’s 77 million customers, along with security specialists and government officials, were surprised by the amount of information that might have been stolen from the company.

headline: More Todd Haynes on My Morning Jacket Concert Film
text: Todd Haynes talked to Nate Chinen about making a film of My Morning Jacket concert. The first half of their conversation can be found here. The second half follows.

headline: Manny in High School: A Slide Show That Tells a Slugger’s Story
Double Take: There Are Recipes, Too
text: After reading Frank Bruni’s article on Torrisi Italian Specialties and the future of Italian-American food, I was curious — and hungry. Even more so after the two chefs agreed to let us post several of their recipes online. As a general rule, I’m not into polyglot food. Curry on pasta? Even pineapple on “Hawaiian” pizza? Not for me. As Bruni points out, fusion has become a bit of a naughty word. But I was intrigued by the chefs’ Lower East Side mash-ups. So last night I resolved to cook their prosciutto fried rice for an unsuspecting friend.

headline: In Bulgaria, a Tradition Meets New Realities
text: Every year, members of the Kalaidzhi, a group of seminomadic Roma, gather in a field outside the town of Stara Zagora to conduct the complex negotiations on a bride price that traditionally lead to marriage. However, support for marriage traditions is waning.

headline: Kronos Quartet Honored with Two Awards
text: As the San Francisco-based Kronos Quartet prepared for a European tour, beginning on Thursday in Athens, its bags became a little heavier on Tuesday with two major awards. Kronos will receive the Avery Fisher Prize, awarded in New York to individuals or chamber ensembles for outstanding achievement and excellence in music, as well as the Polar Music Prize, awarded in Stockholm (not on the quartet’s current itinerary), also intended to recognize exceptional achievement in music.

headline: Behind High Walls, Model Neighbors Were Harboring a Fugitive
text: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan — In his last days, Osama bin Laden was not surrounded by a circle of heavily armed Arab bodyguards or mujahedeen who had fought with him in Afghanistan against the Soviet Union. Rather, he relied on two Pakistanis, one of whom, according to American officials, was his most trusted courier. Both men died with him in the American raid on their compound.

headline: NYSE Euronext Chief Isn’t Fazed by Hostile Nasdaq Bid
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — While the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange finally said on Monday they intended to go directly to NYSE Euronext shareholders to win over the exchange operator, the Big Board’s chief executive said he wasn’t worried.

headline: To Meet Demand for Chips, Samsung Bets Big on Austin
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — Samsung Electronics, one of the world’s biggest chip makers, is betting $3.6 billion that people will keep buying smartphones and tablet computers.

headline: Cables Show U.S. Concern on Japan’s Disaster Readiness
text: TOKYO — In March 2008, the American ambassador in Tokyo sent a classified cable to Washington that contained a prophetic warning about the disaster preparedness of Japan, the United States’ most important ally in Asia.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Libya, Missouri, and New Zealand.

headline: Low-Salt Diet Ineffective, Study Finds. Disagreement Abounds.
text: A new study found that low-salt diets increase the risk of death from heart attacks and strokes and do not prevent high blood pressure, but the research’s limitations mean the debate over the effects of salt in the diet is far from over.

headline: A Perfect Baby
text: When my older son was born, I quietly pitied other mothers of newborns. Mine was just so gorgeous, while theirs were, let’s face it, somewhat misshapen and blobby.

headline: Pakistan Pushes Back Against U.S. Criticism on Bin Laden
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Toughening its stand, the Pakistani government lashed out at the United States on Tuesday for the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, saying that the United States had made “an unauthorized unilateral action” that would be not be tolerated in the future.

headline: Malcolm McKellar, Pioneer of the Pontiac Overhead-Cam Engine
text: Malcolm McKellar died on April 9, just a little more than a year after Pontiac — the brand he helped elevate to high-performance prominence — met its end. He was believed to be 90.

headline: TimesCast | May 3, 2011
text: May 3, 2011 - New details on Bin Laden's life and surroundings, the uneasy relationship between the U.S. and Pakistani intelligence agencies, and Pakistan's culture of conspiracy theories.

headline: Former Aide to Rangel Pleads Guilty in Tax Case
text: James Capel, who had been a top adviser to Representative Charles B. Rangel for more than a decade, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to failing to file tax returns, months after Mr. Rangel was censured on the House floor over his own tax problems.
