text: Photographs from Pakistan, Libya, Missouri, and New Zealand.

headline: The Hut Next Door
text: When I found out that Osama bin Laden was dead, I couldn’t help but reminisce about the times my platoon had killed him, over and over again, in my mind.

headline: Florida Puts Overhaul of Courts to the Voters
text: MIAMI — The Florida Senate has decided to put major changes in the state court system before voters next year but only after rejecting the most contentious proposal, which would have split the Supreme Court in two.

headline: In Tornado Zones, Seeking Shelter From the Storm
text: As communities across the storm-raked stretch of the South cope with the aftermath of the country’s second deadliest tornado outbreak, it’s worth reviewing the prime sources of vulnerability behind the terrible death counts: the substantial growth in southern populations in recent decades, a dearth of basements and the enduring popularity of mobile homes.

headline: Virginia Woolf’s Words, a Singer’s Voice
text: “At intervals some emotion broke in.” This astringent line, about Thomas Hardy’s funeral, is from the diary of Virginia Woolf, and also from Dominick Argento’s classic 1974 song cycle, “From the Diary of Virginia Woolf.”

headline: A Work Force for the World
text: China is increasingly known for shipping out cheap labor, and a backlash against it has grown across Africa and Asia, especially Vietnam.

headline: Board Disciplines 3 Doctors
text: The Board of Medical Examiners in New Jersey, which is responsible for licensing doctors practicing in the state, said on Tuesday that it had disciplined three orthopedic surgeons because they did not disclose their personal financial interests in the success of an artificial spinal disk they were studying in clinical trials that were used by federal regulators to approve the disk.

headline: USA Network’s Twist on ‘Upfront’ Puts Stars Up Front
text: 10:50 a.m. | Updated The executives at the USA Network cable channel decided to have some fun with the first large-scale presentation to advertisers, agencies and reporters of their coming season by sending out the stars of USA series to speak in their place.

headline: Scandal-Scarred Formula One Men Return
text: After disappointing performances by the Williams Formula One car in the first three races, the team announced on Tuesday that its technical director, Sam Michael, and its chief aerodynamicist, Jon Tomlinson, had resigned, effective at the end of the season. The team also announced that Mike Coughlan, the race car designer behind a spying scandal four years ago, would join the team in June as chief engineer.

headline: Scandal-Scarred Formula One Men Return
text: After disappointing performances by the Williams Formula One car in the first three races, the team announced on Tuesday that its technical director, Sam Michael, and its chief aerodynamicist, Jon Tomlinson, had resigned, effective at the end of the season. The team also announced that Mike Coughlan, the race car designer behind a spying scandal four years ago, would join the team in June as chief engineer.

headline: Off the Beaten Path, History in Philadelphia
text: The No. 23 city bus running along the cobblestones is still known as the “trolley,”and you can take it to visit the house where a young Benjamin Franklin stopped for advice on books or to other homes where Revolutionary War battles left powder marks and bloodstains. George Washington slept here, a lot, and decades later so did runaway slaves at a well-preserved stop on the Underground Railroad. There’s also a homey lunch spot known for its veggie burger.

headline: How to Yoke Oxen
text: A demonstration by the farmer Tim Huppe of how to yoke a pair of oxen for work in the field, from the 2003 how-to DVD "Training Oxen," a cult classic in the draft-power community.

headline: Planetary iPad App Offers Visual Music Search
text: Video of Planetary from Bloom Studio.

headline: Among Friends
text: Gays — and the heterosexuals who love them, including Chelsea Clinton — will gather tonight in New York for a fund-raiser for Friendfactor, a nonprofit organization that counts on the power of friendship to help gays and lesbians achieve equal rights.

headline: Moving Students, Honoring Teachers
text: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama surprised students at the Alice Deal Middle School in northwest Washington on Tuesday afternoon when she showed up to work out with them.

headline: Tour d’Art | Berlin Gallery Week
text: Where is Ai Weiwei? It’s a good question, and one posed by the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija on a banner created to accompany Ai’s exhibition at Berlin’s Neugerriemschneider gallery, the opening of which Ai was regrettably unable to attend this past weekend because of a previous engagement with Chinese authorities. Despite his absence, his show was a big crowd pleaser during Berlin’s Gallery Weekend. The 44 participating galleries and numerous off-calendar spaces presented a thoughtful program that celebrated Berlin’s low-key ethos, and where the work, rather than celebrity-stocked private dinners and A-list parties, was the main attraction.

headline: No Shades Needed in Not-So-Bright Future
text: It’s the end of the world as we know it, or mighty close to it, in Laurel Haines’s agreeably disjointed “Future Anxiety,” which opened on Thursday night at the Flea Theater. And while its many, many inhabitants may not exactly feel fine, they’re largely at peace with a world in which China imports American debtors as slave laborers, and the unemployment rate has dropped to a mere 65 percent.

headline: Quiet Proxy Season Means Fewer Fights in the Boardroom
text: Proxy season is a bust.

headline: A Good Night for ABC
text: ABC earned a solid victory in the ratings on Monday night as 20.9 million viewers tuned in to the network’s reality competition “Dancing With the Stars,” according to Nielsen’s estimates. The two-hour installment dominated the ratings and boosted ABC’s “Castle” (12.2 million) in the 10 p.m. hour ahead of CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (9.4 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: Los Angeles” (4.8 million). CBS placed second with sitcoms from 8 to 10 including “How I Met Your Mother” (6.7 million), “Mad Love” (5.8 million), “Mike & Molly” (8.1 million), as well as a repeat of “Two and a Half Men” at 9 (7.6 million). Fox was third with “House” (8.5 million) and “The Chicago Code” (5.5 million), while NBC placed fourth with “Chuck” at 8 (4.1 million) and “The Event” at 9 (4 million).

headline: The Subway Gets a Dining Car
text: For one half-hour luncheon, a car on the L train was transformed into a traveling bistro, complete with tables, linens, silverware and a bow-tied maître d’hôtel.

headline: Analyzing a Sea Change in Canada
text: Even for observers who were the most optimistic about the New Democratic Party’s chances, the results of Monday’s general election in Canada were nothing short of astounding.

headline: India Sees New Reason to Distrust Pakistan
text: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s often lonely efforts to improve relations with Pakistan are certain to become more complicated, and more difficult, after the disclosure that Osama bin Laden had been hiding in a military town in the heart of Pakistan.

headline: Wall Street Journal Still First in Daily Circulation
text: Despite a new way to measure newspaper circulation, the top four daily papers are unchanged from six months ago, according to a report released Tuesday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

headline: A Boon to Birds: Public Preserves
text: Publicly owned land, ocean and marshes provide habitats for at least half of the American populations of 300 bird species, the Department of Interior reports.

headline: Huntsman Opens Committee to Raise Money
text: Three days after resigning as President Obama’s ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. took the first steps on Tuesday toward joining the Republican presidential race by opening a political action committee allowing him to raise and spend money as he considers a candidacy.

headline: Barring a Miracle, There Will Be No Baby Hawks
text: Violet the red-tailed hawk has been sitting on those eggs for a very long while. But sometimes, eggs don’t hatch. This appears to be one of those times. Read more »

headline: H Plus X Plus Z, Formula for 3 Intersecting Lives
text: The independent Argentine film “Extraordinary Stories” interweaves the obscurely circuitous story lines of three cryptically named and decidedly unextraordinary characters: H (Agustín Mendilaharzu, the film’s cinematographer), a visibly bored civil engineer; X (Mariano Llinás, the director), a frustrated architect slumming as a land surveyor; and Z (Walter Jakob), a midlevel bureaucrat in a provincial agricultural agency.

headline: Funny or Die: Webby Awards Choose Funny
text: When Justin Bieber lost out on the Grammy Award for best new artist this year, all his fans could do was complain (and hack the Wikipedia page of the winner, Esperanza Spalding).

headline: Portugal Agrees to a $116 Billion Bailout
text: Portugal agreed on Tuesday to accept an international aid plan of 78 billion euros ($116 billion) that the country’s caretaker prime minister, José Sócrates, suggested would involve more lenient conditions than those imposed on Greece and Ireland in return for similar bailouts.

headline: Aboard the L Train, Luncheon Is Served
text: IN the era of pop-up restaurants and speakeasies, flash mobs and social stunts, it was perhaps inevitable that a formal luncheon for a dozen people would be staged aboard the Brooklyn-bound L train. Inevitable, but still impressive.

headline: James and Wade, Inseparable Even in the Interview Room
text: MIAMI — Dwyane Wade and LeBron James are close. Very close. Biceps to biceps close. So close that you could barely slide a deflated basketball between them. Or a tape recorder.

headline: No Feather Left Unpreened
text: IN the category of Things People Were Talking About during Monday night’s Costume Institute gala: Weren’t you just thrilled for Sarah Burton, the creative director of Alexander McQueen, for the timing of her royal wedding coup, three days before the big ball? Did you see Kate Hudson’s baby bump? How about Christina Ricci’s tightly corseted waist? And, most pressingly, what was with the egg on Anna Dello Russo’s head?

headline: After Bin Laden, Reliving the Iraq ‘Mistake’
text: Since hearing that U.S. forces killed Osama bin Laden, I have been thinking a great deal about what this means to me not only as an American, but also as a medically retired soldier. As someone who has led soldiers in combat in Iraq, I have held these wars close to me for some time.

headline: ‘Book of Mormon’ Tops Tony Nomination List
text: The Tony Award nominations on Tuesday snubbed a stretch limo’s worth of Hollywood stars who converged on Broadway during the 2010-11 season, bypassing actors who received critical praise (Robin Williams in “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo”) and others who put their fame on the line by playing against type (a scheming Daniel Radcliffe, a mellow Chris Rock and a droopy Kiefer Sutherland, for starters).

headline: A Whiff of Camembert, From Upstate
text: Kinderhook Creek is the first Camembert-style soft-ripening cheese that the Old Chatham Sheepherding Company in the Hudson Valley has made entirely with sheep’s milk, not a blend of sheep’s and cow’s milk. Named for a stream on the property, it’s aged up to three weeks, and has a bloomy rind, a creamy ivory center and a border of satiny ripeness. The bouquet is fresh and lightly mushroomy, and it has a gently tangy herbal flavor, which will deepen even in the refrigerator, after another week. Wrap it in cheese paper; don’t suffocate it in plastic.

headline: New Tastes From Daniel Boulud, for Shoppers and Diners
text: At Daniel Boulud’s first takeout shop, Épicerie Boulud, the array of finely crafted terrines and pâtés, cheeses and pastries may be unrivaled in the city. Like the charcuterie served next door at Bar Boulud, they are made under the direction of Gilles Verot of Paris. Some, like the breaded boned pork shank, or jambonneau (above), are not available at Bar Boulud. Many of the cheeses are aged by Saxelby Cheesemongers. Sandwiches, salads, breads and ice cream are also sold. A coffee and pastry bar will convert to an oyster and wine bar in the evenings.

headline: Christina Tosi, a Border-Crossing Pastry Chef
text: PARENTS of picky eaters, take heart!

headline: A New Cookbook Devoted to Herbs
text: No cookbook is easier to organize than one about herbs. Arrange it alphabetically, add some recipes that can be grouped in an index listing, and you are home free. That’s what Jekka McVicar, an English herb grower and expert, has done in this alluring volume, for Mother’s Day perhaps. The book evokes spring from cover to cover, with illustrations by Ms. McVicar’s daughter, Hannah, that suggest William Morris patterns.

headline: Overnight Polls Find Muted Improvement in Obama’s Approval Rating
text: In the parlor game to predict the magnitude of improvement in President Obama’s approval rating after the killing of Osama bin Laden, the weight of the evidence is with the skeptics so far.

headline: A New First Stop for Homeless Families
text: The city’s Department of Homeless Services on Tuesday opened a new intake center in the South Bronx, a $65.5 million building designed to greet families seeking shelter with much more of a smile than in the old days.

headline: Inside The Libyan Rebels’ Hidden Weapons Shops
text: With much of the port city of Misurata reclaimed, part of the rebels’ success has roots in the network of hidden metal workshops, where the uprising’s killing tools have been assembled and pushed out.

headline: Teamwork
text: So, driven to a rustic frenzy by the Northeast’s oxen craze, you’ve just bought a pair of brawny bovines and are ready to put them to work in your garden. But you have no idea how to do that. For $29.95 you can buy the DVD “Training Oxen,” made in 2003 by Drew Conroy, a professor at the University of New Hampshire who is known in draft-power circles as “the ox guru.” Or, to get started, you can take a look at this clip from the DVD with Tim Huppe of BerryBrook Ox Supply, in Farmington, N.H.

headline: A Mysterious Marsupial That Ambushed Its Prey
text: It was known as the Tasmanian tiger, for its striped coat, or the Tasmanian wolf, for its doglike appearance. But new research indicates the bone structure and hunting habits of Thylacinus cynocephalus may make the “tiger” designation more apt.

headline: Italy’s Birthday Specials
text: Italy is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Risorgimento, the unification of the former patchwork of states up and down the peninsula.

headline: U.S. and Romania Move on Missile Plan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Romania announced an agreement on Tuesday on the location for basing American antimissile interceptors in Romania as part of a program designed to link Washington and its NATO allies against an Iranian threat. The agreement immediately drew complaints from Russian officials.

headline: Barcelona Proves to Be Master of Real Madrid
text: LONDON

headline: Bay Goes on Paternity Leave List as Mets Face Giants
text: Mets left fielder Jason Bay was not in the lineup Tuesday night for the opener of a three-game series against the San Francisco Giants at Citi Field because he was put on the paternity leave list to be with his wife, Kristen, who was expecting their third child.

headline: Obama’s Sunday Address  Draws 56.5 Million Viewers
text: President Obama’s announcement of Osama bin Laden’s death was watched by 56.5 million people in the United States on Sunday night, the Nielsen Company said Tuesday.

headline: The American West as Classroom, Art and Metaphor
text: LUBBOCK, Tex. — The native son Buddy Holly aside, this small city on the tableland of the southern Great Plains has never had a lot to recommend it, culturally or aesthetically. When Coronado passed through the area in the 16th century, he described an acute sense of European disorientation as his men struggled to plot a course across a place “with no more landmarks than if we had been swallowed up by the sea.”

headline: Cerberus and Partner Acquire Innkeepers Hotels
text: Cerberus Capital Management and the Chatham Lodging Trust said on Tuesday that they had won a bankruptcy auction for 64 Innkeepers USA hotels. The winning bid was $1.1 billion, including debt.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,553 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: After the Raid: The Compound in Abbottabad
text: Shortly after Osama bin Laden was killed, the Pakistani military blocked access to the compound where he had been staying. This did not, however, stop journalists and curious residents from stopping by for a look.

headline: Senator Presses Sony on Theft of Customer Data
text: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, sent a follow-up letter to Sony on Tuesday after the company said it had discovered that more company servers had been breached during a catastrophic hacking attack last month.

headline: BP Is Fined $25 Million for ’06 Spills at Pipelines
text: WASHINGTON — BP will pay $25 million in civil fines to settle charges arising from two spills from its network of pipelines in Alaska in 2006 and from a willful failure to comply with a government order to properly maintain the pipelines to prevent corrosion, federal officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: A Once-Promising Field Gets Weaker
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There will be 20 horses in the gate Saturday for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby, but it is a stretch to say that they are the cream of this 3-year-old crop. The field lost another contender Tuesday when Toby’s Corner, the winner of the Wood Memorial, came up lame in his left hind leg and was declared out of the race.

headline: A National Security Strategy That Doesn’t Focus on Threats
text: Here’s a proposition: The death of Osama bin Laden brings a moment to talk about something other than threats — not because they don’t exist, but because for the country to see and speak of nothing else is mortally dangerous.

headline: Ronald D. Asmus, Official Who Favored Expanded NATO, Dies at 53
text: Ronald D. Asmus, an early proponent of expanding the Atlantic alliance to include Eastern European nations and a key figure in the Clinton administration’s realization of that vision, died April 30 in Belgium. He was 53.

headline: China: Database on Each Citizen Is Urged
text: China’s top internal security official called for building a database containing information on each of China’s 1.34 billion residents to improve “social management,” a term that encompasses the state’s efforts to manage public dissent and head off protests in the name of maintaining stability. The official, Zhou Yongkang, said the system should be based on the resident identity cards issued to every Chinese citizen, and should include such details as each person’s tax record and history of education and employment, as well as what property and vehicles he or she owns. Writing in Qiushi, a Communist Party magazine, Mr. Zhou said that a comprehensive database would help neighborhood watchmen enforce stability.

headline: Asthma Rate Rises Sharply in U.S., Government Says
text: Americans are suffering from asthma in record numbers, according to a study released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Nearly one in 10 children and almost one in 12 Americans of all ages now has asthma, government researchers said.

headline: The Cue r1 Alarm Clock Is a Time Machine
text: “Throwback” is a word the Cue r1 clock radio brings to mind. For one thing, it’s a clock radio, by which it has an AM/FM radio built in and which is tied to the clock’s alarm timer.

headline: End in Sight for Darwin Letters Project Thanks to $8.2 Million in Grants
text: Teams of scholars have spent nearly 30 years tracking down, researching and editing the more than 15,000 letters written by or to Charles Darwin. Now, thanks to $8.2 million in grants from the Evolution Education Trust, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and the Isaac Newton Trust, the entire collection will be published in full by 2022. Texts of some 6,000 letters and information on 9,000 more are already available here.

headline: Bruins Have a Lead, but Not Peace of Mind
text: BOSTON — Many hockey fans would be pleased if their team had taken a two-games-to-none lead in a playoff series, especially if those victories came on the road. But not Boston Bruins fans, judging from the radio call-in shows Tuesday morning, only hours after the Bruins had won Game 2 of their second-round series, 3-2, in overtime.

headline: Sudan: Deadly Clashes in Disputed Border Territory
text: More than a dozen soldiers have been killed in clashes in Sudan’s contested Abyei area, Sudanese officials said on Tuesday. The fighting broke out Sunday afternoon when a convoy of northern Sudanese troops tried to enter the specially demarcated Abyei area, which straddles the border of northern and southern Sudan and is administered jointly. Southern Sudanese policemen traded fire with the northern troops; each side says the other one started it. Southern Sudan is preparing to split off from northern Sudan this summer, but Abyei’s status is unresolved. Both sides have been beefing up their military forces in Abyei, raising fears of an all-out border war.

headline: Renren Set to Go Public at $14 a Share
text: 9:20 a.m. | Updated

headline: Land Arts of the American West
text: A program at Texas Tech takes artists and architects on a two-month road trip across the West.

headline: TimesCast | A Culture of Conspiracies
text: The Times's Adam B. Ellick speaks with Pakistani journalist Rabia Mehmood on how Pakistani media is addressing Osama bin Laden's death.

headline: Transgender Woman Settles Suit Against Two Organizations
text: Lana Lawless, the transgender woman who sued the L.P.G.A. and the Long Drivers of America last October challenging their rule that competitors be “female at birth,” has settled her case, her lawyer said. Lawless, 57, won the world long-drive title in 2008 but was later ruled ineligible after Long Drivers of America, which oversees the competition, changed its rules to bar transgender competitors. She was prevented from competing in the L.P.G.A. because of a similar rule.

headline: William Campbell, Who Played ‘Star Trek’ Klingon, Dies at 87
text: William Campbell, an actor who was widely familiar to film and television audiences and who was also known as the first husband of Judith Campbell Exner, a mistress of President John F. Kennedy, died on April 28 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Rhode Island: Civil Unions Proposed
text: Leaders of the State House of Representatives introduced legislation Tuesday to allow civil unions for gay couples after conceding there was not enough support in the chamber for a same-sex marriage bill. Gay rights advocates criticized the move, saying civil unions were an insufficient compromise and protesting outside the State House. Same-sex marriage is legal in Connecticut, Iowa, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and the District of Columbia. Lawmakers in Maryland also failed to muster enough votes to pass a same-sex marriage bill this year.

headline: Huntsman Takes a Step Toward Race
text: Three days after resigning as ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. took the first steps on Tuesday toward joining the Republican presidential race by opening a political action committee allowing him to raise and spend money as he considers a candidacy. Mr. Huntsman, a former governor of Utah, has been ensconced in a Washington hotel for the last two days with advisers who are preparing him for the nominating contest. Politico first reported the opening of the committee.

headline: Junk Food ‘Guidelines’ Won’t Help
text: Imagine your child’s teacher was distributing twice daily snacks, before and after lunch — maybe Snickers and PopTarts in the morning, Mountain Dew and fries in the afternoon. Now let’s pretend you complain to the principal, who tells the teacher, “Could you please stop doing that? You have until … five years from Tuesday.”

headline: Court Agrees To Expedite N.F.L.’s Appeal
text: A federal court said Tuesday that it would expedite the appeal that will probably determine which side in the labor dispute between N.F.L. owners and players will have the most leverage. The good news for fans is that the hearing on the N.F.L.’s appeal of the injunction that stopped the league’s lockout was set for June 3. Although it is impossible to determine when a decision by a three-judge panel would come, it is logical to assume the decision will be expedited as well, said Michael Gans, the clerk of the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis.

headline: New U.S. Account Says Bin Laden Was Unarmed During Raid
text: WASHINGTON — Osama bin Laden was not carrying a weapon when he was killed by American troops in a fortified house in Pakistan, the White House said Tuesday, as it revised its initial account of the nighttime raid.

headline: A Mission Not Yet Accomplished
text: It’s obviously been a good week for the Obama administration. But it comes at a dangerous time, for both the administration and the economy. The excitement over tracking down Osama bin Laden could end up making the president and his advisers less panicked over the state of the economy. And they should be a little panicked.

headline: TimesCast | Voicing Distrust on Pakistan
text: The Times's Mark Mazzetti discusses the uneasy relationship between the C.I.A. and Pakistan's intelligence agency.

headline: As M.L.S. Grows, Concern for Charter Clubs
text: Major League Soccer is bodysurfing a wave of optimism.

headline: Inquest Faults London Officer in 2009 Death During Protests
text: LONDON — At the time, the police said that Ian Tomlinson had died of a heart attack. But after a video handed to a British newspaper by an outraged bystander showed Mr. Tomlinson collapsing after being pushed and savagely struck by a police officer wielding a baton, his family demanded an inquiry.

headline: Heaven, Hell and Love
text: To the Editor:

headline: Class-Action Lawsuit Says Utah Immigration Law Violates Civil Rights
text: Two national civil rights law organizations sued the State of Utah on Tuesday, seeking to block a law that gives the police new powers to question people they stop about immigration status.

headline: U.S. Regulators Face Budget Pinch as Mandates Widen
text: Government regulators on the Wall Street beat have long been outnumbered and outspent by the companies they are supposed to police. But even after receiving budget increases from Congress last month, regulators are still falling behind.

headline: As Barriers to Lawyers Persist, Immigrant Advocates Ponder Solutions
text: More than two years ago, a federal judge in New York began a crusade to find lawyers for the many immigrants who are detained or deported because they lack representation. Powerful figures, including Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, heard the call and helped draw attention to the issue.

headline: Mets Thank Troops in a Meaningful Setting
text: The fastest feet in the ballpark Tuesday night did not belong to Jose Reyes, who was on base all six times, but rather to Steve Castleton, a volunteer with the U.S.O., distributing tickets to service members.

headline: Flooding Along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers
text: Flooded areas in the Midwest and South

headline: Google Takes to TV to Promote Browser
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google is once again taking up arms in the browser wars, in the belief that people who use its Chrome Web browser will be more likely to keep using Google search.

headline: Reconnecting With a Spirit of the Sport
text: Last week I visited RiverRun Books in Portsmouth, N.H., to talk about “Lord of Misrule,” my racetrack novel that won the National Book Award last November. It drizzled all day in the harbor town, but a good crowd showed.

headline: Tensions Rise as U.S. Officials Press Pakistan for Answers
text: WASHINGTON — Tensions between the American and Pakistani governments intensified sharply on Tuesday as senior Obama administration officials demanded answers to how Osama bin Laden managed to hide in Pakistan, and the Pakistani government issued a defiant statement calling the raid that killed the Al Qaeda leader “an unauthorized unilateral action.”

headline: Good Feeling Gone, in Congress, Anyway
text: WASHINGTON — Whatever sense of unity the nation might have felt after the killing of Osama bin Laden, it did not extend to the pressing domestic policy issues that divide Congressional Republicans and Democrats, who returned to work in earnest Tuesday.

headline: Under a Microscope, Jeter Has a Powerless Start
text: DETROIT — Derek Jeter’s 100th at-bat of the season came in the eighth inning Monday night against the Tigers, in a situation that over the years had all but defined his career with the Yankees. With two outs, the score tied and the go-ahead run on third base, Jeter strode to the plate, confident as ever.

headline: Farewell to Geronimo
text: There is only one good thing about the fact that Osama bin Laden survived for nearly 10 years after the mass murder at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon that he organized. And that is that he lived long enough to see so many young Arabs repudiate his ideology. He lived long enough to see Arabs from Tunisia to Egypt to Yemen to Syria rise up peacefully to gain the dignity, justice and self-rule that Bin Laden claimed could be obtained only by murderous violence and a return to puritanical Islam.

headline: 9/11 Inspires Student Patriotism and Celebration
text: Ashley Bright was 15 years old and on her way to school in Cottonwood, Ariz., when she stopped at a friend’s house and saw the news that two planes had hit the World Trade Center.

headline: Central Park, Built for and With the Help of Horses, Will Again Offer Them a Home
text: Central Park is laced with bridle paths and dotted with pastures, and its plants were once fertilized with manure. But though carriage horses trot through it, police horses occasionally patrol it, and wooden steeds gallop around the carousel, horses have not called the park home for more than 100 years.

headline: Prosecutors Are Expected to Seek Dismissal of Charges Against Bin Laden
text: It should happen with little or no fanfare, but it will still represent a moment that some thought might never occur: federal prosecutors in Manhattan are expected to file court papers this week that will formally ask a judge to dismiss all charges against Osama bin Laden.

headline: Net Incomes Rise Solidly for CBS and Comcast
text: Both Comcast and the CBS Corporation reported strongly positive first-quarter earnings Tuesday, in one case reflecting largely the strength of its cable television holdings, in the other its strength in advertising sales for its broadcasting operations.

headline: Bin Laden Raid Revives Debate on Value of Torture
text: WASHINGTON — Did brutal interrogations produce the crucial intelligence that led to the killing of Osama bin Laden?

headline: Security on Higher Alert Across U.S.
text: There have been no known specific or credible threats received since American troops killed Osama bin Laden this week, but on Tuesday security at public spaces — including mosques, synagogues, train stations and basketball arenas — remained at elevated levels.

headline: Lottery Numbers
David J. Sencer Dies at 86; Led Disease-Control Agency
text: David J. Sencer, who as a federal and New York City public health official confronted some of the most threatening infectious diseases of the past half century, finding controversy in both roles, died on Monday in Atlanta. He was 86.

headline: Obama’s TV Audience Was His Largest
text: President Obama’s announcement of Osama bin Laden’s death was watched by 56.5 million people in the United States on Sunday night, the Nielsen Company said Tuesday.

headline: A Levee Breached, and New Worries Downstream
text: SIKESTON, MO. — With a rapid series of explosions late Monday that could be felt for miles through the Missouri soil, the Army Corps of Engineers successfully blew out some 11,000 feet of Mississippi River levee, taking dangerous pressure off the river above.

headline: Farmers Concerned About Insurance
text: CHARLESTON, Mo. — Among the many mysteries swirling amid the floodwaters that rush across the breached Birds Point levee is whether those people who have lost their homes in the floodway will be able to collect on their insurance claims.

headline: My Sister, My Grief
text: “AFTER someone has been murdered, their family members often feel peace when the murderer has been executed,” a friend called to tell me on Monday. “Do you feel peace?” Another friend asked, “Are you going to dance in the streets now and celebrate?”

headline: Developers and Christie Detail a Plan for Xanadu
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Much bigger and more expensive, but less gaudy: Gov. Chris Christie and developers laid out a new vision on Tuesday for completing and expanding the vast retail and entertainment complex formerly known as Xanadu in the Meadowlands.

headline: Party Like It’s 2013
text: Republicans on the House Financial Services Committee are having a campaign fund-raiser this week.

headline: Judge Upholds Verdicts in Synagogue Bomb Plot
text: A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the verdicts of four men convicted of plotting to blow up synagogues in the Bronx and military airplanes, but chided the government for building a “troubling” case that relied on the work of an informer whose methods, she suggested, bordered on entrapment.

headline: Is the Captain a Cause for Concern?
text: At 17-9, the Yankees have the second best record in the American League, yet much of the focus this season has been on the struggles of Derek Jeter. Through 100 plate appearances this season, Jeter is batting .250, some 60 points off his career average, and 20 points lower than his disturbingly unimpressive average of last season.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Ex-Adviser to Booker Is Expected to Lead Newark’s Schools
text: The Christie administration has selected a New York City schools official who is an ally of Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark to lead that city’s school system, according to a person briefed on the appointment.

headline: Hertz Uses Mascot in Effort to Make Rental Cars Cool
text: WHEN it comes to car rental, most people expect the basics — cleanliness and functionality. They do not expect cool.

headline: Wednesday: Gallic Girlfriends
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Jeff Chen made his collaborative debut in The New York Times last July and today marks his first solo venture. He has taken more of a chance on this one, but that’s only natural: this is a midweek puzzle.

headline: Demolition of Levee Floods Missouri Farmland
text: Thousands of acres of Missouri farmland were flooded when the Army Corps of Engineers blew a hole in a levee at the confluence of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers to help save the town of Cairo, Ill.

headline: City’s Next Taxi: A Nissan Van Short on Looks, Perhaps, but Full of Comforts
text: The next New York City taxicab will have airplane-style reading lights, passenger air bags, and a so-called low-annoyance horn, engineered to stifle flagrant honkers. The back seat even has more leg room than the old couch-on-wheels Checker cab.

headline: Ode to a Mall
text: On City Room did we last week

headline: In Haiti, Class Comes With a Peek at Lush Life
text: LABADIE, Haiti — On a jungle-covered hill, about 25 Creole-speaking kindergartners chanted numbers inside a gleaming classroom, the ceiling laced with clotheslines of paper butterflies. Past noon, they spilled into the courtyard to dash across the gravel in a blur of blue and cream uniforms, each one embroidered with an anchor and the school’s unusual name: “École Nouvelle Royal Caribbean,” or the New Royal Caribbean School.

headline: James Takes Command, and the Heat Pulls Ahead
text: MIAMI — It is 50 weeks too late for LeBron James to atone for what happened in Cleveland, in a postseason he would not or could not save for his former team. Personal retribution is another matter, and he nearly has it within his grasp.

headline: Base-Running Blunders Sink Yankees
text: DETROIT — The Yankees did not pitch or hit as well as the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday night, and that, in the simplest of terms, is why they lost.

headline: Life in No Man’s Land
text: For the residents of Boise City, Okla., the current drought — the longest on record — is a reminder of just how parched and unyielding life can be along this wind-raked frontier, fittingly called No Man’s Land,

headline: Survivor of Dust Bowl Now Battles a Fiercer Drought
text: BOISE CITY, Okla. — While tornadoes and floods have ravaged the South and the Midwest, the remote western edge of the Oklahoma Panhandle is quietly enduring a weather calamity of its own: its longest drought on record, even worse than the Dust Bowl, when incessant winds scooped up the soil into billowing black clouds and rolled it through this town like bowling balls.

headline: Glencore I.P.O. Mimics Blackstone and Draws Skeptics
text: Is Glencore the new Blackstone? It has become a theme from Wall Street to the City and beyond that the commodity trader’s planned $12 billion stock offering signals the top of its industry’s cycle, just as Blackstone’s did for private equity. But investors should watch for other similarities when scrubbing Glencore’s prospectus, due out Wednesday.

headline: Prebuilt Offices Now Draw Higher-End Tenants
text: Prebuilt office space — in which the landlord builds out the office before leasing it — has traditionally been seen as inferior to the custom-built variety.

headline: Cool Hand Barack
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Myth of Mr. Obama’s Weakness
text: President Obama’s display of leadership in directing the killing of Osama bin Laden raises the prospect that American politics can move away from mindless debates over the president’s loyalties and fortitude. Perhaps the 2012 campaign might even shift to real issues, like the economy and the major parties’ competing visions of government’s role.

headline: Fit to Rule on Same-Sex Marriage
text: Given ample chance during a 13-day trial to offer an argument apart from prejudice, proponents of Proposition 8, the prohibition against same-sex marriage in California, found no evidence. Now they are trying to disqualify Vaughn Walker, the now-retired Federal District Court judge who ruled that the measure was unconstitutional.

headline: Bush Declines Obama’s Invitation to Ground Zero
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama invited former President George W. Bush to join him at ground zero in New York City on Thursday to mark the killing of Osama bin Laden, but Mr. Bush declined, a spokesman for the former president confirmed on Tuesday.

headline: Past, Present, and the Quantity of the Year
text: How long is a year? Ask most people, and they’d say 365 days and not nearly long enough. The year, of course, is the time it takes the Earth to orbit around the Sun, a rate that is slowing fractionally each century. For many reasons, scientists need a more precise definition of the year than its length in days, yet the only unit of time defined in the International System of Units is the second, which is measured in oscillations of cesium atoms.

headline: A Cruise Company’s School for Haiti
text: Royal Caribbean Cruises has started a school in Haiti, after the company received harsh criticism for docking pleasure ships at a Haitian resort just six days after the 2010 earthquake.

headline: The Mets, Short-Handed From the Start, Fall at the End
text: A new rule pushed the Mets into unfamiliar territory Tuesday night. They opened a three-game series against the San Francisco Giants without left fielder Jason Bay, who went on baseball’s paternity leave list to be with his wife, Kristen, who was expecting their third child.

headline: Bloggingheads: Bin Laden's Death
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate celebrating the death of Bin Laden.

headline: With a Start-Up Company, a Ride Is Just a Tap of an App Away
text: Here is yet another thing you can do with a smartphone: summon a car to pick you up with a tap on the screen.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 3
text: Colonel Qaddafi’s forces kept up their attack on the besieged city of Misurata, and a car bomb exploded in Benghazi.

headline: Hidden Workshops Add to Libyan Rebels’ Arsenal
text: MISURATA, Libya — When the bloody siege of this isolated city began, the rebels who rose against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s conventional army had almost no firearms. Many of them relied on hands, knives and stones.

headline: 44 Works Sell for $170 Million at Sotheby’s Auction
text: Chinese and Russian could be heard in the Sotheby’s salesroom on Tuesday night at the beginning of the big spring auction season. But in spite of the presence of Prada-clad international collectors, it was a tepid start, with a few strong prices and many works selling below expectations.

headline: Morning T | Andrew Bolton on Alexander McQueen
text: In the latest installment of “Morning T,” Andrew Bolton, the British curator of the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, discusses the institute’s current Alexander McQueen exhibition, “Savage Beauty.” The exhibition includes, among other extraordinarily rare pieces, some original designs from McQueen’s graduate student collection, which were lined with human hair. Read Suzy Menkes’s review of the exhibition here.

headline: Morning T: Andrew Bolton
text: Horacio Silva discusses the new Alexander McQueen exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art with its curator, Andrew Bolton.

headline: Amazon Enters the Flash Sale Fray With Myhabit
text: Adrenaline-pumped online shopping, popularized by so-called flash sale sites like Gilt, has arrived at Amazon.com.

headline: L'Amour Fou
text: Scenes from "L'Amour Fou," the new documentary about Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé.

headline: How Sugar Affects the Body in Motion
text: Sugar is getting a bad reputation. A cover article in The New York Times Magazine several weeks ago persuasively reported that our national overindulgence in fructose and other sugars is driving the epidemics of obesity, diabetes and other illnesses. But that much-discussed article, by the writer Gary Taubes, focused on how sugars like fructose affect the body in general. It had little opportunity to examine the related issue of how sugar affects the body in motion. Do sweeteners like fructose — the sweetest of the simple sugars, found abundantly in fruits and honey — have the same effect on active people as on the slothful?

headline: The Chapel of Sacred Mirrors
text: The Chelsea art space, a curious, over-the-top combination of gallery, New Age temple and Coney Island sideshow, will close at the end of the month.

headline: FDR’s First 100 Days, Revisited
text: As the teetering economy and Barack Obama’s election spur plenty of allusions to F.D.R., two exhibitions revisit the early days of the Roosevelt Administration.

headline: Pandora Internet Radio Service to Offer Large Archive of Comedy Clips
text: Since it began six years ago, the Internet radio service Pandora has changed the way millions of people listen to music online. Now the company wants to do the same for comedy.

headline: As China Invests, U.S. Could Lose
text: SHANGHAI — For three decades, wealthy nations have invested hundreds of billions of dollars in China, helping drive one of the most remarkable economic booms in history.

headline: Report on Chinese Investment
text: The full study from the Asia Society and the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars on Chinese foreign direct investment.

headline: Word of the Day | adulterate

headline: Finding on Dialects Casts New Light on the Origins of the Japanese People
text: Researchers studying the various dialects of Japanese have concluded that all are descended from a founding language taken to the Japanese islands about 2,200 years ago. The finding sheds new light on the origin of the Japanese people, suggesting that their language is descended from that of the rice-growing farmers who arrived in Japan from the Korean Peninsula, and not from the hunter-gatherers who first inhabited the islands some 30,000 years ago.

headline: Iraq: Third Day of Blasts in Baghdad Neighborhood
text: Three explosions shook the neighborhood of Dora in south Baghdad on Tuesday, killing at least 10 and wounding 28, according to a local security official. It was the third straight day in which Dora had been attacked. Dora is predominantly Sunni, although the attack on Tuesday evening occurred in a Shiite area. Improvised explosive devices and magnetic bombs were detonated on Sunday and Monday, injuring 12 people, including four police officers and a government official. Members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia have said they would increase attacks after Osama bin Laden’s death.

headline: Some Troops Should Stay in Iraq, Speaker Says
text: WASHINGTON — After a high-level trip to Iraq, House Speaker John A. Boehner said on Tuesday that he would support keeping a contingent of troops in Iraq beyond the end of the year, when all American forces are scheduled to be withdrawn.

headline: Report Implicates Kyrgyzstan Officials in Ethnic Violence Last Year
text: MOSCOW — Video taken during the ethnic violence that broke out in southern Kyrgyzstan last June show armored personnel carriers carousing wildly through devastated neighborhoods, with young men in civilian clothes hanging onto the turrets.

headline: Photo Replay: May 3
text: A look at the day in sports from a rainy trot around Churchill Downs to a superstar performance in Miami.

headline: Gaza: Barenboim Performs in Palestinian Territory
text: The Israeli musician Daniel Barenboim and 25 members of his orchestra performed in the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip on Tuesday. Mr. Barenboim, who has honorary Palestinian citizenship, is a harsh critic of Israel’s occupation of Gaza and the West Bank and he co-founded a music education project in the Palestinian territories.

headline: Voice Recorder From Air France Plane Crash Is Found
text: French investigators said on Tuesday that they had recovered the cockpit voice recorder from the Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic almost two years ago en route to Paris from Rio de Janeiro. After three failed searches and expenditures nearing $30 million, both so-called black boxes are now in hand, giving investigators renewed hope of unraveling the mystery of what caused Flight 447 to go down in a heavy thunderstorm on June 1, 2009. All 228 passengers and crew members were killed. So far, the only information about what happened to the flight is from automated messages that indicated a malfunction of the plane’s airspeed sensors.

headline: The Dry Season
text: A drought in the Oklahoma Panhandle is poised to do what the Dust Bowl couldn't — drive towns in this parched region out of existence.

headline: News Quiz | May 4, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Gilded Home
text: Dr. Anthony Walter uses decorative art in his home to inspire others to devote themselves to their spouses and to God.

headline: The Dining Room Where Buckley Reigned
text: The tables are still set at the Park Avenue home of William F. Buckley Jr.

headline: North Korean Prison Camps Massive and Growing
text: SEOUL, South Korea — New satellite images and firsthand accounts from former political prisoners and former jailers in North Korea have confirmed the enormous scale and bleak conditions of the penal system in the secretive North, according to a report released Wednesday by the human rights group Amnesty International.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 4, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article “As Consumers Cut Spending, ‘Green’ Products Lose Allure.”

text: WHO is shown in this photograph?

headline: What Would You Do With a Gap Year?
text: The New York Times columnist Nicholas D. Kristof’s son Gregory wrote a post on his father’s blog about his experience deferring his college entrance for a year to pursue personal interests. Would you like to take a gap year? If so, what would you do with that time, and why? If not, why not?

headline: Applied Materials to Buy Varian
text: Applied Materials said on Wednesday that it would pay $4.9 billion in cash for Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates, as it looks to capitalize on mobile and other high-growth technologies.

headline: 2010 Seahawks: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the N.F.C. West:

headline: SiriusXM Tunes In a New Program Guide
text: The corporate merger of the satellite radio giants Sirius and XM formally took place in 2008. On Wednesday, a remapped channel lineup should make the two networks finally feel more cohesive for listeners.

headline: New Keynesian Economics Misses the Point, for Now
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: In Rome, Farmers’ Markets Are in Season
text: Nearly every neighborhood in Rome has a local market — a mercato rionale. Market hours — generally Monday to Saturday until around 1:30 p.m. — aren’t convenient for many consumers, who turn increasingly to supermarkets and their industrial products. Rome’s farmers’ markets are seeking to combat this by offering extended weekend hours and an opportunity to purchase local food directly from producers.

headline: The Beatles Discuss Arizona’s Immigration Bill
text: Last weekend, when I wasn’t delivering meals to the homebound, I was “researching” Beatles bootlegs. And I discovered the so-called “Commonwealth Song.” It’s not so much a song as it is an extended improvisation during the interminable “Get Back” studio sessions in 1969 (in fact, some theorize that “The Commonwealth Song” is a prototype for “Get Back”). “Commonwealth” name-checks Enoch Powell (the Tom Tancredo of his day, or Thilo Sarazin, if you prefer a German reference), who had delivered his anti-immigrant “Rivers of Blood” speech the previous year. “Commonwealth” was Paul McCartney’s mocking response. All of which shows that the sun never sets on some issues. It’s also nice to know that as late as 1969, Lennon and McCartney could still crack each other up, especially when John interjects his high-pitched “Yes!”

headline: Angry Rhymes, Dirty Mouth, Goofy Kid

headline: The President's Approval Rating After Bin Laden
text: President Obama’s approval rating is up, following Osama bin Laden’s killing.

headline: What Happens to Bin Ladenism Now?
text: The Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman on the Arab spring's rejection of the culture of violent extremism taught by Bin Laden and his followers.

headline: Business Life After Death in Rwanda
text: In a previous post, I wrote about the Business Council for Peace, a nonprofit network of professionals who provide pro bono business services to mostly female entrepreneurs in countries affected by conflict, including Rwanda. Last month, three Rwandan owners, graduates of the three-year BPeace program, visited the United States during a trip that paired them with American businesses in their industries. The participants included Languida Nyirababeruka, who founded Pompe Funebre Twifatanye, a funeral home, after the 1994 genocide.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 2 and 3 with 532 adults throughout the United States.

headline: For Obama, Big Rise in Poll Numbers After Bin Laden Raid
text: Support for President Obama rose sharply after the killing of Osama bin Laden, with a majority now approving of his overall job performance, as well as his handling of foreign policy, the war in Afghanistan and the threat of terrorism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: A Different Kind of Arab Spring
text: At The Daily Beast’s The Dish, Andrew Sullivan links to an article on the Beast about the first Muslim playmate. It’s hard to embrace this as a form of liberation, as Asra Q. Nomani reluctantly does. (“I’m not a fan of porn as a symbol of empowerment, but as a Muslim woman, hearing divinely sanctioned mandates all my life about what a good Muslim girl looks like, I can understand why Sahin has responded to our community sanctions about honor, shame and modesty by stripping — and why members of her family have ostracized her for it.”) But it did make me flash back to a recent post on 3quarksdaily, showing a graffito of a burqa-clad woman having a Marilyn moment. We all know that hemlines rise during tough economic times. Do they also rise (or disappear altogether) during revolutionary ones?

headline: Bush Aides Walk Delicate Line on Bin Laden

headline: Bin Laden’s Killing Helps President’s Poll Numbers
text: Our colleagues James Dao and Dalia Sussman report that the operation in Pakistan that killed Osama bin Laden has given President Obama a sharp bump in his job performance approval rating among both Republican and Democratic voters, climbing to 57 percent from 46 percent in April. Many more Americans now approve of the job he is doing as president and of the way he is handling foreign policy, the war in Afghanistan and the threat of terrorism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

For the doctrine he’s attacking bears no resemblance to anything Keynesians are saying.

headline: Graphic Content | Neshan
text: Iran’s stunning contemporary graphic design is virtually unknown in the West. But there is some light emerging. Over the past few years, books showcasing Iranian graphic design, posters, calligraphy and typography have been published in the West, opening a very rich vein of design that combines tradition and modernity. And one of the best places to view this work is Iran’s first and only graphic design magazine, Neshan. (Full disclosure: I’m a contributor to the magazine.)

headline: Pakistan Sees Shared Intelligence Lapse

headline: Not Quite a Revival, But Still a Sinful Hybrid

headline: A Blacksmith’s Touch Makes Music Light
text: HEAVY metal usually means a lot of racket, but not here. Across the 30 or so rolling acres of his farm in southwestern Tuscany, the German sculptor and musician Paul Fuchs, 74, cultivates the Giardino dei Suoni, his Garden of Sounds. Weighing tons, his spindly abstractions of steel and bronze — “The Long I,” “Cut Out,” “0 + 1” — inscribe the landscape like quick strokes and squiggles of some titan’s pen. Rising as high as 100 feet they catch movement in the air and give forth vibrations that verge on silence: the gentlest of music. One, “Visit From the Extraterrestrial,” tolls like a buoy on the churning sea.

headline: How to Save on Group Travel
text: WITH summer on the way, many families and friends are starting to think about reunions and group vacations. But as anyone who has tried to organize a large group of travelers knows, the process can be daunting and can carry a big price tag. Luckily, there are ways to make group vacations more affordable and the planning process more streamlined, whether you’re trying to arrange hotel stays, cruises or airline reservations. Here are a few tips.

headline: Now Serving | Egg Cream at Eleven Madison Park
text: These days, fine dining isn’t so much a three-act play of starter/main/dessert as a three-hour spectacular that starts with a couple of rounds of amuse-bouches and ends with the chocolates and dime-size cookies that appear some time after dessert and before the check. The headliners are still foie gras, langoustines and steak from an extremely expensive steer, but sometimes a meal’s brightest star is found between the big numbers.

headline: China Creates New Agency for Patrolling the Internet
text: BEIJING — A powerful arm of China’s government said Wednesday that it had created a new central agency to regulate every corner of the nation’s vast Internet community, a move that appeared to complement a continuing crackdown on political dissidents and other social critics.

headline: What Happened to Air France Flight 447?
text: Late on the morning of April 3, the expedition ship Alucia rocked violently on the South Atlantic Ocean in the middle of a squall. On the aft deck, the crew huddled together in rain slickers and gazed across the heaving seas to a yellow blur on the horizon. This was an unmanned reconnaissance submarine carrying 15,000 photographs that they were nearly desperate to see. But it had buoyed to the surface just as the squall sprang up, and with 30-knot winds and four-foot swells that splashed over the stern, it was too dangerous to retrieve the sub. So they watched and waited.

headline: Reid Dislocates Shoulder During Morning Run
text: Harry Reid, the United States Senate majority leader, took a spill on the rainy streets of Washington on Wednesday, leaving the Democrat from Nevada with a dislocated right shoulder and golf ball-sized bump above his left eye.

headline: Why Moms Should Quit
text: A few weeks ago, in the middle of what I now refer to as my “On the Couch” period, I gave my younger son a list. I don’t remember what exactly was on it, but I clearly recall his response. His expression said he was about to protest. He opened his mouth, closed it again, thought for a moment, then said: “All this is the stuff you usually do around here but I don’t notice, right?”

headline: In Afghanistan, No Time to Celebrate
text: Osama bin Laden is dead. The news was announced in tickers, as I entered my office at Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan on Monday morning. Everyone was gathered around the television, intently sitting on the edge of their black swivel chairs. “All right, let’s pack up now — it’s time to go home,” one of the sergeants in the room said. “I want to see a death certificate,” our chiseled former infantry first sergeant said. “We all know Donald Trump is going to demand to see one.” The blond newscaster described how Bin Laden had been hiding in a luxurious compound 60 miles outside of Islamabad. She exclaimed, “Who would have thought he would be hiding in Pakistan all along?” One sergeant jumped up, muttering, “I would have thought that.” We all laughed.

headline: Stage Is Set for First Republican Debate
text: The contrast with four years ago is likely to be striking.

headline: Shunning Nasdaq, LinkedIn Prepares a Big Board I.P.O.

headline: Falling Dollar Phobia
text: I continue to be amazed by the way Very Serious People find ways to worry about everything except devastating unemployment. They’ve now spent two years warning about the bond vigilantes about to pull the rug out from under us any day now; as of right now, the 10-year interest rate has fallen to 3.21 percent on weak economic data.

headline: Four Construction Executives Are Charged With Fraud
text: Four veteran construction executives were arraigned Wednesday on charges that they systemically stole tens of millions of dollars from investment firms, insurance companies and law firms as they built corporate offices in buildings across Manhattan.

headline: 9/11 and the Silence of Shock
text: Our friends on the Lens blog are marking Bin Laden Week, which is what this seems to be turning into, with a remarkable series of Sept. 11 photos this morning. They’re by Rikki Reich and were shot from the Jersey City waterfront over the course of the unfolding nightmare. As David Dunlap writes on Lens, Ms. Reich’s pictures “convey an awful tranquility, a suspension of everyday existence, the silence of shock.” View the slide show on Lens. »

headline: Still Room for Freshmen at Many Colleges
text: Regular visitors to The Choice know that we try, whenever the opportunity presents itself, to remind readers that in sharp contrast to the competitive admissions landscape at some colleges, hundreds of other universities struggle every year to fill their freshman classes. For some of those institutions, the sluggish economy has only added to the challenge of completing the freshman class.

headline: It’s Still a No-Hitter in the Record Book
text: It’s hard not to love no-hitters. They usually contain so much of what is charming about baseball: the mastery of a locked-in pitcher, superstitious teammates avoiding him in the dugout, dramatic defensive plays and nervous moments in the late innings, the emotional spillover when it is finally in the books. Francisco Liriano’s no-hitter for the Twins on Tuesday night, however? Maybe only a mother could love that one.

headline: Sheridan’s Suit Against ‘Desperate Housewives’ Can Go to Trial, Judge Says
text: It was the producers of “Desperate Housewives” who decided to kill off Edie, the much-married Wisteria Lane resident whom Nicollette Sheridan had played on the prime-time ABC soap opera since its 2004 debut. But it is a California jury that will decide whether the character’s death, in a car accident during the show’s fifth season, was a fair exit for Ms. Sheridan, who has sued for damages for wrongful termination, among other matters.

headline: The Godfather, Before He Was
text: How did the Don become the Don? A new prequel to “The Godfather” promises to explain the “unknown history” of how Vito Corleone rose to power in Depression-era New York. Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, announced on Wednesday that it would publish  “The Family Corleone,” a book based on a screenplay by Mario Puzo, in June of next year.  Mr. Puzo died in 1999, but the book has the blessing of his estate. “The Family Corleone” was written by Ed Falco, the author of three novels and the winner of a Pushcart Prize. “The Godfather” was first published in 1969 and has sold more than 21 million copies.

The heir to the British throne gave an earnest and statistics-heavy address touching on such staples of the natural food movement as the virtues of composting and the need to maintain biodiversity.

headline: On Her Arm, a Symbol of Freedom

headline: One Nurse, One Patient

headline: Campus Camo
text: Looks like the lax bros these days are laying down their lacrosse sticks in favor of something with a little more firepower. In college quads in the south, camouflage is replacing Kelly green as the prepster’s color of choice. K. Cooper Ray, the Charleston, S.C.-based blogger of all things gentlemanly, saw local college kids “polished and groomed and bow-tied and then they turn around and they’ve got their camo on and shotguns over their shoulder, heading off to the marshes of the low country to go duck hunting.” For his third Social Primer for Brooks Brothers accessory collection, Cooper tips his hunting cap to these rustic dandies who proudly refer to themselves as “Prep-necks.” Intrigued by these seemingly opposing ideas of masculinity, Cooper combined a green camouflage print with a “Palm Beach pink” repp stripe for his reversible bow tie, just one of a collection of ties, key fobs and pocket squares available at Brooks Brothers stores nationwide. Those poor ducks don’t stand a chance against these dapper dudes.

headline: In a Slow Week, Adele Tops Chart Again

headline: Coming to a Planet Near You: 3 Billion More Mouths to Feed

headline: More on Tornadoes, Floods, Climate and Risk

headline: Afghanistan Uses News About Bin Laden to Intensify Its Criticism of Pakistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government escalated its criticism of Pakistan on Wednesday, publicly questioning for the first time how the Pakistanis could ensure the security of their nuclear arms if they did not even know that Osama bin Laden, the world’s most wanted terrorist, had been hiding in a compound in a Pakistani military town less than an hour from their capital.

headline: A Stravinksy Program With Ancient Inspiration
text: A couple of years ago the Philadelphia Orchestra seemed adrift as it searched simultaneously for a chief executive, a board chairman and a music director. On top of that were rumblings of financial problems. It was hard to imagine how things could get worse for this great American ensemble.

headline: Get Ready for 14 Hours of Derby TV Coverage
text: NBC has been home to the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes since 2001, but not since 2005 have all three Triple Crown races been shown on one network. Comcast’s acquisition of NBC Universal has led to 14 hours of Kentucky Derby coverage, which is set to begin Wednesday. So pull up a seat or set your DVR.

headline: Senate Thwarts Filibuster on Judge
text: Defying highly unusual opposition by business groups and the Senate minority leader, the Senate on Wednesday voted to proceed with a confirmation vote for a nominee for federal district  court, thwarting a threatened filibuster and signaling an apparent unwillingness among many Republicans to hinder judicial appointments without extraordinary cause.

headline: With Supplies Dwindling, Some Honda Dealers Foresee Long, Dry Summer

headline: Share Six Words About Your Mother

headline: Chance Encounter
text: Julia Leach doesn’t strike you as the type of person who would leave anything to chance. A veteran of the ad agency Chiat/Day, Paper Magazine and Kate Spade, Leach is a prolific and meticulous storyboarder. Ideas seem to spill out of her head fully formed, including graphic sensibility, visual collateral and even potential plot twists. But when she struck out to start her own 360-degree lifestyle brand, she left ample room for serendipity. And as if to drive the concept home — or simply to remind herself that nothing ever really comes out exactly as you plan it — she named the venture Chance.

headline: Chase Ends Test of $5 A.T.M. Fees

headline: Finding Long-Term Value in Renren
