text: KIEV, Ukraine — This former Soviet state in Eastern Europe is betting that the path toward energy independence runs through Fort Worth.

headline: Slushies Coming at You: ‘Glee’ Goes 3-D in  Concert Movie
text: The “Glee” franchise isn’t all about indulging the 1970s nostalgia of its creators and structuring entire episodes around “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” or Fleetwood Mac’s “Rumours” album; that hit Fox musical comedy has a few modern-day tricks up its sleeve, too. For instance: its “Glee Live! In Concert!” series will be filmed this summer for a 3-D movie that will feature 14 members of the television series and utilize whatever remaining exclamation points Fox possesses. On Wednesday, Twentieth Century Fox’s film and television divisions said that the “Glee Live! 3D!” movie will be released in theaters on Aug. 12 and run for two weeks. The film, directed by Kevin Tancharoen (director of the 2009 remake of “Fame,” and the online series “Mortal Kombat: Legacy”) will feature “Glee” stars like Lea Michele, Chris Colfer, Heather Morris and Darren Criss performing numbers like “I’m a Slave 4 U,” “Raise Your Glass” and “Teenage Dream.” (No word about the “Glee” star Matthew Morrison, whose cleft chin would seem tailor-made for the 3-D format.)

headline: Two Students Plead Guilty in Bullying of Teenager
text: Two of the six students in South Hadley, Mass., who were charged with bullying a 15-year-old girl before her suicide last year pleaded guilty to misdemeanor harassment charges on Wednesday and received a year’s probation each, plus 100 hours of community service.

headline: Apple Updates Software to Fix Problems With Collecting Location Data
text: Apple on Wednesday released its promised software update for its mobile devices to fix a problem that enabled the iPhone and iPad 3G to collect customers’ locations.

headline: TimesCast | May 4, 2011
text: President Obama decides not to release photos of Osama bin Laden; Pakistanis question their military’s abilities; and Turkey plays an important role in the Arab spring.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: VEGETABLE LOVE Yes To, a hair and skin care collection made from organic produce and minerals from the Dead Sea, has some new products. Tomato, rich in the antioxidant lycopene, is the featured ingredient in a new acne spot stick that also contains tea tree oil, and in a pore scrub with mango seeds (both $9.99.) And carrots — rich in beta-carotene, a natural form of vitamin A — appear in a new body lotion and hand cream whose other ingredients include soybeans and allantoin ($8.99 to $12.99). Available at Target, Walgreens, Duane Reade and yestocarrots.com.

headline: New Stratagems in the Quest for Hair
text: RICHARD PADUDA, an athletic man with a dark, spiky coiffure, does not look like your typical user of Latisse, the prescription eyelash-enhancing solution that has been endorsed by Brooke Shields and Claire Danes. That’s because he has used it not on his eyelashes, which are fairly lush, but on his hairline, which he noticed last year was beginning to recede.

headline: To Improve Your Swing: Bend Your Knees and Find a Good App
text: Every round of golf I play, I’ll hit maybe three or four shots that go exactly where I want them to go. And every time it happens, it’s a mystery.

headline: Goldman Brushes Off the Gadfly
text: William Thomas Cain/Getty ImagesEvelyn Y. Davis at the Ford Motor Company’s annual meeting last year.

headline: Stamps From Space, With Brooklyn Ties
text: Donato Giancola does not remember the day itself, which, if you happen to be checking the calendar, was 50 years ago on Thursday — May 5, 1961.

headline: Bulls’ Korver Shadowed by Defensive Reputation
text: Over the course of his career, Chicago guard Kyle Korver has developed a reputation for being both one of the league’s top outside shooters and one of its lesser perimeter defenders. The former is unquestionably true: Korver is a career 41.1 percent 3-point marksman, and has connected on a whopping 61.9 percent of his attempts in these playoffs.

headline: Quote Unquote | Small Wonder
text: – Jean Shrimpton tells The Guardian why she likes Kate Moss. Of course “the shrimp” gets along with “the waif.”

headline: Legislation Targets Drug Use in Horse Racing
text: Representative Edward Whitfield, Republican of Kentucky, and Senator Tom Udall, Democrat of New Mexico, introduced legislation Wednesday to regulate the use of performance-enhancing drugs in horse racing.

headline: Adorable Anime Characters Go Speed Metal
text: The films of Hayao Miyazaki — “Ponyo,” “Spirited Away,” “Princess Mononoke” — are unlike anything else. The animation is amazing, but it’s the tone of the films that sets them apart. They are suffused with a mysterious sense of wonderment that is impossible to describe. And yet, the music: why?

headline: New Apps to Post Videos With Ease
text: Most of the video shot in the world today is recorded on mobile phones. That annoying guy who walked around parties with a camcorder has been replaced with an army of annoying people who whip out their phones to capture the moment.

headline: Aquifer’s Depletion Poses Sweeping Threat
text: The small town of Boise City, Okla., which I wrote about in Wednesday’s Times, survived the environmental disaster of the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. But now it faces a confluence of dangers that could push it to the edge of extinction.

headline: Jimmy
text: IN a space-deprived city, the rooftop pool is a symbol of thumb-in-your-eye luxury. Jimmy, which opened on the 18th floor of the James Hotel, joins the Standard, Trump SoHo and Gansevoort hotels as places where patrons can pretend they’re in Miami. It opened last fall, and interest has risen with the temperature.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Indonesia and West Bank.

headline: Clip: 'Midnight in Paris'
text: Owen Wilson and Rachel McAdams in a scene from Woody Allen's "Midnight in Paris."

headline: UBS Settles Fraud Cases Over Munis
text: WASHINGTON — The Swiss bank UBS agreed to pay $160 million in fines and restitution because former employees conspired to rig bids in the municipal bond derivatives market, federal and state officials announced on Wednesday.

headline: Homes for $500,000
text: An 1886 Queen Anne in Bozeman, Mont.; a 1940 house in Miami; and a condo in a converted 1899 commercial building in downtown Los Angeles.

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: BOZEMAN, MONT.

headline: 12 Heads Do the Talking for a Silenced Artist
text: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei began his second month of detention this week, and still the Chinese government has given an increasingly outraged and anxious world no satisfactory answers to questions about his whereabouts, his condition or the charges against him.

headline: Helping Veggie Island’s Garden Grow
text: Veggie Island opened  for last year’s surf season, selling mainly local, mainly organic produce next to Rockaway Taco in Queens. This year, this quirky little stand is getting more serious, trying to raise $15,000 through Kickstarter to build a garden, greenhouse and composting facility at a nearby marina, and to fix up the store. So far it’s raised a little over $5,300 and has eight days to raise the rest.

headline: Docking Your Laptop, Wirelessly
text: Mmmmmm. Wireless.

headline: No, Osama Didn’t Win
text: If you’re looking for a counterpoint to my “Bin Laden died a failure” column from Monday, here’s Radley Balko making that the case that the Al Qaeda founder actually died a great success:

headline: The Gravity Probe B
text: The gravity probe B experiment used four gyroscopes to measure the warping of space and time around a gravitational body.

headline: 52 Years and $750 Million Prove Einstein Was Right
text: In a tour de force of technology and just plain stubbornness spanning half a century and costing more than $750 million, a team of experimenters from Stanford University reported on Wednesday that a set of orbiting gyroscopes had detected a slight sag and an even slighter twist in space-time.

headline: In Belize, a Beachfront Duplex
text: A five-bedroom beachfront duplex with pool and pier in Belize is on the market for $999,000.

headline: Surprise! American Express Picks Your Destination for You
text: The biggest surprise that most travelers face is a flight delay. But American Express Travel is offering a new twist on trip planning that promises to inject some fun spontaneity into travel: it chooses destinations for you, and shares the details later.

headline: Asked & Answered | Pierre Thoretton
text: In the past few years, there have been a number of documentaries about iconic fashion designers, from the critically acclaimed “Valentino: The Last Emperor” to the wayward “Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston.” But none seems as delicately composed and poignant as Pierre Thoretton’s “L’Amour Fou,” which had its United States premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival last month and will be out in theaters on May 13. Thoretton hangs the film on the spectacular $480 million art collection that the French-Algerian couturier Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Bergé, amassed during their 50 years together and its symbolism for the love they had for one another. Still it’s hard not to wonder if it was Bergé, as much as Thoretton, who called the shots in the film much as he did in Saint Laurent’s life and image. Here, the 43-year-old French director discusses the crazy love between the two men and the filmmaking techniques he chose to tell the story.

headline: Beige Never Looked So Bright
text: DOLLY PARTON and Gloria Gaynor singing an impromptu duet. Britney Spears supposedly skipping out on her check. Jocelyne Wildenstein showing off her nip and tuck.

headline: Forest Hills Stadium Loses Bid to Be a Landmark
text: Its courts were the site of the United States Open tennis championship for 62 years and they hosted the Beatles, Frank Sinatra and the Rolling Stones. But time may finally be running out for the now crumbling West Side Tennis Stadium in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, one of the world’s most storied tennis arenas.

headline: House Hunting in ... Belize
text: A FIVE-BEDROOM BEACHFRONT DUPLEX WITH POOL AND PIER IN BELIZE$999,000

headline: Moment of Falsehood
text: Well, remember how the Ryan budget was supposed to mark our national moment of truth, forcing us into a serious discussion of fiscal choices? Neither do I.

headline: Allen Abroad
text: A look at the films Woody Allen has made outside of New York.

headline: Six Gears Come to Brammo E.V. Bikes
text: Until Wednesday, one of the biggest selling points of electric cars and motorcycles has been their seamless, shift-free stream of power.

headline: Into the Spotlight, Gently
text: UNTIL last Friday, Sarah Burton was an understudy in the chorus line of designers, a largely anonymous talent. As the creative director at Alexander McQueen — a role she reluctantly inherited after McQueen’s suicide in February 2010 — she not only worked in his immense shadow, but also preferred the background to the spotlight.

headline: Robbery Defendant, Uncuffed, Scuffles With Officers
text: A man facing robbery charges sent four Manhattan court officers to the hospital with minor injuries on Wednesday after he refused to go to his holding cell and scuffled with them, the authorities said.

headline: TimesCast | No Photos of Bin Laden
text: President Obama decides not to release the photos of Osama bin Laden's corpse.

headline: TimesCast | An Incompetent Military?
text: America's successful mission to kill Osama Bin Laden has Pakistanis questioning the competence of their military.

headline: TimesCast | Turkey's Role
text: May 4, 2011 - As Turkey turns its back on its ally in Libya, will it stay silent on its neighbor Syria?

headline: Pakistani Military Investigates How Bin Laden Was Able to Hide in Plain View
text: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani military has taken charge of investigations into the circumstances that allowed Osama bin Laden to reside quietly in a three-story house on the edge of this town, officials here said. Military intelligence investigators returned to the house on Wednesday and spent most of the day working inside the compound, while the army and the police barred journalists and others from approaching the area.

headline: House Votes to Block School Health Spending
text: House Republicans marched forward Wednesday with their efforts to dismantle the health care overhaul, one bill at a time.

headline: Dialed In Is Early Derby Favorite at 4-1
text: Uncle Mo may or may not show up for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, but if he does he will break from the No. 18 hole as the 9-2 morning-line second favorite.

headline: Stripped Down to Black and White, Revealing Balanchine at His Core
text: The music starts. The curtain rises. There is no scenery, just a backdrop that implies the infinite sky. Yet the stage is far from empty: it features a central tableau of dancers, braced for action. When they start to move, they do so in sharply alive meters. It’s as if they had been waiting for the music to ignite their motors. That little transition from standstill to motion always carries something of the drama of the moment when the sculptor Pygmalion’s statue Galatea comes to life.

headline: Some Off-the-Edge Songs, Placed Front and Center
text: The enterprising New York Festival of Song has presented plenty of new music and even some pop at times (most notably, evenings of Beatles tunes and musical theater pieces). So it would not be entirely correct to suggest that its latest series, Nyfos Next, is an attempt to address a serious deficit in the festival’s purview.

headline: New York Attorney General Subpoenas Sony
text: 7:47 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Sony.

headline: In Scotland, a Modern Farmhouse Rises From Ruins
text: A house on the tiny Isle of Coll was built on the remains of one abandoned 150 years earlier.

headline: ‘Voice’ Grows Stronger
text: The ratings for NBC’s new singing competition “The Voice” grew 10 percent over its impressive debut a week ago, leading Tuesday night’s ratings over all by a wide margin among viewers 18 to 49, and drawing 12.4 million over all. But in total viewers for the night NBC finished in third place, according to Nielsen’s estimates. CBS had the most viewers, garnering 17.3 million for “NCIS” at 8 p.m. and 14 million for “NCIS: Los Angeles” at 9. ABC ranked second over all, earning its best ratings at 9 for a “Dancing With the Stars” results episode (15.6 million), but at 10, its “Body of Proof” (10.4 million) trailed “The Good Wife” on CBS (12.3 million). Fox finished in fourth place for the night.

headline: An ‘Idol’ Judge Heeds Her Tips
text: Steven Tyler may operate on a bizarre frequency, and Jimmy Iovine may be the ruthless engine behind the scenes, but no one has kept “American Idol” afloat this year more than Jennifer Lopez.

headline: Onetime S.E.C. Enforcement Lawyer Joins Weil Gotshal
text: Christian R. Bartholomew, a former senior enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges as head of the law firm’s S.E.C. enforcement and litigation practice in Washington.

headline: ‘The Informant’
Hired Killer, Forced Out of Retirement, Says Hello Again to an Old Adversary
text: Thomas Perry won the Mystery Writers of America’s Edgar Award for  “The Butcher’s Boy,” his 1982 debut novel about an extremely unflappable hired killer. He checks in on the character after long intervals, so the steel-nerved assassin showed up in the 1992 “Sleeping Dogs.” Now the Butcher’s Boy is back at full blast in “The Informant,” a book-length war of nerves that accentuates the best of Mr. Perry’s gift for using pure logic and gamesmanship to generate breathless nonstop suspense.

headline: Daniels Happy With Action on Indiana Schools
text: Just as he was noncommittal about entering the 2012 presidential race on Wednesday, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana was characteristically low key in discussing his sweeping, even landmark changes for schools in his state.

headline: Office Party? Let’s Tweet It
text: ON a rainy Tuesday last month, in an all-white office space in Brooklyn, a blogger known as swissmiss traded productivity tips with some visiting creative strategists. “Our own mini-TED,” she said, half-joking, referring to the high-profile tech conference.

headline: A New Book on Obama's Mother
text: Times reporter Janny Scott talks about her book on the life of Barack Obama's mother, Stanley Ann Dunham.

headline: It’s Official: Wasserman Schultz Is New Democratic Chief
text: Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida officially became the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee on Wednesday.

headline: Liberal Group’s Video Assails Koch Brothers
text: The liberal guerrilla video group Brave New Foundation on Wednesday began what it says will be a prolonged political attack against the industrialist Koch family, which has become synonymous with the anti-Obama conservative movement.

headline: Designer as Dramatist, and the Tales He Left Behind
text: A hairstylist friend of mine used to place leather bondage gear in her downtown shop window to scare off what she called “the wrong element,” meaning anyone wanting a nice wash and trim. She wanted to be sure that if you sat in her chair, you were ready to accept whatever look she decided on for you, because it would change the way you saw yourself in the world. That was the deal.

headline: Warm Respect for a Scottish Ruin
text: ISLE OF COLL, Scotland

headline: Bird Week | ‘Birdman’ of Inwood
text: As he rounds the corner of West 208th Street and Ninth Avenue with two green fishing nets over his shoulder, James Cataldi says: “You go first. They’ll flock toward me if they see me.”

headline: Bargain Plane’s Priceless Heritage
text: MARYSVILLE, Calif. — Matthew and Tina Quy did not look quite ready to part with their vintage Stearman biplane as they showed it off here last weekend at an air show at Beale Air Force Base here: its two open cockpits, its repaired fuselage and the wings they rebuilt from scratch working weekends in their one-car garage.

headline: As Ethier Pursues DiMaggio, Rollins Believes Streak Can Be Broken
text: PHILADELPHIA – Jimmy Rollins will face Jason Marquis of the Washington Nationals on Wednesday, as he has many times before, most memorably on April 6, 2006. That was when Marquis held Rollins hitless three times to help stop the longest hitting streak of the last 24 years.

headline: Citigroup Hires UBS Banker
text: Kevin Cox, formerly head of Americas investment banking at UBS, is joining Citigroup as co-chairman of global industrials banking.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for May 5
text: A chat with Pamela Love; cat-eye sunglasses have been gathering steam with modified styles; Loomstate hosts a party-performance, and store openings, sales and events are scheduled in New York.

headline: Artware Editions Moves to the Bowery
text: After five years in the West Village, Artware Editions has moved to a 2,300-square-foot space on the Bowery — one large enough to display the range of products offered by the gallery, which specializes in functional designs by visual artists. “The space allows us to show pieces in the context of each other,” said Rebecca Kong, a founder of the company. “We can show the Klein table with a couch, so you can see it’s something you can live with.”

headline: Ottomans and Tray Tables Merged With Flowerpots
text: The Oasis collection from the Swedish furniture company Offecct offers a new way to add plant life to interiors, by merging furniture with flowerpots. “Plants and flowers enhance the quality of the air,” said David Lerdell, a spokesman for the company, but some people don’t like the look of ordinary plant containers. With Oasis, he said, you can have vegetation and “the feeling of the interior that you want.”

headline: The Look and Feel of Handmade Furniture
text: Those who have tired of the high-gloss, metal-heavy aesthetic that has dominated the kitchen and bath world in recent years might be interested in Bornholm Kitchen, a new company on Long Island that makes kitchen and bath pieces with a fine-furniture aesthetic.

headline: Five Gadgets for the Backyard
text: Several high-tech gadgets that promise to solve some horticultural hassles.

headline: Shopping for Toys With David Weeks
text: The lighting designer shopped for good-looking toys that would appeal to adults as well as children.

headline: Sales at Moroso, Housing Works and Elsewhere
text: The  Housing Works Design on a Dime event opens Thursday night with a preview party, with merchandise 50 to 70 percent off (a Bunny Williams turquoise lamp, originally $800, will be $350; a Jonathan Adler Lampert sofa, regularly $3,200, will be $1,600); tickets are $250 at the door, at (347) 473-7457 or at housingworks.org. Design on a Dime continues Friday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Sixth Avenue).

headline: At the MoMA Store, Designs From the Streets of Istanbul
text: Destination: Istanbul, the latest in a series of product collections developed in other countries for the Museum of Modern Art, has its debut next week at the museum’s stores in Midtown and SoHo (and is online now).

headline: In Brimfield, Mass., Running the Antiques Show That Dad Founded
text: From Tuesday to May 15, the town of Brimfield, Mass., population 3,600 or so, will swell to many times its size, straining to contain a flood of antiques dealers and the buyers who will rush the gates in search of treasure: a vintage shoe rack, a copper weather vane, a Staffordshire dog, an old postcard from Minnesota.

headline: How to Choose the Best Vines for Your Yard
text: MICHAEL DORF’S backyard vineyard started a decade ago with 10 grapevines, enough to make four cases of wine if everything went well.

headline: Sales of Home Safes Surge, Driven by the Recession and Recent Disasters
text: THE engineer in Danbury, Conn., is feeling more secure now that he has an 875-pound safe bolted to the floor of his den. The 52-year-old, who is a skeet shooter, wanted the 19.2-cubic-foot safe to lock up his seven shotguns, some of which are family heirlooms. But he also stores his wife’s jewelry in there, as well as a stash of emergency cash and a backup hard drive for his computer.

headline: Tools for the Wired Gardener
text: LAST spring my wife and I moved to the suburbs, and although there were many reasons for our relocation (a new job, an imminent baby), what we yearned for most was a backyard.

headline: A Wine to Call Our Own
text: AMONG the great wineries of the 20th century, my grandfather’s basement in the Bronx never got much respect. The best thing you could say about the red wine he made each fall was that there was a lot of it.

headline: Designer Toys
text: AS a designer of light fixtures that are sculptural and modern, David Weeks has long been a favorite of interior designers and architects. But when he recently began designing toys, many of his clients weren’t sure what to think.

headline: Jackie Cooper, Film and Television Actor, Dies at 88
text: Jackie Cooper, the pug-nosed kid who became America’s Boy in tear-jerker films of the Great Depression, then survived Hollywood’s notorious graveyard of child stardom and flourished as an adult in television and modern pictures, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: The Tupperware Party Moves to Social Media
text: LOOKED at a certain way, the venerable Tupperware party could be deemed an early form of social networking or word-of-mouth marketing. Now, the Tupperware parent is making a big bet on the contemporary, digital equivalents.

headline: A Return to Spending and the Front Rows
text: BUSINESS travelers are back, and the airlines are eager to court them again.

headline: Abbey’s Restoration Is First Stitch to Heal a Gash in Central Italy’s Landscape
text: CASTIGLIONE A CASAURIA, Italy — A little more than two years after an earthquake destroyed broad stretches of Italy’s central Abruzzo region, this normally low-buzz community of some 900 souls was a beehive of activity.

headline: A Bin Laden Hunter on Four Legs
text: The identities of all 80 members of the American commando team who thundered into Abbottabad, Pakistan, and killed Osama bin Laden are the subject of intense speculation, but perhaps none more so than the only member with four legs.

headline: Spirit of Tuskegee
text: A Stearman biplane, purchased on eBay in 2005, has been revealed to be one of the few surviving planes that were used to train the Tuskegee Airmen.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 4
text: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces made an artillery strike on the port area of Misurata, killing four people.

headline: Mets Look for an Answer for Thole’s Struggles
text: The Mets young catcher Josh Thole has had several bad games behind the plate recently, which warranted his being benched Wednesday night. But what seemed to bother Manager Terry Collins most was how Thole discussed his defensive play after Tuesday’s game.

headline: Stripped Down to a Bigger Sound
text: Mikel Jollett of the Airborne Toxic Event had just started a song at the Mercury Lounge on Tuesday night, unaccompanied except for those in the room singing along, when he stopped abruptly, as if distracted by something. “I forgot how small this place was,” he said, chuckling. (There was a colorful modifier in that sentence.) He paused, encouraging some rowdy cheers, and then it was on with the song, and the show.

headline: In Sweeping Action, G.M. Recalls 154,000 Chevrolet Cruze Models
text: General Motors is recalling all of its 2011 Chevrolet Cruze compact sedans to check for a steering problem as well as a condition in which an automatic transmission that appears to be in Park may still be in gear, increasing the chance of a roll-away accident.

headline: Seal Hits the Beach in Upper Manhattan
text: Update, 10:04 a.m. Thursday | The seal was still on the beach as of 10 a.m. Thursday, the city parks department said, and still appears healthy and normal. “We have some rangers out there monitoring it but nothing’s really changed,” a parks spokeswoman said.

headline: Gadgets to Ease Travails of Travel
text: IN many ways, travel has gotten worse: security concerns, overcapacity, rising rates — it is a now-familiar list of inconveniences and humiliations.

headline: Some Adventures in Scoring in Advance of the Cavendish
text: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which begins in Henderson, Nev., on Friday, features a two-tier system. The entry fee of $2,800 per pair is redistributed in session and overall prizes. There is also an auction, for which the minimum bid is $12,500. That money is returned to the buyers of the Top 10 pairs.

headline: Portable Technology for Travelers
text: Today’s travelers, for business or leisure, can carry far less electronic gear than they used to, thanks to combinations and innovations.

headline: In Arizona, Tea Party License Plate Draws Opposition From Its Honorees
text: SURPRISE, Ariz. — When conservative Republicans pushed a bill through the Arizona Legislature creating a “Don’t Tread on Me” license plate design that would be used to raise money for Tea Party groups in the state, opposition was expected from Democrats, liberals and other assorted antagonists.

headline: Unrest Around the Arab World Endangers Turkey’s Newfound Influence
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Turkey faces a growing challenge from the tumult sweeping the Arab world to its booming economic stake in the region, newfound political influence and longstanding policy of permitting no problems to fester along its borders.

headline: Mobile Booking Apps Are Only Just Starting to Deliver
text: IT’S happened to all of us: after a mad rush to the airport, you arrive to discover that your flight has been canceled. You run to the ticket counter to book a new one, only to wait alongside other travelers competing to get on the next plane out.

headline: At Sculpture Unveiling, Appeals for Artist’s Release
text: They rose from the majesty of one of New York’s great fountains: 12 bronze statues, each depicting an animal of the Chinese zodiac, staring fiercely at passers-by at the edge of Central Park. The mayor, the curator and artists from around the world were there for the exhibit’s opening on Wednesday. The creator was not.

headline: Tough Rule Eliminates Most Tarmac Strandings
text: WHEN they get together, business travelers complain about the hassles of air transportation, but one big issue has abruptly dropped off the gripe list.

headline: Lacking Blockbuster, News Corp. Falls Short
text: Not every fiscal quarter can have an “Avatar.”

headline: After Bin Laden: The Torture Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Importance of Class Size
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britain: 5 Freed Without Charges
text: The police have released five men who were arrested this week near the Sellafield nuclear processing facility in northwest England. They were freed without charges, the Greater Manchester Police said Wednesday. The men, all in their 20s and from London, were questioned by antiterrorism police officers before being released. Activities at the Sellafield facility include recycling fuel and processing nuclear waste.

headline: A Right to Counsel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Declining Scores on Advanced Placement Exams
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Land of Wild Horses, One Gentle Creature Stands Apart From the Herd
text: HERRIMAN, Utah — The horse in corral No. 2 was alone, eating alfalfa from a tractor tire turned trough, isolated from the wild horses clustered in a corral up the hill. She does not really have a name, said Tami Howell, a wrangler in boots and jeans standing by the fence. Or rather, Ms. Howell added, a few names were tried over the years but none stuck.

headline: For Many Carriers, Business Class Is the Premium Choice
text: TO the question, what does a person get when spending upward of $16,000 for a first-class international airline ticket, the answer is: more than ever. Private lounges with hot food and drink, spalike bathrooms and concierge services. Courteous guards to help passengers through a separate security checkpoint and a private car to whisk them to the plane.

headline: Best of the Best Are Back in the Final
text: The Champions League final at Wembley on May 28 will be a rematch of Rome two years ago, when Barcelona beat Manchester United, 2-0, with, of all things, a flying header from the diminutive Lionel Messi.

headline: Canada: Bishop Pleads Guilty in Child Pornography Case
text: A Roman Catholic bishop pleaded guilty in Ottawa on Wednesday to possession of child pornography for importation. Bishop Raymond Lahey, left, who once led the Diocese of Antigonish, Nova Scotia, was charged after customs agents examined his laptop computer as he returned to Canada from an overseas trip in 2009. They found 588 graphic images of children, 33 videos and the texts of stories featuring the enslavement of children. Customs officials estimated that some boys in the photographs were only 8 years old.

headline: Marian Mercer, Actress With Zany Streak, Is Dead at 75
text: Marian Mercer, a willowy actress with a comedic flair who won a Tony Award in 1969 for her performance in the hit musical “Promises, Promises,” died on April 27 in Newbury Park, Calif. She was 75 and lived in Agoura Hills, Calif.

headline: ‘The Voice’ Brings NBC a Ratings Surge
text: NBC’s new singing competition, “The Voice,” cemented its position as the breakout hit of the network television season Tuesday night by becoming the first new show on any network this season to post ratings growth in its second edition.

headline: Florida Struggles With Arizona’s Immigration Plan
text: MIAMI — With no debate, the Florida Senate on Wednesday approved a watered-down bill to curb illegal immigration, an issue that has divided Republicans in the state, pitting pro-business and Hispanic lawmakers against the party’s more populist wing.

headline: LeBron James’s Decision Is Looking Better
text: MIAMI

headline: Ground-Level Tastings of the Best Food in the Sky
text: AIRLINES are bringing their best food offerings to street level, with roving trucks and pop-up lounges that offer passers-by a taste of what’s being served in the air.

headline: Constructing a Story, With 2,982 Names
text: How do you find a name?

headline: Drop Jeter Down? Girardi Isn’t Even Thinking About It
text: DETROIT — It was a difficult conversation for Joe Girardi when he spoke over the winter with Jorge Posada about ceding his starting catching job to be the Yankees’ full-time designated hitter. Girardi said he had not even begun thinking about what would be an equally awkward discussion, informing Derek Jeter that he had been dropped in the lineup.

headline: Raise Taxes, but Not Tax Rates
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Audit Finds Long Waits for Breast Exams
text: Women have had to wait dangerously long times for mammograms at several of New York’s public hospitals, a city audit released on Wednesday found.

headline: Plan to Build Up Chelsea Market Has Some Up in Arms
text: Chelsea Market, the old Nabisco bakery complex that was transformed into a hip food arcade and office building in the 1990s, has served as a neighborhood anchor as the surrounding area turned from a faded industrial wasteland to a haven for galleries, fashion houses, technology firms and flashy apartment houses.

headline: A Manager Turns Misfortune Into a Lesson
text: WILMINGTON, Del.

headline: Q&A: Upgrading on the Up-and-Up
text: Q.

headline: Q. and A. With Director of ‘Thoroughbred’
text: “Thoroughbred,” produced and directed by the Academy Award winner Paul Wagner, sets out to capture the beauty of the breed and the passion of the people whose lives revolve around the majestic creatures. From the breeding shed, to the auction ring, to the winner’s circle at Churchill Downs, this film takes you along for the joyful and sometimes heartbreaking journey through the world of horse racing. Wagner shared his thoughts about making the film, which includes footage of the road to the 2009 Derby. “Thoroughbred” premieres in the New York area at 10 p.m. Wednesday on WNET/Thirteen and nationally on PBS on Thursday at 9 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Pakistani Army, Shaken by Raid, Faces New Scrutiny
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The reputation of the army, the most powerful and privileged force in Pakistan, has been severely undermined by the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, raising profound questions about its credibility from people at home and from benefactors abroad, including the United States.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Sugary Web Sites
text: On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Matt Richtel, a Times technology reporter, about proposed federal guidelines that could affect how food companies promote their products to children online. The children who visit the companies’ Web sites that feature games, quizzes and other entertainment often can’t distinguish the advertising component, Mr. Richtel says.

headline: Dodgers Say Selig Caused Shortfall
text: Frank McCourt, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ owner, appeared to move closer to a legal confrontation with Major League Baseball on Wednesday by sending two letters accusing Commissioner Bud Selig of causing the team’s financial distress by not approving a pending local television deal with Fox.

headline: Madoff Trustee Readies First Payout for Investors
text: The trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoff’s firm said on Wednesday that he would allocate $2.6 billion to a fund for investors who lost money in Mr. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme and pay an initial $272 million to those with approved claims.

headline: Beyond Flowers for Mom
text: HARGEISA, Somaliland

headline: ConAgra May Have to Go Hostile After Ralcorp Rejects Offer
text: ConAgra Foods’ proposal to buy Ralcorp Holdings for $4.9 billion may be called a bear hug, but the deal is far from warm and fuzzy.

headline: Navigating With Social Media
text: WHEN Mark Rosch and his wife, Carole Levitt, were traveling to Kansas City, Mo., on a recent trip for their legal education and research business, they did not want to miss an opportunity to dine across the state line at  Oklahoma Joe’s Barbecue in Kansas City, Kan. But after arriving by taxi at the award-winning restaurant, located in a former gas station in a residential area, they worried about finding a taxi to take them back to their hotel after dinner.

headline: Doctor, Patient and Politician
text: Let us stop for a minute to consider Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana.

headline: As Baghdad Violence Evolves, Officials Grapple With New Scourge: Assassinations
text: BAGHDAD — Under pressure to respond to a public unnerved by a wave of assassinations, one of the top security officials in Baghdad held an unusual news conference on Wednesday to play video confessions from three suspects from what he said was a cell of Al Qaeda.

headline: Using History to Mold Ideas on the Right
text: ALEDO, Tex. — In an unmarked office building in this ranching town, among thousands of Revolution-era documents and two muskets with bayonets, David Barton might seem like a quirky history buff. But the true ambition of this slender man in cowboy boots is to use America’s past to remake its future, and he has the ear of several would-be presidents.

headline: Derby Field Lacks Speed of Horses in the Past
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — They drew the field for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Wednesday, but it did little to clear up the intrigue over whether Uncle Mo, last year’s 2-year-old champion, will actually show up for the race Saturday. Nor did it solve the mystery of why this group of 3-year-old horses is so slow.

headline: The Torture Apologists
text: The killing of Osama bin Laden provoked a host of reactions from Americans: celebration, triumph, relief, closure and renewed grief. One reaction, however, was both cynical and disturbing: crowing by the apologists and practitioners of torture that Bin Laden’s death vindicated their immoral and illegal behavior after the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: Debt Ceiling Has Some Give, Until Roof Falls In
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government will not run short of money to pay its bills on May 16, when the federal debt reaches the legal maximum of $14.3 trillion.

headline: From Floor Plans to Décor, a Focus on Design
text: Avery Leigh Cox, 24, has been a junior designer for the past year at Amanda Nisbet Design and helped install the frisky bedroom the firm designed for the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, on display through May 26. Ms. Cox graduated with a B.F.A. in interior design from the Lamar Dodd School of Art at the University of Georgia and moved to New York from Dallas, her hometown, in 2009. She scraped along through a couple of unpaid internships before joining Nisbet and lives in Greenwich Village, where she customized her apartment by painting its brick fireplace hot pink.

headline: Connecticut’s Budget Is Done, but Governor’s Work Is Not
text: HARTFORD — Moving from Gorilla A to Gorilla B, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy on Wednesday signed into law a $40.1 billion budget that includes the largest tax increase in Connecticut history, then headed toward a Friday target for extracting $1 billion in annual wage and benefit concessions and program cuts from more than 45,000 state employees.

headline: 17-Year-Old Is Charged in Baby’s Death
text: A Brooklyn teenager was charged on Wednesday with the murder of a 9-month-old boy who had been left in his care, the police said.

headline: In Bin Laden’s Compound, Seals’ All-Star Team
text: WASHINGTON — There were 79 people on the assault team that killed Osama bin Laden, but in the end, the success of the mission turned on some two dozen men who landed inside the Qaeda leader’s compound, made their way to his bedroom and shot him at close range — all while knowing that the president of the United States was keeping watch from Washington.

headline: Tour Officials Labor to Make Golf Work
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — They wear starched white shirts and crisply knotted neckties, carry walkie-talkies and buzz their carts around tournaments with an air of authority. But golf’s version of umpires and referees is all but invisible.

headline: Jury Verdict for Hospital in Suicide Case Is Set Aside
text: A jury verdict that cleared a psychiatric hospital in Connecticut of liability in a patient’s suicide has been overturned by an appeals court that said the judge should have tried to determine if jurors were prejudiced by a newspaper article published just before the trial began.

headline: Lawmakers’ Challenge: A Plan to Lower the Deficit, and Make It Stick
text: WASHINGTON — As bipartisan negotiations were to begin over how to limit the spread of federal red ink, Senator Max Baucus, chairman of the Finance Committee, said Wednesday that he was open to imposing a “trigger” that would force spending cuts if the government exceeded prescribed deficit levels.

headline: Renren May Skew Facebook’s Value
text: Goldman Sachs got a steal of a deal on its Facebook stake. That’s if Renren is anything to go by. Shares in Renren, China’s answer to the social networking giant, surged more than 25 percent on their first day of trading on Wednesday. That meant it was valued at nearly 100 times last year’s revenue. On that basis, Facebook is worth about $200 billion. Goldman bought in at just a quarter of that. With some bubbly assumptions, the higher figure can almost be supported.

headline: Washing Away the Fields of Iowa
text: To an untrained eye, the fields of Iowa have a reassuring solidity. You cannot tell that the state has lost half its topsoil in the past century. According to a new report from the Environmental Working Group, Iowa’s soil is washing away at rates far higher than anyone realized.

headline: Goodbye to All That
text: My first New York apartment was a 9-by-5-foot room on 20th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It was an all-female boarding house, or S.R.O. (single room occupancy) as they were called before my time. The eight women on my floor all lived in cell-like rooms, and shared the two tiny bathrooms in the hallway, one with nothing but a toilet, the other with a moldy shower.

headline: A Chance to Rebuild SUNY
text: Even before the fiscal crisis, the New York State Legislature was doing a terrible job of managing the State University of New York System. Lawmakers who voted to cut financing to the 64-campus system also starved it by forbidding reasonable tuition increases and then hijacked tuition revenue for use in the general state budget. In recent years, administrators have had to cut class offerings, limit enrollment and rely far too much on part-time faculty.

headline: Claiming Fraud in A.I.G. Bailout, Whistle-Blower Lawsuit Names 3 Companies
text: The first known whistle-blower lawsuit to assert that the taxpayers were defrauded when the federal government bailed out the American International Group was unsealed on Friday, joining a number of suits seeking to settle the score on losses related to the financial crisis of 2008.

headline: At an Art Party, Baring All While Remaining Dressed
text: We saw relatively little of Marina Abramovic at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night because, unlike in some of her shows elsewhere, she wasn’t naked.

headline: Big Brother Goes to West Egg
text: Kings Point, N.Y., on Long Island’s gilded North Shore, wants to do criminal checks on every car that enters its placid realm. It has the technology — license-plate cameras hooked up to police computers — and is borrowing the money to install 44 of them. For about a million dollars, it will get what village trustees say is the snuggest security blanket money can buy.

headline: For Next Chief of Newark Schools, Hard Choices
text: As the new superintendent of the Newark schools, Cami Anderson faces the monumental task of rescuing an urban school system that has long been mired in low achievement, high turnover and a culture of failure, despite decades of state intervention.

headline: Recuse Me
text: However the courts eventually resolve the challenge to California’s ban on same-sex marriage, the record of the case will contain an ugly footnote: the last-ditch effort to retrospectively disqualify the federal judge who ruled that the ban is unconstitutional. It turns out that — horrors! — the judge, Vaughn R. Walker, is gay. Perhaps, his critics suggest, Judge Walker secretly intends to marry his partner of 10 years and has thus improperly placed himself in a position to reap personal benefit from his own ruling.

headline: Hotels Add Extras to Cushion Higher Prices
text: Suzanne Dissette won’t pad her expense account with minibar charges or in-room movie fees. She comparison-shops for airfares and drives to the airport, rather than take a taxi, to save money. She walks a line between spending what she needs to do her job and watching her outlays. That is why the free bottle of water at the Doubletree Hotel in Dana Point, Calif., felt like a gift — both personal and spontaneous.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Warner Music Nears a Sale to Access
text: 11:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Cottage, So Preppy, Pops Up for Hilfiger
text: The M11 bus rumbled through the rain on the cobblestone streets of the meatpacking district on Wednesday, splashing past a cottage with gray cedar shingles and blue-and-white-striped awnings plunked down incongruously onto what, only last week, was an empty public plaza.

headline: Mummified Body Found in Former Actress’s Home
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Yvette Vickers’s first appearance on a big screen was a fleeting part in “Sunset Boulevard,” the 1950 classic about a former Hollywood star turned recluse living in a crumbling mansion with her butler.

headline: Jackie Cooper’s Career
text: Jackie Cooper, a child star who flourished as an adult in television and modern pictures, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

headline: Thursday: City Known as the Big Guava
text: Administrivial NOTEPAD Alert!: There is a notepad in today’s Across Lite version of the puzzle that says: “Some of the black squares in this puzzle’s grid provide a hint to the four longest Down answers.” Now that you have the hint, proceed in an orderly fashion through the puzzle and upon finishing, please wait until this post has come to a full and complete stop to exit the blog.

headline: A Suspect’s Surrender, Eased by a Clergy Program to Curtail Black-on-Black Violence
text: The suspect, Trevin T. Smith, was waiting in the rain with his sister on a Brooklyn street corner on Wednesday morning. The clergyman, Bishop Gerald G. Seabrooks, pulled up alone, as agreed, in his brown four-door car. Then the three set out on a 15-minute ride to Rehoboth Cathedral to meet the police.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: A Brief Victory Lap Before Budget Fight Strains ‘Unity’ Call
text: WASHINGTON — On Monday night President Obama welcomed dozens of Congressional leaders to dinner at the White House and expressed hope that they “can harness some of the unity” forged by the death of Osama bin Laden “to confront the many challenges that we still face.” On Thursday comes the biggest test of that, and few see much prospect of a dawn of bipartisanship.

headline: Hurting Moderates, Helping Militants
text: THE rival Palestinian groups Hamas and Fatah officially agreed this week to reconcile and form a unity government. In response, Israel has decided to punish the Palestinian Authority by withholding two-thirds of its annual revenues. It’s a tactic Israel tried after Hamas won parliamentary elections in 2006 — and it will probably have as little success now as it did then.

headline: Bloggingheads: The Osama Stimulus?
text: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Karl Smith of the University of North Carolina debate whether Bin Laden's death could help the economy.

headline: CUNY Blocks Honor for Tony Kushner
text: In a rare move, the trustees of the City University of New York have voted to shelve an honorary degree that one of its campuses, John Jay College, planned to award to Tony Kushner, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of “Angels in America.” The vote on Monday evening came after a CUNY trustee said that Mr. Kushner had disparaged the State of Israel in past comments, a characterization that the writer attacked on Wednesday.

headline: Yankees’ Rocky Day Continues Into Night
text: DETROIT — A bumpy day Wednesday for the Yankees began with the disclosure that Phil Hughes would miss at least another six to eight weeks, and it continued with Manager Joe Girardi finding himself in an awkward situation, confronted with questions about Derek Jeter’s security atop the lineup.

headline: Suit Accuses U.S. Government of Failing to Protect Earth for Generations Unborn
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Advocates of stringent curbs on greenhouse gas emissions sued the federal government on Wednesday, arguing that key agencies had failed in their duty to protect the earth’s atmosphere as a public trust to be guarded for future generations.

headline: The Amenity Travelers Want Most: Power for Their Gadgets
text: In the lavish days before the recession, there was an amenities arms race in the hospitality industry, as hotel chains replaced dated bedspreads with down comforters and duvet covers, mounted flat-screen TVs in all their rooms and competed to offer fancy toiletries and must-have accessories like iPod docking stations.

headline: As Goaltending Falters, Flyers Find Themselves in a Familiar Hole
text: BOSTON — The Flyers’ playoff goaltending has been a mess.

headline: Lincecum Is Latest to Baffle the Mets
text: The cumulative frustration of facing three of baseball’s elite pitches in four games was expressed in the tense, clipped words of Manager Terry Collins after the final game in the sequence. After seeing the Mets split their games against the Phillies’ Roy Halladay and Cliff Lee last weekend, Collins watched helplessly as the Giants’ Tim Lincecum, a two-time Cy Young Award winner, put the finishing touches on the challenging progression.

headline: Calisthenics Come Back as the Anywhere Workout
text: Pierre Rougier, a publicist in Manhattan, is known as one of the fashion’s industry’s most powerful behind-the-scenes players.

headline: A Workout to Go
text: Rob Morea, an owner at Great Jones Fitness in Manhattan, demonstrates exercises that can be done in a hotel room.

headline: Knicks Castoff, and Now He’s Guarding Bryant
text: LOS ANGELES — The Boston Celtics quickly excused the Knicks from the playoffs. But some of Knicks’ recent alumni have moved into the second round.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,554 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: A Potential Candidate in No Rush for a Race
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana called the leisurely pace of the 2012 presidential campaign “a blessing” for voters. Whether he plans to take advantage of it is another question, which he did not answer as he paid a visit here Wednesday.

headline: Illinois: State Leaves Immigration Program
text: Gov. Pat Quinn has withdrawn the state from a federal program that runs immigration checks on fingerprints of everyone arrested by the state and local police. In a letter to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Mr. Quinn, a Democrat, said he was canceling Illinois’ participation in the program, known as Secure Communities, because of “a conflict” between its stated purpose and its results. Although officials had said the program would deport immigrants who were convicted criminals, Mr. Quinn wrote, fewer than 20 percent of immigrants deported under the program had serious convictions.

headline: Vlaminck and Monet Tie for Top Sale at Christie’s
text: An early sighting of Leonardo DiCaprio trying to hide under a navy-blue baseball cap and sitting next to his actor pal Lukas Haas added a bit of Hollywood flavor to a generally lively sale of Impressionist and modern art at Christie’s on Wednesday night. Although neither man could be seen raising his hand, others certainly did, though in a controlled, price-conscious fashion. Blue-chip names including Monet, Matisse and Picasso brought solid prices — even if the works were far from their best — a day after auction season got off to a bumpy start at Sotheby’s.

headline: House Votes to Limit Access to Abortion
text: House Republicans continued Wednesday with their efforts to dismantle the health care law. On a 251-to-175 vote, the House approved a bill prohibiting federal money to be used for insurance plans that cover abortions. The bill goes beyond current federal law, which prohibits the use of federal funds for abortions. It would also wipe out tax breaks for private employers who provide coverage if their plans offer abortion services and would eliminate the ability to pay for an abortion with pretax dollars from a flexible spending plan. Voting 235 to 191, the House blocked money for construction of school-based health centers that had been earmarked in the health care act.

headline: Shaping Human Path to 15, or 6, Billion by 2100
text: Following up on the latest United Nations projections for population growth through 2100, Room for Debate, drawing on some familiar Dot Earth voices, has elicited five fascinating takes on alternative human futures:

headline: When the Fur Doesn’t Fly
text: Spacious rooms, plush bedding, spa treatments, a large swimming pool and a lively social scene. It sounds like a dream vacation. But these amenities are not for humans; they are for pets left behind when their owners take plane trips.

headline: Resort Living for Pets
text: While their owners are out of town, some pets live the good life at boarding facilities that are more spa than kennel. And they’re convenient to the airport.

headline: How to Beat High Airfares
text: Air travel remains a necessity, even as it gets ever more expensive. First, the cost of flights, which fell throughout most of the 2000s relative to inflation, is climbing once again thanks to higher fuel prices. And then there are the added fees for everything from checked baggage to those vile croissanwiches.

headline: Jerry Brown, the Contender
text: California and Brown have changed in the 28 years since he left the governor’s office, and now they are relearning each other.

headline: Jerry Brown’s Last Stand
text: The 39th, and 34th, governor of California was making his first trip to Los Angeles since being sworn in, for an evening speech in February to the city’s Chamber of Commerce, and a swarm of reporters was waiting at Terminal A of the Bob Hope Airport in Burbank. Edmund G. Brown Jr. — he has always preferred Jerry — arrived from Sacramento not on a state aircraft (and certainly not a private jet, as was the preference of his predecessor, Arnold Schwarzenegger) but aboard Flight 896 on Southwest Airlines. As Brown walked off the plane and into the terminal, he was essentially alone, save for a few police guards who hung off to the side. There were no press aides, no advance staff, no speechwriters, no policy mavens; in short, nothing like the bustling entourage of self-importance that typically buffers a chief executive.

headline: Sports Replay: May 4
text: A look back at the day in sports, from the Champions League to hockey fights and sweeps.

headline: Creator of Google Voice Starts a Company Starter
text: The creator of Google Voice left Google last fall to work on a new start-up, and now he’s ready to talk about what he’s doing.

headline: Americans Abroad: Should These 5 Guys Come Home to M.L.S?
text: The early returns are in on the transfer of Benny Feilhaber from AGF Aarhus to Major League Soccer’s New England Revolution: It was a shrewd move.

headline: Bank of America to Triple Number of Mortgage Help Centers
text: Bank of America plans to triple the number of local centers across the country that provide assistance to mortgage customers facing foreclosure, lifting the total to 40 from 12 by early summer.

headline: A Better Medical School Admissions Test
text: Recently the college-age daughter of a friend talked to me about her dream of becoming a doctor. She was doing well as a psychology major and in her pre-medical courses, was working as a research assistant for a pediatrician at a nearby medical school and volunteered on the cancer ward at a children’s hospital.

headline: Obama Honors Victims of Bin Laden at Ground Zero
text: President Obama laid a wreath of red, white and blue flowers at ground zero on Thursday, honoring the nearly 3,000 people killed in the September 2001 terrorist attacks and marking the death of the perpetrator, Osama bin Laden.

headline: Word of the Day | parlance
text: parlance •\ˈpär-lən(t)s\• noun

headline: News Quiz | May 5, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Mavericks Prevail and Send Lakers Into Panic Mode
text: LOS ANGELES — The Lakers celebrated last June on the Staples Center court in gold glitter when Kobe Bryant persevered, Pau Gasol dominated and Ron Artest chipped in. They had outlasted the Boston Celtics and cemented another championship.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 5, 2011
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “A Faltering Ruble, Long Lines and a Bomb Attack Rattle Belarus.”

headline: Topping the Tonys
text: WHAT is “The Book of Mormon”?WHAT is the record for most Tony Award nominations?WHAT are the best live theatrical performances you’ve ever seen?

headline: Qaeda Affiliate Is Blamed in Iraq Suicide Bombing
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber attacked a police training center on Thursday in the predominantly Shiite city of Hilla, south of Baghdad, killing 25 people and wounding at least 75 in the second major bombing in Iraq this week.

headline: Accord Brings New Sense of Urgency to Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
text: CAIRO — A day after Palestinian leaders signed what many called a landmark reconciliation accord, the antagonists in the protracted Israeli-Palestinian conflict and their international mediators in Europe staked out positions in a rapidly shifting political and diplomatic landscape on Thursday.

headline: The Inner Lives of Wartime Photographers
text: This has been a grievous season for the tight-knit tribe of combat photographers. For The Times, the sorrow began last October, when a land mine exploded under Joao Silva while he was shooting pictures of an American patrol near Kandahar, Afghanistan, destroying both of his legs and shredding his intestinal tract. This spring, three other photographers working for The Times — Jehad Nga, Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario — were among the numerous journalists who disappeared into the custody of Libyan state thugs, where they were beaten and terrorized before we could negotiate their release. The darkness deepened by several hues last month when two admired lensmen — Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros — were killed while embedded with Libya’s hapless rebel militia.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Ichthyophagist
text: Today’s word, in association with the dependable Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Is There Too Much Federal Debt?
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Should Obama Have Released the Photos of Bin Laden’s Body?
text: After intense debate within his administration, the president has decided not to release photographs taken of Osama bin Laden after he was killed by the United States military. Do you agree or disagree with that decision, and why?

headline: Workers Enter Japan’s Crippled Reactor Building
text: TOKYO — Workers entered a damaged reactor building at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Thursday for the first time since explosions crippled the Japanese power plant two months ago.

headline: In London, a Slice of Downtown New York, Circa 1970s
text: The Barbican Art Gallery is offering a glimpse of life in downtown Manhattan in the early 1970s — at least through the eyes of a particular group of artists. The “Pioneers of the Downtown Scene, New York 1970s” exhibition, at the gallery through May 22 (Barbican Centre, Silk Street; 44-207-638-4141; www.barbican.org.uk/artgallery/), features sculptures, drawings, photographs, documentation of performances, and mixed-media works.

headline: The Early Word: No Bin Laden Photos, but Thousands of Words
text: In Today’s Times:— In deciding not to release photographs of Osama bin Laden’s corpse, President Obama concluded that the images could incite violence against Americans and would do little to persuade skeptics that Al Qaeda’s founder had been killed in the raid on his Pakistan compound, Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti write. There is still a risk that a photo will be leaked, they say, noting that fakes are already circulating on the Internet. Today, Mr. Obama is scheduled to take part in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Sept. 11 memorial in lower Manhattan before meeting with relatives of the victims. On Friday, he will travel to Fort Campbell, Ky., to speak to troops returning from combat duty in Afghanistan.

headline: 2010 St. Louis Rams: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the N.F.C. West:

headline: Islamism on Campus
text: Recent student council elections at Jordan University in Amman included Muhammad Fawaz, an Islamist candidate.

headline: As Lloyds, BBVA and Société Générale Slip, ING Surprises
text: Three of the four major European banks that reported first-quarter earnings on Thursday performed weaker than had been expected as a result of recent market turmoil and the slow economic recovery in countries including Britain and Spain.

headline: The Mystery of the Delicious-Looking Rectangles
text: Mark Bittman’s recent column, “Steamed, Roasted, Stir-Fried, Grilled,” details 12 delicious ways to serve asparagus. The accompanying photo also promises something tasty — though the exact nature of the mystery dish was a subject of much interest among our online commenters.

headline: Pakistani Army Chief Warns U.S. on Another Raid
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The head of Pakistan’s army, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, said Thursday that he would not tolerate a repeat of the American covert operation that killed Osama bin Laden, warning that any similar action would lead to a reconsideration of the relationship with the United States.

headline: Syria Arrests Scores in House-to-House Roundup
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces raided a restive Damascus suburb on Thursday, going house to house and arresting scores of men in a broad campaign that activists and American officials say represents a new chapter in the crackdown on the country’s uprising against four decades of authoritarian rule.

headline: In General, Don’t Generalize About Breeding
text: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of “Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery” and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.

headline: 100 Restaurant Rules Reconsidered
text: Southfork Kitchen has been open for almost six months. Sussing out a summer season that looms large, I thought it might be instructive to a look at my 100 rules to see which ones were pie-in-the-sky and which ones still hold water, which ones were idealistic foam and which ones have stood up to the reality of Saturday nights.

headline: PowerReviews Raises Money for E-Commerce Reviews
text: PowerReviews, a company that helps e-commerce sites show product reviews written by other customers, has raised $10 million in venture capital.

headline: Bird Week | A Species Settles In. Notice the Long Lenses.
text: Along a path in Central Park’s Ramble woods, two photographers had set up next to each other, with their heavy tripods supporting elaborate cameras partly concealed by leafy camouflage material.

headline: European Central Banks Stand Pat on Rates
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged Thursday, and signaled that it would probably wait until July before it made another move.

headline: Obama Blocks Release of Graphic Photos for Second Time
text: Twice since assuming office, President Obama has been confronted with the question of whether to release grisly photographs depicting the results of American actions overseas.

headline: Linda Ronstadt, First Lady of California
text: In this weekend’s magazine, the New York Times reporter Adam Nagourney writes about Gov. Jerry Brown as he wrestles with California’s budget. Linda Ronstadt makes a cameo appearance as Brown’s former girlfriend. But for me, Ronstadt is always the main event. Seeing her perform in her Cub Scouts uniform at Pine Knob outside Detroit in the late 1970s (or early ’80s; it’s a bit hazy) was a formative experience. With a few not-inconceivable twists of fate, it’s possible (at least to me) to imagine Brown as president and Ronstadt as first lady. That this didn’t happen might have marked the moment when things started to go wrong. Or maybe that was when Johnny Carson retired. Anyway, this clip of “My Boyfriend’s Back” (date uncertain but probably filmed sometime during the campaign for the 1980 Democratic nomination) gives a hint of what we missed.

headline: Gap Dismisses Design Chief as Brand’s Slow Sales Persist
text: Gap announced on Thursday that it had dismissed its star designer, Patrick Robinson, in an acknowledgement that its problems run deeper than the company had previously indicated.

headline: G.M. Reports Earnings Tripled in First Quarter, as Revenue Jumped 15%
text: DETROIT — It wasn’t long ago that a first-quarter profit of $3.2 billion would have been cause for a major celebration at General Motors.

headline: Morning Buzz | Help in Finding One Name in 2,982

headline: This Germ of an Idea Calls for an Antibiotic
text: THE preview at MoMA calculated to ignite euphoric Oscar buzz over the studio’s new $60 million comedy ended and the lights came up, revealing an audience of 400, stiff, with eyes shut, bringing to mind what it must have been like when outsiders first stumbled upon Jonestown. As the local opinion makers revived and shuffled through the exits, I bumped into Philo Cubbage, a schmendrick I knew from the periphery of show business who surfaced intermittently over the years with some fresh scheme for achieving bankruptcy. After the customary exchange of insincere remarks about how neither of us had aged, we agreed to masticate a pair of sirloins and repaired to Upchuck’s, where we could dine and disembowel the film we’d seen at leisure.

headline: Notes From the Underground | Cansei de Ser Sexy
text: The Brazilian pop band Cansei de Ser Sexy (CSS) kicked off its current American tour with a star turn at Coachella, then stepped off the stage and went straight to Pomona, Calif., and an all-ages show at the Glass House the following night. Fans mobbed the barricades to get a closer look at the lead singer, Lovefoxxx (pictured here). Dressed in a sequined bolero ensemble and Doc Martens boots, she turned cartwheels and surfed the crowd. The audience read like a throng of exultant misfits, gathered to hail their beloved leaders. Lovefoxxx gave a shout-out to someone watching that night, who had written the band an e-mail explaining how they had inspired him to come out and be honest about who he was with his family and friends, and later she brought several teenage girls to the stage to dance alongside her. CSS will perform three nights in New York City in May.

headline: Asked & Answered | Flavin Judd
text: When Donald Judd died in 1994, he had a couple thousand dollars in the bank but was millions of dollars in debt. The task of sorting out his estate was left to his two children, Rainer and Flavin, who persevered against what many considered insurmountable odds, resulting in the creation of the now seemingly solid Judd Foundation. Judd’s daughter, Rainer, is the president of the board of the foundation and the more public of the two while his son, Flavin, is vice president (but referred to himself as the “curatorial consultant”). Despite being very involved in the day-to-day running of the foundation, he remains relatively out of the public eye. T recently caught up with Flavin Judd, who was in town to oversee the installation of a major exhibit of his father’s work at David Zwirner gallery. “Donald Judd,” which opens on Friday, features nine aluminum boxes originally shown in a 1989 exhibition at Staatliche Kunsthalle Baden-Baden. It is the first time since that such a large number pieces from that show have been installed in one place.

headline: Have Golden Locks, Seeking Hammer
text: As I stumbled out of the Imax multiplex all-media advance screening of “Thor,” depositing my 3-D glasses in the appropriate bin, I thought of seeking shelter: in a nearby bar; under a passing bus; in the velvet shadows of an art house playing the longest, slowest, most obscure movie imaginable. But when something like “Thor” comes to town, there is really no refuge to be found in drink, death or subtitles, and so I tried to reason myself out of the leaden gloom that lay upon my soul as heavy as Mjolnir. (That’s Thor’s magic hammer, for those not versed in Marvelized Norse mythology.)

headline: Another Capitals Exit
text: Even if you are not a Washington Capitals fan, please feel free to boo them. It may seem unfair — and a little weird if you’re nowhere near Washington and, say, in a business meeting — but go ahead anyway. The Capitals are more than a No. 1 seed bounced from the Stanley Cup playoffs in a gruesome second-round sweep, they are a four-year story of promise gone haywire. They boast a handful of the game’s most exhilarating players — Alex Ovechkin, Alexander Semin, Nicklas Backstrom and Mike Green — who treat the big stage of the playoffs like children being forced to eat overcooked cabbage.

headline: Cuisine Art | Subodh Gupta at Hauser & Wirth
text: Every morning, the the gallery staff at Hauser & Wirth on the Upper East Side must top off a glass of water that sits on a bare wooden table under a glass display box. “A Glass of Water,” as the work is appropriately titled, is by the artist Subodh Gupta, whose show, by the same name, opens today. “If guests drinks a glass of water offered at another person’s home, it means they’ve taken the reception,” said Gupta, explaining its significance in his native India. And yet, there is something inhospitable here. The found stainless steel vessel is filled to that delicate point where the liquid threatens to spill over on to the table. Gupta — who has been called the Damien Hirst of India — is thrilled by its dynamics: the beauty in that delicate curvature of the water and the precipice of something almost, but not quite, being pushed over the edge.

headline: Thinking Through Assassination

Before the practice becomes a bad habit, we might want to heed the counsel of the past.

headline: Why She Went
text: Janny Scott’s article (“The Young Mother Abroad”) about Ann Dunham resonated with me as an American parent who years ago took a small child to live in Southeast Asia. It resonated even more with me as a high-school principal. I have observed that parents who teach their children compassion often forget to teach them resilience, and those who teach their children to “stop being wimpy” often do so with an admonition that the world is a mean place in which they will have to be tough to compete. Ann Dunham’s insistence on both idealism and strength is a model for creating useful adults and perhaps even presidents.EMILY H. JONESPutney, Vt., e-mail

headline: “Thelma and Louise” vs. “Pretty Woman”
text: Where do these two movies, the subject of Carina Chocano’s Riff column, put men? Either our value is reduced to how much is in our bank accounts, so that we can buy love and a beautiful woman, or we are threatened by a woman who thinks for herself and has her own opinions and desires. What about a guy that doesn’t make a lot of money and loves strong, independent women and is loved back? Where is our cultural trope?

headline: It’s All About My Mother
text: Whenever I see my mother (which I do as little as possible), we fall into a terrible rut. She asks me a question. I get out a few words of reply. Then she interrupts me and starts talking about herself. This makes me feel much worse than you would think. I haven’t brought it up with her because she doesn’t take criticism well, and I don’t feel like defending myself. I know I should see her on Mother’s Day, but I really don’t want to. Any advice?

headline: The Pastries and Aromas of Greece
text: IT all started with a sweet, cinnamon-tinted whiff. The subway roaring above, I crossed the street and followed my curiosity to the Greek bakery tucked in the corner of a shopping complex in Astoria, Queens. That afternoon, the first of my many visits to Artopolis Bakery, on 31st Street and 23rd Avenue, there were bohemians, families pushing strollers, and old men in black suits lined up against the counter or crowded at the few wrought-iron tables, dunking cookies in the darkest coffee I’d ever seen.

headline: Body in Jet Wreckage Is Retrieved From Sea Bottom
text: PARIS — An underwater salvage team on Thursday began the grisly task of recovering the remains of the victims of an Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic two years ago, retrieving the first of possibly dozens of bodies from the wreckage as experts gather evidence that they hope will shed more light on what happened in the flight’s final moments.

headline: Now Recalling | ‘Imagined Nostalgia’
text: “I wanted to create objects from a childhood that I never experienced firsthand,” Lucien Smith says, explaining the background of “Imagined Nostalgia,” which opens May 6 at 41 Cooper Gallery. The show is a collaboration between Smith, 22, and Jack Siegel, 24, who shared studio space at Cooper Union (where Smith is enrolled and set to graduate this month). The work is based on how our imaginations create false memories of what actually happened in the past — how we remember something from the past and embellish it to make it seem worse or better, larger than life, different. Highlights include yearbook-style photographs from familiar New York faces like the filmmaker Austin Peters and the artist Brenden Lynch.

headline: Just After ‘Spider-Man’ Reopens, Taymor To Deliver Theater Conference Keynote

Ms. Taymor will also speak that Saturday at a panel session, titled “A Director’s Life,” during the annual conference of Theater Communications Group, a national organization of nearly 700 nonprofit theaters and affiliated groups.

headline: Commission Asks Congress to Support a Smithsonian American Latino Museum
text: A presidential commission called on Congress to establish a Smithsonian American Latino Museum at the Capitol on Thursday morning during a news conference attended by proponents of the project. In a report submitted this week to President Obama and Congress, the commission said that it would cost $600 million to build and open the museum, adding that half of the money could be raised privately. In deference to current budget conditions, the commission said that no federal financing would be needed for six years. Congress established the panel, the National Museum of the American Latino Commission, in 2008.

headline: Global Warming Reduces Expected Yields of Harvests in Some Countries, Study Says
text: Global warming is already cutting substantially into potential crop yields in some countries — to such an extent that it may be a factor in the food price increases that have caused worldwide stress in recent years, researchers suggest in a new study.

headline: Bill Clinton Urges Albany to Legalize Gay Marriage

headline: House Passes a Bill to Expand Offshore Oil Drilling

headline: 36 Hours in Detroit
text: DESPITE recent news stories of a population exodus from Detroit, there are many reasons to make a pilgrimage to this struggling city right now — and not just because Eminem’s slick Super Bowl commercial showcased the inner strength of the Motor City. No video can portray the passion one finds on the streets of Detroit these days, where everyone from the doorman to the D.J. will tell you they believe in this city’s future. While certain areas are indeed eerily empty, other neighborhoods — including midtown, downtown and Corktown — are bustling with new businesses that range from creperies and barbecue joints catering to the young artists and entrepreneurs migrating to Motown, to a just-opened hostel that invites tourists to explore Detroit with the aid of local volunteer guides. In the historic Brush Park district, architecture buffs will find some lovely refurbished houses, and along Woodward Avenue, restored film palaces are a wonderful reminder that this city’s storied past includes not just automobiles, but also the entertainment industry. No urban enthusiast will want to miss the recovery that Detroit is now attempting.

headline: McQueen Almost as Good as Van Gogh
text: The Alexander McQueen retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art set an attendance record for the opening day of a Costume Institute exhibition — and nearly for the entire museum. The show had 5,100 visitors on Wednesday, beating out popular shows like the Jacqueline Kennedy and Chanel exhibitions, though time will tell if the numbers hold up for the duration of the show. The crowd was so large that the Met had to temporarily suspend its guided tours, a spokeswoman said. The museum sold 600 catalogs that day in its gift shop.

headline: Considering a Tornado Shelter
text: The deadly tornadoes that struck the South last month were historic in their intensity and destruction. In their wake,  makers of storm shelters say, they have been receiving a lot of requests for information from homeowners in tornado-prone areas.

text: Midcentury-modern beach houses, their jaunty, angled forms clad in weathered cedar siding, have faced tear-down threats for two decades now. The archives of their architects, however, are sometimes enjoying better fates.

headline: Leave It to the Beaver to Do All the Talking
text: “The Beaver,” a dysfunctional-family melodrama about depression, and the ties that bind and throttle, and the tears that trickle but dry in the warm glow of said family, has a card up (or actually on) its sleeve, and it isn’t entirely Mel Gibson. Directed by Jodie Foster, who has unwisely given herself a supporting role as a weepy little woman, the film involves a depressed toy manufacturer, Walter Black (Mr. Gibson), who, after failing to commit suicide, begins communicating through a hand puppet. Nasty, brutish and as cuddly as a crusty old sock fished out of a sewer, the beaver or the beav, as I like to think of him, owns the film.
