Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. brought to mind another quote mistakenly attributed to another civil rights leader, Nelson Mandela.

headline: TimesCast | May 6, 2011
text: May 6, 2011 - Protests across Syria on Friday, as the government's crackdown continues; remembering the 1982 massacre in Hama, Syria; and the op-ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman.

headline: Actors Take Lead Roles in New Video Game
text: L.A. Noire forgoes typical animation, instead using video of real actors — some 400 of them.

headline: Who Makes Our Magazine?
text: The New York Times daily newspaper is printed at multiple locations across the globe to ensure timely delivery. The entire run of The New York Times Magazine, however, is printed every week at RR Donnelly, a press in Lancaster, Pa. They have been printing our magazine for almost 30 years. We here in New York deliver the last of the files every Friday to them, and they print over 1.5 million copies of the publication for delivery nine days later.

headline: Video Game to Play in Vintage Gumshoes
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: How to Photograph the Cover
text: For this week’s article on the crash of Air France Flight 447, we considered several photographic treatments for the cover. First we considered having a photographer charter a plane and fly over the recovery ship, the Alucia, while it was still near the spot where its crew located the plane in early April.  We decided that option was too costly, so next we tried to take a satellite picture of the Alucia.  But on the chosen day, a combination of vague coordinates — French authorities refused to provide the precise location of the ship — and cloud cover prevented us from getting any usable image.

headline: Bakeries Spring Up in the Twin Cities
text: ON a recent Saturday morning there was a line out the door at Patisserie 46 in Minneapolis’s emerging Kingfield neighborhood, as folks waited to get their daily baked goods. The bakery (4552 Grand Avenue South; 612-354-3257; patisserie46.com) hasn’t yet been open a year and already has achieved cultlike status for its French-style offerings: the croissants are crisp and light as air, the macarons evaporate in the mouth.

headline: A New Way to See Sicily
text: ON a thick summer afternoon in the Sicilian town of Corleone, beneath palm trees in the small central piazza, the old men in their rimmed caps watched us. They rolled their eyes over our touristy selves (cameras and sunhats), and my husband and I scarfed our gelato a little faster.

headline: Restaurant Report: 41° in Barcelona
text: Technically, the buzzy new dining spot 41° in Barcelona, Spain, isn’t a restaurant — it’s a cocktail bar with snacks. But when the surname of the two lead proprietors is Adrià — as in Ferran and Albert, of the famed three-Michelin-starred restaurant El Bulli — such distinctions take a back seat.

headline: Hotel Review: Chicago JW Marriott
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Off the Roman Coast, Bobbing for Views
text: ARRIVING by ferry or hydrofoil at Ponza, an island in the Tyrrhenian Sea, the boat trims the island’s eastern coast, a vista of sheer tuff cliffs bleached white by the sun and eroded by water and wind.

headline: Atlanta Serves Sophisticated Southern
text: WHEN I moved to Atlanta from New York late last year, I made a few rookie food mistakes. I would corner the dry cleaner, the preschool teacher, every food friend I knew. “So where can I find great barbecue?” I asked.

headline: Lost in Java
text: IN 15 years of traveling to Asia, I have seen and done a number of strange things. I have eaten writhing octopus tentacles in Seoul, and I’ve been shepherded into a Phnom Penh nightclub by a Cambodian dwarf in a tuxedo. At this point, little surprises me. But when I arrived in the city of Malang, in the cool hills of inland East Java, I discovered something I never imagined existed.

headline: Letters: Charge It, Please?
text: To the Editor: The article “Picking the Best Credit Card” (April 24) was helpful but did not address the common problem that credit cards issued in the United States have a magnetic strip, not the chip found in European cards. This is an inconvenience, as United States cards are rejected at some kiosks all over Europe, and even for some counter purchases.

headline: Letters: Florida, Here We Come
text: To the Editor: Re “A Post-Spring Break Jaunt to Florida’s Beaches” (April 19): The area around Jacksonville is great. You can camp at Kathryn Abbey Hanna Park. Jax Beach, Neptune Beach and Atlantic Beach are great to visit. Just south of town, on your way to St. Augustine on Route A1A, is Mickler’s Landing and Beach. It’s a great beach, with lots of friendly locals, surfers and families, plus lots of free parking. My favorite place is Cocoa Beach. It’s a relatively small town, with small-town prices. The beach is great, and there’s an even better one south of town at Patrick Air Force Base (lots of free parking). The stretch from Jacksonville to Cocoa Beach is a great part of Florida. You’re guaranteed to enjoy your time there.

headline: A Twist on the B&B in Wales
text: THERE are a few constants on the Pen-y-Wyrlod farm in southeast Wales: the sheep, the rain, the mud, the Black Mountains. And at the top of a small hill, beyond an unmarked gate, across from a medieval church, a Gypsy caravan barely large enough to hold a bed, a wood-burning stove and a paying guest — me.

headline: Offbeat Bargains in Berlin
text: Known primarily for its dreadlocked denizens and enormous warehouse nightclubs, Berlin’s Friedrichshain district has lately developed a reputation as a retail destination.

headline: A Roman Holiday

headline: Demography and Jobs (Wonkish)
text: Catherine Rampell raises the question of how many jobs we need to keep up with population growth, given the aging of the population. I’d been thinking about it a different way. We know that the employment-population ratio has been flat since late 2009; would things look better if we looked at the employment ratio for prime-age workers?

headline: The Morning Line: Scratching of Uncle Mo Is No Surprise
text: The Uncle Mo melodrama has ended for the Derby with the decision this morning that Mo is a no-go. “Owner Mike Repole told reporters the colt hasn’t recovered well enough from his stomach ailment to handle the 1 1/4-mile distance,” according to USA Today. Jay Privman for the Daily Racing Form said that the news was expected,  and Joe Drape  similarly found that the scratch was not surprising since  Uncle Mo “has not looked like himself in the morning here and his owner, Mike Repole, has said all week that it was a 50-50 chance that Uncle Mo would run in America’s greatest race.”

text: AT the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year, I wheedled a ticket to “Becoming Chaz,” a documentary about the sex change of Chastity Bono. Having long admired the Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato World of Wonder productions — slyly edu-taining films like “The Eyes of Tammy Faye” and oodles of just-louche-enough-for-reality-TV shows like “RuPaul’s Drag Race” — I anticipated their usual mix of human interest, alternative lifestyle and salacious tabloid.

headline: ‘Stylelikeu’ | Mother and Daughter Sartorialists
text: Target is offering matching dresses for moms and babies from its new Calypso collaboration. Lucky magazine recently introduced a back-page feature called “My Mom, the Style Icon.” But for most of us, there was a period, in between teetering in Mom’s high heels and aching to steal her vintage blouses, during which we’d balk at anything — anything — she liked. Not so for Lily Mandelbaum, a student at N.Y.U. who has collaborated with her mother, the fashion editor and stylist Elisa Goodkind, on the style blog Stylelikeu since 2008. The popular site features closet tours, style mantras and video interviews with their fashion muses, both known (the fashion designer LaQuan Smith) and unknown (Virginie Sommet, who makes art out of Indian candy and fennel). Now, just in time for Mother’s Day, they’ve released a book of the same name, full of beautiful images of sartorial inspiration, including collages of hands garnished with jaw-dropping gems, club kids posing in their bedrooms and little old ladies who refuse to hang up the toreador pants. As Tziporah Salamon, one such senior, happily explained: “Every single day you get a chance to invent yourself. How fun is that?” Happy Mother’s Day!

headline: Suburbia: What a Concept
text: There is no more iconic suburb than Levittown, the postwar planned community built by the developer William Levitt in the late 1940s, so it is understandable that in launching Open House, a collaborative project to imagine a “future suburbia,” the Dutch design collective Droog in collaboration with Diller Scofidio + Renfro architects would make it the focus of their inquiry.

In recent programs he has focused on chamber music, performing a concert with the Tetzlaff Quartet (of which he is first violinist) and a duo recital with the violinist Antje Weithaas.

headline: Older Workers Without Jobs Face Longest Time Out of Work
text: After reaching record highs month after month, the typical length of time a jobless worker in the United States has been unemployed finally fell in April, to “only” 38.3 weeks. But the outlook is looking bleaker for the nation’s older workers.

headline: A Celebration With a Clock Ticking
text: On May 5, 1891, Carnegie Hall was inaugurated with a gala concert at which Tchaikovsky was the distinguished guest. On Thursday night Carnegie Hall celebrated its 120th anniversary with a gala program performed by the New York Philharmonic, with Alan Gilbert conducting, and a roster of starry solo artists. Television cameras recorded the concert for broadcast in PBS’s “Great Performances” series, and many in the audience were formally dressed and ready to party.

headline: Levine Withdraws From Met Tour and Tanglewood

The casualties include a long-awaited Metropolitan Opera tour to Japan and the Tanglewood Festival season.

headline: Drone Strike in Yemen Was Aimed at Awlaki

text: The rate of prescription pain medication misuse by New York City residents who are 12 or older has increased by 40 percent from 2002 to 2009, according to a report released Friday by the city’s Health Department.

headline: Lots of Drama, but No Fall, During Spider-Man Rehearsal
text: Rehearsal for Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” on Friday was no normal slice of scene work for Christopher Tierney, the actor who fell 30 feet from a platform and nearly died during a performance on Dec. 20. Mr. Tierney, who plays the masked super-hero in stunt sequences, flew Thursday for the first time since rejoining the cast last week; Friday’s work call had him back at the moment in the musical when his accident occurred.

headline: Bird Week| The Lure and Danger of the High Line
text: Bright lights, big city: That combination draws birds to the same kinds of places the characters in a Jay McInerney novel would go if all that ’80s dissipation did not do them in first. There is, for example, the High Line elevated park. Except that at least one spot along the High Line is not for the birds — for them, it can be deadly.

headline: Master of Hounds 101
text: Master of Hounds hardly looked like a Derby contender when he failed to fire in the Breeders’ Cup Juvenile Turf last fall. But a bit of a break over the winter apparently agreed with him, because a bigger, stronger version of the colt took to the track in Dubai on World Cup night.

headline: For These Designers, Mom Knew Best
text: IN “The Importance of Being Earnest,” Oscar Wilde wrote: “All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man does. That’s his.” Fashion designers get around this problem by incorporating their mother’s way of dressing into their work. On the occasion of Mother’s Day, several shared their primal style memories.

headline: A Matter of Degrees
text: In 1940, a Brooklyn woman named Jean Kay filed a suit with the State Supreme Court against the her city’s Board of Higher Education claiming that the renowned mathematician and philosopher Bertrand Russell was morally unfit to teach at the City College of New York, where he had been offered a professorship. Kay, supported by a host of others in the public scrum, including Bishop William Manning of the Episcopal Church, argued that Russell, who advocated sex before marriage and other heretical lifestyle choices, posed a threat to the virtue of her daughter — even though the impressionable youth was not actually a student at the college. A judge ruled in Kay’s favor. Russell, who was not allowed to speak in his own defense, was denied his appointment at the college, which was, and is, part of the publicly financed City University of New York system. Today, the now-notorious incident is chronicled in an exhibition on City College’s Web site, called “The Struggle for Free Speech at CCNY, 1931-1942,” as is a recounting of the subsequent firings, spurred by the McCarthy era Rapp-Coudert Committee, of faculty members accused of being Communist Party members.

headline: Sloan Group Is Lab Partner to the Arts
text: Anna Ziegler’s play “Photograph 51” focuses the spotlight on Rosalind Franklin, the least heralded of the four scientists who discovered the structure of DNA in 1953. Although Franklin’s death from cancer at 37 precluded her sharing the Nobel Prize that this breakthrough brought, her X-ray photography provided the critical evidence of the molecule’s famed double helix.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 6

headline: Recalling and Quoting Her Mother
text: In 1999 the choreographer Muna Tseng paid homage to her brother, the photographer Tseng Kwong Chi, who had died of AIDS. That work, “SlutForArt,” was created in collaboration with the theater artist Ping Chong. Now, in “Stella,” Ms. Tseng tries to get under the skin of her mother, a stylish woman who had a sharp tongue. Stella cared about clothes — included in the show is an exhibition of her luxurious couture dresses — and said memorable things like, “The biggest waste in life is time.”

headline: New Jazz That Keeps an Ear Trained on the Past
text: By the late 1990s, jazz outside the straight-ahead mainstream was looking around itself and worrying. Outlasting a flicker of interest from major-record labels, anticipating audience decline as the “downtown jazz” scene grew diffuse and undefinable, it went in search of its parents and looked backward and Eastward: to Ornette Coleman, Lennie Tristano, Jimmy Giuffre, early fusion and progressive rock, the Art Ensemble of Chicago and Balkan and cantorial music. A whole field of bands gravitated toward intense polyphony, liturgical melodies and the clank: drummers playing roughed-up rhythm, rushing time and forestalling your pleasure, vexing you on purpose.

headline: Youth, Balanchine and Fans Are Served
text: In the Stravinsky-Balanchine “Apollo,” the world itself is young. The boy god Apollo, the first musician, discovers art by creating it in the open air. On Thursday night at New York City Ballet, the title role was danced by Chase Finlay, who had not even graduated from the School of American Ballet when this piece was last performed, in 2008. Afterward the audience would not release the performers until Mr. Finlay had taken a solo bow in front of the curtain.

headline: A Woman’s Persecution, and a Daughter’s Deliverance
text: HOUSTON — On a blustery night the week before Mother’s Day, a woman and her daughter sat together on the sofa at a hair salon here. Nica Sabet had come to the beauty parlor after school, because it was where her mother, Nahid Sabet, worked. By this time, past 8 o’clock, the doors were locked and the customers gone, and Mrs. Sabet could tell the story that Nica had never heard in its entirety.

headline: NBC’s ‘Office’ Takes a Hit
text: In the first episode of “The Office” without its star Steve Carell, ratings for the NBC sitcom were down two million viewers and some 15 percent in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49 compared with a week ago. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 6.8 million people tuned in to the episode at 9 p.m., down from 8.4 million previously. For the night, NBC ranked a distant fourth, earning its second- and third-highest ratings at 9:30 and 10 for “Parks and Recreation” (5.1 million) and “30 Rock” (4.2 million). Fox dominated prime time as usual thanks to an elimination episode of “American Idol” at 8 (20.8 million) in which Jacob Lusk failed to make the cut for the Top 4. CBS was second with “CSI” at 9 (10.5 million) and “The Mentalist” at 10 (13.6 million). ABC finished in third place, attracting its best ratings at 9 for “Grey’s Anatomy” (9.9 million).

text: About 10 percent of the city’s eighth graders did not get into any of the public high schools they wanted, leaving them — and their worried, frustrated parents — to consider what was next.

headline: Struggling Folk Art Museum Hands Off Antique Show

headline: Farm Subsidies Become Target Amid Spending Cuts

But now federal farm subsidies, long decried by policy makers as wasteful and antiquated but protected by powerful political interests, appear to be in serious danger.

headline: With Dallas Leading, Outspoken Owner Lowers the Volume
text: DALLAS — Mark Cuban is not an owner who merely watches his Dallas Mavericks. He seems to internalize the action while outwardly cheering and complaining. When his emotions are released — and they frequently are — the result is often a fine leveled at Cuban by the N.B.A.

headline: Russia: Lawyer’s Killer Gets Life Term
text: A young nationalist was sentenced to life in prison, Russia’s most stringent punishment, on Friday for fatally shooting a human rights lawyer and a young journalist two years ago on a busy street near the Kremlin. His common-law wife, who prosecutors said acted as a lookout, was sentenced to 18 years as an accomplice. The sentence brings to a close a case that deeply shook Russian human rights circles, which have been dogged by a series of high-profile killings. Last week, the couple, Nikita Tikhonov, 30, and Yevgenia Khasis, 26, were found guilty. Defense lawyers appealed the sentence on Friday, saying the judge had sided with prosecutors. “This can be qualified in whatever way you like, a costume ball, a farce, a reprisal, but not a trial,” Aleksandr Vasilyev, Mr. Tikhonov’s lawyer, told the Interfax news service.

headline: Sort of Cool, Not Yet Hot
text: POOR Ninth Avenue. You could dismiss the stretch from West 14th to West 23rd Street as the northern hinterlands of the greater meatpacking district. Or you could pity it, there in the shadow of 10th, the glamorous sister avenue whose profile has been transformed by famous art galleries, starred restaurants and the coursing aorta that is the High Line. But no need to disparage in any way: These blocks in West Chelsea form a self-contained little quarter, with a thriving life all their own.

headline: The Week That Was
text: This is not the column I was going to write, but because of the recent days of relentless saturation — and I don’t mean by or about the Mississippi River — whatever I try to type, my fingers, unbidden, produce the letters “Osama bin …” etc.

headline: A Major Fight, and It’s Not on HBO? Times Are Changing for Big Promoters
text: LAS VEGAS — On Saturday, the MGM Grand will serve as both the site of a welterweight title fight and a network experiment.

headline: Judge Gives Immigrant in Same-Sex Marriage a Reprieve From Deportation
text: An immigration judge in Newark on Friday suspended the deportation of a Venezuelan man who is married to an American man, responding to an unusual signal this week from the Obama administration that it is exploring legal avenues for recognizing same-sex marriages in immigration cases.

headline: George Jetson, Your Room Is Ready
text: We’ve all had this dream for so long that some of us have probably forgotten about it. It’s the dream that someday we’ll be able to navigate New York without ever being at the mercy of a rude cabdriver, an indifferent waiter or a butterfingered bellhop.

headline: Energy Dept. Panel to Revise Standards for Gas Extraction
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, seeing increased domestic natural gas production as a linchpin in its long-term energy strategy, has named a panel of experts to find ways to make hydraulic fracturing, a fast-growing method of extracting natural gas, safer and cleaner.

headline: A Titan Under a Microscope
text: Steven A. Cohen, the once-secretive billionaire hedge fund manager, is suddenly everywhere.

headline: William Craig, Politician in Northern Ireland, Is Dead at 86
text: William Craig, a Protestant politician in Northern Ireland whose banning of a civil rights march by Roman Catholics in 1968 helped set off 30 years of sectarian violence, which he fueled with incendiary pronouncements, died April 25 in Bangor, Northern Ireland. He was 86.

headline: The Man Likes What He Sees in the Mirror
text: Michael R. Bloomberg, long one of the nation’s most-admired big-city mayors, is not accustomed to seeing his popularity used as comic fodder. But there he was, at the black-tie White House Correspondents’ Association dinner, when Seth Meyers, of “Saturday Night Live” fame, strode to the rostrum and, in front of much of the nation’s political, media and entertainment elite, let loose with a joke about a Bloomberg-sponsored after-party.

headline: Florida Legislators Pass H.M.O. Plan for Medicaid
text: MIAMI — In a sweeping overhaul of its $21 billion Medicaid program, the Florida Legislature approved a bill Friday to shift nearly three million Medicaid recipients into managed-care programs in the hope of saving money and improving services.

headline: CUNY and Tony Kushner: A Firestorm

headline: The Nissan Taxi Is Rolling In, to a Bronx Cheer

headline: On a Gas Line in 1979
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Warns Schools Against Checking Immigration Status
text: Federal officials issued a memorandum to the nation’s school districts on Friday saying it was against the law for education officials to seek information that might reveal the immigration status of children applying for enrollment.

headline: Dissecting the Twin Tales of Teams in Distress
text: On Thursday, after the Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-2, Fred Wilpon stood off to the side in a wide corridor near the Mets’ clubhouse at Citi Field and interacted with friends and their families. Wilpon, the Mets’ owner, casually greeted players, kissed their newborn babies and congratulated expectant mothers.

headline: Warner Music Is Sold, Ending a Long Auction
text: Kevin Mazur/Hope for Haiti Now, via European Pressphoto AgencyMadonna is among Warner Music’s artists.

headline: Sainthood for John Paul
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Jersey Rock History: More Than Big Hair and the Boss
text: IN “Jersey Rocks: A History of Rock & Roll in the Garden State,” a new exhibition at the Morris Museum in Morristown that will run through Sept. 5, the background music may be as interesting for some visitors as the 400 or so objects on display. “Stacy’s Mom,” the 2003 hit by the pop band Fountains of Wayne, whose front man, Adam Schlesinger, grew up in Montclair, was followed recently by “Walk on By,” the 1960s classic made famous by Dionne Warwick, who was raised in Newark and now lives in South Orange.

headline: Knocking Them Dead Backstage
text: The leading lady is hopeless. She’s a bosomy redhead who can’t remember her lines, and, rather than act, she just poses. The show’s final number, “Wide Open Spaces,” is pedestrian, and the choreography is longer on energy than style. The Boston reviews are dreadful.

headline: Presidential Spotlight Shines on the Commandos Who Work in the Shadows
text: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. — They are the shadowy warriors of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden: two dozen members of the Navy Seals who stormed the fortified compound in Pakistan where Bin Laden was hiding. Their identities will probably never be known; their faces will most likely never appear in photographs at the White House, on magazine covers or on television talk shows.

headline: How We Reacted to the Killing of Bin Laden
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strangers on a Train, Destination Unknown
text: “Night Train,” a new play by John Biguenet at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, takes viewers on a quick journey into darkening deception as a traveler becomes intrigued — unfortunately, for him — by two of his fellow passengers.

headline: A Wedding in the Winner’s Circle
text: In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasn’t stopped going to the races since. That is when she isn’t isn’t taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nation’s leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

headline: Top Mets Suitor Would Likely Draw Scrutiny
text: With a net worth of $8 billion, Steven A. Cohen, who is in the bidding to purchase a minority stake in the Mets, unquestionably has the money to buy a sizable chunk of the franchise.

headline: Diplomatic Service
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Brief History of Primary Polling, Part III
text: About a month ago, I published a pair of articles (see Part I and Part II) that focused on the predictive value of polls conducted in the early stage of the presidential primary process. Specifically, it looked at national polls conducted in January through June of the year before the primaries — for example, polls taken in January through June 1987 for the 1988 nomination races.

headline: Golfers Reflect as Ballesteros’s Condition Deteriorates
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — An ocean apart, at a PGA Tour event in North Carolina and a PGA European Tour event in Madrid, professional golfers had Seve Ballesteros on their minds Friday. Word of his rapidly worsening health had swept across the golf courses, and its impact was felt by many of the players who had competed against him.

headline: A Hideaway for Wine
text: THE dimly lighted storefront gives Bouchon Wine Bar Café a speakeasy feel, like an exciting hideaway, although it is located only a block from the homey Pleasantville train station. But there’s more to Bouchon than its narrow facade implies: its long, deep space has been divided smartly into cozy areas fitted with couches, a few high and low tables and a full bar.

headline: A Complex Interplay in Latin Cuisine
text: THE chupe at Cienega, a saffron-infused yellow, is lovely just to look at. But sample a spoonful of this Peruvian chowder and the pleasure really begins. Filled with firm shrimp, sweet corn kernels, bits of green and red peppers — even a poached quail egg — the soup is somehow both strong and subtle, rich and light: an interplay of flavors and textures. It is a fitting introduction to Cienega’s complex Latin cuisine and a metaphor for the overall dining experience there.

headline: Facing Criticism, U.S. Official Quits
text: Peter Vidmar, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in gymnastics, stepped down Friday as the chief of mission for the 2012 United States Olympic team after a controversy about his public opposition to same-sex marriage.

headline: U.S. Demands More From Pakistan in Bin Laden Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — Pakistani officials say the Obama administration has demanded the identities of some of their top intelligence operatives as the United States tries to determine whether any of them had contact with Osama bin Laden or his agents in the years before the raid that led to his death early Monday morning in Pakistan.

headline: A Talented Jockey Is No Longer a Secret
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The girl was on horses before she could walk and grew up following her mother around barns in her native New Jersey. She quickly grew out of pony racing and into thoroughbreds, first galloping horses in the mornings on Maryland racetracks. She got a jockey’s license when she was 17 and earned her first victory with her first mount, Ringofdiamonds, on June 9, 2005.

headline: The Spring Quiz
text: I. Match that quote:

headline: The Bin Laden Bounce
text: Osama goes down. Obama ticks up. That’s the narrative of the killing of Osama bin Laden and the lift in the polls for President Obama in its aftermath. In fact, a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted after Bin Laden was killed  found an 11-point jump in the president’s approval rating.

headline: Lincoln, Douglass and the ‘Double-Tongued Document’
text: The two months following Lincoln’s inauguration found Frederick Douglass struggling to understand and bitterly demoralized by the president’s policies, but also exhilarated by the outbreak of war at Fort Sumter. He had no interest in the new president’s oratorical olive branches to the seceded South, his poetry about the “mystic chords of memory” or the “better angels of our nature.” Indeed, Douglass despised the olive branches, calling the speech “little better than our worst fears,” and a “double-tongued document, capable of two constructions,” concealing rather than declaring a “definite policy.”

headline: An Iranian Filmmaker Tiptoes Around the Censors to Explore Risky Subjects
text: TEHRAN This is not something I should be doing,” Mehrdad Oskouei says, shuffling through thick stacks of sepia-tinged postcards of long-bearded Qajar noblemen, mustachioed revolutionaries, veiled women and wandering dervishes. Mr. Oskouei, perhaps Iran’s most prominent documentary filmmaker, has spent a considerable amount of time and money assembling the collection, a venture that many of his friends and relatives see as a quixotic cultural crusade.

headline: Baby Hawk Deaths Greatly Exaggerated, Video Feed Shows
text: Nature, fortunately, does not listen to the experts.

headline: You Call That Tough?
text: The only thing missing from Preet Bharara’s press conference was the blaring of trumpets.

headline: Trying to Game Google on ‘Mother’s Day Flowers’
text: Mother’s Day flowers.

headline: After Reversal, Honor Is Likely for Kushner
text: Under mounting pressure, the City University of New York board of trustees moved on Friday to reverse its decision earlier this week to withhold an honorary degree from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Tony Kushner because of one trustee’s concerns about Mr. Kushner’s views regarding Israel.

headline: A Philosopher in Love
text: Houston

headline: The Return of ‘Drill, Baby, Drill’
text: With the country again facing $4-a-gallon gasoline, the time would seem ripe for a grown-up conversation on energy. What we are getting instead is a mindless rerun of the drill-baby-drill operatics of the 2008 campaign, when gas was also at $4 a gallon. Then, as now, opportunistic politicians insisted that vastly expanded oil drilling would bring relief at the pump and reduced dependence on foreign oil. Then, as now, these arguments were bogus.

headline: One Hand Clapping
text: Jobs data can be hard to read. When an economy is emerging from recession, a rising jobless rate can be a good sign if it reflects an increase in the people actively looking for work. Sadly, that was not the case with the April employment numbers reported on Friday. The jobless rate rose because the people who lost or left their jobs outnumbered those who found new work.

headline: Legal Fight Continues for N.F.L.
text: With silence from a federal appeals court, the N.F.L. headed into another weekend in limbo, with business shut down and players wondering when — or if — they will go back to work.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Search of a Republican Presidential Field
text: Even John Boehner, the speaker of the House and Republican chieftain, didn’t bother to watch his party’s presidential debate on Thursday, and it’s hard to blame him. Only five candidates showed up, none with impressive followings. And what they said demonstrated why Republicans are having such a hard time delivering a coherent and appealing message ahead of the 2012 campaign.

headline: CUNY Shamed Itself
text: The trustees of the City University of New York got it exactly backward this week. They supported the political agenda of an intolerant board member and shunned one of America’s most important playwrights. They should have embraced the artist and tossed out the board member.

headline: In Praise of Brew Masters
text: After the Blue Point Brewing Company opened in Patchogue 13 years ago, said Pete Cotter, 48, the brewery’s co-founder, “we were the only game in town for a while.

headline: An American Newcomer With an Italian Accent
text: CAFÉ RED, in Kings Park, is the newest member of the family of restaurants owned by Nino Antuzzi and Kelley Danek. The others, all in Huntington, are Red, Osteria da Nino and Sapsuckers, a casual, publike spot.

headline: Lanny Friedlander, Founder of Reason Magazine, Dies at 63
text: Lanny Friedlander, who with little more than a typewriter and a stack of paper founded the libertarian magazine Reason in his college dorm room in 1968 and ran it briefly before dropping out of sight for the next 40 years, died on March 19 in Lowell, Mass. He was 63.

headline: Mattingly Looks Past Dodgers’ Financial Fray
text: Shortly after Commissioner Bud Selig appointed Tom Schieffer to run the Los Angeles Dodgers against the will of the team’s ownership last month, Schieffer held a meeting with the players in the clubhouse at Dodger Stadium.

headline: In Fallout of Suicide by Student, a Plea Deal
text: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. — One of two former Rutgers University students accused of spying on another student with a webcam just days before he committed suicide will be allowed to avoid a conviction if she continues to provide information about her co-defendant, prosecutors said Friday.

headline: Power Struggle in Iran Enters the Mosque
text: The unprecedented power struggle between the two most powerful leaders in Iran deepened Friday, spilling out into Tehran’s public prayers where the mullah leading the service indirectly criticized President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad while the crowd chanted “Death to opponents of the supreme leader!”

headline: Saturday: Unlike the Opera “Wozzeck”
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — How long have you been doing late week puzzles? Except for the Sunday, I’m relatively new to them, because I used to believe that the Saturday puzzle, at least, was for the truly suicidal. It just goes to show that practice makes, if not perfect, a lot better. That’s a good thing, and I hope that people who are afraid to try them sit down and give them a chance. And then another and another, until they can crack them almost as easily as they do a midweek puzzle.

headline: Looming Layoffs at Schools Imperil Bloomberg’s Legacy
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s threats of teacher layoffs have had a ring of déjà vu. He used the same threat last year to squeeze more money from the federal government and to press his case for abolishing the state law that protects the most senior teachers from losing their jobs.

headline: In New York, Mayor Seeks Teacher Cuts
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed on Friday to lay off 5,400 New York City workers, including 5 percent of all schoolteachers, in what would be the first significant city job cuts in two decades.

headline: A Union of Comfort Foods
text: The seemingly boundless popularity of burger joints and cupcake shops inspired Rick Ross and his wife, Cathy, to try combining the two. Their Bucu Burger Bar and Bakery on Route 4 in Paramus brings both food trends under the same roof.

headline: A Szechuan Adventure Behind a Shopping Mall
text: SQUEEZED next to a Home Goods store behind the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne, Chengdu 23 looks like little more than a place for weary shoppers to get a quick pick-me-up of moo shu or kung pao. But something happens when you take your seat, scan the menu and inhale scents of jasmine, garlic and others, harder to name, that waft by with every passing plate. Your appetite swells, as does your adventurousness.

headline: At ’80s Party, White Hair Crowns an August Head
text: The ’80s theme was laid on so thick at an auction and party for the public arts group Creative Time on Thursday night that if a member of the Brat Pack had sauntered by, we wouldn’t have blinked.

headline: Sales Surge 50% for Maker of Monster Energy Drinks
text: The Hansen Natural Corporation, the maker of Monster Energy drinks, posted a 50 percent increase in quarterly sales, setting off a 4.5 percent gain in its share price on Friday. The company said after the close of trading Thursday that its sales rose to $356.4 million, and profit rose to 59 cents a share, topping the 49 cents analysts had expected. Stock in Hansen, which is based in Corona, Calif., rose $2.80, to $64.74 a share.

headline: JPMorgan in Talks to Settle S.E.C. Inquiry Into Securities
text: JPMorgan Chase & Company is in negotiations to resolve its role in a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into how mortgage-linked securities were packaged and sold as the housing market came apart.

headline: At a Strip Mall, Fans Keep Vigil for a Champion
text: Some of the best things — and biggest mysteries — in this city can be found hidden in the nondescript strip malls that line miles of thoroughfares, most famously exotic ethnic restaurants tucked into plain storefronts.

headline: Yankees Adjust to Loss of the Versatile Chavez
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The ripples from Eric Chavez’s broken left foot spread throughout the Yankees on Friday, from them calling up Ramiro Pena to potentially giving Jorge Posada repetitions at first base to planning when to rest the aging stars patrolling the left side of their infield.

headline: Drone Strike Said to Kill at Least 8 in Pakistan
text: Missiles believed to have been fired by an American drone killed at least eight suspected militants and wounded four in Pakistan’s tribal regions on Friday, according to a Pakistani security official and a resident in the area of the strike. Later, seven more bodies were recovered, bringing the death toll to 15, the resident said.

headline: Ethier Extends Streak, but Mets Win the Day
text: Just 13 pitches into Friday’s game, the big question of the day was answered virtually without suspense. Andre Ethier, the third batter of the evening, belted a 3-0 fastball into center field for a base hit, and with that his hitting streak moved up a level.

headline: Elliott Erwitt’s Best Picture? The Next One.
text: On Tuesday, the Magnum photographer and filmmaker Elliott Erwitt, 82, will receive the Infinity Award for Lifetime Achievement from the International Center of Photography, which will exhibit his favorite pictures as “Personal Best,” beginning May 20. For the occasion, he agreed to let his son Misha Erwitt, a photographer himself, present him with a list of questions that family members have long wanted to ask.

headline: Photo Replay: May 6
text: A look at the day in sports, from the opening ceremony of the Giro d’Italia cycling race to the morning workouts at Churchill Downs.

headline: Bruins Finish Off Flyers, Leaving Bad Taste Behind
text: BOSTON — The Bruins exorcised some very persistent demons Friday night. It is too soon to tell if they have done so as thoroughly as the Red Sox did when they overcame nearly a century of futility by rallying from three games down in a playoff series against the Yankees in 2004.

headline: Nova Finds His Pitch, Leaving Rangers Helpless
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Ignore the detail that the Texas Rangers were playing without the sluggers Josh Hamilton and Nelson Cruz, and that their flight from Seattle arrived Friday morning after the newspapers had hit the driveways. Just consider the facts. On a muggy night, in a stadium where the ball travels well, and facing a lineup still loaded with power and speed, Ivan Nova dominated like no other starter for the Yankees this season.

headline: With Death Outpacing Birth, a County Slows to a Shuffle
text: WEIRTON, W. Va. — Life in this industrial area has slowed to a shuffle along with the steel mills that used to power it. Young people have moved away, leaving an aging population that no longer has the energy to put on street fairs or holiday parades.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Save the Children
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask that readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section.Can this child be saved? That was the underlying theme of the latest episode of “Friday Night Lights,” as we watched Epyck lash out, fight and get suspended and Buddy’s son roll into town with his quasi-vegan-induced anger and disillusionment. Who among us wouldn’t become cranky if subjected to a step-parent mandated diet of seitan? It seems to take Buddy Jr. about 10 seconds of being in Dillon to steal his father’s credit card and break into the booze and another 20 for everyone to figure that the cure for what ails Buddy is going to be two-a-days. I’m already feeling too optimistic about Buddy’s future, and I don’t want to feel optimistic. I hope for more screeching engines and rebellion, a challenge to Buddy’s narrowly circumscribed gridiron view of the world.

headline: Israel Continues Airstrikes on Gaza
text: The Israeli Army declared some areas around Gaza “closed military zones,” as Israeli aircraft attacked key Hamas symbols of power, raising the death toll to more than 300.

headline: Face That Screamed War’s Pain Looks Back, 6 Hard Years Later
text: MOSUL, Iraq — Until the past week, Samar Hassan had never glimpsed the photograph of her that millions had seen, never knew it had become one of the most famous images of the Iraq war.

headline: With Fourth-Quarter Rally, Mavericks Push Jackson and Lakers to Brink
text: DALLAS — For all of their shared highs, the championships topped with championships, Kobe Bryant and Phil Jackson have never been pinned by the new low the Dallas Mavericks presented Friday evening.

headline: Seve Ballesteros, Dashing Golf Champion, Dies at 54
text: Seve Ballesteros, the charismatic Spanish golfer who won the Masters twice and the British Open three times and helped propel Europe’s rise in the Ryder Cup competition with the United States, died early Saturday at his home in northern Spain, where his struggle with brain cancer had gained wide attention in the sports world. He was 54.

headline: In Majorca, Atoning for the Sins of 1691
text: PALMA, MAJORCA — The old stones of the historic quarter of the Spanish island of Majorca are worn smooth with secrets ignored by most tourists that pour into this city from cruise liners on the sparkling Mediterranean.

headline: As Syria Steps Up Efforts to Crush Unrest, Dissidents Report Attack on a City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hundreds of troops backed by at least seven tanks stormed a city on Syria’s Mediterranean coast before dawn on Saturday, cutting electricity and phone lines and besieging neighborhoods in a locale that has emerged as one of the most restive in the seven-week uprising, opposition groups and human rights activists said.

headline: The Weekend Word: Aftermath
text: Today’s Times

headline: 27 Feared Dead in Indonesia Crash
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Up to 27 people were believed to be dead after a passenger plane crashed into the sea in eastern Indonesia on Saturday, officials said, the latest in a long series of transportation accidents in the archipelago nation.

headline: When One Is Enough
text: Molly Jo Rosen has been involved with thoroughbred racing from coast to coast: from Churchill Downs to TVG to Smarty Jones’s personal assistant to managing a major New York racing operation. She now runs Community Communications at GradeOneRacing, finds future superstars at 2yoSales.com, and serves her blend of pony punditry on her blog, Focused Filly.

headline: Classic Ad: A Chrysler Mash-Up
text: There’s something about this ad for the 1971 Chrysler 300 that just isn’t quite right.

headline: Shadow of the Torturers
text: After reading John Yoo’s attack on the president for not taking Osama alive and bringing him to Gitmo, I thought I might take a minute to explain something I sometimes say. Once in a while I mention, in passing, that the Bush administration saw torturing people as a plus, not a cost. And whenever I do, some readers clutch their breasts and reach for the smelling salts: how dare I say such a thing?

headline: A Healer’s Horse Repays the Favor
text: If Midnight Interlude wins the Kentucky Derby, Bob Baffert should place his friend Philip Thomas on the payroll through the Belmont. In 2002, Baffert’s Derby horse War Emblem bit his groom before winning the Derby. He bit the same groom before winning the Preakness. Word is that the groom disappeared before the Belmont which War Emblem lost. This week, Baffert’s Derby horse Midnight Interlude bit Phillip Thomas twice on the arm. In the world of racetrack superstitions, Baffert views this as a very good sign.

headline: Volatile Prices Are Volatile
text: Commodity Rout Lends Credence to Bernanke’s Inflation Outlook, says Real Time Economics. Well, yes. Volatile prices are volatile, which is why they shouldn’t be used to determine monetary policy.

headline: Race-Day Drugs: Clearing the Air
text: Chris McCarron is a Hall of Fame jockey and the founder and lead instructor of the North American Racing Academy in Lexington, Ky.

headline: On Derby Morning, Dialed In Looks Ready
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — This morning I ventured over to the backside for the final time before the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby. My host, Bob, and I stopped off at Wagner’s to pick up a cup of coffee on the way.

headline: Moving the Goal Posts on Pay
text: PEOPLE scrutinize just about everything Wal-Mart does. As Michael T. Duke, the company’s chief executive, put it recently, “What we do and how we perform is watched closely not only by our customers and shareholders, but also by the whole world.”

headline: Libya Strikes Fuel Supply in City Held by Rebels
text: MISURATA, Libya — Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi struck the fuel terminal of this rebel-controlled city early Saturday with ground-to-ground rockets, igniting a fire that threatened the city’s fuel supply.

headline: Drugs in Racing: Déjà Vu All Over Again
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Four years ago, the Derby week chatter among Twin Spires railbirds centered on the likelihood that the 2008 edition of the Kentucky Derby might be the last in which horses were allowed to compete with anabolic steroids as part of their race regimen. It was.

headline: The Prince of Lord & Taylor
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Answers in a Teenager's Murder, Four Decades Later
text: Police reports offer new details about the murder of Johnny McCabe in 1969.

headline: Browns’ Peyton Hillis Hopes to Defy Madden NFL ‘Curse’
text: With some extra downtime during the N.F.L. lockout, Peyton Hillis, a Cleveland Browns running back, has become proficient at the Madden NFL video game by EA Sports. He also became its unlikely cover boy for Madden NFL 12, winning the sports video game version of “American Idol.” He beat out more glamorous names like Michael Vick and Aaron Rogers after a six-week online fan voting campaign that generated more than 12.7 million votes.

headline: Lessons on Going Viral
text: A class on persuasive technology at Stanford University ended up becoming a laboratory for start-ups making simple products aimed at attracting large numbers of users.

headline: The Class That Built Apps, and Fortunes
text: STANFORD, Calif.

headline: Far From Perfection, but Closer to Vindication
text: If Jim Qualls had a penny for every time he was mentioned for breaking up Tom Seaver’s perfect game, he might be a bit more solvent while he drives a tractor in western Illinois.

headline: For Dorfman, 100 Percent of the Game Was Mental
text: A vast majority of baseball fans never heard of Harvey Dorfman. But for 30 years until his death in February at 75, he had a profound effect on hundreds of major league players. Dorfman was hired by the Oakland Athletics in the mid-1980s to serve as their mental performance coach, and worked his magic with some of the game’s biggest stars.

headline: Yes, Everyone Can Be Stupid for a Minute
text: This interview with  Dominic Orr, president and C.E.O. of Aruba Networks, a wireless networking company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Strong Arms, Long Memories for Smoltz and Morris
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — It was the most magical night a pitcher has ever had, an extra-inning shutout to win the World Series, and Jack Morris wishes he could share it with you. If every person could experience one moment like that, he says, and reach a goal in extraordinary circumstances, think of the positive energy it could bring to the world.

headline: In Rarity, a Player Speaks Out for Gay Rights
text: Since September, advocates for same-sex marriage in New York have released 30-second videos of celebrities endorsing their cause. More than 30 have taken part, including the actors Julianne Moore and Sam Waterston, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the former first daughter Barbara Bush. On Thursday, former President Bill Clinton released a written statement of support, too.

headline: When a Players Union Doesn’t Help the Players
text: Having grown up during the New Deal, my parents made me keenly aware that unions gave workers what they lacked individually — a voice. My childhood hero was Marvin Miller, the labor economist who in 1968 negotiated the Major League Baseball Players Association’s first collective bargaining agreement with team owners. Miller’s own new deal raised the minimum salary to $10,000 from $6,000, the first increase since the 1940s. (It’s now $414,000.)

headline: How to Be Contrarian in a Year of Contrarians
text: Everybody knows that all the favorites in this year’s Kentucky Derby have serious vulnerabilities and that lots of long-priced horses have hidden virtues. Everybody wants to go contrarian, but you got be different from everybody if you want to be contrarian. I can’t add to what everybody already knows. Rather than look at the race comprehensively in a limited space, I will take this opportunity to explore a pure contrarian opportunity in this race that could produce value in a race screaming out for a contrarian approach.

headline: An Engine’s Tall Order: Streamline the Search
text: WHEN a kidney stone had me writhing in pain a few months back, I did what a lot of people with medical ailments do: I headed straight to Google for help with a self-diagnosis.

headline: The Next Step for Researchers Is Not Finding Brain Trauma
text: When the N.F.L. veteran Andre Waters killed himself in late 2006, the subsequent discovery of damage in his brain shocked the football community into asking how many other retired players might have an incurable disease.

headline: For the Phillies’ Polanco, It’s the Little Things
text: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia Phillies led the Washington Nationals by a run in the seventh inning last Tuesday at Citizens Bank Park. Shane Victorino hit a leadoff single, and Phillies Manager Charlie Manuel called for a hit-and-run. He knew he could trust the hitter, Placido Polanco.

headline: Fish Hooks Designed to Avoid the Wrong Catch
text: MOST angling gear is designed to hold onto fish. But some new equipment is fine-tuned to be more selective — holding tight to some fish and letting go of others, especially if they are Atlantic bluefin tuna — a fish whose numbers have fallen sharply.

headline: Huntsman, Ex-Envoy to China, Tests Political Waters With Speech
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A week after resigning his post as ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. made his debut on the American political stage here on Saturday and defended his service in the Obama administration as he began exploring whether to join the Republican presidential race.

headline: A Warranty She Didn’t Want
text: HAGGLER regulars may recall a two-episode cliffhanger a few months back involving an auto dealership in New York City and an unhappy customer who said he’d been overcharged by roughly $6,000.

headline: Greek Leader Irked by Speculation on Debt
text: PARIS — Prime Minister George Papandreou of Greece on Saturday attacked “rumor mongering” and speculation after a German magazine reported that Athens was threatening to leave the euro zone in order to bargain for easier terms on its huge debt obligations.

headline: Which Horse Will Have What It Takes?
text: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of “Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery” and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.

headline: Variety: A Parental Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s acrostic contains a beautiful quote, and perhaps I’m feeling sentimental about it because I am raising two young people who, like their peers, truly do feel the way youth is described here. My job, apparently, is to reassure them that their experiences are not abnormal and their crises are not final.

headline: Bird Week | Watching and Counting
If You Have the Answers, Tell Me
text: AFTER more than a quarter-century as a professional economist, I have a confession to make: There is a lot I don’t know about the economy. Indeed, the area of economics where I have devoted most of my energy and attention — the ups and downs of the business cycle — is where I find myself most often confronting important questions without obvious answers.

headline: Tech Stocks May Become an Unlikely Haven
text: THE stock market has been fighting an army of economic worries — including slowing economic growth and corporate earnings, a weakening dollar and what until last week were surging oil prices.

headline: Overqualified? Don’t Be Overwrought
text: Q. During the recession, you needed a job and wound up taking one for which you are overqualified. Although you were initially grateful just to have the work, you now feel bored and depressed. Is there any way to change that?

headline: Frogs, Chessboards and Grids
text: I  COME from a family of mathematicians. My mother taught math in middle school, high school and college, and my father was a math professor. He was also a poet, a musician and a chess player — a true renaissance man who had an extraordinary influence on me. I’d come home from school to find him listening to orchestra music while following along with the musical score and pretending he was conducting.

headline: Briefing on Bin Laden Documents
text: The Obama administration has briefed reporters on Saturday, including The Times’s Elisabeth Bumiller, on the contents of some videos seized during the commando raid of Osama bin Laden’s compound in Abbottabad, Pakistan. The Lede will provide updates.

headline: Fighting Words
text: A Minnesota legislator took aim at the writer Neil Gaiman, for accepting a $45,000 speaking fee from the state. (Mr. Gaiman says he gave the money to charity.)

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Ballesteros ‘Could Get Up and Down Out of a Garbage Can’
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The reality of the death of the great golf champion Seve Ballesteros in Spain at the age of 54 dawned on Quail Hollow Club on Saturday morning, its arrival fittingly wrapped in a thick fog that shrouded the golf course and delayed the start of play for 90 minutes.

headline: No-Hitter Droughts
text: Before the Minnesota Twins’ Francisco Liriano threw a no-hitter against them last week, the Chicago White Sox had not been no-hit since Bret Saberhagen stymied them on Aug. 26, 1991. The crosstown Cubs, though, have gone much longer.

headline: Law Schools, Grades and Scholarships
text: Law Schools, Grades And Scholarships

headline: A Family’s Long Wait for Answers
text: William McCabe kept after the police in Lowell, Mass., for years, calling them early in the morning or late at night, reminding them about his son, Johnny, and reminding them not to let him be forgotten after his murder on Sept. 26, 1969. Four decades after the murder, three men have been arrested in connection with the case.

headline: Persistence of a Father Brings News in a Killing
text: LOWELL, Mass. — Even though he has answers now after so many years when there were none — his grief scabbing over but never healing, his stubbornness and persistence all that kept him going — William McCabe is still adding to the book about his son.

headline: Norwich City and Whitbread Movin’ on Up
text: Norwich City is going back to the English Premier League for the first time since 2005, and the club is taking its American defender Zak Whitbread with it.

headline: Share Your Memories of Seve Ballesteros
text: Seve Ballesteros, the charismatic Spanish golfer who won the Masters twice and the British Open three times and helped propel Europe’s rise in the Ryder Cup competition with the United States, died early Saturday at his home in northern Spain, where his struggle with brain cancer had gained wide attention in the sports world. He was 54.

headline: Long Odds for the League’s Old Guard
text: Boston

headline: There’s No Data Sheriff on the Wild Web
text: A company suffers a catastrophic attack on its servers. Gone are names, e-mail addresses, home phone numbers, passwords, credit card numbers.

headline: Posada Fights to Keep Positive Outlook
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — It took one question for Jorge Posada to release six weeks of disappointment, one question for his emotions to come tumbling out, and once they did he could not stop. At first, he described his season as “a little frustrating.” The next sentence, he called it “really frustrating.” By the end of his 28-second response, it had become “very frustrating,” and anyone in the same ZIP code as Posada on Friday night, with his brow furrowed and his arms crossed, could sense how much this all gnaws at him.

headline: The Morning Line: Derby Day Talk Centers on Horse Who Won’t Run
text: Even on the morning of Derby Day, the scratching of Uncle Mo is the major news story. Kevin Van Valkenberg, (whose coverage appears in the Los Angeles Times, the Washington Post, the Baltimore Sun, the Chicago Tribune, and assorted other Tribune Co. papers) writes that the  “reality of the 2011 Derby is the horse that isn’t in the race might be a bigger story than the ones that are.”

headline: Role Players Help the Lightning Strike Twice in Playoff Series
text: The surprise team of the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Tampa Bay Lightning, advanced to the semifinal stage of the tournament last week by sweeping the top-seeded, glamorous Washington Capitals, an outcome few had predicted.

headline: Derek Jeter and the Curse of Age
text: Here’s a prediction for how Derek Jeter, the Yankees’ Cooperstown-bound shortstop, will finish his season.

headline: Ecuador Votes on Bid to Give More Control to President
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Ecuadoreans voted on Saturday in a referendum that includes measures aimed at strengthening the power of President Rafael Correa, especially over Ecuador’s independent media organizations and the nation’s judiciary.

headline: Situation: Ambiguous
text: Rarely has a photo revealed so little while evoking so much. It shows an intent President Obama and other officials in the White House Situation Room, but tells little about what exactly the situation is, except that they are watching something off to the left.

headline: Videos From Bin Laden’s Hide-Out Released
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Saturday released five videos recovered from Osama bin Laden‘s hide-out in Abbottabad, Pakistan, that an intelligence official said showed the Qaeda founder threatening the United States, condemning capitalism and at some points flubbing his lines and missing a cue. In the most candid scenes, Bin Laden can be seen watching news coverage of himself on television.

headline: Opposition Makes Inroads in Singapore
text: BANGKOK — The ruling People’s Action Party led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong was returned to power on Sunday with a majority of 60 percent of the vote after a hard-fought parliamentary campaign in which opposition parties made their strongest inroads since Singapore’s independence in 1965.

headline: Charlie Morton’s ‘Step Forward’
text: The Pirates’ Charlie Morton was historically terrible in 2010. In 17 starts, he was 2-12 with a 7.57 earned run average . Only one other pitcher has made so many starts with an E.R.A. so high and a winning percentage so low: Ed Holley, who was 1-11 with an 8.12 E.R.A. for two teams in 1934.

headline: Home Videos of Bin Laden
text: Videos of Osama Bin Laden released on Saturday by the Obama administration. (These videos have no sound.)

headline: Albert Bachmann, a Colorful Swiss Spymaster, Dies at 81
text: Albert Bachmann, Switzerland’s least effective but most colorful spymaster, whose dread of a Soviet invasion led him to create a secret intelligence service and guerrilla force unknown to the Swiss government in the 1970s, died on April 12 in Cork, Ireland. He was 81.

headline: A World Trade Center Progress Report
text: After Sept. 11, it took nearly a decade to locate and kill Osama bin Laden, perhaps giving the nation, and especially the families of those lost in the attacks, some sense of closure.

headline: Bin Laden Watches Himself on TV
text: In a video released by the U.S. Department of Defense, Osama bin Laden is seen watching himself on television.

headline: Bin Laden Video Released
text: First of five videos of Osama bin Laden released Saturday by the United States.

headline: Deadly Attack by Insurgents in Kandahar
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents staged a complicated attack in Kandahar on Saturday that killed four, including an intelligence officer, a police officer and two civilians, and wounded 45 people.

headline: Third Home Video of Bin Laden
text: In the third of the Osama bin Laden videos, he is seen speaking against a black background.

headline: Boston’s Murphy Waits to Help in ‘Exasperating’ Year
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — Talking to Troy Murphy, one gets the distinct feeling that when he releases his life story, it will mention precious little, if anything, about what has been a humbling, vexing 2010-11 season.

headline: Fourth Video of Bin Laden
text: In the fourth of the Bin Laden videos, he is seen speaking against a wooden background.

headline: Fifth Video of Bin Laden
text: In the fifth, and final, video released by the U.S. Department of Defense today, Bin Laden is seen speaking against a blue wrinkled backdrop. The video has no audio.

headline: A Record of Nuclear Oversight
text: Since the partial meltdown at Three Mile Island’s unit 2 reactor in 1979, on 35 occasions reactors have been forced out of service for a year or longer in order to restore safe operation because of a systemic, cumulative degradation of the reactor’s components.

headline: Physician, Heel Thyself
text: Pittsburgh

headline: Freddie Roach to Join Olympians
text: Freddie Roach, widely acknowledged as the best boxing trainer in the world, said Friday he would work with the United States team on a volunteer basis in preparation for the London Olympics in 2012. Roach, who will be director of boxing strategy, said he had always dreamed of winning an Olympic medal.

headline: Woman With Gun Arrested in Waldorf’s Lobby, Police Say
text: A woman staying at the Waldorf-Astoria was arrested in the lobby of the Manhattan hotel on Saturday morning after a security officer spotted a pistol jutting out of her jacket pocket, the police said.

headline: Rays’ Upton Suspended
text: Tampa Bay Rays outfielder B. J. Upton was suspended two games and fined an undisclosed amount by Major League Baseball on Saturday for launching into a tirade following an ejection earlier last week. Upton was to begin serving his suspension Saturday but decided to appeal, and he played against the Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Fighting the Mississippi
text: The battle against North America’s longest river is never-ending. Photographs show some of the Mississippi’s worst floods.

headline: The Untamable Mississippi River
text: The rain-swollen Mississippi River crested to an all-time high last week as it surged past Cairo, Ill., exceeding the 1937 record by 2 feet. Government engineers were left with two choices: Let Cairo flood or explode a levee to save the town. They blew up the levee. But while Cairo was saved, other communities may not be so lucky.

headline: Animal Kingdom Wins Kentucky Derby
text: Animal Kingdom, who had never run a race on dirt, beat Nehro by two and three-quarter lengths to win the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday in his fifth career start. Trained by Graham Motion and owned by Team Valor International, Animal Kingdom had won twice and finished second twice in his previous four starts. Mucho Macho Man finished third.

headline: Federal Tax Chutzpah
text: Chutzpah, according to the traditional definition, is when you murder your mother and father, then plead for mercy from the court on the grounds that you’re an orphan.

headline: 30 Seconds With Juan Marichal
text: In 1963, Juan Marichal was making a name for himself, fresh off a no-hitter and on the way to a 25-win season for the San Francisco Giants. On July 2, his Milwaukee Braves opponent was Warren Spahn, 42 and nearing the end of his career. Marichal and Spahn pitched scoreless inning after scoreless inning until the 16th, when Willie Mays homered to win it for the Giants. The game is celebrated in Jim Kaplan’s book “The Greatest Game Ever Pitched.” Marichal, 73, now has a farm in the Dominican Republic and still remembers the game vividly.

headline: Change With a Straight Face Barrels Into the Castro
text: There’s an old saying in San Francisco: Market Street is straight, until it reaches the Castro.

headline: Watery Grave, Murky Law
text: Nashville

headline: Bin Laden Was Dead Already
text: Paris

headline: Why We Celebrate a Killing
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Bin Laden and the New Unknown in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — From the Taliban’s hidden mud compounds to NATO’s headquarters in Brussels and the Pentagon, combatants in a decade-long war are asking versions of the same question: How does Osama bin Laden’s death change the struggle over who will control Afghanistan?

headline: Bin Laden’s Secret Life in a Diminished World
text: WASHINGTON — The world’s most wanted terrorist lived his last five years imprisoned behind the barbed wire and high walls of his home in Abbottabad, Pakistan, his days consumed by dark arts and domesticity.

headline: A Reporter’s Quest for Osama bin Laden, the Unholy Grail
text: As reporting opportunities go, few can have been more spectacularly flubbed than the one that came my way on a long-ago spring day in the former Northwest Frontier Province of Pakistan. The year was 1989; the location a cramped room at a ramshackle indoctrination camp for Arab militants in the hinterland outside Peshawar, the frontier town that was a staging area for the mujahedeen who forced Soviet troops to withdraw from Afghanistan earlier that year.

headline: Steven Orszag, Pioneer in Fluid Dynamics Study, Dies at 68
text: Steven A. Orszag, a mathematician who performed pioneering work in the field of fluid dynamics and whose research had wide-ranging applications in airplane and auto design, meteorology and astrophysics, died May 1 in New Haven. He was 68.

headline: Louis Stumberg, Who Brought Tex-Mex to TV Dinners, Dies at 87
text: Louis Stumberg, who along with his father and his brother shrugged off their German ancestry to found Patio Foods in 1946, bringing frozen Tex-Mex (after quick heating, of course) to dinner tables and TV viewers’ laps across the nation, died Wednesday at a hospital near his home in San Antonio. He was 87.

headline: Joanna Russ, Who Drew Women to Sci-Fi, Dies at 74
text: Joanna Russ, a writer who four decades ago helped deliver science fiction into the hands of the most alien creatures the genre had yet seen — women — died on April 29 in Tucson. She was 74.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: End of Mideast Wholesale
text: If you look into the different “shop” windows across the Middle East, it is increasingly apparent that the Arab uprisings are bringing to a close the era of “Middle East Wholesale” and ushering in the era of “Middle East Retail.” Everyone is going to have to pay more for their stability.

headline: Running for Mayor, but With Her Money Not in Play
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Food Trucks Are Stalled by Process
text: San Francisco’s small army of food trucks feeds happy consumers every day. But behind the scenes, the mobile vendors have been complaining to the city for several years about a notoriously convoluted permit process.

headline: Flocking to a Park to Stalk Prey
text: ALONG a wooded path in Central Park’s Ramble, two photographers had set up next to each other last Sunday morning, with heavy tripods supporting elaborate cameras partly concealed by leafy camouflage material.

headline: Mothers We Could Save
text: BALIGUBADLE, Somaliland

headline: 30-Year-Old Capital Case Returns to Court, With Defense Alleging Bias
text: For the second time in three decades, a Texas court is preparing to decide whether Delma Banks Jr. should be executed for the 1980 shooting death of 16-year-old Richard Whitehead.

headline: Women Against the Hangman
text: Benghazi, Libya

headline: Mixed Reviews for Brownsville Ban on Plastic Bags
text: BROWNSVILLE — While buying groceries at the A&V Lopez supermarket this week, Rosie Orozco also spent 79 cents on something to put them in: a reusable bag emblazoned “Keep Texas Green.”

headline: Dewhurst’s Curious Role in the Theater of Politics
text: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

headline: Why Should Teachers Be Blamed?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Singer, Songwriter, Prodigy, All at 19
text: A little over two years ago, when Sarah Jarosz was still just 16, Alison Krauss, the acoustic music icon, listened to her demos and politely declined to co-produce her debut record. After explaining that she would be too busy working with Robert Plant, Ms. Krauss sent this message through an intermediary at Ms. Jarosz’s label: “Tell her there’s three songs there I’d cut right now. She shouldn’t let me and should keep them for herself, but I think she’s that good.”

headline: Corporate Donors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Killing Evil Doesn’t Make Us Evil
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Chaplains for Atheists
text: To the Editor:

headline: Personal Data: Safer in America or in Europe?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sunday: Working in Opposition
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people just like to be difficult. You say day, I say night. Tomato, tomahto. You get the idea. In today’s puzzle, however, Daniel Finan has decided to play both sides of the coin, and I think it works very well.

headline: Never Mind the ‘Vast Wasteland.’ Minow Has More to Say
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Pure Logo Wackiness in Wilmington
text: In Fort Wayne, Ind., fans root for the snarling apple logo of the Tin Caps, in honor of Johnny Appleseed. In Las Vegas, home of the 51s, folks cheer for an alien with a baseball-shaped head. A bear with a suitcase once promoted the Asheville (N.C.) Tourists, who now use a smiling moon wearing sunglasses.

headline: Group Homes to Nurture At-Risk Youths
text: For more than 20 years, the Rev. Bruce Wellems has been a cheerleader, a confidant, a voice of reason and, at times, the only advocate for troubled children in Back of the Yards.

headline: A Highly Praised Schools Bill Hits Some Snags
text: A sweeping schools bill that advocacy groups lauded as a landmark and that the federal secretary of education, Arne Duncan, described as a national model is hitting snags in the Illinois House.

headline: Reader Comments on my Family Planning Column
text: My Sunday column is from Somaliland but makes an argument closer to home: that Republican cuts in family planning assistance are short-sighted and will lead to more maternal deaths. And on Mother’s Day (or, as I like to style it, Mothers’ Day), shouldn’t saving mothers’ lives be a top priority?

headline: Democrats, Seduced by Secret Dollars
text: Last year several pro-Republican advocacy groups degraded the Congressional elections by spending at least $138 million in secret donations on advertisements. The public did not know which lobbying interests gave money, or how much, or what they would demand in return. But the donations became a significant factor in the Republican gains in the House and the Senate.

headline: Videos From Bin Laden’s Compound
text: On Saturday, the Obama administration released portions of five videos seized from Osama bin Laden’s compound, none with audio, in part to promote its intelligence triumph.

headline: New Federal Crackdown Confounds States That Allow Medical Marijuana
text: SEATTLE — Marijuana remains illegal under federal law, but that has not stopped a fuzzy industry of marijuana farms and dispensaries from rising to serve the 15 states that allow the drug to be used for medical purposes. Under President Obama, the federal government had seemed to make a point of paying little attention — until now.

headline: When the Court Won’t Let Go
text: ANGEL MARQUEZ was a New York City handball legend. He wore down opponents with his hustling-and-diving playing style, winning countless tournament championships since the 1970s.

headline: Standing Up for Florida’s Courts
text: A handful of Republican state senators in Florida bucked G.O.P. leaders last week to help Democrats block a brazenly partisan court-packing plan from gaining a place on next year’s ballot.

headline: The Goody Pile Survives Bad News
text: The summer people will soon discover that one of their secret vacation pleasures — the obligation to personally tote their refuse to the local dump — is being altered by governments on Long Island’s East End. “NO salvaging, scavenging and/or picking of recyclables” boomed the new sign at the Shelter Island town recycling center.

headline: Fernando Torres and That Other Title Race
text: “We hate you so much because we loved you so much.”

headline: In China, Fear of Fake Eggs and ‘Recycled’ Buns
text: SHANGHAI — On a bustling corner near downtown Shanghai recently, some shoppers avoided the steamed buns sold by Zhu Qinghe in a street-side cubbyhole. Instead, they bought the packaged buns in the freezer section of Hualian, a supermarket chain store in the same building.

headline: Uprooted by Rising Waters, but Not Ready to Walk Away
text: LA CENTER, Ky. — If there ever was a time for Bob Simpson to retire to his farm near this Kentucky high ground, it is now.

headline: When We Hated Mom
text: Olympia, Wash.

headline: Love and Junk Food
text: Cleveland Heights, Ohio

headline: Pitzer College in California Adds Major in Secularism
text: Colleges and universities have long offered majors in religion or theology. But with more and more people now saying they have no religion, one college has decided to be the first to offer a major in secularism.

headline: Bluegrass Blues and Grays
text: “I hope to have God on my side, but I must have Kentucky,” President Abraham Lincoln is reputed to have said in 1861. Whether or not he actually uttered these words, Lincoln made clear his views of his native state in a letter in the fall of that year. “I think to lose Kentucky is nearly the same as to lose the whole game. Kentucky gone, we can not hold Missouri, nor, as I think, Maryland. These all against us, and the job on our hands is too large for us. We would as well consent to separation at once, including the surrender of this capitol.”

headline: Another M.L.S. Star Seriously Injured
text: Real Salt Lake’s Javier Morales, one of the top players in Major League Soccer, sustained a broken left ankle Saturday in a match against Chivas USA at Rio Tinto Stadium in Sandy, Utah.

headline: Secret Held if Bin Laden Lived Here, Village Says
text: CHAK SHAH MUHAMMAD, Pakistan — Chak Shah Muhammad, a small farming village of low brick houses, poultry farms and wheat fields, is reportedly one of Osama bin Laden’s last hiding places.

headline: At Last Minute, Mets’ Young Is Scratched
text: At 7:05 p.m. Saturday, five minutes before the Mets took the field against the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Mets announced that the right-hander Chris Young would be scratched from his start because he could not get loose in the bullpen. The rookie right-hander Dillon Gee started instead.

headline: Talking to China
text: China has vowed to smooth relations with the United States. Since June, it has allowed its artificially cheap currency to rise about 5 percent against the dollar. Its huge trade surplus — a drag on global growth — has shrunk by half since its 2007 peak. During a January visit to Washington, President Hu Jintao promised to end software piracy by government agencies and procurement policies that discriminate against foreign companies. He even admitted that China had to make progress on human rights.

headline: The White House’s Bedtime Bombshell
text: As Helene Cooper, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, recalled it:

headline: Quartet to Present a Sonic Collage
text: Nicholas Kitchen, a founding member of Music From Copland House, speaks with great admiration about his violin. “It’s held together with animal glue,” he said. “There’s not a nail in it. And if you play it a certain way, with proper tone projection, it will speak comfortably to 3,000 people in a huge hall. That’s pretty amazing without even one volt of electricity.”

headline: Keeping It Classical in Interpreting French Works
text: IN a life of tremendous sweep — political refugee and Oscar winner are just two of the labels attached to his name — the pianist, composer and conductor André Previn has never stopped playing jazz. Mr. Previn, 82, started recording the music as a teenager, won a Grammy for it in his 30s and plays it, time and health allowing, in top clubs to this day.

headline: David Mamet, Gone Victorian
