text: HUDSON STAGE is doing a David Mamet play. You know what that means: fast-talking, hard-driving, foulmouthed men like the real estate agents in “Glengarry Glen Ross,” the small-time crooks in “American Buffalo” and the Hollywood types in “Speed-the-Plow.”

headline: Lakers Face Early Exit, and the Potential for Many Off-Season Departures
text: DALLAS — Kobe Bryant moved out of the giant shadow cast by Shaquille O’Neal last summer, when a grinning Bryant celebrated his fifth championship by gloating, “Just got one more than Shaq.”

headline: A Visual Look at The Times in Overdrive
text: My column this week looks at the extraordinary efforts of Times staffers as they responded to the news of Osama Bin Laden’s death in a raid by Navy Seals. Because the news broke late on print deadlines, The Times took extraordinary measures to stop the presses, remake print pages and rush to get updated copies not only to New York readers but to many readers in major cities nationwide. On top of that, the Times mounted an intense global reporting effort aimed at delivering fresh stories through the night for publication on NYTimes.com, which became the key venue for breaking developments after the print edition closed at 12:45 a.m. Monday. The result was an outpouring of fresh copy that was published online-only and then superseded eventually by new stories on Monday, some of which ultimately fed a 10-page special print section titled “The Death of Bin Laden” that was delivered Tuesday.

headline: First Things First: Feed the Fish
text: A man of many morphs, Fred Armisen, 44, formerly the drummer for the band Trenchmouth and the male half of the comedy duo ThunderAnt, is winding up his ninth season on “Saturday Night Live,” where his goofily earnest impression of President Obama is a staple. He was a creator, writer and star of the cult hit “Portlandia” this year on IFC, and is gearing up to write Season 2. Twice divorced, he spends much, if not all, of Sunday in the Upper West Side apartment he shares with Fischie, a red cap oranda.

headline: Putting Romance on the Therapist’s Couch
text: Prudence’s first date with Bruce does not go well. “He talked about my breasts,” she tells her psychiatrist, “he has a male lover, and he wept at the table.”

headline: Rules and Reality Test Chefs Who Think Locally
text: CAROLE PECK can’t forget the horseradish incident: 15 quarts of locally grown and preserved horseradish in the walk-in cooler of her well-known Woodbury restaurant, Good News Cafe, confiscated by the local health inspector.

headline: The Taut Dance of Word and Image
text: Art and literature used to be linked more closely than they are today. Poets and novelists wrote art criticism; artists painted, sculptured and photographed writers. Now, artists are more likely to depict media celebrities, and younger critics are often the product of art history departments. So it’s as if one steps back in time when visiting “Julião Sarmento: Artists and Writers/House and Home,” a cross-media show at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
Run of Seven Birdies in Nine Holes Puts Byrd in Lead
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Before this week, Jonathan Byrd had made just one cut in seven tries at the Wells Fargo Championship, and he had shot only one round in the 60s on the demanding Quail Hollow Club course.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: VSP Economics
text: Dean Baker and Mark Thoma both wax indignant — and rightly — over a WaPo editorial on economic policy, which says that we must act urgently on unemployment, then rules out any action.

headline: A Winner’s Circle Full of Firsts
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Late Thursday night, John Velazquez didn’t know what was worse, failing to get to the winner’s circle of the Kentucky Derby in 12 previous tries or not even making the starting gate with a favorite, as he had for the third straight year. He had gotten the news that Uncle Mo, last year’s Juvenile champion and racing’s latest wonder horse, was still not himself after a stomach infection and would not run.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 7
text: An attack on Misurata’s fuel terminal was another escalation against the besieged city, and the second pinpoint attack by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces in two nights.

headline: Big G.O.P. Donors Adopt Wait-and-See 2012 Tack
text: The vaunted Republican network of high-dollar donors and fund-raisers, for so long a fear factor for Democrats, has been slow to commit itself to the 2012 presidential candidates, contributing to the faltering start of the party’s drive to unseat President Obama.

headline: Nuclear Agency Is Criticized as Too Close to Its Industry
text: In the fall of 2007, workers at the Byron nuclear power plant in Illinois were using a wire brush to clean a badly corroded steel pipe — one in a series that circulate cooling water to essential emergency equipment — when something unexpected happened: the brush poked through.

headline: Now, to Find a Parking Spot, Drivers Look on Their Phones
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is the urban driver’s most agonizing everyday experience: the search for an empty parking place.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 8
text: A week after President Obama announced Osama bin Laden had been killed, the Sunday talk shows are still buzzing about what his death means for the United States. Mr. Obama’s national security adviser, Thomas E. Donilon, appears on “Fox News Sunday,” ABC’s “This Week,” NBC’s “Meet the Press” and CNN’s “State of the Union” to talk about the raid that brought down the 9/11 mastermind who has eluded capture for years.

headline: It’s All in the Programming: Computer Falls to a Beginner
text: It has been commonly accepted for about a decade that computers are better than people at chess. But a couple of weeks ago, a widely circulated story out of Ukraine suggested that a man who learned to play the game less than a year ago had beaten the world’s best chess program.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ethnic Soccer Teams Drift Toward Diversity
text: At first glance, it seems to be your average barren lot next to a railroad track, a sight not uncommon in the industrial neighborhood of Maspeth, Queens. But venture past the tall iron gates, at what is, oddly enough, considered the intersection of 59th and 60th Streets, and the Metropolitan Oval plays host to a good chunk of the city’s ethnic soccer teams.

headline: Mets Stop Ethier With a Fill-In Starter’s Help
text: The person most disappointed to learn that Chris Young would not pitch Saturday might have been on the opposing bench. At 7:05 p.m., five minutes before the scheduled start of the game, the Mets announced that Young could not get loose in the bullpen warming up and would be replaced by the rookie right-hander Dillon Gee.

headline: Rondo Plays Through Pain as Celtics Hang On
text: BOSTON — The elbow was dislocated, according to the medical report, a diagnosis that should have sent Rajon Rondo to a hospital and the Boston Celtics into an epic tailspin. Star point guards generally need two arms to carry a team, or at least to keep their passes and shots on target.

headline: Yankees Fall to the Rangers On a Play They Saw Coming
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Much happens, and much is forgotten over the course of 162 games. A result may linger, but not the final score. A great play can stick in the memory bank, but not its participants. And then there are moments that endure because of their audacity as much as their impact. One such moment occurred at Rangers Ballpark last Sept. 12, in the Yankees’ final regular-season meeting with Texas, and save for a few insignificant details it all but happened again Saturday night.

headline: Archarcharch Fractures a Leg
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Archarcharch was pulled up past the finish line of the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday after fracturing his left front leg. The injury was not life-threatening, according to an on-call veterinarian, Dr. Larry Bramlage.

headline: Designed to Sell
text: Images from the visual books under review.

headline: Kentucky Derby Replay, May 8, 2011
text: Highlights from the 137th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Pacquiao Takes Decision, but Disappoints Fans
text: LAS VEGAS — For much of his welterweight title defense on Saturday, Manny Pacquiao heard from the MGM Grand crowd a unified sound rarely belted at his boxing matches. As Pacquiao and Shane Mosley tapped gloves, made small talk and generally engaged in a glorified sparring session, the crowd, once rowdy, once standing, once into it, simply booed.

headline: Images of NASA’s Future
text: A look at the next generation of NASA space vehicles.

headline: Officers and Inmates Are Killed in Iraq Jail Revolt
text: BAGHDAD — An insurgent leader accused of plotting the deadly siege against an Iraqi church last autumn led a bloody revolt for several hours early on Sunday morning inside a Baghdad prison, the security authorities said. The prison holds some of the people suspected of being the country’s most violent terrorists.

headline: Ancient Roman Portraiture Comes to Life
text: As the Romans expanded their territory and conquered the Mediterranean, they, in turn, were captivated by the portraiture of their subjugated peoples. Images of private citizens, politicians and philosophers in Etruria (what is now central Italy) and Greece influenced the way the Romans portrayed themselves in their own artwork. These external factors were blended with local traditions and gave birth to a portraiture style that was uniquely Roman.

headline: Bird Week | Urban Bird Habitats
Is a Human “Here and Now” Bias Clouding Climate Reasoning?
text: Here’s a “Your Dot” contribution from Jacob Tanenbaum, a computer technology teacher from Tappan, N.Y., who sent the following thoughts after reading “On Birth Certificates, Climate Risk and an Inconvenient Mind“:

headline: When Technology Attacks
text: I recently received a panicked text from a friend who had bumped into his handsome crush on the street, an unrequited love interest who had stood him up after the two made plans for a casual date. He wanted to know what he should do. I hastily tapped out a reply. I tried to send “RUNNNNNN!” which my phone mistook for “SEEEEEEEEEEEEEE” and I accidentally sent that instead. My poor friend sent back a frantic “HUH!?” and I had to send a handful more to clarify and calm him down.

headline: Mother Knows Best | Alanis Morissette
text: Ironic or not, the singer-songwriter Alanis Morissette does not welcome rain or clouds this Mother’s Day. The Los Angeles-based mother is looking forward to repeating her family’s one-year-old Mother’s Day tradition of picnicking with snacks on the beach and nestling in a hammock with her husband, Mario Treadway, and son, Ever Imre, also known as “lil’ man.” She may be “new to the momma gang,” as she calls it, but Morissette isn’t opposed to enjoying every minute of her son and the holiday’s perks. On her wish list? A Gracious Home picnic basket, Lainey blanket and beach bag from Heather Heron for the family’s beach excursion and a Loup Charmant slip dress. Older traditions die hard. “I always sing ‘Happy Mother’s Day’ to my mom in the tune of ‘Happy birthday,’ ” Morissette says. “It’s a sweet little offering—a thank you for having me.”

headline: Mama Didn’t Take Your Kodachrome, She Just Moved It
text: Back in the olden days of photography — maybe 10 years ago — you carefully picked the film you used because it contributed as much to the look of your images as lighting or a lens filter. Each film had it own distinctive grain, color and contrast. If you wanted eye-popping greens for scenery, Fuji Velvia 50 was the stuff. Flattering skin tones? Kodak Portra. The list goes on.

headline: Syria Broadens Deadly Crackdown on Protesters
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A military crackdown on Syria’s seven-week uprising escalated Sunday, with reinforcements sent to two cities, more forces deployed in a southern town and nearly all communications severed to besieged locales, activists and human rights groups said. Fourteen people were killed in the city of Homs, they said, and hundreds were arrested.

headline: The Inflation Monster Under the Bed
text: I’m glad to see Greg Mankiw agreeing with me on the absence of any inflation risk in the current environment. Maybe he should have a word with everyone else in his party.

headline: Japan Reaffirms Nuclear Energy Use
text: TOKYO — Japan remains committed to nuclear power despite the crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, Prime Minister Naoto Kan indicated Sunday, as workers moved closer to repairing the crippled plant by opening the doors of a damaged reactor building.

headline: Overhaul Time for U.S. Nuclear Overseers
text: I’m convinced that the United States will be better off keeping existing nuclear power stations running, where their management can be demonstrated to be reliable, rather than initiating a decades-long decommissioning process that would not resolve community concerns about spent fuel and many other sources of risk.

headline: Clashes in Cairo Leave 12 Dead and 2 Churches in Flames
text: CAIRO — A night of street fighting between hundreds of Muslims and Christians left at least 12 people dead and two churches in flames on Sunday in the latest outbreak of sectarian tensions in the three months since the revolution that ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Dozens Injured as Train Crashes in New Jersey
text: Roughly 30 people were injured on Sunday as their PATH train in Hoboken, N.J., hit a rubberized barrier at the end of the line, said a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the line.

headline: Montage: 'A Minister's Wife'
text: Scenes from the new musical at Lincoln Center Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Hume Day
text: Henry Farrell tells me that I missed David Hume’s birthday. So, a few late notes.

headline: Jack Morris Talks About His Place in History
text: I promised myself I wouldn’t use any part of Sunday’s feature about Game 7 of the 1991 World Series to stump for Jack Morris for the Hall of Fame. I’ve done that before (here and here and here), making the case as strongly as I can. More than half of the Hall of Fame voters agree, but at 53.5 percent, he’s still well shy of the 75 percent needed for election.

headline: Southeast Asia Talks Leave Two Key Issues Unresolved
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — A meeting of Southeast Asian leaders ended here on Sunday with two significant issues unresolved, which led some analysts to question the leaders’ ability to confront entrenched problems.

headline: Vote Forces Singapore’s Leader to Reconsider Style
text: BANGKOK — Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Sunday that his People’s Action Party would re-examine its style of government after it was returned to power with its lowest percentage of the popular vote and its biggest loss of parliamentary seats since Singapore’s independence in 1965.

headline: Israeli Strike on Iran Would Be ‘Stupid,’ Ex-Spy Chief Says
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s former intelligence chief has said that a strike on Iran’s nuclear installations would be “a stupid idea,” adding that military action might not achieve all of its goals and could lead to a long war.

headline: The Invisible Bond Vigilantes Have Resumed Their Invisible Attack
text: Look at 10-year TIPS yields:

headline: A Regrettable First for U.S. Tennis
text: Monday is a historic day for United States tennis, one that will generate no rejoicing in the American tennis community.

headline: Abbas Urges Continuation of U.S. Aid Despite Agreement With Hamas
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority beseeched a group of visiting American Jews on Sunday to urge Congress not to cut off hundreds of millions of dollars in aid as a result of his recent unity agreement with Hamas, the Islamist group that controls Gaza.

headline: U.S. Raises Pressure on Pakistan in Raid’s Wake
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s national security adviser demanded Sunday that Pakistan let American investigators interview Osama bin Laden’s three widows, adding new pressure in a relationship now fraught over how Bin Laden could have been hiding near Islamabad for years before he was killed by commandos last week.

headline: Derby Winner Sets Shining Example for Wayward Industry
text: LOUSIVILLE, KY — Even though the winner has a Brazilian-bred sire and a German-bred dam, the 137th Kentucky Derby made a big run toward retaining its eminence as the world’s greatest race. The reasons are legion.

headline: Bahrain Says It Will End State of Emergency
text: JERUSALEM — The king of Bahrain said Sunday that the state of emergency he imposed in mid-March to quell antigovernment protests on that strategic and contested island will end June 1.

headline: Feel The Rapacity
text: One commenter on my inflation monster post suggests that while private-sector wages may be going nowhere, the story is different for “rapacious” workers in the public sector. Ah, those pillaging schoolteachers (because that’s largely who we’re talking about).

headline: Reads & Reactions
text: In this edition of Reads & Reactions: partisan labels, gasoline politics, a G.O.P. debate, birth certificates and blogging for free.

headline: Vettel Dominates Eventful Turkish Grand Prix
text: ISTANBUL — Sebastian Vettel cruised from pole to victory in the Turkish Grand Prix on Sunday, taking his third victory out of four races this season.

headline: Vettel Dominates Eventful Turkish Grand Prix
text: ISTANBUL — Sebastian Vettel cruised from pole to victory in the Turkish Grand Prix on Sunday, taking his third victory out of four races this season.

headline: Nearing 50th Birthday, Pate Looks Forward to New Tour
text: ATHENS, Ga. — What does Steve Pate have to look forward to when he turns 50 at the end of this month?

headline: European Ventures Seek to Fill a Void in World News
text: PARIS — As news organizations around the world close down foreign bureaus, journalists, entrepreneurs and even government bodies in Europe are creating news ventures to try to fill the void.

headline: Muscle Memory: The Training of Navy Seals Commandos
text: They are America’s Jedi knights: the elite of the elite, an all-star team of commandos, “tier one” special operations warriors given mission-impossible assignments in the most dangerous parts of the planet. A week ago, when Seal Team 6 took out public enemy No. 1, Osama bin Laden, Jon Stewart hailed its members as real-life “X-Men,” ABC compared them to Superman, and Newsweek described them as “the coolest guys in the world,” working “anonymously and without public recognition.” Each year, according to the Navy Seals Web site, about 1,000 men start Seals training, and usually about only 200 to 250 succeed. Basic training includes the infamous “hell week”: five and a half days in which candidates sleep only a total of four hours and must run more than 200 miles, and do physical training for more than 20 hours per day. And after years of more training, only a fraction of experienced Seals members go on to join Seal Team 6, a secret unit created after the failed attempt in 1980 to rescue American hostages in Iran and tasked mainly with counterterrorism and counterinsurgency assignments.

headline: The Morning Line: Spoils Go to Animal Kingdom
text: With the running of the Kentucky Derby, the saga of Uncle Mo has largely been forgotten, and all the news concerns the running and the race and the victory of 20 -1 Animal Kingdom.

headline: Feeding Time at the Nest
text: A video recorded on Sunday submitted by a reader, Jeff Folmsbee.

headline: A Well-Traveled Sailor Tackles Prospect Park
text: Under an angry sky, the young captain stood the helm surveying unfamiliar waters.

headline: Young Put on D.L.; Offense Can’t Pick Up Slack
text: Black equipment bags cluttered the floor of the Mets’ clubhouse late Sunday afternoon, a sign that the team was about to hit the road. So much has gone right for the Mets in the last 18 days that they generally regarded splitting a six-game homestand as a disappointment.

headline: O’Neal, No Stranger to Change, May Soon See More
text: BOSTON — Shaquille O’Neal received an ovation from the TD Garden crowd for standing up and walking to the scorer’s table late in the first quarter. Along the way, he sustained no injury and made it through eight and a half minutes of his first game action in more than two months.

headline: AOL’s Leader Undaunted in Overhaul Efforts
text: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Tim Armstrong, AOL’s chief executive, will tell just about anyone who will listen that AOL is not some washed-up tech company from another era.

headline: Now to Sell Advertisers on Tablets
text: If you wanted to get your message in front of a reader of The New Yorker, it would cost you $141,174 for a full-page ad in the magazine’s glossy pages.

headline: Television’s Curse Was Its Blessing
text: Television shows, Web sites and apps are not considered cultural artifacts, and never will be. They’re public health hazards, like cigarettes and junk food.

headline: To Grow, an Agency Breaks Down Walls
text: A LEADING digital agency is expanding its portfolio of services as part of efforts to help wean marketers and other agencies — and perhaps reporters, too — off the notion that agencies still need to be labeled “digital” or “traditional.”

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: An ‘Idol’ Reunion on ‘The X Factor’
text: Simon Cowell’s televised singing competition “The X Factor,” coming to Fox in September, now appears to have a complete cast. Fox announced on Saturday that the singer Nicole Scherzinger and British television personality Steve Jones would host the show. And on Sunday Paula Abdul was named a judge. Ms. Abdul will fill the final seat at the judges’ table, where Mr. Cowell, Antonio Reid (known as L..A.) and Cheryl Cole will also sit.

headline: Incentives Play Role in Success of Netflix
text: Employees eligible for stock options can adjust the mix of salary and equity in their pay, and options are granted monthly rather than annually.

headline: The Partisan Corners of the News
Plush and Lyrical Strauss (and That’s Just the Conducting)
text: These days people may forget that Fabio Luisi, the Metropolitan Opera’s principal guest conductor, made his acclaimed company debut in 2005 in Verdi’s “Don Carlo.” In the last couple of seasons Mr. Luisi has appeared at the company mostly as a pinch-hitter for James Levine. In April he stepped in again for an ailing Mr. Levine and conducted a compelling performance of Wagner’s “Rheingold.”

headline: A Digital Critique of a Famous Autobiography
text: I ARRIVED at Butler Library on the Columbia campus last week, showed my ID and was directed to a fifth-floor room where I could examine in person a trove of documents related to Malcolm X.

headline: Monday: No Matter What Happens
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always a pleasure to see people who are longtime solvers learn the art of puzzle construction. Constructing is a totally different skill set than solving, and contrary to popular opinion, it’s also a different skill set than that needed to be good at a game like Scrabble.

headline: Nurturer of Authors Is Closing the Book
text: If anyone is qualified to talk about the good old days of book publishing, it is Robert Loomis.

headline: A Crusher of Cars, a Molder of Metal
text: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y. — When a visitor pulled up outside an elegant shingled house here on a recent morning, three intact cars with familiar names — a Mitsubishi, a Land Rover, a Ford — were parked in the driveway. Next to them, wheel-less and sitting atop shipping pallets, were two sinuous, towering conglomerations of paint-encrusted steel that had clearly once been cars but that had been crushed, twisted, crumpled and squeezed into another realm of existence, somewhere between oblivion and timelessness.

headline: Cavendish Craftiness
text: The final 28-board session of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs was played on Sunday in Henderson, Nev., ending late in the day. (Results are at cavendish.bridgewinners.com.) Leading going into Sunday were Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein, who were trying for a threepeat.

headline: Obama’s YouTube Star Turn
text: President Obama was a YouTube star twice over the last week.

headline: Casting Light on Taiwanese Cinema
text: At the turn of the century Taiwanese cinema had a moment, albeit a quiet one that the average American filmgoer probably missed. Edward Yang’s magnificent family drama “Yi Yi” was named the best film of 2000, in any language, by the National Society of Film Critics. Hou Hsiao-Hsien and Tsai Ming-Liang, Mr. Yang’s compatriots in the movement known as the Taiwanese New Wave or the New Taiwan Cinema, were at or near the peaks of their renown; Mr. Hou’s “Millennium Mambo” and Mr. Tsai’s “What Time Is It Over There?” were both released in 2001.

headline: Tens of Thousands March in Mexico City
text: MEXICO CITY — Javier Sicilia, the poet who has become an unlikely hero in a movement calling for an end to Mexico’s drug war, asked for five minutes of silence at the end of a Sunday rally in this city’s giant central plaza.

headline: Jeter Finds Power Stroke, and Texas Pays
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Divining the key to Derek Jeter’s success over 17 seasons is not difficult. He abides by a simple credo, believing that keeping things uncomplicated is the only way to live. As his Yankees teammates and coaches hailed his revival after Sunday’s 12-5 victory against the Rangers, Jeter offered a verbal shrug.

headline: The Mystery That Won’t Go Away
text: It is hard to think of another mystery in recent history that has fired the engines of cultural production quite like the disappearance of Natalee Holloway, the Alabama teenager presumed to have been killed during a senior class trip to Aruba in 2005. The case has been the subject of more than a half-dozen nonfiction books (the latest, “Portrait of a Monster: Joran van der Sloot, a Murder in Peru, and the Natalee Holloway Mystery,” arrives in July), episodes on both “Law & Order: SVU” and “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” uncountable hours of “Nancy Grace” on CNN and an entire subspecies of dramatic programming on Lifetime.

headline: Diving Into the Simulacrum, Moptop First
text: Yuck really nails the drone, that low, slow guitar moan of the early 1990s — not guttural in a grunge way, but something a little more restrained and polite, maybe even a bit resigned.

headline: Something Borrowed and Something New
text: Spring for Music, the new festival of North American symphony and chamber orchestras at Carnegie Hall, started on a relatively subdued note on Friday night with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, but caught fire on Saturday evening with the Toledo Symphony.

headline: Response to Volatility in Silver Takes Hold
text: On April 25, half a dozen officials from the CME Group, which runs many of the nation’s commodities exchanges, met via videophone to discuss the eye-popping rise in the price of silver, which had doubled in just six months to about $47 a troy ounce.

headline: Roaring Back With Rumba and Religion
text: Rhythm serves both gods and lovers in the music of Los Muñequitos de Matanzas, the venerable Cuban group that returned to New York City last week for the first time since 2002 with concerts at Symphony Space. Presented by the World Music Institute, the three shows were part of the citywide ¡Sí Cuba! festival.

headline: Bacharach Musical to Open in San Diego
text: Burt Bacharach’s new musical, “Some Lovers,” will have its debut at the Old Globe theater in San Diego this year, Playbill reported. Mr. Bacharach, whose “I Say a Little Prayer” and “Do You Know the Way to San Jose?” are among his most famous pop songs, wrote the music to the show, which is based on “The Gift of the Magi,” the O. Henry short story. The book and lyrics are by Steven Sater (“Spring Awakening”). “Some Lovers” is to run Nov. 26 to Dec. 31 as part of the Old Globe’s 2011-12 season, which also includes the premieres of works by Matthew Lopez (“The Whipping Man”), Gaby Alter and Itamar Moses, and Jonathan Caren, as well as the West Coast premiere of “The Scottsboro Boys.”

headline: ‘Thor’ Shows Box-Office Muscle
text: Marvel did it again: “Thor,” a thundering big-screen debut for the comic-book realm’s god of thunder, played by Chris Hemsworth, right, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with an estimated $66 million in ticket sales. Imax theaters, showing their might with the fan-boy audience, contributed a notable 10 percent of that total. “Thor” (produced by Disney-owned Marvel for about $150 million and distributed by Paramount Pictures) has taken in an additional $176 million overseas. “Fast Five” (Universal Pictures) dropped 62 percent in its second weekend to second place, taking in about $32.5 million for a new total of about $140 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. “Jumping the Broom” (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was third with a stronger-than-expected $13.7 million. “Something Borrowed,” a romantic comedy from Warner Brothers, was fourth with about $13.2 million. “Rio” (20th Century Fox) chugged along in fifth place, selling about $8.2 million in tickets for a four-week total of $114.9 million. “The Beaver,” representing Mel Gibson’s first film since his domestic meltdown and Jodie Foster’s third attempt at directing, was essentially ignored, taking in $104,000 in 22 theaters.

headline: Contrite Cisco Regroups Before Skeptical Wall St.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — John T. Chambers, one of the best salesmen in Silicon Valley, has been having trouble selling anyone on his company’s future.

headline: Books to Square Off on a Facebook App
text: Simon & Schuster has created a Facebook app called Book Battle, a literary version of hotornot.com. Users can vote on book covers, games, authors or characters, which will be presented in slide-show format. The app could give the publisher the opportunity to gauge readers’ preferences, drum up interest in its books and build a presence in social media. The first matchups on the app will feature two young-adult series by Cassandra Clare, “The Mortal Instruments” and “The Infernal Devices,” the publisher said on Sunday.

headline: Exit for Jackson Comes Sooner Than Expected
text: DALLAS — Phil Jackson took the final stroll alone. His players rushed in front of him and into an off-season of scrutiny and uncertainty. His faithful assistants — Frank Hamblen, Brian Shaw and Jim Cleamons — paced behind him. Away from the court and in the concrete maze in the depths of the American Airlines Center, Jackson cracked a smile, the calm in the storm, during his walk toward retirement Sunday.

headline: Favoring Immigration if Not the Immigrant
text: WASHINGTON — So deeply has the phrase “a nation of immigrants” seeped into the American psyche that millions of people reflexively use it while few know who coined the phrase. (It was Senator John F. Kennedy, in a 1958 book by that name.)

headline: ‘Ariadne auf Naxos’
text: Photos from the production at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: A TV Project Planned on Female Leadership
text: The Independent Television Service and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting are teaming up for a three-year, 50-film project called “Women and Girls Lead,” which will put a documentary spotlight on leadership roles of women and girls and the challenges they face in the United States and worldwide.

headline: Reaction to Manchester United-Chelsea
text: Manchester United essentially won the Premier League title on Sunday, stunning Chelsea with a first-minute goal by Javier Hernandez and holding on to win, 2-1.

headline: N.F.L. Considers Forcing New Testing Standards
text: The N.F.L. has talked to the World Anti-Doping Agency about overseeing testing of players for performance-enhancing drugs if a federal appeals court forces the league to stop the lockout and put in place rules for operating the league this season, an N.F.L. official briefed on its planning said.

headline: A Daring Improviser Who Made Amazing Look Simple
text: The joy of watching the world’s best golfers, especially Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods, involved their accuracy and precision. In the fairway off the tee, on the green in regulation, often with a makeable birdie putt. But with Seve Ballesteros, the dashing matador from Spain who died over the weekend with complications from a brain tumor, the joy was watching him escape from tangled rough or clumps of bushes or towering tree limbs.

headline: Bulldogs Under the Rug? Signs of a Putin-Medvedev Rift
text: MOSCOW — For three years, the power-sharing tandem of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin and President Dmitri A. Medvedev purred along like a sports car, quieting skeptics who said that any division of executive authority in Russia would lead to instability. The ambiguous arrangement seemed to soothe tensions, allowing everyone, from pro-Western technocrats to hawkish hard-liners, to believe they were represented at the very top.

headline: Justice Dept. to Continue Policy Against Same-Sex Marriage
text: After two instances in which deportations were suspended in immigration cases involving same-sex couples, the Justice Department has cautioned that it will continue to enforce a law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages.

headline: A Jewish Date, Then a Movie
text: LOS ANGELES — JDate, the Web-based dating service, has been helping singles “find friendship, romance and lifelong partners within the Jewish faith.” It can also hook you up with a movie.

headline: Tight Race for Congress Prompts Visit by Boehner
text: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, plans to visit upstate New York on Monday to support the struggling campaign of a Republican candidate who is running for a vacant seat in Congress.

text: The South makes a slow recovery from record tornadoes that swept the region this spring.

headline: New Top 10s Won’t Include Any Americans
text: Monday is a historic day for United States tennis, one that will generate no rejoicing in the American tennis community. In the nearly 40 years since the inception of computer rankings, it will be the first time that no man or woman from the United States is ranked in the top 10 in the world in singles. Christopher Clarey looks at what has gone wrong. Read the article, and come back to this post to comment.

headline: Broad Taliban Attack Paralyzes Kandahar
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — For more than 30 hours over the weekend, the Taliban immobilized the southern city of Kandahar, unleashing multiple attacks with small arms and suicide bombers near the city’s downtown, pinning down people in their homes, forcing shops to close and halting most traffic.

headline: Suit Opens a Window Into Google
text: A stack of internal e-mail messages from Google, which a Massachusetts state court made public last week, provide a glimpse into the competitive tactics and decision-making inside a business that is crucial to the company’s growth — its Android software for smartphones.

headline: Mexico Takes Aim at a Titan in Telecom
text: MEXICO CITY — In the two decades that Carlos Slim Helú has turned a crumbling Mexican phone monopoly into a continental telecom giant, he has successfully fought off competitors and challenged authorities who wanted to limit his companies’ control.

headline: After a Ho-Hum Victory, Pacquiao Is Running Out of Challengers
text: LAS VEGAS — Late Saturday, at his postfight news conference, Manny Pacquiao looked less like a combatant in a welterweight prize fight and more like a congressman emerging from a bargaining session. He appeared tired, but wore neither bandages nor bruises; his face was unmarked, his body unharmed, except, perhaps, for a touch of wounded pride.

headline: Beijing Blames Foreigners for Its Fears of Unrest
text: BEIJING — Chinese and American officials are polishing off scripts for a ritual that is set to unfold in Washington on Monday and Tuesday. During a meeting known as the Strategic and Economic Dialogue, they will smile across conference tables and talk about cooperating on a range of issues: trade, currency, North Korea.

headline: Mildred Leet, 88, Who Helped Empower the Poor, Dies
text: Mildred Robbins Leet, a philanthropist who was a co-founder of Trickle Up, one of the first nonprofits to provide microgrants, typically of $100, to help poor people start their own businesses, died on Tuesday in Manhattan.  She was 88.

headline: In Cable Niches, Less Reality and More Original Shows
text: Stacy Littlejohn worked her way up in network television like so many other writers and producers — she was a writers’ assistant on a Fox show, a joke writer on a CW show, a writer-producer on a half-hour ABC show.

headline: Hitting the Bottle
text: SUDDENLY, there’s a baby boom going on around me. I’m making weekly shopping trips to stock friends’ nurseries, and I’m struck by how many signs on the shelves advertise BPA-free bottles, BPA-free sippy cups. It breaks my heart. Manufacturers might be removing BPA, a chemical used to harden certain plastics, from their products, but they are substituting chemicals that may be just as dangerous, if not more so.

headline: The Unwisdom of Elites
text: The past three years have been a disaster for most Western economies. The United States has mass long-term unemployment for the first time since the 1930s. Meanwhile, Europe’s single currency is coming apart at the seams. How did it all go so wrong?

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Russia Kills 8 Militants in South
text: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities announced Sunday that eight insurgents were killed in a large counterterrorism operation in the southern region of Dagestan.

headline: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for April and wholesale trade inventories for March (Tuesday); the trade deficit for March (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for April, retail sales for April, weekly jobless claims and business inventories for March (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for April and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for May (Friday).

headline: The Debt Limit Negotiations
text: Republican leaders and White House officials will meet on Tuesday to continue talks on the federal debt limit. They need to tread very carefully here.

headline: Can You Explain the War Powers Act?
text: The Department of Education’s latest assessment of what young Americans know about civics shows that the light of democracy burns steadily in schools, if too dimly.

headline: Boarding? Denied. Lock and Loading? Sure.
text: Here is a chilling and potentially lethal fact of life: A person on the F.B.I.’s terrorist watch list is barred from boarding an airplane yet is quite free to buy high-power firearms and ammunition at any American gun shop.

headline: In Buffalo, Visions, Perhaps Illusions, of a University-Fueled Revitalization
text: BUFFALO — This city has lost more than one-tenth of its residents in the last decade, and it shows.

headline: Culture of Calm Is Threatened by Budget Cuts
text: As students funneled through the doors of Roberto Clemente High School on a recent Friday, Cristina Pacione-Zayas, the school’s Culture of Calm coordinator, could barely finish a conversation before her walkie-talkie summoned her to the next one.

headline: 50 Years After Trial, Eichmann Secrets Live On
text: BERLIN — Germany is famous for confronting its Nazi past. But confronting the years after the war is another matter. The latest proof comes as the country’s foreign intelligence agency, the BND, refuses to declassify several thousand secret files detailing what Adolf Eichmann, the high-ranking Nazi who helped orchestrate the Holocaust, was doing between 1945 and his capture by Mossad agents in Buenos Aires in 1960. More than a few Germans have been speculating that the refusal has as much to do with tarnishing a cherished era as with betraying potential sources.

headline: After a Tornado, Solace on the Ball Field
text: RINGGOLD, Ga. — Around sunset 12 days ago, Slade Dale, a Ringgold High School ninth grader, took shelter in the bathroom with his sister and father as a tornado bore down on their rental home.

headline: A Bleak Life, Cut Short at 4, Harrowing From the Start
text: She died in September by the ugliest means, weighing an unthinkable 18 pounds, half what a 4-year-old ought to. She withered in poverty in a home in Brooklyn where the authorities said she had been drugged and often bound to a toddler bed by her mother, having realized a bare thimble’s worth of living.

headline: Seeking Business, States Loosen Insurance Rules
text: Companies looking to do business in secret once had to travel to places like the Cayman Islands or Bermuda.

headline: A Fatah-Hamas Deal
text: Ultimately, a successful Palestinian state will need to have all its people, from both the West Bank and Gaza, working together to build a stable and prosperous future. The recent agreement between the two main factions — Fatah, which leads the Palestinian Authority and has committed to peace with Israel, and Hamas, which has committed to Israel’s destruction — is not the answer.

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Sites Raised U.S. Concerns, Cables Show
text: TOKYO — American officials repeatedly raised concerns about the security of Japanese nuclear plants from terrorist attacks but in at least one case were rebuffed by local officials, according to classified State Department cables made available by WikiLeaks.

headline: Hawk and Hatchling Have Wide Audience, and a New Threat in an ID Tag
text: After braving weeks of harsh weather and the risk of accidentally eating a poisoned rat, a red-tailed hawk named Violet became a mother on Friday morning when an eyas, or baby hawk, hatched from one of her eggs. But over the weekend a new threat to Violet emerged — a metal wildlife band constricting blood flow to her leg and making it swell to at least twice its usual size.

headline: With Legs Churning, Reyes Makes the Case to Stay
text: The five letters on the billboard in the deepest part of Citi Field read G-E-I-C-O, but they ought to read R-E-Y-E-S. The Mets’ ballpark is a monument to garish advertising, but also a playpen for Jose Reyes, their most exciting player.

headline: When Wearing Golf Shoes Off the Course Means Breaking News
text: I’m happy President Obama is a golfer; it’s great for the game. But he is setting some golfing benchmarks I did not expect.

headline: The Kushner Flap: Much Ado About Nothing
text: On May 5, the historian Ellen Schrecker of Yeshiva University gave back an honorary degree she had received from John Jay College because the playwright Tony Kushner had been denied the same honor by the CUNY Board of Trustees.  At the urging of a trustee who objected to Kushner’s  views on Israel, the nomination, which had been forwarded by the faculty and administration of John Jay, was tabled.  (Kushner had been informed of the impending honor.)

headline: Family Feuds
text: The narrative of the Civil War revolves around the metaphor of neighbor against neighbor, brother against brother. But in the mountains of the Upper South, this was no metaphor: counties, towns and even families split between the two sides, and then set upon each other with gruesome fury in one of the bloodiest — and least understood — theaters of the war.

headline: Tour Bus Driver Charged in Pedestrian Death on West Side
text: The driver of a tour bus was charged with drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter after being involved in an accident that killed a pedestrian on a West Side street, the police said Sunday.

headline: Stories From the City
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Whose Foreign Policy Is It?
text: For those with eyes to see, the daylight between the foreign policies of George W. Bush and Barack Obama has been shrinking ever since the current president took the oath of office. But last week made it official: When the story of America’s post-9/11 wars is written, historians will be obliged to assess the two administrations together, and pass judgment on the Bush-Obama era.

headline: Beating Friend in Playoff, Glover Ends Drought
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When he won last, Lucas Glover was one of golf’s up-and-comers, a smooth-faced 20-something from the Deep South with a homespun wit and one tour victory. A long hitter who came into the 2009 United States Open at the Black Course at Long Island’s Bethpage State Park as an unknown, he won over the locals and left town with his first major championship.

headline: In Kansas Courtroom, Echoes of Rwanda Genocide
text: WICHITA, Kan. — The faces in the jury box are a cross-section of southern Kansas. The judge has a white beard, wears a bow tie and speaks in the straightforward language of the Great Plains. One defense lawyer favors cowboy boots and sometimes dons bolo ties.

headline: Celtics Face Quandary in Injury to Rondo
text: WALTHAM, Mass. — In basketball, the elbow is a multipurpose tool. It is used for dribbling, shooting, passing and, occasionally, to send messages (as in, when they are thrown). It is useful to have two, and vital to have at least one in working order.

headline: Three Hearts Butt Heads in One Marriage
text: Small stirrings of the heart and mind evoke delicate musical responses in “A Minister’s Wife,” the lovingly composed chamber musical that opened on Sunday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Based on “Candida,” George Bernard Shaw’s comedy about the mysteries of marital love, the musical moves with a gentle step, keeping an intimate focus on its central characters as they circle one another in a cozy London study that becomes the site of a well-mannered moral and intellectual boxing match.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 8
text: Rebels and government forces clashed in Misurata on Sunday as the nation continued to wait out the struggle for power.

headline: Brooklyn Teachers Joined at the Hip, and, to Some Pupils, by a Hyphen
text: In 1999, when Our Lady of Perpetual Help High School closed, Margaret Doria and Anita Dente feared it would be the end of them. For 33 years, Ms. Dente, the school’s Italian teacher, and Ms. Doria, an English teacher, had worked together, car-pooled together to the school in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finished each other’s sentences.

headline: Privacy Disappears at a Trial About Rape
text: Possible rape victims have long been afforded an extra layer of protection from public scrutiny. The news media typically withhold their names, and law enforcement authorities are careful not to release information like tape recordings or public documents that may reveal their identities.

headline: Stars Gain Control of Online Images
text: When Tom Hanks posts a message to Twitter leading his 1.8 million followers to view a photo, perhaps of him in a candid moment on a movie set, they are sent to a special kind of site, one that gives him and other celebrities new control over their presence on social media.

China to Improve Nuclear Safety
text: HONG KONG — China plans to improve its emergency procedures in response to potential problems that became apparent after Japan’s nuclear accident in March, the official newspaper, China Daily, reported Monday.

headline: Battle Over Health Care Law Shifts to Federal Appellate Courts
text: A five-week flurry of federal appellate hearings on the constitutionality of the Obama health care law kicks off Tuesday in Richmond, Va., beginning the second round of a race to the Supreme Court among a multitude of litigants eager to strike down the president’s signature domestic achievement.

headline: Democrats See Strategy to End Big Oil Tax Breaks
text: WASHINGTON — Linking two of the politically volatile issues of the moment, Senate Democrats say they will move forward this week with a plan that would eliminate tax breaks for big oil companies and divert the savings to offset the deficit.

text: In bright daylight, for all to see, Pat Gallagher handed a foursome a can of cooking spray to carry around on the golf course. It was as if he had given a batter a corked bat to take up to the plate.

headline: Obama Elaborates on Bin Laden Raid
text: President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday that his advisers were conflicted over sending Navy Seal commandos after Osama bin Laden inside Pakistan, and that their intelligence suggested only a slightly better-than-even chance that Bin Laden was inside the walled compound where they found and killed him May 2.

text: Politically speaking, President Obama walks taller now that American commandos, on his order, found and killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: Study in Korea Puts Autism’s Prevalence at 2.6%, Surprising Experts
text: An ambitious six-year effort to gauge the rate of childhood autism in a middle-class South Korean city has yielded a figure that stunned experts and is likely to influence the way the disorder’s prevalence is measured around the world, scientists reported on Monday.

headline: In Madrid, Disparate Art Collections Collide
text: It can be a bit of a buzz kill to walk into one of those cozy little “time-capsule” museums that feature the private collection of an enlightened prince or recreate life in that particular place during an earlier century, only to discover that the museum has brought in contemporary art to “dialogue” with their historical holdings. Such presentations can easily break the spell of time travel that so-called house museums typically offer, without helping the visitor appreciate or understand the art of either epoch.

headline: Ten Ideas for ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: I’m imagining the “Two and a Half Men” writers these days thusly: four days without sleep, living off Ho Ho’s and Coke (that’s the cake and the drink, people), clumps of hair strewn on the ground. As Bill Carter reported in The Times in late April, the writers have been given less than three weeks to come up with a newish version of their hit comedy. They are no doubt under just a teensy bit of pressure to produce something with the same award-winning, ratings-generating, money-raking-in qualities as the original, while also having to abruptly write out a major character, Charlie Harper, the jingle-writing cad brother played by Charlie Sheen until he was fired by Warner Brothers in March.

headline: One on One: Ayesha Khanna, Futurist
text: Ayesha Khanna is the director of the Hybrid Reality Institute, a think tank that explores the practical implications of what she refers to as “human-technology co-evolution in the Hybrid Age.” The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Ms. Khanna.

headline: Chinese Crackdown on Domestic Critics Extends to Writer Barred From Traveling
text: HONG KONG — In the latest sign of China’s continuing crackdown on domestic critics, a prominent Chinese writer has been barred from leaving China to attend a literary festival next week in Australia, the writer and festival officials said Monday.

headline: Where’s the App to Help You Read the Menu?
text: Earlier this week, I was at Delfina, a really nice San Francisco restaurant. Everything on the menu looked either delicious or unintelligible. Did I want the salad with “prosecco-black pepper zabaglione” or the one with “pancetta” and “Parmigiano frico?” Was I in the mood for a main dish with “sepia” and “ceci inzimino,” or was I more in a “gremolata” mood?

headline: Aside From the Vampires, Lincoln Film Seeks Accuracy
text: EDGARD, La. — Mary Todd Lincoln, in shimmering evening wear, calls to her husband. They are late. A gaunt, black-clad president strides to join her in a horse-drawn carriage bound for Ford’s Theater.

headline: Libyan Woman Who Claimed Rape Flees to Tunisia
text: Eman al-Obeidy, the Libyan women who burst into a Tripoli hotel filled with journalists in late March and described a brutal rape by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, fled to Tunisia on Thursday, CNN reports.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Respond to the Kushner Storm
text: Last week’s decision by the City University of New York board of trustees to withhold an honorary degree from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Tony Kushner because of one trustee’s concerns about Mr. Kushner’s views about Israel prompted many comments on NYTimes.com and letters to the editor. Readers on the ArtsBeat and City Room blogs called the situation “shameful,” “sad,” “unfortunate” and “very Talibanish.” Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The New York Times, wrote a Theater Talkback essay in support of Mr. Kushner, calling him “one of our most high-reaching dramatists.”

headline: The Price Tag of a ‘Safety’ School Enhances Its Allure

It’s an auspicious feeling as I make my final choices that will guide the beginning of the rest of my life. Senior year is almost over, A.P. exams are close at hand, and all of my classes are winding down into review.

So they came up with a plan: They would hold their own festival featuring films they thought portrayed troops in a more accurate, and positive, light.

headline: Huntsman Says No ‘Self-Financing’ if He Runs

headline: The New York Times Polling Practices: An Introduction
text: The New York Times and CBS News began the first newspaper-television polling partnership between two major national news organizations in 1975. A "CBS Evening News" report on American attitudes toward President Ford's response to the possible default of New York City was introduced by Walter Cronkite on Nov. 4, 1975. The next morning, readers of The Times saw a front-page article by Robert Reinhold titled, "Poll Finds Public Thinks Ford Minimizes City Peril."

headline: Feudin’ and Fussin’ Over a ‘Beverly Hillbillies’ Barbie Doll
text: Y’all get a good intellectual property lawyer now, you hear? Come and listen to our story about a woman named Donna Douglas, an actress who for nine seasons kept herself fed by playing Elly May Clampett, the comely daughter of mountaineer Jed Clampett on “The Beverly Hillbillies.” But then one day, some 40 years after that hit comedy series went off the air, Ms. Douglas took notice of a Barbie doll designed to look like the Elly May character and filed suit against Barbie manufacturer Mattel, saying the toy uses her likeness without her permission, Reuters reported.

headline: Gingrich to Announce Candidacy Online on Wednesday
text: Trying to tap into the spontaneity of Twitter and Facebook, Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, will announce his campaign for the Republican nomination for president on Wednesday by way of the two popular social networking sites, his spokesman, Rick Tyler, said in a Twitter post on Monday.

headline: Syria Proclaims It Now Has Upper Hand Over Uprising
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The Syrian government has gained the upper hand over a seven-week uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, a senior official declared Monday, in the clearest sign yet that the leadership believes its crackdown will crush protests that have begun to falter in the face of hundreds of deaths and mass arrests.
