text: Chad Hurley and Steve Chen, the co-founders of YouTube, are on a shopping spree.

headline: U.N. Urges Ships to Help Migrants in Mediterranean
text: PARIS — The United Nations refugee agency has urged the crews of ships in the Mediterranean to keep watch for unseaworthy vessels carrying migrants from war-torn Libya after a report that a ship with 600 people on board broke up just off the port of Tripoli on Friday.

headline: Shirtless Schock on Cover of Men’s Health
text: Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois, who already had the distinction of being the youngest member of the House, has a new feather in his cap (or maybe, his gym bag): he is the first member of Congress to appear shirtless on the cover of Men’s Health magazine.

headline: On Our Radar: Tigers Found in Indonesian Logging Concession
text: A video and photographs captured by the World Wide Fund for Nature show a dozen highly endangered tigers living within an Indonesian logging concession that could be cleared if a forest protection deal is not finalized, the group said in a statement. The Indonesian government has tentatively agreed to a two-year moratorium on new logging permits under a $1 billion deal with Norway to reduce the carbon emissions associated with deforestation, but the plan has yet to be signed into law. [Reuters]

headline: Baptist Relief Effort
text: The Southern Baptist Convention volunteers are playing a central role in relief efforts for victims of tornadoes that struck Alabama.

headline: Lieutenant Governor, Not Cuomo, Attends Gay Rights Rally
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was conspicuously absent on Monday as more than 1,000 New Yorkers gathered at the State Capitol for the annual lobby day in support of gay rights.

headline: Battle Hymn of the Small-Business Tiger Mother
text: As usual on this Mother’s Day, I found myself not only being waited on by my husband and two sons but also reflecting on my own experiences of motherhood and how I’m measuring up. As a mother and small- business owner, I often find myself squeezed by the double whammy of guilt: time spent in my business is time spent away from my kids, while time with my kids is time away from my business. They all need me, and the struggle to “be there” is ongoing.

headline: The Best Investment Advice: Stop Losing Money
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: At DeMatha, Sports and Music Play Well Together
text: HYATTSVILLE, Md. — The new gym at DeMatha Catholic High is named for a Hall of Fame basketball coach and his wife, and its foyer is lined with championship banners for all the sports the school offers and usually dominates. On a recent afternoon, football players ran sprints under the gaze of coaches from Stanford, Virginia, West Virginia and Duke.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Here They Stood, Until They Ran
text: MISURATA, Libya — The family photo albums, abandoned on the sand, lay open and fluttering in the desert wind. Around them were the personal items with which they had been packed: heaps of clothing, sandals, DVDs, combs, bottles of perfume, cooking utensils, razors, toothbrushes, several teapots, bundled blankets and a few biscuits, broken and dry. Every several yards a dropped suitcase rested on the dirt, looted bare.

headline: Nine Is Enough
text: Melissa Fay Greene, who wrote the Lives essay in yesterday’s magazine, was well qualified to fill the Mother’s Day slot. She and her husband have six sons and three daughters. Or four children by birth and five from foreign orphanages. Divide it however you want; it’s nine kids. This column isn’t about motherhood, exactly, but it shows the way a mother sees and, in Greene’s case, how much she loves seeing her athletically gifted son Fisseha run like the wind. (Her children could field their own baseball team, but Fisseha’s sport of choice is soccer.)

headline: Mississippi River Crowds Memphis
text: MEMPHIS — The Mississippi River was approaching levels it has not reached in over 70 years as it rolled through here on Monday, attracting a festive crowd of spectators to its banks but also sending residents from their homes in some parts of the city as the river shoved its tributaries aside to make way.

headline: Donnelly to Run for Senate in Indiana
text: Representative Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana, announced Monday that he would run for the Senate, declaring, “I want to take the fight for American jobs and opportunity to the United States Senate.”

headline: Gender Neutral Parenting
text: Are gender differences nature or nurture?

headline: A Jockey’s View of the Derby
text: With the help of Trakus, which uses global positioning technology to keep track of every horse in a race, viewers can simulate what it was like for John Velazquez as he rode Animal Kingdom to victory in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

headline: Should I Be a Jerk or a Human Being on Facebook?
text: I want to talk about Facebook as it pertains to identity and public image, but in order to do that, I have to tell a story first.

headline: When Demented Patients Receive Feeding Tubes
text: I wrote a few months back about one of the toughest decisions families face as their elders falter: whether to allow insertion of a feeding tube.   Somehow, this question seems to stir up even more doubt and anxiety than other medical interventions intended to prolong or improve life. When a senior nears death and cannot speak for herself, we may find it easier to say no to cardiopulmonary resuscitation or a ventilator than to say no to nutrition.

headline: How We Could Lose in Libya
text: From a Kenneth Pollack essay making the case for Western escalation:

headline: More on the Change at Chloé
text: In a phone interview, Geoffroy de la Bourdonnaye, chief executive at Chloé, shed a bit more light on Monday’s news. First, he praised Hannah MacGibbon, saying: “I think she’s been extremely good for the house. She put the house back on track, no question about it.” Ms. MacGibbon, who was promoted to creative director in 2008, helped restore attention to the feminine brand, which had briefly faltered under its previous designer.

headline: Eating Local Honey Cures Allergies
text: THE FACTS

headline: Lakers Go Out With a Thud
text: It is not generally fair to compare teams’ fates across sports. They are different games and circumstances, ruled by entirely different committees of the sporting gods. That said, we’ll do it anyway because the Lakers and the Red Wings responded so remarkably differently this weekend when faced with the epitaph being written on their dynasties.

headline: ‘Disease of Kings’ Trickles Down to the Rest
text: A 55-year-old neighbor of mine was awakened in the wee hours of the morning recently with an excruciating pain in his right big toe that rendered him unable to walk. As happens in a classic attack of gout, the onset was sudden and the affected joint red and swollen.

headline: Belgian Cyclist Dies After Crashing in Giro d’Italia
text: Before flying to Italy for the Giro d’Italia, one of cycling’s three Grand Tours, Wouter Weylandt of Belgium made sure he was ready for the grueling three-week race.

headline: One Door Closes, Another Opens
text: Our intrepid blogger was not named to the United States roster, which was announced Monday, for this summer’s Women’s World Cup in Germany. She nevertheless filed this assessment.

headline: A Band Program Apart
text: A high school where there are no band geeks? At DeMatha Catholic High School, many athletes also play music in the school's many competitive ensembles.

headline: High Hopes for ‘Porgy and Bess’ on Broadway
text: The American Repertory Theater’s reconceived production of “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess” looks well-positioned for Broadway in the 2011-12 season, if Sunday’s three-hour developmental performance in Manhattan for potential investors and others was any indication.

headline: Manhattan Theater Club Announces Its New Season
text: A Broadway production of a new work by David Auburn, a new play by Zoe Kazan and a new comedy featuring David Hyde Pierce will be presented during the 2011-2012 season of Manhattan Theater Club, the theater company said on Monday.

headline: Why Success Starts With Failure
text: Tim Harford is a columnist for The Financial Times and the author of “The Undercover Economist.” He’s part of the growing cadre of journalists who try to write about economics in plain English. His new book, “Adapt: Why Success Always Starts With Failure,” will be published this week. Our conversation follows.

headline: Cameras Capture Endangered Tigers in Sumatra Forest
text: If there is one thing that the Internet loves, it is video footage of cats.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Returns to Winning Form at Turkish GP
text: Sebastian Vettel has secured pole position and won all but one race on the 2011 Formula One calendar. Judging from his performance this last weekend, Vettel intends to spare himself any further blemishes.

headline: Caring for an Ill Spouse, and for Other Caregivers
text: Monday morning can be a downer, but for the dozen women and men in our support group, it’s a highlight of our week. That’s when we gather to speak candidly of what is unspeakable in polite society or even among closest friends and family.

headline: The Obama Presidency, Post Bin Laden
text: The Times's John Harwood and Peter Baker discuss President Obama's position as he turns, somewhat strengthened, back to other issues.

headline: Uncle Mo Sent to Farm; Archarcharch Is Retired
text: Uncle Mo, last year’s juvenile champion, was sent to WinStar Farm in Versailles, Ky., on Monday to convalesce as he tries to recover from a gastrointestinal infection. While his return to the races this year is possible, another leading 3-year-old, Archarcharch, has been retired after surgery on his injured left foreleg discovered cartilage damage.

headline: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: A Developer in Debt, and a Reeling Condo
text: Five years ago, when Mayra Kirkendall-Rodriguez decided to buy a two-and-a-half bedroom apartment at the Walden on East 130th Street in Harlem, she says she was happy to find a place that offered the promise of space, light and air, a “lovely property” on a quiet, residential block in an up-and-coming neighborhood. With a 400-square-foot terrace, easy access to transit and, perhaps more important, 24-hour security, it seemed like a good value for the money. Single at the time, she was often out late, she said, so knowing there would be a doorman on duty whenever she got home was “a big, big plus.”

headline: New York Lottery Commercial
text: A commercial that is part of a new campaign for instant games sold by the New York Lottery.

headline: It Only Takes an Instant, Lottery Ads Declare
text: The lottery that contributed “Hey, you never know” to the lengthy list of memorable advertising catch phrases vernacular is hoping to do it again, with a new slogan for its scratch-off games.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Beam Global Spirits and Wine, Deerfield, Ill., expanded its relationship with the Chicago office of Euro RSCG Worldwide by naming it to handle the creative duties for the introduction of Pucker, a flavored vodka. Spending has not been determined. Euro RSCG Chicago already creates campaigns for Beam Global brands like Effen vodka and Sauza tequila. Beam Global is part of Fortune Brands and Euro RSCG Worldwide is part of the Havas Worldwide unit of Havas.

headline: Hertz Gets Back Into the Driver’s Seat
text: It’s not quite the action in the movie “Fast Five,” but the rental car wars just got interesting again.

headline: Thai Premier to Dissolve Parliament; Elections Set for July 3
text: BANGKOK — The prime minister of Thailand said Monday that he had received the king’s approval to dissolve Parliament seven months early. He set elections for July 3.

headline: Marketing Junk to Kids – Or Not
text: New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s attempt to fight fat.

headline: Red Bulls Coach Says M.L.S. Roughness Is Overstated
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — The word has gone out around the world that Major League Soccer is a physically demanding place to play. Whether it is because of a lack of technical ability or something peculiar to the game in North America — whatever — Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe is simply not buying the conventional wisdom.

headline: The Obvious Rarefied
text: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed definitions of wit.

headline: S.E.C. Documents Shed Light on Warner Deal
text: The Warner Music Group, home to Green Day, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Led Zeppelin, reached a deal on Friday to sell itself to Access Industries for $3.3 billion. More details of the deal came to light on Monday in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Obama Fills a Gap in the Seals’ Tool Kit
text: Even the most serious of subjects — like the killing of a hunted terrorist leader — apparently needs its light moments.

headline: A Clip From 'A.N.T. Farm'
text: China McClain performs in a clip from the Disney Channel series "A.N.T. Farm."

headline: Another ‘Early Show’ Producer Is Ousted
text: For the fifth time in less than four years, “The Early Show” on CBS is getting a new boss.

headline: Video: President Obama’s Political Capital
text: Read John Harwood’s related column “Obama Can’t Depend On New Poll Numbers” in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: Sundhage Names U.S. Roster for Women’s World Cup
text: Coach Pia Sundhage on Monday named the 21 players who will represent the United States in the 2011 FIFA Women’s World Cup. This will be the first World Cup for 12 squad members, while the 9 others will be returning to the tournament. The two-time world champions will be aiming to win their first Women’s World Cup since hosting the event in 1999.

headline: As Special House Race Intensifies, Washington Sends Backup
text: DEPEW, N.Y. — This village of strip malls, car dealerships and working-class neighborhoods is an unlikely stage for a battle between the two major parties in Washington.

headline: Like Mother, Like Daughter: Bristol Palin Has a Reality TV Show
text: Following in her mother’s footsteps, Bristol Palin is going to star in her own reality television show.

headline: Changing Like Winds, With Gusto
text: The Miller Theater’s Composer Portraits series covered a lot of ground this year, as it moved from Pierre Boulez’s elaborate serialist explorations to Julia Wolfe’s post-Minimalist string works and Chaya Czernowin’s arcane experiments, with other stylistic detours along the way. The series ended on Thursday evening with chamber music by Joan Tower, a composer whose directness and eclecticism make her music instantly accessible, and whose imaginative sense of development — often by way of insistent but evolving rhythms and surprising juxtapositions — gives it an original, distinctive personality.

headline: Jury in Galleon Case Hears Taped Calls Again
text: 8:50 p.m. | Updated

headline: Democrats Press Boehner on Debt Ceiling
text: With Speaker John A. Boehner preparing to deliver a major economic speech in New York on Monday night, Democrats raced to get out in front of the talk by pressing Mr. Boehner to assure members of the financial community that Republicans would raise the federal debt ceiling this summer.

headline: Risks: Busy Business Traveler? Carry a Pharmacy
text: A new study confirms what many corporate road warriors already know: Frequent business travel takes a toll on one’s health.

headline: House Financial Services Committee Goes Digital
text: The financial crisis prompted Congress to offer a $700 billion banking bailout, a sweeping overhaul of financial regulations — and now a blog.

headline: Numberplay: Mission Shortest Path
text: In the above problem, you had to determine the shortest distance, which, assuming that the speed of the vehicle was constant over the terrain, would also result in the shortest travel time. In the next mission, you have to specifically determine the path that takes the least time.

headline: YouTube Expands Video Rental Service
text: Updated 5:48 p.m.: Adding details about the new movie rentals and correcting the spelling of Salar Kamangar, the head of YouTube’s, last name.

headline: Screening: New Threat Rises Between Mammograms
text: Some breast cancers detected between regular screenings were simply missed on the patient’s last mammogram. But a majority found during the interim periods can’t be found on previous scans at all.

headline: Recent Poll Shows Gingrich Has Work to Do
text: As a former speaker of the House and contributor to Fox News, Newt Gingrich will enter the presidential race this week as one of the better-known Republicans on the list of possible contenders. But a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month found that that may not necessarily be to his advantage.

headline: Sotheby’s to Offer a Founding Father’s Illicit Notebooks
text: In the annals of injudicious disappearances from Manhattan’s mean streets, before there was Judge Crater there was Judge Lansing. And, before Judge John Lansing Jr. vanished in 1829, not so far from where Judge Joseph Force Crater went missing 99 years later, Judge Lansing was already famous — as a Founding Father and New York delegate to the Constitutional Convention in 1787.

headline: Video Game Level Replicates Bin Laden Compound
text: Reading the news coverage of Osama bin Laden’s death last week sometimes sounded like the narrative of a new video game. There were the secret radar-evading government helicopters, the highly trained war dog and the fearless members of Seal Team 6, the best of the best Navy Seal units, which stormed Bin Laden’s compound.

headline: Fixated by Screens, but Seemingly Nothing Else
text: The mother had brought in a note from her son’s elementary school teacher: Dear doctor, I think this child needs to be tested for attention deficit disorder.

headline: Hazy Recall as a Signal Foretelling Depression
text: OXFORD, England — The task given to participants in an Oxford University depression study sounds straightforward. After investigators read them a cue word, they have 30 seconds to recount a single specific memory, meaning an event that lasted less than one day.

headline: Identifying Another Victim, Officials Raise Possibility of a 2nd L.I. Killer
text: Long Island residents, already grappling with the notion that a serial killer has been dumping bodies in their midst, got more disturbing news on Monday: a second serial killer may have been at work.

headline: Quebec to Spend Billions to Develop Resources in Northern Regions
text: OTTAWA — Quebec province, anticipating renewed interest in its natural resources, rolled out on Monday an ambitious 25-year plan to develop its vast but largely untouched northern and Arctic regions.

headline: Dean Heller Sworn In to Senate
text: The Senate welcomed its newest member on Monday with the swearing in of Dean Heller, who on Friday was a Republican congressman from Nevada. Mr. Heller was appointed by Gov. Brian Sandoval of Nevada to replace John Ensign, who resigned from the Senate last month under an ethics cloud before finishing his term.

headline: Reader Idea | From 19th-Century Factories to 21st-Century Sweatshops
text: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

headline: The Goth-Pop Revival
text: For those of us who remember this sound from the first time around, it’s both eerie and nostalgically pleasurable to listen to Austra and Zola Jesus channeling Siouxsie Sioux. Austra’s new album comes out next week; Zola Jesus, whom I sadly missed in New York, is currently on tour.

headline: Henzab
text: Name given by Libyan rebels to homemade caltrops (anti-personnel weapons designed to puncture boots and tyres).

headline: Meryl Streep to Participate in Alan Alda’s Marie Curie Play
text: Opening night of the World Science Festival in New York is going to feature a more glittering lineup of stars than most Broadway shows. Meryl Streep, Amy Adams, Allison Janney, Liev Schreiber, David Morse and Bill Camp are among the actors coming together on June 1 at Alice Tully Hall to participate in a reading of a new play written by Alan Alda about the scientist Marie Curie.

headline: F.D.I.C. Chairwoman to Leave in July
text: Sheila C. Bair, one of the banking industry’s most influential regulators and outspoken critics during the financial crisis, said on Monday that she planned to step down as chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on July 8.

headline: Regimens: Looking Twice at Supplements for Infants
text: Nearly one in 10 babies are given supplements or plant-based teas to soothe colic or help with teething during the first year of life, even though the products are unproven and may contain contaminants or spur allergies, a new study says.

headline: Who Made That Campbell’s Soup Label?
text: In 1962, Andy Warhol produced “Campbell’s Soup Cans”: 32 paintings, each representing a flavor of Campbell’s condensed soup. “With these works, Warhol took on the tradition of still-life painting, declaring a familiar household brand of packaged food a legitimate subject in the age of Post-War economic recovery,” according to Christie’s. Warhol appropriated the famous soup can and reinvented it as a work of art. He can be credited with converging the world of high art and supermarket branding, propelling the pop-art movement forward and possibly even boosting the sales of canned soup, but the label that he rode to stardom was not his design at all.

headline: Stay-at-Home Moms and the Need for Credit
text: If you are a stay-at-home mom (or dad) and want a credit card, you should consider applying for one, pronto. A pending change in the way card companies must evaluate applications will probably make it much harder for people who don’t have their own, independent income to get one.

headline: Inside the Groupon-Live Nation Deal
text: The daily-deals site Groupon is pairing with Live Nation Entertainment, an online ticket seller, to create GrouponLive, a discount ticket seller. In an interview with CNBC, Groupon’s chief executive, Andrew Mason, and Live Nation’s chief executive, Michael Rapino, discuss the rationale behind the deal and their strategy to “grow the pie” of online event marketing.

headline: Attention Problems, Except for Screens
text: Why is it that children with attention deficit problems at school can be held in rapt attention by a video game or television program?

headline: Hot Type
text: The latest entry in the movement to free Ai Weiwei, the Chinese dissident artist who has been detained since April, is this T-shirt, the heavy black bars of which speak volumes about free speech. It’s the creation of Playtype, a self-described “online type foundry” that was established by e-Types, a Copenhagen design agency, to showcase over 20 years of type design, including commissioned works for fonts “created out of pure passion and typographical heartache.” E-Types collaborated on the project with the architecture office Bjarke Ingels Group and V1 Gallery in Copenhagen. Late last year, Playtype opened a concept store — which will operate for one year only, until Dec. 1 — in Copenhagen’s trendy Vesterbro neighborhood, a former red-light district. The store’s wares, which include the aforementioned T-shirt and type-adorned notebooks, wine labels and ceramic mugs, are not sold online, alas, but inquiries are invited at info@playtype.com. You can also download the T-shirt graphic here.

headline: Infant Deaths Drop After Midwives Undergo Inexpensive Training
text: Giving midwives simple training has already been shown to save newborns’ lives, and a new study in Zambia has found that it can be remarkably cost-effective as well.

headline: An Insider Views China, Past and Future
text: It’s been four decades since President Richard M. Nixon sent Henry A. Kissinger to Beijing to re-establish contact with China, an ancient civilization with which the United States, at that point, had had no high-level diplomatic contact for more than two decades. Since then the cold war has ended; the Soviet Union (a threat to both China and the United States and a spur to Sino-American cooperation) has come unwound; and economic reform in China has transformed a poverty-ridden, poorly educated nation into a great power that is playing an increasingly pivotal role in the globalized world.

headline: Woman Who Accused Militiamen of Rape Has Fled Libya
text: CAIRO — A Libyan woman who became a symbol of her country’s repression after security forces tried to silence her accusations that Qaddafi militiamen had raped her said on Monday that she had escaped to neighboring Tunisia.

headline: TimesCast | May 9, 2011
text: The rift between the U.S. and Pakistan escalates, as American officials blame Pakistan for releasing the name of the CIA station chief in Islamabad to Pakistani news media.

headline: The iPad in Your Hand: As Fast as a Supercomputer of Yore
text: It’s common wisdom that the computer you can hold in the palm of your hand today is as powerful as a computer from years ago that filled an entire room.

headline: Live Nation Teams Up With Groupon Amid Worries About Concert Season
text: Live Nation Entertainment, the world’s biggest concert promoter, is teaming with the popular coupon site Groupon to sell discounted tickets.

headline: Florida’s Rejected Rail Funds Head North
text: If there had been a piñata in Pennsylvania Station on Monday, it would have borne a resemblance to Florida’s governor, Rick Scott.

headline: A Parade of Astronauts and Corvettes
text: A group of current and former NASA astronauts gathered in Cocoa Beach, Fla., on Saturday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Alan Shepard’s suborbital flight. The event was marked by a parade, with the astronauts riding in a fleet of Chevrolet Corvettes that included examples of the sports car’s six design iterations.

headline: Unease About Greece Grows as S.&P. Downgrades Its Debt Again
text: ATHENS — Worries about Greece’s intractable debt problem deepened on Monday, stoking fears that the country remains on a path to fiscal disaster and that European leaders do not have a convincing plan to prevent a default.

headline: JPMorgan Hires Former Barclays M.&A. Banker
text: JPMorgan Chase has hired Drago Rajkovic, a Wall Street veteran who most recently worked for Barclays Capital, to lead the bank’s technology-related mergers and acquisitions group, according to an internal e-mail obtained by DealBook.

headline: The Morning Line: All Eyes on Graham Motion
text: The praise continued Monday for Graham Motion, the trainer of Kentucky Derby winner, Animal Kingdom. Joe Drape in the New York Times writes that Animal Kingdom “is trained by an Englishman who has never been cited for violating a medication rule and believes a horse should be allowed to be a horse as much as possible.” Drape adds: “The trainer came to the United States 30 years ago but adheres to European principles of horsemanship. His base is a European-styled training center in Maryland, where his stock hacks, or gallops, on wooded trails or runs in pastures and is turned out in paddocks. Last year, he was one of two trainers on the top 20 earnings list without a medication violation.”

headline: Russian President Reaches Out to Nation’s World War II Allies
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Monday, at an annual celebration of the defeat of Nazi Germany, that a rising generation of young Russians were “working to reinforce bonds of friendship, cooperation and fraternity” with the countries that fought alongside Russia.

headline: Lightening the Paper Load
text: Conferences and trade shows seem to generate vast amounts of paperwork — booklets, programs, handouts, guides. But as increasing numbers of business travelers carry smartphones and tablets, organizers of these events are responding by developing mobile applications.

headline: As Rodriguez Slumps, So Does the Yankees’ Offense
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. – Kevin Long, the Yankees’ hitting coach, considers Alex Rodriguez as being more in tune with his mechanics than any other player he has worked with. When Rodriguez is swinging well, he can explain exactly why. And when he is not, he is a master troubleshooter. At least, usually.

headline: Local Honey for a Runny Nose
text: Among allergy sufferers, there is a widespread belief that locally produced honey can help build immunity to local allergens. The honey, after all, is made by bees that pollinated local plants.

headline: Guerrilla Culinary Brigade Finds a Permanent Home
text: Alan Philips and Jason Apfelbaum, who have been running pop-up dinners in parking lots and similar venues with their company, Guerrilla Culinary Brigade, are settling down. Late next week they plan to open Co-Op Food & Drink in the space that had been Thor in the Hotel on Rivington. “This is my first real restaurant,” Mr. Philips said, “but I haven’t given up on the pop-up dinners either.”

headline: Whole Wheat Spaghetti With Green Garlic and Chicory
text: This dish is inspired by a classic oil and garlic pasta. I’ve added chicory, a bitter green that is much loved in southern Italy but underused here. It’s sold with lettuces in the supermarket, often called escarole or curly endive. Chicory contains a type of soluble fiber called inulin, which some studies suggest may have a positive effect on blood sugar levels.

headline: BMW M1, Painted by Frank Stella, Heading to Auction
text: Visitors to the atrium of the IBM Building, at 56th Street and Madison Avenue, encounter a brightly colored BMW M1 painted by the artist Frank Stella in 1979. Many pause and pose for mobile phone photos, and with good reason.

headline: Asparagus With Green Garlic
text: When you sauté or roast asparagus in hot olive oil, the asparagus will have a much more concentrated flavor than it would if steamed or blanched. Here I add the garlic to the pan once the asparagus is just about done, so that the garlic cooks only long enough to soften and sweeten.

headline: 'The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance'
text: A. O. Scott discusses how truth and justice are sacrificed as order is brought to a lawless land in John Ford's 1962 film.

headline: Neanderthals and Early Humans May Not Have Mingled Much
text: An improvement in the dating of fossils suggests that the Neanderthals, a heavily muscled, thick-boned human species adapted to living in ice age Europe, perished almost immediately on contact with the modern humans who started to enter Europe from the Near East about 44,000 years ago. Until now bones from several Neanderthal sites have been dated to as young as 29,000 years ago, suggesting there was extensive overlap between the two human species. This raised the question of whether there had been interbreeding between humans and Neanderthals, an issue that is still not resolved.

headline: Obama on Bin Laden Mission Lifts ’60 Minutes’
text: President Obama’s interview on “60 Minutes” about the mission that killed Osama bin Laden helped lift the program to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night as 13.8 million people tuned in to the broadcast, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: A Lighter, Lovelier Garlic
text: I first encountered green garlic one summer in Provence. I was working on a garlic cookbook, so I bought lots of it every time I went to the market. But one day in June I came across an unfamiliar variety. The generous cloves — enrobed in several layers of soft, moist, pinkish skin — were almost juicy, and their flavor was less pungent than that of regular garlic.

headline: A Change in Fortune for the West Coast?
text: As I wrote on Friday in the Bay Area edition of The Times, residents of the West Coast have been locally sheltered from the impact of accelerated sea level rise.

headline: Boehner Lays Out Path on Debt Limit
text: House Speaker John A. Boehner plans to tell the Economic Club of New York on Monday night that an increase in the federal debt limit should be accompanied by spending cuts that exceed any rise in borrowing power.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Japan.

headline: Urban Twisters
text: Q. If big tornadoes hit Manhattan, would the skyscrapers break up the winds, or would some of them be destroyed?

headline: Setti Warren to Challenge Scott Brown in 2012
text: Setti Warren, the mayor of Newton, Mass., announced Monday that he would seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Scott Brown next year in what will likely be a crowded primary race.

headline: Burson-Marsteller Heads North of Nine
text: A leading public relations agency is carving out a specialty from its global technology practice.

headline: Tracking Lineage Through a Bramble
text: Those stars among the hunter-gatherers of fossils related to human origins, Donald C. Johanson and Richard Leakey, returned last week to the American Museum of Natural History in New York, the scene of a bitter televised brawl between the two 30 years ago. They were older, presumably wiser and definitely much more temperate. The title of the program, “Human Evolution and Why It Matters: A Conversation with Leakey and Johanson,” signaled that this was not to be a re-enactment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Japan.

headline: Living on Thin Ice
text: Relentless warming in Antarctica is taking a toll on Adélie and emperor penguins.

headline: In a Changing Antarctica, Some Penguins Thrive as Others Suffer
text: ROSS ISLAND, Antarctica — Cape Royds, home to the southernmost colony of penguins in the world, is a rocky promontory overlaid with dirty ice and the stench of pinkish guano. Beyond the croaking din of chicks pestering parents for regurgitated krill lies the Ross Sea, a southern extension of the Pacific Ocean that harbors more than one-third of the world’s Adélie penguin population and a quarter of all emperor penguins, and which may be the last remaining intact marine ecosystem on Earth.

headline: Three-Word Parenting Lessons
text: On the Web site of Psychology Today this month, the psychologist Jim Taylor comes clean.

headline: French, but Conversant in Many Genres
text: The pipe organ is a mysterious and complex instrument, whose flight deck of keys, knobs, tabs and pedals require the performer to be pianist, pilot and tap dancer simultaneously. Organists often work diligently in the shadows, their consoles hidden from view. But the handsome new Manton Memorial Organ at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village was on full display for its inauguration on Thursday evening, with a concert by Jon Gillock.

headline: Waiting and the Deficit (Wonkish)
text: What DC considers a despicable scare tactic: accurately describing a proposal to dismantle Medicare.

headline: Where Do You Eat at the Park?
text: It’s spring in New York – a time when parks fill up with city dwellers who’ve been indoors, patiently waiting for the warm sun to show its face. Among the city’s great perks are its parks, and with parks come outdoor concerts, Frisbee matches, sunbathing, nature-watching and last but far from least, alfresco dining.

headline: Cuban Dancers Complete a 5-Decade Trip to New York
text: HAVANA — At the humid, spare studios of Danza Contemporánea de Cuba here last week, two dozen dancers rolled their spines forward, turning their outstretched arms in their sockets as drummers beat a slow, syncopated song dedicated to the Yoruba deity Obatalá.

headline: Distracted Driving: An Answer Perhaps?
text: There are at least two irrefutable facts about the practice of people communicating by cellphones while driving cars. First, it is a big problem, with studies estimating that more than 500,000 traffic accidents and 2,600 deaths a year are caused by cellphone-distracted drivers. No one has documented the problem as thoroughly as my colleague, Matt Richtel.

headline: PBS Revamps Schedule of Friday Night Shows
text: PBS is making changes to its Friday-night schedule this fall, trimming its public affairs programming and adding a nine-week run of arts performances, the public broadcaster announced on Monday. The Friday newsmagazine “Need to Know” will shrink to a half-hour, beginning Sept. 16, from an hour, and take on a new focus on issues related to the 2012 election. On Oct. 14 the new “PBS Arts Fall Festival” will start its run of offerings from around the country, including “The Little Mermaid From San Francisco Ballet”; “Women Who Rock,” based on an exhibition at the Rock ’n’ Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland; and “Give Me the Banjo,” narrated by Steve Martin, exploring the roots of American music. Other changes this fall include the addition of a Wednesday broadcast for the Sunday-night staple “Nature.”

headline: Featherweight Relative of the T. Rex Is Found
text: Researchers working in the western Gobi Desert in Mongolia have discovered the almost complete skeleton of a tyrannosaurid dinosaur that was less than 3 years old when it died, younger and smaller than any previously known. The animal, Tarbosaurus bataar, is the closest relative of Tyrannosaurus rex, the predator that lived at the same time in North America.

headline: An Eclectic Virtuoso
text: Gary Lucas has a wide-ranging body of work that has channeled musical traditions from Poland, China, Israel, India and elsewhere.

headline: Songwriter With a Global Guitar
text: The music business has never quite known what to make of Gary Lucas. Go to a site for streaming or downloading songs, and you may find his music consigned to a vague category called “other.” Look him up in standard reference works, and he’s likely to be referred to as a “legendary left-field guitarist” whose work is “eclectic” or just plain “eccentric.”

headline: In Digestion, Leeches Show Sophisticated Side
text: Some leeches like it cool, but some like it hot. It all depends on whether they are hungry.

headline: Sports Replay: May 9
text: Whether it be soccer, table tennis or horse racing, a view of the day in sports is firmly focused on the eyes.

headline: Helping Jackson Travel His Path
text: Jerry Krause no longer speaks to Phil Jackson, the N.B.A. coaching legend he helped create. It’s personal, he said, and it really doesn’t much matter anymore, as long as he knows that Jackson is doing the right thing and checking in on the man who will always professionally connect them.

headline: Finding High Spirits in Shakespeare
text: To follow his shattering adaptation of “Othello,” Giuseppe Verdi and his trusted late-career librettist, Arrigo Boito, turned to another Shakespeare play. Not “King Lear,” which had tantalized Verdi for years. Not “The Tempest,” whose storm and complex father-daughter relationship must have appealed to him.

headline: Staten Island’s Secret Oasis
Getty Trust’s Pick for President Surprises Art World
text: The J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles, which emerged from years of instability only to lose its leader to a fatal heart attack last summer, surprised the art world on Monday by announcing that James Cuno, the director of the Art Institute of Chicago and a highly respected figure in the museum world, would take over as the trust’s president and chief executive in August.

headline: Morgan Stanley Lost Money on Just 3 Days in Quarter
text: The highs weren’t quite as high. And the lows were not quite as low.

headline: Japan’s Nuclear Future in the Balance
text: TOKYO — The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant has done more than spew radiation into the air and sea and force tens of thousands of people to evacuate their homes. It has blown a big hole in Japan’s energy policy, which had assumed that nuclear power would supply a growing part of the country’s needs.

headline: A Lot of Hot Water, but Not Much Is Being Used to Produce Electricity
text: YANAIZU, Japan — As visitors to any of Japan’s thousands of hot springs know, this country is sitting on a lot of very hot water.

headline: Lakers’ Bitter Exit Evokes 1991 Pistons’
text: There was a strange symmetry in how Phil Jackson’s 20-season coaching run ended Sunday in Dallas, with his Lakers reprising the role of Coach Chuck Daly’s Pistons against Jackson’s rising Bulls in 1991.

headline: Poker as a Game of Skill
text: Is poker a game of luck or skill? That’s the question the economists Steven D. Levitt (of “Freakonomics” fame) and Thomas J. Miles explore in a new working paper published with the National Bureau of Economic Research.

headline: A Book Publisher Finds Ready Conversation
text: I’VE been a business traveler for most of my career, but I started to fly what seems like nonstop about 15 years ago. I like to travel for business because I like meeting people, but I’m not a great flier.

headline: Fountains of Optimism for Life Way Out There
text: For those who hunt for life on other worlds, water in its liquid form is perhaps the leading indicator. Life as we know it on Earth is based on water and carbon. And if organisms can prosper here in nasty environments — in geysers, in the depths of the sea, in toxic waste, in water that is too hot, too cold, too acidic or too alkaline — why could they not prosper out there?

headline: A Green Banner for Puerto Rican Day
text: The National Puerto Rican Day Parade is going green.

headline: Calm Demeanor, Assertive Sounds
text: The trumpeter Shane Endsley exudes a calm, steadying demeanor on the bandstand, and his tone, dry and matte, falls a long way from brassy effulgence. He’s an interior and economical soloist, averse not only to empty flash but also to wasted effort. And yet his music doesn’t come across as rigid, cold or self-effacing. Quite the opposite, actually.

headline: ‘By the Way, Meet Vera Stark’
text: Photos of Lynn Nottage’s new play at Second Stage Theater.

headline: Unconscious Lessons of a Jazzman
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Fred Hersch is a jazz pianist who has long since gone beyond jazz, and his irreducible gift or skill is for solo playing. The enormous variety in his touch, and his sophisticated sense of musical narrative through arranging and improvising, render him special. Beyond that, he’s a composer in several idioms, a bandleader for groups of many sizes, and a setter of texts to music. A jazz pianist can’t do much better.

headline: Critics’ Choice: New CDs
text: THE ANTLERS

headline: Music in Review
text: MUSICIANS FROM MARLBORO

headline: With Help From NATO, Libyan Rebels Gain Ground
text: QARYAT AZ ZURAYQ, Libya — Rebel fighters made significant gains Monday against forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in both the western and eastern areas of the country, in the first faint signs that NATO airstrikes may be starting to strain the government forces.

headline: The New Yorker Begins to Offer iPad Subscriptions
text: David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, sat in a conference room on the 11th floor at Condé Nast headquarters with Robert A. Sauerberg Jr., the president of Condé Nast, and Eddy Cue, the vice president for Internet services at Apple. The latest print issue, with an erased image of Osama Bin Laden on the cover, was on the table an inch away from its digital sibling, the new New Yorker app for the iPad, which was made available on Monday for subscription.

headline: Bronx Zoo, 9:44 A.M.
text: Enutifa Gamia, 10, and Jordan Gamia, 4, posed with the Bronx Zoo’s mascot, Jose the beaver, before Enutifa, who is from Togo, took the citizenship oath in a ceremony at the zoo at which 35 children from 14 countries became citizens.

headline: Ann Curry to Become a Co-Host of ‘Today’
text: Ann Curry will replace Meredith Vieira as co-host of the “Today” show, NBC announced Monday, confirming much-anticipated changes in the cast of its perennially dominant morning show.

headline: An Irresistible Austrian Riesling Beckons
text: LET me immediately declare my bias: I love Austrian rieslings. I say that knowing I’m speaking very generally, but don’t we always about wine?

headline: Wright Has Been Playing in Pain
text: DENVER — Mets Manager Terry Collins said that David Wright had been playing through back pain ever since he and Carlos Lee of the Houston Astros collided at third base on April 19 as Wright went to apply a tag. Collins said Wright had played down the extent of the injury, but Collins believes it has affected Wright at the plate.

headline: New Call in Albany to Quit U.S. Immigration Program
text: A group of 38 state lawmakers sent a letter to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday urging him to remove New York from a national program that has been a cornerstone of the Obama administration’s immigration enforcement efforts.

headline: The Real Cost of Airline Travel Remains a Mystery, for Now
text: The Transportation Department is moving to require airlines to release much more detailed information about all those extra fees they’ve been collecting in recent years.

headline: LinkedIn and Freescale Join Surge of I.P.O.’s
text: As investor appetite for initial public offerings grows, dozens of technology companies from start-ups to stalwarts are prepping for their stock market debuts.

headline: Study Links Flammable Gas in Water and Nearby Drilling
text: Researchers from Duke University say they have found a clear link between gas drilling in Pennsylvania and Upstate New York and high levels of flammable methane in drinking water — a situation that became a prominent talking point in the drilling debate after flaming faucets were featured in the documentary “Gasland.”

headline: N.F.L. Continues Effort to Maintain Lockout
text: The N.F.L. asked a federal appeals court Monday to vacate a District Court’s preliminary injunction that briefly lifted the two-month lockout and send the case back to the District Court.

headline: Census Data Reveals a Shift in Patterns of Childbearing
text: WASHINGTON — College-educated women are waiting longer to have children than those without a college education, according to new data from the Census Bureau.

headline: Boehner Outlines Demands on Debt Limit Fight
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner said Monday that Republicans would insist on trillions of dollars in federal spending cuts in exchange for their support of an increase in the federal debt limit sought by the Obama administration to prevent a government default later this year.

headline: On Par: A Cure for the Slice?
text: Bill Pennington, golf reporter for The New York Times, gets a few golfers to try out the new Polara golf ball, which claims to straighten out that nasty slice.

headline: A Golf Ball That Won’t Slice Comes With a Catch: It’s Illegal
text: EDGEWATER, N.J. — Ducks quack, dogs bark, cab drivers honk and golfers slice. Among the basic truths of the planet: 80 percent of golfers cannot hit their tee shots where they aim.

headline: Social Networks Offer a Way to Narrow the Field of Friends
text: There are times when you just have to tell your friends about something — but not necessarily your Facebook friends.

headline: In Reversal, City University Trustees Approve Honorary Degree for Tony Kushner
text: In a hastily convened meeting of their executive committee, City University of New York trustees approved an honorary degree for Tony Kushner on Monday night to try to quell widespread criticism over the board’s decision last week to withhold it because of concerns about the playwright’s views on Israel.

headline: Electric Avenue
text: THE American response to rising gas prices has been depressingly predictable. We’re shocked to see prices top $4 a gallon, as if it’s never happened before. We demand that something be done — not to reduce our dependence on oil, but to cut the cost of a fill-up. Fortunately the White House is standing behind a goal that could genuinely transform the nation’s automotive fleet: putting one million electric vehicles on the road by 2015.

headline: Once Vultures, Unwanted Suitors Like Hertz Now Seen as Strategists
text: When it comes to deals, attitude matters.

headline: Physicist Group’s Study Raises Doubts on Capturing Carbon Dioxide From Air
text: Over the last few years, some of world’s brightest minds have become fascinated with a seemingly simple idea: easing the threat of climate change by pulling carbon dioxide out of the air.

headline: Google to Start a Cloud-Based Music Player
text: A month after Amazon angered music labels by starting a cloud-based music player without their cooperation, Google is doing the same thing.

headline: Els, With Hope for More, Is Hall of Famer
text: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. — A gentle giant from Johannesburg, and a self-proclaimed former “mean guy” from Manhattan who grew up on Seaman Avenue in Inwood. One of the most recognizable athletes ever produced by Japan, and a former president of the United States. A Scot born in St. Andrews who emigrated to the United States, and an Armenian immigrant’s son and one of the greatest producers in the history of televised sports.

headline: Antipsychotic Drugs Called Hazardous for the Elderly
text: Nearly one in seven elderly nursing home residents, nearly all of them with dementia, are given powerful atypical antipsychotic drugs even though the medicines increase the risks of death and are not approved for such treatments, a government audit found.

headline: Bloggingheads: Was He Worth It?
text: Mike Konczal, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic reflect on the meaning of Bin Laden's death.

headline: Gunter Sachs, Ex-Husband of Brigitte Bardot, Dies at 78
text: Gunter Sachs, a wealthy German-born art collector who was fodder for gossip columns in the 1960s for his playboy antics and his brief marriage to Brigitte Bardot, died on Saturday at his home in the Swiss Alpine resort of Gstaad. He was 78.

headline: Pursuing Pardon, Steinbrenner Aided F.B.I.
text: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ principal owner, cooperated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation on national security cases and was willing to let it stage an organized-crime raid at Yankee Stadium, according to documents released Monday by the F.B.I, less than a year after Steinbrenner’s death.

headline: Willard S. Boyle, Father of Digital Eye, Dies at 86
text: Willard S. Boyle, who won the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physics for helping to develop a device that is at the heart of virtually every camcorder, digital camera and telescope in use, died on Saturday in Truro, Nova Scotia. He was 86.

headline: Deaths and Injuries Reported in Yemeni Protest March
text: Security forces and government supporters opened fire on protesters in the Yemeni city of Taiz on Monday, witnesses said, while a doctor confirmed that four people were killed and scores wounded after almost a month of stalled negotiations over how and when President Ali Abdullah Saleh would leave office.

headline: Gingrich Set to Run, With Wife in Central Role
text: WASHINGTON — Callista Bisek’s friends from rural Wisconsin were stunned when, well over a decade ago, she confided that she was secretly dating an older, married man: Newt Gingrich.

headline: In Peru, Dreaming of American Glory
text: Diego Chávarri is a household name in his own household, which happens to be in Lima, Peru. His English may be spotty, but his soccer is solid. Perhaps most important of all, Chávarri owns a cherished document: a United States passport.

headline: Mets Get Bad News on Young and Mejia
text: DENVER — Monday was the kind of day that has become all too familiar for the Mets over the past few years, one in which medical jargon was far more relevant than baseball lingo.

headline: U.S. Was Braced for Fight With Pakistanis in Bin Laden Raid
text: This article is by  Eric Schmitt,  Thom Shanker and  David E. Sanger.

headline: Dodd-Frank Dissenters Sound Off
text: Jonathan Alcorn/Bloomberg NewsKenneth Griffin, Citadel’s chief executive, is no fan of the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: The Missing Fifth
text: In 1910, Henry Van Dyke wrote a book called “The Spirit of America,” which opened with this sentence: “The Spirit of America is best known in Europe by one of its qualities — energy.”

headline: In Rape Trial, Officer Calls Woman the Aggressor and Says They Only Snuggled
text: For the past several weeks, Police Officer Kenneth Moreno has sat silently in a courtroom amid accusations that he raped a drunken woman whom he had been called to help. In her testimony, the woman said she remembered an officer rolling down her tights and then penetrating her as she lay face down and dazed on her bed.

headline: Judge Moves Jurors, Not Trial, in Murder Case
text: MIAMI — High-profile murder cases always raise the question: Will jurors be able to weigh the evidence impartially?

headline: The Union’s ‘Shoddy’ Aristocracy
text: With the Pentagon budget up two-thirds over the last decade, it’s no surprise that charges of war profiteering make for regular front-page fodder. But for sheer scale and audacity, nothing beats the corruption that surrounded the Union war effort — and, thanks to the horrendously poor quality of the resulting equipment, did much to undermine it.

headline: Doing More Than Praying for Rain
text: In the United States, insurance against extreme weather is seen as so important that Washington subsidizes it highly and requires it for farmers who want other government benefits.  If American farmers need weather insurance, African peasant farmers need it even more.  But the vast majority of African peasant farmers have no opportunity to insure their crops.

headline: Arizona: Governor Will Appeal to Supreme Court
text: Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, said on Monday that she would petition the United States Supreme Court to lift an injunction blocking some portions of Arizona’s controversial immigration law. The Justice Department sued the state over the law, known as Senate Bill 1070, and persuaded a federal judge to issue an injunction. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld that decision, ruling in April that immigration is predominantly a federal matter. “When faced with injustice, Arizonans will not sit idly by,” Ms. Brewer said in a statement.

headline: Avoiding Greece’s Lehman Moment
California: A Book About 18 Years of Captivity
text: Jaycee Dugard will tell the story of her kidnapping and years as a captive in a book to be published by Simon & Schuster, the publisher said Monday. “A Stolen Life” is to be released on July 12. Ms. Dugard, 31, wrote the book without the help of a ghostwriter, a spokeswoman for the publisher said. She was kidnapped off a street in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., as an 11-year-old and was held for 18 years. In a California courtroom last month on April 28, Phillip Garrido, a convicted sex offender, pleaded guilty to charges including rape and kidnapping.

headline: Cuban Government Outlines Steps Toward a Freer Market
text: MEXICO CITY — For the first time since the Communist revolution 52 years ago, Cubans will be allowed to buy and sell houses and newer automobiles, and they may be able to travel abroad as tourists more freely, under policy changes announced Monday that are intended to shake up the country’s foundering economy.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Westchester Towns Take Hit From Rise in Tax Appeals
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Local governments here in well-to-do Westchester County are being overwhelmed by property tax appeals, driven by a growing industry of companies seeking reductions in homeowners’ bills in exchange for a share of their savings.

headline: More Than a Résumé
text: You must remember this: “He worked as a community organizer.”

headline: Mayor’s World Remade in an Instant
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — In the weeks before the tornadoes demolished one-seventh of his city, Walter Maddox was doing what mayors in small cities do.

headline: The Rejected Windfall
text: After Gov. Rick Scott of Florida thoughtlessly rejected $2.4 billion in federal aid for a high-speed rail line, he claimed last month that he was doing a huge favor for the national Treasury, which he expected would give away the money in tax cuts. That was nonsense, of course; Mr. Scott was really doing a favor for train passengers in the Northeast, Midwest and California, which were given $2 billion of his money on Monday for better service.

headline: New Attacks on Women’s Rights
text: With the help of 16 Democrats, House Republicans passed a bill the other day with the narrow-seeming title of the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act.

headline: In Burkina Faso, Leader Keeps Cool Under Fire
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — The riots have ended for now. The main market is bustling again and fleets of motorcycles have returned to the dusty streets. And in his fortresslike palace miles away, the president appears serene in portraits the newspapers publish.

headline: 2 Planes Crash in Orange County, Killing Pilots
text: Two small airplanes collided in midair over a hamlet in Orange County, N.Y., on Monday, leaving both pilots dead, the Federal Aviation Administration said. No one else was on the planes.

headline: Tuesday: Assists and Steals
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ll just come right out and say it: I really like themes like this one. At first glance, it may not seem too difficult to come up with an idea like this, but look again.

headline: A Black Actress Trying to Rise Above a Maid
text: A biting wind of realism, blowing both hot and cold, sweeps into the second act of “By the Way, Meet Vera Stark,” the fitful comedy by Lynn Nottage that opened on Monday night at Second Stage Theater. Reality, in this instance, assumes the fantastical form of an aging, teetering woman in a psychedelic-print dress and Technicolor makeup, applied with a trowel. She slurs when she speaks or sings, and you just know that her vision is blurry. But as embodied by Sanaa Lathan, she is so sharply focused she stings.

headline: On Jeter, Cashman Broadens His View
text: MONROE TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Brian Cashman, the Yankees’ general manager, showed up Monday morning in a golf shirt, slacks and shoes to play 18 holes at Forsgate Country Club, 54 miles down the New Jersey Turnpike from Yankee Stadium.

headline: Police Department in Newark Is Facing U.S. Inquiry
text: NEWARK — The Justice Department is investigating claims that brutality, baseless searches, intimidation and false arrests are commonplace in the Newark Police Department, officials announced on Monday.

headline: They Should Be Condemning Syria
text: Syrians have shown extraordinary courage, defying a bloody government crackdown to demand greater political rights and freedom. Their courage, and their blood, should shame the many governments that are cynically supporting Syria’s election later this month to the United Nations Human Rights Council.

headline: Indonesia: Tigers Spotted in Forest Where Paper Mill Saws Are Coming
text: Motion-sensing cameras on the island of Sumatra captured video of two families of endangered tigers in a lowland forest scheduled for destruction, the World Wildlife Fund said Monday. Twelve tigers, including two adult females with cubs, passed in front of the cameras over two months between the Bukit Tigapuluh National Park and nearby mountains. Asia Pulp and Paper has plans to clear large areas of the forest.

headline: Continuing Questions About Chernobyl
text: It has been 25 years since the worst nuclear power accident in history at the Chernobyl plant in Ukraine, and we still aren’t certain what health damage it may ultimately cause. That gap needs to be filled by a vigorous research program — both to improve readiness to cope with another bad nuclear accident and to enhance understanding of the long-term effects of low doses of radiation.

headline: More Familiar ‘Spider-Man’ Hopes to Bury the Dark
text: Bathed in green light, Patrick Page took center stage at the Foxwoods Theater on Broadway and hissed his lines with the sinister glee of a villain back from the dead.

headline: West Bank: Tax Withholding by Israel Will Delay Paychecks for Palestinians
text: The Palestinian prime minister, Salam Fayyad, left, said Monday that the Palestinian Authority could not pay the salaries of its employees on time this month because of Israel’s decision to withhold the transfer of tax revenue it collects on behalf of the Palestinians. Israel delayed the transfer of almost $90 million after the reconciliation last week between Fatah, the party that dominates the West Bank-based Palestinian Authority, and Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza. Israel said it was suspending all such transfers until there were guarantees that none of the money would end up in the treasury of Hamas, which is sworn to Israel’s destruction. The Palestinian Authority has had financial difficulties since late last year and is running a monthly deficit of $30 million. The French government provided it with a special grant of $14.3 million on Monday. On Friday, the European Union said it would advance $121.9 million to help it meet its needs.

headline: India: Supreme Court Rejects Order That Religious Site Should be Shared
text: India’s Supreme Court on Monday overturned a lower court ruling that called for the country’s most disputed religious site to be divided between Muslims and Hindus. The Mughal emperor Babur built a mosque at the site, in Ayodhya, in the 16th century. Some Hindus believe that the same spot is the birthplace of the god Ram, and that Babur had destroyed a Hindu shrine to build his mosque. In 1992, Hindu activists tore down the mosque, unleashing sectarian violence in which about 2,000 people were killed, mostly Muslims. In October a court ruled that the site should be split between the two religions, but the Supreme Court rejected that solution, calling it “strange.” The Supreme Court is expected to rule later on the question of how to resolve control of the site.

headline: Kate Swift, Writer Who Rooted Out Sexism in Language, Dies at 87
text: Kate Swift, a writer and editor who in two groundbreaking books — “Words and Women” and “The Handbook of Nonsexist Writing” — brought attention to the sexual discrimination embedded in ordinary English usage, died on Saturday in Middletown, Conn. She was 87.

headline: This Time, Heat Stars Live Up to Name
text: BOSTON — The emotions overcame Chris Bosh again Monday night, in a barely controlled burst, but the timing was right, the purpose pure, and there was no sense in restraining himself.

headline: Beyond Obama’s Bin Laden Bounce
text: A week after the news broke of the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, bettors at Intrade, a political futures market, are barely any more likely to think that President Obama will win re-election.

headline: Art From Allan Stone Estate Is a Big Draw at Sotheby’s
text: Sculptures fashioned from mangled bits of old cars, and paintings depicting cakes topped with fluffy frosting, gave a peek at the visual world of Allan Stone, the legendary Manhattan dealer who died in 2006, and whose collection was the subject of a special sale at Sotheby’s on Monday.

headline: Microsoft in Talks to Acquire Skype for $8.5 Billion

headline: For Journalists, a Call to Rethink Their Online Models
text: Columbia University has surveyed the state of digital journalism, and it has concluded that journalists must rethink their relationships — and their audiences’ relationships — with advertisers.

headline: Schwarzenegger and Shriver Announce Separation
text: LOS ANGELES — One of America’s most unlikely and riveting couples — Arnold Schwarzenegger, the Austrian body builder and movie star who became a Republican governor, and Maria Shriver, the journalist and member of the Kennedy dynasty — have separated.

headline: Researchers Employ New Test to Estimate Concussion Risk for Helmets
text: Football equipment managers nationwide will receive yet another reason to reassess their helmet inventory on Tuesday, when a Virginia Tech research report reveals that two models popular among teenagers might be allowing high rates of concussions.

headline: Chinese Exports Hit Record for April
text: HONG KONG — China’s exports surged last month to a record level, as Chinese factories appear to have passed on rising costs to buyers who are finding that they have few alternatives in other countries.

headline: Google to Unveil Service to Let Users Stream Their Music
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google plans to introduce its long-awaited service to allow people to upload and store their music collections on the Web and listen to their songs on Android phones or tablets and on computers.

headline: News Quiz | May 10, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Venezuela Asked Colombian Rebels to Kill Opposition Figures, Analysis Shows
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Colombia’s main rebel group has an intricate history of collaboration with Venezuelan officials, who have asked it to provide urban guerrilla training to pro-government cells here and to assassinate political opponents of Venezuela’s president, according to a new analysis of the group’s internal communications.

text: Today’s word, in association with the superb Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: Of Coyotes, Crossings and Cellphones
text: WHO is using cellphones to issue and receive alerts about illegal border crossings?

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 10, 2011
text: Test your vocabulary skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “Nation’s Mood at Lowest Level in Two Years, Poll Shows.”

headline: In Tender Moments, a War’s High Cost
text: Many poignant ways have been found to express the cost of wartime deployment on the families left behind. Few have affected me as immediately as a moment in “The Home Front” when 12-year-old Isaac Eisch almost lets down his brave-soldier demeanor as he speaks of his father, Sgt. First Class Brian Eisch, who is half a world away in Afghanistan.

headline: What Is Your Facebook Persona?
text: People use Facebook in different ways and for different purposes — to connect with friends, to post clever observations, to find and share ideas and resources found elsewhere, to help others. If you are on Facebook, how do you use it? How would you characterize your “persona” there?

headline: European Court Rejects Bid to Limit News on Celebrities
text: PARIS — For British celebrities and soccer stars who “play away,” as Fleet Street puts it, the hope of mounting a cover-up is fading fast.

headline: National Express and Elliott Advisors Reach Last-Minute Deal
text: National Express and the activist hedge fund Elliott Advisors have agreed to put aside their differences just in time for the British transport operator’s annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday.

headline: The Role of Economics in an Imperfect World
text: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of “Triumph of the City.”

headline: The Early Word: Fighting Words
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Fantasy Focus: Losing Faith
text: Typically in this space, we talk about some of the players that are moving the needle for us this season in a positive direction, though Dalton Del Don discussed some descenders last week. I’m going to continue in that direction to talk about a few others that I’m starting to write off.

headline: Planes, Trains and Automobiles at Renovated Prague Museum
text: Stern and functionalist in appearance, the National Technical Museum in Prague is actually a wondrous three-story transport hall, filled with antique vehicles. Reopened following a $20 million renovation, the museum is drawing in crowds with novelties like the oldest existing Bugati car and 16th-century instruments employed by famed Prague-based astronomer Tycho Brahe.

headline: Q&A: Fighting a Clickjack Attack
text: Q.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance’
text: Frequently stories that focus on the foundation of a civil society are stories of violence. A. O. Scott finds one such tale in “The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance,” John Ford’s film starring  James Stewart and John Wayne, which looks at a killing that helped to “bring law and order to a lawless land,” as Mr. Scott says.

headline: The Quagmire of Design I.P.
text: Intellectual property is a complicated subject. At TerraCycle, I regularly face I.P. decisions, and I have developed a point of view on them — but I would welcome some feedback. I’m particularly interested in your perspectives on unprotected design.

headline: New York’s Mysterious Fortune 500 Company
text: According to the latest Fortune 500 list, released last week, the seventh-largest company headquartered in New York City is not Goldman Sachs or Morgan Stanley. Those two global investment banks rank behind an up and comer known as INTL FCStone.

headline: Obama Courts Latino Voters With Immigration Speech
text: As a candidate, President Obama promised Latino voters that he would aggressively push for passage of a comprehensive immigration bill during his first year in office.

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Tween Stars Wanted: Must Be Primed for Pressure
text: LOS ANGELES — China Anne McClain, 12, was taping a scene for her new Disney Channel comedy here recently, when fiction and fact collided. As the cameras rolled, her character — heading off to start big, bad high school — got some parental advice.

headline: Troops, Backed by Tanks, Move to Quell Dissent in Syrian Towns
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 10,000 Syrian protesters have been detained in the past several days in a mass arrest campaign aimed at quelling a seven-week uprising in Syria against the government of President Bashar al-Assad, activists said Tuesday, as security forces sent more reinforcements to restive areas across the country.

headline: Microsoft to Buy Skype for $8.5 Billion
text: 10:28 a.m. | Updated Microsoft announced on Tuesday that it would buy Skype Global for $8.5 billion in cash, in its largest acquisition ever.

headline: Kushner Debacle Won’t Be the Last of Its Kind
text: Now that trustees of the City University of New York have done their best to put the Tony Kushner debacle behind them, New Yorkers can rest assured that artistry will never again be put to a political litmus test and that people in positions of authority will never shrink from speaking up when they sense an injustice.

headline: France Clears Soccer Coach of Racial Discrimination
text: Inquiries into allegations of racism at the heart of French soccer have found no evidence that laws were broken or of discrimination by the national coach, investigators said Tuesday.

headline: Goldman Had Just One Losing Day Last Quarter
text: Goldman Sachs lost money on just one trading day in the first quarter, according to a securities filing on Tuesday.

headline: Japan to Cancel Plan to Build More Nuclear Plants
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Naoto Kan said Tuesday that Japan would abandon plans to build more nuclear reactors, saying his country needed to “start from scratch” in creating a new energy policy.

headline: Mississippi River Crests in Memphis
text: MEMPHIS — President Obama declared flood-damaged areas of Tennessee a federal disaster zone on Tuesday as the Mississippi River crested here, flooding low-lying neighborhoods in the city but falling short of record levels that would have caused far more damage. The river topped out at 47.8 feet early Tuesday, far above flood stage, but lower than the predicted crest of 48 feet and almost a foot lower than the record crest of 48.7 feet in 1937.

headline: Confronting Elliott, DuPont Calls Danisco Bid ‘Final’
text: DuPont confirmed on Tuesday that its $6.4 billion bid for the Danish food ingredient company Danisco would not be raised again, a day after it emerged that Elliott Advisors had increased its stake to just above 10 percent.

headline: Kermit the Frog’s Ribbiting Report from the ‘Pirates of the Caribbean’ Premiere
text: As an employee of the Walt Disney Company, Kermit the Frog may have lost his role in vintage Muppet specials like “Emmet Otter’s Jug-Band Christmas,” but his gig affords him other perks, like getting his own celebrity-interview station at the red carpet — make that the black carpet — for the premiere of the new “Pirates of the Caribbean” movie at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. In a winking style more reminiscent of “The Muppet Show” than “Sesame Street,” Kermit is introduced to “Pirates” stars like Geoffrey Rush, Penélope Cruz and Johnny Depp (who appears baffled by the concept of a talking frog), mingles with stray guests like Steven Tyler and Bruno Tonioli, and steals kisses from Vanessa Hudgens and Kirstie Alley. (Miss Piggy might want to skip those scenes.) Yes, it’s all a promotion for a coming Disney-produced Muppets movie, and while we would have preferred to see Gonzo introduced to Keith Richards, Kermit’s brief encounter with that randy Rolling Stone is still worth the price of admission.

headline: Apollo to Buy Out ‘American Idol’ Owner
text: The owner of “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance” agreed on Tuesday to be acquired by Apollo Global Management for more than $509 million.

headline: Adult Conversation
text: Erskine Bowles, co-chairman of President Obama’s debt commission:

headline: Syrian Elite to Fight Protests to ‘the End’
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Syria’s ruling elite, a tight-knit circle at the nexus of absolute power, loyalty to family and a visceral instinct for survival, will fight to the end in a struggle that could cast the Middle East into turmoil and even war, warned Syria’s most powerful businessman, a confidant and cousin of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Price Tags and Safety Schools
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Animal Kingdom Is Heading Home
text: When we last checked in with Joe Clancy at the Steeplechase Times, Toby’s Corner had been scratched from the Kentucky Derby and Animal Kingdom seemed barely an afterthought for the race. On Tuesday, Steeplechase Times was with Animal Kingdom on his return to the Fair Hill Training Center in Maryland after his surprising victory in the Derby on Saturday:

headline: Bleep Tweets & Foul Facebook Filter
text: Software that deletes swear words from online posts.

headline: A Sharp Increase in Appraisals for Queens Co-ops Brings Protests
text: Sherry Davis, more kindly aunt than urban radical, proudly acknowledges that until recently she had not attended a protest since the Vietnam War.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Why Spending Must Rise
text: Amazingly, proposals to cap federal spending at something like its recent historical average as a share of GDP still seem to be getting serious attention. The linked report, from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, explains carefully just how unrealistic this is. But I thought I could add a bit with a broad-brush approach.

headline: Bouchon Bakery Outpost in Rockefeller Center Is Set to Open
text: Thomas Keller’s latest, an edition of Bouchon Bakery on a highly trafficked corner of Rockefeller Center, is opening on Thursday.

headline: Greek Out?
text: Kudos to Mark Weisbrot for saying the unsayable, and making a case for Greek exit from the euro.

headline: Strawberry Fields, Not Quite Forever: Gates at Beatles Landmark Are Removed
text: When John Lennon took us down to Strawberry Fields, he asked our permission first. But the Salvation Army, the owner of the site of the former children’s home that figured prominently in Lennon’s youth and inspired the hit Beatles song “Strawberry Fields Forever,” has decided to take down the iron gates that remained at the site and replace them with replicas, The Guardian reported.

headline: Eleven Madison Park, ABC Kitchen and Gabrielle Hamilton Win James Beard Awards
text: Amid the all heartfelt Oscar-style thank-you speeches Monday evening at the annual James Beard Foundation Awards, Gabrielle Hamilton’s remarks came as a cold shower. The chef and owner of Prune in the East Village, who was named Best Chef for New York City, looked sleek in creamy satin, apologized for not having prepared a speech, and said: “All you have to do is open a can of sardines and a box of Triscuits, call it a signature dish, and you get Best Chef New York City.”

headline: Fill-In | Fascinators
text: Fill in the blanks in this short article, “The Perched, the Frothy, the Fascinator.” Use your own words and phrases, or choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: At a Demolished School, Moving On and Looking Ahead
text: Last month, Tushka, Okla., with a population of 312, was hit by a tornado that damaged much of the town, killed two people and virtually destroyed its school. Tushka, which is the Choctaw word for “warrior,” is finding its way back amid difficult circumstances. Bill Pennington, the town’s school superintendent, discusses.

headline: Magazines’ Top Honors Given Out
text: New York magazine, a favorite in recent years among judges for the National Magazine awards, received the coveted general interest prize for a news, sports or entertainment publication, along with one other award on Monday evening.
