text: Microsoft to Buy Skype for $8.5 Billion | Microsoft announced on Tuesday that it would buy Skype Global for $8.5 billion in cash, in its largest acquisition ever.

headline: U.S. Still Waits for Access to Bin Laden Widows
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The dispute over access for American officials to Osama bin Laden’s three widows, who were taken into Pakistani custody after the raid that killed the leader of Al Qaeda, has become the latest test in the adversarial relationship between the C.I.A. and its Pakistani counterpart, Inter-Services Intelligence.

headline: Investigation of Fuel Leaks Expands to 2.7 Million Ford F-150s
text: Despite Ford’s earlier statements that gas tanks breaking loose on F-150 pickups do not represent “an unreasonable risk to motor vehicle safety,” the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is intensifying an investigation of the problem covering 2.7 million pickups from the 1997–2001 model years.

headline: Singing of Freshkills Park, in Haiku Form
text: Staten Island’s famously putrid Fresh Kills landfill is being transformed into the 2,200-acre Freshkills Park, an urban oasis with wildlife habitats, horseback riding, mountain biking and meandering nature trails.

headline: Major League Soccer: Little Fish, Little Pond
text: Every year, Major League Soccer Players Union releases the salaries of all players under contract in M.L.S. Those figures are just out, and they’re worth a look. (Other people’s salaries always are.) Depending on how you feel about lockouts and LOOGYs who get $8 million for two years, they might make you feel a little bit better about pro sports in America. Yes, there have been some ugly leg-breaking tackles of late. But at least our soccer players aren’t a lot of spoiled rich guys, you know? By my quick count, only six players make more than the $1.2 million Bobby Bonilla will be getting from the Mets every year for the next 25 years (he retired from baseball in 2001, in case you’re wondering why you haven’t heard that name in a while). And if you pool the salaries of the two biggest names in M.L.S., David Beckham and Thierry Henry, you still won’t have enough to cover Eddy Curry’s $11 million-plus salary this past season.

headline: An Epic Game 4 in Memphis
text: It was fitting that something amazing would happen at the FedEx Forum in Memphis Tuesday night. The arena is not much more than a long golf shot from the Mississippi River, which had risen so high Tuesday, people were flocking downtown just to ogle it, perhaps the oddest of all tourist attractions. If some of them filed into the Grizzlies’ playoff game against Oklahoma City, they found themselves watching another force of nature: a 133-123 triple-overtime victory by the Thunder with 256 points, 206 field goal attempts, 90 free throw attempts and 67 personal fouls.

headline: The Big Winners in the Skype Deal
text: Skype is neither a start-up nor a stalwart.

headline: Catching Scent of Revolution, China Moves to Snip Jasmine
text: DAXING, China — Do not be lulled by its intoxicating fragrance or the dainty, starlike blossoms whose whiteness suggests innocence and purity. Jasmine, a stalwart of Chinese tea and the subject of a celebrated folk song often heard while on hold with provincial bureaucrats, is not what it seems.

headline: Antipsychotics Overused in Nursing Homes, Audit Finds
text: The Times reports today that that nearly one in seven elderly nursing home residents, almost all of them with dementia, are given powerful atypical antipsychotic drugs even though the medicines increase the risk of death and are not approved for such treatments, a government audit found.

headline: More Hopes Than Gains At U.S.-China Meetings
text: WASHINGTON — Two days of high-level talks between the United States and China wrapped up Tuesday with both sides hailing modest progress on economic issues even as they traded harsh words about China’s respect for human rights.

headline: Pearl Vision
text: For her latest collection, the jeweler Monique Péan went in search of sustainable pearls — and wound up working in a lagoon in the South Pacific. Péan says she furthered her commitment to eco-minded jewelry during her CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund mentorship at Tiffany & Company; she and the company’s C.E.O., Michael Kowalski, share what he calls “an approach to precious materials that is sustainable and benefits the communities involved.” The quest led Péan to the Ahe atoll in French Polynesia, where the Kamoka Pearl Farm uses fish and sponges to clean its oyster shells. The farm harvests without chemicals, feeds its employees (“Raw oysters, fried oysters, oyster risotto, a lot of oysters!” Péan says) and turns the shells into beads. Péan’s line uses Kamoka’s keshi pearls in hues of blue, aubergine and gold for pieces like a ring set with delicate pavé-diamond tendrils (conflict-free, of course), which Péan says was inspired by Ahe’s “pollution-free midnight sky reflecting against the waves and the light.”

headline: Romney to Deliver Health Care Speech in Michigan
text: Mitt Romney is often asked about health care. On Thursday, he will talk about it.

headline: Trailer: Portal 2
text: The premise is that you are a woman trapped in the future in an abandoned robot factory buried beneath the Midwestern plains.

headline: Video of Arrests in Damascus
text: While the Syrian government continues to keep independent journalists away from protesters, my colleague Anthony Shadid was permitted to make a brief visit to Damascus, the Syrian capital, on Monday to interview two close allies of President Bashar al-Assad — a senior official and a powerful businessman. He reports:

headline: Levine Buoyed by Well-Wishers During Next-to-Last ‘Walküre’
text: James Levine looked heartened by the enormous ovation he received on Monday night when he appeared in the pit at the Metropolitan Opera to conduct Wagner’s “Walküre” in the production by Robert Lepage.

headline: Readers Offer Their Own Restaurant Rules
text: Turns out, 100 rules were not enough. Readers thought I missed a few. Many of them made me feel better, calmer, a more measured individual. Take the first two comments: one threatens a server’s eyeballs, the second his or her very life. And you thought I was tough.

headline: The Oracle of Omaha Comes to Scranton: Warren Buffett to Appear on ‘Office’ Finale
text: If anyone could get Steve Carell to stay on at “The Office” past his departure date it would be Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, whose investors were treated to a taped performance by Mr. Carell and his “Office” colleagues at that company’s annual shareholders meeting (two days after Mr. Carell’s farewell episode).

headline: Physics, With Wormholes by You
text: Physics — the basic behavior of this particular reality —can be beautiful. Read Newton or Einstein. Or you could play Portal 2, the achingly brilliant new game from the Valve Corporation that wrings more fun out of physics than all of the shoot-’em-ups in the world.

headline: Bronx Charter Makes Eating Well Part of Its Philosophy
text: The cafeteria at the Family Life Academy Charter School in the Bronx looks like a standard public school cafeteria. There are stacks of plastic yellow trays, enormous white folding tables and the raucous din of children, released from their classrooms to talk loudly and freely about whatever they want.

headline: Germany Rejects Talk of Easing Bailout Terms
text: BERLIN — Ignoring mounting criticism from Greece and Ireland over the terms of their bailouts, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany refused Tuesday to commit her country to any changes and insisted that “bold reforms” were the only way to make their economies stronger.

headline: Helping New Grads Find a Good Used Car
text: A tight used-car market this spring means new graduates (or, in many cases, their parents) may have to do a bit more hunting than usual to find a ride they can afford on a just-starting-out salary.

headline: French Lean Toward Ban of a Controversial Gas Extraction Technique
text: PARIS — French lawmakers opened debate on Tuesday on proposals to ban a method for extracting oil and gas deposits from shale because of environmental concerns, throwing up the first serious stumbling block to firms that want to use the practice.

headline: Neil Patrick Harris Will Return as Tony Awards Host
text: In a year when offbeat experiments with the hosts of major award shows haven’t always yielded satisfying results, it’s understandable that the organizers of the Tony Awards would turn to someone with experience to serve as their master of ceremonies. Neil Patrick Harris, who  hosted the 2009 Tony Awards program – not to mention the 2009 Emmy Awards and, for some reason, the 2010 Spike Video Game Awards — will return as host of next month’s Tonys show, the award program’s press representatives said on Tuesday.

text: Here’s HotAir’s Allahpundit, mulling the possibility of a Mitch Daniels primary campaign:

headline: Lowering Stress Improves Fertility Treatment
text: Women undergoing certain infertility treatments are more likely to become pregnant if they take part in a simultaneous stress reduction program, new research shows.

text: Microsoft‘s $8.5 billion acquisition of Skype is the biggest technology deal so far this year.

headline: Leaving Home
text: Last night was my last self-cooked home-cooked meal for the next few weeks: I’m embarking on a research trip to Toronto (that’s today; I’m writing on the way to the airport), Immokalee (Florida), Detroit and then seven days in Iowa.

headline: Wheelies: The General Store Edition

headline: Robert Stempel, an Engineer Who Led G.M., Dies at 77
text: DETROIT — Robert C. Stempel, a mechanical engineer who helped develop the catalytic converter and served as chairman and chief executive of General Motors during a troubled two-year period for the automaker, died on Saturday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77.

text: Need more proof that New York is swiftly becoming a hot spot for technology and innovation?

headline: Warner Music Posts $38 Million Net Loss
text: The Warner Music Group, the only one of the four major record labels that reports its financial information in detail as a stand-alone public company, had a net loss of $38 million for the first three months of 2011, with slight growth in its recorded music and publishing operations.

headline: Astrology Will Run in the Preakness
text: Stonestreet Stables has had good luck shipping to Baltimore for the Preakness Stakes. Curlin won it in 2007, and Rachel Alexandra became a star and the first filly in 85 years to win the second leg of the Triple Crown in 2009.

headline: Calder Prize Awarded to American Artist
text: The 2011 Calder Prize, which honors contemporary artists who have completed exemplary work early in their careers, will be awarded to the American artist Rachel Harrison, the Calder Foundation and the Scone Foundation have announced.

headline: Bin Laden Sons Say U.S. Broke International Law
text: WASHINGTON — The adult sons of Osama bin Laden have lashed out at President Obama in their first public reaction to their father’s death, accusing the United States of violating its basic legal principles by killing an unarmed man, shooting his family members and disposing of his body in the sea.

headline: Luster Dims For a Public Microlender
text: MUMBAI, India — After SKS Microfinance, India’s largest microlender, completed its initial public offering last August, its shares quickly shot up 50 percent. Financial analysts charted rosy forecasts about the firm’s future.

headline: Using Economics to Help the World’s Poor
text: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo — both professors at M.I.T. — have helped changed the practice of economics. Mr. Banerjee and Ms. Duflo have pushed anti-poverty programs in developing countries to become more serious about evaluating whether they are actually improving people’s lives.

headline: Thing Thuan, Ploy Phi & Tay Krajard
text: “Dropping of lances,” “setting free the ghosts” and “emptying the baskets” – terms associated with the excessive spending of Thai governments seeking re-election.

headline: Robert Stempel, a Voice for Alternative-Energy Sources, Dies at 77
text: Robert C. Stempel, the former General Motors chairman and chief executive who died on Saturday at 77, spent a turbulent two years atop the country’s largest automaker, during which he cut jobs and closed plants to minimize company losses. However, for every automaker that deepens its experimentation in alternative-energy sources, Mr. Stempel’s legacy as an auto-industry seer is bolstered.

headline: Bag a Winner
text: Kate Moss may have a lot of baggage, but when she marries Jamie Hince this summer, she’ll no doubt leave it all behind for the new Kate Moss for Longchamp travel bag ($1,320; longchamp.com). The attention-grabbing carry-on is designed to meet airline restrictions and keep clothes crease-free. If only it could fend off paparazzi.

headline: Never Mention the Housekeeper
text: There are certain words you learn to use carefully when you write about parenting. Breast-feeding is one. Co-sleeping is another. Home schooling is on the list, too. These are words that tend to divide parents by world views that they did not necessarily even know they had.

headline: Adobe Makes Apps to Enhance Photoshop
text: The Apple iPad is quickly moving from a consumption device to a creation device.

headline: American Crossroads Backs Republican Financially in Upstate House Race
text: WASHINGTON — A conservative group formed with help from the Republican strategist Karl Rove has jumped into a special Congressional election in upstate New York that has become important to the two major parties.

headline: Race and Response
text: Dan Butler and David Broockman of Yale had a very bright idea. They mailed a series of letters to legislators in which a fictional constituent asked for help in registering to vote. Some of the letters were signed with putatively black names (like DeShawn Jackson) and some were signed with putatively white names (like Jake Mueller).  The letters from the putatively black constituents received fewer responses from white legislators and received more responses from minority legislators.

headline: Fishers With Personality?
text: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

headline: Statement From the Family of Osama bin Laden
text: Statement from the family of Sheikh Osama bin Laden

headline: What Does the Skype Deal Mean for Windows Phones?
text: Microsoft’s deal to buy Skype has raised many eyebrows in the technology industry, both for the price tag and the partnership, which many have said is puzzling.

headline: High Art, Which Is to Say 29,029 Feet
text: The cartoonist Ranan R. Lurie has had his downs and ups: He has gone skydiving with Israeli soldiers and the 101st Airborne Division, and he has climbed Mount Fuji in Japan. But only the art, not the artist, is going to the top of Mount Everest.

headline: The Fighting Man’s Beast
text: Luke Mogelson questions the “bad apples” theory of war crimes but doesn’t question the enterprise that makes such crimes possible, perhaps inevitable. What’s the difference between soldiers’ taking advantage of a dangerous and confusing situation to commit murder and countries using a dangerous and confusing situation as an excuse for war? If the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had caused the surrender of the militant fundamentalists who seek our destruction, if they had denied these enemies the ability to attack, if the wars hadn’t devastated the economies and the innocent citizens of the countries we attacked, they might be justified.JAMIE BALDWIN,Redding, Conn., e-mail

headline: Joyce Carol Oates Updates Her ‘Widow’s Story’
text: When Joyce Carol Oates’s memoir, “A Widow’s Story,” came out in February, some reviewers took her to task for not mentioning that 13 months after the death of her husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, she remarried. Writing in The New York Review of Books, Julian Barnes said “some readers will feel they have a good case for breach of narrative promise.” In a letter in the current issue of The New York Review Ms. Oates defended her choice , writing that the book was meant to be about the immediate experience of widowhood, not her subsequent life. But she also wrote that “in retrospect I can see that I should have added something like an appendix, to bring my personal history up to date,” and said that she hopes to add such an appendix to later editions.

headline: Goldman Discloses More Subpoenas
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: Boehner Likes Christie and Daniels for 2012
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: Cuomo Says Legislature Is Rife With Corruption
text: ONONDAGA, N.Y. — Decrying the State Legislature as infiltrated with corruption and unable to police itself, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo began a statewide tour on Tuesday aiming to shame lawmakers into revamping ethics rules and passing the rest of his legislative agenda.

headline: Congress Hears From Apple and Google on Privacy
text: Saying there has been a fundamental shift for cellphone users in determining “who has their information and what they’re doing with it,” Senator Al Franken, a Minnesota Democrat, called a Congressional hearing today to question executives from both Google and Apple on data location and mobile devices. The hearing was the first for the newly formed Senate Judiciary subcommittee on privacy, technology and the law, led by Senator Franken.

headline: Bloom and Bust
text: A brief history of the tulip.

headline: Postcard from the Edge | Clifford Ross for T
text: Pretty much every T we commission for the magazine has a back story. But few go as far back—or have as many plot twists—as the story behind this particular T, which was created by the artist Clifford Ross and will appear in the upcoming Summer Travel issue.

headline: Newspaper ‘Regrets’ Erasing Hillary Clinton
text: Updated | 5:06 p.m. A newspaper catering to ultra-Orthodox Jews in New York apologized on Monday for publishing a photograph of the White House Situation Room during the raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound that was digitally altered to make it seem as if Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and another female official had not been present.

headline: Two New National Magazine Awards
text: There are two new Alexander Calder stabiles in our possession. Last night, the magazine won two National Magazine Awards, or Ellies (so called for the sculpture’s resemblance to an elephant). One was for News and Documentary Photography for “The Shrine Down the Hall,” photographs by Ashley Gilbertson; essay by Dexter Filkins. The photo essay was a portrait of the preserved bedrooms of the young people killed in the wars of Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: Like Magic, Great Sports Nicknames Are Disappearing
text: Today’s baseball rosters are filled with names, not nicknames, not like the ones that used to be. The N.B.A. playoffs are equally devoid of onomastic pleasures, just cheap echoes of Magic and the Mailman, Tiny and Tree, Chief and Cornbread. The N.F.L. cannot match the treasured nicknames that evoke folk heroes like Night Train, Hacksaw and the Refrigerator.

headline: Bathhouse and Gas Company Building Are Named Landmarks
text: A former public bathhouse in Midtown Manhattan and the former headquarters of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in Downtown Brooklyn have been designated as landmarks, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission announced on Tuesday.

headline: Apple and Google Executives Testify on Mobile Privacy
text: Saying there has been a fundamental shift for cellphone users in determining “who has their information and what they’re doing with it,” Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, held a hearing Tuesday to question executives from Google and Apple on data location and mobile devices. The hearing was the first for the newly formed Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology and the Law, led by Mr. Franken. Read more about the hearing on Media Decoder.

headline: Good Citizenship: Assessing Civics Knowledge and Education
text: Overview | Why is civics education important? What are the most effective and engaging ways to engage teenagers in learning civics? In this lesson, students will conduct a research project about civic education and students’ knowledge at their school. They will then prepare a presentation of their findings and recommendations to a panel of their school;s history faculty and administrators.

headline: ‘Dancing’ to the Top
text: “Dancing With the Stars” attracted 20.2 million viewers on Monday, lifting ABC far head of its network competitors in the night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. ABC’s “Castle” won the 10 p.m. time slot after the two-hour installment of “Dancing With the Stars,” garnering 12.6 million viewers and outperforming CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (9.2 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: LA” (5 million) in the hour.

headline: Microsoft Acquires Skype
text: Microsoft's $8.5 billion acquisition of Skype is the biggest technology deal so far this year, and the transaction would rank among the 12 biggest high-tech deals since 2000.

headline: Simon Russell Beale to Drive London Taxi on New York Stage

headline: Presbyterians Approve Ordination of Gay People
text: After 33 years of debate, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has voted to change its constitution and allow openly gay people in same-sex relationships to be ordained as ministers, elders and deacons.

headline: The National Bar and Dining Rooms
text: FIFTIETH Street and Lexington Avenue is the pulsing heart of no particular neighborhood, a lively intersection near the back door to the Waldorf-Astoria, just south of a DoubleTree. Office workers stream through on the way to the subway stop at the corner. Hotel guests pilot wheelie bags deep into yellow-cab traffic, and bark at one another in French. If you were looking for a neighborhood bistro of the sort where you might linger over dinner for a while, happily talking with friends while picking at fries and finishing a bottle of wine, the corner would rank low on a list of possible locations.

headline: Reviewing the National

headline: The Morning Line: Motion Is Still Riding High
text: This is somewhat of slower day for news about the Triple Crown with some of the horses in transit. Animal Kingdom is headed back to his training headquarters at Fair Hill in Maryland. The trainer Graham Motion is still ecstatic about the Kentucky Derby victory. Motion says: “I have a lot of confidence in this horse. He’s the whole package…I guess, to use a term that’s probably overused. He’s got a tremendous disposition and is just a really brilliant horse.”

The sculpture is one of seven to be unveiled in Riverside Park in June as part of the Model to Monument program, a partnership between the Art Students League of New York and the City Parks Department to create art for public parks.

headline: In Japan, a Boat Stranded by Tsunami Is Lifted From Rooftop
text: Photos of compelling cars are nothing new to the Automobiles section. But the shot of a Mitsubishi i-MiEV in a tsunami-struck town in Japan, which ran in Sunday’s Automobiles section, was arresting because, about one block away from the electric vehicle, a two-story building was topped by a boat.

headline: Bill Paying Made Easier, but for a Fee
text: Lots of people like to pay big bills with their credit or debit cards so they can rack up reward points or manage their cash flow when money is tight. But it’s sometimes hard to do that with certain big bills, like those from your mortgage servicer or your electricity provider. Many of those companies still refuse to accept plastic — or accept only certain brands.

headline: Bed and Shrekfast: Gaylord Hotels Meet DreamWorks
text: There are theme parks tied to movie studios and there are theme cruises, and now, the themed hotel stay. The Gaylord hotel company has teamed up with DreamWorks to feature animated characters at its four resorts, in Nashville, Tenn., Kissimme, Fla., on the Potomac in National Harbor, Md., and Grapevine, Tex., Gaylord announced recently.

headline: The Book of Tweets
text: Did we always think in search terms and we just didn’t know it? Thoughts melded into words, and the words, if you squinted, began to yield Dominant Nouns. The dominant nouns then formed their own relationships. Early Internet searching was an art. The available results were mostly useless, so you had to “refine your search” — you had to try to think like the algorithm just as the algorithm was trying to think like you. An unexpected partnership. I always thought this was why search took off: you had the vague feeling that you were working with someone else, on the path to refinement.

headline: Met Museum Elects Trustee as Chairman
text: Daniel Brodsky, a real estate developer, was elected chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday in a vote by the museum’s board. Mr. Brodsky will assume the post on Sept. 13, succeeding James R. Houghton, who has been chairman for the past 13 years and will now become a trustee emeritus.

headline: Disney Profit Declines 1%, Partly on Movies and Parks

headline: A Cautious Memoirist Who Ends With a Laugh
text: Among Nobel laureates of recent vintage, only Mario Vargas Llosa, who won the prize in literature last year, has delivered as much pure pleasure as the Portuguese novelist José Saramago. Saramago’s best books read like hallucinatory thrillers. They’re warm to the touch; they practically palpitate in your hands.

headline: On Our Radar: War-Torn Liberia Signs Timber Deal with E.U.
text: Liberia, home to 45 percent of the rain forests in West Africa, signs a deal with the European Union to prevent illegal timber exports and develop a sustainable forestry industry. Illegal logging flourished during the country’s long civil war but led to crippling sanctions against the timber industry. [BBC]

headline: Genres and Styles Without Borders, in a Brooklyn Series
text: The border-hopping proclivities of classical composers and performers have become more pronounced in recent years, resulting in a freewheeling blend of genres and styles. Gala NYC, a new series (the name means Global Art, Local Audience) founded by Mike Block, a Juilliard-trained cellist and disciple of Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Project, aims to promote this healthy eclecticism by combining performers from varying disciplines.

headline: Deliberative Theater Critics Honor ‘Good People’
text: New York theater critics had an awfully hard time on Monday selecting the best play of the year for their annual award. Four rounds of balloting by the New York Drama Critics’ Circle revealed strong preferences for three Broadway plays that have also been nominated for this year’s Tony Award for best play — “Good People,” “Jerusalem,” and “The ____________ with the Hat.”

headline: For a Sextet’s Substitutes, a Chemistry Test
text: The effect that substitute players can have on an ensemble’s character probably varies according to the size of the group in question. Orchestras use subs on a regular basis, sometimes for extended periods, with no great impact on corporate identity. But for full-time chamber groups, consistent chemistry is a key attribute. It would be hard to imagine a prominent string quartet, for instance, soldiering on for more than a few outings with a pinch-hitter.

headline: Google Plans to Streamline Android
text: Android phones have been a runaway success for Google — perhaps too runaway. Now Google is trying to add some order to the craziness.

headline: One Tenor, Three Voices, in Arias From Handel’s Era
text: Les Violons du Roy, a Quebec  ensemble led by Bernard Labadie, has a broad repertory that includes Romantic and contemporary works. But the ensemble is best known for its zesty performances of Baroque and Classical music, performed on modern instruments, and it played to its strengths on Sunday evening at Zankel Hall in a program devoted to Handel and his contemporaries.

headline: Woman for All Seasons, Ballads and Emotions
text: One of the pleasures of cabaret reviewing over the long haul has been to observe the evolution of K T Sullivan from an effervescent musical comedian into the increasingly fearless and complex singing character actor she is today. Her new show, which opened at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel last week, is called “Rhyme, Women and Song,” but it might just as well be titled “The Seven Ages of Woman,” for all the musical and emotional territory she covers.

headline: A Tale of Nanjing Atrocities That Spares No Brutal Detail
text: Two terrible faces stare out from “City of Life and Death,” a fictionalized telling of the Rape of Nanjing, a pair of indelible bookends for this anguished film. The first belongs to Lu (Liu Ye), who, with hundreds of other soldiers, has been rounded up by invading Japanese troops amid a frenzy of violence. The close-up of Lu’s impassive face locked in unspoken emotion floods the screen. Much later, after innumerable deaths and acts of barbarism and heroism, the face of a woman will similarly fill the screen in close-up, her frantic eyes stretched wide, as if they had been permanently shocked open by what they have seen.

headline: In Border City Talk, Obama Urges G.O.P. to Help Overhaul Immigration Law
text: EL PASO — President Obama came to this border city on Tuesday to argue that he is doing his part to crack down on illegal immigration, and that Republicans must now join him in overhauling the nation’s immigration laws for the millions of workers already here illegally.

headline: TimesCast | The Immigration Agenda

headline: Times Hires James B. Stewart, Financial Writer

headline: U.S. Reaches a Settlement on Decisions About Endangered Species

headline: Fashion With a Twist | Orly Genger at VPL
text: When Victoria Bartlett, the designer behind the Visible Panty Line label, opened her first boutique in New York late last year, she intended it to be more than just a showcase for her clothes — it would also be a gallery, where the artistic collaborations that are a regular feature of her work could be put on display. She put the plan into action for the first time on Monday night, when the Mercer Street shop was the site of an installation by the artist Orly Genger, who’s known for knotting thick nylon climbing rope into massive, room-filling shapes and who has collaborated with Bartlett on installations for her runway shows and also on accessories. “Squat,” as the new piece is called, has an unusual twist: For the duration of the event, it incorporated two live models, both clad in VPL underwear. “The idea was to have it look like something had blown through like a tornado and swept up against the window, engulfing the girls,” Bartlett explained as she surveyed the scene. “It’s this enormous muscle of rope that’s come crashing through the store.”

headline: Whimsical Winds Buffet Hearts on a Magical Isle

headline: Blood Clams: Worth a Second Look
text: Once you get past the off-putting name and appearance, you will find that blood clams have a deliciously crisp succulence, like geoduck, and a flavor that is not as briny as a littleneck or cherrystone clam. The redness that gives these cockles their name is due to a high level of hemoglobin. They are about the size of a lime and have very hard shells, with black, hairy material covering part of the shell.

headline: Tortilla Chips of a Different Munchability
text: A trip to Vermont is no longer the only way to obtain Gringo Jack’s tortilla chips, which are made at the restaurant by the same name in Manchester. These smallish flour chips can now be ordered online. Their munchability is driven by exceptional flakiness — a similar texture, if not taste, to that of the fried noodles offered in Chinese restaurants. The plain ones are fine; the whole-wheat version has deeper flavor; and the spiced ones, hand-dusted with a ruddy, vibrant mixture, suit creamy dips and make a nice garnish for ceviche, salads and soups.

headline: More Greek Out
text: An Argentine commenter on my Greece-leaving-the-euro post notes that Argentina, in addition to letting the peso drop, both defaulted on its debt and imposed temporary restrictions on bank withdrawals. Indeed. Something similar would have to happen for a euro exit to take place.

headline: Killings and Rumors Unsettle a Libyan City

headline: In Popularity Polls of Governors, Cuomo Is High on the List
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s effort to rally the public to support his agenda is based on a simple political calculation: He is popular, and the Legislature is not.

headline: Turn Your Android Phone Into a Remote Control for Your Home
text: Google wants people to use its Android software to operate a lot more than just phones and tablets. And at Google I/O, the company’s conference for developers in San Francisco this week, the company showed off a future where someone could use an Android phone to turn on and off the lights, the dishwasher, a lamp or a sprinkler system — or anything else they want to.

headline: New Bill Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Is Introduced in Assembly
text: With only weeks to go before the end of the legislative session in June, a senior Democratic lawmaker in the New York State Assembly introduced legislation on Tuesday to legalize same-sex marriages, signaling that Assembly lawmakers were unwilling to wait for efforts by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and gay rights groups to pull together enough votes to move the measure through the Republican-controlled State Senate.

headline: Hikers on Trial
text: On May 11, Shane Bauer and Josh Fattal, two of the three American hikers who were detained by Iranian officials after crossing a border between Iraqi Kurdistan and Iran in 2009, will go on trial in Tehran for espionage. They have been held in Evin Prison for almost two years.

headline: Hip Makers Told to Study More Data
text: In an unusual move, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered all producers of a popular category of artificial hip to undertake studies of the implants, which have been linked to high early failure rates and severe health effects in some patients.

headline: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATO’s Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people?

headline: Justice Department Is Investigating Google Advertising
text: The Justice Department is investigating Google advertising, and Google may have to pay $500 million, according to a Google filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday. As a result, Google said, last quarter’s net income was 22 percent lower than it originally reported.

headline: Town Torn by Tsunami Sees Reopened School as a Therapeutic Step
text: OTSUCHI, Japan — The week before classes resumed, the middle school’s gymnasium was still a makeshift morgue. But the bodies were removed and the floor disinfected, so Kirikiri Middle School could welcome back students for the first time since the tsunami swept away much of this port town.

headline: New to Teaching, Idealistic, at Risk for Layoff
text: Samantha Sherwood had lofty aspirations when she settled on a family-studies major at the University of Connecticut, like redrawing welfare rules or weaving together a sturdier safety net for people in need. She figured that she could change the world in big, broad strokes, and that she might pick up a fancy title and ample salary along the way.

headline: Kuwait Viewed As Syria’s Rival For U.N. Council
text: Syria’s attempt to join the United Nations’ main human rights body will very likely be thwarted by Kuwait, which is planning to seek the Asian seat traditionally reserved for an Arab country, Western diplomats said Tuesday.

headline: Guatemalan Court Acquits Former President of Embezzling
text: MEXICO CITY — A Guatemalan court has acquitted a former president, Alfonso Portillo, of charges that he embezzled state money.

headline: No Pardon for Felon Elected Mayor in Oklahoma
text: PHOENIX — Christopher S. Linder has had many monikers over the years: Big Slim was his gang nickname, 151011 was his inmate number, and he has been mayor-elect since voters in Pawnee, Okla., chose him to lead their small town.

headline: The Future of Cafeteria Food
text: If you have gone to school, worked in an office, factory, or other large workplace, you’ve probably eaten — and hated — your fair share of institutional cooking. I still remember the name of the food service company that ran the cafeteria where I went to college, and I would still revile it, except it deserves partial credit for forcing me to learn how to cook.

headline: Iran: Nuclear Reaction Is Begun
text: Iran has started the nuclear reaction at its Bushehr power plant, the Russian company that built the reactor said in a statement on Tuesday that indicated Iran is close to wrapping up work on the site that has dragged on for more than three decades. The German company Siemens abandoned the partly completed plant after the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, and more delays followed even after Russia resumed construction in 1994. The United States once opposed the plant. But the International Atomic Energy Agency monitors it, and the United States dropped its objections after Russia provided assurances of controls on the fuel supply and the disposal of spent fuel rods. The Russian state company that builds reactors abroad said that operators at the plant would test safety and control equipment before connecting the reactor to electricity generating turbines, a process that could take about two months.

headline: Critics Fear G.O.P.’s Proposed Medicaid Changes Could Cut Coverage for the Aged
text: WASHINGTON — As Republicans inch away from their plan to reshape the nation’s Medicare program, their equally transformative ideas for Medicaid, now largely in the shadows of the budget debate, are moving front and center.

headline: A Critique of a Texas Representative’s Air Quality Claims
text: In March, the Environmental Protection Agency, acting under court order, proposed the first national standard for emissions of mercury, sulfur dioxide and other pollutants from coal-fired power plants.

headline: Yankees Prepare for Younger, More Aggressive Royals
text: The Yankees opened a three-game series Tuesday against the Kansas City Royals, who are quite a bit more challenging than they have been for a while. The youthful Royals love to run, apparently from the moment that their manager, Ned Yost, opened spring training.

headline: Horace Freeland Judson, Science Historian, Dies at 80
text: Horace Freeland Judson, a science writer whose 1979 book “The Eighth Day of Creation” is regarded as the definitive account of the breakthroughs that transformed molecular biology in the mid-20th century, died on Friday at his home in Baltimore. He was 80.

headline: Focused on the Swing, Not the Score
text: WINDERMERE, FLA. — When Sean Foley was a college golfer, he sometimes exasperated his coach by giving tips to opposing players. He was precociously interested in swing theory and swing mechanics, more concerned with how many greens he hit in regulation than with his final score. When he was 14, an obsessive reader of golf instruction books, he was offering unsolicited — and possibly incorrect — advice to hapless duffers. At 16, he could imitate Nick Faldo frame by frame on video.

headline: The Composer’s Other Voice
text: I have been a composer for my entire adult life. And for the most part, despite the exhaustion and relative poverty it has entailed, this self-styled “job” has been a source of satisfaction, even great joy.

headline: Saying Farewell to a Gangster of a Bygone Era
text: The man and woman unfolded themselves from a cab at the corner of Ninth Avenue and 42nd Street, then stood blinking in the sunlight for a few seconds, searching for a familiar piece of ground, a bearing. So there: the bus terminal across the street. But their gazes lingered on tall buildings that had risen in the last two decades or so. It was nearly 10:30 on Tuesday morning. They shuffled down the street and melted into a small crowd on the sidewalk outside the Church of the Holy Cross.

headline: After Bin Laden, U.S. Reassesses Afghan Strategy
text: WASHINGTON — The killing of Osama bin Laden has set off a reassessment of the war in Afghanistan and the broader effort to combat terrorism, with Congress, the military and the Obama administration weighing the goals, strategies, costs and underlying authority for a conflict that is now almost a decade old.

headline: Six From FIFA Are Accused in Bribery Case
text: Soccer’s world governing body, which has little international oversight and has long faced charges of corruption, found itself embattled again Tuesday when six of its top officials were accused of participating in a bribery scandal related to bids for the 2018 and the 2022 World Cups.

text: Microsoft has peered into the future, and placed a bet that people the world over want to stay in touch with someone anytime and anywhere — preferably at no cost.

headline: Google Lobbies Nevada to Allow Self-Driving Cars
text: Google, a pioneer of self-driving cars, is quietly lobbying for legislation that would make Nevada the first state where they could be legally operated on public roads.

headline: Bad Bargains
text: So Osama bin Laden was living in a specially built villa in Pakistan. I wonder where he got the money to buy it? Cashed in his Saudi 401(k)? A Pakistani subprime mortgage, perhaps? No. I suspect we will find that it all came from the same place most of Al Qaeda’s funds come from: some combination of private Saudi donations spent under the watchful eye of the Pakistani Army.

headline: Iraqis Share Their Views on U.S. Troop Presence

headline: Google’s Digital Music Service Falls Short of Ambition
text: Google had big plans for its new digital music service. It wanted an online store to compete with iTunes and Amazon, as well as a “smart locker” storage system in which the company would stream music to its millions of users from a gigantic central jukebox.

headline: Pressure Grows for Trustee to Leave Board of CUNY
text: The day after City University of New York trustees approved an honorary degree for the playwright Tony Kushner, pressure continued to mount on Tuesday for the resignation or removal of the trustee who had raised concerns about Mr. Kushner’s views on Israel.

headline: Neo-Nazi Father Is Killed; Son, 10, Steeped in Beliefs, Is Accused
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The day before he allegedly shot his father, the sandy-haired 10-year-old boy showed off a prized possession to a visitor. It was a thin leather belt emblazoned with a silver insignia of the Nazi SS.

headline: Should U.S. Stay or Go? Views Define Iraqi Factions
text: BAGHDAD — In the Shiite enclave of Sadr City, young men demand in militant tones that American troops leave immediately. Iraqi Army officers worry that the country will take a violent turn if the troops go. In the north, Kurdish factions that have enjoyed 20 years of American security guarantees fret about their future, and Sunni Muslims worry about Iran’s rise as a political power. In Parliament, the political leadership has largely stayed silent.

headline: Without Concessions, Connecticut Starts Layoff Process

Malloy began issuing layoff notices on Tuesday to the first of more than 4,700 state employees facing dismissal, after two months of negotiations with unions failed to reach an agreement on worker concessions and budget cuts.

headline: Peace Corps Volunteers Speak Out on Rape
text: WASHINGTON — Jess Smochek arrived in Bangladesh in 2004 as a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer with dreams of teaching English and “helping the world.” She left six weeks later a rape victim after being brutalized in an alley by a knife-wielding gang.

A former F.A. president and one-time leader of England’s failed World Cup bid, David Triesman, accused four top FIFA officials of soliciting bribes for their votes in bidding to host the World Cup. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

headline: President Obama at the Border
text: President Obama went to the border in El Paso on Tuesday and delivered a speech on immigration reform. He didn’t present a bill or issue any executive orders or set deadlines for action. Aides say his goal was to “create a pathway” and “a sense of urgency” to “move forward.” That is a start but not nearly enough.

headline: Bringing the Mall of America Magic to New Jersey
text: When the Ghermezian brothers, immigrants from Iran who had settled in western Canada, wanted to build the largest shopping center in the United States a quarter-century ago, they shipped a submarine that had been custom-built for them in Vancouver — and was an offbeat attraction at their mall in Edmonton — to Bloomington, Minn., and parked it in front of City Hall. Their company, Triple Five, won the development rights for what would become the Mall of America.

headline: Ticket-Fixing: A New Twist in an Inquiry
text: Ticket-fixing was so prevalent among police officers in the Bronx that even a highway officer whose job was to administer Breathalyzer tests — the very tool used to determine if a driver is drunk — was himself caught on a wiretap trying to fix a ticket for someone, according to a person with knowledge of the contents of the wiretap.

headline: Loan Limits' Effect on Counties
text: The National Association of Realtors’ calculations of how the change in government loan limits will affect various counties. The GSEs, or government-sponsored enterprises, are the government-controlled mortgage holding companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

headline: Governor Presses Lawmakers in Albany to Pass His Agenda
text: ONONDAGA, N.Y. — Denouncing the State Legislature as riddled with conflicts of interest and unable to police itself, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo began a statewide tour on Tuesday intended to shame lawmakers into overhauling ethics rules and passing the rest of his legislative agenda.

headline: Federal Retreat on Bigger Loans Rattles Housing
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — By summer’s end, buyers and sellers in some of the country’s most upscale housing markets are slated to lose one their biggest benefactors: the deep pockets of the federal government. In this seaside community of pricey homes, the dread of yet another housing shock is already spreading.

headline: G.M. to Spend $2 Billion in Hiring and to Upgrade U.S. Plants
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — General Motors said Tuesday that it would invest $2 billion in its factories in the United States to meet gradually growing demand for its products in the aftermath of its government-sponsored bankruptcy.

headline: MoMA to Buy Building Used by Museum of Folk Art
text: The Museum of Modern Art is buying the building of the struggling American Folk Art Museum on West 53rd Street, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Prosecution in Rape Trial Assails Story of Officer
text: A prosecutor on Tuesday grilled a police officer accused of rape on numerous minuscule details of the night in question.

headline: Ex-Senator Needs Longer Sentence, Prosecutors Say
text: A former New York state senator who offered to serve as a diplomat in the Middle East to avoid a prison term of up to two years for his conviction on corruption charges should instead receive an even harsher sentence because he has failed to accept responsibility for his crimes, federal prosecutors told a judge on Tuesday.

headline: From Low Draft Pick to Chance in Rotation
text: DENVER — By the time the 21st round of baseball’s amateur draft arrived in 2007, Dillon Gee still had a faint hope of being selected by a major league team. But as he sat through each previous round without his name being called, Gee said he thought more and more about becoming a firefighter, like his father, Kevin Gee.

headline: From Low Draft Pick to Chance in Rotation
text: DENVER — By the time the 21st round of baseball’s amateur draft arrived in 2007, Dillon Gee still had a faint hope of being selected by a major league team. But as he sat through each previous round without his name being called, Gee said he thought more and more about becoming a firefighter, like his father, Kevin Gee.

headline: Voicefeed Tries to Improve Voice Mail
text: It may seem the only way to improve voice mail is to do away with it. But an app called “On Voicefeed,” which lets you customize messages for different callers, makes voice jail a bit more palatable.

text: Brookline, Mass.

headline: Bad Luck and Hard Times on the Menu at a Bus Terminal in West Virginia
text: WEIRTON, W.Va. — The bus terminal in this old mill town used to be for people who were going places. Greyhound would take them to nearby Pittsburgh and Cleveland and other cities where the steel industry was booming.

headline: A Social Networking Device for Smokers
text: Companies have started adding the ability to communicate wirelessly to an increasing range of devices, like tablet computers, cars and refrigerators.

headline: At a Crucial Moment, Rodriguez Delivers for the Yankees
text: The moment would have been filled with noise and high drama even if Alex Rodriguez were not at the plate. The Yankees had loaded the bases with two out in the fifth inning Tuesday, and the sounds of sirens, explosions and rock music were pumped over the loudspeakers at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Haiti’s Continuing Cholera Outbreak
text: A United Nations report on the cholera outbreak that has sickened 300,000 Haitians since last fall, killing nearly 5,000, finds evidence to suggest that the disease may have originated at a United Nations military camp north of the capital, which spilled raw sewage into a tributary of the Artibonite River. The epidemic was able to spread so far only because of the chronic and horrible deficiencies in Haiti’s sanitation and health care systems, which long predate the 2010 earthquake.

headline: Florida Legislature Votes to Ease Rules on Development
text: MIAMI — Just before the Republican-led Florida Legislature finished up its session for the year, it gave developers a parting gift: It pushed through measures that would reverse 25 years of growth management law by loosening state oversight of builders and making it harder for people to challenge development.

headline: Even for Gov. Christie, This One’s a Stretch
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey prides himself on his bluster and relishes the attention it garners in conservative circles beyond the state. He jumped the shark last month, suggesting he might defy the State Supreme Court if it orders him to make up a $1.6 billion shortfall of education financing that disproportionately punishes poorer districts and their students.

headline: Skype Deal Is Unlikely to Pay Off for Microsoft
text: Microsoft has only recently embraced the Internet cloud. But from the perspective of its shareholders, that’s certainly where its $8.5 billion deal to buy Skype belongs.

headline: Prices of Imported Goods Increase as the Dollar Declines
text: Prices of goods imported into the United States rose 2.2 percent in April, more than forecast, as a slumping dollar and growing economies overseas pushed up the cost of fuel and food.

headline: Cake Mixes, Taken Seriously
text: FOR decades, advertising for Duncan Hines cake mix has itself followed a recipe, featuring mothers baking cakes for children, or children encountering a freshly baked cake and mischievously helping themselves to a piece.

headline: M.L.S. Salary Figures Released
text: Major League Soccer’s players union released the 2011 salary figures for the league’s players over the weekend, and the disparity between rich and poor was clear.

headline: Republican Demands and the Debt Limit
text: Even before the White House and the Republicans began talks on the debt limit, John Boehner made clear that he was looking for a political fight, not a compromise.

headline: Appellate Court Hears Defense of Health Law
text: RICHMOND, Va. — The Obama administration opened its appellate defense of the 2010 health care act on Tuesday before three randomly selected judges who each had been appointed by Democratic presidents, including two named by President Obama himself.

headline: Another Bronx Getaway, This Time Without the Scales
text: Has the Bronx Zoo cobra been sharing her getaway secrets?

headline: For Schwarzenegger and Shriver, a Transition and a Separation
text: LOS ANGELES — Since the start of the year, one of the big mysteries here has been what the state’s most famous couple — Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor, and Maria Shriver, a former television news correspondent and a daughter of the Kennedy dynasty— would do after Mr. Schwarzenegger returned to private life.

headline: Utah Immigration Law Is Blocked
text: A federal judge in Utah on Tuesday temporarily barred a state law to curb illegal immigration from taking effect, saying he wanted to give both sides in a lawsuit more time to prepare their arguments.

headline: Ohio: Doctor Found Guilty on Drug Counts
text: A doctor who the federal authorities said was one of the largest national dispensers of Oxycodone, a powerful prescription painkiller, was convicted on Tuesday of illegal distribution. As a result of the verdict, in federal court in Cincinnati, Dr. Paul H. Volkman of Chicago could face life in prison for illegal distribution of a controlled substance that resulted in the death of four people in southern Ohio, where he practiced. Such a sentence would be the first of its kind in Ohio, where the authorities are trying to strengthen laws to combat the drug scourge, one of the worst in the nation.

headline: California: High-Speed Rail Plan Is Questioned
text: California should rethink its plan to build the first leg of the nation’s only true high-speed rail project in a stretch of the Central Valley because it would attract too few riders, a report issued Tuesday by the State Legislative Analyst’s Office said. The report, which warns that the full route from San Francisco to Los Angeles may never be completed and is likely to cost more than the estimated $43 billion, calls for starting construction in a more densely populated area and for giving control of the project to the State Transportation Department. The independent authority currently overseeing the work said it would review the recommendations. The federal government has awarded the project $3.6 billion.

headline: Alabama: Another Twist in Corruption Case
text: A federal appeals court has reversed two charges against a former health executive in a closely watched corruption case. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, based in Atlanta, upheld most of the convictions stemming from $500,000 in contributions by Richard M. Scrushy, a former HealthSouth chief executive, to retire the debt of a state lottery campaign backed by former Gov. Don E. Siegelman, and sent both men’s cases back to Federal District Court for resentencing. A Department of Justice spokeswoman, Laura Sweeney, said the department was “pleased” with the court’s decision. But Sam Heldman, an attorney for Mr. Siegelman, said the court’s definition of bribery was open to interpretation by prosecutors, and many politicians and contributors could run afoul of it. “It places everyone’s liberty at the mercy of mind readers,” he said.

headline: Not Even Warhol Can Liven a Slow Night at Sotheby’s
text: A mix of overly optimistic sellers and price-conscious buyers made for a bumpy evening at Sotheby’s sale of contemporary art on Tuesday night. In an overflowing salesroom filled with big-money collectors like the former Hollywood agent Michael Ovitz, the fashion designer Valentino and the Los Angeles financier Eli Broad, the audience did more watching than shopping, with thin bidding on the most expensive works.

headline: Chip Supplier Sees Full Output in Fall
text: The world’s leading supplier of electronic control chips for automobiles, whose main factory was heavily damaged by Japan’s powerful earthquake, said it hoped to resume full shipments to customers by the end of October.

headline: China’s Efforts to Cut Inflation Fall Short
text: HONG KONG — Consumer prices in April rose faster than the Chinese government’s target for the fourth month in a row, as bank lending also climbed faster than expected, economic data released Wednesday morning showed.

headline: Rent vs. Buy, a Longer List
text: My column this week revisits the question of whether to buy a home or rent one. In the newspaper, we included a chart showing average rent ratios — the purchase price of a house divided by the annual rent of a similar house — for several metropolitan areas. Here, we include a longer list.

headline: Stephen Herrero on Black Bear Attacks
text: Stephen Herrero, a University of Calgary professor emeritus, discusses a new study of fatal black bear attacks in North America.

headline: Fidgeting Your Way to Fitness
text: If work is interfering with your plans for a workout today, perhaps you should drum your fingers against your desktop in frustration. Doing so may help, in some small way, to maintain or augment your fitness, at least according to a study published last month in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise.

headline: Art From Allan Stone Estate Is a Big Draw
text: Sculptures fashioned from mangled bits of old cars, and paintings depicting cakes topped with fluffy frosting, gave a peek at the visual world of Allan Stone, the legendary Manhattan dealer who died in 2006, and whose collection was the subject of a special sale at Sotheby’s on Monday.

headline: Chile: Power Project Approved
text: Officials in Chile have approved a huge hydroelectric project in the heart of Patagonia, setting off protests by environmentalists in several cities. The Environmental Assessment Commission of Coyhaique, a regional government commission in southern Chile, approved on Monday the $3.2 billion project, which involves a series of five dams in the sparsely populated region of Aysén, which is dotted with nature reserves. Government officials say the HidroAysén project is needed to help stave off an energy squeeze in Chile, which imports about 70 percent of its energy. Environmentalists say it will flood thousands of acres of largely undeveloped territory and damage ranching and tourism. The police arrested at least 60 people late Monday in Santiago at a downtown protest that attracted thousands. Hundreds of demonstrators also took to the streets in at least four other Chilean cities. Opponents, including some members of Chile’s Congress, said Tuesday that they would appeal in court, while opposition legislators said they would request a congressional investigation into irregularities in the project’s approval.

headline: Davis Helps Mets Win, but Is Injured in a Collision

headline: F.A. Official Names Names, but Only After Playing Along

Several reports of corruption and bribery within the sport’s world governing body preceded the final voting process, calling into question the integrity of the organization and way in which it operates. And the final decision only served to heighten suspicions.

headline: After Quake, Toyota’s Profit Plummets 77%

I mean that literally: during an interlude in “Love Is Eternal Sacred Light” from his new album, “So Beautiful or So What,” Mr. Simon threw his arms wide, deepened his voice and ventured his best deity. Somehow the Supreme Being, confiding and complaining as if bellied up to the bar, sounded a lot like a guy in a Paul Simon song.

headline: Kanye West Turns Melodious and Moody at MoMA
text: Moving forward, every Kanye West show should conclude with a rant. headline: A Drinker’s Guide to Mumbai’s ‘Permit Rooms’
text: Considering Mumbai’s reputation as India’s night-life capital, it is something of an anomaly that the city is still technically under prohibition. Imposed by the state government shortly after India achieved Independence, prohibition has been gradually eased over the years but was never completely lifted. One of the remaining constraints is that anyone attempting to purchase or consume alcohol must obtain a “permit” declaring that they “continue to require foreign liquor and country liquor for preservation and maintenance of my health.”

headline: The Sweet Spot of Business Growth
text: The growth of business revenue can be steady or sporadic, and it can also reverse itself and go down. Even more complicated is profit, which does not always stay on speaking terms with revenue. Even when sales can go up, profit can go south. The reverse can also happen, which may seem counterintuitive. Let me explain.

headline: Old Mutual Investment Group Hires New C.F.O.
text: Old Mutual Asset Management, the asset management and hedge fund arm of the London-based life insurer, named Steve Belgrad as chief financial officer on Wednesday.

headline: After 60 Years, an Unfaded Desire to Make It ‘Legal’
text: Richard Adrian Dorr first sang for John Mace at the Juilliard School of Music in 1948: a rendition of the show tune “All the Things You Are,” in which the singer elegantly explains all the wonderful things his lover is to him.

headline: Obama and Boehner Face Off on Role of Government
text: The coming clash between President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner over the budget, entitlements and the nation’s debt is being driven by political calculations that will loom large in tense negotiations this spring and into the summer.

headline: Trial of American Hikers Charged With Espionage in Iran Is Unexpectedly Delayed
text: PARIS — The trial of three Americans charged with espionage and illegal entry in Iran after their arrest almost two years ago near the border with Iraqi Kurdistan failed to resume in Tehran on Wednesday, and their Iranian lawyer said he had formally protested the delay.

headline: Inflation and Economic Hooliganism
text: In a way, I miss the months that followed Lehman’s failure. O.K., not really — but if it was a time of terror, it was also a time of clarity. The whole world was going to hell in a handbasket, and policy makers everywhere shared a common goal: stopping the plunge.

headline: Gold Mania in the Yukon
text: When I first met Shawn Ryan and Cathy Wood, in 2005, they were living with their two young children in a small cabin outside Dawson City, at the northernmost end of the paved road system in Canada’s Yukon Territory. It was a beautiful site in the summertime, with clear water lapping the banks of the Klondike River and the sky still bright at midnight. But the sun hit their roof for the last time each year in early December and didn’t show up again for six weeks. Temperatures in the dead of winter could reach 50 below zero. Wood sometimes feared that their children would freeze. Back then Ryan and Wood already knew they had found gold, but they didn’t have proof.

headline: A.I.G. Outlines Share Sale Plan
text: The American International Group and the Treasury Department will sell roughly 300 million shares, in the insurer’s latest step toward regaining its independence from the government.

headline: Woody Allen Headlines Cannes Guest List
text: PARIS — As the film world and its attendant paparazzi and army of scribes descend upon the 64th Cannes Film Festival that begins today and runs through May 22, the French media has mused less about the plot of the opening film, Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” than over whether one of its cast members, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, the first lady of France, would be one of those descending.

headline: Ex-Mets Employee Charged in Theft
text: The former Mets clubhouse manager Charlie Samuels was charged Wednesday in connection with the theft of nearly $2.3 million worth of team equipment and memorabilia — from hats, bats and balls to a full set of autographed 1986 World Series uniforms.

headline: The Duck Starts Here
text: Each of David Chang’s restaurant is a different animal, it seems. Momofuku Ssam Bar has a whole pork butt, Momofuku Noodle Bar serves a mountain of fried chicken, and Má Pêche does beef seven ways.

headline: Duck and Cover and Check Your Cellphone
text: Those of us old enough to remember “I Love Lucy” when it was a hot new thing on television are also old enough to remember civil defense drills that had us ducking under our desks at school. Received wisdom back then seemed to be that if the Russians ever dropped the big one, the desks would keep us from being vaporized like soldiers in the original “The Day the Earth Stood Still.”

headline: Quote Unquote | The Will to Power Indeed
text: -Karl Lagerfeld tells WWD about his latest project: publishing the complete writings of Friedrich Nietzsche. Easy is totally a word I would use to describe Nietzsche’s writing.

headline: Venice Reclaimed
text: The common refrain about Venice, besides that it’s sinking, is that it is no longer a city for Venetians. The native population is declining (as is most of Italy’s), replaced by some 20 million tourists a year. But several recent restoration projects, both well financed and small-scale, are bringing a sense of localism back to the city.

headline: Is Another Housing Crash Coming?
text: Looking at the relative prices of buying and renting homes in Silicon Valley, Manhattan and a few other places is enough to make you wonder whether parts of the housing market are still due for a crash. To consider that question in more detail, I had a conversation with Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody’s Analytics, which provided much of the data for my column:

headline: Wednesday Reading: Antipsychotic Drugs Overused in Nursing Homes
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Merkel Signals Support for Italian to Lead E.C.B.
text: BERLIN — Germany moved Wednesday to reassure financial markets by supporting Mario Draghi as the next president of the European Central Bank, virtually assuring him of the job, but offered no quick end to uncertainty over the continuing Greek and Irish debt crises.

headline: Tea Party Express Endorses Nelson Rival in Nebraska
text: The Tea Party Express, whose money and endorsements proved key to the victories of several Senate candidates in 2010, has made its first endorsement for 2012, backing Jon Bruning, a Republican who serves as Nebraska’s attorney general, in his bid to unseat Senator Ben Nelson, a Democrat.

headline: Confronting the ‘Anthropocene’
text: LONDON — I’m participating in a one-day meeting at the Geological Society of London exploring the evidence for, and meaning of, the Anthropocene. This is the proposed epoch of Earth history that, proponents say, has begun with the rise of the human species as a globally potent biogeophysical force, capable of leaving a durable imprint in the geological record.

headline: Court Backs Veterans’ Complaints on Mental Health Services
text: In a sweeping decision released Tuesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that “unchecked incompetence” by the Department of Veterans Affairs had led to poor mental health care and slow processing of disability claims for veterans.

headline: Warm Welcome for Animal Kingdom at Fair Hill
text: A crowd of about 30 people gathered to welcome Animal Kingdom, winner of the Kentucky Derby, to Fair Hill on Tuesday. The group was a mix of Fair Hill horsemen, fans and local news media.

headline: Americans Abroad, Part 1: The Top of the Class
text: Most of the soccer leagues around the world are winding down this month, which means that it is a good time to assess how United States national team regulars performed for their club teams.

headline: A Polling-Based Forecast of the Republican Primary Field
text: This is the finale of a four-part series (Part I, Part II, Part III) evaluating the utility of early presidential primary polls as forecasting instruments. My contention is that these polls have enough predictive power to be a worthwhile starting point for handicapping a field of candidates. In this article, we’ll see what they have to say about the Republican contenders for 2012.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: A.I.G. Lays Out Plan for Share Sale | The American International Group and the Treasury Department will sell roughly 300 million shares, in the insurer’s latest step toward regaining its independence from the government.

headline: Japan Looks to an Uncertain Future
text: The natural and nuclear disasters unleashed on March 11 have exposed the fragility of Japan’s postwar economic order. Rebuilding will require a national rethinking, many experts say, if this country is to achieve an economic rebirth.

headline: Japan Ponders Its New Normal
text: ISHINOMAKI, Japan — Its factory wiped out by the tsunami, a maker of vital parts for smartphones says it will move production overseas.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Jury Reaches Verdict in Rajaratnam Trial
text: The federal jury in Manhattan deciding the fate of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire chief of the Galleon Group hedge fund, reached a verdict on Wednesday.

headline: Pakistani Is Seeking Inquiry on U.S. Raid
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The leader of the main opposition party called on Wednesday for an independent inquiry into why the Pakistani Army had no knowledge of the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: Bloomberg Given Poor Marks in New Poll
text: It’s the schools, stupid.

headline: Ristretto | In Philadelphia
text: Philadelphia has plenty going for it: the best four-man rotation in baseball, art worth fighting over, a ruin so elegant and haunting it feels like Berlin. It also has superb coffee. Recently, I went on a coffee crawl that took me to a handful of shops where the baristas aren’t just tremendously skilled, they’re disarmingly sweet-natured. I found an energetic scene thriving outside the gravitational pull of the hometown giant La Colombe Torrefaction.

headline: A Report Card on Transportation Spending
text: A study that examined how states account for billions of dollars spent annually on transportation found that most are not tracking how their investments are performing in six important areas, among them mitigating the effects of transportation on the environment.

headline: At 100, Still a Teacher, and Quite a Character
text: When Bel Kaufman sits you down on her sofa and asks, “Are you comfortable?” the right answer, she reminds you, requires a Yiddish inflection, a shrug and the words, “I make a living.”

headline: Senate Democrats Reintroduce Dream Act
text: On the heels of President Obama’s renewed call to overhaul the nation’s immigration laws in Texas on Tuesday, Senate Democrats are reintroducing a bill that would give legal status to some illegal immigrants who came into the United States as children.

headline: Taking Airport, Rebels in Libya Loosen Noose
text: MISURATA, Libya — Rebels in the contested western city of Misurata stormed the city’s airport on Wednesday afternoon, swarming over the grounds from the south and east and reclaiming it from the military of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Syria Sent Missing Al Jazeera Journalist to Iran
text: A reporter for Al Jazeera’s English-language news channel who disappeared while covering the uprising in Syria almost two weeks ago was sent to Iran within two days of being detained by Syrian authorities, the network confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Hedge Fund Billionaire Is Guilty of Insider Trading
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire investor who once ran one of the world’s largest hedge funds, was found guilty on Wednesday of fraud and conspiracy by a federal jury in Manhattan. He is the most prominent figure convicted in the government’s crackdown on insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: The Voices of the Galleon Trial
text: In the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the government built its case against the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group in large part on a series of secretly recorded phone conversations. Prosecutors said these tapes showed how the hedge fund manager obtained illicit information on several stocks and traded on it. Mr. Rajaratnam was found guilty of all the charges against him, and he is the most prominent figure convicted in the government’s crackdown on insider trading on Wall Street.

headline: Can Hate Be Part of Good Parenting?
text: I was riveted and horrified this morning by my colleague Jesse McKinley’s story of the Hall family of Riverside, Calif.

headline: Graphic: The Rajaratnam Verdict
text: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused Raj Rajaratnam, the chief of the Galleon Group hedge fund, of being at the center of a network that traded stocks on illegal tips from 2003 to March 2009.

headline: Goslings Defy Prospect Park’s Birth Control Effort
text: Updated, 12:10 p.m. | Score four, at least, for the Prospect Park geese.

headline: A Fortuneteller’s Prophecy: Dartmouth vs. Princeton
text: Last year, at a school-sponsored event called “After Prom,” a fortuneteller predicted that I was going to make a tough choice between two great colleges. Despite my disbelief in such prophecies, I walked off wondering how likely that would be.

headline: Imagining the Sound of a Taxi Horn Not Honking
text: Out-of-control horns are one of the biggest complaints about taxis in New York. So thousands of ringing ears perked up last week when the city announced that its high-tech new taxicab, the Nissan NV200, would include a so-called “low-annoyance” horn, which promised to reduce ear-splitting honks.

headline: Rare Works Stolen From Exhibition at Forbidden City in Beijing
text: BEIJING — Rare handicrafts from a private museum in Hong Kong that were on display at the Forbidden City in Beijing were stolen on Sunday, forcing a shutdown of one part of the ancient palace, according to an article on Wednesday in the English-language edition of Global Times, a government-run newspaper in Beijing.

headline: Double Faults
text: It hardly qualifies as news these days when another athlete gets in Twitter trouble. But there was something a little deeper going on in the case of the tennis player Donald Young a few weeks ago. Young, upset at how the U.S.T.A. was allotting the wild-card entry it had to the French Open this month (the association used a playoff that Young lost), leveled a tweet at the organization that we can’t print. Patrick McEnroe, the head of player of development, blasted back and demanded an apology from Young before his organization would back Young any further. (Young closed out his Twitter account and apologized.) Beneath it all there seemed to simmer tensions over coaching, player development and support and maybe even race.

headline: Schrödinger’s Seat
text: Term for House seats which may or may not exist, depending on how district lines are drawn.Writing for National Journal, Charlie Cook commented:

headline: Round Up the Usual C.E.O.’s
text: It has been nearly a year since the chief executives of the five biggest multinational oil companies were hauled before a committee of Congress for a ritual flaying. Last June, the heads of Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Shell, BP and ConocoPhillips were called by the House Energy and Commerce Committee to testify on the Deepwater Horizon disaster, which at the time was still pouring 50,000 barrels of oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Collecting Sediments on the Ocean Floor
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

headline: Quote Unquote | Artistic License
text: –Abbey Lee Kershaw describes the difference between her day job and her night job, poet not being one of them.

headline: TimesCast | Revolutionary Jasmine
text: In China, jasmine is seen as a problematic revolutionary symbol.

headline: Woman Who Left Newborn in Trash Is Arrested, Police Say
text: A woman who left her newborn girl in a Queens hospital bathroom trash can on Tuesday has been arrested, the police said.

headline: 13 Ways to Save on Gas this Summer
text: HEADING for the highway this summer? The great American road trip will cost you more than last year thanks to high fuel prices.

headline: Wednesday’s Mets-Rockies Game Rained Out
text: DENVER — Wednesday’s scheduled game here between the Mets and the Colorado Rockies has been rained out and rescheduled for Thursday at 3:10 p.m., Eastern time. Both teams had a free day Thursday, after which the Mets will fly to Houston for a three-game series with the Houston Astros.

headline: Britain Warns of Inflation Risk
text: The Bank of England warned Wednesday that inflation in Britain could hit 5 percent this year, raising the likelihood that the central bank would lift its main interest rate from the record low level at which it has stood since the depths of the financial crisis.

headline: A Sinking Feeling in San Jose
text: It appears to be the year of the psychiatrist’s couch in the N.H.L. playoffs. We found the Vancouver Canucks there in the first round, talking through their franchise’s childhood issues, that being 40 years of acute stress disorder. Therapy resulted in a cathartic Game 7 victory over the tormenting Blackhawks. Now, it’s San Jose’s turn. Driven to near distraction by the Red Wings’ charge back from a 3-0 deficit to tie their second-round series, the Sharks now need to be saved from their own screaming psyches.

headline: Critical Letter by Catholics Cites Boehner on Policies
text: Speaker John A. Boehner, a Republican who grew up in a Roman Catholic family in Ohio, is scheduled to give the commencement address on Saturday at the Catholic University of America in Washington, a prestigious setting in church circles for its affiliation with the nation’s bishops.

headline: Fugitive Bronx Zoo Peahen Surrenders Without Incident
text: The Bronx Zoo’s latest escapee is back in captivity after a day and a night on the lam.

headline: The Lowdown | A. L. Steiner
text: A. L. Steiner is as well known for her thought-provoking and politically charged work as she is for her witty art world mischief. Sharp of tongue and nimble of mind, Steiner often touches on feminist, sometimes lesbian themes, and she is never afraid to court controversy. Steiner’s critically acclaimed installation at last summer’s Greater New York show at MoMA P.S.1 featured a vast collage of images of naked women, nature and beaten body parts, in a somehow celebratory homage to queer culture. She recently completed a film — she likes to call it a “sociosexual” video, but the more usual term is “porno” — in collaboration with the artist A. K. Burns. Titled “Community Action Center,” the film explores queer sexuality and runs an almost impossibly hilarious 69 minutes.

headline: Love? Some for Jennifer Lopez, but More for Beastie Boys and Fleet Foxes
