text: Jennifer Lopez has had a prime television role as a judge on “American Idol” and plenty of airtime to promote her new album, “Love?” But it wasn’t enough for her to top new releases from the Beastie Boys and Fleet Foxes on this week’s Billboard 200 albums chart, Billboard reported.

headline: 2010 Broncos: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: Tension Boils Over Between Sprint Rivals
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — For nine months, Cullen Jones and Josh Schneider have been training side by side for a 22-second duel. Their 50-meter freestyle swim-off Thursday is the sport’s version of musical chairs: when the clock stops, one of them will not have a seat on the plane to the world championships in Shanghai.

headline: Could This Be Paris? No, Leave Me Alone
text: THE French excel at many things — fashion, love, pastry — but customer service is not one of them. Hence it was a bit jarring the other day, upon entering the new branch of Comptoir des Cotonniers that has recently invaded Columbus Avenue, to be attended in quick succession by a triad of eager young americaines.

headline: New Captain for a Series Becalmed
text: LOS ANGELES — When Walt Disney Studios picked Rob Marshall to restart its $3 billion “Pirates of the Caribbean” series, Hollywood did a double take. Sure, there was “Chicago.” Mr. Marshall, a Broadway choreographer and director turned filmmaker, had powered that musical to a best picture Oscar in 2002. But his next two films, “Memoirs of a Geisha” and “Nine,” were kicked in the teeth by critics and sputtered at the multiplex.

headline: Candidate Gingrich Faces Commentator Gingrich
text: As Newt Gingrich officially enters the 2012 presidential contest on Wednesday, the former Republican House speaker is betting on his image as an intellectual heavyweight who can confront the nation’s thorniest challenges.

headline: Amp Delivers Its First Electric Mercedes-Benz ML Conversion
text: As Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla Motors, learned during filming of “Revenge of the Electric Car,” developing an E.V. from the ground up is a prohibitively expensive exercise. Amp Electric Vehicles, an Ohio company that removes the guts of internal-combustion passenger cars and replaces them with electric powertrains, says it has a more viable way to get E.V.’s on the road, even if those roads are almost an ocean away.

headline: Panel Urges Germany to Close Nuclear Plants by 2021
text: BERLIN — Germany should close all of its nuclear power plants by 2021 and rely entirely on other forms of energy, according to a committee appointed by Chancellor Angela Merkel in the wake of the Fukushima Daiichi disaster in Japan.

headline: Fox Cancels ‘Chicago Code’ and Four Others
text: Making room for new shows, Fox on Tuesday gave pink slips to five series, including the dramas “Lie to Me,” which lasted for three seasons, and “Human Target,” which lasted for two.

headline: A Tool to Weigh Debt Payment Options
text: A new tool from Bills.com can pull your actual credit card balances from the credit bureau Experian to analyze your debt. It then provides detailed options for getting rid of it, customized to your situation.

headline: Extreme Work Habits
text: I used to consider myself a pretty hard worker. But then I read Burkhard Bilger’s terrific profile in The New Yorker of David Eagleman, a neuroscientist at Baylor College of Medicine, and it turns out I’m a slacker. I’m never going to pass the potato standard established by Eagleman when he was a grad student:

headline: ‘Ask the Film Critics,’ Cannes Edition
text: Manohla Dargis, a chief film critic of The New York Times, is in France for the Cannes Film Festival where Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris” will open the festival tonight. Ms. Dargis and her colleague A.O. Scott are taking questions by e-mail as part of their regular monthly exchange with Times readers – “Ask the Film Critics” – where they respond to queries about individual films, industry trends and historical trivia.

headline: With a Tapestry of Twists and Turns, a Cuban Troupe Makes Its U.S. Debut
text: Though Danza Contemporánea de Cuba has been in existence for more than five decades, it is only now enjoying its first American tour. Given the dearth of exchange between the United States and Cuba, anticipation had been understandably high before Tuesday night, when the troupe made its Joyce Theater debut as part of the interdisciplinary festival ¡Si Cuba! How would these performances compare to those of more familiar companies?

headline: On Our Radar: Vatican Panel Calls for Climate Change Action
text: A report by a scientific group sponsored by the Vatican blames man-made emissions for recent global warming and the retreat of mountain glaciers and calls for urgent action to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases. “We call on all people and nations to recognize the serious and potentially irreversible impacts of global warming caused by the anthropogenic emissions of greenhouse gases and other pollutants,” the group says. [Catholic News Service]

headline: And the Nominees Should Be ...
text: The theater critics of The New York Times make their Tony Award choices.

headline: Republicans Decry Tactics the Party Used in 2009
text: Yes, it’s true, Republican House freshmen say, our party did help storm town-hall-style meetings to protest changes in the Medicare plan during the debate over the health care overhaul. But they would appreciate it if Democrats did not take that page from their playbook.

headline: Met Plans to Occupy the Whitney’s Uptown Site
text: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will take over the Whitney Museum of American Art’s Marcel Breuer building in 2015, when the Whitney opens its new museum in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, according to the terms of a real estate agreement that the museum boards are pursuing.

headline: Another Pre-Dawn Flight
text: When the hotel clerk recommended that I set my alarm at 3 a.m. for my 6:15 a.m. flight to Miami, I gasped. Why is it that arrangements that seemed so reasonable a month ago are now horrifying? Maybe I should just cancel, spend an extra day in Canada, tour a cattle farm, chill? But no: The Florida trip is important, and so there I was, dutifully, in a cab at 4 a.m., to join a couple of hundred other bleary-eyed travelers on a long customs line that lasted until 4:45 a.m. (or maybe it was 5 a.m.? Who can remember, even only a couple of hours later) and led to a series of steel shutters. The customs officers were not as eager as the rest of us.

headline: Hawk Cam | Rescue of Violet Is Planned for Thursday
text: Updated, 6:33 p.m. | Help is on the way for Violet the red-tailed hawk.

headline: Black is the New Blue
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#729", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: ‘The New Girl’ Is in, ‘Chicago Code’ and ‘Lie to Me’ Are Out at Fox
text: Fans of Zooey Deschanel, the star of “(500) Days of Summer” and lead singer of the band She & Him, will have something to look forward to on Fox’s fall season: she is set to star in “The New Girl,” a new comedy that the network plans to announce next week. And fans of the Fox shows “Lie to Me,” “The Chicago Code,” “Human Target,” “Breaking In” and “Traffic Light” will have more free time on their schedules: the network has canceled those series. Brian Stelter has more at Media Decoder.

headline: Reporter Witnessed Mass Arrests in Syria
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, Syrian activists claim that the country’s security forces shelled the city of Homs on Wednesday and detained hundreds of people suspected of supporting protests. According to human rights groups, more than 10,000 people have been taken into custody in recent weeks, during a crackdown by the Syrian government on dissent.

headline: Kids and Cameras
text: Any parent who finds the time to cobble together an actual photo album these days knows how children love flipping through them — especially baby books and wedding albums. Good reason to take note of two heartfelt and personal picture books about family photography.

headline: Gingrich 2012 Gets Under Way
text: The Caucus: The Times's Matt Bai answers readers' questions on Newt Gingrich, who is expected to announce his candidacy today, and Katharine Q. Seelye looks back on his career.

headline: Nuclear Problems in the Rearview Mirror
text: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said this week that in hindsight, a problem at the Browns Ferry nuclear plant in Alabama last fall was quite serious. And its records indicate that there have been reports in recent days of engineers’ flubbing a basic calculation of reactor operation at two other plants.

headline: National Gallery Treasures Making a Splash in Texas
text: HOUSTON — Vincent van Gogh’s self-portrait from 1889, the haunting oil on canvas of the troubled artist looking sallow in a blue smock, rarely travels from its home at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C. Neither does Claude Monet’s “Japanese Footbridge” or Edgar Degas’ “Dancers Backstage.”

headline: Prosecutors Hope Verdict Will Be a Deterrent to Others
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: Her Cool-Kid Clubhouse
text: NOT long ago, Vashtie Kola — a downtown party hostess, fashion designer and music video director — started wearing a chambray shirt, which she would pair with cutoff denim jean shorts and tights.

headline: When a College Student Loses a Parent
text: Lori Eiler-Hunter was a dynamo, a leader, a force. She was the kind of woman who left instructions for her obituary: “In lieu of flowers Lori requested that you read to your children, call your mother, say please and thank you and mind your P’s and Q’s.” When her brain cancer was first diagnosed six years ago, she made it clear she planned to fight hard to hang in for her husband, Art, and their then middle-school-aged children. Statistics said she should never have had those six years, but Lori used them to see Max and Alexandra both get settled into life at college.

headline: Heated Debate on Wages, and Less So on Corn
text: One side is accusing the Bloomberg administration of using tactics “straight out of the K.G.B.” The other side has screamed “job killing,” taking a page from the national debate over health care.

headline: Belarus Economic Crisis Deepens as Currency Plunges
text: MOSCOW — An economic crisis in Belarus deepened Wednesday when its currency plunged in value after the Central Bank lifted restrictions on the exchange rate.

headline: Why It’s So Difficult for Entrepreneurs to Head for the Exit
text: Like many successful entrepreneurs, Paul Spiegelman often refers to his company as his “baby,” and he becomes emotional when he talks about issues relating to succession or the sale of all or part of his company — an opportunity he recently sought out.

headline: The Morning Line: A Loss in a Racing Dynasty
text: Wednesday brings news of the death of the 24-year-old jockey Michael Baze. He was found dead in his car on the backside at Churchill Downs on Tuesday. Baze had been the fourth-leading rider at the Oaklawn Park meet, and he had ridden Nehro, the runner-up in the Kentucky Derby, to that horse’s only victory before being replaced. Daily Racing Form reports that “police have undertaken an investigation into the death,” and that an  autopsy will be performed.

headline: What Do You Owe Your Employees When You Sell?
text: In a small-business conversation  we’ve just published, Paul Spiegelman talks about how he came very close to selling a controlling interest in his company, Beryl, an unusual call center based near Dallas. “I began to get nervous,” Mr. Spiegelman told Darren Dahl. “I felt like if we went down this road, it would have an irreversible negative impact on Beryl’s culture.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Libya and Afghanistan.

headline: ‘Hat,’ With Chris Rock, Extends Its Broadway Run
text: Call your sponsor, hide your distinguishing headwear and find yourself a spot on Cousin Julio’s couch: “The ___________ With the Hat” is extending its run on Broadway. Press representatives for that Stephen Adly Guirgis play, about the intertwined lives of a former drug dealer struggling with sobriety, his girlfriend, his cousin, his sponsor and the sponsor’s wife, said that it will play at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater through July 17; it was previously scheduled to end its run on June 25. While Chris Rock is making his Broadway debut in this dark, dark, dark comedy – did we mention it was dark? – most of the critical praise for the play, which opened on April 11, has been directed at the performances of Bobby Cannavale and Elizabeth Rodriguez. Last week, it was nominated for six Tony Awards, including best play, direction of a play (Anna D. Shapiro), leading actor in a play (Mr. Cannavale), featured actress in a play (Ms. Rodriguez) and featured actor in a play (Yul Vázquez).

headline: Former Glaxo Lawyer Acquitted
text: The former GlaxoSmithKline lawyer who was indicted last year on charges of making false statements and obstructing a federal investigation into illegal drug marketing was acquitted on Tuesday.

headline: Côte Art Crawl
text: “The days of the ‘easel’ painting are fading,” predicted the American artist Ellsworth Kelly, while living in the French fishing village of Sanary-sur-Mer in the 1950s. As Kelly experimented with color grids, dozens more artists followed suit, kicking off a contemporary art revolution on the Côte d’Azur.

headline: Google’s Chrome Laptops to Go on Sale in June
text: 8:46 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO — Google took another swipe at Microsoft on Wednesday when it introduced a new kind of computer called a Chromebook, which stores everything online.

headline: Homes for $900,000
text: A four-bedroom condo in a Queen Anne in Princeton, N.J.; a contemporary house in Virginia’s Loudon Valley; and a 1905 house set on 17 wooded acres in Pine, Colo.

headline: Guilty Verdict in Galleon Trial
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the hedge fund Galleon Group, was found guilty on 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy today in federal court in Manhattan.

headline: Cuomo Wants More Support on Same-Sex Marriage Bill
text: ALBANY — In a suggestion of the uncertain odds surrounding the push to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Wednesday that he would hold off introducing legislation to allow gay couples to wed until he was confident that the measure would pass.

headline: A Special Election May Be a Special Case
text: I’m generally skeptical about the predictive value of special elections. They occur, by definition, under special circumstances — after a Congressman has died or left office unexpectedly. There may be unusual rules for nominating candidates; turnout is usually low; and they occur in isolation. Any one race can only tell you so much about the mood of the country, since there are always idiosyncrasies related both to the candidates and the district.

headline: The Galleon Case Is Nowhere Near Over
text: With the conviction of Raj Rajaratnam on 14 counts of conspiracy and securities fraud, the Galleon Group insider trading case moves to its next phase.

headline: Is the iPad Just a  New Way to Give Away Magazines?
text: In the last few days, there have been a flurry of deals that suggest that a level of détente  between Apple and the Big Three Manhattan publishers (Condé Nast, Time Inc. and Hearst) has finally been reached. For veteran industry watchers, the announcement that Condé had finally agreed to release an iPad version of The New Yorker seemed like the signing of the Salt treaty.

headline: What You Get for ... $900,000
text: PRINCETON, N.J.

headline: From the Cloud, Google Pulls Down an Energy Saver
text: Engineers have long been trying to adapt the automobile to drivers’ preferences. In partnership with Google, Ford is hoping to create cars that could receive data in real time and predict driver behavior and probable destinations. Such information could then be applied to improve fuel economy and reduce emissions.

headline: Spaving
text: Spending catalysed by saving rather than need or desire.(Spending + Saving)

headline: What the Galleon Verdict Means
text: On Wednesday, a jury found Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the hedge fund Galleon Group, guilty of insider trading. As Mr. Rajaratnam left the federal courthouse in Manhattan, DealBook’s Peter Lattman and Azam Ahmed were on the scene to discuss the impact of his conviction on 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy.

headline: Video: Gingrich 2012 Gets Under Way
text: A closer look at Newt Gingrich, who is expected to announce his candidacy on Wednesday. Matt Bai answers reader questions and Katharine Q. Seelye reflects on Mr. Gingrich in the ′90s.

headline: For Some Sports Figures, Opinions Have a Price
text: When Peter Vidmar, who won two gold medals in gymnastics in the 1984 Olympics, was chosen to be the United States’ chef de mission for next year’s London Games, the chairman of the United States Olympic Committee called him a natural leader and an extraordinary individual.

headline: How to Kill Time During the Lockout: Crank Call the Commissioner
text: Raheem Brock and Chester Pitts of the Seattle Seahawks found some humor in the N.F.L. lockout, using their downtime (with some help from Comedy Central in a Web video on Atom.com) to be children again. Or at least childish.

headline: Saint Laurent’s Other Half
text: PARIS

headline: Paper Computers: The Next New Thing?
text: Science fiction buffs have long dreamed of replacing books, magazines and even computers with a digital flexible display that can be rolled up and stuffed in a pocket or bag. According to some Canadian researchers, this dream may soon come true.

headline: Four Workers for Every Job Opening
text: 05/12/11 | Updated The job market still isn’t good, but at least it’s on its way back.

headline: Rise of the Mavericks, and the Fall of Beaubois
text: A year ago, the fury of Mavericks fans rained down on Rick Carlisle for what was, at the time, deemed to be coaching hubris; Carlisle had the gall to play Jason Terry, an all-time great fourth-quarter performer for the Mavericks, instead of dynamic rookie guard Rodrigue Beaubois down the stretch in a potential elimination game against the San Antonio Spurs. At the time, the mistake appeared fatal, as Dallas’ season ended while Beaubois, who had scored 16 points in just 21 minutes in that game, sat.

headline: FIFA Develops a Salt Lake City Look, Without Doorknobs
text: Before Sepp Blatter could begin reforming soccer with brilliant ideas, like his suggestion that women should wear tighter shorts and lower necklines, he first had to run for president of FIFA in 1998.

headline: On the Fly: Studying Bird Migration and Behavior
text: In many parts of the country, it’s the height of spring – the season when flowers push their stalks through the ground, buds burst into leaves, and insects, frogs and countless other species emerge from winter dormancy. But perhaps the most obvious sign of spring’s return is the arrival of migrating birds on their expedition north for the summer.

headline: Who Are You Calling Grandma?
text: LAST month, Gwyneth Paltrow, promoting her new cookbook, “My Father’s Daughter” (Grand Central Life & Style), on the television show “Chelsea Lately,” revealed that her mother, the actress Blythe Danner, wanted to be called Woof by her grandchildren, Apple and Moses. “My mom’s hot and she didn’t want to be called Grandma,” Ms. Paltrow said. “So she kept trying to make the Woof thing stick. It’s even her e-mail address.”

headline: In Buenos Aires, a Trilevel Penthouse
text: A two-bedroom penthouse in a former textile factory in the Barracas neighborhood of Buenos Aires is on the market for $800,000.

headline: A Homecoming for Hair
text: D.I.Y.-ers who are sick of the mess home hair coloring entails, brands like John Frieda, Clairol and L’Oréal now offer a foaming system that is easy to apply and drip-free. “Color Blend Foam is really the next big thing in hair color,” says the colorist Marie Robinson, Clairol’s color director, referring to the new Nice ’N Easy Foam ($10). “Women can easily cover their entire head with their hands and still won’t make a mess, since the formula doesn’t drip.” John Frieda’s Precision Foam Colour ($13) was seven years in the making, resulting in an innovative coloring system that is as easy to apply as shampoo. You’re even given your own gloves. And L’Oreal’s Sublime Mousse costs just under $10 and comes in 12 different shades. With this kind of easy expertise at your fingertips, you can take full creative control of your hair without the added (and endless) expense. Scared? Don’t be. Harry Josh, the celebrity stylist and creative consultant for John Frieda Hair Care, assures consumers that “with stylist-selected shades, there’s no way to tell that the at-home color isn’t straight out of the salon.”

headline: House Hunting in ... Buenos Aires
text: A two-bedroom penthouse apartment in a former textile factory in the Barracas neighborhood of Buenos Aires

headline: China’s Economy Slows Slightly, but Inflation Remains a Worry
text: HONG KONG — After months of brisk activity, China’s torrid economy is finally growing a little more slowly.

headline: Davis and Wright to Sit, but for Different Reasons
text: DENVER — Ike Davis and David Wright were moving in opposite directions when they collided in front of the Coors Field mound Tuesday night. Each a cornerstone player, Davis and Wright converged from their respective corners on the diamond, but with almost nothing in common at the time.

headline: Zagato-Designed Aston Martin Heading to Villa d’Este
text: Though debuts of one-off concepts are as common as Campari spritzers at the Concorso d’Eleganza, held annually at the Villa d’Este hotel on the shores of Lake Como, Italy, some are more highly anticipated than others.

headline: TimesCast | May 11, 2011
text: A hedge fund chief is found guilty; Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi stays out of the public eye.

headline: Hugh Grant Said to Be in Talks to Replace Sheen
text: Is Hugh Grant about to fill the most high-profile vacancy in television?

headline: If a Seat Is Lost, Blame G.O.P. Medicare Plan, Trump Says
text: Donald Trump says that House Republicans will be to blame if their party’s candidate loses a special election later this month for an open seat in western New York State.

headline: Pasta Primavera: The Remix
text: Pasta primavera, which means “springtime pasta,” is an American invention — at least as American as, say, fettuccine Alfredo. It first appeared on the menu at Le Cirque in the 1970s, and Sirio Maccioni, that restaurant’s owner, not only takes credit for it but was also quoted in 1991 in The Times saying, “It seemed like a good idea and people still like it.”

headline: F.C.C. Commissioner Leaving to Join Comcast
text: 8:02 p.m. | Updated WASHINGTON — Four months after the Federal Communications Commission approved a hotly contested merger of Comcast and NBC Universal, one of the commissioners who voted for the deal said on Wednesday that she would soon join Comcast’s Washington lobbying office.

headline: Syria Loses Spot For Rights Panel
text: UNITED NATIONS — Kuwait replaced Syria on Wednesday on an uncontested slate of countries seeking seats on the United Nations’ main human rights body after an outcry over the violent crackdown on domestic dissent by the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Fiesta Bowl Fined $1 Million but Can Stay in B.C.S.
text: The Fiesta Bowl can remain in the Bowl Championship Series but must pay a $1 million fine, a B.C.S. oversight committee announced Wednesday.

headline: Congo Study Sets Estimate for Rapes Much Higher
text: A new study in The American Journal of Public Health, expected to be published Thursday online, estimates that nearly two million women have been raped in the Democratic Republic of Congo, with women victimized at a rate of nearly one every minute.

headline: Obama to Deliver Speech on Mideast
text: The White House said Wednesday that President Obama planned to deliver an address in the coming days on the Middle East, in the wake of the killing of Osama bin Laden. Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, declined to give a date or place for the speech, but said, “It will be relatively soon.”

headline: Iraqis to Talk About Asking Some U.S. Troops to Stay
text: BAGHDAD — As American troops break down their bases and prepare to head home, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Wednesday that he would meet with Iraqi leaders to discuss whether the United States military should remain after the end of the year.

headline: A Bird’s Convoluted Conservation Odyssey
text: The story of the greater sage grouse offers a wonderful window on the reality of conservation politics in the American West. Its quest for protection under the Endangered Species Act has been subject to politically tinged science and a logjam that the Fish and Wildlife Service finally hopes to break under an agreement that I wrote about on Wednesday in The Times.

headline: General in Abu Ghraib Scandal Files to Run for Senate in Texas
text: A new 10-gallon hat is in the ring: Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, retired, officially began his bid for an open Senate seat in Texas on Wednesday by filing election paperwork in San Antonio.

headline: Notes on the Commodity Plunge
text: Commodity prices are down again today, undoing the mini-rally earlier in the week. Overall, we have still retraced only part of the big rise since last summer. Still, many people seem shocked to discover that commodity prices can go down as well as up.

headline: Report Strengthens Democrats’ Argument to Eliminate Oil Tax Breaks
text: Senate Democrats have a new weapon in their escalating oil and gasoline war with Republicans, though some party members are none too happy with their leadership’s offensive against the major oil companies.

headline: Video: Gingrich Announces for President
text: Newt Gingrich is in.

headline: For Prosecutors, the Case That Got a Head Start on the Crime
text: Which came first: the crime or the investigation?

headline: Prepaid Cards Subject Jobless to Host of Fees
text: When you’re getting unemployment benefits, you by definition don’t have a lot of cash to spare. So it seems especially unfair that people who receive their jobless benefits on prepaid debit cards are subject to a variety of fees they can ill afford to pay.

headline: New York State Arts Official to Run the American Theater Wing
text: The American Theater Wing, which is a presenter of the Tony Awards and has expanded theater education and internship programs in recent years, announced on Wednesday that its next executive director would be Heather Hitchens, who now holds the same position at the New York State Council on the Arts.

headline: Lady Gaga Explains Herself
text: EVER since Lady Gaga announced in March that she would be writing a fashion and art column for V magazine, you may have asked, what exactly does Lady Gaga know about fashion and art?

headline: The Doctrine of Immaculate Crowding Out
text: I’ve written before about the doctrine of immaculate transfer in international macroeconomics, which is a common fallacy but not, I’ve suggested, one that rises to zombie status.

headline: Imps Change Hands in Droves
text: The bare fact is that the Cavendish Invitational Pairs was won on Sunday in Henderson, Nev., by Fred Stewart and Kit Woolsey. They finished 148.68 international match points ahead of Bobby Levin and Steve Weinstein, the two-time defending champions. Third were Billy Cohen and Ron Smith.

headline: Opening Night at Cannes
text: A look at some of the stars and filmmakers at the opening night of the Cannes International Film Festival.

headline: American Hymns, Both Classic and Reimagined
text: With its surging rendition of the Shaker hymn “Simple Gifts,” Aaron Copland’s 1944 ballet “Appalachian Spring” is famous for comforting its audience. It is less known for challenging that audience, as it does with a moody eight-minute antislavery pantomime that Copland cut when he turned the ballet into an orchestral suite.

headline: Cisco Posts Lower Profit, but Exceeds Expectations
text: Cisco Systems’ streak of lackluster earnings continued on Wednesday as the company failed to invigorate its slow-growing business.

headline: A Cabaret Evening of Songs From a Marriage Made Off Broadway
text: It’s a tricky business for a married couple to parade their personal lives on the musical stage, to convey intimacy while also protecting privacy. How do they decide what to reveal and what to withhold? Because even the most solid relationship has its sour moments, how do they factor in a bad day when togetherness through thick and thin is their message? The answer, of course, is a shared sense of humor.

headline: Vacation | Comme des Garçons Video
text: With its skeletal, cut-out blazers, skull-printed skirts, and checkered shorts, Comme des Garçons was easily one of the season’s most ambitious (and hard-to-pull-off) men’s wear collections. To help make sense of it, we asked Brooklyn trio Vacation to take a few looks to the streets. Their experimental pop sound — an amalgamation of influences from the likes of J. Dilla, Brian Eno, and Pierre Schaeffer — lends itself well to the mismatched, layered nature of the clothes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Greece, Libya and Afghanistan.

headline: Shopping Snapshots for May 12
text: Print pants have the ease of pj’s but a bit more panache; a new makeup collection from Illamasqua; store openings, events, sales and other shopping news.

headline: Taxing Parents of Obese Children
text: The nudging war against obesity continues.

headline: Danza Contemporánea de Cuba
text: Images from the company’s debut at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Opening Night at Cannes
text: More Photographs

headline: ‘Dirty Secret’
AT&T and T-Mobile Chiefs Field Skeptical Questions on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — A few weeks ago, AT&T and T-Mobile were robust competitors. T-Mobile ads made merciless fun of AT&T’s reputation for dropped calls and sluggish wireless data connections while celebrating T-Mobile’s fast network and low rates. AT&T promoted superior nationwide service and its exclusive array of the sleekest, fastest smartphones.

headline: A Big Belter Who Found a True Voice
text: AS a little girl growing up in Georgia, Sutton Foster used to make up her own opera arias and sing them in the bathtub. Her family had no background in music, acting or theater — her father worked for General Motors. So as a child her instinctive desire to sound operatic was curious.

headline: Seven Composers, Seven Countries
text: The MATA Festival, now in its 13th year, has always been nondogmatic, even antidogmatic. Its focus is young composers, never a monolithic bunch even when they share nationalities and musical backgrounds, and even harder to pigeonhole once you bring them in from around the globe, as MATA’s directors have always done.

headline: What GoogleMusic: Beta Means to You
text: Wednesday, Google announced Music: Beta, a new cloud-based music service that will be available over the Web and on Android devices (initial users will be by invitation only, which you can request by going to the Music: Beta Web page). As was reported Wednesday, your music will be stored online, for instant retrieval from any Web-enabled or Android device you have.

headline: A MoMA Party, With Rappers
text: Kanye West and Jay-Z performed at the Museum of Modern Art’s annual Party in the Garden.

headline: The Art Crowd Amps It Up
text: MICHAEL DOUGLAS, elegantly dressed in a dark blue suit, white spread-collar shirt, violet tie and a white pocket square, and looking fit despite his recent bout with throat cancer, was standing in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night, one of the hundreds of people who had shown up for the museum’s annual Party in the Garden.

headline: Another Insider Trading Defendant Pleads Guilty
text: Another defendant pleaded guilty on Wednesday in the government’s wide-ranging investigation into insider trading has pleaded guilty — in the same federal courthouse in Manhattan where a jury convicted the hedge fund billionaire Raj Rajaratnam of fraud and conspiracy.

headline: The Buzz
text: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable nightspots for the week ahead.

headline: A Camera That Honors the Flip
text: This column might look like a review of Casio’s radically designed Tryx camera. But it’s really a thinly disguised defense of single-purpose gadgets.

headline: Shooting With the Casio Tryx
text: David Pogue assesses the performance of Casio’s new point-and-shoot camera.

headline: A Director Is Born With ‘The Big Bang’
text: LOS ANGELES — It was 17 degrees and sleet was falling in Spokane, Wash., last November when Tony Krantz called “action” on the set of “The Big Bang,” a neo-noir thriller starring Antonio Banderas. Actually, because Mr. Krantz was suffering from acute bronchitis, the order came out more like a croak.

headline: ‘Voice’ Has a Niche
text: NBC’s singing competition “The Voice” earned the highest ratings on Tuesday in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49, lifting the network to first place on the night in that age group for the third consecutive week. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the reality show attracted a more modest result in total viewers (10.3 million). NBC ranked third over all in total viewers, behind CBS, which drew 17.1 million for “NCIS” and 14.7 million for “NCIS: Los Angeles,” ABC and Fox.

headline: A Case That Got a Head Start on the Crime
text: The insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam stemmed from an investigation that began well before the crimes were committed, and that made all the difference, Floyd Norris of The New York Times reports. Read more »

headline: Two by a Finnish Composer, and Variations Inspired by a Birthday
text: The Finnish composer Magnus Lindberg has become a familiar face to audiences of the New York Philharmonic, where he has been serving as composer in residence since the start of Alan Gilbert’s tenure as music director in 2009. Mr. Lindberg’s chamber music has received comparatively less exposure during his time in New York. (It was the focus of a Making Music program at Carnegie Hall in 2002.)

headline: Seven Tech Trade-Offs Worth Making
text: Buying gadgets can sometimes be like buying a car; it requires sorting through options. Do you go for the navigation package or the rear-seat entertainment system? The faster processor or more memory?

headline: A Guide to D.I.Y. Jeans
text: Taking perfect measurements is tricky, but essential, when ordering custom-made items online.

headline: The Designer: You. The Maker: Who?
text: IN an age of style blogs and “Project Runway,” everyone’s an armchair Alexander Wang. And would-be couturiers who long to design their own wardrobes but can’t sketch or sew are in luck. Do-it-yourself Web sites are making it easy for fashion buffs to design and order custom outfits: all you need is an Internet connection and a credit card.

headline: Video of Libyan Rebels at Misurata’s Airport
text: As my colleague C. J. Chivers reports, Libyan rebels in Misurata, the country’s third-largest city, wrested control of the besieged town’s airport from forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Wednesday.

headline: The Palin Tragedy
text: Josh Green has a great piece in the latest Atlantic on the Sarah Palin who might have been — Palin the reformist governor of Alaska, that is, rather than Palin the spotlight-chasing, media-feuding avatar of right-wing identity politics that we’ve come to know since the 2008 election. The Alaskan Palin fought corruption within her own party, attacked the nexus of government and big business, avoided polarizing feuds and cut successful bipartisan deals; in the process, Green notes, “she succeeded to a remarkable extent in settling, at least for a time, what had seemed insoluble problems, in the process putting Alaska on a trajectory to financial well-being.” This was the Palin that I liked from afar, before John McCain elevated her to national prominence: The charismatic pro-life working mom who was also a good-government reformer capable of thinking outside the ideological box. (Imagine Mitch Daniels crossed with Michelle Bachmann — in a good way.) And it’s a Palin who was swallowed up, almost immediately, by the national culture war, which made her both a right-wing icon and a left-wing hate figure almost instantaneously, and effectively erased her more interesting and complicated past.

headline: Two Staff Moves at The Washington Post
text: The Washington Post has made two crucial changes to its lineup of political writers ahead of the 2012 presidential campaign.

headline: A Pitch for New Music
text: It’s spring and baseball season is under way again — for me, always a welcome event. Lately, I’ve been thinking about the game and its history. Which reminded me of the recent passing of the baseball legend Duke Snider. And, surprisingly, that made me think of classical music. Honest!

headline: Beauty Spots
text: COCONUT COIF Carol’s Daughter, a New York-based skin and hair care company, has a new three-step system for hair, containing monoi oil, which is made from soaking gardenia flowers in coconut oil (a ritual in Polynesia for over 2,000 years). The shampoo ($18) also contains hibiscus extract, while the conditioner ($20) has bamboo water, and the hair mask ($28) contains hydrolyzed silk and various natural butters. At Sephora and Carol’s Daughter stores (carolsdaughter.com).

headline: Lining Up to the Barre
text: EVEN if you never intend to dance onstage at Lincoln Center, like Natalie Portman’s character in “Black Swan,” you probably want to look as if you do (minus, of course, her stab wound).

headline: A Mini-Castle That Dates to 1400, Filled With Contemporary Décor
text: As Florian Staudinger imagines it, the mini-castle will someday be an art and design destination, many of its outbuildings turned into studios and galleries.

headline: Excerpt: 'Hoarders'
text: Jason Brunet returns to his mother's home in an episode of the A&E show and surveys the squalor.

headline: Veterans Take Over ‘Early Show’ and ‘Evening News’
text: New producers will soon be in place on both the morning and evening newscasts on CBS.

headline: What the U.S. Needs to Break Even on A.I.G.
text: The Obama administration has said the $130 billion bailout of American International Group could one day produce a profit for taxpayers.

headline: Which Tech Tradeoffs Do You Make?
text: I wrote an article for Thursday’s paper, which is online now, about which tech tradeoffs to make when you’re out shopping: Should you spend more for RAM than processor speed, pay more for a camera’s sensor size, less for its megapixel count?

headline: Stage Scenes: Sutton Foster
text: Photos of some of Ms. Foster’s past performances in New York.

headline: Reimagining an Austrian Estate
text: GÖSTLING AN DER YBBS, Austria

headline: Near the Top at Paramount, Handling Players and Egos
text: Peter Bart’s latest Hollywood book includes a 1976 picture of its author as a bare-chested, longish-haired guy in jeans, taken at a Hawaiian location for the Hemingway adaptation “Islands in the Stream.” Despite this extremely business-casual look, Mr. Bart’s “Infamous Players” is about his stint at Paramount Pictures as what was then known, and is still known, as “a suit.” He was a Paramount vice president from 1967 to 1975. And he served as a kind of literary aide to the studio’s larger- and noisier-than-life head of production, Robert Evans.

headline: Tutorials and Exercises to Help Students Prepare for the SAT
text: Teenagers have a hard time paying attention to anything that’s not flashed across a smartphone screen. Yet somehow, parents still expect results when they plop an SAT study book in front of their children.

headline: Acrylic Pieces
text: THERE was a time when some considered the name John Mascheroni synonymous with acrylic furniture, because of the popular collection of modernist pieces he produced in the late 1960s and early ’70s.

headline: Shopping for Acrylic Pieces With John Mascheroni
text: The designer, who became well known for a popular collection of modernist pieces he produced in the late 1960s, shopped for acrylic objects for the home.

headline: Children of Hoarders on Leaving the Cluttered Nest
text: JESSIE SHOLL’S West Village apartment is a rent-stabilized fifth-floor walk-up, three small rooms and a sleeping loft where she and her husband, both writers, have lived for seven years. Perfect-storm conditions for clutter. But Ms. Sholl, a petite, pale-skinned woman of 42, keeps things tidy with routine “purges.” Even of objects she likes.

headline: Enforcing Veil Ban, the French Have Stopped 46 Violators
text: PARIS — The French police have stopped 46 women seen wearing facial veils in public since a ban on such coverings went into effect last month, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

headline: A Circle of Tipsters Who Shared Illicit Secrets
text: As Raj Rajaratnam and Anil Kumar, a McKinsey consultant, walked out of a fund-raiser in Manhattan, Mr. Rajaratnam pulled his old friend aside and made him an offer: would Mr. Kumar provide him with insights for $500,000 a year?

headline: The Art of Books
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sales at DwellStudio, Moss and Others
text: During the DwellStudio sample sale, through Sunday, a large selection of bed and table linens is up to 70 percent off (full/queen-size duvet sets, originally $280, are $140; organic twin duvet sets, originally $166, are $80; and organic layette sets, regularly $28 to $72, are $14 to $36); 60 Grand Street (West Broadway); dwellstudio.com.

headline: Three Design Shops Popping Up in New York
text: For the past few years, Finland has organized its own exhibition of design that runs concurrently with the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York in May. This year, the display includes a pop-up shop with about 100 products for the home.

headline: Vineyard Notes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tender Is the Nightstand
text: Felix Burrichter, editor of Pin-Up magazine, sees the nightstand as “the black sheep of furniture design.” So Mr. Burrichter, who is also an architect, asked 11 designers, architects and artists to create nightstands as a story for the magazine; those same nightstands will be featured in an exhibition at Phillips de Pury & Company in Midtown, opening on Saturday.

headline: Dieter Rams, Designer of Stereos, Shavers and Shelves
text: Dieter Rams is considered by many to be a design legend. The 78-year-old German designer is probably best known for the work he did as the design director at Braun (a job he held from 1961 until 1997), where he was responsible for some of the best-looking and -sounding stereo components ever made, along with a host of other products like shavers and kitchen appliances. He has inspired a number of other designers, including Jasper Morrison, Naoto Fukasawa and Jonathan Ive, the senior vice president for industrial design at Apple, who wrote the foreword to “As Little Design as Possible: The Work of Dieter Rams,” by Sophie Lovell, out next month from Phaidon Press.

headline: After a Stroke, Relearning Home
text: AFTER his stroke several years ago, my husband, Paul West, lived in the hospital rehabilitation unit for weeks, relearning the everyday feats we take for granted. How to swallow food, sit in a chair, steer a spoon, comb his hair. By far the toughest to relearn was language. To his shock and horror, he — a novelist — no longer knew how to speak, read, write or understand anything anyone said. Arduous work with physical therapists brought back some balance and dexterity. Then a few words returned to Paul helter-skelter, including one, usually slurred, that he sometimes uttered as a plea and often as a demand: “Home!”

headline: A Site for Secondhand Baby and Kids’ Gear
text: “Baby and kids’ gear now is fantastic: it’s beautiful, modern and well designed,” said Michelle Lehmann, a mother of two, ages 5 and 3. “It’s also really expensive.” That’s why she and her husband, Daniel, started reCrib, an online market for gently used furniture and toys for children.

headline: Learning to Tile and Taking It Slow
text: MY Italian forbears might be pleased that their descendants could make a living without a set of masonry tools, but I’ve long considered it a mark of shame that I never learned how to handle a trowel.

headline: Coming Soon: Smoke-Free in the Park
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spilled Beveridge
text: Last year there was a flurry of interest in the apparent fact that there were many more job vacancies than one should have expected given the high level of unemployment — a shift in the so-called Beveridge curve. And this was seized on by a number of people as evidence that much of our current unemployment is structural, that we need to accept a “new normal” of high unemployment rates. See Mike Konczal on this eagerness.

headline: The Playwright and the CUNY Trustee: Act II
text: To the Editor:

headline: Forces Fire on Protesters in 3 Cities Across Yemen
text: Security forces fired on antigovernment protesters in three cities in Yemen on Wednesday, killing at least 12 people and wounding more than 100, doctors said.

headline: The Syrian Envoy’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recidivism in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Need for Family Planning
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gingrich Officially Enters 2012 Race
text: After flirting for years with running for president, Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, officially declared Wednesday that he is a candidate for the 2012 Republican nomination, claiming the mantle of Ronald Reagan and urging Americans to “talk together, work together and find solutions together.” In a video posted on the Internet, Mr. Gingrich, 67, promoted his tenure as leader of the House and said: “We’ve done it before. We can do it again.”

headline: Feature at Trade Center Is Halted After $10 Million
text: It was supposed to be an elegant solution to a very large problem: how to disguise the 185-foot-tall fortified concrete base of 1 World Trade Center so it does not look like a gigantic bunker.

headline: The Fallout for Chiding the Royals in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — For most of his 17-year career, Somsak Jeamteerasakul wrote about the Thai monarchy from what seemed to be the haven of a Bangkok university campus.

headline: Is Inflation Vastly Understated?
text: One thing I see fairly often in comments, and which has been picked up by gullible pundits, is the notion that the true rate of inflation is vastly higher than the official statistics say. I could offer a defense of the BLS, which to my knowledge is quite scrupulous in its work. But let me also point out that independent measures are not very far from the official consumer price index.

headline: Whiners
text: Hard to believe:

headline: Berlusconi Makes Election in Milan All About Him
text: MILAN — In her campaign posters, Mayor Letizia Moratti of Milan, the candidate backed by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi in an election this weekend, clearly has top billing. Yet she has been regularly upstaged every time he has come here to campaign for her.

headline: After Half a Century, Yankees’ Trainer Will Hang Up His Scissors
text: In the spring of 1962, months before Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris and Whitey Ford led the Yankees to a world championship, they trained in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where a high school senior named Gene Monahan served as a bat boy and clubhouse attendant.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Malware and Travel Apps
text: There’s always some new evil lurking on the Internet. On this week’s Bits: Tech Talk show, J.D. Biersdorfer learns about the latest trends in malware from the global director of education for the security firm Trend Micro, David Perry. Mr. Perry says malware is becoming increasingly decentralized, with components controlled by different people or groups in different locations.

headline: Greeks Stage Protests Against Spending Cuts and Tax Increases
text: ATHENS — Tens of thousands of Greeks took to the streets here on Wednesday for a largely peaceful protest against the debt-ridden government’s austerity drive, as a general strike called by labor unions disrupted transport services and closed schools and other public services.

headline: Good News for Detroit: It’s Been Done
text: It used to happen about once every three and a half decades, but on Thursday it will happen for the second time this postseason and the third time in 12 months: a Stanley Cup playoff Game 7 after a team has clawed back from a three-games-to-none deficit.

headline: Schools Chief Appoints Two Deputies
text: Dennis M. Walcott, the new city schools chancellor, made his first senior appointments on Wednesday, selecting a Philadelphia school official to oversee labor issues, and promoting a local superintendent supervisor to lead efforts to teach at-risk students and reduce the achievement gap between students of different races and economic classes.

headline: A President Loves Movies, but Perhaps Not This One
text: PARIS — As if the life of Nicolas Sarkozy has not produced enough melodrama — especially with rumors now that his third wife, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, may be pregnant — French moviemakers have produced a semifictional drama, called “La Conquête,” or “The Conquest,” that purports to take us behind the scenes of his rise to power.

headline: In a Green Town, Activists See Red Over Lockheed Martin
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — Car sharing is beloved in this laid-back college town, as are solar panels, rain gardens and most anything designed to fight global warming from the ground up. A bicycle service will pick up your kitchen scraps for composting, and farmers will deliver your vegetables in a biodiesel-fueled truck.

headline: Pitcher’s Treatment Draws Scrutiny
text: BOCA RATON, Fla. — A year ago, Bartolo Colon, once one of major league baseball’s more durable starting pitchers, looked close to the end of the line: he had struggled with injuries after 2005, and elbow surgery had kept him out of baseball for the entire 2010 season.

headline: Don’t Let Go of the Anger
text: One of the most frustrating facts of the recently abated financial crisis is that those who might have been partly responsible for it have got off scot-free. The only two people prosecuted criminally — the Bear Stearns hedge fund managers Ralph Cioffi and Matthew Tannin — were found not guilty by a jury in Brooklyn. Other potential culprits — Angelo Mozilo, chief executive of Countrywide Financial, Joseph Cassano, chief executive of AIG Financial Products, and Dick Fuld, the chief executive of Lehman Brothers — were either slapped with a small civil penalty, in the case of Mozilo, or the Justice Department made the decision not to prosecute after months of investigation.

headline: Demanding Answers From Pakistan
text: Washington

headline: Congress Urged to Increase Oversight of Peace Corps
text: WASHINGTON — The mother of a murdered Peace Corps volunteer told Congress on Wednesday that the agency’s mishandling of confidential e-mails “ultimately led” to her daughter’s death, and she said the Peace Corps later cut off communications with her family, “leaving us by ourselves to piece together what happened to our daughter.”

headline: Jockey Found Dead, Promise Unfulfilled
text: Michael Baze understood the hard life of a race rider. He came from a family of them. He understood the rigors of making weight. His father, Michael, and uncle Gary were top riders in the Pacific Northwest and told him about the temptations awaiting a young man making a lot of money.

headline: Brazil Debates Easing Curbs on Developing Amazon Forest
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Brazil’s Congress fiercely debated changing a cornerstone environmental law on Wednesday night, a move conservationists warned could roll back one of the most effective pieces of legislation protecting forests and biodiversity in Brazil and undermine the country’s efforts to slow greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: A Rite of Torture for Girls
text: HARGEISA, Somaliland

headline: Navy Rescinds Guidelines For Same-Sex Marriages
text: Facing strong criticism from Congressional Republicans and conservative organizations, the Navy said Wednesday that it had suspended new guidelines that would have allowed chaplains to perform same-sex marriages.

headline: Purse Snatcher Embarrasses Chinese Museum
text: HONG KONG — A thief hid in the Palace Museum in Beijing’s Forbidden City after closing time on Sunday night and stole nine 20th-century gold purses encrusted with jewels from a temporary exhibition, embarrassed Chinese officials said Wednesday.

headline: Don’t Give Up Your Day Job
text: Cleveland

headline: Squeezed Cities Ask Nonprofits for More Money
text: As recession-racked cities struggle to balance their budgets with everything short of feeling behind sofa cushions for loose change, a growing number are seeking more money — just don’t use the word taxes — from nonprofit institutions that occupy valuable land but by law do not pay property taxes.

headline: Robert Traylor, a Center Known for Filling the Lane, Dies at 34
text: Robert Traylor, who played seven seasons in the N.B.A. and whose wide frame earned him the nickname Tractor, was found dead on Wednesday in his apartment in Isla Verde, Puerto Rico. He was 34.

headline: 8 Die and Scores Are Hurt as Quakes Jolt Southeast Spain
text: MADRID — Two earthquakes struck within two hours of each other in southeast Spain on Wednesday, killing at least eight people, injuring scores more and severely damaging some buildings.

headline: Bloggingheads: Rape and Abortion
text: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate the rape exception to anti-abortion laws.

headline: A Car Doctor Who Caters to the Classics
text: For that rarefied stratum of New Yorkers who own classic Mercedes-Benzes, Manfred Podschlapp, 56, offers the automotive equivalent of eternal youth, fixing models that are decades old and restoring them to their former glory. A native of Vienna, Mr. Podschlapp moved to New York with his mother when he was 14, fell in love with buying and fixing vintage American cars and was offered a job at a Mercedes repair shop when he was 20. He opened Rheinland Motors, now in Sunnyside, Queens, in 1981. He lives in Chelsea.

headline: Mr. Gingrich’s Intolerant History
text: Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker and latest entrant in the Republican presidential field, has money, experience and name recognition. His introductory video is all serenity and hope, a deceptively calm way for many voters to meet a splenetic politician with a long history of slashing divisiveness and intolerance.

headline: The Decline of the ‘Lib-Dems’ in Britain
text: The remarkable political story in Britain is the dizzying decline of the third party, the Liberal Democrats, from kingmakers to helpless dependents on a Conservative coalition partner whose core beliefs could not be more different from their own. The result has been an economic disaster for Britain and an electoral disaster for the Liberal Democrats in this month’s local elections.

headline: China: 2 Tibetan Monks Sentenced to Prison
text: Two Tibetan monks from a restive monastery have been sentenced to three years in prison during a two-month crackdown in Sichuan Province, and about 300 monks taken away in April from the same monastery are still in detention, according to a report by the International Campaign for Tibet, an advocacy group based outside China. The two monks, both from the Kirti Monastery, are Losang Dargye, 31, and Konchok Tsultrim, 33; they were arrested separately in the last two months, the group said. Chinese security forces began surrounding Kirti Monastery in March, when a young monk, Phuntsog, died after setting himself on fire to protest Chinese policies. Local officers have declined to comment.

headline: Stalking Big Names, Young Pros Are Full of Confidence
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — If golf trends continue as they have for the first five months of the year, the Players Championship, which starts Thursday at the Stadium Course at T.P.C. Sawgrass, could produce a winner whose name did not come up in the weeklong frenzy of prognostication that always accompanies a big event.

headline: Ex-Senator Said to Have Paid Contractors at Discount
text: Former State Senator Vincent L. Leibell III, who pleaded guilty to corruption charges late last year, built a $1.7 million home in Putnam County in part using contractors to whom he had awarded lucrative work on publicly financed projects he controlled, prosecutors said in court papers filed last month.

headline: Next Up, a Crackdown on Outside-Expert Firms
text: With the government securing a conviction against Raj Rajaratnam of the Galleon Group on Wednesday, federal prosecutors will shift their focus to expert networks — the intricate web of money managers, corporate executives and consultants at the center of another wave of insider trading cases.

headline: Texas Passes Bill to Make Some Fish Tales a Crime
text: Telling tall tales may be a matter of pride in Texas. But it may soon be against state law to tell one about a fish.

headline: India: Court Stands by Charges in Bhopal Leak
text: India’s Supreme Court dismissed a petition on Wednesday to reconsider a decision to reduce the charges against seven men convicted for their roles in the 1984 leak at the Union Carbide chemical plant in Bhopal. The ruling was a setback to the victims of the gas leak who sought tougher penalties against the executives serving at the time of the accident, which killed 3,000 people and sickened thousands more. India’s Central Bureau of Investigation had filed a petition requesting that the men be charged with the Indian equivalent of manslaughter instead of negligence. The executives, all Indian citizens, were sentenced last year to two years in prison. Union Carbide paid a $470 million settlement.

headline: Burt Reinhardt, Ex-CNN President, Is Dead at 91
text: Burt Reinhardt, who as the detail-minded, taciturn television executive behind his more extroverted boss, Ted Turner, played a crucial role in the formative years of CNN and the 24-hour cable news cycle, died on Tuesday at his home in Marietta, Ga. He was 91.

headline: Uganda: Opposition Leader Kept Off Flight
text: Uganda’s main opposition politician and recent protest leader was barred Wednesday from flying home after undergoing medical treatment in Kenya, Kenya Airways said. Kizza Besigye, left, who was being treated for injuries sustained during a recent arrest, was blocked from boarding a flight to Uganda after the airline said it was told by “internal intelligence sources” that the flight would not be allowed to land in Uganda with Mr. Besigye onboard. Uganda’s minister of information, Kabakumba Matsiko, told Parliament that the government did not block Mr. Besigye’s return, but that the former Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi was on the plane and did not want him on it, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Party Whose Honoree Was So Very Touchable
text: There is a teddy bear, its weight measured in tons, sitting along Park Avenue, and we spent Saturday night at a curbside party for said bear. But that was not the strangest part of our outing. The lumpy, 23-foot-tall lemon-yellow bear — its forlorn button eyes and akimbo ears appear nearly hacked off by, of all things, a giant black gas lamp that bisects its head — looks as squishy as the Velveteen Rabbit, despite being made of rumpled bronze.

headline: How St. Louis Was Won
text: Missouri began the Civil War early: from the rancorous debates over the Compromise of 1850 to the ideologically driven violence spilling over the border in Kansas, its residents had long seen how disagreements over the future of slavery and westward expansion could easily spark armed conflict. But in the second week of May 1861, St. Louisans could imagine what the end of the Civil War might bring as well: after a bloody skirmish between Confederate sympathizers and federal troops in St. Louis, city leaders sought to instill a new order, one that would maintain the property rights of Confederate sympathizers while guaranteeing Union control of the city. Some called it victory; some called it occupation. With the perspective of 150 years, we might call it the beginnings of Reconstruction.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Head of Cisco Mends His Ways
text: John Chambers and Steve Ballmer have much in common. For more than a decade, both have run dominant, rapidly maturing tech juggernauts — Mr. Chambers at Cisco Systems and Mr. Ballmer at Microsoft. And both have let down their shareholders. The difference is that one seems to have recognized the error of his ways and is repenting.

headline: Watch as She Gracefully Knocks the Fuzz Off the Tennis Ball
text: A NEW commercial for the Women’s Tennis Association opens with slow-motion film of top players hitting ground strokes while wearing billowy dresses and scarves.

headline: Sports-Gear Firm Accused of Bilking Schools
text: NEWARK — A company that sold and refurbished athletic equipment used fraud to wring millions of dollars from more than 100 schools, most of them in New Jersey, sometimes with the collusion of school officials, federal prosecutors charged on Wednesday.

headline: Weighing a White House Bid as Opening a Door to Past Pain
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Cheri Daniels has made no secret of her distaste for politics. She did not campaign for her husband, Mitch Daniels, during two races for governor. She did not fully move into the governor’s mansion after his election. She has never delivered a political speech.

headline: Wall Street, Held Accountable
text: The jury in the illegal insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, did what the government has largely failed to do: hold a major Wall Street figure accountable for his reckless behavior. It is an important step toward restoring trust as a prerequisite of America’s financial markets.

headline: Education Is the Last Thing on Their Minds
text: The for-profit education industry complained of excessive regulation last fall when the Obama administration issued new rules intended to curb abuses at profit-making colleges and trade schools. But lawsuits brought by whistle-blowers with firsthand knowledge of the industry make a strong case for why tough rules are needed.

headline: Vote Scheduled on Bonds for New Islanders Arena
text: The fate of the Islanders’ long quest for another home may be decided Aug. 1, when Nassau County residents will vote in a special referendum to approve or reject a $400 million bond issue to finance a new arena for the team.

headline: Galleon Conviction Likely to Embolden Prosecutors
text: Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire investor who once ran one of the world’s largest hedge funds, was found guilty on Wednesday of fraud and conspiracy by a federal jury in Manhattan, giving the government its biggest victory yet in a widening investigation of insider trading.

headline: Bill Gallo, Sports Cartoonist, Dies at 88
text: Bill Gallo, who captured the spectacles and personalities of sports as a cartoonist at The Daily News for more than 50 years, expressing in warmhearted caricatures the deep affection New York fans felt for their heroes, died on Tuesday in White Plains. He was 88.

headline: Reading, ’Riting and Revenues
text: American education is going to be reformed until it rolls over and begs for mercy. Vouchers! Guns on campus! Just the other day, the Florida State Legislature took a giant step toward ending the scourge of droopy drawers in high school by upping the penalties for underwear-exposing pants.

headline: Proms as Do-Overs for Adults
text: Revelers dance away at the Adult Prom, a charity event for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, in Green Bay, Wis.

headline: Undercover Officer Kills Gun Trafficker in Brooklyn, Police Say
text: An undercover officer posing as a gun buyer shot and killed a gun trafficker in Brooklyn on Wednesday night after the man pointed a gun at him, the police said.

headline: Four-Legged Warriors on the Battlefield
text: American troops may be starting to come home this summer, but more dogs are going in, with about 2,700 currently on active duty in the military.

headline: The Dogs of War: Beloved Comrades in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — Marines were on a foot patrol last fall in the Taliban stronghold of Marja, Afghanistan, when they shot and killed a lethal threat: a local dog that made the mistake of attacking the Marines’ Labrador retriever.

headline: A.I.G. Tells Shareholders Stock Sale Still Planned
text: The American International Group said Wednesday it would forge ahead with its planned public stock offering, even though the market seems so cool that taxpayers will recover less on their 2008 investment to save the company.

headline: Thursday: Brand Name That Might Ring a Bell
text: Administrivial Alert-From-the-Future! Because some people don’t read the blog until after they have solved, I wanted to post this today. There will be a notepad at the top of the Friday puzzle that does not interfere with solving, but might be interesting to read. In addition, the print version has no clue numbered 13, and goes from 12 to 14. This was not possible in Across Lite (clues have to be numbered normally), so the online version will have different clue numbers from the print version after 12. This may be confusing when referring to clues in the blog, because I solve using the Across Lite version. It may be more satisfying to solve using the PDF.

headline: A Second Shot to Have the Best Night of Their Lives
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The last time Ashley Moeller shimmied into a satin dress and glittering high heels for the prom, her father issued a stern warning: be home by 11 p.m. sharp. He waited at the door, careful to smell her breath for even the slightest trace of alcohol.

headline: A Slow Auction Night, Even With Warhol
text: A mix of overly optimistic sellers and price-conscious buyers made for a bumpy evening at Sotheby’s sale of contemporary art on Tuesday night. In an overflowing salesroom filled with big-money collectors like the former Hollywood agent Michael Ovitz, the fashion designer Valentino and the Los Angeles financier Eli Broad, the audience did more watching than shopping, with thin bidding on the most expensive works.

headline: Obama Seeks Reset in Arab World
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the killing of Osama bin Laden is more than a milestone in America’s decade-long battle against terrorism. It is a chance to recast his response to the upheaval in the Arab world after a frustrating stretch in which the stalemate in Libya, the murky power struggle in Yemen and the brutal crackdown in Syria have dimmed the glow of the Egyptian revolution.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,556 American service members who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Dolores Fuller, Actress and Ed Wood’s Muse, Dies at 88
text: Dolores Fuller, the muse, girlfriend, leading lady and involuntary costumer of Ed Wood Jr., the cross-dressing writer and director of films so awful they have a stupefying, apocalyptic beauty, died on Monday at her home in Las Vegas. She was 88.

headline: Discrepancies Are Claimed in Testimony by Officer
text: If the accuser in the rape trial of two New York police officers really came on to one of them, why did that officer not tell his partner about it immediately afterward?

headline: Heat Overcomes the Celtics
text: MIAMI — The arena corridors are plastered with memories of the only championship that was ever celebrated here. Images of the Larry O’Brien Trophy cling to doors and hallways like stale wallpaper. It can be touched, but not grasped.

headline: Coal Curriculum Called Unfit for 4th Graders
text: Three advocacy groups have started a letter-writing campaign asking Scholastic Inc. to stop distributing the fourth-grade curriculum materials that the American Coal Foundation paid the company to develop.

headline: With Taxis of Tomorrow, City Aims to Change HONK! Into Honk
text: The Bloomberg administration has vanquished indoor smoking and trans fats. Its latest goal? A kinder, gentler taxi horn.

headline: Republicans Propose More Cuts to Spending
text: WASHINGTON — Forging ahead with another round of spending reductions, House Republicans on Wednesday moved to slash federal spending for next year by another $30 billion below the cuts enacted in the April deal that averted a government shutdown.

headline: Photo Replay: May 11
text: The day in sports, from ice hockey in Slovakia to tennis in Rome and basketball in Miami.

headline: Is Your Religion Your Financial Destiny?
text: The economic differences among the country’s various religions are strikingly large, much larger than the differences among states and even larger than those among racial groups.

headline: Ailey Awards New Choreography Fellowships
text: Making his creative vision public for the first time, Robert Battle, the incoming artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will announce a major new choreography program on Thursday as he unveils the highlights of the company’s 2011-12 season.

headline: Citizens’ Arrest: Repair-Shop Workers Put End to Peahen’s Ramble
text: Most of the time, Edison Matos has eight parakeets in his auto-glass repair shop in the Bronx. For 40 minutes or so on Wednesday, he had eight parakeets and a peahen, the latest escapee from the Bronx Zoo.

headline: Robert Ellsworth, Lawmaker and Nixon Aide, Is Dead at 84
text: Robert F. Ellsworth, an independent-minded former Republican congressman from Kansas who helped run the 1968 presidential campaign of Richard M. Nixon and was rewarded with a top White House job and then the ambassadorship to NATO, died on Monday in Encinitas, Calif. He was 84.

headline: House Approves a Bill to Spur Oil Exploration
text: WASHINGTON — Maneuvering on oil drilling, gas prices and industry profits intensified on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. House Republicans pushed through a bill to accelerate offshore oil and gas exploration as Democrats vowed action on measures to rescind billions of dollars in tax breaks for major oil and gas companies.

headline: Jim Cramer Hits an All-Time High
text: Elks Lodge 1246 is located on the floor above Tony’s Clip Joint in Summit, N.J., a small town about 40 minutes from Wall Street. On a chilly Monday evening in February, I climbed the musty stairwell to the clubhouse and walked in on a scene right out of Norman Rockwell — 30 or so middle-aged men sipping bottled beer, idly watching a hockey game on TV and engaging in good-natured banter as they stood around the pool table. My host, Jim Cramer, was showered with greetings of fraternal bonhomie.

headline: In Census, Evolving Families Make Manhattan Stand Out
text: Manhattan was the only borough in New York City to record an increase in the number of children under age 5 in the last decade as well as in the number of married couples with children, according to census figures released on Wednesday.

headline: Bidding War for a Warhol Breaks Out at Christie’s
text: If, as Andy Warhol once said, “Making money is art,” he was responsible for a lot of creative activity at Christie’s sale of postwar and contemporary art on Wednesday night. He might also have added that making money is not just art, but theater, too.

headline: Two Men Arrested in New York Terror Case
text: Two men who the authorities said intended to carry out a terrorist attack in New York City were arrested late Wednesday, two law enforcement officials said.

headline: Yankees Betrayed by Their Bats and Their Bullpen
text: They played baseball for 11 innings Wednesday night at Yankee Stadium, or about two too many as far as the Yankees were concerned. In their minds, there never should have been a 10th inning. Or an 11th.

headline: Rebels Reclaim Misurata Airport
text: Libyan rebels in the contested western city of Misurata stormed the airport on Wednesday afternoon, reclaiming it from the military of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

text: The police said Wednesday that they were looking for a yellow-cab driver accused of raping a female passenger in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last week.

headline: College Football Pictures of the Day, Nov. 22
text: No. 5 Oklahoma dominated No.2 Texas Tech, Harvard defeated Yale and No. 7 Penn State routed No. 17 Michigan State and clinched a trip to the Rose Bowl.

headline: What Nicknames Have You Ever Gotten or Given?
text: “Magic,” “Chief,” “Nighttrain,” “Hacksaw,” “The Refrigerator.” These are just some of the nicknames bestowed on athletes in the past, but as this article laments, fewer athletes today have nicknames and, therefore, a part of sports is “slowly dying an unimaginative death.” What nicknames have you been called, or called others? What makes for a great nicknames? What nickname do you wish you had? Why?

headline: Troubles at Saab Continue as Chinese Deal Collapses
text: PARIS — The future of Saab Automobile was thrown into doubt yet again on Thursday when it announced that a partnership with a small Chinese automaker had collapsed.

headline: Close-Ups of Puerto Rican New York
text: Though they might get an argument from those who were born and raised in Puerto Rico, many New Yorkers identify themselves — first and foremost — as Puerto Rican. What does that mean?

headline: For California Mille Drivers, a Mobile Triage Unit
text: Last April, while gathering notes for a recent article which appeared in the Automobiles section, I spent a day riding shotgun in a trio of vintage Alfa Romeos participating in the 20th annual California Mille, a rally that pays tribute to Italy’s historic road race, the Mille Miglia.

headline: Our Health and the Luck of the Draw
text: Sometimes you hear stories from your patients that leave you staggered by the caprice of life. A young West African patient told me how his extended family had trudged through the forest on foot to escape rebels. He was 10 years old at the time. At one point in the journey, he had to urinate. He excused himself and retreated several feet into the bush. Moments later shots rang out. When he finally had the courage to crawl back out onto the path, he saw that his entire family had been killed in an ambush.

headline: Turkish Designs for Sale in Istanbul and New York
text: Great design transcends borders and, in the case of “Destination: Istanbul,’’ it literally crosses them. In the project, a joint effort by the Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, cleverly rendered items by Turkish designers will be for sale at the MoMA Design Store starting this month and at the IKSV Design Store (Sadi Konuralp Caddesi No: 5; 90-212-334-0830; www.iksvtasarim.com/giris.asp) in the Sishane neighborhood of Istanbul.

headline: 2010 Titans: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.
