headline: Weekend Fare
text: The Manhattan Cocktail Classic kicks off Friday with a tasting party from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m. at the New York Public Library that includes art and live music. Other events throughout the weekend include seminars on the history of distilling in New York, cocktail competitions and an 1980s-themed party with rum-based drinks. Many events are sold out, but check for available tickets online.

headline: Speed Bumps on the Way to an A.D.H.D. Diagnosis
text: WHEN Liz Goldberg, 53, was growing up, she always felt “a little off.” She received good grades and even completed a master’s degree in health administration, but it was always a struggle.

headline: Kutcher to Replace Sheen on ‘Two and a Half Men’
text: Ashton Kutcher, one of the former stars of the sitcom “That 70’s Show,” has been selected to replace Charlie Sheen on the hit comedy “Two and a Half Men,” Warner Brothers and CBS announced on Friday.

headline: Into the Heart of Guyana
text: In the opening paragraph of Rahul Bhattacharya’s first novel, “The Sly Company of People Who Care,” the unnamed narrator, a former cricket journalist from India, declares his intentions for his life, and thus his story — to be a wanderer, or in his words, “a slow ramblin’ stranger.” That rambling, through the forests of Guyana; the ruined streets of its capital, Georgetown; and out to the borders of Brazil and Venezuela, constitutes the novel’s central action. But its heart lies in the exuberant and often arresting observations of a man plunging himself into a world full of beauty, violence and cultural strife.

headline: Weekend Competition: Rhyming Slang
text: This weekend, Schott’s Vocab is soliciting contemporary rhyming slang.

headline: Gathering Photos of Kate Moss
text: Those of us who follow fashion and photography tend to have a favorite image of Kate Moss. I have two: Corinne Day’s portrait (styled by Melanie Ward) of a laughing and feather-headdressed Kate for a 1990 cover of The Face; and Mario Sorrenti’s 1993 image of her, with its deep shadow and her eyes looking at once tender and wary. The early ’90s announced a more stripped-down view of fashion — call it grunge, if you like — and the waif Kate fit the bill as she inspired an industry.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Long-Lost Heroes
text: Undiscovered truths are a big part of comic-book stories. On our hardcover list this week, “S.H.I.E.L.D.: Architects of Forever” (No. 10) shares some big secrets about the Marvel Universe. The story, by Jonathan Hickman and Dustin Weaver, collects the first six issues of an adventure that reveals how some luminaries of the past – including Leonardo Da Vinci, Michelangelo and Isaac Newton – protected the Marvel Universe long before heroes like Captain America, Iron Man and Spider-Man were born.

headline: A Jobs Recovery Is Happening Faster for Some Countries Than Others
text: THE financial crisis and the severe recession that followed destroyed jobs in every industrialized country. While many countries have started to recover, in only one major one, Germany, has unemployment declined to a level lower than it was in September 2008.

headline: A Life Span Predictor? The Readers Have Spoken
text: It’s virtually unanimous: About 70 readers (including several who weighed in by e-mail) commented on the plan by palliative care specialists at the University of California, San Francisco, to build a Web site containing tested geriatric calculators that can predict older people’s odds of dying in the coming six months, or four years, or nine.

headline: The Population Shifts Westward
text: 2:28 p.m. | Updated The Census Bureau has put together a neat interactive map showing the shifting center of the population, defined as “the place where an imaginary, flat, weightless and rigid map of the United States would balance perfectly if all residents were of identical weight.”

headline: Psyched for the Semifinals
text: You have to hand it to the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. for producing conference finals with great psychodramatic subplots. Now, you don’t have to credit the actual leagues — especially the N.H.L., which was too busy trying to figure out what to do with the Green Men to concoct any actual strategy — but feel free to enjoy the results.

headline: Killebrew Ends Treatment and Looks to Hospice Care
text: Harmon Killebrew, the brawny slugger who announced last year that he was being treated for esophageal cancer, said in a statement Friday: “With the continued love and support of my wife, Nita, I have exhausted all options with respect to controlling this awful disease. My illness has progressed beyond my doctors’ expectation of cure.”

headline: Debts, Deficits and Defaults in Sin City
text: LAS VEGAS — Nothing much happens on the Las Vegas Strip at 8 a.m.

headline: Bin Laden Widows in Pakistan Questioned by C.I.A.
text: WASHINGTON — C.I.A. interrogators questioned three wives of Osama bin Laden for the first time on Thursday, 10 days after they were taken by Pakistani security forces from the compound where the Al Qaeda leader was killed, an American official confirmed on Friday.

headline: Making Sense of a Toxic World
text: We all know by now — don’t we? — that many of the synthetic chemicals in our food, personal-­care and cleaning products, toys and household goods are harming not just the environment but ourselves. Body-burden tests, for measuring exposure to chemicals, reveal flame retardants, plasticizers, pesticides and perfluorinated chemicals in the blood of almost every person studied. We see rising rates of some cancers, autoimmune disorders, reproductive illnesses, autism and learning disabilities. Meanwhile, our consumption of synthetic chemicals, a majority of which haven’t been tested for human health impacts, has skyrocketed. A growing number of books make the case that these phenomena are linked.

headline: MoMA Calls ‘Action!’ on Kathryn Bigelow Retrospective
text: Could this be the first event at the Museum of Modern Art where a full-body blast suit, a parachute and a rubber Richard M. Nixon mask might be appropriate attire? The museum said on Friday that it would host a retrospective of the works of Kathryn Bigelow, the Academy Award-winning director of films including “The Hurt Locker” and “Point Break.”

headline: From a Stranger in an Airport, a Decision Becomes Clear
text: It was in an airport restaurant, talking with a complete stranger, that I found myself making the most important decision of my life thus far.

headline: Edna O’Brien’s Elemental Fiction
text: Fraughans, bostoons, coolth, coatee, turloughs, chambering, doyleys, billio. These words are all plucked from Edna O’Brien’s sublime new collection of stories, “Saints and Sinners.” To read O’Brien is not only to succumb to her sibyl’s vision of other people’s fates, it’s to fall under the spell of her singular, potent language, which clings to the tactile realities of another century’s earthier, guiltier sensibility — to bogs and turf fires, to poverty and proud airs, lust and furtive ­passions.

headline: Now Showing | Design Fever
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#240", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Anatomy of a Showstopper
text: A closer look at show-stopping numbers from three Broadway musicals.

headline: Jobless in MInnesota
text: Minnesota has been viewed a state whose mix of demographics, varied industries, educated citizenry and public policy provided a shield against economic woes. But the state stands as an example of the disconnect between positive data and the harsher reality of people’s lives.

headline: No, Mayor Says, Peahen Was Not Fleeing Budget Cuts
text: It’s been a tough spring for the Bronx Zoo. First, an Egyptian cobra disappeared. And then, a peahen fled.

headline: Encouraging Numbers, at First Glance
text: MINNEAPOLIS — When it comes to economic recovery, Minnesota is about as good as it gets.

headline: F.C.C. Commissioner Defends Taking Comcast Job
text: WASHINGTON — A Federal Communications commissioner who announced this week that she planned to join the lobbying office of Comcast defended her actions on Friday, saying she had no contact with Comcast about a potential job while the company’s takeover of NBC Universal was pending before the commission this year.

headline: Allegations Upend Lives of 2 Muslims in Army
text: Two years ago, Khalid Lyaacoubi and Yassine Bahammou, immigrants from Morocco, enlisted in the Army National Guard, recruited for a program that promised higher rank, bonuses and quick citizenship to Arabic speakers who could help fill the military’s need for interpreters.

headline: Setback for New Stem Cell Treatment
text: In an unexpected setback to efforts to harness a promising new type of stem cell to treat diseases, researchers reported on Friday that tissues made from those stem cells might be rejected by a patient’s immune system — even though the tissues would be derived from the same patient.

headline: Lincoln Steffens: Muckraker’s Progress
text: He knew everyone and he went ­everywhere. He was a confidant to presidents, a mentor to two of the most influential journalists in American history, a friend to industrialists, artists, ward heelers, Communists and bohemians. He claimed to have spent the rest of his life after college “unlearning” everything he had been taught. He saw through all pretenses, circumventions and lies — even the ones he told himself — until in the end he was hornswoggled by the biggest lie of all.

headline: 3-D Art, Ready to Print
text: The MakerBot, a new consumer-grade, desktop-size 3-D printer, makes, or “prints,” three-dimensional objects from molten plastic based on its users designs.

headline: Classic Tales of Temptation in the Woods
text: IF the world of Ballet Ever After employed Match.com, a good many entries would run along the following lines: “Handsome prince seeks the ideal beloved. Enjoys hunting, adores the big beyond, and will travel. Is already affianced to a woman he knows well, but seeks to forget this and other minor inconveniences with perfect and irresistible female.”

headline: Architect as Auto Designer: Le Corbusier’s Minimum Car
text: A “machine for living” was how Le Corbusier famously described his vision for the home. Le Corbusier, the Swiss architect, however, was transfixed by machines of less metaphorical form, like airplanes, ocean liners and locomotives. He called steam shovels and fountain pens the “fauna of the new age.” And he was particularly fascinated with the car, or so argues the author of a new book.

headline: Accessing a Place Of Shaggy Wildness
text: PETER LIEBERSON, who wrote music of such visceral intensity that it seemed to startle even him, died last month at 64. If he dealt with his final illness the way he handled previous misfortunes, I suspect he saw it as an opportunity for growth. Peter never let a crisis go to waste. He took a tortuous road toward maturity, and every difficulty enriched his imagination, bringing him closer to the music he was meant to write.

headline: How Bernard Madoff Did It
text: Ever since the Madoff scandal broke in December 2008, the public has been morbidly fascinated by the affair. How had so ordinary a man pulled off the largest swindle in history? How had he gotten away with it for so long? Then there were the casualties. In contrast to so many other financial scandals of the last 20 years, those who lost money this time were not just impersonal institutions — they were real people. And what a spectrum of the world: Jewish philanthropists from the Upper East Side; almost half the membership of the Palm Beach Country Club; rich South Americans; retired accountants living in Florida; the demimonde of Monaco; even, it was whispered, figures from the Russian mafia and the Colombian drug cartels. Some of us could imagine ourselves among the victims; others found a certain voyeuristic pleasure in the financial travails of the rich and famous.

headline: Risks: Acid Reflux Drugs Tied to Bone Fractures
text: A new analysis adds to growing evidence that people using proton pump inhibitors to control symptoms of acid reflux are more likely to fracture bones than those who do not.

headline: Screenings: When It’s Too Soon for a New Colonoscopy
text: While many uninsured patients cannot afford to undergo colonoscopy screening as often as they should, a new study suggests many older Medicare beneficiaries receive the colon cancer test too often.

headline: Safety: Report Questions Studies on Stun Guns
text: Advocates of electrical stun guns say they provide police officers with a nonlethal method of subduing suspects. But some experts believe the devices may have contributed to the deaths of suspects.

headline: Gilbert Gottfried’s Laughs and Gaffes
text: In comedy, the saying goes, timing is everything. The publication of Gilbert Gottfried’s first book, which is kind of a memoir but not really, comes little more than a month after Gottfried made news by tweeting jokes about the Japanese earthquake and tsunami so tasteless that they cost him the longest-lasting and perhaps most lucrative job of his career: providing the duck’s voice in those omni­present Aflac commercials. He quickly apologized, but the damage was done.

headline: Amid Impasse in Peace Negotiations, America’s Chief Middle East Envoy Resigns
text: WASHINGTON — George J. Mitchell Jr., the former senator who brokered peace in Northern Ireland and investigated the use of steroids in Major League Baseball, is resigning as the chief United States envoy to the Israelis and Palestinians amid growing frustration over the impasse in peace talks, the White House announced Friday.

headline: Charting Julianna Barwick
text: Julianna Barwick is an experimental singer/songwriter from Brooklyn who makes ethereal music with vocal loops and other electronic effects. Her latest album is called “The Magic Place” and she recently performed at Glasslands in Brooklyn. The artist Andrew Kuo charts the show.

headline: Donatella Arpaia and Allan Stewart
text: IN early 2010, Dr. Allan Stewart, a cardiac surgeon, was challenged by a patient on whom he had operated the previous year, to sign up for the New York City Triathlon. The doctor broke two ribs while training, but soldiered on, knowing his patient had overcome a much bigger obstacle.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE BOY IN THE MOON: A Father’s Journey to Understand His Extraordinary Son,  by Ian Brown (St. Martin’s, $24.99.) The truth Brown learns from his severely disabled child is a rare one: The life that seems to destroy you is the one you long to embrace.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE SABBATH WORLD: Glimpses of a Different Order of Time,  by Judith Shulevitz (Random House, $15.) Dissatisfied with the frenzied quality of modern life, Shulevitz explores the history and philosophical foundations of the Sabbath, the day of rest. Part spiritual memoir, part religious history, part literary exegesis, this is “a book of richness and depth,” Rebecca Newberger Goldstein wrote here.

headline: Algorithms
text: Jonathan Chait gets angry, rightly over Dana Milbank asserting that Mitt Romney has an “Al Gore problem”, seeming insincere whatever he does. As Chait says,

headline: Red Wings Comeback Falls Just Short
text: There were only two ways Thursday night could end for the Detroit Red Wings: either with the joy of accomplishing one of the greatest playoff comebacks in N.H.L. history, or crushed by falling just short to the San Jose Sharks.

headline: Houses Passes Intelligence Authorization Bill
text: The House of Representatives departed from its usually partisan caviling on Friday and approved a 2011 intelligence authorization bill that increases spending for 16 intelligence agencies, but at a lower level than requested by President Obama. The amount of the increase is classified but is reported to be substantial.

headline: Salon Glam
text: “This is going to be the sexiest salon uptown,” said Ric Pipino, whose sprawling new beauty destination, Ric Pipino-Wella Professional Flagship, is more like a really cool apartment. Conceived by Rawlins Calderone Design, the space is superglam, with black and white walls that serve as graphic foil to a colorful mix of vintage and custom furniture and accessories. The front desk is an homage to the ’70s designer Paul Evans, while the slick red “color bar” is pure Donald Judd. Besides a full menu of services, there’s a boutique selling art books and chocolate, and a bar stocked with Scotch and tequila for clients needing something stiffer than Elnett. 115 East 57th Street; (212) 355-5544.

headline: Adam Gwon and Michelle Elliott Win Musical-Theater Writing Prizes
text: The composer and lyricist Adam Gwon and the book writer and lyricist Michelle Elliott are the recipients of the 2011 Kleban Prize, which recognizes talent and promise in musical theater, the sponsors of the prize said this week. Each award comes with a cash prize of $100,000, payable over two years.

headline: Inside the List
text: BIN LADEN BUMP: President Obama isn’t the only one to get a numbers boost from the recent kill operation against Osama bin Laden. Books by and about Navy Seals have also been flying off the shelves. “The Heart and the Fist,” a memoir of derring-do in Iraq, Afghanistan and beyond by Eric Greitens, a Rhodes scholar turned Navy Seal officer turned humanitarian volunteer, lands at No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Meanwhile over on the paperback list, Marcus Luttrell and Patrick Robinson’s “Lone Survivor: The Eyewitness Account of Operation Redwing and the Lost Heroes of Seal Team 10,” jumps to No. 3, up from No. 18 two weeks ago. (The book, first published in 2007, has spent 61 weeks on the printed paperback list so far, on top of a 38-week run in hardcover.) There’s no sign yet of “Seal Team Six” — a memoir by a former member of the supersecret unit that brought down Bin Laden, which was rushed into stores a few weeks early following the raid — but stay tuned.

headline: Caucus | The YouTube Primary
text: Michael D. Shear gets reader feedback on which candidate has the best Web video so far. Also, Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the Republican field taking shape.

headline: Dave Ramsey’s 12% Solution
text: Thousands of people swear by the philosophy of Dave Ramsey, an up-by-the-bootstraps kind of guy who doles out tough financial advice about getting out of debt and living within your means. His legions of fans call his nationally syndicated radio show to seek his advice, attend his self-help seminars in both big arenas and small church classrooms and buy his best-selling books and DVDs. He’s part entertainer, part financial coach.

headline: British Parakeet Boom Is a Mystery, and a Mess
text: STANWELL, England — The evening started peacefully enough at Long Lane Recreation Park in the western suburbs of London, disturbed only by the occasional rumble of a distant jet landing at Heathrow Airport. But just before sunset, five bright green missiles streaked through the air toward a row of poplars at the park’s edge.

headline: Film Announcements Are Always More Fun Aboard a Yacht
text: CANNES, France— We’ve traversed the red carpets and the publicity stunts. But there is another side to the film festival here: the maritime side. We’re talking, of course, about yachts. Big ones and bigger ones, they crowd the harbor, drawing gawkers and aspirants (and Diddy). Really, no trip to the French Riviera is complete without a yacht party. And though the festival may be the pinnacle of the “glamour racket,” as Manohla Dargis noted in The New York Times, but that doesn’t mean it’s without its share of left-field come-ons.

headline: Denmark Warned Over Border Plans
text: BRUSSELS — Controversy over the future of Europe’s passport-free travel zone grew Friday when Denmark was warned that its plans to restart checks at its frontiers could be against European Union law.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $13.5 Million
text: Big Ticket is a new feature with the Big Deal column that will list one of the priciest sales of the previous week.

headline: Faith, Education and Income
text: In this weekend’s Times Magazine, I have a column explaining the tight link between education and income for religious groups in this country. The most educated groups, like Hindus and Jews, are the most affluent, while the least educated are the least affluent. The chart with the column has more details.

headline: Wisconsin Retirement Adds to Democrats’ Burden in Senate Races
text: Today, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin will become the sixth Democratic senator to retire rather than seek another term in 2012. Of those six retirement announcements, this is surely among the more problematic for Democrats.

headline: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Dead First
text: Charlaine Harris is back atop the hardcover fiction list with “Dead Reckoning.”

headline: Wealthy Hesitate to Take a Break on Estate Taxes
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA and the Republican Congress gave the wealthiest Americans an enormous gift at the end of 2010. They increased the exemption on a series of estate-related taxes and lowered the tax rate on any amount over those limits. The catch is it lasts only two years.

headline: Andy Reid Talks Horses With Graham Motion
text: Steeplechase Times has been with Animal Kingdom, winner of the Kentucky Derby, at the Fair Hill Training Center in Maryland. Joe Clancy was there when Andy Reid, head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, and two others — the offensive coordinator Marty Mornhinweg and the scout Brett Veach — talked with Animal Kingdom’s trainer, Graham Motion.

headline: In Galaxy, Less Hype and Finally Real Action
text: Spore, released in 2008, was the most over-hyped game in recent memory. Through years of prerelease publicitymongering, Spore’s publisher, Electronic Arts, and its famed designer, Will Wright, managed to convince much of the general public and the gaming world that they had created an “everything simulator.”

headline: Citigroup’s Symbolic Dividend
text: CNBC looks at how investors are reacting to Citigroup after it resumed paying a dividend. The bank, which required a huge bailout during the financial crisis, cut the payout in 2009.

headline: Fox Rides ‘Idol’ to Another Ratings Victory
text: Fox finished atop the Thursday-night ratings as 21.6 million viewers tuned in for the “American Idol” elimination episode at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. The “Idol” finalist James Durbin failed to advance to next week’s round, earning the lowest vote tally of nearly 72 million cast, leaving Lauren Alaina, Scotty McCreery and Haley Reinhart in the running.

headline: The Tonys: Stop the Show!
text: “Catch Me if You Can” might have gotten mixed reviews, but pretty much everyone agrees that Norbert Leo Butz’s rendition of “Don’t Break the Rules” in the first act is the kind of showstopper you don’t see on Broadway all that often. Except this season, which is notable for numbers that, through the alchemy of song, sound, legs, lights and star power — not to mention tap dancing — build into something more joyful than the sum of their parts.

headline: Sunny Delight
text: Arthur Kulkov, the Siberian born, Coney Island raised in-demand model currently towering over Port Authority in an ad over five stories tall, is known around town for his eccentric and super-stylish way. His ease with fashion and sense of humor about his style adds to his appeal as a professional model, certainly. But his eye-catching outfits and lack of self-consciousness are what really sets him apart. “I hate to say that this business has influenced my style, but it certainly did. All these years you have no choice but to pick up on things here and there, but obviously with my own spin on things. Ha.” While on the set for a campaign shoot in Sarasota, Fla., he caught stares sporting these Day-Glo orange pieces (athletic sandals and shorts by Adidas, hat by American Apparel). He ordered the flip-flops from a soccer magazine, got the shorts at Y-3 and snagged the hat from another shoot. “I thought it was brightly cool … I wouldn’t rock all together, but I think it looks cool in parts.”

headline: Antigay Bill in Uganda Is Shelved in Parliament
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — After receiving overwhelming criticism from across the globe, Uganda’s Parliament on Friday let the time expire on a contentious anti-homosexuality bill that had threatened this East African country’s international standing.

headline: Why 401(k)’s Should Offer Index Funds
text: The people who help you with your investments ought to act in your best interest.

headline: Lobbying for a Better 401(k) Plan
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I encouraged readers to storm the barricades (but nicely!) to suggest improvements to their 401(k) or other retirement plans. Namely, I suggest that the majority of plans could use more index mutual funds.

headline: 22 Miles and a World Away From Los Angeles
text: THE problem with wilderness is that it is, by definition, too darn far from where most people live. Yes, many cities have a few nice day hikes, but it’s a lucky accident of geography and conservation that creates serious, “out there” backcountry hiking opportunities close to a major urban area.

headline: The Trans-Catalina Trail
text: A 37-mile trail takes hikers on a four-day trek.

headline: Regarding the Royal Consummation
text: By now we can assume that Prince William and the new Duchess of Cambridge have consummated their marriage, or anyway we can hope. These things can be problematic. It’s said, for example, to have taken seven years for the Dauphin Louis-Auguste of France, later Louis XVI, and the Hapsburg Archduchess Maria Antonia, known as Marie Antoinette, to consummate their union. (They were just teenagers, 15 and 14, at the time of their wedding in 1770, though on the face of it that would hardly explain the delay.) But at least William and Kate can spend time alone. In the old days, servants and witnesses would have been spending the night in the royal bedchamber with them.

headline: May 15 — 21
text: Film

headline: Letters: Short-Hop Airlines
text: To the Editor: Regarding “Small Airlines for Shorter Hops” (Practical Traveler, May 1): As a frequent purchaser of direct air, my only complaint thus far is trying to book a flight when seats are limited and not always available unless one pays full price. Other than that the convenience of going direct far outweighs the limitations. One has to be flexible with an itinerary.

headline: New Host Needed: Be Prepared to Fill Big Shoes
text: Wanted: Host for a two-hour live public radio show Saturday nights, from the Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul. Qualifications: Brilliant writer; eclectic musical tastes with a fondness for traditional Protestant hymns and patriotic songs; knack for poking fun at Midwesterners without offending them. Ability to charm four million listeners unhappy to see the present occupant go a plus.

headline: An Explorer of Black History’s Uncharted Terrain
text: FOR some people, filmmaking is a lifelong dream. For Stanley Nelson, it began as more of a situational thing, a response to time and place. The time was the late 1960s and early ’70s, the place to be avoided was Vietnam, the refuge was film school at the City University of New York. “It was kind of my motive to stay in school no matter what, you know what I’m saying?”

headline: Rock Star Tunes in to the Elders of the Tribe
text: SINCE 2006, when Arctic Monkeys appeared on the British music scene, Alex Turner, the frontman, has been acclaimed as a songwriter wise beyond his years. (He was 20 when the group hit it big, thanks in part to the tendency of the British press to trumpet and acclaim.) Through lineup changes and side projects, and a recent foray in New York with his girlfriend, Alexa Chung, the MTV personality and Madewell designer, Mr. Turner has gravitated toward classic musicians, like Gene Clark of the Byrds, and films like the 1959 western “Rio Bravo.” His retro sensibility is evident on the band’s fourth album, “Suck It and See” (Domino), to be released June 6. The title seems cheeky but it’s not, Mr. Turner said. “It’s an old Britishism, like a bit Dick van Dyke-y, like ‘give it a try’ almost — it’d be a slogan for some candy,” he said. “That’s not really traveled very well.” In a conversation peppered with other Britishisms (“nice one, love” he said, often, alongside saucier phrases) he recently spoke with Melena Ryzik from Stockholm, where the band members were starting their tour, performing together for the first time in over a year. “I’m a bit nervous, to be honest with you,” Mr. Turner said. “I have just opened a beer, actually. We’ll see if that’s going to help it out. I don’t want to do too much of that. I’m worried I might become forgetful, and there’s a lot of words in our songs.” Here are excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Something Genre Crossing, Something Bold
text: BRET EASTON ELLIS, the author of “Less Than Zero” and a man who knows a thing or two about the 1980s, recently tweeted, “The two key American films of the 1980s: ‘Blue Velvet,’ ‘Something Wild’...” The first choice is no surprise, but the second confused some of his followers. “When I tweeted it, people responded to ‘Blue Velvet’ but asked, ‘What’s the other one?,’ ” Mr. Ellis said in a telephone interview.

headline: Late Preminger, the Un-Swinger
text: TOWARD the middle of Otto Preminger’s 1967 “Hurry Sundown,” a land-rich, cash-poor Southern belle, Julie Ann Warren (Jane Fonda), visits Rose Scott (Beah Richards), the black woman who raised her and who, Julie Ann remembers, gave her the only semblance of love she knew in childhood.

headline: In Search of Star Power
text: The 2011 Audi A5 and S5 coupes and convertibles are exquisitely styled, but lacking in character.

headline: Your Palm’s Telling Me You Must Let Go. Of $27,000.
text: Can psychics see their own futures? If so, Sylvia Mitchell, 36, peering into her crystal ball on a busy corner of Greenwich Village, might have caught a glimpse of her driver’s license photo, blown up and attached to an unpleasant poster saying “Wanted” and “Grand Larceny” and “$28,000.” And so she apparently took off.

headline: Citadel’s Griffin Debates Dodd-Frank
text: 4:37 p.m. | Updated

headline: S.E.C. Official Demoted Despite Spotting Stanford
text: In 1997, Julie Preuitt sounded the alarms that the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford was operating a huge Ponzi scheme.

headline: Divorce, in Style
text: CHARLES Bronfman and his wife, Bonnie, are inviting 100 of their friends to an elegant evening of cocktails for what they hope will be a once-in-a-lifetime event.

headline: Rejection May Hurt More Than Feelings
text: THE GIST Being socially rejected doesn’t just feel bad. It hurts.

headline: Big Deal | Price Cuts and Foie Gras
text: In the cutthroat world of high-end New York City real estate, there is a simple maxim among brokers: Sell what you have seen.

headline: Something About a Witch
text: FOR years, Scott Murdock was haunted by a cinematic image fluttering at the periphery of his memory. It involved a witch. She was serving pancakes. And there were lots of colorful bubbles floating over the screen.

headline: Name-Dropping in Designer Audio
text: IN 1982, General Motors began selling three models that for the first time offered high-end designer sound systems, made by Bose, starting a trend in which branded audio systems are now available in almost every vehicle.

headline: Homework Follies
text: Many parents dread homework time, and the struggle they will have to go through to get their kids to do it. So, is all this effort worthwhile? Over the years a disturbing amount of evidence has emerged suggesting that it is not.  For a forthcoming study in the journal Economics of Education Review, Ozkan Eren and Daniel Henderson measured the effect of homework on math, science, English and history tests for 8th grade students in the United States. They used a method that controlled student and teacher traits.  They found that doing additional math homework had large and statistically significant effects on math test scores. They found that additional homework in science, English and history had little or no impact.

headline: Romancing the Stars
text: AS Carrie Bradshaw would have recognized, a museum’s cultivation of a potential patron is a form of courtship, with the same flirtation, grand gestures, ardent hopes for a future together — and then, sometimes, of course, the realization that the person you’re wooing is, well, just not that into you.

headline: The Continental Battle of the Bands
text: Since 1956, Eurovision has been one of the few cultural institutions that bind citizens of Europe together.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, Jerusalem, China and Spain.

headline: Qaddafi Calls From ‘a Place You Cannot Reach’
text: Updated | 4:46 p.m. Hours after Italy’s foreign minister said on Friday that he had heard from the Roman Catholic bishop of Tripoli that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had been wounded and left the Libyan capital, Libyan state television broadcast a brief audio statement from the country’s leader, who told NATO that he was in “a place you cannot reach.”

headline: Douglas Crase, Frank Polach
text: Douglas Crase and Frank Polach were married Tuesday afternoon at Center Church, the First Church of Christ, in Hartford. The Rev. Paulo G. França, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Laura DiBetta, Gregory Hopper
text: Laura Lynn DiBetta and Gregory John Hopper were married Thursday on the beach at Magens Bay on St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands. The Rev. Jeffrey Neevel, a minister of the Reform Church in America, officiated.

headline: Melissa Gronlund, Christian Le Mière
text: Melissa Kai Gronlund and Christian Paul Le Mière were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor.

headline: Allison Maimona, Stephen DeVito
text: Capt. Allison Anne Maimona and Capt. Stephen Roy DeVito, both of the Air Force, were married Saturday evening at Club Hillbrook, an inn and private club in Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The bride’s brother, Matthew P. Maimona, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Johanna Vespe, Anthony Aulisa
text: Johanna King Vespe and Anthony Jerome Aulisa were married Saturday at the Regis High School Chapel in Manhattan. The Rev. Philip Judge, a Roman Catholic priest and the school’s president, performed the ceremony.

headline: Megan Barrick,Harvey Taylor II
text: Megan Frances Barrick and Harvey Parnell Taylor II were married Saturday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. Patrick in Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Christopher A. Roux, the cathedral’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Sophie Balzora, Eric Siddall Jr.
text: Dr. Sophie Myriam Balzora, a daughter of Micheline Balzora and Dr. Jean Daniel Balzora of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday morning to Dr. Eric Clayton Siddall Jr., the son of Mary Jane Collins of Oswego, N.Y., and Mr. Siddall Sr. of Baldwinsville, N.Y. Lulrick Balzora, a cousin of the bride who was ordained as a Baptist minister and was a Navy chaplain, officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Kalpana Narayan, Ganesh Shankar
text: Dr. Kalpana Narayan and Dr. Ganesh Mani Shankar were married Thursday morning at the Hyatt hotel in Westlake Village, Calif. Samudrala Krishnamachari, a Hindu priest, officiated.

headline: Joseph Carino Jr. and Michael Pace

headline: Dolan Reasserts Traditional Definition of Marriage
text: Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, on Friday added his voice to the growing debate over legalization of same-sex marriage in New York, telling readers of his blog that the traditional definition of marriage as the union of one man and one woman “is hardwired into our human reason.”

headline: Desert Prose
text: The Harvard historian Roger Owen is one of the pre-eminent minds on the modern Middle East, but even he was dumbstruck by the civil unrest sweeping the Arab world. The books that will shed light on it all, he says, have yet to be written. In the meantime, one could turn to the classics: “The literature you need now is almost Shakespearean. We’re dealing with family rule with fatal flaws.” Or to the following volumes, selected by Owen, which give some background on this complicated revolutionary moment.

headline: The Photo P.&G. Probably Wanted to Retouch
text: The Fortune 500 issue, which hit newsstands this week, has the business magazine’s annual look of seven of “the most photogenic” boards in the United States.

headline: 21 Months in Prison for Former State Senator
text: WHITE PLAINS — A former state senator was sentenced in federal district court here on Friday to 21 months in prison and three years of supervised release after pleading guilty last year to obstruction of justice and tax evasion.

headline: Metropolitan Preview | The Fleas
text: “In a city that thrums with opportunity and a veritable buffet of wonderful things to do — theaters! museums! parks! — flea markets have somehow emerged as many people’s first choice of a way to spend the weekend,” writes Ashley Parker in this week’s Metropolitan cover article, “The Flea Marketing of New York.” Over the last few years, the markets, with their vintage clothing, handmade jewelry and profusion of handcrafted foods have proliferated, as have the crowds drawn to them. On Brooklyn Flea’s opening weekend, about 25,000 people filed through the Fort Greene and Williamsburg markets, according to the organizers, and SuChin Pak, a founder of the Hester Street Fair, estimated that 11,000 people came to her market’s opening day this year. Read Ms. Parker’s explanation of how shopping for vintage clothing, old typewriters and artisanal cheese became the hippest way to spend your weekend here.

headline: British Parakeets and the Tumbleweed Blues
text: Life on Earth is getting stranger by the minute. Parakeets are flocking in Britain, as described in Elisabeth Rosenthal’s news story today. But don’t forget the monk parrots in Brooklyn, the American bullfrogs in Japan and France, the Burmese pythons in the Everglades, the West Nile virus spanning the Americas. (Oh, and the American squirrels that are also displacing their kin in Britain.) You get the idea.

headline: TimesCast | May 13, 2011
text: The Pakistani Army chief balks at American demands to cooperate; evaluating the billions in American aid to Pakistan; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on Pakistan’s rampant illiteracy.

headline: Video: The YouTube Primary

headline: Book Review Video: Jane Goodall
text: This week’s Book Review contains a special section on children’s books: more than a dozen reviews of picture books, chapter books and novels for kids and teenagers. Inside is a review of two new picture books about Jane Goodall — “Me … Jane” by Patrick McDonnell, and “The Watcher” by Jeanette Winter. Recently, Dr. Goodall and both authors visited The Times for a video interview, embedded above.

headline: Vines and Valleys in Oregon
text: OREGON is hiking country. It’s also wine country, with vineyards that are increasingly destinations for oenophiles. So perhaps it’s no surprise that the combination of hiking and wine tasting has a name: wiking.

headline: Hiking With a Child (and Tricks) in Tow
text: “CHARLIE likes a lot of outdoor things,” said my son Gus, then 4 1/2, about a friend who likes nothing more than classifying lichens in the forest. “I like indoor things.” This was, and still is, true. Gus can spend hours with his cheek on his bedroom rug, building Lego space stations and acting out savage battles upon them. Two years ago, summer break from preschool meant to Gus a happy vacation from being trundled off to parks and beaches with the rest of his class. But I had a different idea.

headline: The Birds of Kauai
text: An abundance of species, but many are imperiled.

headline: An Eden for Rare Birds in Hawaii
text: THE trade winds were pushing a misty fog across the treetops of the Alakai wilderness — a cloud forest atop the mountain hinterlands of Kauai — when my guide spotted something yellowish flitting among the boughs of an ohia tree.

headline: It’s a Bear’s World in Kodiak, Alaska
text: SHE gave a chuff and pulled up short, as surprised to see us as we were to see her. Her dense, fluffy fur was blond. I watched her square, expressive face very closely because this bear — maybe 300 pounds and 10 yards away — would be the one deciding how the encounter played out. An adrenaline-driven voice in my head said, “This could go badly.” But it was also telling me how incredibly thrilling it was to be so near this animal. Not being on top of the food chain certainly heightens one’s awareness.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are
text: Bear-watching trip on Kodiak Island in Alaska.

text: Let’s play a Friday afternoon game of  “Did the School Overreact?”

headline: Powered by an Idea
text: The Paxton steam car did not revolutionize the auto industry, but it remains a benchmark of innovative design.

headline: A Directory of Rare Wonders
text: A regional guide of endangered species.

headline: A Coast-to-Coast Guide to Endangered Species
text: THE whoosh of a surfacing orca and the glower of a mother grizzly still have the power to raise goose bumps; a soaring California condor can yet astonish. But chances to admire many of our wildlife neighbors are becoming increasingly uncommon. Invasive buffelgrass is crowding out saguaros and other native cactuses throughout the Southwest, while melting sea ice is threatening the Pacific walrus and polar bear in Alaska. Mosquito-borne diseases are threatening Hawaii’s songbirds, and white-nose syndrome is wiping out bats in the East.

headline: Google Is Said to Have Broken Internal Rules on Drug Ads
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google allowed rogue online pharmacies to advertise on its site in violation of its own advertising policies, according to one of the companies subpoenaed in the federal investigation of Google’s drug ad sales.

text: Death panels notwithstanding, Grandpa gets to live a little longer.

text: Looking for little ways to help endangered species?

headline: For a Violinist, Success Means a New Low Point
text: SINCE Pythagoras, musicians and scientists have known (or thought they knew) that the lowest pitch a string stretched taut can produce — the fundamental — is the pitch it produces when vibrating freely. “Stop” the string anywhere between the end points, and the vibrating section sounds at a higher pitch. Theoretically, there is no ceiling. As with dancing, the sky’s the limit, but the floor is always the floor.

headline: Now Opening | Salvor Projects
text: After about seven years of collaborating with various retailers, the men behind Salvor Projects will open their first shop this Saturday. “The store is like a lab,” the designer Ross Menuez says, having sought a space where he could continue to experiment with his designs as well as bring together everything Salvor has done in the past. Specializing in screen prints, they hope to cater to a range of customers from the Madison Avenue woman interested in a graphic tote bag to your average skateboarder looking for a printed shirt. At the shop, these mostly one-of-a-kind pieces are displayed against an austere, monotone interior that allows the clothes to be the focal point — an architectural decision that should attract many a design enthusiast.Prices range from $140 – $300. Salvor Projects, 172 Forsyth Street. Go to www.salvorprojects.com.

headline: Pilot Paternalism
text: The dearth of women television writers is well documented. But it reached a sort of negative milestone last year when Neely Swanson, a former development executive and adjunct professor at the U.S.C. School of Cinematic Arts, published her essay “Women Can’t Create and White Men Can’t Jump” at the behest of the Deadline Hollywood blogger Nikki Fink, who called 2010 the “worst network pilot season for women.” Melissa Silverstein, of the blog Women and Hollywood, was one of many to pick up the story. She compared the numbers and showed, for example, that there was an 11 percent decline in comedy pilots by women writers between 2009 and 2010.

headline: Gus Van Sant on Young Love and Young Death
text: CANNES, France — For the last decade the director Gus Van Sant, a regular presence at the Cannes Film Festival, has undergone an artistic rebirth with movies about death. In 2003 he won the festival’s top prize, the Palme d’Or, for “Elephant,” his minimalist evocation of a Columbine-like school shooting. He returned to the competition here with “Last Days” (2005), an opaque antibiopic about the final hours of a suicidal rock star modeled on Kurt Cobain, and “Paranoid Park” (2007), a coming-of-age tale whose teenage hero wrestles with his culpability in a man’s gruesome trainyard demise.

headline: Appalachian Mountain Club Rolls Out Specials for Children
text: Best known for its backcountry hut-to-hut hiking system in the White Mountains, the Appalachian Mountain Club is seeking to encourage the next generation of trekkers with new youth-oriented program called “Kid Spoken Here.”

headline: Pakistan Loses Another Journalist
text: “You better come to your senses.” This was the last threat received by the Pakistani journalist Nasrullah Afridi days before he was killed in a car bomb blast in Peshawar on May 10, his friend and colleague Sher Khan said in a telephone interview.

text: THE Brooks Stevens automotive designs of the mid-20th century, including the one-off Paxton Phoenix he created for Robert P. McCulloch, have long been recognized as fresh and distinctive departures from Detroit creations of the era. His singular perspective had many roots, but it grew at least in part from his fertile background as an innovator of a broad range of products.

text: TO Robert Paxton McCulloch, the idea of transplanting London Bridge to an Arizona desert probably seemed no more far-fetched in the 1960s than his dream, nearly two decades earlier, of mass-producing a steam-powered automobile.

headline: Slow Recovery Worsens Financial State of Medicare
text: WASHINGTON — The financial outlook for Medicare deteriorated in the last year because of the sluggish economic recovery, and the program’s hospital insurance trust fund will be exhausted in 2024, five years earlier than projected last year, the government said Friday.

Dannel P. Malloy says includes pain for everyone: record tax increases, substantial program cuts and worker givebacks in health care, pension benefits and wages.

text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan looks at the reasons wealthy families are not giving a lot of large gifts to children and grandchildren right now, even though they may miss out on the opportunity to take advantage of generous tax rules that will only last until the end of 2012.

headline: Around the Web, a Push for ‘Bridesmaids’
text: Does the future of female-driven comedy rest on on how well “Bridesmaids” fares at the box office? Writers around the Web are standing up for the film, hoping it will lead to more projects and opportunities for funny women in Hollywood. In her review, The Times’s Manohla Dargis praises the screenwriters Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, saying they “know what female moviegoers want: honest laughs with, and not solely about, women.” She added that the film offers “irrefutable proof that along with producing and starring in a hit TV series (thank you, Tina Fey), women can go aggressive laugh to aggressive-and-absurd laugh with men. All they need, beyond talent and timing, a decent director and better lines, is a chance.”

headline: In a Hyphenated Program, the Movement Takes and Holds Center Stage
text: Interdisciplinary. That’s the word that crops up in almost every contemporary choreographer’s biography or mission statement. Just about every dance troupe, it seems, is dedicated to collaboration, democracy, conversation, exchange. And so it is with Catherine Cabeen and Company, which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night and is described in the program as “a forum for investigating both the creative processes and artistic products that result when artists of different mediums collide.”

headline: A Defiant Qaddafi Says He Survived Attack
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — A day after an underground command center in his central Tripoli compound was blasted by a barrage of bunker-busting bombs, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi issued a defiant message to NATO on Friday, saying that he had survived and was now “in a place where you can’t get me.”

headline: Footnote
text: The Kitchen, the 40-year-old performance and exhibition space on West 19th Street in New York, said that its board of directors had appointed Tim Griffin as its new executive director and chief curator. Mr. Griffin, a former editor of Artforum magazine, will replace Debra Singer, who has held the job since 2004 and who announced plans in January to resign.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Delivers Yet Again
text: Fox finished atop the Thursday-night ratings as 21.6 million viewers tuned in for the “American Idol” elimination episode at 8, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The “Idol” finalist James Durbin failed to advance to next week’s round, earning fewest votes of the nearly 72 million cast, leaving Lauren Alaina, Scotty McCreery and Haley Reinhart in the finale. Fox’s “Bones” (11 million) trailed slightly behind CBS’s “CSI” (11.5 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS delivered a second-place finish over all, attracting 13.8 million at 10 for “The Mentalist” and broadcasting the sitcoms “The Big Bang Theory” (10.5 million) and “Rules of Engagement” (8 million) at 8 and 8:30. ABC was third with “Wipeout” (5.5 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (9.4 million) and “Private Practice” (7.2 million). In a distant fourth place, NBC’s comedy lineup struggled, led by “The Office” at 9 (6.2 million) and back-to-back episodes of “Parks and Recreation” at 9:30 (4.5 million) and 10 (3.6 million).

headline: Denying Links to Militants, Pakistan’s Spy Chief Denounces U.S. Before Parliament
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In an unusual, and apparently heated, closed-door session of Parliament, Pakistan’s spy chief issued a rousing denunciation of the United States on Friday for its raid that killed Osama bin Laden and denied that Pakistan maintained any links with militant groups, according to lawmakers.

headline: Rap Duo Heads Back to the Stage, Granting No Compromises (or Smiles)
text: No rap group — maybe no act in any genre — has gotten more mileage from straight talk than Mobb Deep. This Queens duo, Havoc and Prodigy, have specialized in plainspoken menace for almost two decades: almost every song is in the aggressive, threatening second person. Havoc and Prodigy can go long stretches — whole albums, it can feel like — without so much as one metaphor. Metaphors are indirect. Mobb Deep doesn’t want to confuse you.

headline: A Top SUNY Official Is Accused of Giving a No-Show Job
text: The state’s ethics commission on Friday charged the president of the research foundation of the State University of New York, John J. O’Connor, with giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno.

headline: A Christian Avenger
text: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Chicago Is Winfrey’s Town, but There Is Room for the Bulls
text: Oprah Winfrey is powerful, but she did not single-handedly reschedule the Eastern Conference finals. However, she will be borrowing the Chicago Bulls’ home court for 48 hours next week.

headline: Teenage Dreams
text: Nearly every teenager I’ve ever known likes to go to bed late and wake up late. So why does high school often start at 8 a.m.? Robert Daniel Vorona and a team of researchers decided to take advantage of a natural experiment. High schools in Virginia Beach, Virginia start 75-80 minutes earlier than high schools in the neighboring town of Chesapeake, which has similar demographics. Vorona and his team investigated whether students in Virginia Beach also had more automobile crashes. They did. Virginia Beach crash rates were significantly higher and their peak crash times were one hour earlier than peak Chesapeake crash times.  The study was published in the Journal of Clinical Sleep Medicine.

headline: Hip-Hop for Life
text: Opened on Friday nationwide.

headline: Video of Protests and Clashes in Syria
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, despite a brutal crackdown in Syria, protesters took to the streets in at least five neighborhoods in Homs, Syria’s third-largest city and a center of the two-month uprising. Activists said protests ranged in numbers from hundreds to thousands, and at least two people were killed when security forces opened fire.

headline: ‘To End All Wars’
text: Introduction: Clash of Dreams

headline: Exploring Themes of War, Both the Existential and the Concrete
text: It is hard to believe that the Oregon Symphony had never performed in Carnegie Hall until Thursday evening, when it played a vivid, often wrenching program, “Music for a Time of War,” as part of the Spring for Music festival. The orchestra was formed in 1896, and its international reputation has grown since 1987, when it began recording big, opulent works and sonic spectacular CDs for the Delos label. Many of these discs, conducted by James DePreist, the orchestra’s music director at the time (and now emeritus), remain in print and show the ensemble to be a highly polished precision instrument. Since 2003 it has been directed by Carlos Kalmar, a Uruguayan conductor who has maintained it admirably.

headline: Taking the Audience Up Close and Personal, and Beyond Skin Deep
text: RoseAnne Spradlin has a knack for placing dancers and audience members in close quarters. For a while in downtown dance, this sort of intimacy was the new black. Choreographers moved the audience closer to the stage, limited the seating and favored a deadpan display of body parts.

headline: Hot Rocks
text: The unofficial sub-theme of our Money Issue is, What now? The worldwide recession is over (fingers crossed), and the developing world has seemingly forgotten that anything untoward ever happened. Meanwhile, in the U.S. and Europe, doubt, confusion and recriminations reign. While the recovery lurches ahead, dangers loom everywhere — the deficit battle in Washington, dissension in the European Union, oil-price shocks. For this year’s Money Issue, we went out in search of narratives that reflect this mixed-up state of affairs.

headline: A Little Offbeat Humor in Cyclical Explorations
text: Attending a concert by the pianist Bruce Levingston can feel a bit like showing up at a party at which you don’t know most of your fellow guests. Don’t hold it against him. Evidence indicates that Mr. Levingston mingles with ease in an exalted social stratum. Its members presumably help to support his nonprofit organization, Premiere Commission, which has financed the creation of some 40 new works; admirably, they also attend his concerts, greeting his efforts with exuberant response.

headline: App Smart Extra: Keeping Track of Great Wines
text: I’ve probably collected more than 50 corks from bottles of wine that I tasted at restaurants and wanted to remember later. The corks were invariably chewed up by my dog or tossed in the garbage.

text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman drives the entire Audi A5/S5 family in a quest to find a combination of engine, transmission and body style that best suits the car’s handsome lines.

headline: Merck’s Hepatitis C Drug Wins F.D.A. Approval
text: The Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday the first of a new generation of hepatitis C drugs that promises to increase the cure rate while shortening the time required for treatment.

text: SHE arrived like a modern-day Cleopatra, smiling and waving down at her adoring masses from the top deck of a trolley, her blown-out tresses fluttering in the wind.

headline: Singing the Praises of Water
text: Spring vegetables are the star of this week’s Eat column on pasta primavera, but water plays a key supporting role, and in fact, the most important step of many pasta recipes is scooping up a cupful of pasta-cooking water right before you drain the pasta. Without that water, you’ll never be able to bring the pasta and sauce—in this case, cooked vegetables—together into a cohesive dish (unless you add tons and tons of olive oil, which has the drawback of weighing down a pasta dish, taste- and texture-wise).

headline: California Cuts Mean 70 Parks Will Be Closed
text: LOS ANGELES — Want to see the California Governor’s Mansion, once home to such political giants as Ronald Reagan and Earl Warren? You’d better hurry.

text: To the Editor:

headline: New Series Pits James Against an Old Foe
text: A late-game scoring burst enabled LeBron James to vanquish the Celtics and silence those detractors who had said he couldn’t close. Now that he has finally beaten the Big 3 — Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce — in a playoff series, James will turn his attention to the Chicago Bulls in the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Georgia Gives Police Added Power to Seek Out Illegal Immigrants
text: ATLANTA — Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia on Friday signed into law one of the nation’s toughest immigration measures, empowering local police officers to question certain suspects about their immigration status.

text: In this homemade video, Brittany Bochow and Matthew Brandwein tell of their "magic bus" ride.
