text: Consciousness. A foggy memory. The lack of physical evidence.

headline: Two Straight Athletes Combat Homophobia
text: Ben Cohen is a world-class English rugby star, and Hudson Taylor is a three-time college all-American wrestler. They live on opposite sides of the Atlantic Ocean. They barely know each other.

headline: For a Member of the First Black Class, a Second Chance
text: As one of its first black students in 1956, Burlyce Sherell Logan faced so much resistance at her Texas college that she dropped out. But 50 years later, she re-enrolled.

headline: F.A. Cup Final: Stoke City Is Ready for Its Close-Up
text: It was only a matter of moments after Kenwyne Jones had put Stoke City ahead against Arsenal on Sunday that the chant began to ring out around the Britannia Stadium. It was immediately obvious what was being said and who it was being aimed at:

headline: Friends Help Hold Back the Flood
text: A community of friends helped Russell Petty build a levee around his home in DeValls Bluff, Ark., and saved it from the flooding White River.

headline: Neighbors 1, the Elements 0 (for Now)
text: DeVALLS BLUFF, Ark. — Muddy children stood in a human chain, passing sandbags to others who were two, three or four times their age. One volunteer was an exchange student from the Czech Republic. One man was in his 70s. Coolers of food, drinks and ice appeared, and no one knew where they had come from.

headline: Taste of China Not as Far East: Egyptian Wing at the Met
text: There was a pagoda in the Egyptian wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night, at least at first glance. The sandstone Temple of Dendur was bathed in red light, as several hundred people — mostly Chinese-Americans — gathered to celebrate connections between China and the United States. At times, the shadows cast on the temple’s lintel conjured the up-ticked eaves of Asian architecture.

headline: Pornography Is Found in Bin Laden Compound Files, U.S. Officials Say
text: WASHINGTON — The enormous cache of computer files taken from Osama bin Laden’s compound contained a considerable quantity of pornographic videos, American officials said on Friday, adding a discordant note to the public image of the Islamist militant who long denounced the West for its lax sexual mores.

headline: Cities Nationwide Heighten Vigilance on Terror
text: MIAMI — In large and midsize cities across the country, police chiefs and domestic security officials say they have drastically increased counterterrorism operations under the assumption that a “lone wolf” or a small group of terrorists will try to strike on American soil to avenge the killing of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Promoting Peace, Nobel Laureates Square Off, Politely
text: NEWARK — Of the many rare scenes provided here on Friday by renowned advocates of enlightenment and nonviolence, the rarest may have been a pair of Nobel Peace Prize winners getting about as close as such people ever get to actual confrontation.

headline: Report From a Pashtun Teen: Cricket, Diplomacy and Hope
text: Our Pashtun teenage blogger, Sher Bano, wrote this piece late last month on how the Cricket World Cup semi-final match between India and Pakistan really brought the country together and gave Pakistanis hope and something to cheer for. As we were getting ready to post it, the news broke that Osama bin Laden had been killed in Abbottabad. We decided not to run the piece until things calmed down. In the meantime, Sher emailed us her reactions to the killing, and they perhaps offer a window into the thinking of some young Pakistanis. This is some of what she said:

headline: A College Degree, 55 Years and an Era in the Making
text: DENTON, Tex. — As she prepares for her commencement at the University of North Texas here on Saturday, Burlyce Sherrell Logan can still hear the words the institution’s president spoke at her freshman welcoming ceremony.

headline: A True Finnish Spring
text: Helsinki, Finland

headline: An Ailing Killebrew Simply Says Farewell
text: Harmon Killebrew’s modest farewell on Friday — in which the slugger of 573 home runs said his battle against esophageal cancer had come to an end — evoked the goodbyes made by former President Ronald Reagan as he faced Alzheimer’s disease and Charlton Heston as he described symptoms consistent with Alzheimer’s.

headline: Areas Will Be Flooded to Protect Louisiana Cities
text: MORGAN CITY, La. — To relieve the pressure bearing down on the levees brought by a Mississippi River that has swollen to epic proportions, the Army Corps of Engineers will open the Morganza spillway, a gated structure north of Baton Rouge that would divert water from the river to protect New Orleans and other areas downriver by flooding a large area in southern Louisiana.

headline: May Madness in N.H.L. Playoffs: Collapse and Advance
text: Of the four teams left in these Stanley Cup playoffs, three have survived near-disastrous collapses.

headline: Recovery Seen in Rising Use of Credit Cards
text: Ever since the United States emerged from the recession, economists have been watching for signs that Americans are spending again.

headline: Volunteers and Victims
text: Houston

headline: Facebook, Foe of Anonymity, Is Forced to Explain a Secret
text: Facebook, it seems, doesn’t always practice what it preaches.

headline: Sabbatini Puts Possible Suspension Aside and Vies for Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — While controversy continued to swirl around him, Rory Sabbatini played himself into contention for a second consecutive week. Sabbatini, who finished third in the Wells Fargo Championship, carded a one-under-par 71 Friday and is four strokes off the lead at the halfway point of the Players Championship.

headline: Presidential Primary Book Club
text: Newt! Newt! Newt!

headline: With Low Profile, Rays Rise to Top
text: Contrary to the popular belief that the rest of baseball devoutly observes the high, holy occasions when the Yankees play the Red Sox, a full slate of games was scheduled for Friday night. That included one in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the defending American League East division champion and leading Rays were hosting the Orioles.

headline: Libyan Immigrants Flock to Italy
text: More than 9,000 people have arrived in Lampedusa, Italy, from Libya since its unrest began.

headline: Libyan Immigrants Becoming Italian Immigrants
text: LAMPEDUSA, Italy — The fishing boats from Tripoli began arriving in the clear light of morning and continued well into the day on Friday, unloading more than 1,000 immigrants to this tiny Sicilian island. Most who made the rough crossing were men in their 20s and 30s, but there were also dozens of women, some pregnant, and several babies, whose sharp cries pierced the fresh sea air.

headline: Bernard Greenhouse, Acclaimed Cellist, Dies at 95
text: Bernard Greenhouse, an internationally acclaimed cellist and a founding member of the Beaux Arts Trio, died on Friday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 95.

headline: Pakistan After Bin Laden
text: Like most Americans, we have long despaired at the cynicism of Pakistan’s leaders, who accept American “counterterrorist” aid while also sheltering and enabling some of the worst anti-American extremists. But we never imagined that Osama bin Laden would be found hiding in plain sight, a stone’s throw from Pakistan’s leading military academy and an hour’s drive from Islamabad. Pakistan’s behavior since then has only added to the outrage.

headline: Jeff Gralnick, Power in News at 3 TV Networks, Dies at 72
text: Jeff Gralnick, a blunt, gravel-voiced television news executive who got his start in the days of the 15-minute, black-and-white evening newscast and went on to play leading roles in the news divisions of three major broadcast networks, died on Monday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 72.

headline: Health Insurers Making Record Profits as Many Postpone Care
text: The nation’s major health insurers are barreling into a third year of record profits, enriched in recent months by a lingering recessionary mind-set among Americans who are postponing or forgoing medical care.

headline: Millrose Games Will Move Uptown
text: The Millrose Games will be broken into two sessions and held on a Saturday when the meet moves next year to the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

headline: One Year and Many Billions Later
text: Last May’s $140 billion European bailout was supposed to ease Greece’s return to private financial markets. But it demanded too much too soon in the way of growth-killing austerity. And it insisted that Greece keep paying its lenders in full and on time.

headline: Reach Sambath, Tribunal Spokesman in Cambodia, Dies at 47
text: Reach Sambath, who survived the Khmer Rouge killing fields as an orphan and rose through journalism and teaching to become the spokesman for a tribunal in Cambodia that is trying the leaders of the Khmer Rouge, died on Wednesday. He was 47.

headline: Toms Skips the Pitfalls of T.P.C. Sawgrass and Grabs the Lead
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — It has been awhile since David Toms last won a PGA Tour event, but in the past few weeks he has looked more and more like someone who remembers just how he won a dozen of them before his 40th birthday.

headline: The Ensign Investigation, to Be Continued
text: The Senate Ethics Committee acted responsibly in referring the sordid case of former Senator John Ensign to federal authorities for possible criminal violations. Rather than let the matter fade with the Nevada Republican’s hurried resignation before his scheduled deposition, the panel stressed that there was “substantial credible evidence” he violated the law.

headline: In Shift, Ads Try to Entice Over-55 Set
text: After 40 years of catering to younger consumers, advertisers and media executives are coming to a different realization: older people aren’t so bad, after all.

headline: U.S. Scrutinized Ensign, but Senate Dug Deeper
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Department officials investigating Senator John Ensign spent many hours last year in a Las Vegas office interviewing his ex-aide, Douglas Hampton, as they scrutinized e-mails, handwritten notes and the aide’s detailed recollections about payoffs, secret lobbying and hush money over a disastrous affair.

headline: From a Footnote in American Baseball to a Record-Breaker in Japan
text: GINOZA, Japan — Few foreigners are likely to learn the word akage no matter how long they play baseball in Japan, but Matt Murton will hear it a lot in just his second season here. Adoring fans use the word to describe the top of his crown — redhead — an unusual sight in Japan.

headline: Lawrence Johnson, Who Helped Ease Boats Into Water, Dies at 97
text: Lawrence N. Johnson, the founder of a boat trailer company who designed a trailer that made launching a boat almost as easy as parking a station wagon, died on May 6. He was 97 and lived in Spokane, Wash.

headline: Chicago Ordered to Hire 111 Black Firefighters
text: CHICAGO — The City of Chicago must hire 111 black firefighter applicants who were passed over for jobs years ago and pay tens of millions of dollars in damages to about 6,000 other black candidates under a ruling issued on Friday by a federal appeals court.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Donors to G.O.P. Are Backing Gay Marriage Push
text: As gay rights advocates intensify their campaign to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, the bulk of their money is coming from an unexpected source: a group of conservative financiers and wealthy donors to the Republican Party, most of whom are known for bankrolling right-leaning candidates and causes.

headline: H.I.V. S O S
text: Treatment as prevention.

headline: Footnote in Majors, Sensation in Japan
text: GINOZA, Japan — Few foreigners are likely to learn the word akage no matter how long they play baseball in Japan, but Matt Murton will hear it a lot in just his second season here. Adoring fans use the word to describe the top of his crown — redhead — an unusual sight in Japan.

headline: Debate Over Intelligent Design Ensnares a Journal
text: According to one cynical view, academic disputes are so vicious only because the stakes are so low. Yet as the editors of Synthese, a leading philosophy journal, can tell you, what they publish matters: in debates over Christianity, the teaching of evolution, and American politics.

headline: Saturday: Home to One and a Half Billion People
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s tough to pinpoint exactly where I crashed and burned on this one, because normally I like to fancy myself on Mike Nothnagel’s wavelength. His puzzles usually fall fairly readily for me, and I always enjoy them. This one was highly enjoyable once I got a toehold in the puzzle.

headline: Family Quarrel Imperils a Labor Hero’s Legacy
text: KEENE, Calif. — A series of dirt roads in this tiny Central Valley town leads to a warren of homes and offices that has been, for decades, the headquarters of the United Farm Workers union. This is where Cesar Chavez, the labor and civil rights leader, carved out a retreat and raised his family. In a former tuberculosis sanatorium, the Chavez children learned the lessons of the union and listened to endless conversations about the backbreaking work in the nearby fields.

headline: Victory Lap for Beltran in Houston
text: HOUSTON — In the mind of the typical Houston Astros fan, it must seem fitting that Carlos Beltran came back to play here a day after having a career game.

headline: The Andy
text: Uptown, art lovers were bidding as much as $38.4 million this week for Andy Warhol’s early paintings. Downtown, where Mr. Warhol reigned for years as a pop artist-provocateur, things were considerably different.

headline: For a Gala Concert, 90 Years of Songs
text: MARVIN HAMLISCH has won multiple Grammys, Oscars and Emmys, along with a Tony and many other awards. Despite all those accolades, however, it does not take much to make the 66-year-old composer feel special, he said in a recent phone interview.

headline: Captive Soldiers Tell of Discord in Libyan Army
text: MISURATA, Libya — The army and militias of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who for more than two months have fought rebels seeking to overthrow the Libyan leader, are undermined by self-serving officers, strained logistics and units hastily reinforced with untrained cadets, according to captured soldiers from their ranks.

headline: Teacher Reviews Will Put More Focus on State Tests
text: Responding to criticism from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and others, state education officials on Friday revised their plans for evaluating teachers so that up to 40 percent of their annual reviews could be based on students’ scores on state standardized tests.

headline: Ex-Senator Gets 21-Month Prison Term in Tax Evasion Case
text: WHITE PLAINS — A former state senator was sentenced in federal district court here on Friday to 21 months in prison and three years of supervised release after pleading guilty last year to obstruction of justice and tax evasion.

headline: Bloggingheads:  Leave Afghanistan?
text: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss Bin Laden and the war in Afghanistan.

headline: Huge Protests in Yemen as Talks Drag On
text: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into the streets of Yemen’s capital, Sana, and cities across the country on Friday, keeping alive their efforts to drive President Ali Abdullah Saleh from office, according to activists and news reports from Yemen.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Microsoft’s purchase of Skype, Music Beta from Google, guilty verdict for Raj Rajaratnam, G.M. investments and more.

headline: It’s Continental, but Not Old-Fashioned
text: EVERYTHING is new at Vitae, which has taken the place of Abel Conklin’s, a 25-year veteran in an 1841 building in Huntington Village. In addition to the new name, the restaurant, which opened in March, has a new owner, chef and look.

headline: Wölffer Wins Merlot Contest
text: Like regional vintners’ organizations nationwide, the Long Island Merlot Alliance seeks evidence that its wines are the peers of better-known ones elsewhere.

headline: Vulnerability Shows in a Longtime Rivalry
text: The fan in the right-field seats at Yankee Stadium who caught Boston third baseman Kevin Youkilis’s home run ball in the seventh inning Friday night heaved it onto the field, where a ball boy scooped it up and hurriedly took it away, as if the whole thing never happened.

headline: Violence Suffocated a Father’s Poetry, but Not His Voice
text: MEXICO CITY

headline: Buffet or à la Carte, and Spicy or Not
text: THE many storefront restaurants on Broadway near its intersection with Tarrytown’s busy Main Street, with its popular Tarrytown Music Hall, offer a panoply of dining choices for just about any occasion or appetite. The selections are international: Asian, Italian, Portuguese, Greek, new and old American, pizza and hot dogs.

headline: Whites That Go With Spring
text: Remember when white wine by the glass came in one flavor, chardonnay? As diners have become more knowledgeable about food, restaurants and wine shops have kept pace, with chardonnay giving ground to albarino and aligoté, grüner veltliner and gewürztraminer, viognier and verdicchio. Consumers have backed off cheap, over-oaked chardonnays and embraced outlier varietals that offer better quality for the money.

headline: Corrections
Germany: Ex-Nazi Guard Released Pending Appeals
text: John Demjanjuk, a former concentration camp guard who was convicted Thursday in what may have been one of the last Nazi war crimes trials, was released from a Munich prison on Friday pending the outcome of his appeals. Mr. Demjanjuk, 91, who is ill and stateless, was not considered a flight risk, but the authorities had trouble finding a nursing home to accept him. He will remain free while he appeals his conviction and five-year sentence for taking part in the killing of 28,000 Jews as a guard at the Sobibor concentration camp in Nazi-occupied Poland. A court spokeswoman said the appeals could take 18 months to two years.

headline: Mets Have Another Powerful Night, but This Time Others Contribute
text: HOUSTON — Carlos Beltran had a rather modest night. One day after bashing three home runs, all Beltran could muster Friday was a double. But on a night of breakouts and comebacks, the Mets still got their three home runs anyway.

headline: Photo Replay: May 13
text: A look at the day in sports, from the court to the links.

headline: China: Credit Cooperative is Firebombed
text: A former worker at a rural credit cooperative in northwest China lighted a bottle full of gasoline and threw it into a meeting of his former colleagues on Friday morning, injuring 49 people, 19 of them seriously, the Chinese government said in a statement. The suspect was identified as Yang Xianwen, who fled after starting the fire about 8:30 a.m., the statement said. He was captured by the police at 5 p.m. Mr. Yang had been fired from the cooperative for embezzling public funds, the statement said, without explaining whether the money had belonged to the cooperative or another public entity. The incident occurred in Wuwei City in Gansu Province.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Forging and Breaking Ties
text: Before we get into breaking down the most recent episode of “Friday Night Lights,” I want to address a question that came up in the comments section last week about what was going on with T.M.U.’s back-channel method of aiming to recruit Vince.

headline: France Chides Britain for Support of Parliament Move
text: France’s European affairs minister scolded the British government for an “unfriendly and aggressive gesture” on Friday, after Prime Minister David Cameron and his deputy, Nick Clegg, backed a move to phase out the French city of Strasbourg as the seat of the European Parliament. In March, European legislators approved a bill to reduce time spent by the Parliament at the official chamber in Strasbourg, and allow for more time at the administrative offices in Brussels, where they conduct most of their business. The French minister, Laurent Wauquiez, said he told his British counterpart, David Lidington, that European institutions should reside in a “plurality” of locations, as doing so “reflects the diversity of the European Union.” Mr. Wauquiez said that the bill ran contrary to European treaties, and that France would contest it before the European Court of Justice.

headline: Uganda: Deadly Ebola Virus Confirmed Near Capital
text: Preliminary tests have identified a case of hemorrhagic fever caused by the rare and deadly Ebola virus in central Uganda, a medical official said Friday. A young girl who died in a hospital in the town of Bombo, about 25 miles from the capital, Kampala, tested positive for the virus, said Dr. Nelson Mugisha, a member of the medical team working on the case. He said the United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had  helped the government with the initial diagnosis. The virus can lead to large outbreaks with high death rates.

headline: Rangers Player Is Found Dead in His Home
text: Derek Boogaard, a 28-year-old Ranger regarded as one of the toughest fighters in the N.H.L., was found dead on Friday, the team announced.

headline: Two Are Dead After a Fire in Brooklyn
text: Two people were killed on Friday night when a fast-moving fire engulfed the top floor of a building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the authorities said.

headline: Japanese Worker’s Death Not Linked to Radiation
text: TOKYO — A worker at Japan’s crippled nuclear plant died Saturday of causes that appeared to be unrelated to radiation, the plant’s operator said.

headline: Remembering Ron Springs, the Football Player
text: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Ron Springs, who died Thursday, was known  for raising awareness about organ donations. But he was quite a football player as well.

headline: Red Bulls’ Tim Ream Answers Your Questions
text: The second-year defender did his homework during the club’s trip to Montreal for an exhibition game on Wednesday, and here are his answers to questions from readers of the Goal blog:

text: Today’s Times

headline: Obama Shifts to Speed Oil and Gas Drilling in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, facing voter anger over high gasoline prices and complaints from Republicans and business leaders that his policies are restricting the development of domestic energy resources, announced Saturday that he was taking several steps to speed oil and gas drilling on public lands and waters.

headline: Sentence of the Week
text: So many good sentences this week — a springtime burst of phrasal fecundity:

headline: Farming Shrimp With the Planet in Mind
text: 7:41 a.m. | Updated Here’s a shout-out to the amazing team of Pace University graduate and undergraduate students who, led by  professor Maria Luskay (with my assistance), just completed the short documentary “Linda Thornton: Seeking Sustainability, One Shrimp at a Time.” I hope you’ll give it a look and offer your reaction.

headline: March of the Hooligans
text: Me on currency wars and all that, in the magazine.

headline: Monetarist Pathos
text: I feel David Beckworth’s pain. Really, I do.

headline: Old Man River
text: Whee! They’re letting the Mississippi spill into the Atchafalaya.

headline: Urban Forager | Ramp Season
text: In recent weeks, while traversing the wet, wooded areas of friends’ backyards in Greenwich, Conn., and Westchester County, I discovered lush carpets of two-leaved plants under the dappled light of deciduous trees. Crouching down low among last year’s foliage, I found that while the stems of the plants in Greenwich were white and the ones in Westchester were reddish, the air in both areas was filled with the distinctive fragrance of onions. Ramps. I quickly considered the culinary possibilities — savory ramp pie, scrambled eggs with ramps, ramps with morels.

headline: Racing’s Drug Problem: More Complicated Than It Looks
text: Steve Zorn is racing manager of Castle Village Farm thoroughbred partnerships, and a director of the New York Thoroughbred Horsemen’s Association and the Backstretch Employees Service Team. He writes the Business of Racing blog.

headline: Basic Black for U.S. Women
text: The United States women’s national team will be wearing its new all black uniforms in Saturday’s exhibition match against Japan.

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Weekend Plans? World to End
text: The last time he predicted the world would end (on Sept. 6, 1994, to be specific) his research was flawed, Harold Camping acknowledges. Not this time, he says. Mr. Camping, a retired civil engineer and the leader of Family Radio Worldwide, an independent Christian ministry, says he is convinced, based on a close reading of the Bible, that the end will begin on Saturday, heralded by huge earthquakes. His group has erected billboards across the country urging people to repent. Volunteers have traveled the country and the world spreading the same message. One of them, Lincoln Ropp, a medical student in Florida, went to Bulgaria. “We definitely see a lot of scoffing and mocking,” Mr. Ropp told the South Florida Sun-Sentinel. “But really, we take this as expected. Jesus said when you speak the truth, you’ll be hated.”

headline: As Baghdad Erupts in Riot of Color, Calls to Tone It Down
text: BAGHDAD — In downtown Baghdad, a police headquarters has been painted two shades of purple: lilac and grape. The central bank, a staid building in many countries, is coated in bright red candy cane stripes.

headline: Prime Number
text: 1: The estimated number of rapes per minute, on average, of women in Congo, which United Nations officials have called the epicenter of sexual assault as a weapon of war.

headline: Tensions Rise as Palestinians Mourn Israel’s Founding
text: JERUSALEM — Tensions were high in East Jerusalem on Saturday as hundreds of Palestinians buried a 17-year-old demonstrator and preparations were under way for rallies on Sunday to mark the founding of Israel 63 years ago, an event that Palestinians call the “nakba,” Arabic for catastrophe.

headline: Back Then: 1955
text: As any fan of Dick Tracy video wristwatches knows, the idea of video calling long predates Skype, the pioneer in Internet phone-calling to be acquired by Microsoft in an $8.5 billion deal announced last week. Here is how The  Times covered an early videophone call between the mayors of San Francisco and Palo Alto, Calif., at a public demonstration in 1955: "Spokesmen predicted that the elaborate gadget, combining the telephone in the same panel with a maze of television tubes, would have an important place in American life ’probably in the 1960s.’ "

headline: Fighting Words
text: Last week, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and would-be Republican presidential candidate, sought to differentiate the health insurance plan he signed from President Obama’s.

headline: A Mexican Soccer Symbol Adjusts to the U.S.
text: Rafael Marquez does not spend much time in the kitchen, except when he is out sampling the restaurants of New York.

headline: Teeing Up a Duffer Debate
text: MIAMI — The tiny red arrow on the irregularly dimpled golf ball offers the slice-prone hacker an irresistible pledge: Point the ball that way and, yes, it will go that way.

headline: The Morning Line: Figuring Out Animal Kingdom
text: There is considerable news today in thoroughbred racing, and not all of it concerns the Preakness.

headline: Recent Inflation History
text: During the Bush years, I used to get triumphant letters from conservatives saying things like, “You say Bush’s policies are bad, but the economy added 110,000 jobs last month” — as if that was a big number; they had no idea what good job creation looks like.

headline: Some Fans in Canada See Vancouver as Foreign
text: If you are American, you might think that the Vancouver Canucks are now Canada’s team because they are the last Canada-based club standing among the final four in the Stanley Cup playoffs. Well, think again.

headline: For Second Time in 3 Days, NATO Raid Kills Afghan Child
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in three days, a night raid in eastern Afghanistan by NATO forces resulted in the death of a child, setting off protests on Saturday that turned violent and ended in the death of a second boy.

headline: Bin Laden’s Family Tree
text: Bin Laden had six marriages and at least 20 children over the course of 37 years. Here’s a look at the family tree of a terrorist.

headline: Bin Laden as Patriarch
text: WASHINGTON — When a man stalks the world as a mass killer, it distracts from the ordinary interest we might otherwise take in the mundane details of his life. And so it was with Osama bin Laden.

headline: A Call From Within for the N.C.A.A. to Act Decisively Against Cheating
text: RICHMOND, Va. — There are few more optimistic places in college athletics right now than Virginia Commonwealth University. The campus hosted raucous impromptu street parties after its men’s basketball team ambushed the Final Four, blitzing brackets and conventional wisdom with its charmed run.

headline: Variety: A Headbanging Cryptic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — This has been a fun but tough week for me, puzzlewise. Yesterday I got Nothnageled, the day before that I was Naticked. Today, I am very grateful that I got my business degree in Strategic Guessing*, because that’s precisely how I was able to get through this cryptic. That, and walking away from it once in a while.

headline: Hawk, Man and Webcam
text: What could be rarer, in this city where the works of man blot out earth and sky alike and what wilderness persists seems compromised and debased, than a chance to bear close witness to a sacred spectacle of nature: a majestic hawk and her mate, hatching and raising a family.

headline: Crawford Struggles at Plate and With Boston Spotlight
text: By the time Carl Crawford emerged from the trainer’s room late Friday, the Boston locker room had all but cleared out. Crawford’s Red Sox had defeated the Yankees, 5-4, to take the opener of a three-game series at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Norse Fantasy
text: Jake Halpern has an exuberant curiosity about people in their natural habitats; I think of him as a kind of maestro of attentively hanging out (for instance here and here). So when we sent him to Iceland to report on that country’s small steps toward economic recovery, we knew we’d get a great tale about people. We did. And we got a bonus. Even before he’d even left Iceland, Jake sent an e-mail containing another, more personal tale (see what I mean about exuberant?), this one about scalding rivers running through an icy landscape, a snowstorm and what’s best left to the imagination.

headline: Mets Closer Is Smiling Through the Pain
text: HOUSTON — Of all the changes that have taken place with the Mets since last year’s tumultuous season, perhaps the most striking has been the apparent transformation of Francisco Rodriguez.

headline: In East, Intrigue in Series With Intersecting Story Lines
text: Nearly three decades ago, the Lakers pitched their training camp tent at the College of the Desert in Palm Desert, a couple of hours east of Los Angeles on Interstate 10. Every once in a while, Pat Riley, on his way to coaching the Lakers to three championships, ran into the college’s men’s basketball coach, Gar Forman.

headline: Whiff of Scandal Wafts Over 1918 World Series
text: More than any other American sport, baseball has an established historical footprint, and among its significant early events is the fixing of the 1919 World Series by gamblers and the Chicago White Sox, a team forever labeled the Black Sox. It is the only recognized gambling scandal to tarnish a World Series.

headline: Assault in Border Town Sends Syrians Into Lebanon
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hundreds of Syrians fled into Lebanon on Saturday after Syrian Army troops assaulted a border town, killing at least three people and arresting hundreds in the latest phase of a ferocious crackdown on the two-month uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Damon Sharpens Focus, With Eye on 3,000 Hits
text: CLEVELAND — Reverse the letters on the back of Johnny Damon’s jersey, and they spell nomad. That is what Damon has become as he bounces around the American League, from the Yankees in 2009 to the Detroit Tigers last season to the Tampa Bay Rays now.

headline: Rich and Sort of Rich
text: How did $250,000 become the magic number?

headline: Alaska’s Ferries Go Farther North
text: Passengers from the lower 48 traveling to Alaska using its ferry system will be able to go farther north than before with new service that deposits them 60 miles south of Anchorage.

headline: Undrafted Are Trapped in Lockout Netherworld
text: On the day the N.F.L. lockout entered its third month, while players and owners argued in a Minneapolis court over billions of dollars in television revenue, Dan DePalma was exerting his sliver of control over football on a high school field in Hoboken, N.J., last week.

headline: Louisiana Spillway Opened to Relieve Flooding
text: MORGANZA, La. — After declaring that “public safety is our No. 1 priority,” officials from the Army Corps of Engineers opened the Morganza spillway, sending water from the engorged Mississippi River rushing into the pastures and cropland here to forestall potentially catastrophic damage farther downstream.

headline: Chicago Trial May Unmask Pakistan’s Links to Militants
text: WASHINGTON — Two years before terrorists struck the Indian port city of Mumbai, a Pakistani-American man named David Coleman Headley began laying the groundwork for the attack, financed, he claims, by $25,000 from an officer in Pakistan’s powerful intelligence service.

headline: Rodman, Heading to Hall of Fame, Is Already Back on ‘A’ List
text: Dennis Rodman sat in a Midtown hotel lobby Wednesday, a few hours before kicking off a monthlong, multicity celebration of his 50th birthday at a Manhattan strip club. He pointed to each of his five rings.

headline: ‘Sex on Wheels’? Now It’s ‘Room for Groceries,’ Too
text: MARANELLO, Italy

headline: A Coach With a ‘Situation’ for Almost Any Occasion
text: Phil Jackson ambled away last Sunday with a contented half-grin and a creaky gait, taking his 11 championships, Zen musings, literary references, book-giving habits and beloved triangle offense with him.

headline: As Rift Deepens, Kerry Has a Warning for Pakistan
text: WASHINGTON — The United States and Pakistan are veering toward a deeper clash, with Pakistan’s Parliament demanding a permanent halt to all drone strikes just as the most senior American official since the killing of Osama bin Laden is to arrive with a stern message that the country has only months to show it is committed to rooting out Al Qaeda and associated groups.

headline: The Buyers Are Back at Cannes
text: CANNES, France— The success of independent films like “Black Swan” and “The King’s Speech” appears to have emboldened buyers here at the 2011 edition of the Cannes Film Festival. There’s been a bull market for acquisitions in the early days of the festival, even among American companies, which, battered by the financial downturn and other film industry woes, have largely sat on the sidelines in recent years, as The Hollywood Reporter noted.

headline: A Panorama of the World Trade Center Site
text: A view of the south memorial pool at ground zero with 4 World Trade Center rising above newly planted white oak trees and 1 World Trade Center beyond the pool. The temporary wooden barrier is where the names of the victims of 9/11 will be placed. As part of the design, a system is being installed that will keep the temperature of the bronze name panels constant regardless of the weather, according to a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: A Long Time Coming for a Mariners Outfielder
text: When the Seattle Mariners cut the troubled Milton Bradley last week, they opened a spot for a player with a deep appreciation of his chance. Outfielder Mike Wilson, who spent 10 seasons in the team’s farm system, earned his first promotion to the majors.

headline: Marital Matters and the 2012 Election
text: WASHINGTON — Cheri Daniels, whose aversion to politics appears to be the reason her husband, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana, is dithering about running for president, had no shortage of stories during her much-hyped speech in Indianapolis last week. There was the one about her driving a dump truck, the one about how she attended a senior citizen’s prom, about how she took a prize for cow milking at the state fair.

headline: Foods With Benefits, or So They Say
text: START in Aisle 2, third shelf from the bottom: here is grape juice for your heart. Over to Aisle 4: there are frozen carrots for your eyes.

headline: Comparisons in Chief
text: WASHINGTON — As a candidate in 2008, Barack Obama pointedly noted that he “doesn’t look like all the presidents on the dollar bills.”

headline: A Low Bid for Fixing a Big Mess
text: SO the feds finally got one: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund tycoon, is going down for insider trading.

headline: Note to Staff: We’re a Team, Not a Family
text: This interview with  Linda Lausell Bryant, executive director of Inwood House in New York, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Inwood House focuses on teenagers’ health issues.

headline: A Curve Isn’t the Cure
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Third Factor on the Economy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Innovation, Gliding Across the Generations
text: DOES inventiveness run in families? Is there a gene that awakens the entrepreneurial urge? A look at the Smith family offers at least anecdotal evidence that the answer is yes.

headline: When It Comes to Inbox Advertising, Less Is Still More
text: WHEN Google introduced Gmail seven years ago, it didn’t copy Yahoo Mail or Microsoft’s Hotmail. Gmail was built for distraction-free speed. The ads were text-only, and so unobtrusive that you could forget they were even there.

headline: Why Worry? It’s Good for You
text: THE late Amos Tversky, a Stanford psychologist and a founding father of behavioral economics, used to say, “My colleagues, they study artificial intelligence; me, I study natural stupidity.”

headline: Suddenly, Gold Isn’t Looking So Solid
text: A  RICH man carrying a heavy bag of gold coins set sail on a voyage, but his ship ran into stormy weather. Before it capsized, he attached the bag of gold to his waist and jumped overboard. He sank with his fortune, never to be seen again.

headline: Behind the Greening of Wal-Mart
text: GIVEN our daily struggles with information overload, I suppose it’s inevitable that there will always be major, perhaps global, issues that some of us simply don’t follow. Bosnia was like that for me. As serious as I knew the situation was, it went on for so long that I finally just gave up.

headline: When Fear Stifles Initiative
text: CALL it trickle-down anxiety. Accustomed to hearing about budget cuts and layoffs from on high, employees at every level are becoming risk-averse. Dedicated, ambitious workers tell me they are so afraid of making a mistake that they feel it’s safer for their careers to avoid innovation and initiative. Managers need to realize that this paralysis threatens their companies’ health.

headline: Head, Talking
text: From Cvltvre Made Stupid.

headline: Belarus Opposition Leader Gets a Five-Year Sentence
text: MOSCOW — Belarus sentenced a leading opponent of the country’s authoritarian president to five years in prison on Saturday for organizing a large antigovernment protest. The sentence is the harshest punishment yet in a far-reaching crackdown that shows little sign of abating.

headline: Still Making the Cool Stuff
text: I  WAS focused on building things from an early age. When I was about 3, our toilet broke and my mother was ready to call the plumber. I told her I would fix it and asked her to get my Richard Scarry book “How Things Work in Busytown.” Between the picture of a toilet, and the text she read to me explaining how the parts worked, I fixed it.

headline: Florida Men Accused of Aiding Pakistani Taliban
text: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. on Saturday arrested three Pakistani-Americans, including father and son imams from South Florida mosques, charging them with providing financing and other material support to the Pakistani Taliban.

headline: Tunica Casinos Flooded
text: Rain falls in Tunica's town center, but a levee protects it from river flooding.

headline: Tunica Casinos Flooded
text: Kate Thomas, a resident of Tunica, Miss., discusses the impact of flooding in the area.

headline: Tunica Casinos Flooded
text: Qwondra Smith, a Tunica casino worker, discusses the impact of flooding there.

headline: Tunica Casinos Flooded
text: Mayor Chuck Cariker discusses the impact of flooding in Tunica.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: 30 Seconds With Mia Hamm
text: Mia Hamm is soccer’s leading international scorer in history, man or woman, with 158 goals. She was a leader on the United States team that won the inaugural Women’s World Cup in 1991, the 1999 Cup, and Olympic gold medals in 1996 and 2004. Now 39, Hamm, who has 4-year-old twin girls with her husband, the former baseball player Nomar Garciaparra, took part in ESPN the Weekend at Walt Disney World in Florida.

headline: Mets’ Beltran Sits Out Because of Eye Irritation
text: HOUSTON — Carlos Beltran was a late scratch from the lineup today after he woke up with swelling in his right eye. Fernando Martinez, who homered Friday night against the Houston Astros in the Mets’ 6-4 victory, was placed in right field, batting eighth.

headline: Struggling Franchises Plot Their Next Moves in an Uncertain Climate
text: In the midst of one of the most exciting Stanley Cup playoffs in memory, some troubled N.H.L. franchises made news last week.

headline: Seeing Beauty in the Rust Belt
text: Amid the decline of the American steel industry, years of disuse have transformed components of the Bethlehem Steel plant in Bethlehem, Pa., in striking ways.

headline: News Corp. Will Disclose Its Political Donations
text: Beginning this summer, the News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, will announce each year all the political contributions it has made.

headline: West Provides Game 7 Drama
text: This N.B.A. postseason has featured the two-time defending champion Los Angeles Lakers’ being swept away, the verification of the Miami Heat conglomerate in the vanquishing of the Boston Celtics, and an unlikely upstart in the Memphis Grizzlies, who were involved in a triple-overtime game against the Oklahoma City Thunder.

headline: TMX Group Gets Takeover Bid
text: OTTAWA — The parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange said on Saturday that it had received an unsolicited takeover bid from several Canadian banks and pension funds.

headline: In Flooded Tunica, the Casinos Are Idle but Concerns Are Nonstop
text: TUNICA, Miss. — Like countless communities up and down the Mississippi River, life these days in this town of 1100, and its surrounding countryside, depends on which side of the levee you’re on. The town center, shielded from the river, looks nothing more than a bit bedraggled, while on the other side, flood waters have invaded homes, displaced hundreds and submerged crop fields.

headline: Brewery With a British Flavor
text: To an out-of-towner, Oxford’s narrow, winding Hurley Road holds a couple of surprises. The first is its proximity to an airport. The second, just off the slightly overgrown country lane in a modern industrial park, is Cavalry Brewing, which began producing beer last July.

headline: A Steakhouse With Quite a View
text: THERE will always be a place for a traditional New England-style steakhouse serving plain, sturdy cuisine. Particularly if it sits on an exquisite piece of Connecticut real estate. Brushmill by the Waterfall in Chester is such a destination.

headline: Mired in Drought, García Tries to Stay Positive
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — A shot facing Sergio García last week had a high degree of difficulty. It required timing, finesse, concentration and extreme accuracy, and García was hyperfocused on pulling it off.

headline: Eating Out Gets Easier for Celiac Patients
text: CLIFTON, N.J.

headline: Erasing the Face of History
text: Chapel Hill, N.C.

headline: Verlander Nearing Elite Company
text: The Tigers’ Justin Verlander became the 30th pitcher to throw multiple no-hitters when he blanked the Toronto Blue Jays last Sunday. The first pitcher to throw a no-hitter twice actually threw three gems in a brief career in the 1880s.

headline: Corsets, Cleavage, Fishnets
text: HOLLYWOOD

headline: Who Benefits If Huckabee Doesn’t Run?
text: I’m not going to speculate on what decision Mike Huckabee will make when he provides “clarity” tonight on his Fox News program about whether or not he will run for president.

headline: Republicans Optimistic About Retaking Senate
text: WASHINGTON — Just two years after watching Democrats claim a 60th seat in the Senate, Republicans are heading into the 2012 election season well positioned to challenge them for control of the chamber, giving the party reason for optimism even as it worries about the strength of its presidential field.

headline: Florida Men Accused of Supporting Pakistani Taliban
text: MIAMI — Six people, including two imams at South Florida mosques, have been indicted on federal charges of providing financial support and encouraging violence by the Pakistani Taliban, the United States attorney here announced Saturday.

headline: ‘I Am a Man’
text: Watching the Arab uprisings these days leaves me with a smile on my face and a pit in my stomach. The smile comes from witnessing a whole swath of humanity losing its fear and regaining its dignity. The pit comes from a rising worry that the Arab Spring may have been both inevitable and too late. If you are not feeling both these impulses, you’re not paying attention.

headline: Driver Runs Down Narcotics Officer in the Village
text: A Westchester man turned his vehicle into a weapon on Friday night, steering it onto a sidewalk in Greenwich Village and ramming into a plainclothes police officer who, with his partner, was trying to arrest three drug suspects, the authorities said.

headline: Where Water Is an Old Friend, Until It Turns Into a Nemesis
text: BUTTE LA ROSE, La. — You do not really want to ask a Cajun why he lives in a swamp, especially when he is packing everything he owns because the very swamp he loves is about to swallow up his house.

headline: Venice Tourist Ships Rattle Windows and Nerves
text: VENICE — When cruise ships and ferries stream their way down the Giudecca Canal to dock at Venice’s main passenger terminal, the windowpanes on some of the palazzos on the quay have been known to tremble. Sometimes, even the walls shake.

headline: What Holbrooke Knew
text: When he was alive, Ambassador Richard Holbrooke was effectively gagged, unable to comment on what he saw as missteps of the Obama administration that he served. But as we face a crisis in Pakistan after the killing of Osama bin Laden, it’s worth listening to Holbrooke’s counsel — from beyond the grave.

headline: San Mateo’s Asian and Hispanic Voters Speak Up
text: Like many residents in this corner of San Mateo County, Violeta Ortega can name the exact intersection on Middlefield Road where sun-blanched taquerías and car repair shops fade into leafy oaks and 10-foot-high walls that circle some of the most expensive houses in the United States.

headline: A Big Whine From Big Oil
text: With gas at $4 a gallon, oil at $100 a barrel and profits at near-record levels, it is hard to feel sympathy for the oil industry. Yet sympathy is what the C.E.O.’s of the five biggest companies asked for when they appeared Thursday before a Senate hearing on a Democratic proposal to eliminate about $2 billion in tax breaks for the Big Five.

headline: Big Deal. I Just Said It. I Didn’t Say It Was True.
text: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Oakland Police Force Restructuring Could Hinder Murder Investigations and More
text: The Oakland Police Department, reeling from budget cuts, is planning an organizational overhaul that will push more officers onto the streets, but could undermine its ability to investigate murders and other serious offenses at a time when the homicide rate is soaring.

headline: When Doctors Humiliate Nurses
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Newly Pastel Capital
text: Artists, city officials and designers in Baghdad are lamenting what they feel is of the ugliest periods in the city’s history, as banks and police buildings are outfitted with unconventional color schemes.

headline: Red Rock Island
text: Jutting out of the blue near the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge is Red Rock Island, a homely atoll with a colorful history and a sizable price tag. Many have made plans over the years to develop this ideally situated islet with spectacular views, but it is currently uninhabited.

headline: Children of War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Radiation and Cancer
text: To the Editor:

headline: Cardiologists Accuse Hospital of Discrimination
text: VICTORIA — The e-mails and memos written by administrators and doctors at Citizens Medical Center here about three of their colleagues of Indian descent are, at best, derogatory. An operating room chief wrote of trying to force “the Indians off the reservation.” Others wrote about their “Indian troubles,” or labeled the hospital’s two rival cardiology practices as “the Cowboys” and “the Indians.”

headline: Electric Cars of the Future
text: To the Editor:

headline: Outdoor Smoking Bans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Westchester Tax Appeals
text: To the Editor:

headline: Do-or-Die Time for Bills Has All Eyes on the Clock
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: For Subway Cars, The Final Trip
text: Because new trains have more plastic, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has suspended the “reefing” program after 10 years and 2,500 burials.

headline: Lawmakers and Others Discuss Changes to Education Programs for Prisoners
text: As state lawmakers combed the budget this year for cuts to close a multibillion-dollar shortfall, some leaders focused on a line item that usually draws little attention: the Windham School District, which received more than $128 million in 2010-11 to provide education to inmates in the state’s sprawling prison system.

headline: In Prison Reform, Money Trumps Civil Rights
text: Columbus, Ohio

headline: Pat’s Pick
text: The best new restaurant in Texas right now.

headline: Did the Microsoft Case Change the World?
text: Remember when Microsoft ruled the PC industry? In the 1990s, its Windows operating system became so dominant that government trust-busters took it to court. They spent four years and millions of dollars making the case that Microsoft was unduly using its power to wipe out rivals in the Web browser business and other domains.

headline: The Secrecy Tax
text: Who are the fat-cat five? Political money bundlers are wondering now that the Internal Revenue Service has put five unnamed donors on notice that it is looking at the checks they write to nonprofit groups that are increasingly funneling money directly to political campaign troughs.

headline: Strolling Coney Island the Hard Way
text: Not since Charles Feltman was credited with inventing the hot dog 140 years ago has Coney Island had to adjust to such radical change as the “concrete compromise” that’s about to alter its signature boardwalk along the Atlantic beachfront.

headline: A Mayor Moves on, and a Myth Moves In
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Figure in 2006 City Hall Patronage Case Has a New Career Lobbying City Hall
text: The city’s inspector general forced Christopher Kozicki from his high-ranking job in Mayor Richard M. Daley’s administration three years ago, citing his involvement in the infamous hiring of an unqualified, but politically connected, teenager as a building inspector. At the time, his lawyer said Mr. Kozicki would move on to “pursue other opportunities.”

headline: The Other Torture Debate
text: IT wasn’t long after Osama bin Laden’s killing that the arguing began: did the Bush administration’s torture policy produce essential intelligence that led the United States to Bin Laden’s hideout in Pakistan?

headline: Big Business Threatens and New Tax Break Is Readied
text: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Bringing the High Line Back to Earth
text: THE second section of the High Line, the park built atop an abandoned elevated rail trestle on the west side of Manhattan, is scheduled to open next month. Like a movie sequel, High Line II will have some things that are the same — more of those neat high-tech concrete planks underfoot and “peel-up” benches — as well as some things that are different: a “woodland flyover” of dense vegetation; a lawn; and a dramatic glass cutout exposing traffic on the street below. Food carts and something called a wine porch are promised, as well as a Renzo Piano-designed restaurant.

headline: Charles McPhee, Host of ‘Dream Doctor’ on Radio, Dies at 49
text: Charles McPhee, a nationally syndicated talk radio host who made a career analyzing the stuff of dreams, died last Sunday at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 49.

headline: Cornell Dupree, Guitarist and Sideman to the Stars, Dies at 68
text: Cornell Dupree, a guitarist whose quietly bluesy style made him an in-demand session musician throughout the 1960s and ’70s for artists like Aretha Franklin, Paul Simon and Ringo Starr, died May 8 at his home in Fort Worth. He was 68.

headline: Montezemolo in the News
text: There have been reports in recent days of Luca di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, saying that the Formula One teams are now open to the possibility of a breakaway series.

headline: Montezemolo in the News
text: There have been reports in recent days of Luca di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, saying that the Formula One teams are now open to the possibility of a breakaway series.

headline: Sunday: Included Herewit
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, that’s more like it: A puzzle I can solve without bloodshed.

headline: Credit Error? It Pays to Be on V.I.P. List
text: The credit rating bureaus, whose reports influence everything from credit cards to mortgages to job offers, have a two-tiered system for resolving errors — one for the rich, the well-connected, the well-known and the powerful, and the other for everyone else.

headline: Playgrounds of the Past
text: New York’s vibrant flea markets offers patrons a large volume of food, scavenger hunts and nostalgic items from the past.

headline: Tackling the Problems of Appalachia, Theatrically
text: CUMBERLAND, Ky. — Robert Gipe, an expert on Appalachia, had grown weary of watching flip-chart presentations about the region’s problems. Their remedies were too sweeping, and their language, full of terms like “sustainable development,” were too lofty.

headline: Service Complaint
text: Is it just me, or has Verizon Wireless 3G service along the Northeast Corridor gotten significantly worse over the past few months? There were always gaps, but they seem to have multiplied — no signal much of the way between Baltimore and Washington.

headline: The Supreme Court Had Its Say. Now Let Shareholders Decide.
text: Valley Forge, Pa.

headline: Broadcast of ‘Die Walküre’ Performance at the Met Is Delayed
text: The massive set for Wagner’s “Ring” being staged at the Metropolitan Opera picked a fine time to misbehave. A technical problem left an estimated 175,000 people sitting in movie theaters around the world (and nearly 4,000 people at the Met itself) twiddling their thumbs while waiting for the start of a live high-definition broadcast of “Die Walküre,” the cycle’s second installment. Finally, after about 45 minutes, the performance started.

headline: Major Delusions
text: London

headline: Dessert, Laid-Back and Legal
text: Remember melatonin? In the 1990s, this over-the-counter dietary supplement was all the rage among frequent fliers, promoted as the miracle cure for jet lag. Now it is back in vogue, this time as a prominent ingredient in at least a half-dozen baked goods that flagrantly mimic the soothing effects of hash brownies — and do so legally. At least for now.

headline: Your So-Called Education
text: COMMENCEMENT is a special time on college campuses: an occasion for students, families, faculty and administrators to come together to celebrate a job well done. And perhaps there is reason to be pleased. In recent surveys of college seniors, more than 90 percent report gaining subject-specific knowledge and developing the ability to think critically and analytically. Almost 9 out of 10 report that overall, they were satisfied with their collegiate experiences.

headline: Site of Fatal Fire Was a Boarding House, Fire Officials Say
text: A Brooklyn row house where two men died in a fire on Friday night was an improvised boarding house, fire officials said.

headline: Readers Comment on my Holbrooke Column
text: My Sunday column offers advice from Ambassador Richard Holbrooke, the late American envoy to Afghanistan and Pakistan, for the crisis we now face in relations with that region. Holbrooke couldn’t speak out publicly at the time, but his posthumous views could not be more relevant at a time when we face a crisis in relations with Pakistan.

headline: U.S.D.A. May Hire an Ex-Employee’s Group
text: WASHINGTON — The federal Department of Agriculture may soon issue a contract to a community organization co-founded by Shirley Sherrod, the former department employee who was asked to resign last year after a conservative activist issued an edited videotape that appeared to show her making racially insensitive remarks.

headline: Black or White?
text: In February 1861, just weeks after Louisiana seceded from the Union, Randall Lee Gibson enlisted as a private in a state army regiment. The son of a wealthy sugar planter and valedictorian of Yale’s Class of 1853, Gibson had long supported secession. Conflict was inevitable, he believed, not because of states’ rights or the propriety or necessity of slavery. Rather, a war would be fought over the inexorable gulf between whites and blacks, or what he called “the most enlightened race” and “the most degraded of all the races of men.” Because Northern abolitionists were forcing the South to recognize “the political, civil, and social equality of all the races of men,” Gibson wrote, the South was compelled to enjoy “independence out of the Union.” (Read Randall Lee Gibson’s article, “Our Federal Union.”)

headline: Struggling Again, Dickey Gives Knuckleball a Day Off
text: HOUSTON — If there is one thing that R. A. Dickey has never been over his 12-month Mets career, it is conventional. An avid reader who yearns to climb mountains and to be a ball boy at the United States Open, Dickey is unique among professional athletes.

headline: Posada Sits Rather Than Hit Ninth in the Lineup
text: At 4 p.m. Saturday, Jorge Posada said he understood why Manager Joe Girardi had dropped him to ninth in the Yankees’ batting order. “I put myself in this spot,” Posada said. Two hours later, Posada marched into Girardi’s office and told him that he felt disrespected. Rather than suffer the ignominy of hitting last in a nationally televised game against the Boston Red Sox, Posada pulled himself out of the lineup.

headline: Chicago Braces for the Unknown and a New Mayor
text: CHICAGO — With only a few days to go, Richard M. Daley, the longest-serving mayor in Chicago’s history, had yet to pack up his City Hall office, which was cluttered with old photographs, trinkets from other towns, even the desk from which his father once governed this city.

headline: I.M.F. Chief, Apprehended at Airport, Is Accused of Sexual Attack
text: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, was taken off an Air France plane at Kennedy International Airport minutes before it was to depart for Paris on Saturday, in connection with the sexual attack of a maid at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, the authorities said.

headline: Daley’s Next Task: Adapting to Life Outside City Hall
text: CHICAGO — Yes, there will be the shock of not going to work on the fifth floor of City Hall on Monday, as Mayor Richard M. Daley has for more than two decades. But there are more pressing matters to worry about. Like getting used to carrying a wallet, buying a cellphone, and remembering how to drive a car.

headline: Sony Begins Phased Restoration of PlayStation Services
text: Sony said on Saturday that it would begin restoring the PlayStation Network for its 77 million users after hackers infiltrated the service and forced it offline almost a month ago.

headline: Stack of Evidence Sealed Galleon Case, Juror Says
text: Andrew Burton/Getty ImagesRaj Rajaratnam leaving federal court after his conviction.

headline: Secret Desert Force Set Up by Blackwater’s Founder
text: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates — Late one night last November, a plane carrying dozens of Colombian men touched down in this glittering seaside capital. Whisked through customs by an Emirati intelligence officer, the group boarded an unmarked bus and drove roughly 20 miles to a windswept military complex in the desert sand.

headline: Boogaard Family Authorizes Brain Study
text: In poll after poll of N.H.L. players it was always a landslide: Derek Boogaard was the toughest, most feared fighter in the league.

headline: McDowell and Watney Lead, but Storms Leave Much of Two Rounds to Play
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — A four-and-a-half-hour rain delay during Saturday’s third round of the Players Championship defanged T.P.C. Sawgrass, and golfers filled with pent-up energy attacked the softened course like a swarm of children at an Easter egg hunt.

headline: China Delays Report Suggesting North Korea Violated Sanctions
text: China has tried to suppress a report at the United Nations suggesting that North Korea and Iran have been routinely sharing ballistic missile technology, United Nations diplomats said Saturday, expressing concern that Beijing was again working to shield the North.

headline: At a 10-Year Reunion, Old Songs and New Voices
text: As if guided by sense memory, they took their positions from their gospel chorus days, only they were standing on a sidewalk on the Upper West Side.

headline: A Visual Narrative of Old England, Rude, Lewd and Colorful
text: America’s baby boomers savored the joyously irreverent cartoons of Mad Magazine and the leeringly carnal comix of R. Crumb. Gilded Age New Yorkers either cheered or fumed at the political savagery in the drawings of Thomas Nast. And Georgian-era Londoners got early versions of all three in the rude, lewd, devilishly funny prints of Thomas Rowlandson.

headline: The Bruise Patrol of Central Park
text: THE three men wearing in-line skates stood quietly in the shade in Central Park, studying the passing crowd. Then a nearby skater, Jesse Madigan, 25, slammed into a curb, doubling over, and they pounced.

headline: An Operatic, Comic Romance
text: One look at the set for “Italian American Reconciliation” and you may form an opinion as to just what kind of production this is.

headline: A Power Breakfast With a Cozier Touch
text: Breakfast in the main dining room of the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue at 61st Street is still the see-and-be-seen meal for New Yorkers with money and influence, but a younger generation of power brokers is establishing its own beachhead in the Library. It is a quieter, cozier spot off the lobby, with a mounted flat-screen television, a plush couch in the window and enormous reproductions of classic books standing upright. On Wednesday, in the main dining room, called 540 Park, Larry King dined near Jonathan M. Tisch, the chief executive of Loews Hotels, who was with Jane Rosenthal, Robert De Niro’s producing partner. But in the Library, a nonprofit executive and her frequent consulting partner sat between “The Grapes of Wrath,” by John Steinbeck, and “Bullet Park,” by John Cheever, talking baby names and home renovation. DIANE CARDWELL

headline: In Southampton, Portraits From a Luxe Life
text: Southampton, N.Y.

headline: The Consciousness of a Feminist Expressionist
text: For many painters, prints serve as a place to try out new ideas, experiment in a different medium or circulate their images in a reproducible format, while earning some extra money. Sometimes, however, a print exhibition can feel like a vital key to an artist’s career. Such is the case with “Dancing With the Dark: Joan Snyder Prints 1963-2010” at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick.

headline: Pick a Car, Then Off to Church
text: A connoisseur of and a cheerleader for all things Staten Island, John C. Gustafsson, president (until June 30) of the Staten Island Historical Society, was born there 49 years ago. Both he and the borough expect a busy summer as the celebration of Staten Island’s 350th anniversary hits its peak. Mr. Gustafsson retired in 2006 from a law career that began at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and concluded at Sheppard Mullin Richter & Hampton, where he was administrative partner in the New York office. He and his wife, Mary Beth, general counsel of First Solar, live in a Stanford White house in West Brighton; Mr. Gustafsson’s son, Christopher, 13, visits every other weekend.  ROBIN FINN

headline: As a Festival Expands, Its Needs Do, Too
text: MEMORIAL DAY weekend will bring the third installment of Bombfest — an acronym for Bring Our Music Back Festival. But instead of bringing the music back to Durham, where the multigenre festival was held last year, the event’s founders, Frank Bombaci and his son, also named Frank Bombaci, will be delivering headliners like Weezer, Wiz Khalifa and Snoop Dogg to Hartford.

headline: You Can Do That on a Sunday?
text: It was Sunday morning, about 11 o’clock, and a casual glance might have suggested I was in church. There were a couple of bibles nearby; a depiction of the Garden of Eden was available for examination. But I wasn’t in church. I was in the Museum of Sex. New York’s blue laws, it appears, are not holding up so well.

headline: Corrections
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Unrest Continues as Libya Mourns Dead
text: Protests broke out across the country even as Libyans buried victims.

headline: As Libya Buries Victims, Hints of Deception
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — As the nine pinewood coffins were laid on scrubland beside the glistening blue waters of the Mediterranean, uniformed men with Kalashnikov rifles fired volley after volley into an azure sky, and a trumpeter blew the discordant melancholy of a final farewell.

headline: After Hinting Otherwise, Huckabee Says He Won’t Run for President
text: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas said Saturday night that he would not seek the Republican nomination for president next year in an announcement that had been hotly anticipated — in part because of contradicting hints he gave right up to the minute he finally made his intentions known.

headline: How Libyan Rebels Have Repelled Qaddafi in the Western Mountains
text: How Libyan rebels have repelled Qaddafi in the western mountain region.

headline: Photo Replay: May 14
text: The day in sports was filled with kicks, slides and celebrations.

headline: Voices Soar Again, 10 Years Later
text: In 2001, a teacher took her students from P.S. 86 in the Bronx on an unlikely journey: to a small island in Finland, where they would perform their music. They reunited 10 years later.

headline: Upsets Are Paving the Way to the World Championship
text: The first round of the World Championship Candidates Matches in Kazan, Russia, produced several surprises.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Line Up to Compliment Huckabee
text: Now comes Huck, Part 2 — the effort by other candidates to pick up his supporters with kind statements about the latest noncandidate, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas.

headline: Running on Moderation in Immoderate Times
text: BRAZIL, Ind. — Senator Richard G. Lugar had already been introduced to the Clay County Republican Club as “a leader in reducing the threat of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons,” a man of “Hoosier common sense” and “a true statesman for our time.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 15
text: The 2012 presidential race gained momentum this week as potential Republican challengers began announcing their candidacies, making the election a major topic of conversation on the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Times Square Pastor Remembered as Charismatic and Charitable
text: While many speakers at the memorial service for the Rev. David Wilkerson on Saturday spoke of how many lives his ministry had touched, one clergyman spoke from very personal experience.

headline: Yanks’ Night Starts Oddly, Then Turns to Disaster
text: The Yankees’ night began on a curious note, with an announcement shortly before the first pitch that Jorge Posada, penciled into the No. 9 spot in the team’s batting order by Manager Joe Girardi, had been scratched from the lineup.

headline: When a Batting Order Becomes a Reflection of Disorder
text: There’s nothing like going to the office and being blindsided by the news that you have been demoted.

headline: Posada’s Mental Health Day
text: Jorge Posada’s late scratch from the Yankees’ lineup shortly before a 6-0 loss to the Boston Red Sox on Saturday at Yankee Stadium led to a night of speculation and disagreement over why he did not play.

headline: No. 20 on Your Roster, No. 9 in the Order
text: Jorge Posada and Derek Jeter have been friends for nearly 20 years, since they were teammates at Class A Greensboro in 1992. Their daily interaction is part of the fabric of the Yankees’ clubhouse. Jeter, holding a cup from Starbucks, grabs a pair of sanitary socks and belts out, “Sado!” – his nickname for Posada. They have won together – five World Series championships – and they have lost together, and now they are, almost inevitably, declining together, a 36-year-old shortstop and a 39-year-old designated hitter.

headline: In Paris, the Striking Strokes of Japanese Calligraphy
text: When Ritsuko Koga met Ayako Wakahara, the president of the Young Japanese Calligraphers collective, she was “moved by her ambition and her objective to make the value of Japanese calligraphy known to the world.” Ms. Koga, who oversees the gallery space at Espace Japon (12 rue de Nancy; 33-1-47-00-77-47; www.espacejapon.com), then invited the group to display their oeuvre in Paris. All of the artists studied calligraphy at Tokyo’s University of Taito-bunka, an institution that puts special emphasis on Eastern traditions and culture. By working as a collective, the Young Japanese Calligraphers’ communal nature fortifies the solitary aspects of this written art.

headline: 2010 Texans: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: Q. and A. With the Red Bulls’ Rafael Marquez
text: Rafael Marquez, the captain of Mexico’s national team, is in his second season with the Red Bulls of M.L.S. The veteran, who has played in France and for Barcelona in Spain, is back at his natural center back position and has helped to steady the club’s defense as the Red Bulls prepare for Sunday’s game against visiting Chivas USA. Marquez, a superstar in Mexico, has often times seemed like that other guy as the club and league promote the exploits of Thierry Henry, who was also his teammate in Spain. Marquez spoke recently with Jack Bell of The Times.

headline: Going Dutch
text: For those of us fortunate enough to regularly patronize New York City’s wondrous bodegas, the appearance of cut tulips ($7 a bunch, two for $12) in mid-February is our first inkling that spring is coming. Most of us don’t have access to real trees, after all. Besides, those other, more fluorescent flowers, the ones that require a certain level of patience to sift through, don’t appear to be tied to a particular season — or to Earth, even — as they sit huddled in green buckets, illuminated by fluorescent lights.

headline: With Europe in Crisis, Fragile Time for I.M.F.
text: LONDON — It’s hard to imagine a worse time for the International Monetary Fund to be without a forceful European leader.

headline: A Morning at Fair Hill
text: On Saturday morning, I met three friends and headed over to Fair Hill to watch Animal Kingdom train. We met at the local deli, formerly named Prizzios, and drove to the clocker’s stand. There was light chatter among my friends, who had not yet seen the Derby champion.

headline: Credit Report Errors: How Have You Handled Them?
text: On today’s front page, Tara Siegel Bernard uncovers something you’ve probably suspected for a long time: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion has one system for solving important people’s credit report errors and another for everybody else.

headline: Singers From Azerbaijan Win Eurovision Contest
text: FRANKFURT — A singing duo from Azerbaijan was the surprise winner of the Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday, the first victory for the country — technically located in Asia — since it began competing in the popular event four years ago.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

headline: Soul-Searching in France After Official’s Arrest Jolts Nation
text: PARIS — The arrest in New York of one of France’s leading global figures and a possible next president, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, on charges of attempted rape produced an earthquake of shock, outrage, disbelief and embarrassment throughout France on Sunday.

headline: Muslims and Coptic Christians Clash Again in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Muslims and Coptic Christians clashed with bullets, rocks and Molotov cocktails here for the second time in seven days on Saturday night, sending at least 55 people to the hospital, officials with Egypt’s Interior Ministry said.

headline: Salmon-Eating Sea Lions Sentenced to Die
text: For the crime of snacking on endangered salmon, dozens of sea lions have been sentenced to die.

headline: Cannes Q. and A.: Julia Leigh on a Modern-Day ‘Sleeping Beauty’
text: CANNES, France— The Australian novelist-turned-director Julia Leigh traces the origins of her first feature, “Sleeping Beauty,” to what she calls a bout of “self-exposure.” The attention she received for her well-received first novel, “The Hunter” (1999), led to a recurring nightmare about being watched in her sleep.

headline: Israeli Troops Fire as Marchers Breach Borders
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s borders erupted in deadly clashes on Sunday as thousands of Palestinians — marching from Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank — confronted Israeli troops to mark the anniversary of Israel’s creation. More than a dozen people were reported killed and scores injured.

headline: Seven Tips to Better Landscape Photos
text: The photographer Ansel Adams is reputed to have said “Landscape photography is the supreme test of the photographer — and often the supreme disappointment.”

headline: Landscape, With Flowers
text: This week’s Look features tulips seen from such a height that we see not flowers but a colorful abstraction. That picture above looks more like a worn throw rug from a northern European department store than a planted field. The tulip, of course, is a signature icon of Dutchness, along with windmills, clogs, pointy bonnets, dark Rembrandt portraits/bright Van Gogh craziness, certain Amsterdam liberties and — on my altar, at least — soccer wizards like Johann Cruyff and Dennis Bergkamp. And Cruyff has his own move named after him and is one of the architects behind totaalvoetbal; Bergkamp did this (and this).

headline: He Saw Plenty From the Ring, Not So Much in It
text: There was a time, a few decades ago, when pro wrestling thrived in New York City, whether at Madison Square Garden, or in high school gyms.

headline: Update on Verizon
text: Well, with regard to this post, I’m on Amtrak now, and my connection seems OK. In fact, I’m sure that it’s perfectly reliable; there’s no chance whatsoever that I will be cut off in the middle of a

headline: The Morning Line: Motion and Fair Hill Are Hot Topics
text: Almost all of the Triple Crown news today involves varying aspects of Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom.

headline: Faye Dunaway Defends Cannes’s Artistic Soul
text: CANNES, France— International sex scandals with likely candidates for the French presidency have not disrupted proceedings at the film festival here. On Sunday afternoon, Frédéric Mitterrand, the French minister of culture, gave Faye Dunaway a medal and the honor of being an officer in “L’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres.” Ms. Dunaway, whose kohl-eyed, sex-kitten image, photographed by Jerry Schatzberg in 1970, graces program guides and advertisements all over town, and hangs stories high above the Palais des Festivals, seemed to deserve the title, or at least she was ready to defend it. At the opening night dinner following the premiere last Wednesday of Woody Allen’s “Midnight in Paris,” she bristled at the notion that Cannes might have a commercial bent. “Don’t say that, because it’s wrong,” she said. “Cannes is not commercial, for God’s sake. Cannes is the only festival in the world, and the only entity in the world, that honors great film, from all over the world.”

headline: Google Turns On Charm to Win Over Europeans
text: PARIS — Chiseled into the stone facade of the vacant Second Empire building at 8, rue de Londres here is the name of the French national railroad, a former occupant. Most recently, the site housed another conservative pillar of the French corporate establishment, the insurer AXA. The proud new owner is a company with a very different image in France, more bomb-thrower than bourgeois: Google.

headline: Upfronts: NBC Bets on Talent Shows and Scripted Series
