text: 2:52 p.m. | Updated NBC, hoping to rebound from almost a decade of conspicuous failure, will count heavily on its lineup of talent competitions to set up a new season packed with 12 new scripted series.

headline: A Sports Executive Leaves the Safety of His Shadow Life
text: Last month, in a Midtown office adorned with sports memorabilia, two longtime friends met for a private talk. David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, sipped his morning coffee, expecting to be asked for career advice. Across from him sat Rick Welts, the president and chief executive of the Phoenix Suns, who had come to New York not to discuss careers, but to say, finally, I am gay.

headline: The French Reaction to I.M.F. Chief’s Arrest
text: The arrest of the chief of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, for an alleged sexual attack of a maid at a New York hotel sent tremors through the French media and blogosphere on Sunday, inspiring a mix of contempt, sympathy, expressions of national humiliation and more than a few conspiracy theories that the contender for the French presidency had been set up by his rivals.

headline: A Classical Guitarist Making Herself Heard
text: The classical guitar is mostly a solitary instrument, partly because the greatest works written for it are in the solo repertory, but for practical reasons too: It is so soft-spoken that its voice easily gets lost alongside louder orchestral instruments and in the large halls where orchestras tend to play. So even though its concerto repertory has grown prodigiously since the late 1930s and is plentifully available on recordings, opportunities to hear guitarists play concertos in concert remain comparatively rare.

headline: Choi Wins in Playoff After 3-Putt by Toms
text: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — K. J. Choi was the last man standing at the Players Championship on Sunday, winning on the first hole of sudden death with a short par putt after David Toms — who had made a 17-foot birdie putt at the 72nd hole to tie — missed a putt that was two inches shorter than Choi’s.

headline: I.M.F. Names New Leader
text: Hours after its chief, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, was arrested in connection with the alleged sexual attack of a maid at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, the International Monetary Fund on Sunday named John Lipsky as acting managing director.

headline: This Week Panel
text: Basically, what Digby said.

headline: Money 1937 (Slightly Wonkish)
text: A followup on my note on monetarist pathos: I’ve been rereading Friedman and Schwartz, and it’s striking just how much the debate in 1936-7 paralleled the debate now.

headline: Resistance and Desire, With a Little Mud Wrestling
text: For the choreographer Nai-Ni Chen, her piece “Dragons on the Wall (Tianji)” doesn’t have much to do with mythical, fire-breathing creatures. She’s more focused on what the dragon can symbolize: individual freedom. As she writes in the program notes, a dragon is about “power and tremendous energy.”

headline: E.U. Panel to Propose Tighter Data Protection
text: BERLIN — The European Commission’s advisory panel on data protection plans this week to urge governments in the European Union to treat the geographic location of cellphone users as personal data, deserving of the highest level of privacy protection.

headline: Gingrich Calls G.O.P.’s Medicare Plan Too Radical
text: WASHINGTON — Days after formally announcing his candidacy for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, Newt Gingrich on Sunday sharply criticized a plan by House Republicans that would drastically overhaul Medicare, the federal health care program for retirees.

headline: Hollywood’s Box-Office Slump Continues
text: LOS ANGELES— Hollywood still couldn’t shake its box-office slump, as “Thor,” the top performer for a second weekend, posted $34.5 million in North American tickets sales for Marvel and Paramount Pictures, down 34 percent from $52 million on the same weekend last year for “Iron Man 2,” another Marvel-Paramount action fantasy that was also in its second week. “Thor,” starring Chris Hemsworth, above, has had $119.3 million in domestic ticket sales to date.

headline: Ahead of Schedule, Indians Rock Again
text: CLEVELAND — Two flags hang from each lamppost on Ontario Street here, outside the home of the best team in baseball. On one side is a head shot of a smiling Cleveland Indians player. On the other is a photograph of that player shaking hands with a fan.

headline: Evolution, and a Definitive Endpoint
text: Titles of concert programs can be misleading. Take “The Evolution of the Symphony,” as the conductor Kent Nagano called the program he presented with the Montreal Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, the final concert in the first Spring for Music festival. This sounds like the title of a music history course in college. But the actual program, which alternated performances of Bach’s keyboard sinfonias, played by the pianist Angela Hewitt, with works by Gabrieli, Webern, Stravinsky and Beethoven, was more subversive than that drab thematic heading suggested.

headline: Broadway Union Takes On ‘Priscilla’ Over Music
text: In a bid to protect jobs, the Broadway musicians’ union is waging an unusually aggressive, political-style campaign against the new musical “Priscilla Queen of the Desert” in hopes of undercutting the use of recorded music during live theatrical performances.

headline: Foodies vs. Techies
text: Forget James Beard and Julia Child. When it comes to American cookery, I’m for their foe: Poppy Cannon, food editor of Ladies’ Home Journal and House Beautiful and much-mocked author of “The Can-Opener Cookbook.”

headline: The Indians’ Manny Acta: Follow Me
text: CLEVELAND – The Cleveland Indians finished last in the majors in attendance last season, which is where they are now. But they have tried hard to recruit more fans and create a sense of closeness between the community and the players.

headline: An Accomplished Premiere, Served Along With Other Flourishes
text: The generous breadth of taste shown by New York Theater Ballet with its Signatures series is good for New York’s whole dance scene. This weekend at the Florence Gould Hall it showed pieces by Frederick Ashton, Merce Cunningham and Antony Tudor — three of the 20th century’s supreme choreographers — as well as a world premiere by the British choreographer Richard Alston. Larger than the excellence of any one work here, which is saying much, was the stylistic diversity of the program. I’ve been grateful for this company before; I’ve never admired it more than on this occasion.

headline: Getting a Slice of LimeWire’s Pie
text: The music industry scored a victory against online piracy last week by winning a $105 million settlement against the file-sharing network LimeWire. But where will that money go? And will any of it end up with the artists whose work was illegally downloaded?

headline: Eyes on the Bermuda Bowl
text: The semifinals of the open trial to pick the second United States team for this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship were slated to end late on Sunday night in Henderson, Nev.

headline: Housewives, Sure, but What Makes Them Real?
text: So many questions with no clear answers. Does a significant chunk of the universe really consist of dark matter, and why can’t we detect it? Is free will real or just a carefully orchestrated divine illusion? Who is still watching “The Real Housewives of New Jersey,” one of the most idiotic shows on television?

headline: Renovations That Seek to Put Film Out Front
text: People have long joked about the challenge of how to find the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

headline: At Cannes, Synergy but Not Consensus
text: CANNES, France — There may not have been consensus by Day 4 of the Cannes Film Festival — no movie has yet been universally loved, loathed or violently debated — but the critics have staked out their positions and fired up their thumbs. The British are keen on the British film “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” Lynne Ramsay’s drama about an American mother and her psycho son, while the French are less impressed. The reviewer at Cahiers du Cinéma anointed it with an unsmiley face in a trade magazine, a perfect representation of what sometimes seems to be the default critical attitude here.

headline: Monday: Like the Best Straight in Poker
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Your mileage may vary, but I knew I was going to be having a good puzzle day when this one opened at 1 Across with the word SCRUM. I’m not sure why it put me in such a good mood, but it’s a fun word.

headline: Skype-Style Calls Force Wireless Carriers to Adapt
text: Today, long-winded talkers need to worry about running out of minutes on their cellphone plans. But someday there will be no minutes to run out of — just megabytes.

headline: Turner, the Second Baseman Come Lately, Breaks Out
text: HOUSTON — Justin Turner, the Mets’ surging second baseman, is playing well enough that on Sunday, Mets Manager Terry Collins heaped his highest praise on him.

headline: Her Folksy Parlor, Crowded With Family and Friends
text: When the Canadian songwriter Kate McGarrigle died on Jan. 18, 2010, she left behind an extended musical family and a quietly magnificent catalog. Both were at the center of “A Celebration of Kate McGarrigle,” tribute concerts on Thursday and Friday nights at Town Hall.

headline: Voices From the Buses on the Road to Civil Rights
text: The filmmaker Stanley Nelson has a stunning accomplishment in “Freedom Riders,” a documentary that chronicles a crucial, devastating episode of the civil rights movement, an episode whose gruesome visuals impinged on the perception of American liberty around the world. Commemorating the 50th anniversary of the freedom rides, the film (to be shown Monday on PBS) is a story of ennobled youth and noxious hatred, of decided courage and inexplicable brutality. In May 1961 the Congress of Racial Equality sought to challenge the segregation of interstate travel on public transport and sent forth activists, both black and white, and many of them students, on a bus journey through the South, where they were received with violence that law enforcers refused to tame.

headline: Comedian Who Raps, or Rapper?
text: Donald Glover was part of a comedy troupe that became famous for making viral videos, which earned him a job as a sitcom writer, which he abandoned before landing a spot as a sitcom star, which he’s now leveraged into a side career in music.

headline: A Military Post’s Secrets: Espionage, Not Aliens
text: At the start of “Area 51,” Annie Jacobsen’s cauldron-stirring book about America’s most mysterious military installation, Ms. Jacobsen offers a passing glimpse of a large-headed little gray space alien being interrogated by scientists in white coats. This is both a tease and a distraction. Yes, Ms. Jacobsen will eventually address the U.F.O. issue with which conspiracy theorists eagerly associate Area 51, but her book is not science fiction. It’s much more levelheaded. It is an assertive account, revelatory but also mystifying, of the long-hidden United States weaponry and espionage programs to which she says Area 51 is home. (Some say Area 51 is home to nothing, because it does not officially exist.)

headline: Web Critics Sum It All Up in a Word
text: The online review, long the default means on the Internet to express support for a local business, has been eclipsed by Facebook’s one-click “Like” button.

headline: Footnotes
text: Georgiana Pickett has been named the new executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the center has announced. Ms. Pickett has been the executive director of 651 ARTS at the Brooklyn Academy of Music since 2004. She replaces Stanford Makishi, a former dancer, who resigned in February. ... The director Darko Tresnjak (“The Merchant of Venice”) will take over as artistic director of the Hartford Stage theater company in Connecticut in July, Playbill.com reported. He will succeed Michael Wilson, who has served for the past 13 years and is to retire in June.

headline: New Victory to Open With ‘The Little Prince’
text: The New Victory Theater will open its new season on Oct. 1 with a show starring new creations from an “Avenue Q” puppet maker. The show, “The Little Prince,” an adaptation of the French fable by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, written by Rick Cummins and John Scoullar, will feature life-size puppets designed by Michael Schupbach, an alumnus of the Jim Henson Muppet Workshop. The season continues Oct. 13 with the United States premiere of “White,” a contemporary work from the Catherine Wheels Theater Company, of Scotland, that was a 2010 Edinburgh Festival Fringe award-winner last year; and the Reduced Shakespeare Company’s “Complete World of Sports (abridged),” beginning on Oct. 21. Other highlights will include “Untapped!,” a dance and rock review from Australia (Nov. 11), and “Bai Xi,” a circus show from Shanghai (Dec. 2).

headline: Durant Seizes Control for Thunder
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — No matter where he spotted up Sunday, Kevin Durant was going to hold the ball and the outcome of Game 7 in his hands. The Oklahoma City Thunder, after all, was built around him when it moved here in 2008 from Seattle, only to settle into its new home with a 3-29 start.

headline: How Drudge Has Stayed on Top
text: For most big news Web sites, about 60 percent of the traffic is homegrown, people who come directly to the site by dint of a bookmark or typing in www.latimes.com or www.huffingtonpost.com. The other critical 40 percent comes by referrals, the links that are the source of drive-by traffic, new readers and heat-seekers on a particular story.

headline: Alibaba and Yahoo Try to Make Up
text: SHANGHAI — It was an unexpected dispute over two continents that floored technology investors.

headline: Lincoln Captured!
text: Despite recent rumors to the contrary, Lincoln displayed no vampiric powers in his early presidency. But it is true that he could appear many places at the same time, thanks to a chemical process that seemed to borrow as much from the dark arts as from science.

headline: Obama and Immigration Reform
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Road, but at Home
text: CHICAGO — Dwyane Wade was a Chicago kid and a Bulls fan long before he was a Miami Heat star, but his hometown loyalties stop at the baseline.

headline: Options for Bringing Down the Cost of Health Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Shirtless Congressman
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Rule Gives as It Takes Away
text: Goldman Sachs is lobbying to weaken limits on proprietary trading imposed by the so-called Volcker Rule that was part of last year’s financial overhaul. But like most hastily written legislation, the rule has unintended effects that are only now becoming apparent. One may make the business of managing private equity investments even more lucrative for the likes of Goldman.

headline: Gay Marriage
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tax Stock Transactions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Forty Years After a Dream Mile, a Harsh Reality for Track
text: The news that the Millrose Games are leaving Madison Square Garden after 97 years to relocate uptown to the 168th Street armory reminds us of how indifferent we are to track and field. And yet, in a coincidence of timing, we remember, too, that we were not always this way. Friday’s announcement came almost exactly 40 years after an event that placed the sport, however briefly, front and center in the consciousness of the American public.

headline: New York Theater Ballet
text: Photos from the company’s performance at Florence Gould Hall.

headline: ‘Dragons on the Wall’
text: Photos from the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Company’s performance.

headline: Doric Wilson, Playwright and Mainstay of Gay Theater, Dies at 72
text: Doric Wilson, a playwright whose satirical, wisecracking works are considered bricks in the foundations of the Off Off Broadway and gay theater movements, died May 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

headline: Homegrown Drones
text: A growing group of hobbyists and engineers are designing and selling do-it-yourself drones of near military caliber.

headline: Secrecy Breeds Curiosity Over an ESPN Exposé
text: Inside James Andrew Miller’s black messenger bag was potential sports-world dynamite: the 770-page oral history of ESPN that he has written with Tom Shales.

headline: In This Sky, the Planes Fly Alone
text: BOULDER, Colo. — A father of five and a professed geek, Chris Anderson, editor in chief of Wired magazine, is always looking for child-friendly activities that could, he hopes, inculcate his children with techie sensibilities.

headline: Former Galleon Employee Is Next Target in Inquiry
text: Among the more intriguing spectators at the trial of Raj Rajaratnam was Zvi Goffer, a former Galleon employee. His interest was more than just curiosity about his former boss.

headline: Before It Can Rebuild, Japanese Town Must Survive
text: OTSUCHI, Japan — The crumpled cars have reddened with rust, and spring rains and a warming sun have left the ashes and mud hardened into an earthen plate of armor. But Satoshi Watanabe still comes every day to pick through the charred debris that was once his home, searching for the remains of his 2-month-old infant daughter.

headline: Is College Worth It? Answers From Presidents and the Public
text: The Pew Research Center has just released a report incorporating two surveys — one of 2,142 adults 18 or older; the other of 1,055 college presidents — each centered on the question, “Is college worth it?”

headline: TV Networks Expect a Jump in Spending on Commercials
text: Fox is the only television network that broadcasts “Glee,” but just about every network is gleeful as this week begins.

headline: United Arab Emirates Confirms Hiring Blackwater Founder’s Firm
text: The United Arab Emirates confirmed on Sunday that it had hired a company run by Erik Prince, the billionaire founder of Blackwater Worldwide, to provide “operational, planning and training support” to its military. But it gave no details of the company’s project to build a foreign mercenary battalion for the Emirati government.

headline: When New York Was Ready to Rumble
text: A two-minute history of the glory days of pro wrestling in New York City, from the memory and photographs of Al (Samson) Vass, a veteran referee.

headline: Despite Restrictions, Microblogs Catch on in China
text: SHANGHAI — Wang Yin, a 24-year-old graduate student at the elite Tsinghua University in Beijing, constantly uses Sina Weibo, China’s Twitter-like social networking site.

headline: Varitek Understands Posada’s Distress
text: The many parallels in the two players’ careers make comparisons inevitable.

headline: The Wrong Reasons for Same-Sex Marriage
text: Forest Grove, Ore.

headline: Afghanistan May Be Open to New Path, Kerry Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Osama bin Laden’s death will allow “a new phase” in the United States’ relationship with Afghanistan, one that could include reductions in troops and spending, Senator John Kerry said while visiting here on Sunday.

headline: Support for Antipiracy Bill
text: The entertainment industry threw its weight behind a proposed law that would give law enforcement officials and others new authority to move against Internet sites that traffic without permission in copyrighted material.

headline: Patience, Not Punishment, for Pakistan
text: Islamabad, Pakistan

headline: Internet Filters Set Off Protests Around Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Thousands of people in more than 30 cities around Turkey took to the streets on Sunday to protest a new system of filtering the Internet that opponents consider censorship.

headline: Murray Handwerker, 89, Dies; Made Nathan’s More Famous
text: Murray Handwerker, who transformed his father’s Brooklyn hot dog business, Nathan’s Famous, into a celebrated national fast-food chain, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 89.

headline: Wallace McCain Dies at 81; Fed the World Frozen Fries
text: Wallace McCain, who helped create the world’s largest frozen French fry maker, lost one of Canada’s most public family feuds and then built another major food company specializing in cold cuts and sliced bread, died on Friday night in Toronto. He was 81.

headline: After Weak Season, Networks Strive for Fresh Ideas
text: Acknowledging that the crop of new television programs last year was almost a complete washout, the networks are spending big this year to promise, if not genuine excitement, at least something different.

headline: A Day After a Prideful Outburst, Posada Apologizes
text: Before he could start his workday on Sunday, Jorge Posada took time to reflect on perhaps the worst day of his decorated career, and realized that he needed to apologize to Joe Girardi. In the manager’s office at Yankee Stadium, they had a conversation with a far friendlier tenor than on Saturday, when Posada removed himself from the lineup an hour before the Yankees’ game against Boston, feeling slighted that he had been dropped to ninth in the batting order.

headline: Eurovision Joy Deflects Cares for a While
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — For three hours on Sunday morning, as the nightclub around him filled up with dry ice and stiletto heels, 28-year-old Ziya Rahbarli watched the gigantic screen with the gravity of a social scientist.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for April and industrial production and capacity utilization for April (Tuesday); and weekly jobless claims, existing home sales for April, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for May, and leading economic indicators for April (Thursday).

headline: Senator and Granddaughter on Two Sides, but One Stage, in Debate on Gay Marriage
text: Rubén Díaz Sr., the Bronx state senator, Pentecostal minister and steadfast opponent of same-sex marriage, gathered his flock on Sunday for a rally on the steps of the monumental Art Deco courthouse in the Bronx, serenaded by church bands and an ear-piercing soundtrack of Latin song.

headline: Space Shuttle Endeavour Is Readied, Once Again, for Its Final Launching
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — NASA made final preparations for the launching of the shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station, confident that it had fixed an electrical problem that grounded the spacecraft two weeks earlier.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Managing at the Intersection of Then and Now
text: Joe Girardi saw this coming. Not this, specifically, because no one could have imagined the proud Jorge Posada asking out of a game with a bruised ego. But when Girardi became the Yankees’ manager before the 2008 season, he understood what he would inherit if he stayed long enough.

headline: Salute to a Movie Producer
text: LOS ANGELES — “Swearsies.”

headline: British Commander Says Libya Fight Must Expand
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Two months into the NATO bombing campaign against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces, Britain’s top military commander has said that the Libyan leader could remain “clinging to power” unless NATO broadened its bombing targets to include the country’s infrastructure.

headline: Money Troubles Take Personal Toll in Greece
text: ATHENS — His face contorted with anguish, Anargyros D. recounted how he had lost everything in the aftermath of the Greek economic collapse — the food-processing factory founded by his father 30 years ago, his house, his car, his Rolex, his pride and now, he said, his will to live.

headline: Cuts Could Stall Sluggish Courts at Every Turn
text: Extensive budget cutbacks being rolled out in New York State’s courts are expected to add new delays to practically every facet of the judicial process, from the moment a suspect is brought in to be charged until the case is heard in court, and onward into appeals.

headline: America Held Hostage
text: Six months ago President Obama faced a hostage situation. Republicans threatened to block an extension of middle-class tax cuts unless Mr. Obama gave in and extended tax cuts for the rich too. And the president essentially folded, giving the G.O.P. everything it wanted.

headline: Mets Travel Home With a Smile
text: HOUSTON — Although the Mets are still tied for last place in the National League East, and still have a losing record (19-21), they were feeling pretty good about themselves as they left Texas on Sunday night.

headline: Teeing It Up for Their Clubs, Not Their Feet
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Golf was going to form a wedge between Al Del Greco and his son Trey. The younger Del Greco was convinced it would as he nervously rehearsed what he planned to say to his father, a former N.F.L. place-kicker.

headline: A Requiem for Huckabee
text: Most candidates for the highest office in the land spend months, if not years, currying favor with the rich and powerful: glad-handing at fund-raising dinners, schmoozing in mansions, pressing the flesh in Aspen and Manhattan and Nob Hill.

headline: Going Back on the Deal
text: Last year, Republicans refused to renew unemployment benefits unless the high-end Bush-era tax cuts were preserved. After the White House agreed to keep the tax cuts through 2012, they agreed to extend federal jobless benefits through 2011. Now, they want to renege.

headline: Police Seek Evidence From I.M.F. Chief on Sex Attack
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the leader of the International Monetary Fund, spent most of Sunday at the Manhattan Special Victims Unit in East Harlem as prosecutors sought additional evidence, including possible DNA evidence on his skin or beneath his fingernails, to bolster allegations that he had sexually assaulted a maid in a $3,000-a-night suite at a Midtown hotel, officials said.

headline: Syrian Border Violence May Hold Message for Israel
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For 37 years the border between Israel and Syria, still technically at war, has proven as quiet as any of the Arab-Israeli frontiers silenced by peace agreements. On Sunday, it was not, and the tumult on the Golan Heights could augur a new phase of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and the web of international relations he is navigating.

headline: Tunisia Is Uneasy Over Party of Islamists
text: TUNIS — Accused as subversives or terrorists, they bore the repressive brunt of the Tunisian dictator’s reign — two decades of torture, prison or exile.

headline: Despite City Crackdown, Immigrants Still Are Often Cheated by Job Agencies
text: Cristina Rivas, 49, an immigrant from El Salvador, thought her one-year search for steady work had finally come to an end. A Queens employment agency that she had paid $120 said it had found her a job as a waitress at an upscale restaurant. She needed only to show up.

headline: Governor Cuomo’s List
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York began barnstorming the state last week to rally support for three of his campaign promises: ethics reform, same-sex marriage and, unfortunately, his misguided cap on property taxes. He advised voters upstate to tell their representatives: “pass these bills or don’t come home.”

headline: The Rush to Secret Money
text: President Obama should waste no more time and sign an executive order requiring government contractors to disclose any checks they write to the newly legal troughs of secret campaign donations. House Republicans, who in the past loudly supported such transparency, are holding hearings to push the absurd claim that Mr. Obama is aiming to violate donors’ free speech.

headline: Remembering the Freedom Riders
text: Fifty years ago this month, a group of black and white volunteers boarded two public buses in the District of Columbia to travel into the Deep South, where segregated waiting rooms, restrooms, lunch counters and other indignities were a fact of life despite Supreme Court rulings striking down segregation in interstate travel.

headline: Commuters Feel Pinch as Christie Tightens
text: As a standard-bearer of fiscal conservatism, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey won over voters with his aggressive, no-excuses approach to taming budget problems and identifying the parties he held responsible for them. He has sparred with unions, cut spending and sworn off raising taxes, including the state’s low gasoline tax.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cleverness Expressed in Felt-Tip Marker
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Palestinians Mark 63rd Anniversary of the ‘Nakba’
text: Israel’s borders erupted in deadly clashes on Sunday as thousands of Palestinians confronted Israeli troops on the anniversary of Israel’s creation.

headline: Tears in the Social Fabric
text: The transformation of the Greek economy has been jarring to a citizenry long accustomed to a generous welfare state.

headline: If Truth Is Elusive, Rape Trial May Turn on Prosecutor’s Tug of War With Officer
text: The conflicting agendas of Coleen Balbert, a Manhattan prosecutor, and Franklin Mata, a police officer on trial for rape, were colliding.

headline: Gay CNN Anchor Sees Risk in Book
text: Don Lemon, the weekend prime-time anchor for CNN, was on the air on Sunday night this month when the news broke that President Obama would address the nation at the unusual hour of 10:30 p.m.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: A Reconstruction Begins, but an Exodus Does, Too
text: The devastated coastal community of Otsuchi has started picking up the pieces of their lives after the tsunami, but there may not be enough people willing to stay there for a lengthy reconstruction.

headline: For Bulls, Rose and Rebounds Are Winning Combination
text: CHICAGO — LeBron James fiddled with his mouth guard in one hand, the drawstring on his shorts with the other. Dwyane Wade flung a towel into the stands. Then they disappeared into a dim tunnel, staring into unfamiliar terrain.

headline: Braving the Mississippi River Floodwaters
text: The battle against North America’s longest river continues, with residents in the South making the most of rising floodwaters as they prepare for the worst.

headline: Record Water for a Mississippi River City
text: VICKSBURG, Miss. — Late Sunday morning, as the Mississippi River was rushing faster and higher past this town than it has in 183 years of record-keeping, Dontaye Buck was sitting perfectly still.

headline: Rhode Island’s Medicaid Experiment Becomes a Talking Point for Budget Cutters
text: With Republicans pushing to rein in Medicaid costs, an experiment in Rhode Island is drawing the attention of some conservatives who say it has led to substantial savings without reducing care for the state’s poorest patients.

headline: Ask Questions About the N.B.A. Playoffs
text: Updated

headline: Frugality Is a Virtue, but Politics Rule the Debt-Limit Fight
text: The president needed an increase in the federal debt limit. His partisan adversary, a powerful Ohio congressman, wanted something in return: deep spending cuts.

headline: Idea Rebounds: Automatic Cuts to Curb Deficits
text: WASHINGTON — Among the highest-profile laws of recent decades was a failed one: the 1985 deficit-reduction statute called Gramm-Rudman-Hollings for its Senate sponsors. Intended to force a balanced budget, it spawned budget gimmicks and did little to cut deficits, provoking one of its authors, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, to say, “I’m filing for divorce on grounds of infidelity and irreconcilable differences.”

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: At School for the Disabled, High Pay Leads to State Pressure and Now Layoffs
text: ALBERTSON, N.Y. — Kathleen Cervasio’s daughter, Gina, who is 12, has cerebral palsy, cannot speak and is quadriplegic. Without a doubt, Ms. Cervasio said, the best thing that ever happened to Gina was getting into the Henry Viscardi School, one of 11 state-supported public schools for the severely disabled in New York.

headline: Many Eyes on a Fight in Nassau County Over a G.O.P. Proposal for Redistricting
text: MINEOLA, N.Y. — Even by the raucous standards of Nassau County politics, it was a wild day. Almost 200 residents, mostly minorities, trooped into the county office building for 10 hours last Monday to testify, shout, wave placards and threaten to sue over a redistricting plan being rushed through in record speed by the Legislature’s Republican majority.

headline: Nursing Homes Seek Exemptions From Health Law
text: WASHINGTON — It is an oddity of American health care: Many nursing homes and home care agencies do not provide health insurance to their workers, or they pay wages so low that employees cannot afford the coverage that is offered.

headline: Photo Replay: May 15
text: A look at the day in sports, from soccer in Europe to baseball in the United States.

headline: When Detroit Thought Small
text: After World War II, American manufacturers made an attempt to build smaller, more economical cars.

headline: Word of the Day | atone
text: atone •\ə-ˈton\• verb

headline: Audit Gives Limited Nod to Reports on Schools
text: The Department of Education has been the most frequent target of audits by City Comptroller John C. Liu. He has completed three of them since winning election in 2009 and has nine more under way, focusing on subjects like online learning and the $80 million database that tracks students’ academic records, which has been widely criticized as not living up to its promise.

headline: Tensions Are Smoothed Over, but Yankees Are Still Swept
text: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was asked Sunday afternoon about the status of Phil Hughes, one of his injured starting pitchers. Girardi let out a laugh and said: “I don’t know. I’ve had a busy day.”

headline: The Battle for Libya
text: Rebels continued training in Benghazi while new explosions sounded throughout Tripoli.

headline: Djokovic and Sharapova Have Surge Into French Open
text: With her Italian Open win on Sunday, Maria Sharapova is a step closer to regaining a top-five ranking on the WTA tour, where her take-no-prisoners power game belongs.

headline: The Rent-to-Own Option
text: As residential sales have softened in the city and throughout the region, many developments are offering rent-to-own options.

headline: A Rift Repaired, an Alderman Is Back to Business
text: In the void created when Mayor Richard M. Daley announced his retirement last year, the man who would become Chicago’s next leader appeared headed for conflict with the most powerful figure in Daley’s City Council.

headline: News Quiz | May 16, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: China Allows Dissident Artist’s Wife to Visit Him
text: BEIJING — The dissident artist Ai Weiwei was allowed a visit from his wife on Sunday, the first time he has been seen or heard from since being detained by authorities 43 days ago and held incommunicado in a secret Beijing-area location, Mr. Ai’s attorney said on Monday.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 16, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article “A Winner’s Circle Full of Firsts.”

headline: Gunmen on Motorcycles Kill Saudi Diplomat in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Saudi Arabian diplomat was killed on Monday in the volatile southern port city of Karachi, police officials said.

headline: Cathay Pacific Airliner Makes Emergency Landing in Singapore
text: HONG KONG — A Cathay Pacific airliner was forced to make an emergency landing after engine trouble on Monday, prompting the airline and the engine maker Rolls-Royce to start an investigation into the incident.

headline: Canadian Banks Make Rival Bid for Toronto Exchange
text: The competition for exchanges continues to heat up.

headline: Are Adults Hurting Young Children by Pushing Them to Achieve?
text: An article this weekend described a program in New York City in which parents pay $200 to $300 a month for children as young as two and three years old to spend up to an hour twice weekly being tutored in math and reading skills to get ahead. What do you think of programs like this? Why do you think more and more parents seem to be interested in them?

headline: Tsunami/Sakura
text: TOKYO — I stood in Ofunato, in Iwate Prefecture, with a photographer friend. We were mesmerized by a scene that seemed too outlandish even to imagine. She told me how her grandmother described clothes, reduced to rags, hanging from trees after Tokyo was bombed to the ground in World War II.

headline: The Old World’s Growing Pains
text: It makes sense to think of Europe as a family, because all its arguments are over money and children. Although the most recent economic numbers were better than expected, German politics churns on as voters question the utility of continuing to bail out Greece and other weak eurozone economies.

headline: Predictions and Suggestions for the U.S. Gold Cup Roster
text: Two summers ago, Mexico humiliated the United States in the Concacaf Gold Cup final at Giants Stadium.

headline: Economics for Sale
text: 05/17/10 | Updated

headline: Mumbai Slum Home to Artistic ‘Beehive’
text: Buried deep inside a labyrinthine Mumbai slum, a tiny lane has become the unlikely flag-bearer of gritty urban art. A cluster of cardboard canisters, shaped like a beehive, bright blue and pink graffiti and a collage of red wax splatters punctuate the myriad tin-roofed huts and single-story factories of Dharavi’s 13th compound.

headline: The Early Word: Medicare
text: Today’s Times

headline: As Case Unfolds, France Speculates and Steams
text: PARIS — France’s shock at the arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn on sexual assault charges has turned among some to suspicion and anger, with his defenders questioning the initial New York police account and speculating about entrapment, and many others characterizing the photos of the handcuffed suspect as insulting and unfair.

headline: Rob Lowe Wrote a Book
text: Rob Lowe discusses his memoir, “Stories I Only Tell My Friends,” with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review.

headline: This Week in Small Business: Get Your Party Hats On!
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: The Unreality of Being a Celebrity
text: Someday, someone will write a definitive phenomenological study of what it’s like now to be famous, although a simple infographic would probably just about cover it. “This Is Your Consciousness on Fame” would be the heading, just above arrows representing a positive feedback loop and captions reading: “Noncelebrities become convinced that celebrity dwells on a different plane of existence . . . which increases the magnitude of unreality, solipsism and alienation already being experienced by celebrity; celebrity succumbs to exponentially alienated and surreal view of reality and with behavior to match . . . which further increases the fascination exerted on noncelebrities; celebrity builds permanent residence on a different plane of existence, applies for passport.”

headline: Nasdaq and ICE Drop Offer for NYSE Euronext
text: 10:05 a.m. | Updated The Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange announced on Monday they were withdrawing their bid for NYSE Euronext, after antitrust regulators said the deal would not gain the necessary approvals.

headline: International Court Seeks Warrant for Qaddafi
text: PARIS — The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague on Monday sought arrest warrants for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, a son and the colonel’s brother-in-law on charges of orchestrating systematic attacks against civilians that amount to crimes against humanity.

headline: Data Recovered From Air France Flight Recorders
text: PARIS — French accident investigators said Monday that they had succeeded in downloading all of the flight data and cockpit conversations from the so-called black boxes of an Air France jet that crashed two years ago in the Atlantic Ocean — a critical breakthrough that could finally resolve the mystery behind why the plane went down.

headline: DuPont Offer for Danisco Succeeds
text: DuPont has won a five-month takeover fight for the Danish food ingredient maker Danisco, after more than 92 percent of shareholders approved its $6.3 billion tender offer, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Mystery Remains in Death of Marathon Champion
text: When he won the Chicago Marathon in October after a frustrating year of injury and illness, Sammy Wanjiru of Kenya seemed relieved and upbeat. Finally, he said, he could think about chasing the world record held by Haile Gebrselassie of Ethiopia.

headline: Empire Diner Is Reborn as the Highliner
text: When people see the Highliner, in what was the iconic Empire Diner and remark that “nothing has changed,” it’s music to Charles Milite’s ears.

headline: Alfama Returns, in Midtown
text: Tarcisio Costa and Miguel Jerónimo are reopening Alfama, one of the city’s rare Portuguese restaurants.

headline: Vatican Tells Bishops to Set Clear Strategy Against Abuse
text: VATICAN CITY — The Vatican told bishops worldwide on Monday to make fighting sexual abuse of minors by clerics a priority, telling them to create “clear and coordinated” procedures by next year and cooperate with law enforcement authorities when required.

headline: Philips Brightens Its LED Lineup
text: LED lamps are expected to revolutionize the lighting industry because of their sharply reduced power consumption and their long life compared with standard incandescents. But to date, market acceptance has been slow given the high initial cost ($50 and up in many cases) and limited brightness. LED lamps have only been able to emit light equivalent to a 60-watt standard bulb.

headline: Civilian Courts Are Getting Job Done in Terror Trials
text: Security seemed more intense than usual on Saturday for worshipers attending Sabbath services at some prominent synagogues in Manhattan. Two police officers and a patrol car planted themselves outside the Lexington Avenue entrance of Central Synagogue. On Fifth Avenue, officers stood on the front steps of Temple Emanu-El, while around the corner an enormous police van commanded a stretch of East 65th Street.

headline: Former Hershey Chief Joins Friedman Fleischer & Lowe
text: Richard H. Lenny, the former chief executive and chairman of Hershey, has joined the private equity firm Friedman Fleischer & Lowe as an operating partner.

headline: Best Political Quotes of the Weekend
text: Miss the political chatter this weekend? The Caucus has rounded up some of the most memorable political quotes.

headline: Now Reading | The Allure of Scripts
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#514", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Credit Where It’s Due: A ‘Simpsons’ Spelling Lesson
text: There wouldn’t seem to be many milestones left for “The Simpsons” to achieve after 22 seasons, but we think we saw a first for the show on Sunday night: Bart Simpson apologizing for a mistake. Though Bart’s chalkboard gag in the opening credits of the show is usually reserved for a throwaway one-liner or a joke about current events, “The Simpsons” used the space to make good with the comedian Kristen Schaal, whose name had been misspelled in the closing credits of last week’s episode. (There are many worthy reasons for “The Simpsons” to stay on good terms with Ms. Schaal, including the fact that it’s the right thing to do and, as a voice performer on the Fox animated series “Bob’s Burgers,” she’s a next-door neighbor of the show.)

headline: Endeavour Lifts Off on Its Final Flight
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — With Gabrielle Giffords, the wounded Arizona congresswoman, watching from a wheelchair, the shuttle Endeavour lifted off Monday morning on a mission to pry secrets from the universe.

headline: Upfronts: Fox Schedules ‘X Factor,’ ‘Terra Nova,’ New Sitcoms
text: Fox will introduce an ambitious adventure series, “Terra Nova,” on Mondays and an equally ambitious talent competition, “The X Factor,” on Wednesdays and Thursdays in the fall, the network said Monday in a preview of its 2011-12 schedule.

headline: Mining Equipment Maker Expands With $1.1 Billion Deal
text: 6:26 p.m. | Updated

headline: Rob Lowe, Studio Investor, Marvels at the Excess of Cannes
text: CANNES, France— “Cannes is a little bit like French wine,” Rob Lowe said the other day. “There are certain years that people prefer over others. Last year: very bad year. This year: very good year.”

headline: Geography, Income and Religion
text: In response to my column on religion and income (and my follow-up post on Economix), several readers have asked whether geography plays a big role. As one reader wrote, “Jews (and Asians) live primarily on the coasts, where above average incomes are earned (and needed).” The implication here is that Jews and Hindus aren’t the most affluent religions largely because they’re the most educated; according to this view, much of their affluence instead stems from the fact that they tend to live in expensive, high-income metropolitan areas, like New York, San Francisco, Washington and Boston.

headline: A Rendezvous With Manet in Paris
text: PARIS — Before I do my Torquemada routine, let’s begin on a positive note with an all-time favorite, that gorgeous redhead in the woods. She’s a shocker, even now, stark naked and turned to meet our gaze, at ease beside those two stiff, fully dressed men at a picnic. Something seems to have distracted her outside the picture’s frame, our arrival maybe, or something behind us; it’s hard to tell. Her look has cracked the wall between her and us. She’s in our space.

headline: As Mayor, Emanuel Will Have Washington’s Ear
text: CHICAGO — When Rahm Emanuel is sworn in as the mayor of Chicago on Monday, his influence in Washington will be on full display.

headline: Means-Testing Doublethink
text: Reading Dean Baker this morning, something occurred to me: if you look at what passes for serious commentary about our fiscal situation, what you see is a remarkable example of doublethink: believing two contradictory things at the same time.

headline: Bomb Threat in London Ahead of Queen’s Ireland Visit
text: LONDON — The British police said on Monday that they had received a credible bomb threat in central London on the eve of Queen Elizabeth’s visit to Ireland, the first by a reigning monarch in a hundred years.

headline: Monday Reading: How to Cut Gas Costs This Summer
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Debt Talks Continue, Minus a Key Figure
text: BRUSSELS — European finance ministers on Monday pressed ahead with efforts to control the debt crisis, approving a bailout package for Portugal and demanding that Greece start a privatization program before it gets any further help.

headline: Upfronts: Fox Sidelines ‘America’s Most Wanted’
text: Most of Fox’s 2011-12 schedule was predictable, but there was one surprise when it was revealed on Monday morning: the effective end of “America’s Most Wanted,” the long-running series that profiles — and sometimes helps find — fugitives.

headline: Nursing Homes Seek Exemption From Employee Insurance Requirement
text: Many nursing homes do not provide health insurance for their employees and are lobbying for an exemption to the new health care law, which would require them to do so, The Times reports this morning.

headline: Coen Brothers Receive Million-Dollar Prize in Israel

headline: Central China Hit by Drought, as Reservoirs Become ‘Dead Water’

headline: ‘War Horse’ Named Best New Broadway Play by Outer Critics Circle
text: Lincoln Center Theater’s production of “War Horse” has won the Outer Critics Circle Award for outstanding new Broadway play, the critics’ organization said on Monday, beating out two other plays — “Good People” and “The ____________ With the Hat” — that it is also competing against for this year’s Tony Award for best play. The fourth nominee for the Outer Critics outstanding play award was “Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo;” the fourth for the best play Tony is “Jerusalem.”

headline: Flannel Surfing: Pearl Jam Documentary by Cameron Crowe Gets PBS Debut
text: When you think of who or what constitutes an American master your mind probably flashes first on artists or writers like Norman Rockwell, Ernest Hemingway or Georgia O’Keeffe, and not necessarily the guys whose song “Evenflow” you spent many a night singing along with in the collegiate taprooms of your youth. But there you have it: Pearl Jam will join the “American Masters” roster when Cameron Crowe‘s documentary about that influential Seattle rock band, “Pearl Jam Twenty,” makes its PBS debut on Oct. 21, representatives for PBS said on Monday.

headline: The Morning Line: What’s in a Name?
text: Today, much of the news media plays the “Name Game” with the horses likely to be entered in the Preakness. The Baltimore Sun explains how horses get their names and asks “Shouldn’t there be a hall of fame somewhere for thoroughbreds whose accomplishments are few, but whose names are marvelous?”  Apparently, “Yakahickamickadola” may be the winner of the oddest — if not greatest — horse name ever.

headline: MoMA to Pay $31.2 Million for Folk Art Museum Building
text: The Museum of Modern Art will pay $31.2 million for the American Folk Art Museum’s building, according to a notice the folk art museum filed to its bondholders. The two museums announced the planned sale last week but had not disclosed the price. The folk art museum took on $32 million of debt to construct the building on West 53rd Street, but attendance never met expectations, and after sustaining investment losses in the financial crisis, the museum defaulted on its debt. The folk art museum had said that the sale would allow it to retire its debt, as well as pay fees to lawyers and consultants. The numbers are close: As of June 30, 2009, the museum owed a principal of $29,945,000 on the bonds.

headline: Even James Bond Can Use Help Sometimes
text: BECAUSE of the sensitive nature of my work, I do face-to-face meetings. That makes my flight schedule brutal. It’s not uncommon for me to fly from Miami to New York City on Monday, go to Los Angeles on Tuesday, Moscow on Thursday and then back to Miami for my son’s lacrosse or football games on Saturday.

headline: In Women, Hernias May Be Hidden Agony
text: Laura Sweet was an active, upbeat 42-year-old saleswoman living in Santa Monica, Calif., when the agony first started — debilitating, flaring pains in her pelvis that lasted for days and recurred periodically. The discomfort resulted in many visits to the emergency room, referrals to various specialists, wrong diagnoses and a daily cocktail of painkillers.

headline: CBS and ‘Boston Rob’ Win on Sunday Night
text: CBS’s “Survivor: Redemption Island” topped the ratings on Sunday as 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the reality show’s two-hour season finale, according to Nielsen’s estimates. After three previous tries, Rob Mariano, a k a Boston Rob, was finally victorious, winning this season’s $1 million prize. CBS ranked No. 1 for the night, leading at 7 p.m. with “60 Minutes” (12 million) as well as at 10, following the “Survivor” finale with a reunion special (11.3 million). ABC placed second for the night, garnering 10 million viewers from 9 to 11 for the season finale of “Desperate Housewives.” NBC was third with “Dateline” at 7 (5.2 million), “Minute to Win It” at 8 (3.5 million) and “The Celebrity Apprentice” from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). Fox and its animated comedy lineup finished fourth.

headline: Vain Glorious | Jemma Kidd’s Secrets to a Brilliant Body
text: Jemma Kidd has been busy: the 36-year-old former model runs the Jemma Kidd Makeup School in London, looks after two successful cosmetics lines — JK for Target, available at the mass retailer, and her makeup “academy,” for which she makes the QVC rounds — and last year, had twins with Arthur Wellesley, the Earl of Mornington (when she married him in 2005, it made her an official countess). All of this left her feeling, understandably, sluggish, until she adopted the Metabolic Balance Diet. “It’s this German diet. They take your blood and they analyze your hormone levels, vitamin levels, what’s right for you, your body type, your height, your weight. They analyze everything and give you this big list of what you can and cannot eat,” Kidd explained while previewing her summer and fall collections. “But the main rules are one type of protein for each meal, you’ve got to wait five hours between each meal, no snacking, an apple a day. The first thing you eat should be protein — it’s all about leveling your blood sugar and your hormones. Weight loss is the third thing. It’s detox for the first two weeks — you’re not allowed any fat. I’ve lost 23 pounds since January, 15 of them in the first 10 days.” The svelte Kidd was in New York a couple of weeks ago for the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Gala (she wore McQueen), where she was privy to some testimonials to one of her Target products, Show Stopper Year-Round Body Glow. “It’s organically grown into quite a successful little product,” she said. “I had five people at the Met ball come up to me and say, ‘My makeup artist put it on me. It’s fabulous!’”

headline: On Our Radar: A Satellite Tour of a Threatened Rain Forest
text: A computer illustration created by the wildlife activist group WWF-Indonesia using Google Earth provides a tour of Sumatran rain forest areas at risk of destruction by logging companies and palm oil producers. The animation focuses on Bukit Tigapuluh, a hilly region that provides habitat to endangered tigers, elephants, orangutans and other rare species. Camera trap footage from this area released by WWF this month showed a dozen tigers living in a logging concession. [Yale Environment 360]

headline: Company’s Arenas Leave Cities With Big Problems

headline: Israel Leader Outlines Points Before U.S. Trip
text: JERUSALEM — Days before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is to meet with President Obama, he laid out his principles Monday for accepting a Palestinian state, showing greater flexibility on territory but still pursuing a far more hawkish approach than any Palestinian leader is likely to accept.

headline: An Online 20th-Century Playlist From the Library of Congress
text: Listen up. Now you can tune into the National Jukebox, the Library of Congress’ new online collection of popular recorded music, monologues and more from the early decades of the 20th century. At the moment, the Jukebox includes more than 10,000 recordings on 78-r.p.m. discs made by the Victor Talking Machine Company from 1901 to 1925, but the library plans to expand the collection regularly. You can hear the opera star Enrico Caruso, Tin Pan Alley and Irving Berlin’s Broadway hits. The site enables you to create your own playlist. The collection also include hundreds of offensive, though historically significant, ethnic, religious and racial characterizations that come with a warning label. There is also a detailed explanation of the painstaking process of transferring these old discs into digital recordings.

headline: Rahmbo No More: Call Him ‘Mr. Mayor’

headline: Southern Swell
text: Now that Costa Rica’s best breaks have been overrun, Nicaragua is luring wave riders with low-key surf camps and undiscovered beaches. Popoyo, on the southern Pacific coast, has the most consistent barrel, along with hotels like the Popoyo Beach Lodge (popoyobeachlodge.com; doubles from $55 ). But two and a half hours north of Managua and just west of the town of Chinandega lies the country’s undeveloped northern Pacific coast — and dozens of breaks so new that many don’t have names. This is where the pro surfer and model Holly Beck set up her camp, Suave Dulce (surfwithhollybeck.com) after she stopped competing in 2008. Nicaragua, says Beck, a California native, is the ideal place to “help people experience the joy of getting pushed by the ocean.” Many of Beck’s students stay at El Coco Loco (011-505-8999-8662; elcocolocoresort.com; doubles from $100), a rustic resort near the town of Santa Maria del Mar with five palm-thatch cabanas near several surf spots. La Bahia Beach Hodel (011-505-8958-5075; labahiabeachhotel.com; doubles from $150) is a more luxurious option: four stone-and-teak casitas with outdoor showers, private pathways to one of Nicaragua’s most beautiful beaches and three breaks in front of the hotel (with more nearby). Both resorts serve seafood delivered daily by local fishermen, and there’s also plenty of the local catch at Al Cielo (011-505-8993-4840), a popular open-air palapa run by two French guys, with 360-degree views.

headline: Basque Boogie
text: The laid-back Basque town of Biarritz has been Europe’s surf capital since the 1950s. Yet despite the crowds and the casinos, it has retained its scruffy coolness. The Bay of Biscay provides the town with two main waves: the Plage de la Côte des Basques, a popular and consistent sandbar break; and the Grande Plage, an unpredictable, high-performance beach break up the coast. At least a dozen groups give surfing lessons, among them Jo Moraiz (011-33-6-62-76-17-24; jomoraiz.com), France’s first surf school. Biarritz’s plushest beach hotel is the Hôtel Du Palais (011-33-5-59-41-64-00; hotel-du-palais.com; doubles from about $665), a palace-turned-hotel where Alain Ducasse worked one of his first kitchen jobs. You’re less likely to see surfers there than at one of the campgrounds on Biarritz’s outskirts. A happy medium between opulence and outdoors is Hôtel Le Caritz (011-33-5-59-24-41-84; hotel-lecaritz-biarritz.com; doubles from $210), a handsome inn with a terrace restaurant. For the closest surf proximity, try the basic but comfortable Carlina Lodge (011-33-5-59-24-42-14; carlina.com; doubles from $190), which has direct access to the Côte des Basques. For post-surf refueling, the lovely covered market Les Halles (halles-biarritz.fr) offers outdoor fish and tapas restaurants, palpable reminders of the city’s vicinity to Spain. And Le Surfing (011-33-5-59-24-78-72; lesurfingbiarritz.fr), an inviting bar and restaurant where vintage surf memorabilia serves as décor, might be the only brasserie in town that allows sandy feet.

headline: TimesCast | May 16, 2011
text: The I.M.F. chief is denied bail in a sexual assault case; some in France see a setup; French journalists’ unspoken rule to protect politicians’ privacy.

headline: Vote to Name the Baby Hawk
text: Update, May 17, 4:08 p.m. | Read about the baby hawk’s newly bestowed name. »

headline: Wright Has Stress Fracture in Back
text: David Wright pulled on a maroon Virginia Tech T-shirt, jeans and running shoes, then strolled out of the Mets’ clubhouse at 4:40 p.m. Monday, done for the day and who knows how much longer. A half-hour earlier, the club disclosed that he had a stress fracture in his lower back.

headline: Earning Power of ‘Spider-Man’ Undiminished
text: Returning to Broadway after a brief hiatus to accommodate a creative overhaul, the musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” earned $809,941 for five preview performances last week before mostly full audiences at the Foxwoods Theater, according to the weekly box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: For Two Hours, a Vintage Car Collector Throws Open His Garage Doors
text: When he was growing up, Malcolm Pray went to the 1939 New York World’s Fair, where he saw a 1937 Delahaye. He promptly fell in love, and 25 years later, when he found that very car for sale, he bought it. That was the first purchase in a vintage-car collection that today consists of more than 50 vehicles.

headline: Obama and Graduates Cheer for Each Other
text: The graduating class of Booker T. Washington High School in Memphis was getting a last-minute pep talk from its principal, Alisha Kiner, on Monday, just before the ceremony began, when an out-of-town visitor dropped by to offer his own words of encouragement.

headline: One Death Provides New Life for Many
text: Mirtala Garcia laid a hand on Sebastiao Lourenco’s chest, then pressed her ear there for a moment.

headline: Nate Silver, Guest Ethicist
text: Not everyone was pleased with Nate Silver’s Acts of Mild Subversion column about “hidden-city ticketing,” a trick to save money on airfares. In fact, several readers — who saw the tactic as tantamount to lying — sought out the views of The Times’s resident ethicist, Ariel Kaminer. So Ms. Kaminer, over at the The 6th Floor blog, asked Nate to comment on the ethical underpinnings of “hidden-city ticketing.”

headline: Parade of Bodies and Tame Exoticism
text: When a dance company’s identity is predicated on its national or ethnic identity, the choreographic traps it can fall into are precipitous and deep. It’s a problem that the Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, currently at the Joyce Theater, shares with, among others, Ballet Hispanico, Dance Brazil and, to some extent, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

headline: Tunes to Help Gray Skies Clear Up
text: Ur-show tunes belted by a brassy show-tune voice: that describes “Herman on Herman ...With a Touch of Merman,” the program of Jerry Herman songs being performed by Peggy Herman (she is not related to the composer) at the Metropolitan Room. The show, which has the distinction of being directed by Tommy Tune (with Peter Glebo), exemplifies a pep-for-pep’s-sake Broadway musical atavism.

headline: P.R. Guru Linda Robinson Joins BlackRock
text: After 25 years with her public relations firm, Robinson Lerer & Montgomery, Linda G. Robinson has left to join BlackRock as a senior managing director and the global head of marketing and communications.

headline: With Huckabee Out, Whither Iowa?
text: The decision by Mike Huckabee to forgo another presidential bid means that the former governor of Arkansas won’t be seeking back-to-back victories in the the Iowa caucuses, and leaves the first-in-the-nation presidential contest without a clear Republican front-runner.

headline: Democrats Take Aim at G.O.P. Freshmen on Medicare
text: Members of the House are back home in their districts this week, and in the case of some Republicans, protesters are along for the ride.

headline: Critics' Picks: 'Umbrellas of Cherbourg'
text: A.O. Scott looks back at Jacques Demy's 1964 musical with Catherine Deneuve.

headline: Humm and Guidara of Eleven Madison Park Will Run Restaurants in the NoMad Hotel
text: Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, the executive chef and manager of Eleven Madison Park, will be running the lounges and restaurants in the NoMad hotel, which is being developed on Broadway and 28th Street.

headline: French Shocked by I.M.F. Chief’s ‘Perp Walk’
text: As our colleagues Steven Erlanger and Katrin Bennhold report, “The arrest in New York of one of France’s leading global figures and a possible next president, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, on charges of attempted rape produced an earthquake of shock, outrage, disbelief and embarrassment throughout France on Sunday.”

headline: Senate Posturing Kills Small Business Investment Research Renewal
text: Efforts to renew — and overhaul — the well-regarded Small Business Investment Research and Small Business Technology Transfer programs, which expire at the end of this month, may be in jeopardy now that the Senate appears unlikely to vote on its reauthorization bill anytime soon. And the person behind that bill’s demise, according to Democrats, at least, happens to be one of its chief architects — Senator Olympia Snowe, the Maine Republican on the Senate Small Business Committee.

headline: In Trump Coverage, Catchphrase Becomes Cliché
text: It was as common as the lack of surprise that greeted Donald Trump’s announcement that he would not run for president.

headline: Feet’s Too Big? No Problem; Everyone Dances Here
text: Once, a special event in jazz meant something warm and secretive and spontaneous: two guys who hadn’t seen each other in a while, improvising several choruses together. But lately — since the early 1990s, when jazz became fixed in the world of arts grants and cultural institutions — it has often meant something more structured, official and imposing: heady written music, presented before a theater audience, sometimes elaborated with text or image or drama, program-noted and documented and ready to be reproduced elsewhere.

headline: Latino Music, From Tango Back to the 16th Century
text: Since their founding in 1978, the annual Wall to Wall 12-hour marathons at Symphony Space have focused on a single composer; a genre, like opera; or a region, as did last year’s survey of music from behind the Iron Curtain. On Saturday the Wall to Wall Sonidos program explored Latino culture, with performers and composers from Spain and Central and South America representing myriad styles, including 16th-century vocal polyphony, tango, contemporary string quartets and Latin jazz.

headline: DNA Exposed
text: Q. What does a test tube of DNA look like?

headline: Arc of Life and Love, Unbent by Treatment
text: Gavin Snow’s skin cancer was discovered routinely enough: a mole on his back seemed suspicious to a dermatologist, who removed it for biopsy. The diagnosis was less typical. In 2006, Mr. Snow had Stage 3 melanoma, a disease usually found in people three decades older.

headline: Love Endures Even Cancer
text: Gavin Snow found out he had stage 3 melanoma two months before meeting Haley Tanner. Together they have endured the ups and downs of living with a tragic disease.

headline: Endeavour’s Final Flight
text: On May 16, the shuttle Endeavour rose slowly on a pillar of fire, picking up speed and eventually disappearing from view as it stabbed through a layer of clouds on its way to orbit.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Israel, Lebanon, Libya and Turkey.

headline: Profile in Style | Dick Page
text: As one of the world’s most in-demand makeup artists and the artistic director of Shiseido Makeup, Page traverses the usual New York-Paris-London-Milan-Tokyo circuit. When it comes to his coveted downtime, however, he gets off fashion’s beaten track, heading for rugged destinations like Iceland and the Arctic. The Long Island country ‘‘shack’’ he shares with his husband, James Gibbs, serves as the starting point for his favorite way to explore: camping. ‘‘Our Teardrop trailer is always ready to go,’’ he says. As is his Olympus digital camera: ‘‘I photograph everything.’’ Naturally, Page’s photos don’t merely serve as souvenirs — they also become makeup colors. View slide show >>

headline: Donating Lives
text: Julio Garcia died unexpectedly in 2010. His widow decided to donate his organs to seven different people. And they recently had the opportunity to thank her in person.

headline: A Lizard That Builds With the Family in Mind
text: Many animals build houses for their offspring, but no one thought lizards were among them. Now researchers have found that great desert skinks, lizards that live only in northern Australia, build and maintain elaborate tunneled homes, where they live in cooperative multigenerational family groups.

headline: Back to a Time (the ’80s) When Digital Was a Mere Dream
text: Much of “Radio Play,” a formless jumble of dopey humor and loopy music, by Tommy Smith and the alt-comedy darling Reggie Watts, is performed in almost complete darkness. This places a higher premium on what we hear as opposed to on what we see — a shift in focus that, Mr. Watts’s considerable musical gifts notwithstanding, doesn’t always play to his strengths.

headline: At Vox Festival, Future of City Opera Sounds All Too Familiar
text: The board of New York City Opera is to meet on Thursday and consider that beleaguered company’s plans for next season. As it happened, the discussion about City Opera’s uncertain future coincided with Vox, the company’s annual festival of contemporary American opera, which was held over the weekend at New York University’s Skirball Center and at Le Poisson Rouge. Since its start in 1999, Vox has been the centerpiece of City Opera’s vision of itself as a “lab” for new work; the festival’s tag line has long been “Preview the Future of Opera.”

headline: Group Spent Nearly $5 Million Backing Cuomo Budget
text: ALBANY – A coalition of business leaders supportive of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent nearly $5 million in the past two months lobbying in favor of the governor’s budget and his proposal to limit local property taxes, according to a new filing with the state ethics commission.

headline: Malick’s Film Adds a Dose of Sincerity to the Festivities
text: CANNES, France — In “The Tree of Life,” a cosmic head movie of the most ambitious order, Terrence Malick reaches high, his ecstatic camera and thoughts soaring. Shown on Monday morning at a press screening at the 64th Cannes Film Festival, where it was met with pre-emptive, harshly insistent boos and a vigorous rejoinder of equally determined applause, the film directly addresses the larger questions of existence that are woven throughout Mr. Malick’s work. It seeks to affirm the beauty of a world in which God is present in all things.

headline: Salzburg Must Replace Berlin Philharmonic
text: The Salzburg Easter Festival is scrambling to find a substitute for the Berlin Philharmonic, which said last week that after next year it would move to Baden-Baden’s Festspielhaus, or festival hall. “This has to be a reinvention, a restart of the whole thing, or we have to quit it,” Martin Riegler, the festival’s spokesman, said on Monday. Officials were trying to “find a future for the festival,” including a new orchestra, he said. The festival was founded in 1967 by the Philharmonic’s conductor, Herbert von Karajan, as a place for it to play opera. The decision to move to Baden-Baden follows a financial scandal that led to allegations of fraud against two former officials. In explaining the move, a Philharmonic spokesman, Olaf Maninger, said, “We need the kind of long-term security that the Baden-Baden Festspielhaus has to offer,” according to Bloomberg News. Mr. Riegler said the orchestra wanted to expand its offerings beyond the two opera performances, six concerts and handful of chamber music performances it has been giving in Salzburg. “We don’t have the money for it, and Baden-Baden seems to have,” he said.

headline: Hold On for One More Day: Judd Apatow Talks About the Aftermath of ‘Bridesmaids’
text: It looks like moviegoers tossed Kristen Wiig a bigger bouquet than was originally expected this weekend: her new Universal comedy “Bridesmaids” sold $26.2 million through Sunday, according to box-office numbers released on Monday, up from the $24.4 million in ticket sales estimated on Sunday. That’s good news for Ms. Wiig and her co-screenwriter, Annie Mumolo; the film’s director, Paul Feig; its prolific producer, Judd Apatow (of “Knocked Up” and “Funny People” renown), fans of funny women and anyone who likes to laugh at moving images displayed on a screen, all of whom had pretty much concluded that “Bridesmaids” was a crucial standard-bearer for studio comedies with female leads.

headline: Backing Up Your Facebook Content
text: As more and more of us put more of our online lives onto Facebook, the world’s biggest social network is moving from a convenient accessory to a necessary utility. People I communicate with for work have begun using Facebook rather than e-mail for important conversations.

headline: Libyan Woman Describes Rape by Qaddafi Forces
text: Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan woman who burst into a Tripoli hotel packed with foreign journalists in March to say that she had been raped by members of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s security forces, described her ordeal in an interview with Britain’s Channel 4 News conducted in Doha, the capital of Qatar, where she has found refuge.

headline: Turning to Biomechanics to Build a Kinder, Gentler Rib Spreader
text: DURHAM, N.C.—The sign on the door at the renovated tobacco warehouse reads “Physcient.” Inside are a few rooms that, depending on where you look, seem like an artist’s studio, a machine shop or a natural history museum. A lathe stands next to a drill press; along other walls are vises, huge enamel-red C-clamps, microscopes and plywood frames covered in electronics. But there are also reed-woven sculptures of insects called water boatmen hanging on the walls, along with glass-fronted boxes holding preserved flying dragon lizards. Casts of human rib bones are scattered on tables. A huge cast of a fearsome pair of fish jaws rests on a row of books.

headline: Party Love at Cirque de Cannes
text: CANNES, France — There were some parties here the other night. Of course there are parties here every night, because who wouldn’t want to celebrate being on the French Riviera, for decades a symbol of sun-dappled, Champagne-fueled luxury? Especially during the Cannes Film Festival, the annual pageant of haut aesthetics and a beacon to starlets since the early days of the bikini.

headline: One Family, Lots of Watercress Sandwiches
text: THE streets of the Upper East Side were almost deserted on a recent rainy Saturday. But inside William Poll, a food and catering shop at 1051 Lexington Avenue, things were happening.

headline: Citizens United Lawyer Creates Super PAC
text: While the comedian Stephen Colbert’s plan to form a so-called Super PAC to raise money for federal elections attracted some attention last week, another Super PAC formed by a key Republican campaign lawyer filed registration papers with the Federal Election Commission. The Republican Super PAC Inc., formed by James Bopp Jr., an Indiana lawyer, and Roger Villere, chairman of the Louisiana Republican Party, is designed to be a vehicle for unlimited contributions toward independent expenditures in support of Republican candidates at the national and state levels.

headline: The Funeral Party Ran Off; Now Go Chase It Down
text: The Israeli playwright Hanoch Levin (1943-99) ticked off many of his countrymen with his blowtorch satires on human venality, often with a political dimension. With “Winter Wedding,” now in a revival ably directed by David Willinger at Theater for the New City, he pillories the familial calamities of matrimony with cynicism, absurdist flair and relish for whoopee-cushion humor. (The play, translated by the director and Laurel Hessing, has been retitled from its original, “Winter Funeral.”)

headline: Obama Is a Millionaire, Records Show
text: President Obama is a millionaire with assets that could reach as much as $12 million, mostly from proceeds from his two best-selling books, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Monday.

headline: Running Down a Sanity Checklist
text: As Jon Ronson undertakes one of the journalistic escapades that make up “The Psychopath Test,” he describes renting a car and savoring its smell. This aroma “never fails to bring back happy memories of past sleuthing adventures.” The particular episode that springs to his mind is “trailing the conspiracy theorist David Icke around as he hypothesized his theory that the secret rulers of the world were giant, blood-drinking, child-sacrificing pedophile lizards that had adopted human form.”

headline: Japanese Officials Ignored or Concealed Dangers

headline: TED Talks: A Light Switch for Neurons
text: Ed Boyden shows how, by inserting genes for light-sensitive proteins into brain cells, he can selectively activate or de-activate specific neurons with fiber-optic implants.

headline: Control Desk for the Neural Switchboard
text: Treating anxiety no longer requires years of pills or psychotherapy. At least, not for a certain set of bioengineered mice.

headline: Police Officer’s Lawyer Says Money Motivated Rape Accuser
text: The lawyer for a police officer accused of serving as a lookout while his partner raped a woman argued Monday that no rape had occurred, that the woman was motivated by money and that his client had no motive to help his partner break the law.

headline: Ultimatum Holding Up Trade Deals
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Monday that it would not seek Congressional approval of free trade agreements with Colombia, Panama and South Korea until Republicans agree to expand assistance for American workers who might lose jobs as a result.

headline: Clemens Judge Asks for More
text: The federal judge overseeing the Roger Clemens perjury case wants more information from lawyers who investigated the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.

headline: Mets’ Wright Has Stress Fracture in His Back
text: The Mets announced Monday that third baseman David Wright has a stress fracture in his back and could end up on the disabled list for several weeks while it heals, the latest blow to a team used to them this season. The injury could be partly to blame for Wright’s .226 batting average, but he took pains on Monday not to use it as an excuse for his slow start. Read the article here, and come back to this post comment.
