headline: N.B.A. Draft Lottery Could Create More Problems Than Solutions
text: The N.B.A. draft lottery, an event that hinges on bouncing Ping-Pong balls, can give a team hope of claiming direction and focus out of years of misfortune.

headline: Home Tech: Tankless Water Heaters Explained
text: A few months ago my husband and I moved into a house outfitted with a “demand” or “tankless” water heater. Having lived only in rentals that were tapped into giant hot-water tanks, I was intrigued by the device’s claims of energy efficiency. But after a few weeks of turning on the faucet as I normally do, I began to wonder if I was using my newfangled appliance the way it was meant to be. I decided to find out exactly how these new warmers work, and how to best to take advantage of their efficiency claims.

headline: Lightning Leads With Its Focus, Not With Its Fists
text: BOSTON — Last season, the Tampa Bay Lightning was the most penalized team in the N.H.L. This season, under its first-year coach, Guy Boucher, 21 teams took more penalties.

headline: Bing Taps Facebook Data for Fight With Google
text: Microsoft is hoping that its alliance with Facebook will get more people to choose Bing over Google.

headline: Japan: U.S. Agency to Stop Monitoring Nuclear Plant
text: The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Monday that its 24-hour operations center had stopped monitoring the nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant because the situation there had improved. “The conditions at the Japanese reactors are slowly stabilizing,” said William Borchardt, the agency’s chief staff official. “As conditions have continued to improve and the Japanese continue to implement their recovery plan, the N.R.C. has determined that it is time to adjust our response,” he said. The agency still has a team of engineers in Tokyo, he said. Mr. Borchardt said last week that the condition of the reactors was “static but not stable.”

headline: Amid Tension, Yanks’ Slump Hits 6
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — A new workweek dawned Monday, and with it came the opportunity for the Yankees to purge themselves of one of the uglier stretches in Joe Girardi’s tenure. Off the field, a messy dispute engulfed the front office, the manager and two of the club’s iconic players. On it, ragged performances had dropped them out of first place in the American League East, sending them backsliding toward mediocrity.

headline: Belarus: Government Critic Sentenced Over Protest
text: A Belarussian court convicted a journalist and critic of the nation’s authoritarian president on Monday of helping to organize a large antigovernment protest in December. The journalist, Irina Khalip, received a two-year suspended sentence. Her husband, Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate, was sentenced to five years in prison on Saturday for a similar offense, and the authorities had previously threatened to take custody of their young son.

headline: China: Rumors of a Private Club in the Forbidden City
text: The Forbidden City’s management group handed out registration forms last month for a luxury private club to be located in the compound’s Jianfu Pavilion, which was restored with money from a fund in Hong Kong, according to a report in The Beijing News on Sunday and in the English-language edition of Global Times on Monday. Rumors about the club surfaced last week, when Rui Chenggang, an anchor for China Central Television, said on his microblog that the entry fee was one million renminbi, or about $154,000. Officials sent a statement to Global Times saying there were no plans to open any club.

headline: Houston Businessman to Buy Astros
text: Jim Crane, who lost a bid to buy the Texas Rangers last year, announced a deal Monday to acquire the Houston Astros from Drayton McLane for $680 million, which includes the lease on Minute Maid Park.

headline: Questions Raised About a Code of Silence
text: PARIS — The ritual follows a clear script: a scandal threatens to destroy the reputation of a powerful figure in France. Politicians say they are shocked. Friends say they are incredulous. Journalists debate whether they should have investigated rumors and revealed secrets. The dust settles. The status quo returns. Private life is protected.

headline: Libyan Officials Threaten to Use ‘Human Shields’

headline: Obama Is a Millionaire, Records Show
text: President Obama is a millionaire with assets that could reach as high as $12 million, mostly from proceeds from his two best sellers, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Monday. The disclosures only require Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, to list the value of their assets in wide ranges. For example, the president lists royalties from “Dreams From My Father” as between $1 million and $5 million. Mr. Obama’s financial disclosures have largely remained the same since he took office in 2009.

headline: For Fox and NBC, Let the Singing Begin
text: AS the television upfront week began on Monday, the presentations of the two networks that were first to outline their 2011-12 schedules to advertisers differed drastically. But their basic points were the same: broadcasting is alive and well.

headline: Sammy Wanjiru, Marathon Champion, Is Dead at 24
text: Sammy Wanjiru, who set a blistering pace to shatter the 24-year-old Olympic record in the marathon, becoming the youngest winner of the event, died on Sunday in Nyahururu, Kenya. He was 24.

headline: U.S. Calls for Global Cybersecurity Strategy

headline: Sex, the Koch Brothers and Academic Freedom
text: More than a few of the respondents to my column about CUNY’s on-again-off-again-on-again awarding of an honorary degree to Tony Kushner say that while I may be correct about the “technical” definition of academic freedom, I miss the larger point. That’s because there isn’t one. A board of trustees with every right to make a decision made it in a way that (a) ran counter to its previous practice (b) permitted a single member (Jeffrey Wiesenfeld) to derail a process that had seemed to be on a familiar track and (c) put CUNY right in the middle of the briar patch called the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Maladroit, unfortunate and (as I said) dumb. But that’s it. It was just the board screwing up with the predictable public-relations disaster as the result. No one’s freedom was curtailed, no one’s speech was censored, no harm, except to the board’s reputation and by extension to CUNY’s, was done.Because Wiesenfeld’s objections were to Kushner’s views on Israel, the uproar that followed the board’s decision to table his nomination quickly escalated into a shouting match between those who said that Israel was engaged in ethnic cleansing and those who replied that people who said that were anti-Semites and/or self-hating Jews. The responses to my column followed the same pattern. No one wanted to hear the topic of academic freedom “parsed” (a word used in derision by one reader, as if parsing something, trying to get it right, were a crime). MSP Shiloh complained that “Dr. Fish misdirects our attention to the arcane and off topic of the academic honorary degree process,” when “[t]his was, and is, about Israel’s persecution” of Palestinians. Other respondents were just as sure that “this was, and is, about” a university honoring a “self–righteous hack” (mcghostoflectricity) who spews “current day Palestinian propaganda” (neilrobert). Both sides are wrong, not about Israel – I did not and will not come down on that issue — but about what “this” is about. It’s about institutional ineptness, a relatively small matter that nevertheless can teach us some lessons. The back-and-forth trading of ritual insults is hardly edifying, but a proper understanding of what academic freedom is might be.

headline: Uganda: Opposition Leader’s Wife Is Briefly Held
text: The Ugandan government briefly detained the wife of the country’s leading opposition figure on Monday. The woman, Winnie Byanyima, the wife of the opposition leader Kizza Besigye and a senior director at the United Nations Development Program in New York, had been on her way to the airport to fly to the United States when her car was stopped by security forces and towed to a police station. She was soon released. Mr. Besigye has staged twice-weekly street demonstrations over the last month and has been arrested repeatedly.

In his starched white shirt and crisp suit, Tom Thibodeau looks more likely to sell James a life insurance policy than he is to thwart his title hopes.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Candidate Trails in Milan Race
text: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy was dealt a resounding blow on Monday when Mayor Letizia Moratti, left, of Milan failed to avoid a runoff in her bid for re-election. Mr. Berlusconi had staked his reputation in support of Ms. Moratti and had campaigned strenuously for her. But with two-thirds of the votes counted, the center-left candidate Giuliano Pisapia was well out in front, but was short of a majority. The runoff election will be in two weeks.

headline: ‘I Didn’t Wish to Be the Girl Who Had a Problem ...’
text: Tristane Banon, 31, a journalist and writer who has publicly claimed that Dominique Strauss-Kahn tried to rape her during an interview in 2002, now plans to file the legal complaint against him that she had decided against nine years ago, her lawyer, David Koubbi, said Monday.

headline: For Elite Club of Cabbies, Only a Lexus Will Suffice
text: When they see each other on the streets of New York, they often honk, wave, flash their lights and sometimes even stop to trade maintenance advice. The camaraderie is owed to a shared experience: each drives a Lexus as a New York City taxi.

headline: Out of Politics and Closet, McGreevey Pursues Dream to Join Clergy
text: NEWARK — The man once known as “robo-candidate” still acts like a campaigner in the thick of a close race. He does not enter rooms of people so much as plunge into them, hugging and hand-clasping his way from wall to wall. His smile is outsize, and almost as indelible as a campaign poster.

headline: Trump Bows Out, but Spotlight Barely Dims
text: Donald J. Trump announced on Monday that he would not seek the presidency, a development less important for the Republican field or his national political future — if he ever had one — than for what it said about a media culture that increasingly seems to give the spotlight to the loudest, most outrageous voices.

headline: In Getting Stars to Backpedal, Yankees Make Point
text: The corny stuff is the bedrock of sports. We teach our children about fair play and sportsmanship. We tell them to try their best at all times. We honor hard work and hustle and respect for authority.

headline: Poetic Justice for Chrysler’s Bondholders
text: What goes around comes around. Two years ago, the United States government bullied bondholders into accepting the steep losses involved in Chrysler’s bankruptcy plan. Now, the creditors have the upper hand as the automaker seeks $6 billion to pay back the Treasury. The creditors are pressing their advantage.

headline: Woman in 2008 Affair Is Said to Have Accused I.M.F. Director of Coercing Her
text: In the fall of 2007, just as Dominique Strauss-Kahn was starting his job as managing director at the International Monetary Fund, he asked all divisional heads to give him presentations on their specific areas of focus.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Goldman Sachs Diaspora
text: Retirement often conjures images of shuffleboard or fishing. But for most Goldman Sachs partners, it signals the start of another career.

headline: A Once-Tight Flock at Goldman, Now Scattered
text: When Goldman Sachs went public 12 years ago this month, an elite group of 221 executives controlled the strategy and shares of the investment bank.

headline: $60 Million Gift to Bolster Bard College’s Global Work
text: Bard College, a small liberal arts institution in the Hudson Valley, has received a $60 million gift from the Open Society Foundations in recognition of its global involvement, which includes programs in New Orleans, Nicaragua and Russia, officials are to announce on Tuesday.

headline: Nice Guys Finish First
text: The story of evolution, we have been told, is the story of the survival of the fittest. The strong eat the weak. The creatures that adapt to the environment pass on their selfish genes. Those that do not become extinct.

headline: A Book in Every Home, and Then Some
text: When we imagine people without books, we think of villagers in places like Afghanistan. But many families in the United States have no children’s books at home. In some of the poorest areas of the country, it’s hard to find books for sale. A study (pdf) of low-income neighborhoods in Philadelphia, for example, found a ratio of one book for sale for every 300 children. Tens of millions of poor Americans can’t afford to buy books at all.

headline: The Need for Greed
text: The bet was audacious from the beginning, and given the miserable, low-down tenor of contemporary politics, not unfathomable: Could you divide the country between greedy geezers and everyone else as a way to radically alter the social contract?

headline: Miami Imam Will Plead Not Guilty to Aiding Terror Group, Lawyer Says
text: MIAMI — The 76-year-old imam of South Florida’s oldest mosque will plead not guilty to charges of financing terrorism in Pakistan, his defense lawyer said on Monday.

headline: A Conflict Without End
text: Osama bin Laden had been dead only a few days when House Republicans began their efforts to expand, rather than contract, the war on terror. Not content with the president’s wide-ranging powers to pursue the archcriminals of Sept. 11, 2001, Republicans want to authorize the military to pursue virtually anyone suspected of terrorism, anywhere on earth, from now to the end of time.

headline: Regents Add Test Results to Teacher Evaluations and Cut Some High School Exams
text: New York State education officials voted on Monday to put into effect, for the first time, regulations that teachers be evaluated in part by the progress their students make on standardized tests.

headline: Demjanjuk in Munich

headline: Tuesday: A Few Words Between Friends
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — I know what some of you are thinking. Some of you are thinking, “So what? It’s a list of well-known people who happen to have two pairs of the same consonants in their name.” Allow me to point out once again why that makes a cool puzzle. I won’t convince everyone, but it’s worth repeating.

headline: Ex-Hospital Worker Accused of Cover-Up in Patient’s Death
text: A hospital worker has been charged with falsifying records in the case of a psychiatric patient who died on a waiting room floor nearly 24 hours after arriving in an ambulance, the Brooklyn district attorney said on Monday.

headline: Hoping Third Party Is Charm, Industrialist Jolts House Race
text: People in western New York used to roll their eyes when the name Jack Davis came up.

headline: ‘Chad Deity’ Takes Obie for Best New American Play
text: Kristoffer Diaz’s play “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,” a comic drama about televised professional wrestling and identity politics, won the Obie award for best new American play on Monday night at a ceremony marking the 56th year of the awards, presented by The Village Voice to honor Off Broadway theater.

headline: Orchestras on Tour: Names Strike a False Note
text: Every year foreign orchestras with exotic or impressive-sounding names crisscross the country. They follow grueling routes and play in arts centers, small theaters and school auditoriums in places like Pembroke, N.C., and Modesto, Calif.

headline: Hewlett-Packard to Report Its Earnings a Day Early
text: Hewlett-Packard is moving up its second-quarter earnings report to Tuesday rather than Wednesday, the company announced in a statement on Monday without citing a reason.

headline: Costly Hairstyle Is a Beauty Trend That Draws Thieves’ Notice
text: The thieves pulled the iron bars out of the windows, outsmarted the motion detector that would have triggered a burglar alarm and did not give the safe or cash register a second look.

headline: The Value of Comparison
text: Before you take a drug or undergo a medical procedure, wouldn’t you want to be sure it is the most effective and, if possible, the least costly available?

headline: Another Misguided Idea From the Gun Lobby
text: The Environmental Protection Agency declined to block the use of lead in hunting and fishing last year. It was the wrong call. To ensure that the agency doesn’t come to its senses, the National Rifle Association — assisted, as usual, by Congress — is pushing legislation that would bar the E.P.A. from restricting the sale of lead shot and bullets or lead sinkers.

headline: A Washington Flavor as Chicago Swears in a Mayor
text: CHICAGO — As a cast of top Washington figures looked on, Rahm Emanuel was sworn in Monday as mayor of Chicago, offering praise to the longtime mayor he succeeds but mainly promising sweeping change.

headline: In Georgia, Court Ruling Could Close Some Charter Schools
text: A ruling by the Georgia Supreme Court on Monday cast doubt on the future of 17 charter schools there, leaving thousands of families uncertain about whether classes will continue through the end of the academic year and how students will continue in the fall.

headline: The Gateses as ‘Living Sitters’
text: The new portrait of Bill and Melinda Gates commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in Washington depicts the leaders of the giant foundation bearing their name, and its work, with a respectful familiarity. Sitting on the arm of a chair with his arms crossed, Bill Gates appears supremely self-assured. Sitting slightly in front, Melinda looks confident. Over her shoulder is a video monitor showing two African girls and displaying “ALL LIVES HAVE EQUAL VALUE.” That is the credo of their foundation that addresses huge problems in American education, global health and other areas.

headline: SUNY Official in Bruno Case Takes Leave of Absence
text: ALBANY — A top official at the State University of New York accused of giving a no-show job to the daughter of former Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno agreed on Monday to take a leave of absence until his case is resolved.

headline: A Movie Premiere Just Like Hollywood Used to Make Them
text: There was the 3,000-foot red carpet (though in this case it was black) that rolled up Main Street in Disneyland, right to Frontierland. The street was lined with television cameras, correspondents and photographers. Nearly 20,000 fans, many wearing mouse ears, screamed at people they recognized, or thought they recognized. It all led to a full-blown outdoor theater, with a 3-D screen and stadium seating for 2,000 guests, built — for this night only— over a lake in the center of Disneyland.

headline: New York Investigates Banks’ Role in Financial Crisis
text: The New York attorney general has requested information and documents in recent weeks from three major Wall Street banks about their mortgage securities operations during the credit boom, indicating the existence of a new investigation into practices that contributed to billions in mortgage losses.

headline: Tough Democrats?
text: Robert Farley, left, of the University of Kentucky and Matt Duss of the Center for American Progress debate the politics of foreign policy.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 16, 2011

headline: Video: Decoding the Upfronts
text: On the outside looking in at NBC’s upfront presentation.

headline: Soriano to Have Elbow Examined
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — Rafael Soriano has been with the Yankees for an eventful four months, and his tenure took another fascinating turn Monday night after their 6-5 loss to the Tampa Bay Rays.

headline: Bob Flanigan, Four Freshmen Founder, Dies at 84
text: Bob Flanigan, a founding member of the Four Freshmen, the well-scrubbed tight-harmony group begun more than 60 years ago, when all of its members really were undergraduates, died on Sunday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 84.

headline: Pilots Avoid Jail in Brazil Crash
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A Brazilian federal judge on Monday sentenced two American pilots involved in a fatal air crash over the Amazon rain forest in 2006 to community service.

headline: Penguin’s New Imprint: Blue Rider Press
text: For six months, the new imprint at Penguin Group USA headed by David Rosenthal has remained stubbornly nameless. No longer, Mr. Rosenthal said on Monday: it will be called Blue Rider Press, a name inspired by the group of painters in early 20th-century Germany who bucked convention and promoted individual expression. “The Blue Rider name historically represents individuality and quality in the arts,” Mr. Rosenthal said in an e-mail. “And that same intent will be reflected in the eclectic fiction and nonfiction books Blue Rider Press will publish.” Mr. Rosenthal’s imprint will release its first titles in the fall, including “The New New Rules” by Bill Maher and a bedtime story parody, “Goodnight iPad.” It has also acquired books by Valerie Plame Wilson, Delia Ephron and R. A. Dickey. Mr. Rosenthal was offered his own imprint at Penguin after losing his job as publisher of the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster last summer, and joins other Penguin imprints like Riverhead Books, Portfolio and the Penguin Press.

headline: Pam Gems, British Playwright, Dies at 85
text: Pam Gems, a British playwright who, in works like “Piaf” and “Stanley,” explored the temperament of impassioned, embattled artists and politically engaged women, died on Friday in London. She was 85.

headline: Mets Score Early Run Against Marlins’ Ace, but None Off Their Bullpen
text: Carlos Beltran found a way Monday to chase Josh Johnson, the Florida Marlins pitcher and Mets tormentor. Beltran hit one of Johnson’s pitches so hard in the fifth inning that it bounced off Johnson’s right forearm, bruising it. Johnson left the game after retiring the side.

headline: On Wild Night in Flushing, Reliever Is Marlins’ Hitting Hero
text: If a player is gifted enough to make the major leagues as a pitcher, chances are he had enough athletic skill to have once been a fine hitter, too. Burke Badenhop makes no such claim.

headline: News Quiz |May 17, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Bay’s Bunts Can’t Clear Up Foggy Night for Mets
text: Jason Bay made such solid contact on a first-inning pitch from Florida righthander Josh Johnson that the ball seemed destined to soar well over the left-field wall at Citi Field. But Monday night was foggy and glum, and Bay’s majestic shot only got as far as the warning track. It was caught.

headline: BP Deal With Russian Oil Giant Collapses
text: LONDON — The disputed share swap and oil exploration agreement between BP and the Russian state-owned company Rosneft has collapsed, leaving some BP investors questioning the company’s future strategy and freeing Rosneft to look for a new partner in Russia.

text: Note To Teacher: The article contains some content that may not be appropriate for all students. Please preview the article before assigning it to your students.

headline: White House Stops Post-Speech Photo Ops
text: On Monday morning, May 2, readers of The New York Times — and newspapers around the country — could pick up the latest editions to see the face of President Obama staring back at them from Page 1 with that quiet but steely resolve that had been evident the night before. It seemed a fitting record of his announcement that Osama bin Laden had been killed by American forces.

headline: Was Manchester City’s Trophy Worth What It Cost?
text: Manchester City has a shiny new silver trophy, paid for largely with Middle Eastern gold, and a reason to beat its chest in the streets of a city long dominated by its crosstown rival. It will surely take more than an F.A. Cup triumph for Manchester City to close the gap on mighty Manchester United, but after hundreds of millions of dollars spent to build a Premier League contender, it’s something.

headline: How Do You Define Wealthy?
text: To separate the middle class from the wealthy, federal income tax policy sets the dividing line at $250,000 for family income. But some people have disputed that policy, arguing that there’s a big difference between earning a quarter of a million dollars a year – especially in a high-cost-of-living area – and earning millions or even billions. What do you think? How do you define “wealthy”? How much do you think a family needs to earn to be considered wealthy by the government?

headline: Bomb Found in Bus in Ireland Hours Before Queen Arrives
text: LONDON — Brushing aside bomb threats, Queen Elizabeth II embarked on the first visit by a reigning British monarch to the Irish Republic on Tuesday — a visit heavy on symbolism after decades of hostility and mistrust, and protected by some of the tightest security Dubliners could recall.

headline: Toshiba in Discussions to Buy Landis & Gyr
text: Toshiba is in advanced talks on a deal worth more than $2 billion to acquire Landis & Gyr, a Swiss smart-metering company, a person with direct knowledge of the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: New York Public Library Launches iPad App
text: Here an app, there an app, everywhere an apt app. Now, the New York Public Library has created a new iPad app that bring the library’s research collections into “the palms of the public’s hand,” as library officials put it in a statement released Tuesday. “Biblion: The Boundless Library” is the name for a series of apps available on Apple’s tablet computer that highlight different elements in the library’s collection. It was developed by the library and the design firm Potion.

headline: Supporters of Speed-Camera Locators Mobilize Against French Government

headline: Fantasy Focus: Moving the Needle
text: We discussed Jose Bautista a few weeks ago, but after his three-home-run night in Target Field — the hardest park in the majors to homer in last year — he was hitting .368/.520/.868, numbers approached by only two players in major league history: Barry Bonds and Babe Ruth. Bautista already has 16 home runs, leading the second-place hitter in that category, Curtis Granderson, by two. And Bautista missed eight of his team’s first 40 games.

text: Most social networking services are for sharing what you’ve done in the past or what you’re doing right now. A new one, WhereBerry, is for sharing what you want to do in the future.

headline: Pakistan’s Prime Minister Visits China
text: BEIJING — The Pakistani prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, arrived in China on Tuesday for a four-day visit, picking up some welcome diplomatic support at a critical moment in Pakistan’s relations with the United States.

headline: Trump and Huckabee Leave Boring Race Behind
text: The departure of Mike Huckabee from the 2012 presidential campaign probably means that the subject of frying squirrel meat in a popcorn popper will not come up this year.

headline: LinkedIn Raises I.P.O. Goal to More Than $405 Million
text: LinkedIn, which is set for an initial public offering on Thursday, could raise more than $405 million, up from an estimate of $315 million earlier this month, according to a regulatory filing on Tuesday.

headline: Oh, the Stuff Those Lions Guard
text: “One of the five greatest public libraries in the world” is the boast made at a new exhibition celebrating the centennial of the New York Public Library’s august building on Fifth Avenue. And if we are inclined to question the claim, it is only because the institution’s distinctiveness is scarcely suggested by putting it in a class with the Library of Congress, the British Library, the National Library of France and the Russian State Library.

headline: Blip.tv Reintroduces Itself as a Curated Video Site
text: If you think professional video shows created exclusively for the Web are difficult to find, you’re not alone. Blip.tv, a video site that specializes in Web-created shows, has heard the same complaint from its users too. To fix this problem, the company reintroduced its Web site on Tuesday with a focus on curating the best video shows for its users.

headline: Pakistan and NATO Trade Fire Near Afghan Border
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani soldiers exchanged fire with two NATO helicopters that crossed into Pakistan’s airspace from Afghanistan early Tuesday, the Pakistani Army said, as United States senators increased calls in Washington to suspend or put conditions on billions of dollars in American aid to Pakistan.

headline: The Silver Lining

But the reef under the island’s most famous wave, at Lagundri Bay, shifted up, making what surfers say was already a dream break even longer and more hollow. Go with a guide who knows the ropes, like those at the local-run Keyhole Surf Camp (niaskeyholesurfcamp.com).

headline: Tuesday Reading: Taking Measure of Weight-Loss Plans
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Umbrellas of Cherbourg’
text: In this week’s Critics’ Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Jacques Demy‘s 1964 musical “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.” The film stars Catherine Deneuve and Nino Castelnuovo as a couple in love who are separated by war. Mr. Scott calls it “one of the most romantic films ever made.” With every line of dialogue sung, the film plays more like an opera than a musical. “This is singing as conversation,” Mr. Scott says, “a way for the actors to express their emotions, simply, sincerely and with a minimum of artifice.” Yet the film itself uses the artifice of cinema to its advantage, with bright colors and an attractive cast. Have you seen “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

headline: Libyan Oil Minister Said to Defect to Tunisia
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The oil minister of Libya fled to neighboring Tunisia over the weekend, the Tunisian Interior Ministry said Tuesday, in what appeared to be another high-level defection from the increasingly isolated government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Officials in Tripoli said the oil minister was on official business outside the country.

headline: The Invisible Attack Intensifies
text: Those wily invisible bond vigilantes are at it again: as part of their cunning plan, they have driven the 10-year bond rate down to 3.11 percent.

headline: Christie Keeps Saying No to a Presidential Race, but Republicans Keep Calling
text: So many people want to talk to Gov. Chris Christie about the 2012 presidential campaign that he probably could not drop the subject if he wanted to.

headline: Agreement Will Allow a Mubarak to Be Freed
text: CAIRO — Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the ousted president Hosni Mubarak, has agreed to turn over about $4 million worth of assets to the Egyptian government in exchange for her release from detention without bail, her lawyer and Interior Ministry officials said Tuesday.

headline: Scenes From a Cannes Gala
text: CANNES, France— As expected, Terrence Malick skipped the gala premiere of his film “The Tree of Life” on Monday night, but he was in town, according to a publicist for Fox Searchlight, which is releasing the film. He attended a cast dinner after the premiere, she said, but was apparently too shy for any public festivities. “He’s like a big teddy bear,” she said. “You just want to protect him.”

headline: Pressure Eases on Mississippi River Levees
text: The opening of the Morganza Spillway has relieved pressure on levees downriver, leading the Mississippi River to crest at Baton Rouge and New Orleans on Tuesday, sooner and at lower levels than had been predicted.

headline: Jerry Lewis Will Retire From Labor Day Telethon
text: After 45 years as the spirited host of his annual Labor Day telethon to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association, Jerry Lewis said this year’s broadcast will be his last. “As a labor of love, I’ve hosted the annual Telethon since 1966,” Mr. Lewis said in a statement reported by The Associated Press, “and I’ll be making my final appearance on the show this year by performing my signature song, ‘You’ll Never Walk Alone.'”

headline: Elaine’s Is Closing
text: City Room reports that Elaine’s, the venerable Upper East Side literary saloon, will close on May 26. Elaine Kaufman, the proprietor whose name had been on the yellow marquee since 1963, died last year. Her longtime manager, Diane Becker, who inherited the restaurant, said that things weren’t the same.

headline: More Trouble in W.P.S.
text: Dan Borislow, the millionaire inventor of the magicJack voice over Internet telephone device, a thoroughbred racehorse owner and the coach of his daughter’s soccer team, has roiled the choppy waters of the struggling Women’s Professional Soccer league.

headline: Cuomo Releases Message Urging Stronger Rent Laws
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo released a video message on Tuesday in which he reaffirmed his support for the renewal and strengthening of rent regulation laws, an issue that has been largely overshadowed in recent days as the governor toured the state pressing his other legislative priorities.

headline: Libyan City Buries Its Attackers Respectfully
text: MISURATA, Libya — The gravediggers worked methodically and with few words. By now their grisly labor was a routine.

headline: Bulls Trying to Maintain Edge After Routing Heat
text: The Chicago Bulls opened the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday with a dramatic rout of the much-favored Miami Heat. Bulls fans were already happy to have their team back in the elite limelight, but getting a 103-82 win at home was icing on the cake.

headline: Race and Republican Attacks on Obama
text: Newt Gingrich did his level best to appear level in his “Meet the Press” interview Sunday, maintaining a mostly subdued, thoughtful tone except for one telling moment — when David Gregory, the host, asked him if his labeling of President Obama as the “food stamp president” might have racist connotations. “Oh, come on,” the former House speaker huffed. “That’s bizarre.” All he meant, Mr. Gingrich went on to explain, was that Mr. Obama’s policies would turn all of America into Detroit, which probably didn’t endear him to Eminem.

headline: In Misurata, Fallen Qaddafi Soldiers Receive Respect
text: At a seaside cemetery in rebel-held Misurata, the remains of Libyan government soldiers are methodically documented and buried, according to Islamic tradition, though some may never be identified.

headline: Under the Ice, Sounds of Spring

headline: Harmon Killebrew, Hall of Fame Slugger for the Minnesota Twins, Dies at 74
text: Harmon Killebrew, the Hall of Famer who developed the strength to hit home runs by lifting 10-gallon milk cans as an Idaho farmhand and grew up to be one of the most feared sluggers of his generation, died Tuesday morning at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz., four days after announcing that he was ending treatment for esophageal cancer. He was 74.

headline: Citing Safety Concerns, Vocal Group Cancels Visit to Japan
text: Not all musical groups are following the Metropolitan Opera’s lead in forging ahead with tours to post-earthquake Japan. The Collegium Vocale Gent, a highly regarded ensemble that helped open the newly renovated Alice Tully Hall two years ago, has canceled a June tour that was to have included three performances in and near Tokyo because of concerns over nuclear safety brought on by the March quake and tsunami that crippled a nuclear power plant, resulting in releases of radiation.

headline: Animal Kingdom Gallops at Fair Hill
text: It was a damp morning on Tuesday at Fair Hill. A lot of rain had fallen through the night, but we were fortunate that the rain had eased off a little for training hours. Animal Kingdom was scheduled to train at his usual time, 9 a.m., on the Tapeta track. More news media were in attendance, but the weather had scared off any fans who might have considered coming out to see the Kentucky Derby winner.

headline: Upfronts: ESPN Shows Its (Upfront) Game Face

And the ESPN upfront presentation for 2011-12, held on Tuesday morning in Times Square, was no exception.

headline: Music Library at Harvard Acquires a Trove of Solti’s Scores
text: Like most conductors, Georg Solti marked up his scores, noting tempos, voices to emphasize and the occasional cut. But he was also a prodigious reviser of his interpretations, according to scholars, leading him sometimes to acquire four or five copies of a score to note his ideas freshly each time. That has led to a large collection of scores — some 500 — that Harvard University has just received. The family of Solti, who died in 1997, donated the collection to the Loeb Music Library at Harvard, university officials said on Tuesday. “They are the most heavily marked-up scores I have ever seen,” said Virginia Danielson, the Loeb’s librarian, and a source of valuable insight into Solti’s musical thinking.

headline: The Hardest Part of Running a Restaurant
text: Rafael thanked me for offering him a dream job. A fisherman since childhood, a painter of fish by day and a server at night, he had been waiting for a sustainable seafood place in which to work. He was well-spoken and mannerly, a good listener. We talked for an hour, going over his experience, his ambitions, how he stretched his canvases. He wanted to start work immediately. We agreed he would start the next day, at noon, train and taste and get familiar with our steps of service. That was a month ago. We have not heard from Rafael since.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Leaves Rivals in the Dust
text: A two-hour installment of semifinal performances on “Dancing With the Stars” topped the ratings on Monday night as 21.4 million viewers tuned in to the ABC reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other network came close to matching ABC’s ratings, including during the 10 p.m. hour when ABC’s “Castle” (13.2 million) outperformed CBS’s “Hawaii Five-0” (9.8 million) and NBC’s “Law & Order: LA” (4.3 million).

headline: Parties in France Adjust to Changed Landscape
text: PARIS — With its presumptive presidential candidate in a New York jail awaiting resolution of sexual assault charges, including attempted rape, the Socialist Party moved on Tuesday to try to reassure its troops, while President Nicolas Sarkozy was reported to have told his party’s legislators that the arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn was a disaster for the Socialists, who had lost “the moral part of the battle for the presidency.”

headline: From Land to Sea | Ryan Burch Video
text: The California-based surfer and shaper Ryan Burch is fast gaining recognition for his iconoclastic D.I.Y. board designs and ability to ride almost any shape and size with spontaneity and grace. Here, Burch shapes from scratch a five-foot, two-inch asymmetrical board he calls the Sledgehammer.

headline: Gear Gurus
text: From the late ’80s through the early 2000s, much of surf culture was marked by homogeneity. The gear companies became behemoths, and the most popular boards (many shaped by computers) looked largely the same. In recent years, though, surfing’s zeitgeist has begun to celebrate individuality — a shift back to the homespun ethos of the sport’s early days. A surfer now is more likely to be riding a board he made himself, often a radically new shape. Even high-ranked pros are working collaboratively with their preferred shaper to come up with original, untested designs. Here, from left to right, some of the California-based gear guys who are leading the way.Mitch Abshere The owner of the Captain Fin Company produces surfboard fins and wet suits from Japanese rubber, which is especially soft, allowing for more agility (captainfincompany.com).

headline: Iran Says Missing Al Jazeera Reporter Committed Offenses
text: Iran said Tuesday that it was pursuing information about a missing Al Jazeera reporter sent to Tehran by the Syrian government in early May, saying she had committed “several offenses,” including traveling without a valid passport.

headline: Egypt Holds 136 for Israeli Embassy Protest
text: The Egyptian military could bring charges against 136 people arrested during a protest outside the Israeli Embassy in Cairo on Sunday, including two prominent bloggers.

headline: His Back Pages, Captured on Film
text: Bob Dylan will turn 70 next Tuesday — unless of course Judgment Day arrives in the meantime, an eventuality that Mr. Dylan might well take in stride. After all, the scope of his historical imagination stretches from before the flood to the end of days, and the man himself can sometimes seem to dwell outside of time altogether. Devotees who use the age of their idol to calculate their own dismaying senescence may be shocked that he is so old, but to many more of us he has always been around. He was never young. Or else he was so much older then, and he’s younger than that now.

headline: Swapping War Stories Outside a Wal-Mart
text: The musical and experimental theater — the two theatrical forms in which New York is arguably the world leader — have more in common than you might think. Currently dominated by technologically sophisticated, rigorously precise and highly self-aware productions, they are both generally more visceral than intellectual. And when something goes wrong, it’s always the book writer’s fault.

headline: Body of a Nation: Examining the Role of the Mississippi River in American History
text: Overview | What roles has the Mississippi River played throughout United States history? How has the river been central to struggles to define “America” and “American”? In this lesson, students examine what life was like on the banks of the Mississippi River during pivotal moments in American history. They will then write diary entries from the perspective of riverbank residents during different historical eras.

headline: If Men Are From Mars, It Appears That Some Women Can Be, Too

headline: Impact of Bulls’ Reserves Transcends Scoring
text: Bench success in the N.B.A. is typically measured in terms of the lowest possible denominator; the Sixth Man of the Year award typically honors the highest scoring reserve (this season’s winner, Lamar Odom, provides a rare exception), and the oft-used bench points measure inherently trumpets scoring above all else. It is telling that bench rebounds and bench assists” are nonexistent as a talking point, as reserves seem to warrant public praise only when they score sufficiently.

headline: Condé Nast Will Be Anchor of 1 World Trade Center
text: Condé Nast Publications, whose stable of magazines chronicles the American zeitgeist as meticulously as any anthropologist, has reached an agreement to lease one million square feet at 1 World Trade Center, giving ground zero a much-needed corporate anchor with a proven ability to attract other businesses.

headline: Scooter Enthusiasts Descend on Times Square
text: The New York Scooter Club held its sixth annual Block Party last weekend, and despite various barbecues and concerts packing the calendar, the unofficial highlight for the club is a nighttime cruise through Times Square.

headline: Plan a Week in Italy for the Frugal Traveler: The Rules
text: For my trip around the Mediterranean, I’m asking readers to plan a fun-filled, smartly-themed, low-budget five-day trip to somewhere on the Italian coast. It’s up to you to come up with a destination and associated theme. A multiday hike through gorgeous countryside and small towns? A lesser-known side of a much-visited tourist destination? Sampling the seafood specialties along a string of coastal villages? Anything goes, as long as you can get me there from Naples (where I’ll be the week before) and keep the budget light.

headline: The Mediterranean on a Budget: The Voyage Begins
text: On Thursday, I head to Spain to begin what sounds like a foolhardy adventure: high season in the Mediterranean on a budget. For 10 weeks, I’ll be just one soul among the gobs of tourists descending on its azure waters from around the world. Why would someone with a schedule as flexible and a wallet as light as mine want to fight the hordes of Italian and British and Norwegian and Chinese and Pennsylvanian vacationers and their affiliated bathing suit styles?

headline: A Final Season of ‘House,’ but Without Dr. Cuddy
text: Whatever final-season plans the creators of the Fox drama “House” may have had for sending the curmudgeonly and lovelorn title character off into the sunset with his boss, Dr. Lisa Cuddy, were dashed Tuesday when the actress Lisa Edelstein announced she would not return to wrap up the popular series.

headline: New York Board of Regents Approves Restrictions on Museum Sales
text: The New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday made permanent a set of emergency regulations regarding the deaccessioning of artworks. In September the Regents approved the expiration of the regulations, which enjoined museums from selling artworks for operating costs and had been in effect since 2008.

headline: Exploring Roots of Climate Stasis, and Next Steps
text: David Roberts, the Grist blogger, has written a double-barreled book review for the American Prospect that’s well worth reading. It explores “The Climate War,” Eric Pooley’s deconstruction of the long, and ultimately failed, effort to pass a comprehensive climate bill in the United States. But Roberts focuses most on David Victor‘s new book “Global Warming Gridlock,” which I’m way overdue to read. Victor, from the University of California, San Diego, has been a frequent and welcome voice on Dot Earth.

headline: U.S. Agencies Plan a Public Forum on Location Services
text: Location-based services, the mobile-phone applications that make use of a person’s geographic location, are attracting growing attention in Washington following reports that phone and software companies might have been sharing location information with third parties.

headline: Bloomberg Visits Albany to Lobby for Same-Sex Marriage
text: ALBANY — Calling same-sex marriage the single most important issue facing New York State, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday visited the Capitol and pledged to support the campaign of any Republican senator who votes in favor of allowing gay couples to wed.

headline: Fiji for All
text: Tavarua, the small, heart-shaped island in the Fijian archipelago, has two of the world’s most sought-after waves, Cloudbreak and Restaurants. Since 1984, access to them had been controlled by the Tavarua Island Resort (tavarua.com). But last year, Fiji’s military dictatorship put an end to the hotel’s exclusive rights, to the delight of local Fijians and international surfers, who have begun boating to the breaks from neighboring islands. Look for other resorts to spring up nearby and take advantage of the new access.

headline: Lincoln Center Theater  Entices a Younger Crowd
text: Lincoln Center Theater on Tuesday started a program to provide $30 seats to its performances for people ages 21 to 35, theater officials announced. The program, called LincTix, allows members to buy tickets for productions at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse Theaters at Lincoln Center, as well as to Lincoln Center Theater productions on Broadway. A limited number of LincTix will be available for every performance and available in advance. Once registered online, LincTix members (memberships are available at LincTix.org) can buy tickets for coming productions and to “War Horse,” now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (regular tickets cost $75 to $125), and to “A Minister’s Wife,” now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater (regular tickets are $85). LincTix members will also have a chance to purchase seats together with other LincTix members and will get invitations to free LincTix parties and other special events. Mem Membership includes advance notice of the $20 tickets for all LCT3 productions, which showcase the work of new playwrights, directors and designers.

headline: Interesting Rock Talk. No, Really.
text: Promotional band videos — virtually without exception — are joy vacuums. No one wants to see a musician droning on about how this new record is a break with the past/a return to his roots. Rock star, your lack of introspection is compensated by the fact that you can play guitar: no more self-analysis for you! And yet, the “electronic press kit” persists.

headline: Killebrew Was Always First With a Hello
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Harmon Killebrew’s reputation as one of the nicest and most approachable people in baseball was well deserved. He made several trips a year to the Twin Cities, and if he passed you in the hallway at the Metrodome or at Target Field, he would, without fail, say hello first. That’s just how he was.

headline: Church Report Cites Social Tumult in Priest Scandals

headline: In Cannes, an Upbeat View of the Film World
text: CANNES, France — As he sat on his balcony overlooking the Mediterranean, Dan Talbot, the celebrated founder of New Yorker Films, could have lighted every screen here with his optimism. Up close, this town can sometimes look a little grubby, the business somewhat desperate, the movies too. But on the fifth floor of the Hotel Splendid on Tuesday, as he sat taking in the bright blues of the sky and sea, the rushing festivalgoers and languidly moving rest, and even said hello to a dove perched on a railing, life looked pretty grand and so did the 64th Cannes Film Festival.
