headline: Inside Souvlaki GR
Capturing Beauty, With All Its Flaws
text: IN 2010 there were more than 12 million cosmetic procedures — from breast implants to Botox injections — performed in the United States, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Meanwhile, there is at least one mother who has injected Botox into her child, a beauty pageant contestant (as seen on “Good Morning America” last week); a steady stream of models in uneasy relationships with their body weight, and magazine layouts in which skin color and body shapes have been digitally modified.

headline: Artichoke Basics
text: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to prepare artichokes, a spring staple.

headline: A Stream of Words, Painting a Picture
text: Gather a bunch of teenagers together in a room, and usually what you sense is an abundance of hormones. But in “Louder Than a Bomb,” a documentary about a high school poetry slam of that name in Chicago, it is earnestness that is thick in the air as these young writers convene and try to shape their emotions and observations into competition-worthy poetry.

headline: Mushrooms, From Dazzling to Deadly
text: How dazzling is the world of mushrooms? The fan-shaped cinnabar oysterling looks like something you would find undersea. The violet webcap is vibrant. These are among the more than 600 fungi described and illustrated in this scholarly and beautiful book. It gives examples of cultivated mushrooms like shiitake, explains why porcini cannot be cultivated (no spores), has an interesting section on truffles and describes dozens of edible wild mushrooms. It also covers hundreds of mushrooms that are inedible or deadly poisonous.

headline: Kazakhstan: Suicide Bomber Strikes
text: Authorities in Kazakhstan were trying to determine whether a man who blew himself up on Tuesday inside a government office building in a provincial town had links to Islamic radicals. If so, it would be the first known terrorist suicide bombing in oil-rich Kazakhastan. Governments in the region, including Russia, have expressed concern that violence from the Afghan war is spreading to formerly Soviet Central Asia. The attack wounded two bystanders at a local police headquarters in the city of Aktobe. Kazakh prosecutors said it appeared that the bomber had ties to organized crime but not to radical Islamic groups.

headline: With Reactor Damage Thought to Be Worse, Tokyo Utility Sticks to Plan
text: TOKYO — Japan vowed Tuesday to stick to its goal of stabilizing a stricken nuclear power plant in as soon as six months, despite recently acknowledging that damage to the plant’s reactors might be worse than initially estimated.

headline: Can Recipe Search Engines Make You a Better Cook?
text: LET’S say you have invited four people for dinner on Saturday. It’s now Wednesday morning, and reality is setting in. On the guest list: two pescatarians, a “Top Chef” fanboy and a gluten avoider. Also, spring is in the air; local asparagus, arriving now. The challenge, as always: how to find dishes that are reliable, delicious and gastronomically correct?

headline: Google’s Most Wanted Recipes
text: Julia Moskin’s article on recipe search engines discusses some the major players in that world, including the newest member of that group: Google’s Recipe View tool.

headline: TimesCast | Wall Street's New Enforcer
text: Gretchen Morgenson discusses the investigation into three major Wall Street banks by the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: VPN for the Masses
text: If you’ve ever worked for a large (or even not so large) company, you may have encountered a virtual private network, or VPN. VPN is a technology that adds a layer of security to outside networks (like the one in your home, the airport, or a hotel room) that may not be as secure as what you have at the office.

headline: Gus Johnson Is Eager to Expand His Horizons at Fox
text: Last week, at the exact moment that the broadcaster Gus Johnson learned he would no longer call the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament, he was shooting baskets. Johnson found that a remarkable coincidence. In many ways, the tournament defined him, made him famous. His cult following had grown from his work in March.

headline: Senate Group on Debt Loses a Key Republican
text: WASHINGTON — The already weak prospects for a bipartisan debt-reduction deal this year dimmed further on Tuesday when a Republican member of the Senate’s “Gang of Six,” Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, withdrew after months of private negotiations amid differences over changes to Medicare.

headline: In Japan Reactor Failings, Danger Signs for the U.S.
text: TOKYO — Emergency vents that American officials have said would prevent devastating hydrogen explosions at nuclear plants in the United States were put to the test in Japan — and failed to work, according to experts and officials with the company that operates the crippled Fukushima Daiichi plant.

headline: How to Protect the iPad in the Kitchen
text: The tablet computer, with those wonderful apps that display recipes and color pictures, is one of the best new kitchen tools. But if you cook like Julia Child did — splashing the bouillabaisse and tossing the flour all over the counter— there is no way you’d bring it into the kitchen. An iPad, after all, doesn’t rinse off like a cutting board. Moisture is its chief enemy.

headline: Greece Has Ways to Fix Debt Woes, but All Lead to Misery
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Reviewing Gotham Bar and Grill
Gotham Bar and Grill
text: IN a city obsessed with the shiny and novel, Gotham Bar and Grill is an outlier. Open since 1984, it celebrates stability and excellence, perhaps even opulence. Fabric chandeliers billow beneath soaring ceilings. Elaborate flowers are everywhere. People dress for dinner and are escorted past marvelous photographs on the way to their tables. It is all very civilized there.

headline: Couples’ Affair, Business Edition
text: The gowns were elaborate. The Champagne was flowing. The starburst chandeliers in the Metropolitan Opera House lifted magically to the ceiling as the lights dimmed. The curtain rose smoothly, and the conductor raised his baton.

headline: New Season Opens for American Ballet Theater
text: American Ballet Theater opened its new season with gala on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House that featured 12 short performances.

headline: South African Vote May Reflect Lessening of A.N.C.’s Luster
text: SOSHANGUVE, South Africa — The crowd was black and poor, and the politician was white and well-to-do. She was onstage, gamely singing a song with Xhosa-language lyrics, and when she started to dance a few simple steps, Simon Mahlangu, a 42-year-old man looking on, nodded appreciatively and said, “She’s really not as bad you’d expect.”

headline: Treats Without Calories? Imagine That
text: I HAVE a belt of adipose tissue lodged around my middle. I’m a bumper car, protected from unwarranted bumping. Need a gently sloping shelf on which to display historical thimbles or wee porcelain Scotties? Call me. The Alford steaks, they are marbled.

headline: Farewell to 'America's Most Wanted'?
text: Brian Stelter on Fox's announcement that "America's Most Wanted" will no longer be a weekly show.

headline: Considering Next Steps for ‘Wanted’
text: Most TV shows have fans. “America’s Most Wanted” has deputies.

headline: Christo’s Colorado Project May Hinge on Sheep
text: Nearly 20 years after the artist Christo and his wife, Jeanne-Claude, proposed draping a river canyon in southern Colorado in miles of translucent fabric, a federal thumbs up or down on the project may hinge on one factor above all others: the happiness of several hundred bighorn sheep.

headline: U.S. to Extend Haitians’ Post-Quake Immigration Status
text: Haitians who received a special American immigration status after last year’s earthquake will be allowed an additional year and a half to live and work in the United States while their country struggles to recover, the Obama administration announced on Tuesday.

headline: The Mideast Conflict, Past and Present
text: To the Editor:

headline: France and the ‘Perp Walk’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spare Parts Find a Home: Waffles
text: “OFFAL and waffles” may not have the appeal of “surf and turf,” but give it time.

headline: Lasagna From Brucie to Bake at Home
text: At her rustic little restaurant, Brucie, Zahra Tangorra gives the home cook a worthy resource. Bring in your 9-by-14-inch baking pan and she will fill it with enough lasagna for 12 people, ready to bake at home, or to take away parbaked or fully cooked. As you put the bubbling pan on the table, let your guests make their assumptions about who deserves credit. Meatless lasagna, with marinara, ricotta and mozzarella, with Ms. Tangorra’s fresh pasta, was delicious, though there was a little too much sauce and cheese to cut neat portions. Ms. Tangorra, above, suggests letting it sit after baking and then reheating it. Mushroom and goat cheese lasagna, and an eggplant with Swiss chard variety, are also offered.

headline: At Nice Matin, a Wine List That Hits All the Marks
text: AS exciting as it feels to pick up a wine list already well known for its great bottles, it’s even more electrifying to have few expectations and to be knocked back in goggle-eyed surprise.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: The Gang’s All Here

headline: Chemical Suspected in Cancer Is in Baby Products
text: More than 30 years after chemical flame retardants were removed from children’s pajamas because they were suspected of being carcinogens, new research into flame retardants shows that one of the chemicals is prevalent in baby’s products made with polyurethane foam, including nursing pillows, car seats and highchairs.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Gilt Taste Arrives, With Ruth Reichl at the Helm
text: Along with selling high-end clothing and luxury travel online, the Gilt Groupe has started Gilt Taste, offering artisanal hard-to-find foods. Some are exclusive and some have been sold only to chefs. Ruth Reichl, the former editor of Gourmet magazine and former restaurant critic of The New York Times, is its editorial adviser, curating the selections, as well as editing essays, articles and recipes that will be included.

headline: British Lesson for the U.S.
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Wake of Ruling, Possibility of Progress in N.F.L. Lockout
text: N.F.L. players and owners ended a brief round of negotiations Tuesday against a landscape dramatically altered by an appeals court decision that allowed the league to continue a shutdown that threatens the start of the regular season.

headline: California: Honor for Immigrant Activist
text: The University of San Francisco will award an honorary doctorate at graduation ceremonies on Friday to an illegal immigrant, Isabel Castillo, 26, of Harrisonburg, Va., who has been a leading advocate for passage of the Dream Act. The legislation would give legal status to people like her, who were brought to the United States at a young age and went on to attend college. Ms. Castillo came to the United States from Mexico at age 6; she graduated with honors from Eastern Mennonite University. Stephen A. Privett, the president of the University of San Francisco, said he decided to award the degree after reading about Ms. Castillo in the On Education column in The New York Times earlier this year. He said the university wanted to “underscore the fundamental unfairness of our denying a path to citizenship to some of the most motivated college students in the country.”

headline: Venting Failure in the Nuclear Reactors at Fukushima Daiichi
text: The emergency vent system designed to help prevent hydrogen explosions failed to work in at least two of the three reactors in operation. Venting would have reduced the amount of hydrogen gas that accumulated in the buildings.

headline: Palestinian Authority Delays Elections
text: The Palestinian Authority said Tuesday that it was delaying local elections scheduled for July until late October in order to organize the voting in Gaza, which is controlled by Hamas. Last month, Hamas and its rival, Fatah, which dominates the Palestinian Authority, announced a surprise unity agreement. Palestinians have not held an election in five years because of a bitter split between the groups. The October poll will indicate how each party is faring as it prepares for legislative and presidential elections within a year, as called for in the unity accord.

headline: Sixth Soldier Charged in Afghan Killings
text: SEATTLE — A sixth soldier was charged Tuesday in connection with what Army prosecutors have described as the sport killings of three Afghan civilians last year, officials at Joint Base Lewis-McChord near here said.

headline: Abortion and Choice
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Legal War, a West Side Landmark May Rise
text: Since its construction in 1933, the Metro Theater on the Upper West Side has had a turbulent history. Among its numerous iterations: a pornography house, an art-house movie theater and home to two national cinema chains.

headline: A Tale of Two Teachers
text: To the Editor:

headline: PC Makers Are Seeing a Slowdown
Imagining Detroit
text: Detroit was once called the Paris of the West, but at this point it’s more reminiscent of Venice. Like Venice, its demise has been imminent for some time, as crucial businesses and huge chunks of the population flee.

headline: Top Hispanic Name Loses Ground, Even as Birthrates Stay High
text: No way, Jose!

headline: Canucks Are Falling, Sharks Are Complaining, and One Fight Is Not Happening
text: The Vancouver-San Jose series is only one game old, but the gamesmanship is already in full swing.

headline: Buffalo’s Attractions
text: To the Editor:

headline: The War in Libya’s Western Mountains
text: Video from the Nafusah Mountains of western Libya gives a glimpse of a little-seen front in the battle for control of the country.

headline: Mayor Presses Republicans In Albany on Gay Marriage
text: ALBANY — Urging lawmakers to put themselves on “the right side of history,” Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg visited the Capitol on Tuesday and vowed to support the re-election campaign of any Republican senator who votes to allow gay couples to wed.

headline: Why Be a Tree Stump When You Can Soar?
text: “My God. Look at you.” That’s what Jon-Jon Goulian’s grandfather, the political philosopher Sidney Hook, said to him while Mr. Goulian was visiting Hook’s house in Vermont during the summer of 1987. The elderly man held a rolled-up copy of Commentary magazine in one hand, as if to smack his 19-year-old grandson like a horsefly.

headline: Joseph Wershba, a Journalist Who Helped Take On McCarthy, Dies at 90
text: Joseph Wershba, who as a CBS television reporter working with Edward R. Murrow revealed the story of Lt. Milo Radulovich, whose dismissal from the Air Force because of his relatives’ leftist leanings became a symbol of the anti-Communist witch hunts of the 1950s, died on Saturday at a hospital near his home in Floral Park on Long Island. He was 90.

headline: When Mahler Took Manhattan
text: HERE’S an often overlooked bit of music history: Gustav Mahler, who died in Vienna a century ago today, was a New Yorker for the last three years of his life and, for that brief time, arguably the most famous musician in town. It’s not a trivial point — as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and then at the New York Philharmonic, he set musical standards that resonate even today.

headline: At Preakness, Not Everybody’s Idea of Fun
text: Excessive drinking at the Preakness Stakes, the second jewel of horse racing’s Triple Crown, reached its nadir in 2007 when videos of young men racing atop portable toilets in the Pimlico Race Course infield as beer cans rained on them went viral. There was safety to consider, and the threat of lawsuits loomed.

headline: As Uprisings Transform Mideast, Obama Aims to Reshape the Peace Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Six months after the Arab world erupted in a political firestorm, President Obama has been searching for ways to link the region’s historic transformation to the long-stymied peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. It is far from clear how he can do that.

headline: Maurice Goldhaber, Atomic Physicist, Is Dead at 100
text: Maurice Goldhaber, a physicist who delved into the intricacies of atoms and headed the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island for more than a decade, died last Wednesday at his home in East Setauket, N.Y. He was 100.

headline: Bibi and Barack
text: Reading the headlines from the Middle East these days — Christians and Muslims clashing in Egypt, Syria attempting to crush its democracy rebellion and Palestinians climbing over fences into Israel — you get the sense of a region where the wheels could really start to come off.

headline: Video: ‘America’s Most Wanted’ Unwanted by Fox
text: Brian Stelter discusses Fox’s announcement that “America’s Most Wanted,” a mainstay on the network for 23 years, will no longer be a weekly show.

headline: A Legacy of Insubordination
text: When he took office, Abraham Lincoln faced the greatest strategic challenge of any American president before or since: that of holding the country together as political and moral tensions that had risen steadily over the course of nearly 100 years strained mightily to tear it apart. But he also confronted a standard of civil-military relations that internalized domestic political intrigue and countenanced soldierly insubordination. Epitomized by Gen. George B. McClellan, this organizational problem was a crippling impediment for Lincoln early in the Civil War that required all of his political and psychological acumen to overcome. It was substantially a product of the Mexican War of 1846-48.

headline: Day After Contentious Remarks, Soriano Heads to Disabled List
text: The Yankees put reliever Rafael Soriano on the disabled list Tuesday, but, befitting their fortunes recently, they also dealt with a matter unrelated to his ailing right elbow.

headline: F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Lying for Lover
text: An agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation got too close to a confidential informer in a criminal investigation and is now in trouble with the law, an indictment made clear on Tuesday.

headline: President Obama and the Arab Spring
text: It should be no surprise that the ferment in the Arab world has touched the Palestinians, whose promised two-state solution is no closer than ever. On Sunday, the anniversary of Israel’s creation, thousands marching from Syria, Gaza, Lebanon and the West Bank breached Israel’s borders and confronted Israeli troops. More than a dozen people were killed; scores were injured.

headline: For States, a Glimmer of Hope on Deficits
text: From stronger-than-expected tax collections in deficit-ridden California to projected surpluses in struggling states like Michigan and Pennsylvania, a growing number of recession-weary states are finally announcing a bit of good budget news for the first time since the downturn began.

headline: Condé Nast Publications
text: FOUNDED 1909 by Condé Montrose Nast

headline: Hotel Keycard of I.M.F. Chief May Tell a Tale
text: Under siege by thieves who regularly got their hands on old-fashioned room keys, hotels in New York began using electronic locks on their doors in 1977, led by the fabled, fusty Algonquin. The new keys would be plastic, with a magnetic strip swiped through a card reader on the door.

headline: For Buyers of Web Start-Ups, Quest to Corral Young Talent
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Sam Lessin sold his Web start-up to Facebook for millions last year, and Facebook promptly shut it down. All Facebook wanted was Mr. Lessin.

headline: Flooding Takes Economic Toll, and It’s Hardly Done
text: The swollen Mississippi River, already spilling over into wide areas of the Mississippi Delta, has dealt the South a heavy economic blow that is seeping into every possible corner of the region’s commercial and agricultural life.

headline: Droit du Dirty Old Men
text: Paris

headline: In Heat’s Buddy Act, Nearly All Interviews Come With an Assist
text: CHICAGO — An unruly swarm of cameras, microphones, recording devices and elbows had engulfed Dwyane Wade when an advisory was issued from outside the tangle of humanity and technology.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,561 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

headline: Will the Banks Finally Have to Answer?
text: At long last, there may be a serious investigation into the mortgage mess — the kind that results in clarity as well as big fines and maybe even accountability.

headline: What’s Good for Workers ...
text: The refusal by Congressional Republicans to renew assistance for workers who lose their jobs to overseas competition is another instance of their callous determination to slash the budget at the expense of the most vulnerable Americans. It is also bad for American business and other constituents dearer to their hearts.

headline: Wagons North!
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg didn’t make many friends when he offered his own idea for saving Detroit, which has lost one-fourth of its population over the last decade.

headline: Curtains for Elaine’s, a Legendary New York Hangout
text: When the restaurateur Elaine Kaufman died last year, the manager who inherited her legendary restaurant on the Upper East Side said, “We’re going to try to run it as usual.”

headline: Ryan Says He Will Stay in the House
text: Representative Paul D. Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican and the chairman of the House Budget Committee, made it clear on Tuesday that he would not run for the Senate seat being vacated by Herb Kohl, a Democrat who was first elected in 1988. Instead, Mr. Ryan said he would remain in the House and lead the Republican fight over the budget and the national debt. “Our nation is quickly approaching a debt crisis that will do serious damage to Wisconsinites and all Americans if it is not properly addressed,” Mr. Ryan said in a statement on his Web site. “I believe continuing to serve as chairman of the House Budget Committee allows me to have a greater impact in averting this debt-fueled economic crisis than if I were to run for the United States Senate.”

headline: Up Front: Tom Carson
text: The critic Tom Carson has written about music, books, television and film for publications as diverse as The Village Voice and GQ.

headline: Albert Brooks's First Novel
text: Albert Brooks has written his first novel, “2030.” The Book Review’s editor, Sam Tanenhaus, interviews the acclaimed actor, screenwriter and director about the art of writing fiction.

headline: Albert Brooks’s Dark Vision of the Future
text: As a comedian and filmmaker, the very gifted Albert Brooks has specialized for more than 30 years in cooking up quandaries with no ready solution except humiliation. His often ingenious first novel is no exception to that rule. In the future America of “2030,” the national debt has long since surpassed the gross national product. Why anyone would want to be president is “more and more of a mystery.” On the rosy side — well, sort of — a cure for cancer has been found, turning the man who did it, Dr. Sam Mueller, into a billionaire and a guru.

headline: Officer in Rape Trial May Have Convinced Himself of Relationship, Prosecutor Says
text: When a police officer had sex with a woman in her East Village apartment, a Manhattan prosecutor said Tuesday, he may actually have felt he was doing nothing wrong.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Yale Restricts a Fraternity for Five Years
text: A Yale fraternity whose alumni include both President Bushes has been banned from conducting any activities on campus for five years, including recruiting, as punishment for an episode last October in which members led pledges in chants offensive to women, the university announced on Tuesday.

headline: Atop I.M.F., Contradiction and Energy
text: Artful politician that he is, Dominique Strauss-Kahn has a keen sense for not just his strengths but also his potential weaknesses — though few would be quite as blunt in saying so.

headline: Powerful and Primitive
text: WASHINGTON

headline: American Coach Finds Success in Guatemala
text: ANTIGUA, Guatemala — A gem of a town nestled in the central Guatemalan highlands, Antigua attracts plenty of Americans. They come for all sorts of reasons — to see the ruins of this one-time Central American capital, to climb the picturesque volcanoes that surround the city, and to get a taste of a region known as the land of eternal spring.

headline: Wednesday: Cubic Rubik
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — The subject of today’s puzzle passed away recently, and this is a fine tribute to him by David J. Kahn, as it is chock full of his work.

headline: Assembly Leader Seeks to Keep Millionaires’ Tax
text: ALBANY — The millionaires’ tax may be on its way back. Or so Democrats in the State Assembly hope.

headline: Cavs Get the No. 1 Pick and a Rebuilding Boost
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — The Ping-Pong balls danced to a karmic rhythm at Tuesday’s N.B.A. lottery by delivering two of the top four selections to the Cleveland Cavaliers, who nearly a year ago lost LeBron James to free agency in a harbinger of their humbling regular season.

headline: Programming for Latinos
text: Fox Hispanic Media and Mun2, part of the Telemundo network, showed their upcoming slate of programs for Spanish-language viewers.

headline: Wright’s Injury Prompts Series of Moves by Mets
text: Two hours before they were scheduled to face the Florida Marlins at Citi Field Tuesday night, the Mets announced the game was canceled because of inclement weather. The news was met with some amusement in the clubhouse, considering there was plenty of sun peeking through the clouds at the time.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Yankees Snap Losing Streak, Quieting Concerns Along Way
text: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — In the hours before Tuesday’s game, the Yankees were worried enough about their slumping cleanup hitter, Alex Rodriguez, that they wondered whether something was physically wrong with him. The hitting coach Kevin Long said Rodriguez was failing to incorporate the lower half of his body into his swing, that he had lost the explosiveness the Yankees saw from him during spring training and in early April.

headline: Boehner and Catholics
text: To the Editor:

headline: TV Steps Up Pitch to Hispanic Market
text: AS television executives peddle their coming programs to advertisers this week, before the start of the 2011-12 season, their sales spiels are taking on a decided Spanish accent.

headline: With Time Slipping Away, N.B.A. and Players Plan to Meet
text: SECAUCUS, N.J. — The N.B.A. and the players union are meeting with greater frequency as time dwindles for reaching a new labor agreement and avoiding the league’s first lockout since 1998.

headline: Goldman No Longer Laps the Field
text: Goldman Sachs has lost its luster. The firm earned a best-in-class reputation for its history of profitability and navigating upheaval. But it seems less assured lately. In fact, Goldman is in danger of looking downright average.

headline: Drug Study a Setback for Abbott
text: A study has suggested that an anticholesterol drug, TriLipix, does not protect against heart attacks or strokes better than a generic medicine, according to a report released on Tuesday. As a result, uses of the drug, made by Abbott Laboratories, may be limited in the United States or be subject to more testing.

headline: Seguin’s Breakout Night Helps Bruins Tie Series
text: BOSTON — The solution to what was ailing the Boston Bruins was right there in their dressing room all along: the highly regarded but underused 19-year-old rookie center, Tyler Seguin.

headline: European Container Shipping Lines Are Raided by Antitrust Officials
text: European antitrust officials raided several of the world’s largest container shipping companies over possible collusion, the European Commission said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Oaktree Plans Initial Public Offering
text: Oaktree Capital Management is planning to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, the latest private investment firm to tap the public markets.

headline: Video From the Upfronts: Spanish-Language Programming on the Rise
text: As Stuart Elliott and Tanzina Vega reported, the continuing growth of the Spanish-speaking population shown by the 2010 census is not going unnoticed by media and marketers. This year’s upfront week features presentations from as many Spanish-language programmers as there are from English-language broadcasters. This video takes a look at some of the shows pitched to advertisers. Executives also discuss the goals and spirit of their programs.

headline: Senate Refuses to End Tax Breaks for Big Oil
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Tuesday blocked a Democratic proposal to strip the five leading oil companies of tax breaks that backers of the measure said were unfairly padding industry profits while consumers were struggling with high gas prices.

headline: Diabetic? Ford May Have an App for That
text: While driving recently along the Ventura Freeway in Los Angeles, I watched a driver drift across traffic and settle at the shoulder of the road. Other drivers pulled over, exited their vehicles and began slapping the car’s windows in an effort to arouse the motorist, who was slumped over the wheel. I do not know the driver’s fate, as I was traveling in the leftmost lane.

headline: The True Cost of Carbon
text: Michael Greenstone and Adam Looney, economists at The Hamilton Project, are releasing a new paper Wednesday on the costs of American energy policy. They argue:

headline: The Body Weight-Muscle Mismatch
text: Recently scientists at Penn State sewed tiny weighted vests and slipped them around the middles of healthy laboratory rats, hoping to discover how animals’ muscles respond to changes in body size. The vests increased the animals’ weight by as much as 36 percent. After five days, the scientists found that the rats’ muscles contained increased amounts of certain proteins involved in the generation of muscle force. The muscles were redesigning themselves to be stronger.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: A Toothache and Slurred Speech
text: May 19 9:39 a.m. | Thanks for all your submissions! You can find the correct diagnosis in “Think Like a Doctor: A Toothache and Slurred Speech Solved!”

headline: Photo Replay: May 17
text: A view of the day in sports, from the waters of Brazil to baseball fields in the United States.

headline: Word of the Day | dowdy
text: dowdy •\ˈdau̇-de\• adjective

headline: Nowitzki Scores 48 as Mavericks Show Experience, Not Their Age
text: DALLAS — As the oldest team in the N.B.A. playoffs, the Dallas Mavericks have embarked on a farewell tour of sorts, as if they were aging rock stars refusing to stop the music. Tuesday night, they hit virtually every note and rolled the Oklahoma City Thunder, 121-112, to take a 1-0 lead in the Western Conference finals.

headline: Jim Toomey's Cousteau Memories
text: Jacques Cousteau's granddaughter asked fans to send in 100-second film shorts honoring her grandfather and explaining what he meant to them.

headline: Checkpoint in Pakistan Is Stormed By Militants
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — More than 100 militants stormed a Pakistani security post close to this provincial capital on Tuesday night, one of the heaviest attacks in recent months, a senior police official said.

headline: Dirty Politics: From Halls of Power to Hotel Suites
text: Had the sexual assault charges against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, never surfaced, “The Good Wife” would have invented them. It is easy to imagine that the writers are already mining a story from his ugly circumstances for a forthcoming script. (And then moving on to an episode about Arnold Schwarzenegger.) The details would change — the nationality of the accused might shift from French to Italian; the I.M.F. might become the Fund for Global Monetary Alliance; the New York hotel suite where the police said the attack took place might become a hospital room in Chicago.

headline: Libya Releases Journalists It Held for Weeks
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Four foreign journalists held for several weeks by the Libyan government were released on Wednesday and taken to a Tripoli hotel, with government officials saying they would be provided with transport to a border crossing with Tunisia on Thursday.

headline: Stupid Stimulus Tricks
text: So there’s another the-stimulus-didn’t-work paper (pdf) making the rounds, and as usual being seized on by people who have no idea what the issues are with this kind of estimation.

headline: Daily Lexeme: Zenocratically
text: Today’s word, in association with the singular Oxford English Dictionary, is

headline: News Quiz | May 18, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Two Different Organizations
text: A commenter writes, in response to this post,

headline: Think of the Children
text: One of the favorite lines of austerians is to claim that they’re concerned, above all, with the future prospects of our children. Paul Ryan says it all the time. So a couple of interesting points:

headline: Clashes on Israel’s Border
text: Note: Today’s 6 Q’s About the News pulls from multiple Times sources to help students understand the basics of this complex topic. Each question links to a resource in which they can find an answer, including the Times Topics page that features a short overview of power divide in the Palestinian territories. In some cases the link will take students directly to the page or paragraph from which the information comes.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, May 18, 2011
text: Test your math skills with today’s question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the graphic that accompanied the article “Lost in the School Maze.”

headline: ROR

headline: Beauty’s Sharp Edges
text: Nino Muñoz has an unusual perspective to offer on Gisele Bündchen. Unaltered.

headline: Was Common a Good Choice for White House Poetry Night?
text: Last week, the performer Common took part in a poetry event at the White House hosted by the first lady, Michelle Obama, prompting criticism from some who believe he should not have been invited. They contend that some of Common’s lyrics about should make him ineligible for such an honor. What do you think about Common’s participation in the White House event?

headline: Queen Elizabeth Visits Irish Massacre Site
text: LONDON — On the second day of a visit to the Irish Republic, Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday visited the site of a massacre more than 90 years ago that still evokes memories of fierce hostilities between Ireland and Britain.

headline: In Prague, Celebrating the Richness of Romani
text: The rhythmic, pulsating sounds of brass and rich voices, a film premiere and a wedding reconstruction are all part of the festive week of Khamoro in Prague. Now in its 13th year, the Khamoro Festival, which runs from May 22 to 28, aims to show the richness of Romani culture, and contribute to the integration of Roma into society, while also encouraging the improvement of relations between the Romani community and Czech society.

headline: The Early Word: Scandal
text: Today’s Times

headline: Digging Deeper Into What Caused Job Losses
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

headline: Q&A: Twitter Posts, Public and Private
text: Q.

headline: Adaptive Bombshells
text: Tim Harford, a columnist for The Financial Times, has a book out this month, “Adapt: Why Success Always Starts With Failure.” It’s an argument about the virtues — and necessity, really — of trial and error. In his words, there are three essential steps: “to try new things, in the expectations that some will fail; to make failure survivable, because it will be common; and to make sure that you know when you’ve failed.” It sort of seems like common sense, but the book’s wealth of fascinating case studies shows just how uncommon and difficult it often is for people and institutions to follow such a program.

headline: H.P. Dodges a Thunderbolt
text: Hewlett-Packard, the world’s largest personal computer manufacturer, announced Tuesday that it would not be installing Intel’s new Thunderbolt I/O connections on its desktop computers. The company said it would continue fitting USB 3.0 connections to its machines.

headline: A Mississippi Town’s Holdouts Wait Out the Flood at the Bar
text: EAGLE LAKE, Miss. — If you need to get ahold of somebody here, this is how.

headline: Are We Cutting Fat or Bone?
text: I have spent many years focusing on how to increase revenue in my custom picture-framing business. Much of what we’ve done has worked, and the business is now roughly 20 times the size of the average framing shop in America. Lately, however, because of the economy, the housing crisis, and other factors, the framing industry has shrunk, and I now spend quite a bit of time looking for cost reductions.

headline: Preakness TV Coverage
text: The NBC Sports Group will not televise the post position draw ahead of the Preakness Stakes as it did for the Kentucky Derby. Instead, HRTV will broadcast the draw from Pimlico Race Course at 5 p.m. Eastern on Wednesday as part of its “Pursuit of the Crown” show. On Friday, the Animal Kingdom extravaganza will begin in earnest.

headline: Raccoon Peekaboo
Can Newt Gingrich Control Newt Gingrich?
text: The problem for Newt Gingrich does not appear to be a lack of self-awareness. But self-awareness is not the same thing as self-control.

headline: Even Offstage, Lady Gaga’s Ready for the Stage
text: EVEN for a rehearsal, Lady Gaga dresses up. She was preparing to headline the annual gala for the Robin Hood Foundation, a gathering of 4,000 of New York City’s richest people to benefit antipoverty programs, in a ballroom at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on May 9.

headline: Brad Pitt Discusses ‘The Tree of Life’
text: CANNES, France — At the Cannes Film Festival, the world capital of auteur cinema, “The Tree of Life” was greeted with the sense of occasion befitting a Terrence Malick movie. But for much of the assembled media at this glamour-hungry event, it was also — and perhaps more to the point — a Brad Pitt movie. In fact, a good number of journalists left the film’s Monday morning press screening early to get in line for the news conference, where Mr. Pitt was the star attraction. (Mr. Malick, as expected, was not there.)

headline: Bloomberg Lobbies for Gay Marriage. Well, It Couldn’t Hurt.
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went to Albany to ask that lawmakers make it possible for gay couples to marry in New York State. Naturally, advocates of same-sex marriage applauded him. They might just as easily have said, “Uh, oh.”

headline: Blogging Morgan Stanley’s Annual Meeting
text: There was no shortage of good topics on which shareholders can grill Morgan Stanley’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, at the firm’s annual meeting on Wednesday in Purchase, N.Y.

headline: Upfronts: CBS Adds Three Dramas, Two Sitcoms for Fall
text: From a position of strength, CBS is adding three dramas and two sitcoms to its prime-time schedule in the fall, and is moving several of its established franchises to new time slots.

headline: Follow Their Nose
text: If there is a place that the name Astier de Villatte conjures, it is most definitely Paris. For 15 years, Ivan Pericoli and Benoît Astier de Villatte have been creating furniture and wonderfully goopy, overglazed ceramics which they sell from their charming shop on the rue Saint Honoré. But when the two set out to create a new collection of candles, they broadened their horizons, following their noses — in their imaginations, at least — to far flung places like Brasilia and Kobe. Of the 20 different destination-oriented scents, created in collaboration with the fragrance company Takasago, some might seem vaguely familiar: Naples, for example, is a bouquet of “almond, orange blossom, and Ylang-Ylang, lightened by a refreshing touch of petitgrain and neroli.” Alcatraz, on the other hand (“Indian blond tobacco, yerba maté with its notes of dried hay, smoked lignum vitae and cinnamon spiced with black pepper”) seems to have been conjured not from an actual three-hour tour but a dream. And what is the smell of home? Rue Saint Honoré is described as a powdery cloud in which a few delicate green notes and a jasmine rose accord merge deliciously with the amber and leather atmosphere.

headline: You’ve Got to Start Somewhere: A Climate Prescription
text: Hoping to find a way around the current political impasse on climate change and energy policy, a former top adviser to President Obama has devised a policy proposal to drive down greenhouse gas emissions from the utility industry over the next 20 years.

headline: The Hot-Money Cowboys of Baghdad
text: “My friend, Iraq is a rich, virgin country!” one of its richest men, Namir al-Akabi, told me with a startling enthusiasm when I met him earlier this year at his office in Baghdad. Akabi is the chairman of the Almco Group of Companies, a conglomerate he built from nothing in the wake of the American invasion in 2003. What makes Iraq’s economic potential so great, he explained, despite everything, is not just its abundant natural resources — it is the shattered state of Iraq itself: the damage done by the American war, but also the long, steady decay under Saddam Hussein, from the war with Iran that began in 1980 through the invasion of Kuwait a decade later and the crushing international sanctions that followed the first gulf war. The country has been decimated, and therein lies its potential.

headline: Barbaro: Getting Ready for the Derby
text: Alex Brown, a regular contributor to The Rail, is author of the newly published “Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy.” In this excerpt, he describes Barbaro’s preparations before his dazzling performance in the Kentucky Derby.

headline: The Hiroshima Files
text: Two months after an atomic bomb destroyed Hiroshima, President Harry S. Truman commissioned a study of the damage done to the city.

headline: Allstate Buys Insurance Businesses for $1 Billion
text: 2:58 p.m. | Updated The Allstate Corporation said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire two insurance businesses from the White Mountains Insurance Group for about $1 billion.

headline: Huntsman Chooses Orlando for 2012 Headquarters
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is a former governor of Utah. He now lives in Washington. But the site of his presidential campaign — if he jumps into the race next month — will be in Florida.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Fewer Emergency Rooms As Need Rises
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

headline: A Pause, to Give Thanks
text: I am an exceptionally average pool player. When faced with a game of billiards, I turn mediocrity into an art form, spinning with my cue a beautiful tapestry of mild competence.

headline: Reaction to ‘The Good Wife’ Finale: Your Questions Answered
text: Let’s get right down to the brass tacks of the the season finale of “The Good Wife” on Tuesday. (Those who haven’t yet watched and intend to, read no further; those who’d like a broader look at the whole season see my Critic’s Notebook here.)

headline: Philip Roth Wins Man Booker International Prize in Disputed Decision
text: Calling him the “most decorated living American writer,” a panel named Philip Roth the winner of the Man Booker International Prize on Wednesday, an honor awarded every two years to an author for extraordinary work in fiction.

headline: A Handmade Tale
text: “I wanted to do something with my hands,’’ says James Roberts, explaining how he became a shoemaker. Together with Thom Grogan, Roberts owns Captains of Industry, a ‘‘gentlemans outfitter and cafe’’ in Melbourne, Australia. Grogan, who runs the bespoke-suiting side of the business, thinks the Internet Age has inspired a craving for things that aren’t mass-produced. ‘‘People are getting pretty sick of being anonymous online and just buying stuff through online stores,’’ he says. ‘‘They want interaction.’’ Roberts and Grogan don’t stop at shoes and jams: they even make their own thread from scratch. ‘‘It’s kind of relaxing,’’ Roberts says, ‘‘if all goes well.’’ View interactive feature >>

headline: Kitchen Coverup
text: On Gadgetwise, Damon Darlin presents a few new ways to keep iPads and other tablet computers clean and neat while you’re cooking. His favorite is Chef Sleeve, a clear plastic envelope that costs less than a buck and lets you use the touch screen with greasy fingers. Plus its box doubles as an iPad stand.

headline: X-Ray Scan Reveals 513 Migrants in 2 Trucks
text: When police ran X-ray scanners over two cargo trucks at a checkpoint in southeastern Mexico on Tuesday, they made a surprising discovery: Inside the trailer were the ghostly shadows of 513 migrants — some suffering from dehydration — packed together in near-suffocating conditions.

headline: Overseer of 9/11 Health Fund Is Chosen
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday chose a special master to administer a multibillion-dollar fund created to provide compensation to rescue workers and others sickened from exposure to toxic fumes, dust and smoke from ground zero after the 2001 terrorist attack.

text: My colleagues Hiroko Tabuchi, Keith Bradsher and Matthew Wald report on the front page of Wednesday’s Times on a critical failure that led to the explosions at the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, after the earthquake and tsunami in March.

text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: What to Know When Traveling With Your Pet
text: SUMMER vacation is no longer just for two-legged travelers. Room service menus for Fido, massages for over-stressed terriers and tabbies, cushy beds for canines: many hotels have been ratcheting up the pet amenities. Best Western has even hired Cesar Millan of National Geographic Channel’s “Dog Whisperer” to be the chain’s pet travel expert.

text: Felix Salmon reads Ben Stein defending Strauss-Kahn. Better him than me.

headline: Cousteau Cousins Pitch Water Issues
text: Few environmental legends rival Jacques Cousteau, who died in 1997, for his energy, charisma, popularity and skills as an educator. This week, two of his granddaughters stopped by The New York Times. Alexandra and Céline Cousteau, cousins, did not seem to know each other’s schedule but were on the same wavelength in some other respects.

headline: For Iraqis and U.S. Troops, a Question Is Still Unanswered
text: UMM QASR, Iraq — Wherever American military leaders turn in Iraq, they are peppered with a question they don’t seem to be able to answer: Will the United States keep its troops in Iraq after 2011?

headline: With 700 E.V.’s to Lease, BMW Announces Charging Partner for U.S. Market
text: BMW will lease 700 ActiveE electric cars, which are based on the 1 Series coupe, in the United States beginning this year. On Wednesday, the automaker announced a partnership to ensure that customers have a place to plug in.

headline: Eventbrite Raises $50 Million to Tackle Ticketmaster
text: Eventbrite, a ticketing start-up based in San Francisco, got its start by offering to help any event organizer peddle tickets — whether it be for a yoga class or an indie comedy show.

headline: Mex It Up
text: The globe-trotting surferati have been quietly colonizing Mexico’s Pacific coast for years. Alongside cheap and cheery beach shacks, you now find famous artists hanging out in French bistros. But not all is spoiled; the stretch of coastline from Acapulco to Puerto Vallarta offers a range of surf towns, from established to emerging. Pick your paradise.

headline: The Twitter Trap
text: Last week my wife and I told our 13-year-old daughter she could join Facebook. Within a few hours she had accumulated 171 friends, and I felt a little as if I had passed my child a pipe of crystal meth.

text: It used to be that the children were off limits.

headline: Bedtime Books for Boys
text: Bedtime stories are charged with the mighty, sometimes seemingly insurmountable task of quieting and perhaps even inducing an audience to slumber. At the very least, they’re meant to compel the intended listener, say, a 4-year old boy, to stop somersaulting off the bunk bed and to please, please sit down. (That this process is often fraught with irritation has recently been showcased by a forthcoming children's-book parody, “Go the — to Sleep,” by Adam Mansbach and Ricardo Cortés, whose appearance online ricocheted among parental Twitterers like the answer key to next week’s S.A.T. exam.)

headline: Sex-Assault Case Puts Focus on Police Unit, Not Quite as Seen on TV
text: In some ways, last weekend was not especially remarkable for the New York Police Department’s Special Victims Squad. About 30 new cases came in, typical for the citywide unit of 190 specially trained investigators and supervisors.

headline: W.T.O. Ruling on Airbus Subsidies Upheld on Appeal
text: A World Trade Organization appeals panel on Wednesday upheld a ruling that Boeing lost market share to its European rival, Airbus, as a result of billions of dollars in low-cost government loans, according to European and American officials.

headline: In ‘Earth v. Humanity,’ Nobelists Issue Verdict
text: 12:40 p.m. | Updated Now here’s a new way to get the public to heed a warning: Hold a trial in Stockholm in which planet Earth is the plaintiff, humanity the defendant and a panel of Nobel Prize winners the jury, then issue a verdict centered on a to-do list including fundamentally unachievable goals (stabilizing global emissions of carbon dioxide by 2015, for starters).

headline: Turner to Ad Executives: Please Stand By
text: Turner Broadcasting, aiming to make a splash in the middle of the broadcast network upfront week, fell quite a bit short on Wednesday when its upfront presentation became a disaster of epic technical proportions.

headline: Freight Elevator Plunge Injures 22
text: Updated, 6:42 p.m. | A freight elevator being used illegally as a passenger elevator plunged at least three stories in a Flatiron district building Wednesday morning, injuring nearly two dozen people, the authorities said.

headline: In His Dreams? Not Quite. David Hyde Pierce Plans His Directing Debut
text: After 11 seasons spent playing the Jungian analyst Niles Crane on “Frasier” and a parallel career on the stages of Broadway productions including “Monty Python’s Spamalot,” “Curtains” and “La Bête,” David Hyde Pierce, the Emmy and Tony Award-winning actor is ready for a change of scenery. He’ll be sitting in the front of the house when he makes his directorial debut with “It Shoulda Been You,” a musical comedy that will be presented at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., this fall.

headline: Sleep Loggers, Take Two
text: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

headline: Hey, Mr. Critic!

headline: In Paris, a Fly-Through of the Ralph Lauren Collection
text: At the Musée des Arts Décoratifs in Paris, selections from the car collection of Ralph Lauren, the American fashion designer, are on view through Aug. 28.

headline: Rating Agencies Face Crackdown
text: Alex Wong/Getty ImagesMary L. Schapiro, the Securities and Exchange Commission chairwoman.

headline: Upfronts: Discovery Ups the Stakes in Hispanic Media
text: To underscore the priority that Discovery Communications says it is placing on Hispanic viewers, the president and chief executive, David Zaslav, made a herculean effort to attend the Discovery U.S. Hispanic upfront presentation at the Four Seasons restaurant in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday.

headline: A NATO Raid Sets Off a Deadly Afghan Protest
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A normally peaceful northern city erupted in violence on Wednesday, as thousands of protesters clashed with security forces after a NATO night raid that local officials claim killed four civilians. NATO defended the night operation and said the four people who were killed, two of them women, were armed insurgents who fired on its troops.

headline: Another Month, Another Home
text: For five years, Jim Casparie pleaded with his parents, Robert and Virginia Casparie, to accept more help. His father, then 91, had Alzheimer’s disease, and his mother, 84, had diabetes and poor balance, falling frequently. When they finally agreed to move to an independent living apartment in 2008, Mr. Casparie, 61, an investment banker, thought at last he could stop worrying about their safety.

headline: Air Force One Lands Safely After Circling
text: Amid poor visibility and a light rain, Air Force One had a missed approach before landing safely at Bradley International Airport near Hartford on Wednesday morning, White House officials said.

headline: Widow of Madoff Son to Write Memoir
text: A member of the Madoff family is telling all in a memoir to be released in December, its publisher said on Wednesday. Stephanie Madoff-Mack, the widow of Mark Madoff, the son of Bernard L. Madoff who committed suicide last year, sold her book to Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: Best Wishes Turn Middling
text: FORGETTING a friend’s birthday used to be uncomplicated. The excuse would be made, the gaffe forgiven. But among the many changes wrought by Facebook, the site’s ritual birthday reminders — those jolly alerts on the edge of that blue-and-white screen — have rendered old rules moot.

headline: Extending Credit Card Protections to Small Business Users
text: Each month, Americans get more than 10 million business credit card pitches in their home mailboxes. The cards are aimed at small businesses and sole proprietors, but they generally lack the new protections that apply to consumer cards, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts says.

headline: Improving the View at the Beach
text: OUR guarantee: 10 seconds after putting on a pair of Orlebar Brown swim trunks, you will immediately lose your muffin top, develop a six-pack and instantly bear an uncanny resemblance to the smooth god-beings in the accompanying photograph.

headline: Performance Art and Immigrant Rights
text: Tania Bruguera, an artist, works to address issues facing illegal immigrants.

headline: An Artist’s Performance: A Year as a Poor Immigrant
text: Tania Bruguera has eaten dirt, hung a dead lamb from her neck and served trays of cocaine to a gallery audience, all in the name of art. She has shown her work at the Venice Biennale, been feted at the Pompidou Center in Paris and landed a Guggenheim fellowship.

headline: Wishful Wedges and the Energy Quest
text: 10:02 p.m. | UpdatedRob Socolow of Princeton University is quoted by National Geographic as saying the popular “wedges” approach to charting climate progress that he proposed with his colleague Stephen Pacala in 2004 was misused by climate campaigners to overstate the ease with which the world could cut tens of billions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide emissions out of its energy menu.

headline: Cannes Q. and A.: Nanni Moretti on Tackling Big Game
text: CANNES, France— Outspoken in interviews and in his offscreen role as a political activist, the Italian writer, director and actor Nanni Moretti tends to take a lighter touch in his films. “Habemus Papam” (“We Have a Pope”), screening in the official competition at the Cannes Film Festival, concerns a newly elected pope named Melville (the French actor Michel Piccoli), whose existential panic attack prompts the cardinals to call in a psychoanalyst (Mr. Moretti). But while the shrink is sequestered at the Vatican, the pope goes on a walkabout through the streets of Rome, rekindling an old love of acting as he stumbles into a theater production of Chekhov’s “Seagull.”

headline: Test Head
text: Test description text.

headline: Can Batteries Replace Power Generators?
text: When the Long Island Power Authority said last summer that it was going to need new power capacity in the next few years, most people assumed that meant new generating stations or new transmission cables. But of the 16 companies that submitted proposals, one, AES Energy Storage, took an entirely different tack: it proposed batteries.

headline: Fate Hands Cavaliers the No. 1 Overall Pick
text: There is a salty New York flavor to the New Jersey narrative of Kyrie Irving, who made the 20-minute drive from his home in West Orange to the N.B.A. Entertainment studio in Secaucus on Tuesday night and landed with both feet inside a made-for-television draft lottery drama.

headline: Maggie Gyllenhaal to Replace Streep in Reading of Play About Marie Curie
text: Citing a scheduling conflict, Meryl Streep has dropped out of a reading of Alan Alda’s new play about Marie Curie at the World Science Festival gala at Alice Tully Hall on June 1. Maggie Gyllenhaal, whose most recent appearance on a New York Stage was in “Three Sisters,” is taking on the role of that pioneering scientist in “Radiance: The Passion of Marie Curie” at the fund-raising event. Bob Balaban is directing the reading, which will also feature Amy Adams, Bill Camp, Allison Janney, David Morse, Liev Schreiber and Brent Sexton.

headline: The Morning Line: Full Field for Preakness, Minus Nehro
text: The lead story on the Triple Crown trail is the decision of the owner Amed Zayat not to enter his horse Nehro in the Preakness. Nehro finished second in the Kentucky Derby. Zayat’s racing manager said in the New York Post, “The main decision came down to Mr. Zayat feeling it was a little much to ask the horse to run four great races in an eight-week time frame.”  Zayat told the Daily News, “”I let my horse tell me what the next step is. In the last six weeks he’s run a lot. I’ve got to be kind to him. Patience rewards you. I don’t want to get my ego involved. You do what is right by the horse.”

headline: Setsuden
text: Japanese term for “energy saving,” which became a buzzword after the March 11 earthquake and tsunami.

headline: Sex and the Politician
text: David Brooks: Gail, can I talk to you about that hoary old intersection between private life and politics?

headline: What’s Wrong and What’s Right With These Web Sites?
text: One thing I’ve learned over the years is that the quality of a Web site depends as much on the quality of the design and the effectiveness of the messaging as it does on the amount of money invested in technology and features. That’s why there are lots of major companies that have invested millions in their online business but have Web sites that fail miserably.

headline: Tiny Treasures | Missbibi’s Dollhouse Gems
text: At 43 square feet, Missbibi, the recently opened jewelry store in Paris’s Palais Royal, is so small, if you blink on your way down the arcade you might miss it. This suits Brigitte Giraudi, 34, who is known as Miss Bibi, just fine. “I’ve always appreciated small, delicate, beautifully made things,” says the jeweler, who turned from stop-motion animation and miniature model construction to sautoirs and broaches. Oddly enough it was Giraudi’s fascination with dollhouse furniture that spurred her move to jewelry.

headline: China’s Rich Try to Fly Around Red Tape
text: WENZHOU, China — Here in this smoggy coastal metropolis, the nouveau-riche heart of entrepreneurial China, the latest sign that one has really made it is not a Benz, or even a Bentley. It is a helicopter. Perhaps 10 of Wenzhou’s super-rich have one.

headline: Jazz at Noon Is Closing Out a 46-Year Run
text: Leslie Lieber wants to make it clear: His age is not the issue.

headline: Lars von Trier Kicks Ups a Cannes Controversy
text: CANNES, France — It wouldn’t be a film festival without a little controversy. On Wednesday at the Cannes Film Festival, the director Lars von Trier caused a media firestorm when, at a news conference for his film “Melancholia,” he seemed to sympathize with Hitler.

headline: The Lessons of Gingrich v. Ryan
text: There are two obvious ways to look at the firestorm that greeted Newt Gingrich’s criticisms of the Ryan budget, and the humiliating walkback that quickly followed. From one perspective, it’s a sign that Gingrich is hopelessly out-of-touch with his own party’s newfound seriousness about tackling entitlements. Thus Pete Wehner:

headline: Cast Adrift in the Milky Way, Billions of Planets, All Alone
text: Is the galaxy full of orphans?

headline: Harsh Light on Two Men, but Glare Falls on Women
text: A flotilla of TV news trucks was stationed outside a Bronx apartment building this week, as photographers scrambled to get a shot of the hotel cleaning woman who accused the managing director of the International Monetary Fund of sexually assaulting her. Inside, reporters fired questions at her neighbors: Was she good-looking? Did she pay her rent on time? What was her behavior like?

headline: Darby Downstairs
text: THE Darby, a seven-month-old supper club that occupies the former Nell’s space, quietly opened a subterranean lounge in April, trying to recapture some of the spot’s old magic. Called the Darby Downstairs, the basement bar (with a separate entrance) is run by Richie Akiva, Ronnie Madra and Scott Sartiano — night-life veterans who operate Butter and 1Oak, which cater to bankers and models.

headline: Safety Agency Cracks Down on Novelty Motorcycle Helmets
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has revised its labeling for new motorcycle helmets.

headline: Caucus | Obama and the Middle East
text: The Times's Mark Landler in Washington and David Kirkpatrick in Cairo report on President Obama's challenges ahead of a speech tomorrow on the Middle East.

headline: Now Remapping His Life
text: A WHITE cockatoo named Koko rested on the shoulder of Florent Morellet, its blood-curdling shrieks punctuating Mr. Morellet’s raspy French accent. In all his years in New York he never had a pet, until one day last August the cockatoo just flew into his massive, art-filled loft on Lafayette Street in SoHo.

headline: No Jail Time for Ex-Political Boss in Pension Case
text: Raymond B. Harding, the former chairman of the New York State Liberal Party, was spared jail time on Wednesday for his role in a pay-to-play scheme involving the state’s $141 billion pension fund.

headline: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Syrian Leader and 6 Aides
text: WASHINGTON — The United States intensified political and economic pressure on Syria on Wednesday by imposing sanctions on President Bashar al-Assad and six other senior Syrian officials in the wake of a bloody crackdown on political protests in the country.

headline: Cash Crops Under Glass and Up on the Roof
text: When Lufa Farms began selling produce to customers in Montreal in late April, it signaled what could be the beginning of a tantalizing new era in the gastronomic fortunes of that Canadian metropolis.

headline: Video: President Obama and the Middle East
text: Mark Landler in Washington and David Kirkpatrick in Cairo report on the challenges facing President Obama as he prepares to deliver a major speech on the Middle East on Thursday.

headline: Homes for $1.3 Million
text: A condo in a 1920 building in Seattle; a house in Boston built in 1860; and a contemporary in San Diego.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.3 Million

headline: Beware the Doorman Wielding an iPad
text: IT’S 2 a.m. at Lavo, the East 58th Street hot spot, and there’s an impenetrable mob radiating from a single point: the doorman. His name is Richard Wheeler, he speaks softly with a British accent, and he’s not nearly as intimidating as the two beefy bouncers who flank him.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from South Africa, Kuwait and Russia.

headline: Spike Jonze Finds Inspiration in a Handbag
text: CANNES, France –- The directors here are serious of purpose, creating films that take on love, death, social ills, political turmoil, and, in the case of Terrence Malick in his “Tree of Life,” even the origin of the universe itself.

headline: California Special Election Produces Unexpected Result
text: It was supposed to be a race among Democrats to succeed Representative Jane Harman in one of the most Democratic districts in the county.

headline: Teachers’ Union Sues to Stop School Closings
text: 9:51 p.m. | Updated The United Federation of Teachers filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in an effort to halt two tools the city’s Education Department uses to change the school system: closing schools for poor performance and giving charter schools space in buildings occupied by traditional public schools.

headline: As Stimulus Nears End, Fed Signals Focus on Rates
text: A majority of Federal Reserve policy makers said at their most recent meeting that the best next step in their program to stimulate the economy would be to reduce the balance sheet and then focus on interest rates, according to minutes of the April meeting released on Wednesday. But they also said that simply discussing interest rates and other options did not mean that any move “would necessarily begin soon.”

headline: Do My High School Jeans Still Fit?
text: IN the early 1990s, when I was in high school, one of my best friends got an after-school job at his local Gap. I could only imagine the glories, which seemed as foreign as Gstaad or Marrakesh: the folding, making those stacks of T-shirts perfectly neat! The chance to listen to the company-issue store soundtracks, filled with hits of the day, over and over! The discounts!

headline: Everything Is Illuminated | Rinko Kawauchi at the Hermès Gallery
text: The Japanese photographer Rinko Kawauchi is finely tuned to what she likes to call the small voices in our world — those that whisper. Her eyes, she says, naturally focus on small things. And her latest body of work, “Illuminance,” which provides the content for both an exhibition, opening Friday at the Hermès gallery, and a lush book published by Aperture, is resplendent in them. A tiny green frog perches on the palm of a seemingly enormous hand; a lit cigarette, its ash a fiery orange, juts from the fingers of another. A slab of raw tuna is approached in such proximity that it takes on the monumentality of landscape. An image of goldfish packed to the gills in a plastic bag brings to mind the Tokyo subway during rush hour.

headline: Consumer Bureau Plans New Mortgage Form
text: The mountains of paperwork are one of the few certainties of home buying.

headline: Answers About the N.B.A. Playoffs and More
text: The following are the responses from Jonathan Abrams and Howard Beck, who took questions from readers this week about the N.B.A. playoffs, which head into the conference finals, as well as the Knicks and Nets.

headline: Are Talent Acquisitions a Sign of a New Bubble?
text: There’s no question that the “bubbly” feeling has returned to Silicon Valley. The signs are everywhere. Lavish parties are back and so are the highly valued start-ups. There’s a seeming frenzy over the coming LinkedIn IPO. And now, there’s a surge in “talent acquisitions,” which I wrote about today.

headline: Under a Cosmic Magnifying Glass
text: An illustration of the method by which astronomers using a ground-based telescope found evidence for 10 free-floating, Jupiter-mass planets in space.

headline: Personal Hardware
text: When I ventured into the world of personal manufacturing for last Sunday’s magazine article, “The Kitchen-Table Industrialists,” I found myself itching to make something myself. Like many urban professionals, I spend a lot of time producing things on a screen and very little time making anything tangible — besides lunch. As I describe in my article, I tried, on a trip to Detroit, to make an iPad stand, based on a design I downloaded from the Web. But the 3-D printer — yes, this exists — kept botching it. So I scaled back my ambitions and 3-D printed this lovely hexagonal nut. It’s not much, and it’s not much use without a bolt, but it’s something.

headline: Charles Schwab to Offer Index-Only 401(k) Plans
text: Ron Lieber’s Your Money column last weekend urged investors to ask their employers for more index-fund choices in their 401(k) retirement plans. Many plans are heavy on actively managed funds, even though index funds offer lower administrative costs and relatively lower risk that benefit investors as they build their nest eggs.

headline: In Amsterdam, a Loft on a Canal
text: A two-bedroom loft condominium in a former candy factory overlooking the Looiersgracht canal in Amsterdam is on the market for $1.4 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Amsterdam
text: A LOFT IN A FORMER FACTORY ON A CANAL IN THE NETHERLANDS

headline: Crime Pays Again for CBS
text: A “Dancing With the Stars” elimination episode attracted 17.7 million viewers on Tuesday night, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The ABC reality show won its 9 p.m. time slot but for the night over all the network finished in second place behind CBS’s lineup of crime show finales, including “NCIS” (18.1 million) and “NCIS: Los Angeles” (15.4 million).

headline: Key Question Is Left Open as Medvedev Faces Media
text: SKOLKOVO, Russia — As the start of President Dmitri A. Medvedev’s news conference drew near on Wednesday, 800 journalists were in such a state of anticipation that they burst into spontaneous applause when an aide climbed up to the podium to adjust a teacup set out for the president.

headline: Another Long Gallop for Animal Kingdom
text: Steeplechase Times is with Animal Kingdom at the Fair Hill Training Center as he prepares for the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. On Wednesday, Joe Clancy captured the scene:

headline: India’s Anti-Poverty Programs Are Big but Troubled
text: NEW DELHI — India spends more on programs for the poor than most developing countries, but it has failed to eradicate poverty because of widespread corruption and faulty government administration, the World Bank said Wednesday.

headline: Adele Is at No. 1 for 8th Week, but Lady Gaga Is On Deck
text: Adele still dominates the Billboard charts, but with Lady Gaga on deck her reign probably won’t last much longer.

headline: At a Time of Needed Financial Overhaul, a Leadership Vacuum
text: After the worst crisis since the Great Depression, President Obama has unleashed an unusual force to regulate the financial system: a bunch of empty seats.

headline: Changing of the Guard on Morgan Library & Museum Board
text: When the board of the Morgan Library & Museum meets on Thursday afternoon, a new president will preside for the first time in time 23 years. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, a retired I.B.M. executive, is taking over the post from S. Parker Gilbert, who held it for more than two decades.

headline: In Nebraska, Alfresco Automobile Trove Awaits Bidders
text: Car collectors, in their undying quests for the Find, would not let the pending liquidation of a salvage yard full of old and rusting vehicles go unnoticed.

headline: A Familiar Face in Peru, and a More Local Recruiting Effort
text: In a sunny auditorium in Trujillo, Peru, the other day, a crowd of political activists waved orange flags and shouted, “Rudí, Rudí, Rudí!”

headline: Endangered Species Ecotourism: Developing Citizen Science Travel Itineraries
text: Overview | What are endangered species? How and where can people observe and encounter endangered species in the world today? In this lesson, students survey endangered species across the country and around the world. They explore the ecosystems where different endangered species live and develop ecotourism itineraries to introduce travelers to endangered species across the globe.

headline: Roaming the Streets, Taking Surreal Turns
text: The narrator of Teju Cole’s odd, sometimes striking, sometimes frustrating first novel is a med student named Julius who likes to wander through the streets of New York City, and the book is filled with arresting, strobe-lit glimpses of Manhattan, “this strangest of islands.”

text: THE model Veronica Webb made charming faces at the camera. Michael Stipe, the lead vocalist for R.E.M., cozied up to a snake. The actor David Arquette designed a T-shirt that read: “I love. Therefore I am.”

headline: Want a Copy of Obama’s Birth Certificate?
text: President Obama took the issue of where he was born seriously enough to release his long-form birth certificate last month. But his campaign is not above using it to have a bit of fun.

headline: Delta-Northwest Merger’s Long and Complex Path
text: ATLANTA — How many chimes should pilots ring to signal the plane is about to land — two or four? Should flight attendants first pour drinks into a cup or just hand over the can?

text: Another day in Iowa, where complete strangers say irony-free things like “Jeez! Thanks for stopping by!” (Think Frances McDormand in “Fargo.”)

headline: Beyond Bunny Yeager’s Lens, a Shy Pinup
text: Bunny Yeager is shunning the cameras, for the moment at least. Strange, since only last week she professed in an interview: “I like to pose. I like to be in front of anybody’s camera.”

text: Updated, May 19 | A former police detective was arrested Tuesday in connection with a string of gunpoint robberies of Brooklyn pharmacies in which the holdup man demanded narcotics rather than money, the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said.

headline: Republican Senators Query I.R.S. on Nonprofit Donations

text: Les Lieber, 99, has run a weekly lunchtime jam session for nonprofessional musicians since 1945. But interest is waning, and the longtime series may close.

text: THE bronze statue of Rocky near the Philadelphia Museum of Art irked Jessie Hemmons. She found the statue too big, too macho and too touristy, so last month Ms. Hemmons, a 24-year-old artist, bombed him. With pinkish yarn.

headline: A Favorite Emerges for Helm of I.M.F.
text: PARIS — The French finance minister, Christine Lagarde, was on a panel at the World Economic Forum in Davos this January when her usual smile turned into a frown. Next to her, Robert E. Diamond Jr., chief executive of Barclays and one of the most powerful bankers in the world, thanked regulators and finance ministers for their role in shaping a better environment after the financial crisis.

headline: Upfronts: Turner Brings New Series to TBS and TNT
text: After joking his way (very effectively) through the technical glitches that plagued his company’s upfront presentation Wednesday morning, the Turner Entertainment president, Steve Koonin, urged advertisers to “stop leaving” the event and promised Turner’s networks, TNT and TBS, would be on all but equal footing with the broadcast networks in the coming year.

headline: How to Merge Two Airlines
text: After Delta and Northwest announced their merger in 2008, they began planning for what turned out to be an 18-month sprint to integrate 1,200 systems across the airlines. Managers built this master guide. Each note represents a project that could involve thousands of tasks.

headline: Live Blogging the Upfronts: CBS
text: CBS is bringing advertisers to Carnegie Hall — in the midst of a monster rainstorm in midtown Manhattan — for a preview of its fall 2011 schedule. It is adding five shows in the fall and doing so from a position of strength, since it continues to draw more total viewers than any other broadcaster.

headline: Gates Says No Sign That Top Pakistanis Knew of Bin Laden
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that he surmised that “somebody” in Pakistan had been aware that Osama bin Laden was hiding in a compound in the Pakistani garrison town of Abbottabad, but that there was no evidence so far that anyone in the country’s senior leadership had known.

text: BALTIMORE — I never watched Harmon Killebrew play or had the pleasure of meeting him, but I felt a connection with him. One of my favorite things to do when I got home from school was to turn on ESPN and watch reruns of “Home Run Derby,” which pitted some of baseball’s top power hitters against each other in, yes, a home run hitting contest.

text: Tom Postilio, a suave, witty Frank Sinatra acolyte with a mischievous twinkle in his eye, remembers the epiphanic moment when he first saw his idol in June 1984 at Carnegie Hall. He was 14 years old.

headline: In England, a Former Factory to Call Home
text: LONDON — Four years ago, Eric Guibert, an architect, and his fiancé, Robin Pembrooke, an online television executive, were growing tired of their two-bedroom home in Waterloo, a bustling South London neighborhood. Mr. Guibert, whose specialty is developing unconventional properties like reclaimed churches and barns, took issue with many of its features.

headline: Senate Rejects Republican Bill on Exploration for Oil and Gas
text: WASHINGTON — With Democrats citing last year’s oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico as a cautionary tale, the Senate on Wednesday decisively rejected a Republican plan to allow more coastal oil and gas exploration and to speed the issuance of drilling permits to oil companies.

headline: Turkish Magnate Puts His Passion on Display
text: The textile magnate Oner Kocabeyoglu is exhibiting the work of more than 430 works by 20 modern artists from his country.

headline: Scott Brooks and the Task of Stopping Nowitzki
text: Scott Brooks’s team faces an impossible riddle in defending Dirk Nowitzki, but on a micro level, Brooks has stumbled into an interesting opportunity for redemption. No coach has taken a bigger hit to his reputation over the course of this postseason than Brooks. Phil Jackson was ushered out gracefully, despite his team’s being swept by the Dallas Mavericks in the second round. Gregg Popovich did what he could, but succumbed to the fate of an aging roster. Doc Rivers coached admirably in the face of injuries to his team, but a series win against the Heat wasn’t in the cards.

Adult siblings, new couples and a family in political danger redefine home. Meanwhile, Will Allison looks at how a snap decision causes one American family to come undone.
