headline: Exploring Boxwood
text: If you love green, and the deer are eating everything in your garden, boxwood — which comes in a range of shades, shapes and sizes — is a lovely alternative. Unlike English boxwood, which prefers partial shade, most will tolerate sun without turning yellow, but almost all are darker green in the shade.

headline: Prestige Can’t Halt Downfall of Theater
text: SEATTLE — When Bartlett Sher handpicked Kate Whoriskey to succeed him as artistic director of Intiman Theater here in 2009, he appeared to be giving her a dream job. Under Mr. Sher, Intiman had become one of the country’s most prestigious theaters, nurturing a growing audience while basking in the reflected glow of Mr. Sher’s increasing fame as a freelance director of operas and musicals, including an acclaimed Broadway revival of “South Pacific.” For Ms. Whoriskey, then 38 and best known for directing Lynn Nottage’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play, “Ruined,” Intiman seemed like the perfect artistic home.

headline: Boxwood: Loving What the Deer Don’t

headline: Boxwood Gardens
text: All around Andrea Filippone’s many gardens are wonderfully different boxwood.

headline: Three Twists on Classical Style, in Movement and in Character
text: A dancer extends a leg forward above hip-height, then, keeping that leg outstretched, starts to fall forward in the direction it is pointing. By the time he has brought the raised foot down to the floor, he has transferred much of his weight to it.

headline: Footnote
text: Citing a scheduling conflict, Meryl Streep has dropped out of a reading of Alan Alda’s new play about Marie Curie at the World Science Festival gala at Alice Tully Hall on June 1. Maggie Gyllenhaal is taking on the role of that pioneering scientist in “Radiance: The Passion of Marie Curie” at the fund-raising event. Other readers are Amy Adams, Bill Camp, Allison Janney, David Morse, Liev Schreiber and Brent Sexton.

headline: City Releases List of 20 Fire Companies Slated to Close
text: The city on Wednesday afternoon released a list of the 20 fire companies it is considering closing to help fill a $600 million budget gap. The city had initially refused to release the list, prompting the City Council to threaten to subpoena it.

headline: Disputed Statue Is Back Home in Italy
text: A statue of a cult deity, below left, that was once the subject of litigation between the Italian government and the J. Paul Getty Museum of Los Angeles, was publicly unveiled on Tuesday in its new home in Aidone, Sicily. The Getty bought the seven-foot-tall limestone-and-marble statue in 1988 for $18 million, giving rise to a two-decade legal battle after Italian authorities determined it had been looted from Italy. The museum agreed to return the statue, often identified as Aphrodite, as part of a 2007 accord with the Italian government for the restitution of 40 illegally excavated artifacts. The statue was finally shipped to Rome in March. It has been installed in what is expected to be its permanent home, the archaeological museum in Aidone, a hilltop town near the ruins of the ancient Greek colony of Morgantina, where some experts believe the statue once stood.

headline: At the Furniture Fair, Sustainable Furniture Gets Playful
text: THE table lamp is laid-back, and no wonder. Created by Peter Stathis, a San Francisco industrial designer, for Joby, a San Francisco consumer products company, Trapeze has the easygoing affect of a Bay Area windsurfer on a fair-trade coffee break.

headline: Designs From the 2011 International Contemporary Furniture Fair
text: The fair showed that objects as banal as fruit crates can have flair.

text: Assembling a 2,000-square-foot cabinet of curiosities.

headline: At Home on the Farm and in E-Books
text: PINE PLAINS, N.Y. — Last Friday Susan Orlean was on the verge of some serious animal acquisitions. Her latest herd of 12 Black Angus cattle was scheduled to be dropped off within days. And the local post office could call at any minute to report that four rare and eye-catching Swedish flower hens were ready for pickup, having been shipped overnight from Florida.

headline: Demanding Hillary Clinton’s E-Mail — Now
text: The Canadian company TransCanada is hoping to win State Department approval of construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry “oil sands” oil to the Gulf Coast for refining. To this end, it has spent $310,000 this year lobbying in Washington for the cause.

headline: In Williamsburg, a Live-In Cabinet of Curiosities
text: PAIGE STEVENSON moved every few years when she was a child in the 1970s, living, among other places, in a tepee on a commune in Mendocino County, Calif.; on a goat farm near the commune; and in a Victorian house in San Francisco with her father, stepmother and a coterie of drag performers. In her adult life, she has chosen something far less nomadic: a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where she has been since 1989.

headline: Shopping for 1960s Design With Wayne Burgess
text: A collector of vintage furnishings, Mr. Burgess has long been enamored of other things from the 1960s as well.

headline: Schwarzenegger’s Next Film May Have a Familiar Plot
text: LOS ANGELES — If all goes well, Arnold Schwarzenegger will by next year be working out a complicated relationship with an 11-year-old who unexpectedly turned up in his life. That’s the plot of his planned next movie, never mind the rest of it.

headline: Paging Rick Perry: How a Southerner Could Sweep to the G.O.P. Nomination
text: Being a Southerner conveys certain advantages upon a Republican presidential candidate.

headline: When It Comes to Helping Others: Just Do It
text: It’s graduation season, and for the past two months I’ve been traveling to campuses in the United States on a book tour to talk about service in the Marines and social entrepreneurship in Africa. One point seems to resonate with students above all of the others. From a commuter college in the plains of Indiana to Stanford and MIT, students have been latching onto one simple sentence: be a doer.

headline: 1960s Design
text: IN 1961, Jaguar introduced the E-Type, a low-slung sports car with a long hood and seductively curvaceous lines. Many enthusiasts still consider it one of the most beautiful cars of all time, an opinion shared by the Museum of Modern Art, which acquired one for its permanent collection in 1996.

headline: With the Matadors, Capes, Gypsies and Dancing, Who Needs a Plot?
text: There’s not much of Cervantes’s picaresque tale left in the ballet version of “Don Quixote.” The plot, taken from Book 2 of the 1615 novel, is barely there, boiled down to the aged don’s quest for his dream woman, Dulcinea, and his belief that he has found her in the earthy peasant girl, Kitri. She, however, has her own problems, since her father wants her to marry a rich nobleman rather than her penniless sweetheart, the barber Basilio.

headline: An Ancient Victory, Honoring a Later One
text: You would think that because Handel’s “Judas Maccabaeus” tells a vague approximation of the story of Hanukkah — or at least it portrays the Maccabees, the story’s central characters — it should have become part of the seasonal repertory, as a Jewish alternative to “Messiah.” But it remains a rarity, and when it is performed at all — as it was on Tuesday evening by the Clarion Choir and Orchestra at Park Avenue Christian Church — it is calendar pages away from the holiday.

headline: Made to Order, by Ruby Beets
text: Tiny Ruby Beets, tucked into an old silent-film theater on a side street in Sag Harbor, N.Y., is all of a sudden not so tiny, having doubled in size this month to accommodate a new line of furniture, Ruby Beets Made to Order. Sharone Einhorn and Honey Wolters, the store’s owners, have long filled the place with antiquarian goods (like apothecary cabinets, bottom right) and artisanal objects (like Moroccan blankets), as well as clean-lined modern and estate-sale pieces and contemporary artwork (like seascapes by the local photographer Mary Ellen Bartley), all in a muted palette.

headline: Ins and Outs of Using Gadgetry
text: Every time a reader asks me a basic question, struggles with a computer or lets a cellphone keep ringing at a performance, I have the same thought: There ought to be a license to use technology.

headline: An Eco-Friendly Lamp From Foster & Partners
text: The Dash task light, a collaboration between the London-based architects Foster & Partners and designers at the office furniture company Steelcase, combines sleek styling with a tiny eco-footprint.

headline: Turning Photos Into Paint-by-Numbers Art
text: Paintapic, a new service that crosses the low-tech fun of paint-by-numbers with the instant gratification of a Web click, is the brainchild of Keith Gould, a technical director for a design industry Web site and the creator of the photo app Daily Mugshot.

headline: At Pop Pub, Deliberate Design for a Fast-Food Menu
text: For 15 years, the restaurateur Roy Liebenthal has been serving fast food in environments that are anything but off-the-cuff. Pop Burger and Pop Pizza, spaces created by the Turkish-born, Manhattan-based architect Ali Tayar, explored the layering of high-tech details with rough surfaces.

headline: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Bail Application
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn’s bail application and related exhibits.

headline: Raising Concerns About Chemicals in Recycled Carpet Padding
text: Every week, it seems, a new study identifies potentially harmful chemicals in the food we eat, the makeup we wear, the toys and bottles used by our children. Next up: the recycled foam padding installed under wall-to-wall carpeting.

headline: Sales at Sferra, Pottery Barn and Others

headline: Weighing a Tough Choice With a 5-3 Major Fit
text: The second United States team for this year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship will be Kevin Bathurst, Daniel Zagorin, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge. Originally seeded ninth, they won the 120-board trial final in Henderson, Nev., on Tuesday against the Rosenblum Cup world champions and top seeds, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson, by 288 international match points to 257.

headline: TimesCast | Timely TV: "The Good Wife"

headline: Until the Next Revolution
text: I was 19 years old when I first heard the Kronos Quartet’s “Howl, U.S.A.”  The album dons as its cover Robert Mapplethorpe’s stunning portrait of a tattered, weatherworn and ever-so-slightly transparent American flag.  The image seemed symbolic of the music — political works by Scott Johnson, Michael Daugherty, Harry Partch (arr. Ben Johnston) and Lee Hyla — which struck me as an honest, direct and sometimes difficult-to-hear assessment of a country in tatters.  I was enthralled.

headline: Round 2: More Reaction to Abbas’s View of History

headline: Slowed by Injuries, and Weather, the Mets Push Through to Victory
text: Before thousands of empty green seats, with black storm clouds practically tripping over the light stanchions at Citi Field, the Mets left-hander Jon Niese threw his first pitch at 7:11 p.m. Wednesday, even though it might have made more sense to take the night off.

headline: James Tempers Expectations for Cavaliers’ No. 1 Pick

text: May 18, 2011 - The Times's Beirut Bureau Chief Anthony Shadid on the U.S. sanctions imposed on Syria's leadership.

headline: New York Voters Pass 93% of School Budgets in State
text: Voters across New York State approved more than 93 percent of school budgets on Tuesday, as administrators facing sharp reductions in state education aid offered plans to cut staff and programs, tap into reserves and keep tax increases relatively low.

headline: Study Finds Women Slower to Wed, and Divorce Easing
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly half of all women between the ages of 25 and 29 have never been married, up from about a quarter of that age group in 1986, according to a report released on Wednesday by the Census Bureau.

headline: The E.P.A.’s Secret Agenda
text: Birthers, truthers, Osama-death doubters. These paranoiacs are distracting us from the real menace: one of the government’s most powerful agencies is sending sinister messages through its logo.

headline: Animal Kingdom Is Morning Line Favorite for Preakness
text: After the field was drawn Wednesday for the Preakness Stakes, the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom was made the early 2-1 favorite for Saturday’s race. If all the horses reach the gate, the race will have a full, 14-horse field for the first time since 2005.

text: Daniel Levy, left, of the New America Foundation and Daniel Drezner of Tufts University debate Middle East peace.

headline: For Oaktree Capital, a Balancing Act
text: Oaktree Capital’s plans to pursue a public stock listing will test one of the main philosophies of its outspoken founder, Howard Marks. Mr. Marks, whose investment missives are widely followed on Wall Street, has often lamented the tradeoff that fund managers make between gathering assets and maintaining performance. Balancing his preference for returns with the demands for growth among public shareholders won’t be easy.

headline: China Reports AIDS Mortality Is Cut by Two-Thirds
text: China has slashed AIDS mortality by nearly two-thirds since it began distributing free antiretroviral drugs in 2002, Chinese government scientists are reporting.

headline: As an Insecticide Makes a Comeback, Uganda Must Weigh Its Costs

headline: Hybrid Owners Look to Extend Carpool Privilege
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Virtue may be its own reward, but incentives don’t hurt. In California in 2004, when the country’s first measure restricting vehicles’ greenhouse gas emissions became law, 75,000 owners of the gas-stingiest hybrid cars were assured access to carpool lanes.

headline: Bias Case May Pose a Problem for Bidder
text: In 2000, the federal agency charged with monitoring workplace discrimination ended its investigation of Eagle Global Logistics, a Texas freight company.

headline: Restoring Tradition of Quail Hunting
text: PIGGOTT, Ark. — During his periodic stays in this small town in the Arkansas delta, Ernest Hemingway was looked upon by the locals as something of a proto-hippy with his shabby clothes, unshaven face and artistic disposition. He was once mistaken for a hobo. Children taunted him and pelted him with rocks. Obliged to visit his in-laws’ home in Piggott, Hemingway made the most of it and became a bird-hunting bum.

headline: G.O.P. Senators Question I.R.S. Scrutiny of Donors
text: A group of Republican senators wrote to the head of the Internal Revenue Service on Wednesday seeking internal correspondence and other information about the agency’s heightened scrutiny of donations to some nonprofit advocacy groups that are playing a growing role in political campaigns.

headline: Clinton Aims to Improve Ties With Latin America
text: WASHINGTON — As tumult rages across the Middle East, and relations with Pakistan border on a breakdown, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was scheduled Wednesday night to host a private dinner with at least six former Latin American presidents, part of a quiet campaign to repair relations with a region that complains it has been ignored by American policy makers.

headline: Rodriguez Will Have Hip Examined When Yanks Return Home
text: BALTIMORE — With Alex Rodriguez under contract through the 2017 season, the Yankees have every reason to protect their investment in him. Even though he said his surgically repaired right hip felt “great, tremendous,” he will have it checked out during the team’s next homestand.

headline: Azerbaijan: Court Sentences Activist to Two Years on Draft Evasion Charges
text: A court in Azerbaijan on Wednesday sentenced the political activist Bakhtiyar Hajiyev, who used Facebook to help organize antigovernment demonstrations, to two years in prison on draft evasion charges. Mr. Hajiyev, 29, who studied public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, ran for Parliament last year as an opposition candidate. He was arrested after his name was listed on a Facebook page calling on young people to join protests on March 11. Mr. Hajiyev’s arrest follows the sentencing of Jabbar Savalan, 20, to two and a half years on drug possession charges. Mr. Savalan was arrested in February after he announced a protest on his Facebook page, according to Amnesty International. A week ago, the European Parliament passed a resolution condemning Azeri officials for human rights violations, including the violent dispersal of peaceful protests. Azeri officials warned that it could damage relations between Azerbaijan and European governments.

headline: A Blood Test Offers Clues to Longevity
text: Want to know how long you will live?

headline: Scraping and Cutting to Find $22 Million
text: Troy, Mich., a Detroit suburb where the median family income is more than $90,000, may be one of the more unlikely American cities to find itself in fiscal distress. On paper, it is difficult to understand how this city of 80,000 is struggling: only about 2 percent of its families live below the poverty line; 92 percent of its population has a high school diploma; about half of its adults have at least a bachelor’s degree; it is one of the safest cities in the country; and the median value of a house is more than $200,000. Still, Troy’s wealth has proved poor inoculation against the financial problems of cities and states across the country. John Szerlag, Troy’s city manager, discusses.

headline: Gingrich’s Rocky Start Not Unusual
text: Can Newt Gingrich recover?

headline: Dancer at Heart, and Executive in the Making
text: Nneka Onuorah began taking tap-dancing lessons when she was 4, and by her teenage years, she was proficient in jazz, contemporary and hip-hop moves. She assumed she was destined to be a professional dancer. Instead, after attending LaGuardia Community College, she wound up in a different corner of the entertainment business, as the music specials coordinator at Black Entertainment Television. Ms. Onuorah, 23, lives in Corona, Queens.

text: BALTIMORE

headline: Anger Lingers in Iraqi Kurdistan After a Crackdown
text: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq — The protesters are gone from the central square, pushed out by the brutal tactics of the security forces. The jails have been emptied of the young students and journalists who were rounded up for speaking their mind in public. The wounded are home, quietly nursing their injuries.

headline: Bruce Ricker, Who Made Jazz Documentaries, Is Dead at 68
text: Bruce Ricker, a lawyer turned filmmaker who made jazz resoundingly visible in a series of highly regarded documentaries, died on Friday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 68.

headline: Texas Catches Fire
text: Even as Texas prepared for war, its fate within the Confederacy sealed, parts of the state still seethed with Union sentiment. And no place was more fervently pro-Union that spring than Bexar County and its largest city, San Antonio, the home of the Alamo, the very cradle of Texas independence.

headline: Prosecutors Get Delay in Bonds Hearing
text: A post-trial hearing in San Francisco for Barry Bonds’s federal perjury case was postponed from Friday to June 17, giving prosecutors more time to decide if they will retry any of the three counts in which the jury deadlocked. The delay also will allow defense lawyers to hone their arguments for the judge to overrule the jury and throw out Bonds’s lone conviction.

headline: Bill Skiles, Frantic Clown to a Straight Man, Dies at 79
text: Bill Skiles, the frenzied, jabbering, sound-effecting clown to the straight man Pete Henderson in the comedy team Skiles and Henderson, died on Monday at his home in St. Cloud, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Focus Is on Obama as Tensions Soar Across Mideast
text: WASHINGTON — Few game-changing proposals are emerging to defuse tensions in the Middle East as a busy week of diplomacy unfolds with President Obama’s address to the region and his meeting with Israel’s prime minister.

headline: Snooky Young, a Big Band Trumpeter, Is Dead at 92
text: Snooky Young, who led the trumpet sections of some of the world’s most famous big bands — including, for some 30 years, Doc Severinsen’s “Tonight Show” orchestra — died on May 11 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 92.

headline: California: Boy Accused in Killing of His Father Says He Was Abused
text: A 10-year-old boy accused of murdering his father — a prominent member of the National Socialist Movement, the nation’s largest neo-Nazi organization — told the police that his father had physically abused him and his stepmother before the killing, according to documents filed with Superior Court in Riverside County. The boy, whose name is being withheld, said he decided to shoot his father — point blank in the head as he slept on a couch — because he was afraid that his father, Jeff Hall, was having an affair and that the boy’s living situation would change. The gun was apparently left on a low shelf in the family’s home in suburban Riverside, Calif., according to the boy’s statement to police. It was later found under his bed. The police have issued an arrest warrant for the boy’s stepmother, Krista F. McCary, with charges including criminal storage of a firearm and child neglect.

headline: Nowitzki and the Mavericks Still in Attack Mode Against the Thunder
text: DALLAS — Dirk Nowitzki emerged from the trainer’s room and bounded down a metal staircase Wednesday, remarkably fresh considering how he had dismantled the Oklahoma City Thunder only 18 hours earlier.

headline: Anticipating Obama's Middle East Speech
text: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen's hopes for President Obama's Middle East peace efforts.

headline: Church Abuse Report Authors Defend Findings as Critics Weigh In
text: WASHINGTON — The criminologists hired by the nation’s Roman Catholic bishops to study the sexual abuse crisis in the church defended their findings on Wednesday at the bishops’ headquarters — in particular their thesis that the abuse peaked in the 1960s and 1970s and dropped off significantly by the mid-1980s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Private Prisons Found to Offer Little in Savings
text: PHOENIX — The conviction that private prisons save money helped drive more than 30 states to turn to them for housing inmates. But Arizona shows that popular wisdom might be wrong: Data there suggest that privately operated prisons can cost more to operate than state-run prisons — even though they often steer clear of the sickest, costliest inmates.

headline: Getting Smart on Aid
text: One cost of the uproar over Greg Mortenson, and the allegations that he fictionalized his school-building story in the best-selling book “Three Cups of Tea,” is likely to be cynicism about whether aid makes a difference.

headline: Yemeni Leader Refuses Deal
text: WASHINGTON — A renewed effort to resolve Yemen’s political crisis collapsed Wednesday after the Yemeni president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, again backed away from signing an agreement to transfer power, prompting Yemeni officials and analysts to warn that the stalemate could descend into factional violence.

headline: The Year of Living Adulterously
text: What is it with Republicans lately?

headline: General Says Beijing Won’t Challenge American Military
text: WASHINGTON — A top Chinese general said Wednesday that China had no intention of challenging the American military and that it was “very strange” that questions were raised about his country’s military buildup when the same concerns were not voiced about the United States.

headline: Two 9/11 Flight Numbers Retired
text: United Continental Holdings said the company would permanently retire flight numbers 93 and 175, the designations of the United flights hijacked in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, after they reappeared in a computer reservation system.

headline: Justice in Dreamland
text: Police officers following a suspect into an apartment complex in Lexington, Ky., don’t know which apartment their man has entered. But wafting through one of the closed apartment doors is the familiar odor of marijuana. The smell provides reason to believe criminal activity is afoot, probable cause for a warrant to search the apartment.

headline: U.S. Was Warned on Vents Before Failure at Japan’s Plant
text: WASHINGTON — Five years before the crucial emergency vents at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant were disabled by an accident they were supposed to help handle, engineers at a reactor in Minnesota warned American regulators about that very problem.

headline: Budget Hopes, Further From Reach
text: There was probably never much chance that a self-appointed gang of six senators could produce a comprehensive solution for the nation’s long-term deficit, given the ruthless political environment. The best hoped was that it could give bipartisan traction to a few useful ideas before they were attacked and destroyed by ideologues.

headline: Israel Bares Russia Spy Claim
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s military attaché in Russia was expelled this week on suspicion of spying, the Israeli Defense Ministry announced on Wednesday, adding that its own investigation into the allegations had found them to be baseless.

headline: Upset Over Community Roots Charter School’s Expansion
text: As a parent of a student who started in the inaugural first-grade class at Community Roots Charter School in Brooklyn in 2006, Chris Thompson has watched his son grow up in an elementary school that has transformed itself from an experiment in progressive education to one of District 13’s most popular destinations for young families.

headline: Georgia: Conflicting Reports Surround Shooting on Border With an Enclave
text: There were conflicting reports on Wednesday about a shooting at the border between Georgia and South Ossetia, a breakaway enclave under Russia’s military protection. The government of Georgia accused “occupation forces” of firing on unarmed civilians it said were gathering herbs near the boundary, wounding two, one of them seriously. But South Ossetian officials said that members of the enclave’s K.G.B., which patrols the boundary, discovered a group of Georgian youths inside the border. According to Res, an Ossetian news service, a firefight was begun from the Georgian side and Georgian citizens were arrested. South Ossetia gained de facto independence in 2008 after Russia and Georgia fought a short war over it and another rebellious territory.

headline: China: Company That Tried to Open Forbidden City Club to Be Investigated
text: A government agency in Beijing has said it will investigate a company that tried to open a luxury private club inside the Forbidden City, according to a report on the Web site of People’s Daily, the official newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party. The agency, the Beijing Administration of Industry and Commerce, is looking into wrongdoing by the Forbidden City Cultural Development Company, which had been charged by the palace’s management office with organizing salons and lectures. Instead, the company began handing out “membership sign-up forms” without telling the managers, a palace spokesman said. The company reportedly wanted to sign up 500 members at a charge of one million renminbi each, or about $154,000.

headline: Thursday: Three Time Tour de France Winner
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Hey there, come on in and have a seat. Make yourself comfortable. May I get you a refreshing beverage? How about a nice, tall cold one? There’s plenty of stuff to cool you down in Paula Gamache’s puzzle. We’ll just chisel some off and put it in our drinks.

headline: Produce Your Own Vows
text: Tell your story in your own Vows video. Click here for more information. Here are some of our first and best submissions.

headline: The World’s Best Horse? She’s in Australia
text: Kerry Lonergan has kept his bookmaker driving a Mercedes Benz for years. He’s also had shares in many slow racehorses, and like all owners, remains convinced that the next one he buys will be the next Secretariat. He lives in Brisbane, Australia.

headline: Brazil: Government Vows Crackdown on Cattle Ranchers in the Amazon
text: Brazilian government officials said Wednesday that they would crack down on cattle ranchers in the Amazon after new data showed that deforestation there had increased by 26 percent in the nine months that ended in April, compared to with the same period a year before. The data showed to that about 710 square miles had been deforested in that time. Izabella Teixeira, Brazil’s environment minister, called the jump “unacceptable” and vowed to seize the cattle of farmers who are practicing deforestation to cultivate new pastureland. Ibama, Brazil’s environmental protection agency, more than doubled police operations this year intended to deter deforestation. Despite those efforts, Mato Grosso, Brazil’s leading soybean-producing state, saw a 43 percent increase in deforestation in the nine-month period that ended in April, compared to with the same period last year. Leading environmentalists said some farmers had cut down trees because they expected they would be allowed to do so anyway under a bill being considered in Brazil’s Congress to ease restrictions on the amount of land that needed to remain forested.

headline: Field in Women’s 200 Bolstered for Grand Prix
text: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce of Jamaica, the reigning world and Olympic champion in the 100 meters, and Carmelita Jeter of the United States, who was ranked No. 1 in the world in the 100 last year, will compete in the 200 on June 11 at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island, meet organizers announced. Allyson Felix of the United States and Sherone Simpson of Jamaica had already entered.

headline: New Police Unit Will Monitor City Courts for Ticket-Fixing
text: Investigators from the Internal Affairs Bureau will be assigned to monitor the city’s traffic courts in an effort to determine whether police officers are intentionally losing cases as favors to colleagues, police officials said Wednesday.

headline: Networks Try a Social Media Spin at the Upfronts
text: AT almost every turn this week, television networks are talking about being liked — not only in the ratings, but also on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Status of Libya’s Oil Minister Remains Uncertain
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — After the NATO bombing and the rebel forces that have pushed forward at Misurata, only 130 miles from Tripoli, the greatest threat facing the Libyan government may lie in high-level defections that undermine morale and set senior officials to wondering who may be next to abandon Colonel Muammer el-Qaddafi’s elite.

headline: A Victory for Veterans
text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ordered an overhaul of mental health care for veterans, who are killing themselves by the thousands each year because of what the court called the “unchecked incompetence” of the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: About That Checking Account
text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, created by Congress last year as part of financial reform, has broad authority to ban unfair or abusive practices in financial products and services. Protecting checking account holders from unreasonable fees and other costly traps should be one of the agency’s first priorities when it opens for business in July.

headline: The Vatican Comes Up Short
text: The Vatican’s long overdue guidelines for fighting sexual abuse of children are, unfortunately, just that — flimsy guidelines for a global problem that requires an unequivocal mandate for church officials to work with secular authorities in prosecuting rogue priests.

headline: Earthquake and Aftermath Push Japan Into a Recession
text: TOKYO — Japan’s economy shrank at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the first quarter, tipping the country into a recession, as the March 11 earthquake and tsunami disrupted production and prompted consumers to cut back on spending.

headline: The Heat Surges Late and Gains a Split in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — The bodies and jersey numbers did not need to change. That much, Erik Spoelstra and the Miami Heat insisted to anyone who would listen. This battle with the Bulls would not come down to personnel, but personality, and the Heat went in search of its own during a tedious two-day gap in the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: In Message, Bin Laden Praised Arab Revolt
text: In a message to Muslims made public 16 days after his death, Osama bin Laden praised the pro-democracy uprisings that had swept the Arab world and, in the view of some experts, had called into question the relevance of Al Qaeda, the terrorist network he founded and led for 23 years.

headline: Finding the Patient in a Sea of Guidelines
text: Every Friday morning, the patient, a homeless man in his 60s, lumbered into one of our exam rooms, slipped off the running shoes he wore like bedroom slippers and gingerly lifted his swollen legs so we could remove the medicated bandages and examine the raw wounds on his inner ankles.

headline: For Yankees, Start and Finish Make Up for What’s Between
text: BALTIMORE — Hector Noesi woke up Wednesday as an untested rookie who had spent 16 days with the Yankees without throwing a pitch. He walked off the mound at Camden Yards early Thursday as their savior, the symbol of a brilliant effort by a short-handed bullpen.

text: A newborn girl abandoned last week in a hospital trash can in Queens died on Wednesday, officials said.

headline: Longing To Perform Opera
text: Young singers audition for the Metropolitan Opera’s annual contest, a kind of American Idol for serious vocalists.

headline: Sing for Your Life
text: Ryan Speedo Green stands almost six-foot-five and weighs 300 pounds and wears size 17 shoes, and on a Sunday afternoon in March he was running in place and doing jumping jacks as he waited in the wings of the Metropolitan Opera for his turn to sing. It was the semifinals of the most important operatic voice competition in America, and Ryan was seized by such anxiety that he felt his massive body vanishing. Seventeen of the 22 singers left in the contest had gone before him; to his ears their performances were spectacular. He was fighting off the feeling that he didn’t belong here. Ryan, who is African-American, grew up in low-income housing and a trailer park in southeastern Virginia. When he was 12, he spent time in juvenile detention for threatening his brother and mother. During high school he moved to a street of shacklike homes, with a drug dealer’s headquarters across from his family’s front door and with bullet holes from stray gunfire just above his mother’s bedroom window.

headline: Scary Moment, Puzzling Ejection
text: BALTIMORE – Of all the bizarre moments in 296 minutes of baseball at Camden Yards on Wednesday, nothing was weirder than the plate umpire, Dan Bellino, ejecting Orioles pitcher Mike Gonzalez in the 15th inning. Gonzalez had just drilled the Yankees’ Chris Dickerson in the head, cracking his helmet and forcing Dickerson from the game.

headline: A Shaken Agency Looks to the Future
text: European officials moved quickly to assert their claim over the leadership of the International Monetary Fund on Thursday, suggesting a serious challenge is being mounted by emerging economic powers like China and India that believe the time has come to break Europe’s historic grip on the post.

headline: J.F.K. Bus Collision Kills One
text: A collision between a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus and a car at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday night left one person dead and several people injured, officials said. The crash occurred at 10:25 p.m. on Pan Am Road near parking lot eight. One man in the car was killed, and another was seriously injured. A Port Authority of New York and New Jersey spokesman said that six to seven people on the bus suffered non-life threatening injuries. The crash is still under investigation.

headline: What Are the Best Things You’ve Acquired Secondhand?

headline: Wordless Grief in a Bosnian Morgue
text: Michel Slomka, 24, graduated from the Université Paris Ouest Nanterre La Défense with a degree in anthropology and history, then studied photography for a year. Born and based in Paris, he often works in Bosnia and will return there next month. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

headline: Porto Wins Europa League. Can It Get Better Than This?
text: The best team in Portugal won the Europa League on Wednesday when a Colombian named after a Brazilian scored the winning goal in Dublin. Afterward, their coach praised the Englishman who gave him his start. The world game indeed.

headline: Deadly Blasts in Kirkuk Hit Iraqi Security Forces
text: BAGHDAD — Three explosions aimed at Iraqi security forces ripped through the divided northern city of Kirkuk on Thursday morning, killing at least 29 people, most of them police officers, and wounding scores more.

headline: NIMLOS
text: Not In My Line Of Sight – acronym denoting opposition to plans to construct multi-storey buildings on San Francisco’s Treasure Island.

headline: Garret FitzGerald, Ex-Irish Premier, Dies at 85
text: LONDON — Garret FitzGerald, who served twice as Irish prime minister, helped set the stage for peace in Northern Ireland and shifted the tone of Ireland’s relations with Britain, died Thursday in Dublin. He was 85.

headline: Facebook’s New Way to Combat Child Pornography
text: As online photo sharing has exploded so has, tragically, the distribution of child pornography. But while the rise of the Internet and digital cameras have revived a scourge that had nearly been eliminated in the late 1980s, new technology may also help to beat it back again.

headline: Festival Brings Dormant Berlin Park to Life
text: A borderline apocalyptic scene awaits when you enter Spreepark, Berlin’s only theme park, in the Treptow-Köpenick district in the former East Berlin. Life-size replicas of dinosaurs lie toppled on the ground. A pirate ship sits disintegrating in an algae-covered pond. A rusty Ferris wheel stands askew. Spreepark has been dormant since its insolvency in 2002. But from May 26 through 29, the fairground will come alive with the arrival of a multimedia festival called Lunapark Berlin.

headline: Does Facebook Help or Hinder Offline Friendships?
text: Two recent articles in the New York Times have raised the question of whether or not the daily interactions on Twitter and Facebook are trivializing our real world friendships by making it easier to do things like wish our friends a happy birthday online and send a tweet instead of picking up the phone, effectively diminishing our desire to have actual, face-to-face conversations.

headline: Judge Allows Florida Case Against Trump to Proceed
text: As Donald J. Trump tries to fend off lawsuits from angry home buyers, who claim he misled them about his role in developing luxury towers, his lawyers have repeatedly put forth a simple argument.

headline: Should Green Companies Work With Giant Companies?
text: When I started TerraCycle, we quickly came to a defining crossroads: Did we want to sell our made-from-waste products to independent retailers or to big-box retailers? Basically, we were told that if we sold to the big-box chains we would be blackballed by the independents.

headline: Remembering Carry Back
text: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. She’s confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

headline: Obama’s Middle East Speech Has Many American Audiences
text: Thursday’s speech by President Obama on the upheaval in the Middle East is aimed at a global audience. But it will also play out in a domestic — and political — context as Mr. Obama seeks a second term in the White House.

headline: Rouge Tomate Says It Will Have a Food Cart by Central Park
text: Earlier this week, some cutting-edge Brooklyn restaurateurs said that the parks department has agreed to let them run food stands on the Rockaway Boardwalk. Now, the owners of the more refined Rouge Tomatesay that the department had given them permission to open a food cart at the 64th street entrance to Central Park along Fifth Avenue, starting in mid-June. The cart’s menu, by the restaurant’s executive chef, Jeremy Bearman, will use seasonal and local ingredients in sandwiches — like BLTs made with local bacon and lettuce, heirloom tomatoes and whole wheat bread from Amy’s Bread — soups, snacks, juices and house-made ice cream and sorbets.

headline: The Old Ennui and the Lost Generation
text: The definitive poem in English on the subject of cultural nostalgia may be a short verse by Robert Browning called “Memorabilia.” It begins with a gasp of astonishment — “Ah, did you once see Shelley plain?” — and ends with a shrug: “Well I forget the rest.” Isn’t that always how it goes? The past seems so much more vivid, more substantial, than the present, and then it evaporates with the cold touch of reality. The good old days are so alluring because we were not around, however much we wish we were.

headline: With Hospoda, Czech Food Returns to the Upper East Side
text: Beer is a big part of the vibe at Hospoda, the restaurant set to open on Monday in the landmark Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side, once a bastion of Czech food.

headline: It’s Been a Sullen Few Days, but the End Is Near

headline: Report Faults Mine Owner for Explosion That Killed 29
text: WASHINGTON — In the first comprehensive state report on the 2010 coal mine disaster in West Virginia, an independent team of investigators has put the blame squarely on the owner of the mine, Massey Energy, concluding that it had “made life difficult” for miners who tried to address safety and built “a culture in which wrongdoing became acceptable.”

headline: Reporter Describes Captivity in Syria

headline: A ‘Military Covenant’ for America
text: In Britain, two news items dominated the airwaves this past weekend: the Eurovision Song Contest finale and the proposal to make into law the “military covenant” — the informal pact between the British government and members of the armed forces, promising fair treatment in return for military service. While the value of bringing something like Eurovision to the United States may be debatable, there may be value in exploring the military covenant, especially as a potential framework for bridging what we know as the civilian-military divide.

headline: The ‘American Idol’ of Opera
text: In this week’s magazine, Daniel Bergner writes about the “American Idol” of opera — the Metropolitan Opera’s annual National Council Auditions. These tryouts are open to anyone between 20 and 30 and take place at venues across the country. This year more than 1,200 aspiring singers took part. Daniel started reporting last fall when he sat in on some of the early rounds. One enduring memory was his time in Lexington, Ky., where 30-odd singers were auditioning in a small theater at the University of Kentucky. Before the proceedings began, the crowd — voice teachers and coaches, friends, family — “stood up and sang a tremendously rousing version of ‘The Star Spangled Banner.'”

headline: How About a Nice Swedish Punsch?
text: The passion for resurrecting pre-Prohibition cocktails has helped fetch out of history’s dustbin several forgotten elixirs, including Crème Yvette, allspice dram, orange bitters and, most famously, absinthe. The latest one to be rehabilitated is Swedish punsch. Beginning this summer, the sweet liqueur will return to liquor stores courtesy of Eric Seed, the owner of Haus Alpenz, a Minnesota-based importing company that specializes in unique and arcane liquors.

headline: Patient Voices: Childhood Cancer
text: An unimaginable diagnosis is followed by worry, fear and tough decisions. Six people speak about how childhood cancer changed their lives.

headline: The Frick Collection Names a New Director
text: The Frick Collection, a small but sumptuous museum in a limestone mansion on Fifth Avenue, has chosen as its next director Ian Wardropper, chairman of the department of European sculpture and decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He will assume the post on Oct. 3, succeeding Anne L. Poulet, who has run the Frick since 2003.

headline: Spleen Removal
text: A slide show about spleen removal.

headline: Notes of a Screenwriter, Mad as Hell
text: LAMENTING the lack of “satirical clarity” in the screenplay he was laboring on in the early 1970s, Paddy Chayefsky was mad at himself and American television viewers at large. He was seeing the venomous spirit of the era of Watergate and the Vietnam War infiltrate every program the broadcast networks offered, from their news shows to their sitcoms, and he concluded in a typewritten note to himself that the American people “don’t want jolly, happy family type shows like Eye Witness News”; no, he wrote, “the American people are angry and want angry shows.” He had set out to write a comedy, but if his film script was funny at all, he said, "the only joke we have going for us is the idea of ANGER."

headline: Academies Push For Sanitation and Science Literacy

headline: Stephen Colbert on ‘Network': Great Film or the Greatest Film?
text: An article in Arts & Leisure looks at the notes, drafts and correspondence kept by the screenwriter Paddy Chayefsky during the years he wrote “Network,” his dark 1976 comedy about the corruption of the news media, the degradation of the truth and the downfall of Howard Beale, a television news anchor with a messiah complex. So who’s better qualified to speak about the contemporary relevance of “Network” than Stephen Colbert, who holds a mocking mirror up to the Howard Beales of the present day while playing one himself on his Comedy Central program, “The Colbert Report”?

headline: Upfronts: The CW Adds Six New Series

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Female Programmers in History
text: Contrary to popular stereotype, computer programmers have not always been caffeine-fueled men in T-shirts coding deep into the night. In fact, some of the earliest programmers were female mathematicians, originally recruited to calculate ballistics trajectories for the Army during World War II.  Several of these pioneering women went on to program ENIAC, the world’s first all-electronic computer. In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kathy Kleiman of the ENIAC Programmers Project about their valuable contributions to computing history.

Unlike other political bosses, he fields no phalanx of high-priced lobbyists and consultants. He is virtually unknown to most New Yorkers.

headline: Taking a Stand | Igor Dewe
text: No matter what fashion week you attend around the world, part of the fun is checking out the cuckoo creatures who prance around outside in seriously thought-out get-ups. One who flies his freak flag high is Igor Dewe, a 21-year-old Parisian personality and performer, who made headlines in March when he paraded outside the Dior show carrying a placard offering sympathy for John Galliano. Dewe, who said he was shocked by the designer’s ethnic slurs but felt that his body of work deserved more respect, is best known for his “enhanced” Louboutins and other pricey footwear which he customizes with the help of his father, a welder. As to how he affords them, he says: “You don’t need money for clothes when you are fabulous, but for food, that is another story.”

The exhibitions will be housed in a temporary structure designed by the New York architecture and design firm SO-IL.

headline: Zombies Upstage a Routine Public Health Bulletin

headline: A Fresh Glow for the New York Public Library
text: When Paul LeClerc, the president of the New York Public Library, was preparing to unveil his Beaux-Arts Fifth Avenue beauty after a $50 million, three-year renovation, he knew that he would need to show it in literally the best light possible. So he went to Paris to consult François Jousse, who was then City Hall’s chief engineer for “doctrine, expertise and technical control” — something like the lighting director of the City of Light. Mr. Jousse took Mr. LeClerc on tours of Paris by night, showing him lighting canisters, electrical wiring and spotlight colors of the city’s monuments, official buildings, bridges and boulevards.

headline: Sad and Haunted Girls Who Couldn’t Play Worth a Lick
text: THEY may be the most defensive album liner notes in rock history: “The Shaggs love you and love to perform for you,” begins one paragraph on the back of the 1969 LP “The Shaggs: Philosophy of the World,” a cult classic for its guilelessly awful music and otherworldly lyrics. “You may love their music or you may not, but whatever you feel, at last you know you can listen to artists who are real.” The three members of this young sister act, we read, “are happy people and love what they are doing.”

headline: I Sing the Gadget Electronic
text: ON a rainy April morning in what looked more like a makeshift office than an art studio, Cory Arcangel was deciding what drawings to produce for his survey show “Cory Arcangel: Pro Tools,” which opens Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Of two possible contenders, one would present the lyrics of the Miley Cyrus song “Party in the U.S.A.” in playful, loopy lettering; the other would be an intricately rendered tree. Both images would feature delicate lines laid down by a steady hand, though not Mr. Arcangel’s: the drawings would in fact be the product of a 1990s pen plotter machine, until recently defunct, which Mr. Arcangel had rerigged and reprogrammed.

headline: The Morning Line: Is the Outside the Right Side for Animal Kingdom?

headline: The New Wave
text: Surf culture has long produced its own aesthetic, along with a tradition of surfer-artists. On the visual vanguard at the moment are Alex Kopps and Tin Ojeda. Kopps’s films, graffiti and collage-like prints (alexkopps.com) give an urban edge to what is usually a beachy domain. “The content and events that have influenced my artwork were not discovered at the beach,” says Kopps, who lives in the Bay Area and sells some of his T-shirts and posters (right) at Mollusk Surf Shop. His film “Displacement,” about “displacement hull” surfboards, uses 1970s Super-8 footage with abstract effects. Ojeda, the Argentinian-born painter and surfer behind the Drug Money Art clothing line (drugmoneyart.com), is bringing the beach to the city. His tees, on which he hand-prints phrases (“Beauty Is Boring,” says one), first gained a following in his home base of Montauk, N.Y. Now they’re at Barneys and in stores in Tokyo, Berlin and London.

headline: Syria Condemns U.S. Sanctions on Assad
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government condemned on Thursday American sanctions against President Bashar al-Assad and six of his top officials over the ferocious crackdown on antigovernment protesters that human rights activists say has killed at least 850 people.

headline: Netanyahu Responds Icily to Obama Remarks
text: JERUSALEM — President Obama’s endorsement on Thursday of using the 1967 boundaries as the baseline for a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian dispute — the first by an American president — prompted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to push back testily and the Palestinian leadership to call an urgent meeting.

headline: G.O.P. Blocks Judicial Nominee in a Sign of Battles to Come
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked a final vote on President Obama’s choice for a federal appeals court opening, marking the first successful Republican filibuster of an Obama administration judicial nominee.

headline: Are Young College Grads Too Lazy to Work?
text: I’ve received a lot of passionate (and angry) e-mails in response to my article today on the employment fate of recent college graduates. While the messages from young people almost uniformly expressed frustration at the job market they’d been thrust into, some of the e-mails from older readers argued that today’s college graduates were having trouble finding jobs because they hadn’t worked hard enough. For example, a reader named Norman Berger asks why graduates wonder why they prove worthless to a potential employer when they follow this approach:

headline: The Importance of Venting, When a Reactor Threatens to Blow Its Stack
text: As I wrote in Thursday’s paper, the Fukushima Daiichi accident is renewing a debate over whether the emergency venting systems that were added to boiling water reactors 20 years ago should be opened only directly by operators or function automatically.

headline: Joe Drape’s Preakness Picks
text: The Pimlico oddsmaker Frank Carulli set the morning line for Saturday’s Preakness Stakes, and Joe Drape has listed the horses in order of preference.

headline: Suit Seeks Higher Royalties From Universal Music
text: Two months after Eminem’s producers won a case against the Universal Music Group over how royalties are computed for digital music, more artists have followed with complaints that they are owed what may amount to millions of dollars in unpaid earnings.

headline: Online Treasury Sales Challenge Elderly Investors
text: The federal government has started shifting the purchase of Treasury securities to the Internet to cut costs, which means many elderly investors are facing an unwelcome change.

headline: Report on the Upper Big Branch Mine Explosion ﻿
text: An independent team investigating 2010 coal mine explosion in West Virginia put the blame squarely on Massey Energy.

headline: Perched in Berlin With Hitler Rising
text: One of the malicious nicknames given to William E. Dodd by his fellow American diplomats in the 1930s was “Telephone Book Dodd.” The joke was that Franklin D. Roosevelt, who appointed Dodd ambassador to Germany in 1933, had supposedly meant to offer the post to a Yale law professor named Walter F. Dodd but made a mistake in looking up the name.

headline: Nothing New as No-Hit Bid Again Teases Mets
text: The first batter Mets starter Dillon Gee faced Thursday, Roger Bernadina, fouled off one two-strike pitch after another, eight in all. Twelve pitches into the at-bat, Bernadina still stood in the batter’s box, as determined as Gee.

headline: Theater Talkback: The Skittish Play
text: My patience with “Sleep No More,” the elaborate haunted house masquerading as theater in Chelsea, began to wear thin at about the time the pointy plastic mask I was wearing started pinching at the bridge of my nose.

headline: Reaction in Arab Capitals Is Muted and Mixed
text: CAIRO — President Obama may have hoped that his embrace of the democracy movement sweeping the Arab world might revive the warmth his name evoked after his speech to the Muslim world two years ago. But across the region, many said his soaring words and financial pledges did little to undo their disappointment at his apparent equivocation during the early days of the Arab revolt.

headline: For U.S., Matching Moral and Financial Support for Revolts Proves Difficult
text: WASHINGTON — After six months of struggle inside the White House to reconcile American interests in the Arab uprisings with American values, President Obama on Thursday sought to portray the region’s revolt in the historical tradition of the American Revolution and the civil rights movement.

headline: Photo Replay: May 19
text: The day in sports included preparations for the Preakness Stakes and the French Open, and a crash in practice for the coming Indianapolis 500.

headline: Update on Violet: One Good Leg, but Still Hanging On
text: A week after the state decided not to intervene, Violet the red-tailed hawk is neither worse nor better, which offers some relief to those who have been monitoring her condition.

headline: Republicans Pounce on Obama’s Mideast Speech
text: Republicans on Thursday lashed out at President Obama, accusing him of abandoning support for the United States’ most important ally in the Middle East by calling for a peace deal built around Israel’s 1967 borders.

headline: An Inventory of Curiosities, Tales Included
text: IT would seem an almost impossible feat to stand out amid the clutter of Archangel Antiques, in the East Village, where tightly packed rails of vintage clothing vie for attention with glass cabinets lined with jewelry and curiosities. Yet the first thing most customers notice after descending to the subterranean entrance is Michael Duggan, who can usually be found sitting toward the back of the musty space, peering out from behind a pair of beige, 1950s tortoiseshell glasses.

headline: As School Roofs Crumble, Toronto Finds Solar Solution
text: Like many of its counterparts in the United States, the Toronto District School Board oversees a large number of schools that were built as a result of the baby boom. Now that those schools, like their former pupils, are firmly in late middle age, their roofs have become a major financial problem. The board estimates that it faces a $3 billion backlog in roofing repairs.

headline: Movie Listings for May 20-26
text: Movies

headline: Bucking Up the British in the Midst of the Fight
text: Most of what happens in “Went the Day Well?” — an undeservedly forgotten British film showing at Film Forum starting on Friday — is a flashback. In the first scene, a friendly chap in a village churchyard addresses the camera, which is to say the audience, and supposes we want to hear about the big battle that happened in the town a few years before.

headline: Posada to Start in Field; Teixeira to D.H.
text: BALTIMORE — Jorge Posada will play in the field Thursday night for the first time this season, but it will not be at catcher.

headline: Theater Listings: May 20 — 26
text: Theater

headline: Enjoying the Long Haul
text: I had just shifted the 26-foot Penske Truck Rental rig into Park at the end of a 2,225-mile journey, when it struck me. I had as much fun driving from Ann Arbor to Southern California in this big, dumb, bucking behemoth as I did hustling a Ferrari 458 Italia from Italy to England last summer.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Had Worked as Qaeda Courier
text: The Guantánamo Bay detainee who apparently committed suicide on Wednesday had worked as a courier for senior officials for Al Qaeda in Pakistan, a job similar to those who ultimately were instrumental in leading the United States military to tracking down Osama bin Laden, according to government documents.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 20-26
text: Art

headline: The Art of Collecting Collections
text: SHELBURNE, Vt. — There is a mystery about the Shelburne Museum. And you could easily spend a day here, just south of Burlington, walking around its 45 acres, amazed, awed and amused, and still not figure it out.

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
text: Italy’s most cosmopolitan city refuses to coast on its legendary treasures.

headline: 36 Hours in Milan
text: For updated suggestions on what to do in Milan, see this more recent 36 Hours column.

headline: Calling a Rape a Rape
text: Reading the story in The Times earlier this week about Tristane Banon, a 31-year-old journalist who said that Dominique Strauss-Kahn tried to rape her during an interview in 2002, I was struck by the conversation she had soon after with her mother, who discouraged her from filing charges against a powerful man who was a friend of the family. As Banon’s mother, Anne Mansouret, a Socialist Party official, recounted the conversation, she told her daughter: “Listen, you know, if he had raped you, I wouldn’t have any hesitation, but that wasn’t the case. He sexually assaulted you, there wasn’t any rape per se; so until the end of your life, you’re going to have on your résumé, you know, Tristane Banon is the girl who. …” Banon ultimately decided not to press charges.

headline: Study Sees Way to Win Spam Fight
text: For years, a team of computer scientists at two University of California campuses has been looking deeply into the nature of spam, the billions of unwanted e-mail messages generated by networks of zombie computers controlled by the rogue programs called botnets. They even coined a term, “spamalytics,” to describe their work.

headline: Chinese Characters and Matisse at the Morgan; ‘Hide/Seek’ Heads to the Brooklyn
text: A “floating, iridescent cloud of calligraphy” is how the conceptual artist Xu Bing describes “The Living Word,” his installation of about 400 carved and painted acrylic Chinese characters. This summer, “The Living Word 3” — the latest version in a series that began in 2001 — will rise to the highest point of the Morgan Library & Museum’s glass atrium.

headline: Beatles Photos, Medieval Fashion and Forbes’s Auctions
text: In the early 1960s the Beatles posed for hours for the German photographer Astrid Kirchherr, even before the roster of four band members was finalized. She met them when they first played in her native Hamburg and encouraged them to imitate her bowl-cut hair and collarless jackets.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Israel, Egypt and Afghanistan.

headline: City Unemployment Rate Dips to 8.6%
text: Even though New York City’s stalled construction industry has not begun to hire back laid-off workers, the city’s unemployment rate dipped again in April to its lowest level in more than two years.

headline: Empowering People of Spaceship Earth
text: For a generation that came of age in the late 1960s and early ’70s, three unusual reference books were catalytic consciousness raisers. “The Joy of Sex” and “Our Bodies, Ourselves” are still in print; the third and possibly most influential of all is less familiar to people born after 1980: the Whole Earth Catalog. Brainchild of the visionary techno-hippie artist Steward Brand, this compendium of resources for the New Age is the subject of “Access to Tools: Publications From the Whole Earth Catalog, 1968-1974,” a modest but stirring time capsule of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: TimesCast | May 19, 2011
text: President Obama speaks on sweeping changes in the Mideast and outlines a potential peace deal between Palestinians and Israel; the view from Jerusalem; and reaction from Cairo.

headline: In LinkedIn, Some See Potential
text: Whether LinkedIn becomes a worthwhile long-term investment will depend largely on how effectively it can translate its place as "the" go-to social networking site for professionals into revenue.

headline: In LinkedIn, Advertisers See Potential
text: LinkedIn’s potential as a long-term investment will depend largely on how effectively the company can translate its position as “the” networking site for professionals into revenue. DealBook spoke to several digital advertising executives about the site’s status within the social media world.

headline: A Grand Tour, With Asterisks
text: A road trip in the new Fiat 500 wouldn’t be complete without stops in Naples (Me.), Verona (N.J.), Rome (Ga.) and Venice (Fla.).

headline: Stuck at the Border Between the Sexes
text: SOME people assume transgender men are lesbians who couldn’t handle being gay. They really think a female would go through all the hassles of transitioning to male just so she could trick other women into sleeping with her.

headline: Court Documents Show F.B.I. Is Investigating Unabomber in Tylenol Case
text: An examination by the Federal Bureau of Investigation brings together two of the highest profile domestic crimes of the late 20th century.

headline: An Inventory of Curiosities, Tales Included
text: It would seem an almost impossible feat to stand out amid the clutter of Archangel Antiques, in the East Village, where tightly packed rails of vintage clothing vie for attention with glass cabinets lined with jewelry and curiosities. Yet the first thing most customers notice after descending to the subterranean entrance is Michael Duggan, who can usually be found sitting toward the back of the musty space, peering out from behind a pair of beige, 1950s tortoiseshell glasses.

headline: Danish Director Barred From Festival After Making Hitler Jokes
text: CANNES, France — The Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier has been a fixture at the Cannes Film Festival throughout his career. All but one of his features have had their premieres here, and he won the top prize, the Palme d’Or, in 2000 for “Dancer in the Dark.” But the longstanding relationship came to an abrupt halt on Thursday when the festival’s board of directors declared Mr. von Trier “persona non grata” a day after he joked at a news conference for his latest film, “Melancholia,” that he was a Nazi and sympathized with Hitler.

headline: Uninterrupted Landscape
text: On the road with Mark Bittman on his Spring Farm and Food Tour.

headline: Facebook Page, R.I.P.
text: My sister-in-law died in September. I removed her from my list of Facebook friends, but her Facebook page is still active, and the site keeps asking me if I want to friend her. At what point would it be O.K. to mention to her husband that maybe it’s time to close her account?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Israel, Egypt and Afghanistan.

headline: A Provocateur Steals Cannes Spotlight
text: CANNES, France — On Thursday the 64th Cannes Film Festival took a surreal turn when the festival’s board of directors announced that the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier had been declared persona non grata, the news erupting shortly before the latest movie from the now imprisoned Iranian director Jafar Panahi was shown.

headline: Your Photos: Prom Nights to Remember, and Nightmares
text: New York Times readers around the country (and world) submitted their photos and stories of proms recent and long-past.

headline: Close to Eden, Where the Music Is Artisanal
text: The oohs have it — along with that ahs, ohs, and whoas — in songs by Fleet Foxes, a band formed in Seattle that started a two-night stand at the United Palace on Wednesday night. Sooner or later, nearly every Fleet Foxes song gives way to a stretch of wordless vocal harmonies shared by three, four, perhaps five voices, moving together in chords or interweaving in counterpoint. Those harmonies are many things at once: a show of skill and preparation, an offering of sweetness, a utopian communal project and, perhaps most of all, a temporary paradise, a refuge from any kind of discord.

headline: From the Classical World of Apollos and Fauns to a Romantic Passion
text: Some things that happened for the first time seem to be happening again. The first three ballets of Wednesday’s program at New York City Ballet — George Balanchine’s “Apollo,” and Jerome Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun” and “Antique Epigraphs” — all address different aspects of innocence, with the world seeming new; it’s heartening to see them all in good shape. The fourth, Balanchine’s “Sonnambula,” alternately suggests a society both old and sophisticated, death and a dark form of transcendence.

headline: From Thornton to Sioux City
text: I spent yesterday with Linus Solberg, a soybean farmer in Cylinder, Iowa, no doubt ruining his day – he was trying to get his beans in the ground – and compressing the rest of mine. But it’s impossible to leave when someone is friendly, warm and funny.

headline: In Polar Bear Territory
text: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

headline: She Loved Herself, Yes, but She Also Loved Art
text: Peggy Guggenheim did what she wanted, which was fairly unusual for women born in 1898. A rich New Yorker (although not as rich as some of the other Guggenheims), she married twice and had children but devoted most of her adult life to her modern-art collection and to love affairs, often with men who made art.

headline: Q & A
text: Related by Marriage and Co-op Board

headline: Leave the Stuff, Keep the Memories
text: JAY GOLDSTEIN and his wife, Carrie, accumulated 15,000 books in the 46 years they lived in the Glen Cove split ranch where they raised their four children. Its sixth bedroom became the second story of a library. All sorts of memorabilia and other hard-to-toss belongings accumulated in the attic and basement.  In February, when their home went into contract for $550,000, deciding what to take, what to dispose of and how to lay out their new $8,050-a-month two-bedroom rental apartment at the Atria on Roslyn Harbor, an independent senior community in Roslyn, seemed overwhelming.

headline: In House Pricing, Own Up to Flaws
text: BROKERS say conventional wisdom still holds: Price a house right, and do so from the start. But even when a seller is willing to follow that advice, it’s not always obvious what the right price is. The challenge seems to lie in accurately assessing what factors might make a house less than immediately saleable — and in knowing just how much money those negative factors should chop from the price tag.

headline: A 30-Month Short-Sale Saga
text: TEANECK

headline: Ronald Dickerman
text: Mr. Dickerman, 47, is the founder and president of Madison International Realty, a real estate private equity firm, which through its investment funds holds ownership stakes in buildings around the world, including several in the New York area, among them the Chrysler East Building and 520 Madison Avenue. The company has also had investments in the Seagram Building over the years.

headline: Mr. Disability
text: As we’ve noted here before, the federal disability program cost about $190 billion last year, in payments to disabled workers and health care for them. That’s the equivalent of roughly $1,500 in taxes for every American household.

text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#750", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Keeping Score: Posada Put Off Decline for Years
text: Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

headline: The Caucus Podcast: Obama’s Speech and Republican Reaction
text: Tune into The Caucus podcast to hear a discussion of President Obama’s Middle East speech and the reaction of some of the Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Sculpture in High Relief
text: It has been a while since sculpture could be dismissed as “something you bump into when you back up to look at a painting,” as Ad Reinhardt, the Abstract Expressionist painter, once said. Even before Reinhardt died, in 1967, the medium was going supernova, expanding and diversifying at an astounding pace. First it began incorporating all manner of found objects and nontraditional materials; then it lifted brilliant color from painting and achieved new levels of abstraction. Since then it has come to include installations, environments, land art, performance and all manner of spectacle.

headline: British Police Warn Rwandan Dissidents of Threat
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — The British police have warned two outspoken Rwandan dissidents living in London that their lives are in danger because the Rwandan government may be plotting to kill them, according to British officials and documents.

headline: Sasha Mullins and Patrick Lassiter
text: FOR Lisa Sasha Mullins, the best solution to any problem is a road trip on her motorcycle, a Harley Davidson she calls Tigerlily. Riding motorcycles is her “wind meditation,” she said, as well as her career.

headline: A Hike Down Herkimer Street
text: HERKIMER Street, from Bedford to Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, is a perfect urban jumble: old frame houses smothered in aluminum siding; apartment buildings jammed in next to tiny brownstones; an empty mansion; a Baptist church in the Islamic style. It requires three or four passes (and a slide show online) to take in even half the details on this complex block.

headline: New Brokerage Donates Portion of Fees to Charity
text: A NEW brokerage in New York says it will donate part of its fee from every sale to a group that helps provide safe drinking water in developing countries like Haiti, Liberia and the Central African Republic.

headline: Trump Cancels Iowa Dinner
text: The first real casualty of Donald J. Trump‘s shuttered presidential ambitions has been claimed: the Republican Party of Iowa’s Lincoln Day Dinner.

headline: First Adult Apartment (Must Be a Deal)
text: FOR three years, Shai Benhamou lived with a roommate in a walk-up rental on the Upper East Side. They spent just over $1,600 a month for the two-bedroom apartment, but the bedrooms were only nine feet square. The York Avenue location was far from downtown, where Mr. Benhamou spent most of his nonworking hours.

headline: How to Avoid Roommate Regret
text: IF you are a recent college graduate, you may think your roommate days are behind you. But in New York, where real estate is expensive and in short supply, there’s a very good chance you will be sharing an apartment well into your professional years.

headline: UBS Names Head of Energy Banking
text: UBS said Thursday that it had hired Thomas Langford from Morgan Stanley to be its global head of energy investment banking.

headline: China Admits Problems With Three Gorges Dam
text: BEIJING — The Three Gorges Dam, the world’s largest hydroelectric project and a symbol of China’s confidence in risky technological solutions, is troubled by urgent pollution and geologic problems, a high-level government body acknowledged Thursday.

headline: Capitalists Who Fear Free Markets
text: Capitalism is supposed to produce losses on bad investments.

headline: Counseling Before Borrowing
text: EVEN though the housing market remains sluggish, Bernell Grier says that her nonprofit agency is hearing from “record numbers of people” seeking advice on how home-buying works and whether they’re in a position to own now that real estate prices have fallen.

headline: Israeli Settlers Reject the ‘Auschwitz Borders’ of 1967
text: While journalists in the Arab world reported that it was difficult to find any reaction at all to President Obama’s speech on the Middle East, his remarks on the future shape of a Palestinian state did prompt a lengthy and pointed reply on one Israeli Facebook page, that of the Israeli prime minister’s office.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Archangel Antiques
text: At Archangel Antiques in the West Village, it’s the curious range of objects — and the colorful store manager — that draw you in.

headline: Schwarzenegger’s Movie Career Put on Hold
text: Arnold Schwarzenegger is putting his acting career on pause, one of his lawyers said Thursday, amid the news that he fathered a child with a former member of his household staff more than a decade ago.

headline: The Shelburne Museum
text: Images from the collections at the Shelburne Museum in Vermont.

headline: Florent, the Restaurant and the Man, on Film
text: David Sigal’s documentary “Florent: Queen of the Meat Market” isn’t just the story of a pioneering restaurateur and his scruffy New York establishment that flourished for 23 years. It is a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.

headline: A Workout, Even for a Runner
text: I’M suspicious of workouts that don’t give the same kind of cardio buzz that running and plyometrics do, and I often write off these so-called softer exercise routines as unchallenging. The Nalini Method, however, recently put me in my place.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Theater nerds all over the city are beginning to geek out about the 2011 Tony Awards. The ceremony isn’t until June 12, but you can feed your theatrical beast at the American Theater Wing’s free Tony documentary film series at the Times Square Visitor Center on Monday.

headline: Conrad to Defer Work on Budget
text: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, announced Thursday that the panel would defer work indefinitely on a budget for the coming fiscal year, and wait to see whether negotiations between the White House and Congressional leaders yield a bipartisan deficit-reduction compromise.

headline: A Former Basketball Prodigy, Bereft of All but His Memories
text: LOS ANGELES — When Stephen Turner pulled his silver Mercedes into the Mobil station on a gritty stretch of Hollywood near Vine Street and Santa Monica Boulevard, he did not immediately recognize the gigantic man with Windex who ambled over and offered to wash his windows for a tip.

headline: Postgraduate Work in Bergman Madness
text: WHEN Mark Romanek was casting his movie version of the Kazuo Ishiguro novel “Never Let Me Go” in 2009, the producers gave him one bit of advice, he said: “Hire the genius, Mulligan.” That would be Carey Mulligan, the almost freakishly talented young British actress, who has embarked on an eight-week run in the Atlantic Theater Company’s production of “Through a Glass Darkly,” Jenny Worton’s stage adaptation of the 1961 Ingmar Bergman film.

headline: Stage Scenes: Carey Mulligan
text: Photos of some of the actress’s work on stage and screen.

headline: Guessing Game Over Prominent Blagojevich Witnesses
text: CHICAGO – Lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, said on Thursday that they planned to call several witnesses of “some prominence” at his retrial next week, leading to speculation here over who could take the stand. Could it be Rahm Emanuel, the city’s new mayor? Or Representative Jesse Jackson Jr.?

headline: TimesCast | Reaction From Cairo
text: May 19, 2011 - Journalists at Daily News Egypt, an English-language newspaper in Cairo, react to President Obama's Middle East speech.

headline: Spidey Syndrome Invades the Opera
