headline: A City in Peril
text: Electrified by images of gore-drenched interiors and chaotic street massacres, “8 Murders a Day” is an impassioned attack on the 2006 decision by Mexican President Felipe Calderón to enact a military campaign against two warring drug cartels in Juarez.

headline: The Sensors Are Coming!
text: If you own a smartphone, you probably know just how smart those little gadgets are. They know where you’re standing, the direction you’re moving in and if you’re holding the phone vertically or horizontally.

headline: Contrarian Investor Shuns Hot Idea for Bigger Picture
text: As investors clamor for shares of social media darlings, Peter Thiel is avoiding the frenzy.

headline: The Residents Go, the Music Stays
text: “Lost Bohemia,” a new documentary by Josef Astor, is a sad and spirited elegy for the Carnegie Hall Studios, which for more than a century provided working, living and teaching space for all kinds of artists on the floors above the famous concert hall. Mr. Astor, a photographer who moved into the building in 1985, pays tribute to his neighbors and friends who made up the last generation of studio residents. He also acknowledges the famous ghosts who haunt the place, ranging from Isadora Duncan and Enrico Caruso to Marilyn Monroe and Martha Graham.

headline: Court Filings Assert Iran Had Link to 9/11 Attacks
text: Two defectors from Iran’s intelligence service have testified that Iranian officials had “foreknowledge of the 9/11 attacks,” according to a court filing Thursday in a federal lawsuit in Manhattan that seeks damages for Iran’s “direct support for, and sponsorship of, the most deadly act of terrorism in American history.”

headline: A Solemn Homecoming
text: Equally awash in blood and sentiment, “Cost of a Soul” is a remorselessly violent drama populated by weeping women and tormented men.

headline: Virtually a Good Time
text: As you might expect from a documentary whose producers include the Oprah Winfrey Network, “Life 2.0” is less about the realities of Second Life, the immersive online world, than it is about the offline pathologies of the people who choose to live there.

headline: Thrashers Appear Poised to Relocate to Winnipeg
text: The Thrashers stood on the brink of relocation to Winnipeg on Thursday, with the last hope for keeping the team in Atlanta hinging on negotiations with one remaining potential buyer, according to the team’s president.

headline: Upwardly Mobile Nannies Move Into the Brazilian Middle Class

headline: China: Censorship Suit Filed Against Web Company
text: Eight Chinese-born pro-democracy advocates filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Wednesday against one of China’s largest Internet companies, Baidu, accusing it of colluding with the government in censoring Web search results. The suit charges that there is a “conspiracy” between Baidu and the government to censor “any political speech that is pro-democracy.” Jiang Yu, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, said Thursday that China guaranteed freedom of speech online and that American courts had no jurisdiction in the country, the news agency Xinhua reported.

headline: Belarus: A $3 Billion Bailout? Not So Fast, Says Russia
text: Officials in Belarus said Thursday they had won a $3 billion loan from a Russian-backed fund to alleviate the economic crisis, but Russia’s finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, said no such decision by the Eurasian Economic Community had been made. Belarus has little hope of winning loans from Western governments, so Russia and other former Soviet states are negotiating a bailout. Twice this week, Belarussian officials have announced a deal, apparently eager to tamp down market panic, only to be contradicted by Mr. Kudrin.

headline: A Contemporary Romantic Melodrama
text: Among the steady stream of new Chinese movies opening in America, “A Beautiful Life” stands out — rather than an overstuffed, jingoistic historical tale or martial-arts blowout, it’s a contemporary romantic melodrama with a plaintive pop soundtrack that might call to mind “Terms of Endearment,” “The Other Sister” or, most strongly, a Nora Ephron comedy minus most of the laughs. (There’s also a bit of “Memento” thrown in.)

headline: Liberty Media Offers to Buy Barnes & Noble

headline: Electrode Experiment Shows Promise as a Paralyzed Man Stands
text: A young man paralyzed by an injury to his spinal cord has regained the ability to stand for short periods, take steps with help and move his legs and feet at will, with the help of an electrical stimulator implanted in his lower back.

headline: Libya Revolt Sidelines Women, Who Led It
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — In recent days, after weeks of delays and closed-door meetings, rebel leaders here have announced a slate of new appointments, including a defense chief and a minister for reconstruction and infrastructure. They have added members to a national council, to represent areas in southern, central and western Libya, all in an effort to bolster the revolution, better represent the country as a whole and — in the event that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi bolts — make civil war unlikely, the rebel leaders explained.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 19, 2011
text: Libyans watched a television broadcast of a speech by President Obama on Thursday.

headline: Don Barden, a Leading Black Businessman, Dies at 67
text: DETROIT — Don H. Barden, who rose from poverty to build one of the nation’s largest black-owned businesses through casinos and cable television, died on Thursday in Detroit. He was 67.

headline: NASA Installs Device at Space Station in Long-Sought Quest for Antimatter
text: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. — The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour attached a $2 billion cosmic ray detector to the International Space Station on Thursday, and delighted scientists immediately began detecting “thousands and thousands” of subatomic particles from deep space.

headline: Worth Reading: LinkedIn Traded for $14.50 a Share Last Year
text: Liz Gannes at AllThings D looks at the price of LinkedIn shares when they were traded on SecondMarket.

headline: Parents Battle School Districts for Special Support

headline: Ex-Teammate Says He Saw Armstrong Dope
text: Tyler Hamilton, a former cyclist who was on three of Lance Armstrong’s victorious Tour de France teams, told CBS News that he had witnessed Armstrong’s use of performance-enhancing drugs.

headline: Deal Reached on Extension of Patriot Act
text: WASHINGTON — Congressional leaders on Thursday reached a deal to extend by four years several statutes that expanded the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s counterterrorism and surveillance powers after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, aides said.

headline: Ex-I.M.F. Chief Granted Bail
text: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, was granted $1 million bail, and will remain under 24-hour surveillance with an ankle monitor.

headline: Arizona: 21 Arrested in Smuggling Ring
text: Law enforcement officials announced Thursday the arrest of 21 people who they said used a remote area of the Tohono O’Odham Indian reservation to smuggle marijuana and migrants from Mexico into the United States. Working with spotters equipped with night-vision goggles and radios, the smugglers were allied with a Mexican drug trafficking organization, officials said.

headline: Mets Looked at Fraud Coverage for Madoff Stakes
text: In 2001, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets, decided to explore a fairly novel way of protecting the hundreds of millions of dollars they, their families and their businesses had invested with Bernard L. Madoff: they considered buying something called fraud insurance.

headline: Refusing to Give In to Eviction
text: On Jan. 19, 63-year-old Tanya Dennis hired a locksmith and broke into her South Berkeley home.

headline: California: Schwarzenegger Postpones Return to Film
text: Former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is putting his acting career on pause, one of his lawyers said Thursday, amid the news that he had fathered a child with a former member of his household staff more than a decade ago. The lawyer, Patrick Knapp, said in a statement that at Mr. Schwarzenegger’s request “we asked Creative Artists Agency to inform all his motion picture projects currently under way or being negotiated to stop planning until further notice. Governor Schwarzenegger is focusing on personal matters and is not willing to commit to any production schedules or timelines.” The hiatus will include “Cry Macho,” a movie that was expected to begin production in August. The Terminator franchise and all other projects under consideration are also on hold, Mr. Knapp said, adding: “We will resume discussions when Governor Schwarzenegger decides.”

headline: Armstrong Accused of Drug Use by Ex-Teammate
text: The cyclist Tyler Hamilton, one of Lance Armstrong’s former teammates on the United States Postal Service team, said he saw Armstrong inject himself with the banned performance-enhancing drug EPO to win the Tour de France, according to a report on CBS’s “60 Minutes” that will run Sunday.

text: Atlanta

headline: Losing (but Loving) the Green Card Lottery
text: Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Washington: Senate Committee to Defer Budget Talks
text: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, announced Thursday that the panel would indefinitely defer work on a budget for the coming fiscal year. Mr. Conrad said the size of the projected annual deficits and the divisions between the two parties argued for awaiting the results of the bipartisan talks between Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Congressional leaders of both parties. All 11 Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee issued a statement criticizing the budget delay.

headline: A Havana Connection Infuses the Music Scene
text: You won’t find many Cuban sandwich shops around San Francisco or Cuban coffee on the menu at many taquerías, but those interested in Latin music and dance can’t swing a batá drum without hitting a Cuban salsa class or finding Afro-Cuban-style timba music in clubs.

headline: Retailers Fall Short as Shoppers Cut Back
text: Sears Holdings, the department store chain, swung to a first-quarter loss as shoppers cut back on spending.

headline: Aiming to Rein In the Anarchy on 2 Wheels
text: Lunchtime on a spring day in 2009, and people in Midtown Manhattan swarmed from their offices, drawing breath on a fine afternoon. Stuart Gruskin, a 51-year-old executive in the financial industry, was on West 43rd Street near Fifth Avenue. He stepped off the curb in front of the Princeton Club.

headline: ‘The Death Knell of Slavery’
text: When North Carolina finally voted to secede on May 20, 1861, editor William Holden later wrote, the state’s convention “looked like a sea partly in storm, partly calm, the secessionists shouting and throwing up their hats and rejoicing, the Conservatives sitting quietly, calm, and depressed.” Even as they voted unanimously to leave the Union, North Carolina’s leading politicians could not conceal the conflicts that would divide the state throughout the war.

headline: A Conversation About Food, Cooking and Alice B. Toklas
text: Virginia Heffernan talks with Amanda Hesser, a co-founder of food52 and the author of “The Essential New York Times Cookbook,” about some of the issues raised in a recent column.  — The Editors

headline: Publishers as Partners in Literacy
text: This week, I reported on the First Book Marketplace, which sells new books at steep discounts to schools and reading programs serving low-income children. Based on sales growth, First Book, which is a nonprofit, anticipates that the marketplace will be financially self-sustaining within a few years. It’s hard to find fault with a social-purpose business that makes quality books more affordable for underprivileged children. But, surprisingly, many readers responded to the idea by suggesting that the problem of book access can be adequately addressed through rummage sales, thrift shops, used book outlets and libraries. This reflects a misunderstanding of the problem, which I’d like to clarify.

headline: Blagojevich’s Courtroom, Oprah’s Arena
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Obama and Netanyahu, Distrustful Allies, Meet
text: WASHINGTON — As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel heads to the White House on Friday for the seventh meeting since President Obama took office, the two men are facing a turning point in a relationship that has never been warm.

headline: A Memorable Debut for Hector Noesi
text: Hector Noesi’s two children had been long asleep by the time their father made his major league debut Wednesday night, pitching four scoreless innings in the Yankees’ 4-1 victory. But when Yeudri, his 5-year-old son, woke up and heard that Noesi had finally pitched, he had but one question: “Did my daddy win the game?” Noesi recounted that story Thursday afternoon, when he was still trying to process his good fortune.

headline: Making Things in America
text: Some years ago, one of my neighbors, an émigré Russian engineer, offered an observation about his adopted country. “America seems very rich,” he said, “but I never see anyone actually making anything.”

headline: A River’s Crest Arrives, and Is Set to Linger
text: VICKSBURG, Miss. — Here it was at last — high, fast and in a very bad mood.

headline: Judgment Day Followers Await Rapture
text: Thousands of people around the country prepared for Saturday, May 21, also known as Judgment Day, when believers expected to be absorbed into heaven in a process known as Rapture.

headline: Here’s a Great Place to Cut
text: It seems hard to believe, but the federal farm subsidy program — wasteful, inefficient and virtually indestructible — may at last be headed for serious downsizing.

headline: Insurers Told to Justify Rate Increases Over 10 Percent
text: WASHINGTON — Alarmed at soaring premiums and profits in the health insurance industry, the Obama administration demanded on Thursday that insurers justify proposed rate increases of more than 10 percent, starting in September.

headline: A Season Interrupted for Barcelona’s Abidal
text: BARCELONA, Spain — Surgery in mid-March to have a tumor removed from his liver brought a scary disruption to Éric Abidal’s professional soccer career. His unexpectedly fast return to the sport also brought a reassessment of his life.

headline: LinkedIn’s Surge Sets Stage for More Internet I.P.O.’s
text: It’s not 1999, but the big Internet I.P.O. is back.

headline: Peace and Change
text: We have been waiting for President Obama to lay out his vision of the promises and challenges of the upheaval in the Arab world. His speech on Thursday did not go far enough — there was no game-changing proposal on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict — but he did promise strong support to those yearning for freedom and goaded American allies, including Israel, to take the political risks that are essential for peaceful change and the only way to build a lasting peace.

headline: Iran’s President to Lead Next OPEC Meeting
text: The Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is expected to lead next month’s OPEC conference in Vienna as he presses for higher oil prices to aid Iran’s struggling economy, while also seeking to protect and consolidate his power at home as he confronts a growing split with the nation’s supreme leader.

headline: Zenyatta’s Trainer Uncovers a Colt That Gives Him Hope
text: BALTIMORE — Zenyatta’s stall at Hollywood Park remains empty except for a few portraits of her drawn by her fans. She is at Lane’s End farm in Kentucky working on becoming a broodmare. Her trainer, John Shirreffs, is here at Pimlico for the 136th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday with a pretty good colt named Mr. Commons.

headline: Lights on Earth Impede Arizona’s Eyes on Space
text: MOUNT HOPKINS, Ariz. — There is no Border Patrol in space. But the very earthly cat-and-mouse game between smugglers and America’s border agents is affecting the exploration of space, lighting up the nighttime sky in southern Arizona and making astronomers strain even harder to figure out the mysteries of the universe.

headline: Make My Bed? But You Say the World’s Ending
text: The Haddad children of Middletown, Md., have a lot on their minds: school projects, SATs, weekend parties. And parents who believe the earth will begin to self-destruct on Saturday.

headline: They Need to Be Counted
text: It was a relief to see one politician showing political courage and sense in Albany this week. Of course, that politician was Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City and not a state lawmaker. But every bit helps.

headline: Way Back Machine | Doomsday, East Patchogue, 1925
text: Almost since the moment the ink dried on the Book of Revelation, seers and scriptural interpreters have been announcing the precise date and time at which the faithful would be whisked off to heaven and those left behind abandoned to immediate and unpleasant annihilation.

headline: The Truth About Upper Big Branch
text: An inquiry by the state of West Virginia into the Upper Big Branch Mine explosion that killed 29 workers has found the mine’s owner, Massey Energy, “profoundly reckless” in elevating its drive to produce profits above worker safety. Pervasive safety violations — from shoddy ventilation to slapdash control of explosive coal dust — made the mine “an accident waiting to happen,” according to a panel of experts reporting to the governor’s office.

text: After discovering last week that nearly a quarter of their teachers were being dismissed, students at Austin Polytechnical Academy decided to take extreme action. Holding secret planning sessions under the guise of a robotics team meeting, they plotted.

text: HERE is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual television upfront week, which took place around Manhattan from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered advertisers previews of their fare for the 2011-12 season.

headline: Ex-Sheriff’s Employee Draws Prison for Theft
text: PATERSON, N.J. — The former director of the Passaic County Sheriff’s Department motor pool was sentenced on Thursday to four years in prison for stealing $20,000 and a car engine from the department.

text: For as long as anyone can remember, students who have tried to transfer within the City University of New York system — from, say, a community college to a four-year school — have run into delays or denials in getting their course credits accepted. Many have wound up spending additional time and money to secure their degree, while others have simply given up.

headline: Friday: Watchdog in the House
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — There are 500 clues in the Cruciverb.com database that refer to the entry ONO, and the reason that there are only 500 clues listed is because that is the maximum number the database can hold. Yoko Ono has become a startlingly popular entry in crossword puzzles because of the alternating vowel-consonant pattern in her name. Ms. Ono has gotten me out of a sticky filling situation on more than one occasion myself.

headline: Aldermen, Moving In, Lobby to Get Best Offices
text: Even before the April runoff election determined the membership of the new City Council, veteran aldermen were engaged in another, far less public, campaign: lobbying for premier office space at City Hall.

headline: When ‘Boy Meets Girl’ Plays Second Fiddle
text: Thanks to two central performances that go a long way toward transcending the occasional placeholder melody and clunky double entendre (O.K., the more-than-occasional clunky double entendre), “Lucky Guy” is more fun than it ought to be.

headline: Before the Baby Is Born, Dad Needs to Soothe His Own Inner Child
text: Impending parenthood whips up a familiar tempest of anxieties in the hero of “Knickerbocker,” a new play by Jonathan Marc Sherman that opened on Thursday night at the Public Theater. Doubts about his readiness to assume the role of responsible caregiver all but ooze from the pores of Jerry (Alexander Chaplin), a 40-year-old book editor whose garden-variety neuroses are inflamed by the knowledge that he will soon have to relinquish gazing at his own navel in favor of cooing over his little boy’s.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Pressure to Improve Water Quality in Chicago River
text: In recent days, the federal government and environmental groups have increased the pressure on Chicago’s wastewater treatment agency to stop discharging untreated sewage into the Chicago River during storms and to disinfect the treated sewage that makes up 70 percent of the river’s flow.

headline: Budgeters Try to Save Season for the New York City Opera
text: Board members of the New York City Opera hashed through the company’s budget and programming options for next season in a grueling daylong meeting on Thursday, a watershed moment for what was once one of the country’s major opera companies. Adding to the pressure, union officials appealed for more mainstream programming and denounced the way the company has been marketing itself.

headline: Bloggingheads: Google and Free Speech
text: Ann Althouse, left, of the University of Wisconsin Law School and Matt Welch of Reason debate Google's threat to free speech.

text: On Wednesday, The Times’s media reporter Tanzina Vega visited the CBS and Adult Swim upfront after-parties. CBS held its post-presentation festivities in a tent at Lincoln Center with a D.J. and television stars, while Adult Swim’s affair at the Roseland Ballroom included a performance by Jay-Z.

headline: A Cloud Over Turkish Candidate’s Chances to Lead I.M.F.
text: LONDON — On paper Kemal Dervis would seem to be the perfect candidate to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn as leader of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: At I.M.F., Men on Prowl and Women on Guard
text: WASHINGTON — It is an international island in the midst of the American capital, a sharp-elbowed place ruled by alpha male economists. The days are long, and employees are regularly pressed together for weeks on end during overseas “missions.” It is a climate in which romances often flourish — and lines are sometimes crossed.

headline: Education Legislation Struggle Breaks Old Alliances, Builds New Ones
text: Just past midnight, at the close of a 14-hour day last week on the floor of the Texas House, Representative Rob Eissler stood joking with reporters.

headline: N.F.L. Requests More Time to Respond to Players’ Lawsuit
text: The N.F.L. asked Thursday for more time to respond to the antitrust lawsuit brought by players in the Brady vs. N.F.L. case. The N.F.L. has asked that the deadline, which is next Monday, be extended until July 6, arguing that the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is likely to have decided on the appeal of the now-delayed injunction that would end the lockout. That decision, the N.F.L. said, is likely to inform future actions, including whether to file a motion to dismiss the case. When the N.F.L. asked the players represented in the Brady suit to consent to the extension, they declined. The league’s motion asking for the extension is pending. The Brady plaintiffs would prefer no delays in the lawsuit, which, with its threat of treble damages if the league is found to have violated antitrust law with restrictions on free agency and the draft, may present the best leverage the players have in their contract negotiations.

headline: There Is More Than One Way to Land a Catfish
text: Brady Knowlton has scurried up trees to escape elephants. He has been chased by lions. But in years of hunting, he said, no experience compares to plunging his bare hand into murky water and feeling the powerful jaw of a big catfish clamp down on his arm.

headline: Saying He’s Not Running Puts Perry in a Good Spot
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

headline: NATO Warplanes Attack Libyan Ships in 3 Ports
text: NAPLES, Italy — NATO warplanes attacked eight Libyan ships on Thursday night in three coastal locations, including the port of Tripoli, expanding the air campaign against what allied officials said was an increasing seaborne threat from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s forces.

headline: Exuberant Days for LinkedIn
text: It looks as if even LinkedIn’s bankers underestimated the hype. The shares more than doubled on the day of their debut, meaning underwriters left more money on the table than they harvested for LinkedIn and its selling shareholders. But if the hype doesn’t wear off soon, the scarcity value of social network investments surely will.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Quiet Departure Is Stark Contrast to Heralded Arrival
text: “CBS Evening News” bade farewell to its anchor, Katie Couric, on Thursday with a five-minute highlights reel and a rendition of the Beatles ballad “In My Life,” but there wasn’t much sadness on the set. Ms. Couric, brisk and dry-eyed, looked almost relieved as she thanked viewers for, as she put it, “coming along with me on this incredible journey.”

headline: E-Books Outsell Print Books at Amazon
text: In the latest chapter in the unfolding tale of the book evolution from ink to pixels, Amazon.com said Thursday that its customers now buy more e-books than print books.

headline: Reviving a Rarity, Right on Time
text: Why certain composers who were popular in their day become marginalized over time is often inexplicable. Somehow this happens especially in opera, perhaps because opera composers so often tailored their works to the specific tastes of the theaters and audiences for which they were writing.

headline: FrontPoint to Shut Most Funds After Insider Trading Charges
text: FrontPoint Partners, once a multibillion-dollar hedge fund before it was battered by allegations of insider trading, will shut down most of its funds by the end of the month.

headline: Debussy Flows in Ripples and Seductive Warbles
text: Introducing a performance of Debussy’s Rhapsody for Clarinet and Piano at the Kosciuszko Foundation on East 65th Street in Manhattan on Wednesday night, the distinguished clarinetist David Shifrin mused to the audience that Debussy probably first heard the piece played in a similarly intimate space. While listening to Mr. Shifrin’s seductive warble and the pianist Gloria Chien’s elegant ripples and shadings, your eyes might wander across warm, wood-paneled walls bedecked with old oil paintings; an ornately sculptured ceiling; and vintage tapestries hung over the windows.

headline: School’s in Session, but Don’t You Dare Take Notes
text: One way jazz can seem from the outside is as a never-ending eulogy. This week in New York there are or have been concerts paying homage to or performing the repertory of: Count Basie, Clifford Jordan, Thelonious Monk, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and the Modern Jazz Quartet. It’s just an average week. Is that O.K.? Is that strange?

headline: From Milan to New York in 240 Years
text: Mozart’s opera “Mitridate, Re di Ponto,” had its premiere in Milan on Dec. 26, 1770. A month later, Mozart turned 15.

headline: New York Public Library Introduces iPad Apps
text: Here an app, there an app, everywhere an apt app. Now the New York Public Library is creating iPad apps that bring its research collections into “the palms of the public’s hand,” as library officials put it in a statement. Biblion: The Boundless Library is the name for a series of apps available on Apple’s tablet computer that highlight different elements in the library’s collection. It was developed by the library and the design firm Potion. The first edition showcases the library’s holdings about the 1939-40 New York World’s Fair, which are among those most consulted by researchers. Users will be able to turn over, zoom in on and roam through hundreds of items. At the end of this week the library is putting out an app that lets the public play Find That Future, from the game designer Jane McGonigal. This summer, look for an app enabling people to reserve books. The first app is available free at Apple’s iTunes store and nypl.org.

headline: Missing Photographer in Libya Is Presumed Dead
text: The family of Anton Hammerl, a South African photojournalist who has been missing in Libya since early last month, said late Thursday that they think he died after being shot on April 5 in the desert.

headline: Widow of Bernard Madoff’s Son Signs a Deal for a Memoir
text: A member of the Madoff family is telling all in a memoir to be released in December, its publisher said on Wednesday. Stephanie Madoff-Mack, the widow of Mark Madoff, the son of Bernard L. Madoff who committed suicide last year, has sold her book to Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. David Rosenthal, the publisher of Blue Rider Press, called it the “first genuine inside account” from a Madoff family member, a memoir that begins with the unraveling of Mr. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme. Ms. Madoff-Mack’s story, he said in a statement, is “heartbreaking, compelling and ultimately courageous.”

headline: ‘American Idol’ Again, by a Mile
text: The three “American Idol” finalists still standing (Haley Reinhart, Scotty McCreery and Lauren Alaina, below from left) competed on Wednesday night for a chance to advance to next week’s finale as 23 million viewers tuned in to Fox’s two-hour reality show broadcast, according to Nielsen’s estimates. No other network came close to matching Fox’s ratings. CBS placed second, earning its best ratings at 9 p.m. with “Criminal Minds” (12.5 million) followed by “Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior” at 10 (8.4 million). At 8, CBS’s rerun of “Criminal Minds” (6.3 million) lagged behind ABC’s sitcom “The Middle” (7.7 million). ABC finished in third place over all, attracting 10.1 million viewers at 9 for “Modern Family” but more modest results for “Cougar Town” at 9:30 (5.4 million) and “Happy Endings” at 10 (3.8 million) and 10:30 (3.1 million). NBC was fourth, leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order: SVU” (8.7 million) but struggling earlier in the night with back-to-back episodes of “Minute to Win It” at 8 (3.5 million) and at 9 (2.9 million).

headline: A 2012 Release Date Is Set for a ‘Titanic’ in 3-D
text: In case you ever doubted it, James Cameron is truly the king of the three-dimensional world. Or he will be when his “Titanic” is re-released by Paramount Pictures and 20th Century Fox on April 6 in 3-D. Mr. Cameron, whose 3-D “Avatar,” with almost $2.8 billion in ticket sales at the worldwide box office, is the highest-grossing film in history, will revise the record books when “Titanic,” the second-highest-grossing film of all time, with $1.8 billion in worldwide sales, returns to theaters in 3-D. Fox and Paramount joined Mr. Cameron’s Lightstorm Entertainment in announcing the re-release date on Thursday. The next frontier in 3-D may well involve not fantasies and cartoons but naturalistic dramas like “Titanic” (starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, left). Steven Soderbergh, for instance, had planned to shoot his coming “Contagion,” a disease drama, in 3-D, but backed off when he couldn’t quite get the results he needed. Still, 3-D thrillers, love stories and raunchy teen comedies (shudder) clearly are just a matter of time.

headline: Barbara Stuart, TV Actress, Is Dead at 81
text: Barbara Stuart, an actress with a familiar if not famous face on television for half a century, who appeared on nearly 80 television series that spanned much of the medium’s history, died on Sunday in St. George, Utah. She was 81.

headline: Posada Provides the Suspense in a One-Sided Game

text: Vengeance is soulful for the English singer and songwriter Adele.

headline: Queen’s Ireland Visit Seen as Significant Advance
text: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II wrapped up her groundbreaking four-day visit to the Irish Republic on Friday, a trip that ranked among the most politically freighted of her almost 60 years on the throne.

headline: Week-Endvy
text: Envy of the social lives of friends – as (mis)described on social networking sites.

headline: Prada Is Cleared for Hong Kong I.P.O.
text: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

headline: An Early Ad Targets Romney
text: An advertisement scheduled to run in South Carolina during a visit there by Mitt Romney seeks to exploit critiques of his statements on health care.

headline: What’s Your Reaction to the Schwarzenegger Scandal?
text: One of the top stories in the news this week is the revelation that Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Hollywood actor who served two terms as governor of California, fathered a child with a member of his household’s staff approximately 13 years ago, and kept it a secret until now. What are your thoughts about this story, and about the controversy over the related privacy issues?

headline: The Early Word: Netanyahu Arrives
text: In Today’s Times

headline: Food Festival to Feed Prague ‘Gastronauts’
text: Long gone are the days when the primary dining options in Prague revolved around meat, dumplings and cabbage. Come the weekend of May 27 to 29, visitors to the Prague Food Festival can see — and taste — exactly how far the capital city has come in embracing cuisines from around the world, not to mention its own.

headline: The Rise of the Five-Year Four-Year Degree
text: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

headline: Group Unleashes Early Ad Against Romney
text: 8:59 a.m. | Updated The new political group co-founded last month by two former aides to President Obama is unleashing its first television broadside against Republicans Friday, attacking former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts on health care and needling former House Speaker Newt Gingrich in the process.

headline: Will Barcelona Be a Different Race?
text: BARCELONA – The talk around the paddock here is about a few points of interest, like Fernando Alonso signing until 2016 with Ferrari and a potential change in date for the Indian Grand Prix to December in order to accommodate a return of Bahrain Grand Prix in October. But in anticipation of the Spanish Grand Prix race on Sunday, the big question is, “Will the new rules allow overtaking to happen at this circuit?”

headline: Will Barcelona Be a Different Race?
text: BARCELONA – The talk around the paddock here is about a few points of interest, like Fernando Alonso signing until 2016 with Ferrari and a potential change in date for the Indian Grand Prix to December in order to accommodate a return of Bahrain Grand Prix in October. But in anticipation of the Spanish Grand Prix race on Sunday, the big question is, “Will the new rules allow overtaking to happen at this circuit?”

headline: Tip of the Week: Logging Out of Facebook Remotely
text: If you forget to log out of your Facebook account before you leave your home, office or other location where the computer might be shared, you do not have to worry about someone else messing around with your profile page. Just log into your account from another computer or device, go to the Account menu in the top right corner of the page and select Account Settings.

headline: At Racing’s Poker Table, Owners and Breeders Are the Marks
text: Billy Walters, one of the world’s most successful professional gamblers, warns that no matter what game you are playing, if you look around the room and can’t find the mark, you are it.

headline: Patience, Fortitude and a Whole Lot of Legos
text: Nathan Sawaya did Patience first, just as the other guy did. You know, Edward Clark Potter, the sculptor who did the lions in front of the New York Public Library, on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street.

headline: South Africa Assails Libya Over Death of Photographer
text: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa accused Libyan leaders including Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Friday of spreading “misinformation” about the fate of a South African photojournalist by saying he was alive when they knew him to be dead.

headline: Embracing the Anthropocene
text: Following up on my coverage of the first scientific conference on the proposition that we have entered a geological epoch of our own making, the Anthropocene, Room for Debate has assembled a great cast of characters to discuss whether this is a good, bad or indifferent thing.

headline: Democrats’ New Tactic: Praising 2012 Republicans
text: At a fund-raiser in Boston this week, President Obama went out of his way to praise Mitt Romney, the former Republican governor of the state, for “an assist” in passing health care reform.

headline: BP Partner Agrees to $1.1 Billion Settlement Related to Gulf Spill
text: LONDON — BP said Friday that Moex Offshore, one of its partners in the oil well that leaked into the Gulf of Mexico last year, had agreed to pay $1.1 billion as part of a settlement for any claims related to the oil spill.

headline: Girl Overboard
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#968", 592, 450, true, chameleonData);

headline: Moving Murray
text: I spent a recent weekend in southern New Jersey with my father, carefully labeling his entire wardrobe — every sock, pajama top and handkerchief — with a black Sharpie. The continuing care retirement community he’s moving to will do his laundry weekly, and it wants his name on each garment.

headline: Q. and A. With Lady Gaga on Her ‘Freedom Ride’
text: For a profile in Arts & Leisure, Jon Pareles sat down with Lady Gaga as she prepares for the release of “Born This Way,” her second studio album. “The album is as catchy and euphorically overblown as the music that made her a sensation,” Mr. Pareles writes about the pop superstar. “It also adds an additional dimension to her songs: her cherished relationship with a mass audience — fans who call themselves Little Monsters and dress up with a gender-bending zeal — to whom she is a goddess, a big sister, a mouthpiece, a counselor and a cheerleader.”

headline: Answers to Readers’ Baseball Questions, Part 2
text: The following are responses from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Ben Shpigel, the Times’s baseball writers, who took questions from readers this week about the Mets, Yankees and the game overall through the first quarter of the 2011 season.

headline: Bark Hot Dogs Will Open at Pier 6 in Brooklyn Bridge Park
text: The eating options in Brooklyn Bridge Park will spread south to Pier 6 on May 28 when Bark, the haute dog spot in Park Slope, Brooklyn, opens a stand there serving franks and burgers, along with ice cream from Blue Marble and Uncle Louie G’s, and sandwiches from Milk Truck Grilled Cheese. Later next month it will move to a terrace cafe on the pier with 200 seats and will start serving beers from Sixpoint Craft Ales and wine. The stand will be open Saturdays and Sundays, then the terrace will be open Friday nights, Saturdays and Sundays through Labor Day.

headline: A Downgrade by Fitch Leads to a Decline in Greek Bonds
text: Greek bonds led declines among euro area nations on Friday on concern a restructuring of its debt would reignite Europe’s sovereign debt crisis.

headline: As NATO Claims Progress in Libya, a U.S. Deadline Is Put to the Test
text: WASHINGTON — With NATO officials expressing increased confidence on Friday that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s military position in Libya was weakening, the Obama administration appeared to ignore a statute requiring hostilities to cease after two months if Congress had not authorized them to continue.

headline: The Deepest End
text: Wil S. Hylton’s article on Air France Flight 447 was informative, fair and moving. I would have never thought that an article on an air disaster would so insightfully touch on so many aspects of the human heart and mind. Hylton’s exploration captured in words what the cover photograph so chillingly represented to me: the unfathomable scope of nature’s capacity to challenge man’s quest to advance and the heartbreaking tragedies that will invariably accompany that contest.

headline: Unsafe at Any Speed?
text: When my family rents a car, the rental company sends someone to pick us up. The driver they send has sleep apnea (as do I), and he is not getting any treatment. I haven’t seen him drive dangerously, but drivers with sleep apnea are as much as five times more likely to be involved in car accidents. I doubt I can persuade him to get treatment. I am also uncomfortable tattling on him to his employer. What should I do? A. G., MASSACHUSETTS

headline: Germany’s Anti-Chaos Crusaders
text: Knuth Kaufmann, a 41-year-old former accountant for the German Air Force and current member of the local Ordnungsbehörde, or Department of Order, eyed a young woman bicycling down the cobblestone lane. As she approached, he ordered her to dismount, and he reached into his pocket. Out came a yellow card with a large red circle around a picture of a bicycle, a reminder that it’s against the rules to ride in a pedestrian-only shopping zone.

headline: My New Kentucky Baby
text: We came to Bowling Green, Ky., home of our good-humored surrogate, Gail, with a court order from California designating me and Richard — my husband in some states, though not in Kentucky — as the future baby’s legal parents. I’d been hoping to avoid Kentucky. Its laws make it seem unwelcoming to gay people and ambivalent about surrogacy. I figured that culturally it would be red-statey too, full of homophobia, guns and fatty foods. The coasts seemed safer, especially for a black man, a Jew and their black-Jewish daughter.

headline: Jimmy Lai Animates the News
text: You own magazines and newspapers in Hong Kong and Taiwan and have been called the Rupert Murdoch of Asia — and yet you’re best known here for your company’s very enjoyable and weird animated re-enactments of news events. The one you did for Tiger Woods’s Thanksgiving-weekend car accident got more than five million YouTube views. Why did you get into animation?  I started the animations because print media was going into a sunset business environment. It’s obvious that we have arrived at an era of images. I thought that if I could speed up the production of animation, I could make a big business out of recreating the amazing images of the news, because what we get on TV is always the last bit of image. What happened before that image is always missing.

headline: ‘An Unspeakable Word Is the Word That Has to Be Spoken’
text: What have writers got but words? And what have people got but their own bodies to inhabit?

headline: Block Quote: The Case Against Cursing
text: The Times writes unblushingly about sexual behavior, arts censorship, science, health, crime and similar subjects, opening its columns to any newsworthy detail, however disturbing, provided the approach is dignified and the vocabulary clinical rather than coarse. In these situations, the paper rejects evasiveness and euphemism, which would be a disservice to readers who need to understand issues.

headline: Fortune Brands Sells Golf Business for $1.23 Billion
text: Fortune Brands said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its golf business to a group led by the owner of the Fila sports brand for $1.23 billion in cash.

headline: Warren Buffett: Regional Manager, Scranton, Pa.
text: Is there a new job in Warren E. Buffett’s future?

headline: Harold Bloom: An Uncommon Reader
text: At the age of 80, with almost 40 books behind him and nearly as many accumulated honors, Harold Bloom has written, in “The Anatomy of Influence,” a kind of summing-up — or, as he puts it in his distinctive idiom, mixing irony with histrionism, “my virtual swan song,” born of his urge “to say in one place most of what I have learned to think about how influence works in imaginative literature.”

headline: Growing Up Anxious and Androgynous
text: Jon-Jon Goulian’s eyes are beady and his head is small, at least in proportion to the rest of him. He went prematurely bald. He has seriously bowed legs and exasperating skin, inasmuch as it long served as the bumpy battleground between him and his acne. But his nose, well, that’s quite possibly the worst of him. He has had it surgically altered not once but twice, and a third intervention may well be in order. It’s no longer huge but not yet acceptable.

headline: ‘Swim Back to Me’
text: Walk for Mankind

headline: Ann Packer’s Unhappy Heroines
text: Oh, California, you aren’t as young as you used to be. Your years of bad decisions and fast living have finally caught up with you. Not to mention the sting of the past decade’s tumultuous relationships: that nasty breakup with Gray Davis; the fling with the former bodybuilder; and now an 11th-hour reconciliation with an ex, both of you silver at the temples and ready to be done with the drama. You’ve seen your share of crises and ruin, but it’s time to pick up the pieces.

headline: Who Was Theodosia Burr?
text: American history brims with stories of mysterious disappearances. We still wonder what happened to Virginia Dare, the first English infant born in this country, in 1587, in the lost Roanoke settlement of what would become North Carolina. Also unknown is the fate of a woman who disappeared in the same region generations later: Theodosia Burr Alston, daughter of Aaron Burr and wife of the governor of South Carolina, whose ship sank off the coast in January 1813.

headline: Juniors: In the Quiet of Summer, Start Your Essays
text: Mr. Gelb is the author of “Conquering the College Admissions Essay in 10 Steps.”

headline: Julian Barnes on Not Talking About Love
text: Couples are the beating heart, the systole and diastole, of “Pulse,” Julian Barnes’s diverting third collection of stories. Author of the best-selling “Arthur & George” (an odd-couple historical novel in which “Arthur” is the creator of Sherlock Holmes) and the unclassifiable masterpiece “Flaubert’s Parrot,” Barnes is among the most adventurous writers — in style, versatility and narrative structure — of his Amis-McEwan-Hitchens generation. Another of his beguiling novels, “Talking It Over,” was about a loquacious love triangle, and what the characters mainly talk over in “Pulse” is what makes couples tick. “What do we look for in a partner?” the puzzled narrator, who was “still unmarried at 30,” asks in the title story. Someone who “matches us”? Perhaps. But is it possible that “we’re sometimes driven towards people with the same faults as we have?”

headline: Can Social Networking Cure Social Ills?
text: Man, Aristotle said, is by nature a social animal. This is the premise of Tina Rosenberg’s new and important book, “Join the Club,” which examines the idea that human behavior is defined by our relationships with our acquaintances. Peer pressure, she finds, can lead to acts of great courage, or to great harm. But Rosenberg’s particular ambition is to unlock the secret of using it to “transform the world,” in the words of her subtitle. Calling this approach the “social cure,” she examines how social networks can address some of the world’s most recalcitrant problems — from adolescent cigarette smoking to despotism.

headline: A New York Jewish Girl Becomes an Islamist
text: Deborah Baker is a serious biographer who specializes in fairly crazy writers. Her study of the poet Laura Riding, who survived a suicide attempt in 1929, during her 14-year ménage-à-trois with Robert Graves and his wife, was a Pulitzer finalist. Next came “A Blue Hand,” her portrait of the Beats in India, few of whom were in robust mental health. Yet even these have nothing on Maryam Jameelah, a New York Jewish convert to Islam, who — as a disciple of Pakistan’s most world-renowned fundamentalist — made a career out of condemning the West in dozens of books and pamphlets.

headline: Von Trier’s Company Apologizes for Director’s Remarks at Cannes
text: The production company that the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier helped found apologized on Friday for remarks the director made at the Cannes Film Festival on Wednesday in which he said he understood and sympathized with Hitler.

headline: The Last Casbah
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#380", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Friday Reading: A New App Helps Used-Car Buyers
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: ‘Coming Out’: Gay Teenagers, in Their Own Words
text: The suicide of Tyler Clementi, a Rutgers University freshman who jumped from the George Washington Bridge last year after discovering that his roommate had secretly streamed his romantic interlude with another man on the Internet, captured worldwide  attention. In the wake of his death, stories of gay youths being bullied and taking their own lives proliferated.

headline: To Win More, Perhaps Woods Should Play Less
text: Until now, most comparisons between Tiger Woods and golfers from other eras have focused on Jack Nicklaus, whose record of 18 major championship victories has been circled on Woods’s to-do list since he was a skinny kid living in the Los Angeles suburb of Cypress, Calif.

headline: The Muslim Art of Science
text: In the thousand years between the decline of Rome and the springtime of the Renaissance, science and other branches of learning took a holiday throughout Europe. It was a benighted time in the history most of us raced through in school, skipping lightly through Charlemagne and Richard the Lion-Hearted, the Norman Conquest and the Crusades, and arriving none too soon at the time of Leonardo and Michelangelo, Columbus and da Gama, Erasmus and Luther.

headline: Who Will Reap the Dividends of Fuel Economy?
text: There are two basic arguments over whether and how the country should respond to climate change and other environmental challenges. One focuses on government’s right to regulate industry, and the other on the costs and benefits of such regulation.

headline: Consciousness: The Great Illusion?
text: “Soul Dust,” Nicholas Humphrey’s new book about consciousness, is seductive — early 1960s, “Mad Men” seductive. His writing is as elegant, and hypnotic, as that cool jazz stacked on the record player. His argument feels as crystalline and bracing as that double martini going down, though you might find yourself a little woozy afterward. And his tone is as warm and inviting as that big, crackling fire, even if the dim flicker does leave things a bit obscure in the corners. I mean, the man recites Rupert Brooke love poetry at length. Very different from the usual awkward geeks of academic philosophy and psychology.

headline: Finding More Founders
text: Historians refer to the trend as Founders’ Chic: the recent flurry of interest in biographies of the “great white men” of our nation’s founding generation. Although George Washington has consistently attracted Americans’ attention since Parson Weems’s biography appeared in 1800, during the last decade published examinations of Washington’s contemporaries have multiplied dramatically. Take John Adams. By my rough count, he alone or in conjunction with other men has been the subject of 19 biographical studies and five documentary collections since 2001. Two more books have examined his marriage to Abigail Smith; she herself has warranted two separate biographies. Remarkably, a recent search in the Cornell library catalog for the phrase “founding fathers” in titles of books on American history published since 2001 identified 37 volumes.

headline: Agency Investigates 170,000 Ford Freestyle Crossovers for ‘Lunging’ Condition
text: An investigation is under way into the possibility that 170,000 Ford Freestyles have a tendency to accelerate without the driver’s foot on the gas pedal.

headline: Extra Innings
text: If you wanted to write a novel about the redemptive power of America’s pastime, you would imagine a Midwestern cornfield sculptured into a diamond that brought back the dead and healed generational wounds. Then you would remember that this idea has been taken, and instead you would invent the tale of the longest professional game ever played. You would make it a minor league contest, featuring players with mostly faint hopes of getting to the majors; they would absurdly play into the wee hours with no scouts in sight in April’s irrelevant cold. Therefore — and here’s your grand novelistic gesture — they must be persevering for some purpose larger than themselves. It would take place on Easter, the day the dead are reborn, in a decaying Northeastern mill town peopled by working-class Catholics who believe that unimportant things like wafers, wine and baseball can be made holy through faith. If you wished to be really obvious, the game would last 33 innings — one for each of Jesus’ years on earth.

headline: Pete Hamill’s Tabloid Thriller
text: Granted, as silver linings go this may be scant consolation, but the decline and demise of newspapers seems to be ushering in a raft of good novels by journalists who miss the old ink and newsprint. Reporters harking back to footloose times are not new (think of Evelyn Waugh’s “When the Going Was Good”), but now that end days may actually be upon us, we may be facing a complete subgenre: Où sont les news d’antan? We’ve already had Tom Rachman’s book “The Imperfectionists.” Now comes Pete Hamill’s “Tabloid City,” which sets a high bar for those that ­follow.

headline: The Case for Self-Publishing
text: Many thousands of years ago, when I was still a whelpish newspaper reporter in Chicago, I did a short profile of a retired television repairman who’d written a memoir entitled “The Perilous Life of Boris B. Gursky.” As a boy in Ukraine, Gursky said, he was stepped on by a horse; when he was a young man in Mexico, his stepfather had tried to murder him; and when he was a middle-aged man in Chicago, his ex-wife had clawed his face with her fingernails and threatened him with a loaded pistol. Most perilously, Gursky suffered from prostate cancer. He wrote, “My body had become so sensitive from staying too long in an environment surrounded with radiation from television sets.”

headline: Corey Taylor of Slipknot to Speak at Oxford Union
text: After a centuries-long tradition of gussying up its debates with a little pomp and circumstance, one of Britain’s foremost institutions of oratory apparently has decided that gowns and powdered wigs won’t cut it anymore, and has turned to a man known for performing in jumpsuits and fetishistic masks. Corey Taylor, the lead singer of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, will be among the speakers to address the Oxford Union in the coming weeks, according to the schedule published on the union’s Web site.

headline: D.N.C. Raises More Money Than R.N.C. in April
text: The Democratic National Committee significantly outraised its Republican counterpart in April, powered in part by millions of dollars from successful fund-raisers that featured President Obama, a D.N.C. official said.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: TO END ALL WARS: A Story of Loyalty and Rebellion, 1914-1918,  by Adam Hochschild (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $28.) Hochschild’s stirring account concentrates on the appalling losses in the ranks and on the extraordinary courage of the dissenters.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE GOOD MAN JESUS AND THE SCOUNDREL CHRIST,  by Philip Pullman (Canongate, $14.) This provocative retelling of the Gospels, by the author of the fantasy series “His Dark Materials,” separates the ethical teachings from the miracles and damnations by having the Virgin Mary give birth to twins: Jesus, wise and strong-willed; and the shrewd Christ, who is tempted by a silver-tongued stranger.

headline: Journalism on Trial
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Definitive F. A. Hayek
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Music for Silenced Voices’
text: To the Editor:

headline: The President’s Middle East Speech
text: The evidence for the Bush-Obama foreign policy convergence continues to pile up: In its broad strokes, yesterday’s address was a speech that George W. Bush could have given, from its summary of the neoconservative case against a stability-oriented Middle East policy to its invocation of Iraq as a model for the region to its defense of military interventionism against dictators to its assertion that henceforth, the promotion of democracy would lie at the center of American foreign policy in the Muslim world. Not for nothing are some of the president’s admirers suddenly praising Barack Obama for being a better Bush than Bush himself.

headline: Fighting for the Right to Tell Lies
text: DENVER — In 2009, a burly Colorado man named Rick Duncan was a rising star among local veterans groups, advocating on behalf of struggling soldiers and holding forth about his own powerful experiences returning from Iraq as a wounded Marine.

headline: Pawlenty to Announce 2012 Run on Monday
text: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota who has been exploring a presidential candidacy for months, will formally announce his intention to join the Republican field on Monday during a visit to Iowa, an adviser said.

headline: Harris in Lineup Means Ace on the Mound
text: Willie Harris is not having a good month. He is not having a good season, either, based on his .205 batting average, but perhaps he deserves sympathy for what he has gone through the past four weeks.

headline: The 50-Foot Commute
text: AS technology makes it easier for workers to do their jobs from home, buyers and renters in New York are seeking dedicated space where they can install a computer, a comfortable swivel chair and a desk, and block out productivity-sapping distractions.

headline: The Last Jam Session
text: IGNORE the splintered banisters leading up the stoop at 106 Rivington Street. Instead, go down the four steps on the right, push through the graffiti-marked metal door into the basement and gird yourself against the rank smell — a perfumed mix of sweat and soaked carpet.

headline: South Africa Assails Libya Over Photographer’s Death
text: The family of Anton Hammerl, a South African photojournalist missing in Libya since early April, said Thursday that they believed he died after being shot on April 5 in the desert.

headline: If World Ends, So Does Alternate-Side Parking
text: If the world begins to self-destruct on Saturday, as some religious figures have predicted, there may be a bit of consolation for New Yorkers left behind to perish: alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules would be suspended.

headline: The Caucus Click: Jon Huntsman in Hancock, N.H.
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. on a listening tour — literally — in New Hampshire.

headline: Hold the Onions and Cook With Leeks
text: In this week’s Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman asks why leeks are so underused in the United States.

headline: Hotels Pitch Savings for Family Vacations
text: With summer approaching, many parents are planning family vacations. And just in time, some hotels are offering specials for travelers with children.

headline: On Our Radar: Indonesia Signs Deal to Protect Virgin Forests
text: Indonesia’s president signs a two-year moratorium on new logging concessions in the island nation’s still-prolific virgin forests, part of a $1 billion climate change deal with Norway intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from deforestation. Under the deal, more than 150 million acres of primary forest are expected to be protected. Indonesia “will not return to the past of unsustainable development practices,” a top environment adviser says. [The Jakarta Post]

headline: Now Open | Nights and Weekends
text: Five Leaves, the Brooklyn cafe and bar known for its ties to the late actor Heath Ledger (he discovered the space while skateboarding), is about to expand its laid-back Aussie vibe with its new spot, Nights and Weekends, located around the corner on Bedford Avenue. “I’m sort of spellbound by how the restaurant comes alive and becomes part of the street,” says Jud Mongell, one of several owners of the popular watering hole. On any given sunny day, hungry patrons pack the pavement in front of the cafe, which is across the street from McCarren Park.

headline: Michel Gondry, Reluctant Cannes Judge
text: CANNES, France — By his own admission, Michel Gondry is not really cut out to be a judge. “I’m against competition,” Mr. Gondry, the French-born director of “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “The Green Hornet,” explained recently. This may present a challenge to his role as the president of the short film jury at the Cannes Film Festival here, where he is tasked with, you know, picking a winner.

headline: Living In | Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn
text: Sheepshead Bay, a busy area that is home to various ethnicities, retains a tranquillty, in part because of the water.

headline: Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure
text: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul — or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the swirl of ethnicities in this rambling neighborhood at the city’s southern edge.

headline: Its Footprint Is Small, but Its Chassis Is Classy
text: A FRIEND recently asked me to recommend an economical, not altogether unattractive small car for his fiancée, whose Honda Fit was nearing the end of its lease. I have not met the lucky woman, but as her appointed car-geek counsel, I felt compelled to suggest a 1990 Subaru Loyale — roomy and good on gas, but about as pretty as a rust spot.

headline: Bronx Children’s Museum Rolls Out, in Bus Form
text: More than a century after the world’s first children’s museum opened in Brooklyn, the Bronx is finally catching up. Sort of.

headline: Syrian Protesters Defy Crackdown and Gain Momentum
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of Syrians took to the streets in virtually every region of the country on Friday in what appeared to be a sign of new momentum and a potentially dangerous turn in the nine-week uprising. Activists said security forces killed at least 26 people and wounded hundreds.

headline: Lloyd Webber Pledges Funds From Picasso Sale to British Arts Groups
text: Apparently not content for musicals like “Evita,” “Phantom of the Opera” and “Starlight Express” to be his only gifts to posterity, Andrew Lloyd Webber has decided to make a more easily quantifiable contribution to British culture: he has said he will donate £32 million – nearly $52 million – to arts organizations in his home country, BBC News reported. The announcement comes at a time when the British government has drastically reduced its financial support of cultural institutions as part of a nationwide austerity program.

headline: Reflections on Warnings Unheeded
text: FRANKFURT — Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, famously said at Davos in January that he was tired of everybody always picking on banks. Good thing he wasn’t at the going-away event for Gertrude Tumpel-Gugerell, outgoing member of the executive board of the European Central Bank.

headline: Our Preakness Picks (Don’t Sweat, We’ve Got This)
text: The Rail’s contributors welcome this year’s Preakness Stakes guest picker, Kevin Plank, the founder and chief executive of Under Armour, the Baltimore-based athletic apparel company.

headline: Do Tips on Nearby Bargains Outweigh Privacy Concerns?
text: Ever been in an unfamiliar neighborhood, hungry but without much cash in your pocket? That’s where Cheapism would like to come in. The Web site, which helps you find bargains and inexpensive products, is now offering a “location-based” version.

headline: Harold Bloom's Influence
text: Sam Tanenhaus, the Book Review editor, interviewed Harold Bloom, who has achieved an almost unheard-of celebrity for a literary scholar. Bloom's new book is "The Anatomy of Influence."

headline: Words We Don’t Say
text: In 1997, when I was first hired at New York magazine, Kurt Andersen, now a best-selling novelist and radio-show host, had just been fired as editor. Everybody was grieving about this, though not me, since I wouldn’t have had a job there otherwise. And though it wasn’t until years later that I even met Kurt, he unwittingly left me a gift: tacked to the bulletin board in the office I took over was a single page titled “Words We Don’t Say.” It contained, as you might surmise, words and phrases that Kurt found annoying and didn’t want used in his magazine. Just yesterday, I rescued it from a bunch of old office stuff that I was throwing out, and I have to say, 14 years later, it’s still a pretty useful list of phony-baloney vocabulary that editors are well-advised to excise from stories.

headline: Summer 2011: Tracking Topics in the News
text: Though the school year is winding down, we want to encourage students to continue to watch what’s going on in the world.

headline: Borg Roots for Nadal to Join Him as New Rival Arises
text: PARIS — What once seemed a foregone conclusion — that Rafael Nadal would match Bjorn Borg by winning his sixth French Open this year — now looks more like a tennis thriller in the making thanks to the rise and prodigious efforts of Novak Djokovic.

headline: Touch of Evil
text: The city isn’t what it used to be in A DROP OF THE HARD STUFF (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $25.99), as Matt Scudder, the independent (and unlicensed) gumshoe in Lawrence Block’s timeless New York crime novels, sits down late one night to reminisce with Mick Ballou, the proprietor of Grogan’s Open House, a bar in Hell’s Kitchen. Gentrification has gussied up that once raffish neighborhood, and “a gentler and more refined bunch” of patrons has replaced the colorful and largely criminal riffraff that lent character to the old saloon. But instead of forcing Scudder to make his peace with this new world, Block thoughtfully sends him back to the early 1970s, when he was still a working cop and crime was still “the leading occupation” in the neighborhood.

headline: Who Are These People?
text: Can you identify any of these people?

headline: Huntsman Criticizes Obama on Libya
text: HANCOCK, N.H. – Jon M. Huntsman Jr., who resigned last month as ambassador to China to explore a campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, said Friday that President Obama should not have intervened in Libya and that future military engagements should be weighed carefully based on their financial toll to the United States.

headline: Stone Soul Picnic
text: An island can be paradise or prison, Aruba or Alcatraz or both. Or neither. There are tourist islands and desert islands, islands of treasure or target practice, tropical atolls and frozen specks, islands for Gilligan or Godzilla, Dr. Moreau or Dr. No — even metaphorical islands, which no man can be. Each is a petri dish parenthesized by ocean, fermenting its unique varietal of weirdness.

headline: Ahead of Villa d’Este, Aston Martin Reveals V-12 Zagato Concept
text: “Brutal” is not a word that design chiefs commonly trot out to describe their creations, but Marek Reichman, the design director of Aston Martin, applied it on Friday in reference to the V-12 Zagato concept, to be shown on Saturday at the Concorso d’Eleganza at the Villa d’Este in Italy.

headline: For Mazda Designers, It’s Out With the Nagare, in With the Kodo

headline: Hamilton Surrenders Cycling Gold Medal
text: The American cyclist Tyler Hamilton, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the time trial, has voluntarily surrendered his gold medal to the United States Anti-Doping Agency after admitting to doping during his cycling career, the International Olympic Committee said Friday.

headline: In Houston, Retooling, Not Rebuilding

(It is a useful look, but it would be even more valuable if the union, instead of listing the players alphabetically or by club in the static PDF format, presented the material in an Excel spreadsheet for easy manipulation. But why quibble?)

headline: A Day Spent Foraging for Food, and Ideas
text: During the week, the  Leningrad-born author Gary Shteyngart, 38, whose most recent novel is “Super Sad True Love Story,” writes and teaches at Columbia. (The title of one class: “Writing: The Hysterical Male.”) On Sundays in spring, he sets out from the apartment near Gramercy Park that he shares with his fiancée and wanders the city, often on his own, feeding mind and body.  JOHN SCHWARTZ

headline: Every Generation Needs Its Howl
text: The magazine has made a number of noteworthy recent additions: new columns, new sections and new writers. Among the new contributing writers is Alex Pappademas, who’ll be reporting regularly for us on popular culture (as well, we hope, on an array of other subjects). To experience firsthand Alex’s Rumplestiltskinian ability to spin magical gold from apparent cultural dross — and to see just why we’re so excited to have him here — read his excellent GQ profile of Mike Sorrentino, a k a the Situation, the star of “Jersey Shore.”

headline: Strauss-Kahn Is Released From Jail
text: A week ago, Dominique Strauss-Kahn was a man of international stature and influence. By Friday, he had become something of a pariah, turned away from the Upper East Side luxury building he sought to inhabit and stuck on Rikers Island for much of the day as lawyers tried to agree on an appropriate location for his house arrest.

headline: On the Economics of Mass Transit and the Value of Common Sense
text: Let’s say there’s a public transit line near your house. Your commute from home to work on this line will average about 40 minutes, door to door. Are you going to take it, or not?

headline: Animal Kingdom’s Final Preparations
text: Animal Kingdom completed his final preparations at Fair Hill Training Center Friday morning, ahead of Saturday’s Preakness Stakes. With more rain overnight, the main track was sloppy, so he went out to the Tapeta track to train at his usual time, 9 a.m.

headline: Opera Singers at Work
text: For this Sunday’s article about the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the acclaimed photographer Lee Friedlander shot 125 singers in New York, Philadelphia and Lexington, Ky. We were able to publish only a fraction of the remarkable images he made, but we can offer a few more of them online.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: People who flock to the Brooklyn Flea for the food now have Smorgasburg to check out on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. along the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 27 North Sixth Street (Kent Avenue). A mix of about 100 vendors, from Greenmarket farmers to hawkers of handmade food, will gather weekly. Blue Bottle Coffee, Brooklyn Oyster Party, the Meat Hook and Vietnamese food from Bep and Queen’s Dahn Tu are among the newest participants.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Denounces Republicans and Warns Democrats
text: In what was advertised as a major policy address, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Richard Trumka, denounced Republicans on Friday over their efforts to cut Medicare spending and curb collective bargaining while promising — in a warning to Democrats – that organized labor would show greater independence in politics.

headline: Harrison Fails to Qualify for French Open
text: PARIS — Ryan Harrison of the United States, who had spurned a chance to earn a U.S.T.A. wild card to the French Open and chose to seek a berth as a qualifier, lost in straight sets in the final round of competition to the energetic Javier Marti of Spain, 6-2, 7-6 (5).

headline: Greg Allman Joins the Aging-Rocker Memoir Brigade
text: Another aging rocker, another tell-all memoir. Gregg Allman, one of the founding members of the Allman Brothers Band, will tell his life story in a book to be published by William Morrow, an imprint of HarperCollins. The deal follows one that was made earlier this week in which HarperCollins acquired the English-language rights to an autobiography by Pete Townshend of the Who.

headline: Explaining the Rapture to Kids
text: Lisa McElroy is worrying about the end of the world. Not because she is one of the parents my colleague Ashley Parker wrote about on the front page of the New York Times this morning — the ones who have stopped funding their children’s college accounts because what will money matter after the Rapture — but because she isn’t. And in a guest post today she explores what to tell children who have seen the posters and heard the talk about tomorrow being the beginning of the end of the world.

headline: The Hiroshima Exhibit That Almost Wasn’t
text: The “Little Boy” that devastated Hiroshima in 1945 altered the Earth’s axis, while also (albeit briefly) changing the way war would be waged. It virtually leveled an entire city — the scope of which is only hinted at in these dramatic photographs — and, followed three days later by a second, smaller detonation on Nagasaki, did what determined American military bombing was unable to do: it forced a Japanese surrender.

In an interview with CNBC, David Strasser, an analyst with Janney Capital Markets, weighs in on Liberty Media’s $1 billion offer for the giant bookseller.

headline: Boogaard Died From Alcohol and Drug Mix
text: Derek Boogaard of the Rangers died from an accidental overdose of the drug oxycodone mixed with alcohol, the office of the medical examiner in Minnesota’s Hennepin County announced Friday.

headline: A Director of Ideas With Decades of Them
text: “FOR me, films are about ideas,” said Norman Jewison, looking out over Central Park on a fine New York day not long ago. “Every director should ask himself, ‘Why am I making this picture?’ And if you can’t answer that, you shouldn’t make it.”

headline: Inside Hong Kong’s Private Kitchens
text: ON little Star Street, a sliver of a lane in Hong Kong’s Wan Chai neighborhood, a group of hungry friends and I walked up and down the same block, iPhone maps in hand, a handful of times before pausing before a quiet apartment building. “Is this it?” I asked, triple-checking the address before pressing the buzzer.

headline: Letters: Hello, Tour Operator
text: To the Editor: Regarding the May 8 Practical Traveler column, “How to Save on Group Travel”: The article provides some useful information, but omits the single easiest solution: using a tour operator. Someone planning a group tour needn’t negotiate with the cruise line, the airline, the hotel or the visitor/convention bureau separately. Tour operators have special group departments that make all the arrangements, saving not only money but time, one of today’s most precious commodities. Terry Dale New York City

headline: Letters: Passing on Upgrades
text: To the Editor: Regarding the May 15 Practical Traveler column, “13 Ways to Save on Gas This Summer”: An other important tip when renting cars: think twice before accepting the “upgrade” offer they often throw at you while at the counter — bigger, fancier or sportier cars often burn more gas. Many rental companies will now tell you what are the most fuel-efficient models available, and many now have hybrids. If you plan on driving your rental far, this kind of thinking can save a small fortune.

headline: The Charms of Viña del Mar, Along Chile’s Coast
text: DANNY DIAZ stared out into the Pacific, scanning the water, ready to dash at the right moment. “We are here to catch a sider,” Mr. Diaz, 24, said, referring to what he considers the perfect wave, as he stood on the sandy embankment where the inlet Estero Marga Marga meets the ocean in Viña del Mar, Chile. He was with a group of friends, all skimboarders, a sport Mr. Diaz described as “a mix between skateboarding and surfing.”

headline: On Virginia’s Crooked Road, Mountain Music Lights the Way
text: IT starts with a well-worn fiddle, held in equally well-worn hands above a tapping black cowboy boot. Then in comes the banjo, plucked with steel finger picks, followed by the autoharp, the mandolin, the percussive beat of an upright bass. Another banjo grabs the melody, and suddenly the room is bursting with knee-slapping, country-porch music. A man in a crisp checked shirt gets up and starts to dance, bouncing out a complicated bumbumBAM bumbumBAM with his feet, moving as smoothly as a Martha Graham dancer, hitting the floor on the downbeat.

headline: Restaurant Report: Little Otik in Berlin
text: American cuisine in Berlin is something of an anomaly. Food in the German capital is about Turkish kebabs, Greek shawarma, Thai green curry and the ubiquitous German trinity of bockwurst, currywurst and schnitzel.

headline: Treading Lightly in the Simanjiro Plains of Tanzania
text: WE’D been hiking for a half-hour when Mark Thornton raised his hand and drew us to a halt. Tracing a circle in the air with his index finger, he whispered, “They’re all around us.”
