headline: Sentence of the Week: Rapture Edition
text: This is our second straight week of superabundant sentence harvesting — which is good, given that it will apparently be our final Sentence of the Week post ever. (Does Twitter still work when the moon has turned to blood?) So let’s all really settle in and savor these together, the last good sentences ever tweeted in the Cycle of Human Time:

headline: Now Online | T’s Summer Travel Issue
text: The new Summer Travel issue of T sets sail with the model-sailor-adventurer Daria Werbowy, who skippers a sailboat from St. Bart’s into the spectacularly blue Caribbean Sea. The watery idylls continue on Favignana, a tiny island off Sicily that has lately been discovered by the fashion crowd; in the Cape Cod town of Wellfleet, where a collection of Bauhaus-style bungalows conjures a lost bohemia; and on the banks of the Thames, in which amateur archaeologists called mudlarkers dig for scraps of history. We peel back layers of the past in Kuala Lumpur, one of Asia’s most cosmopolitan cities, then get lost in time in Tangier, a last redoubt for romantic dropouts. For beach-blanket readers, there’s an excerpt from Elaine Sciolino’s timely new book, La Seduction, about the role of flirtation and provocation in French society. And for wave-riders we’ve assembled a guide to cool new surf spots around the globe. Plus: the Selby heads to Melbourne. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: The Morning Line: Handicapping the Preakness
text: After a week of articles on Team Animal Kingdom (the horse; the trainer, Graham Motion; Team Valor’s chief executive, Barry Irwin; and the horse’s home at Fair Hill) on Friday attention turned to betting the Preakness.

headline: Will the I.M.F. Rise Again?
text: Everyone has some fascination with the combination of sex, money and power, but who would have thought they would all point to a career at the International Monetary Fund? Founded in 1945 at the Bretton Woods Conference with a mandate to prevent wild swings in national currency values, the fund, I would have imagined, would set itself against swinging of every kind.  That is clearly not the case. According to Alan Beattie’s interview this morning with I.M.F. semi-renegade Simon Johnson, the fund was firstly aimed at helping struggling postwar economies in Western Europe, and its first loan (in 1947) was to France.  For 35 of the fund’s 64 years, its managing director was French. When Western Europe had recovered, the fund went on to other things and secured for itself, let’s say, a mixed reputation.  From the 1960s onward, and culminating in the period of strict I.M.F. loan “conditionality” and rigid programs of “structural adjustment,” the fund earned a reputation as a corps of technocratic drones pitilessly contented in their air-conditioned hotel rooms as they imposed cookie-cutter “solutions” on prostrate governments. You would read from time to time of “anti-I.M.F. riots” in one poor capital or another, and you could guess what it meant, and it wasn’t pretty.    By the early part of our own century, the fund was entering a period of repentance, not least because some poorer countries were now “emerging markets” and making a big point of repaying I.M.F. loans and swearing never to take them again. Escaping the I.M.F. became a symbol of freedom. But if the fund wasn’t making loans it had no income, and we know what that means: time for reform! Emerging-market players, with a sympathetic United States, pushed for changes in voting power. In essence, the developing world would get more I.M.F. power at the expense (slightly) of the United States and (mainly) of Europe. Several reforms, first undertaken in 2006 and most recently last year, would take the voting share of “advanced economies” from 60.6 to 55.3, and of “emerging market and developing countries” from 39.4 to 44.7.

text: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama on Friday that he shared his vision for a peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and then promptly listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions that have kept the two sides at an impasse for years.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $16.6 Million
text: After almost three years on the market, a sprawling penthouse at One Jackson Square in the West Village with a private swimming pool on its roof terrace sold on Monday for $16.6 million, according to the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which represented the owners. The penthouse sale was the priciest of the week, according to transactions posted on Streeteasy.com.

headline: Eat Her Words
text: Some people put photographs of lithe supermodels on their fridges to help avert caloric mishaps. Now you can reproach yourself in any room of the house, with words from one of the slimmest supes of all. Stitched with Kate Moss’s infamous quote, Jonathan Adler’s needlepoint pillow is $119 at Kirna Zabête, 96 Greene Street (Spring Street). Or go to kirnazabete.com.

headline: Inside the List
text: CITY LIGHTS: Erik Larson’s “In the Garden of Beasts” hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4, without any help from Navy Seals or Steven Tyler’s hairdresser. Instead, it’s got Nazis, romance and old-fashioned storytelling chops, not to mention a cover that makes Berlin in 1933 look an awful lot like the Chicago of the 1893 World’s Fair depicted on the front of Larson’s blockbuster “The Devil in the White City,” which spent a total of 182 weeks on the hardcover and paperback lists starting back in 2003. Like that book, “In the Garden of Beasts” is shaped around the interlocking stories of two characters, the American ambassador William Dodd, who views Hitler’s Berlin with growing alarm, and his daughter, Martha, who finds herself rather enchanted by all the glamorous men in uniform. (“Think Carrie Bradshaw in Berlin,” as USA Today’s reviewer, Deirdre Donahue, put it.) In an interview with The Huffington Post Chicago, Larson, inset, explained his decision to give so much space to Martha, a former assistant literary editor at The Chicago Tribune who left her husband behind to gallivant with French diplomats, Russian agents and the head of the Gestapo: “If I’d hung the entire book on Dodd, it might have been interesting, but it would have lapsed into a diplomatic history. I find diplomatic histories the dullest of histories.”

headline: Talking, and Listening, in the Oval Office
text: When President Obama met with Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, in the Oval Office on Friday, this photo caught our eye. The two men have had a sometimes rocky relationship, (see today’s story by Helene Cooper) but they exchanged cordial words on Friday. This picture was snapped as Mr. Obama listened, almost frozen, during long remarks by Mr. Netanyahu, in which the Israeli leader pushed back against the framework for a peace deal that Mr. Obama outlined in a speech Thursday at the State Department. It made us wonder: What is Mr. Obama thinking?

headline: Singers Embrace the TV Road to Stardom
text: BETWEEN 2003 and 2006 Javier released two albums and a live EP on Capitol Records, a fair shot by any music industry standard. He was an amiable and warm singer, precise and flexible, with a crisp pop voice and smooth R&B inflections. And yet that voice, perhaps too clean and pretty, made for unremarkable records that left little impact. Soon after his second album Javier and Capitol parted ways, another quiet casualty of the record business.

headline: Private Offerings Come With Many Caveats
text: Paul Sullivan’s Wealth Matters column this week makes the point that some investors are not any more aware of the risks involved in private equity and debt offerings than they were nearly three years ago, in the depths of the recession. The biggest risk is that they will lose all their money. That is probably not as big a deal for the wealthy as it is for those who aspire to be rich.

headline: Timely | Jules Marquis • Art in America
text: Whether by filming an ode to NBC in a field or by having small-town Little Leaguers pace around a New York gallery and mutter ‘‘good game’’ to one another, Colin Snapp (left) and Daniel Turner frequently take aspects of globalized culture and consumerism and trickle them down to a rural level. The two New York-based artists, who recently began exhibiting collaborative work under the name Jules Marquis, share a Greenpoint studio but regularly shuttle to southeast Virginia, where they’ve created a nonprofit art space on a corner of the Turner family farm. Named Jericho Ditch, after a local logging canal, it serves as a venue and creative getaway for fellow artists. It also embodies the Jules Marquis ethos: from the outside, it’s a shed in a field; inside, it’s a big-city-gallery-style white box lighted by symmetrical fluorescent tubes. Snapp and Turner have two shows opening in June: at Jericho Ditch and at Martos Gallery in New York.

headline: Graphic Book Best Sellers: Star-Crossed Romance
text: The first volume of “Ai Ore-Love Me!” hits the manga list at No. 10 this week. The book is about what happens when Mizuki, the lead guitarist at an all-girl school, is approached by Akira, a student at an all-boys school, who wants to join her band. Seems like a reasonable enough premise, but things get more confusing, according to the description on the web site of VIZ Media, which publishes the book: “Love may be on his mind, but romance is difficult when everyone keeps mistaking Mizuki for a boy and Akira for a girl!”

headline: Can Scientists Arouse and Fulfill?
text: Here’s a Dot Earth Postcard from Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and science-communication evangelist, who recently attended a conference on neglected diseases, complex systems, learning and more organized by Larry Gold, a biotechnology entrepreneur and microbiologist at the University of Colorado:

headline: Goldikova, Racing’s Grande Dame, Returns on Sunday
text: She was around when Curlin won the Preakness in 2007. She saw Big Brown come and go in 2008, too. She had already staked her turf in the history books when Rachel Alexandra won her Preakness in 2009, and she saw Lookin at Lucky’s short burst of fame last year, too. All those champions flowered and faded in the blink of an eye next to her glittering career, which is still far from over. Goldikova, the grande dame of worldwide thoroughbred racing, is set to make her seasonal reappearance on Sunday in the Group 1 Prix d’Ispahan at Longchamp.

headline: The Women Who Would Be President. Will They Run?
text: The women who would be president in 2012 are still sitting on the sidelines. But that could change soon.

headline: Los Angeles, City of Artists
text: “There’s no such thing as L.A.,” says the curator Benjamin Godsill. “There’s multiple, sometimes overlapping bits of community, ideologies and neighborhoods.” Organizing a group show around the theme of a major metropolis poses risks. Hyperbole, dime store anthropology and overlooked artists often crowd the presentation. But the best of these endeavors don’t seek to galvanize a scene, per se, but provide the most basic of contexts: place. In this way, the mercurial nature of Los Angeles provides a valid starting point for an investigation of its artists. This summer, two separate curatorial teams (both based in New York, funnily enough) will tackle the behemoth subject of art in Los Angeles with group shows staged far from home. “Greater LA,” on view until June 10 in SoHo, looks at the city’s contemporary artists, whereas “Venice in Venice,” which opens on June 4 at the Venice Biennial, revisits the city’s rebel artists from the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Remembering the Tunes That Broke Boundaries
text: Songs by African-American jazz musicians that became standards; racially conscious protest songs written by Tin Pan Alley titans and made famous by black performers: the back-and-forth crossover process that accelerated with the birth of rock ’n’ roll was the theme of “More Than a Song: The Music That Integrated America,” a sturdy, thoughtful revue that had performances at the Allen Room on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

headline: Silk Production Takes a Walk on the Wild Side
text: Most commercial silk today comes from the cocoons of domesticated silkworms, bred over thousands of years to produce cocoons that are easy to unravel into silk that is easy to dye. The use of silkworms is thought to have originated in China nearly 6,000 years ago. There are many species of wild silkworms as well, but their cocoons are more difficult to unravel.

headline: Aggressive Bid Leads to a Slam
text: The advance of the young guard. That would be a fair headline for the final of the open trial in Henderson, Nev., this week. The average age of the winning team of Kevin Bathurst, Daniel Zagorin, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge was 31, the youngest being Lall, at 24.

headline: Comedy With a Side of Disgust
text: THE few times I have seen the talk show “Chelsea Lately,” a premonition of a world flattened by small talk and Kim Kardashian’s rear, my sense of its outspoken and attractive host, Chelsea Handler, has been that she is not so much giving quarter to her guests as holding them at bay with her intelligence.

headline: ‘Sleep No More’ Is a Feast for Style Fanatics
text: Talk about cravings. At one point in the eerily staged production of “Sleep No More” at a mock hotel in Chelsea, a showily pregnant Lady Macduff hikes up her blue velvet evening dress, hops on to a bar and laps milk from a saucer. At another moment in this crazily meandering interpretation of “Macbeth” by Punchdrunk, the British experimental theater company, her dress is laid out on a bed, leaving masked spectators free to pore over its capacious folds and seams.

headline: Brünnhilde Meets Broadway at Benefit for Collegiate Chorale
text: No question: the musical forces on the stage of Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening were mighty. Take the 180-voice Collegiate Chorale, add a real-life Brünnhilde in the person of the great dramatic soprano Deborah Voigt, and you should expect nothing less than thunder and lightning. But it was not to be. A distant rumble, a flicker on the horizon, a spritz of rain, yes. But except for a rip-roaring “Oklahoma!” when everything suddenly converged, there was only a hint of a storm.

headline: Saying Farewell to School, With Some Help From Brahms
text: The music surrounding graduation festivities at most colleges begins and ends with a weak version of Elgar’s famous “Pomp and Circumstance” March. At the Juilliard School, as you might imagine, things are a bit different.

headline: More Employers Equalize Health Benefits for Gay Workers
text: This week’s Your Money column looks at the growing number of companies that have decided to equalize the cost of health benefits for their gay employees.

headline: For Gay Employees, an Equalizer
text: The battle to legalize same-sex marriage may be dominating the headlines, but that issue could take years to resolve. More immediately, a growing number of companies have taken it upon themselves to make life a little more equal for their gay employees.

Her own life is chronicled in the 2007 memoir, Witness: One of the Great Correspondents of the 20th Century Tells Her Story” (Random House, 2007).

headline: Palestinian Sees Prospects of Deal Receding
text: JERUSALEM — After President Obama’s high-profile speech on Thursday in which he laid out broad principles for reaching an Israeli-Palestinian deal, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, called an emergency meeting at his headquarters in Ramallah in the West Bank. He advised his associates not to comment on the speech, according to a senior Palestinian official who attended the meeting, but to wait instead for Mr. Obama’s meeting with the prime minister of Israel in the White House “and see if there are any positive signs.”

headline: This Week’s Magazine: A Picture Show
text: Though there is great stuff to read this week (I promise!), I am going to focus on photography. Just last week, we won a National Magazine Award for a photo essay by Ashley Gilbertson on the bedrooms of dead U.S. soldiers. But as rewarding as the big events like that are, it’s the week-to-week excellence of our photo director, Kathy Ryan, and her staff that impresses me even more. They don’t pursue a particular style or idea about pictures. Their interests are gloriously catholic. They pull stuff out of archives. They come up with stunning ideas that enliven subjects that have been photographed a million times before. They scour the earth for new talent. And they are always receptive to ideas that photographers bring to them, a more important skill than you might think.

headline: ‘Idol,’ Down to Two, Makes Fox No. 1
text: Haley Reinhart, above, received the fewest votes on Thursday night’s elimination episode of “American Idol,” as 21.2 million viewers tuned in to the Fox reality show, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Lauren Alaina and Scotty McCreery advanced to next week’s final round. Fox led the night as the top-rated network, garnering 10 million viewers at 9 for “Bones,” the crime drama’s highest ratings for a season finale in three years. But CBS’s “Mentalist” led the time slot with the first half of its two-hour finale, which averaged 13.8 million viewers from 9 to 11. CBS was second, drawing 11.1 million at 8 for “The Big Bang Theory” and 8.8 million at 8:30 for “Rules of Engagement.” ABC finished third with finales of “Wipeout” (5.6 million), “Grey’s Anatomy” (9.6 million) and “Private Practice” (7.5 million). NBC was fourth, averaging 7.1 million viewers for its hourlong season finale of “The Office” at 9 but had lower ratings for “Parks and Recreation” at 10 (4.2 million) and 10:30 (3.7 million).

headline: Footnote
text: The PEN American Center will administer the PEN/Bellwether Prize for Socially Engaged Fiction, an award that was originally founded by Barbara Kingsolver in 2000 as the Bellwether Prize, the organization said on Friday. Beginning in 2012 it will award the prize to the author of a new novel that “exemplifies the prize’s founding principles.” Algonquin Books has agreed to give a publishing contract to at least the next two winners. Going forward, the prize will be awarded every other year.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Scandal at the International Monetary Fund, the fiscal crisis in Greece, rising gas prices and continuing problems at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex in Japan.

headline: Where an Audience Becomes the Star
text: Perhaps nothing is more controversial in experimental dance today than performance style. Most of “Nameless forest,” a new piece by the choreographer Dean Moss that opened at the Kitchen on Thursday night, was unimpeachable. Trying to create a world of human behavior in a three-dimensional set, it involved a number of theater games for its six dancers and for 12 members of the audience, who, invited to sit onstage, at times became involved in both the choreography and some interviews. But it was tediously performed. At Thursday night’s show some of the participating innocent bystanders proved more stageworthy than any of the performers.

headline: Toronto Exchange Rejects Rival Bid by Canadian Banks
text: The TMX Group, the parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange, said late on Friday that it had rejected a unsolicited takeover bid from a consortium of Canadian banks and pension funds, saying the offer was “inadequate” and not superior to its merger agreement with the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Experiencing Art With Eyes Peeled, Ears Trained and Hands On
text: The wonderfully eclectic Look & Listen Festival opened on Thursday evening with a program that prized vigor and muscularity over intricacy and nuance: a victory lap, of sorts, in celebration of the festival’s 10th anniversary. The point of Look & Listen, as its title suggests, is to bring together music and visual arts, and this year the concerts are in the large, resonant gallery of the Chelsea Art Museum, where an exhibition of colorful abstracts by the painter Jean Miotte surrounds the musicians and audience.

headline: New Territory, With Hues of Nature
text: The Trinity Choir, the superb resident ensemble of Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, is rightly renowned for its polished, spirited renditions of major works from the classical choral repertory. Its activities in contemporary music, though distinguished, have been emphasized less. That changed on Thursday night, when Julian Wachner, Trinity’s director of music and the arts, conducted the first formal concert by Novus NY, the church’s newly formed new-music ensemble.

headline: Obama Thanks the C.I.A. for Hunting Down Bin Laden
text: WASHINGTON -- Praising them for what he called “one of the greatest intelligence successes in American history,” President Obama told a jubilant crowd at the Central Intelligence Agency on Friday that the tracking and killing of Osama bin Laden was a crucial milestone in the larger American war to “defeat al Qaeda.”

headline: Young, Aimless and Primed for a Revolution
text: The bubble-headed terrorists of Zack Russell’s satiric comedy “Just Cause” at the Flea Theater have no cause, just or otherwise, and no ideology. That’s Mr. Russell’s point. About the only thing they respond to is a slogan as lazy as they are: “Freedom comes to those who love it.”

headline: 2 Networks Pin Their Hopes on One Comedian
text: On Monday NBC unveiled its hottest prospect for a new hit sitcom, a show called “Whitney,” created, produced by and starring Whitney Cummings.

headline: Derailed Director Cites Urge to Entertain
text: MOUGINS, France — The Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier showed up at this year’s Cannes Film Festival with “Melancholia,” a disaster movie about a planet crashing into Earth. He leaves having blazed his own destructive trail through the event, which since Wednesday has been dominated by talk of his rambling comments about Nazism at a news conference and his subsequent expulsion from the festival.

headline: Temptations Found in Gardens of Islamic Delight
text: The smell I remember. It was sensuous and sweet in the early summer morning but also airy, light, with an almost spicy edge. And it shifted character as I walked past the murmuring fountains and groomed myrtle bushes. But I didn’t pay much attention. Eight years ago there were other impressions to attend to, made by the honeycombed ceilings and ornamented stucco, the interweaving geometries on tiles and stone, the views of tall cypresses and corrugated rooftops. The place, in uniting opposites, seemed to insist on a mythical significance as fortress and pleasure garden, a seat of power and a meditative retreat: the Alhambra.

headline: U.S. Finish at Worlds Does Not Reflect Overall Program
text: Although the N.H.L. playoffs are continuing at breakneck speed, the international hockey season officially ended last week with the gold medal game of the 75th world championship.

headline: Once Again: Is College Worth It?
text: The dismal job prospects for new college graduates have revived debates about whether college is “worth it.” The PayPal founder Peter Thiel is among the major skeptics, but there are plenty of others. Check out the comments on yesterday’s article about employment rates for recent grads to see what I mean.

headline: Enter Laughing, From the Liberal Wing
text: Perhaps you, like City Critic, thought that liberals had been eradicated through some kind of spraying program or mass inoculation. No elected official has admitted to being one since the Carter administration, and the very word “liberal” ranks right up there with “care to respond to the rumors about your love child?” as guaranteed to make Sunday morning talk-show guests change the subject.

headline: Video of the ‘Nakba Day’ Protest in Lebanon
text: On Friday, a senior official who traveled to Washington with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told Yediot Aharonot, an Israeli newspaper, that it was important for the White House to understand the seriousness of last Sunday’s protests along Israel’s frontiers with Lebanon and Syria. “People are waging war along the fences,” the official said, “and it’s not an exaggeration.”

headline: A Bad Year for Car Bargains
text: DETROIT — The average price for a new car in the United States is edging toward $30,000, as automakers remain stingy with discounts and there just are not enough of the most popular vehicles available.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 20, 2011
text: NATO warplanes attacked eight Libyan ships on Thursday night in three coastal locations, including the port of Tripoli.

headline: Through Rowing, New Confidence
text: “I’M bored,” announced Shlomo Orenstein, 14, a seventh grader from Brooklyn, as he lay on a floating dock on the Harlem River on Thursday, picking splinters out of the wooden planks with his idle hands.

headline: Health in Doubt, Mugabe, 87, Vows to Stay in Power
text: JOHANNESBURG — Some of his fellow autocrats may be struggling — with Hosni Mubarak detained in Egypt and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi hiding from NATO air bombardments in Libya — but Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, another of Africa’s longest-serving leaders, declared in an interview published Friday that he intended to run for president this year at the age of 87, and live to be 100.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
New York City Opera to Leave Lincoln Center
text: Just two years after a $107 million renovation at its Lincoln Center home, the troubled New York City Opera plans to move out and perform in various places around New York, officials of the company said on Friday.

headline: Sexual Affronts Are a Known Hotel Hazard
text: A lot of people were shocked by the charges that the head of the International Monetary Fund sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper in New York last weekend.

headline: The Defense Can’t Afford to Rest
text: WHEN clients call Ivan Vogel’s cellphone, they are treated to an unintentional, 13-second economic truth. “This,” the recorded message says, “is the law office of Ivan A. Vogel. Leave your name and number. I’ll get back to you as soon as I can.”

headline: At an Adult Swim Party, the Sharks Are Corporate
text: As if the two 12-foot-tall, fog-shrouded golden owls that stood sentry over the crowd at a party for the Adult Swim cable television channel on Wednesday night weren’t imposing enough, they also shot lasers out of their eyes.

headline: A Case That Put a System on Trial
text: THE epigraph of a new book about the Central Park jogger case in 1989 establishes its premise: “I think that everybody here — and maybe across the nation — will look at this case to see how the criminal justice system works,” Mayor Edward I. Koch said at the time. “This is, I think, putting the criminal justice system on trial.”

headline: At Apocalypse Central, Preparing for What Happens, or Doesn’t
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — If Harold Camping and his followers are correct, Gertrude Stein’s famous comment about Oakland — that there is no there there — may finally be true. If not, some local churchgoers say they will set up encampments outside the headquarters of Mr. Camping, the self-proclaimed biblical soothsayer who has prophesied the end of the world on Saturday, with an eye toward consoling the disappointed.

headline: Small, Poor, Successful School Waits for Obama, in Vain
text: BRIDGEPORT, Wash. — President Obama stood near the Mexican border last week and challenged Republicans to join him in reforming federal immigration policy. Among the people he said were unfairly at risk under current laws: “bright, eager students.”

headline: An Italian Newcomer That Sticks to the Script
text: I HAVE never seen a wait staff burn more calories than I did on a recent night at Massa’, a vigorous new Italian restaurant in Scarsdale (Massa’ is short for “masseria,” a fortified southern Italian farmhouse). Seated at the base of a broad staircase leading from the main dining room up to a spacious bar and ancillary dining area, where a private party for 30 was in full swing, my guests and I had the equivalent of front-row seats as we watched waiters dash from the kitchen and sprint up the stairs, then trot back down again, taking two steps at a time.

headline: Not Sausage, but Soysage
text: Many restaurants offer vegetarian dishes these days, but diners who want to avoid any kind of animal products, including fish and dairy, will find the pickings slim — unless they visit Jolo’s Kitchen in New Rochelle.

text: For the second year in a row, to the day, the buzz at the Tour of California on Friday was about something other than the race. All the talk was again about Lance Armstrong and the former teammates who have publicly accused him of doping to win the Tour de France.

headline: Report Finds Data Lacking on Exposure to Defoliant
text: An independent panel of experts has concluded that there is not enough data available to determine whether sailors who served on deep-water ships during the Vietnam War were exposed to Agent Orange, the defoliant that has been linked to cancer and other serious diseases.

text: ESPAÑA is the real thing, as authentic a tapas bar and Spanish restaurant as one will find on Long Island. Diners at this two-month-old St. James spot may feel as if they are in Madrid; indeed, the dapper host, Julio Caro, is from there.

headline: Jack Wolf, Who Did the Math Behind Computers, Dies at 76
text: Jack Keil Wolf, an engineer and computer theorist whose mathematical reasoning about how best to transmit and store information helped shape the digital innards of computers and other devices that power modern society, died on May 12 at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 76.

headline: Corned Beef and Cannoli
text: When Rosario Minnocci opened Avventura in 1990, it was an all-purpose neighborhood grocery, much like any across the state. A decade later, the store is a first-rate delicatessen and pastry shop — a result of Mr. Minnocci’s decision to concentrate on house-made foods and pastries.

headline: Fatal Blast and Fire Halt Work at Chinese Plant That Makes iPads
text: An explosion and fire at a plant that makes Apple and Dell products in China killed two people and injured 16 and brought production to a halt, a spokesman for the plant said.

headline: At a New Steakhouse, Big Portions and Tabs
text: LODGED in a handsome, free-standing building just off U.S. 1., Gabriele’s Italian Steakhouse is a world unto itself, with a dark, circular dining room, several alcoves well suited to foursomes, a lively bar and a large, genial staff.

headline: A Certifiably Green Cafe
text: As its name suggests, Fresh, a sprightly little place in the Hills strip mall in Basking Ridge, uses local and organic ingredients whenever possible. Its owners serve made-from-scratch soups and salads, sandwiches like roasted pork on a brioche bun ($8.95) and blue-plate specials, including barbecued ribs and steak frites, that change daily.

headline: Japanese Flavors, Traditional and Modern
Disparate Musicians With a Shared Sensibility
text: THE trumpeter Marvin Stamm and the saxophonist Jason Rigby might seem unlikely band mates. While both are members of the Westchester Jazz Orchestra, they are of different generations (Mr. Stamm is 71, Mr. Rigby, 36) and arguably of contrasting musical temperament, with Mr. Rigby’s small-group projects offering a decidedly freer brand of jazz than Mr. Stamm’s.

text: TAPPAN, N.Y. — In August 2007, two firefighters died of smoke inhalation battling a fire at the former Deutsche Bank building at the World Trade Center site.

headline: Illegal Immigrants’ Children Suffer, Study Finds
text: Eulogia was scared and adrift. At 25, she was poor, pregnant and an illegal immigrant. She worried about how she would pay for medical care and raise her baby, and even whether a trip to the hospital might prompt her deportation to Mexico.

headline: Show for Black Artists (Even Those Disliking Label)
text: Some of the knottiest issues in “Embodied: Black Identities in American Art From the Yale University Art Gallery” don’t reveal themselves at the entrance to the show. Instead, they appear later, like in the “Viewer’s Note” on the wall next to Adrian Piper’s photographs from the 1971 series “Food for the Spirit.”

headline: Helping Catholic Students Remain Catholic in a Setting of Nietzsche and Beer Pong

It was a hand-painted crucifix, intended for her college dorm room, with a note from him on the back urging her: “Be sure to stay as grounded and awesome as you are now.”

headline: Advice for Young Journalists in the Digital Age
text: This Tuesday, I was fortunate enough to be invited to deliver the Henry Pringle Lecture to the very bright group of rising graduates at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.As someone who frequently warns about the perils of small sample sizes, I’ve long been reluctant to make too much of my personal path within the media industry. Too often, the advice that one professional gives to another is based too much on idiosyncratic personal experience and boils down to “The way I do things is exactly right, and everyone else is wrong.”

headline: Fortune Brands Sells Its Golf Line for $1.2 Billion
text: Fortune Brands said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its golf business to a group led by the owner of the Fila sports brand for $1.23 billion. The sale of the business, which includes the Titleist and FootJoy brands, is the first big step toward a planned breakup of Fortune Brands, long an unusual conglomerate with a big spirits portfolio and home and hardware business, in addition to golf products. The buyers are led by Fila Korea and Mirae Asset Private Equity, the largest private equity firm in South Korea. Fortune Brands said it expected to net $1.1 billion after taxes and expenses. The golf business accounted for nearly a fifth of the total revenue of Fortune Brands. Nearly half of the $1.2 billion in net sales for the company’s golf products came in markets outside the United States. The business had operating income of $89 million in 2010. After the split, Fortune Brands will be a liquor company, with brands like Jim Beam, Canadian Club, Courvoisier, Maker’s Mark and Laphroaig. Fortune said it expected to complete the breakup in the fourth quarter.

headline: Backing for Multiple Sclerosis Drug Lifts Stock
text: Acorda Therapeutics, a biotechnology company, won the backing of European Union regulators for a drug it makes with Biogen Idec to improve walking in multiple sclerosis patients, setting off a 14 percent gain in its share price. The regulators, at the European Medicines Agency’s Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use, recommended conditional marketing authorization for the drug, Fampyra, and asked for further study of the treatment. The drug was approved in the United States in January 2010 and generated $133.1 million last year for Acorda. Biogen markets the medicine outside the United States and pays Acorda royalties. Shares of Acorda, which is based in Hawthorne, N.Y., rose $3.67, or 13.7 percent, to $30.38.

headline: Spontaneity Again Causes Mayor Trouble

headline: Huntsman Takes His Potential Campaign for Test Drive in New Hampshire

headline: Georgia Says Russia Committed Genocide in 19th Century
text: TBILISI, Georgia — The Georgian Parliament voted Friday to recognize the 19th-century killings and deportations of ethnic Circassians by czarist Russia as genocide, a move that is likely to inflame tensions between the two countries.

Instead, it is merely the second jewel in horse racing’s Triple Crown.

headline: Racing Should Care for Its Own

Shortly after crossing the finish line, Eight Belles collapsed and was euthanized, marking one of the saddest days in Triple Crown history.

headline: Job Description of Managing Mets Adds an Unlikely Word: Fun

Unlike its glamorous uptown peers, the factory-chic Chelsea Market and the glossy food palace that is Eataly, it is more Plain Jane than beauty, with utilitarian flooring and generic signs that announce each vendor while screaming municipal ownership.

text: The Subway Series has become an annual event that for six days each season captures the attention of baseball fans in the New York area. But on Friday it seemed as if the subway extended all the way to Buffalo.

headline: Who Should Run the I.M.F.?
text: The arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn has turned the International Monetary Fund into front-page news and cast a harsh light on its dysfunctional workplace culture. Whoever is chosen to succeed Mr. Strauss-Kahn must be prepared to address both the European debt crisis and the institution’s own problems.

headline: Afghanistan: German Troops Fired on Protesters
text: The German Defense Ministry acknowledged Friday that its troops had fired on demonstrators during a violent protest in the northern Afghan city of Taliqan this week, wounding several civilians and possibly killing some. The demonstrations erupted Wednesday after a joint American and Afghan night raid at a family compound just outside the city that left four people dead, two of them women. NATO said the four were insurgents who tried to fire at its troops, but local officials insisted they were civilians. When the protesters tried to attack a small German-run NATO base on the outskirts of the city, the ministry said, German troops fired warning shots in the air before shooting at the legs of the attackers. Some protesters were hit in the torso and at least one was hit in the neck and head region, the statement said. At least 12 people were killed in the two days of protests. German authorities said they were investigating the shootings.

headline: Haiti’s President Martelly
text: The peaceful inauguration this month of Haiti’s new president, Michel Martelly, should give Haitians cause for pride and cautious hope that their country can move beyond mere survival and start rebuilding.

headline: France: Chirac Corruption Trial to Go Forward
text: The corruption trial of former President Jacques Chirac, suspended in March, can go ahead, France’s highest appeals court ruled Friday. Mr. Chirac, 78, the first former French president to go on trial since Marshal Philippe Pétain after World War II, is accused of embezzling public funds as Paris mayor to pay people working for his party. He has denied knowledge of any illegal payments. Co-defendants had argued in vain that some charges were unconstitutional under the statute of limitations.

headline: China: Dissident Artist Is Accused of Tax Evasion
text: A company controlled by the dissident artist Ai Weiwei evaded a “huge amount” of taxes and intentionally destroyed financial documents, Xinhua, the government’s official news agency, reported Friday. Xinhua, quoting the police, said that the authorities were focusing on Beijing Fake Cultural Development Ltd. The artist’s sister, Gao Ge, told Reuters that Mr. Ai is neither the company’s legal representative nor its chief executive. “So even if the company is accused of these crimes, Ai Weiwei should not be detained,” she said. Mr. Ai has been detained at an undisclosed location since April 3.

headline: Gas Prices and Political Pandering
text: The closer one looks at what passes for serious debate in Washington over energy, the more depressing it gets. The Republicans have nothing to offer but drill, baby, drill. The Democrats are rightly trying to end industry’s cushy tax breaks, but that’s not an energy strategy.

headline: Iran: Panel Rules President Overreached, Report Says
text: The Guardian Council, Iran’s top legal panel, has ruled that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad overstepped his authority by assuming control of the Oil Ministry when he fired the oil minister a week ago, the state-run Fars news agency reported Friday. The report casts doubt on whether Mr. Ahmadinejad will be able to lead the OPEC meeting in Vienna next month, and suggests a further deterioration of his relationship with Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country’s supreme leader. The Guardian Council is partly appointed by the ayatollah. The council has not confirmed the report, which said that the president’s appointment of himself as acting oil minister was unconstitutional. Last month, Mr. Ahmadinejad tried to dismiss the intelligence chief, but was reversed by Ayatollah Khamenei.

headline: A Mets Site About Nothing

headline: Sudan: Fighting Reported in Disputed Region
text: New fighting has broken out in the contested region of Abyei in central Sudan, the United Nations said Friday. Two bombs were dropped by aircraft on a bridge outside the town of Abyei on Friday evening, a United Nations official said. Hua Jiang, a United Nations spokeswoman in Sudan, said the world body had also been alerted to possible artillery fire in villages surrounding Abyei, which had not been independently confirmed. There were no casualties reported. On Thursday a United Nations convoy carrying 200 northern Sudanese soldiers was attacked in a southern-controlled part of the region.

headline: South Africa: Rail Collision in Soweto Investigated
text: Inspectors from the Railway Safety Regulator were investigating Friday a commuter rail collision that occurred in Soweto during rush hour on Thursday. A packed train full of people returning home from work to the township of Soweto crashed into a stationary train, injuring 857 people, but only three seriously, said Douglas Chauke, acting provincial manager for Metrorail, the public commuter line. Four coaches were damaged, but the rail line reopened Friday in time for the morning rush hour, Mr. Chauke said.

headline: Boogaard Is Remembered by His ‘Billet Mom’
text: As family and friends gathered for the funeral of Derek Boogaard in Regina, Saskatchewan, on Saturday, Boogaard was remembered in the context of a different kind of family — his last “billet mom,” in Medicine Hat, Alberta.

headline: Suicide Bomber Attacks Kabul Military Hospital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A powerful midday blast on the grounds of the heavily guarded national military hospital here killed at least 6 people and injured more than 20 others, government officials said.

headline: Cannes Q. and A.: Gerardo Naranjo and Mexico’s State of Fear
text: CANNES, France— In his new film “Miss Bala,” the director Gerardo Naranjo, tackles a topical issue — drug violence in Mexico — though an unlikely protagonist: an aspiring Tijuana beauty queen (Stephanie Sigman) who gets caught up with the local kingpins. Instead of delving into the social or political aspects of the problem, docudrama-style, Mr. Naranjo fashions a tense mood piece steeped in confusion and anxiety. He sticks to the captive heroine’s frequently befogged point of view while ruthless cartel operatives and corrupt cops remain on the periphery or outside the frame, their actions often unseen and their motivations murky.

headline: At French Open, This Plot Looks Familiar
text: Being the third wheel, almost an afterthought, going into Slam tournaments can’t be easy if you’re a player who has gone into such events as a favorite for nearly a decade. I mean, imagine if you started winning Slam titles when you were 21. At one point you were No. 1 on the computer for so many consecutive weeks that people had a hard time remembering who held the spot before you did.

headline: The Weekend Word: Nonnegotiable

headline: Oil Truck Explosion Kills at Least 15 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 15 people were killed when a damaged oil tanker carrying fuel for NATO forces in Afghanistan exploded Saturday in the northwestern tribal region, government officials said.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Turns of Fortune
text: The episode up for discussion is called “Swerve,” alluding both to Julie’s self-imposed car accident and various other instances of changes of heart and turns of fortune. Unable to muster the stamina to return to college after her run-in with Derek’s wife last, week Julie decides that the way to bide more time at home is to ram her car into a mailbox near her parents’ house. Maybe I’d be a really weak and bad parent to a teenager, but I don’t think I would have tried to force Julie to go back to Burleson, which is after all, a fictitious college and one at a significant psychic remove from her dreams of a Northeastern educational experience. Coach Taylor being Coach Taylor, he wanted Julie to man up and face the mess. The whole point of the affair now seems to have been to stack the deck so in favor of Julie’s return home that the show could easily situate her back in Dillon. Perhaps it was too implausible that Julie would just go to Dillon Tech in the first place, so the writers dispatched her to a place where she implausibly made no friends and experienced not a second’s worth of intellectual fulfillment or genuine freshman pleasure.It was interesting to see Coach having the correct perception of Julie’s motives rather than Tami. It is coach who realizes that Julie must have crashed on purpose. Tami is a disbeliever. It was interesting to see the show cast Coach’s impotence — he can’t get Julie in the car and back to school because she refuses with every fiber of her being to go — against Vince’s father’s assertion of paternal authority. Vince is in trouble with his thug lender, and his father steps in and solves problems by beating the daylights out of the guy, hoping to make sure the guy never gets within a yard of Vince again. Will this work? It sure felt as if it would. I’d hate to see this come back to haunt Vince’s father, or worse, for Vince to take the moral high ground against his dad in response.

headline: Black-Eyed Susan Winner Pointed Toward Mother Goose
text: BALTIMORE — Royal Delta rolled to a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $250,000 Black-Eyed Susan Stakes on Friday afternoon at Pimlico Race Course. Trained by the Hall of Famer Bill Mott, Royal Delta completed the one and one-eighth miles in 1:49 3/5 over a fast track. Buster’s Ready was second, followed by Hot Summer.

headline: Cannes Q. and A.: The Loneliness of the Banned Filmmaker
text: CANNES, France— Film festivals around the world have reacted to the arrest, banning and conviction of the Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi with official statements, special screenings and gestures of solidarity — at the Berlin Film Festival earlier this year, a seat was left empty for Mr. Panahi at every screening in the main venue. But the most meaningful act of all may be the Cannes Film Festival’s decision — announced just days before screenings got under way — to show new films that Mr. Panahi and his countryman Mohammed Rasoulof had made in defiance of their bans. (Like Mr. Panahi, Mr. Rasoulof, whose new film, “Goodbye,” is about an Iranian woman trying to leave the country, has been convicted for collusion against the regime — both were given six-year prison sentences, which are being appealed.)

headline: Beyond the Food Labels

He was the only horse in his van, although his trainer, Graham Motion, has a number of other horses in the races at Pimlico this afternoon. They were in a second Cooper Transportation horse van. The vans were joined by a one-car police escort, and a truck behind that in which I was a passenger.

headline: In the Golan Heights, Anxious Eyes Look East

headline: Lord Onslow, a Peer by Birth and Contrarian by Nature, Dies at 73
text: Michael William Coplestone Dillon Onslow, the seventh Earl of Onslow, who publicly advocated purging hereditary peers from the British House of Lords but who then, in the sort of full-bore reversal that seems a peerly prerogative, vowed to fight such an action “like a football hooligan” when it threatened to become a reality, died in England on May 14.

headline: Raising Children Is Heck
text: OF the many moments during the day in which parents and children operate at cross purposes, none are so fraught as bedtime. After a certain amount of hair detangling, into-your-pajamas-now cajoling, recitations of “Goodnight Moon” and singing of shopworn lullabies, the parent is done. Done! And this moment is precisely when the child gets started: the repeat trip to the bathroom, the urgent request for water, the sudden fear of the radiator, the artfully misplaced lovey.

headline: Mythical Creatures in the Infield: Calm Crowds

headline: Drugs Stop AIDS. Take Your Medicine.
text: THERE is now, for the first time, hard clinical evidence of an effect that AIDS doctors have suspected for years: If you are H.I.V.-positive, being on antiretroviral drugs will probably save not only your life, but also the lives of your sexual partners.

headline: Prime Number
text: The number of sequels on tap from Hollywood this year, many of them coming out this summer, according to a tally by Brandon Gray of Box Office Mojo, cited by the critic Roger Ebert in Newsweek. That is a record, topping the previous high of 24 sequels in 2003, Mr. Gray says. The trips back to the cinematic well (or chum bucket, as the case may be) include “Kung Fu Panda 2,” “Paranormal Activity 3,” “Scream 4,” “Fast Five,” and the eighth Harry Potter movie, “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Part Two).” You might call the latter a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel.

headline: The Stone Returns

headline: Reader Comments on my Religion Quiz
text: The back story behind my Sunday column is a measure of irritation that the Bible is so often cited as a basis for what seem to me to be archaic or backward positions on social issues — such as support for slavery in the 19th century, or opposition to gay marriage today. In particular, there’s a widespread sense that religion is deeply conservative on social and sexual issues, when in fact it’s pretty much all over the map and is much more focused on questions of social justice. So that’s why I wrote this 2011 religion quiz as my Sunday column.

headline: Shackleford Wins Preakness Stakes
text: BALTIMORE — Shackleford, who appeared agitated before the race, was able to edge the Derby winner Animal Kingdom by a half length to win the Preakness Stakes on Saturday at Pimlico Race Course. Astrology finished third.

headline: Back Then: 1911
text: A minor bomb scare aside, Queen Elizabeth II’s visit to Ireland last week seemed less tense than the last visit by a reigning British monarch, a century ago, before the creation of the Irish Free State in 1922. The New York Times reported from Dublin on July 8, 1911, that — amid tight security in the “poorest and roughest” district — a sergeant’s arm was broken in a scuffle before King George V’s entourage arrived, at which time “men and women who had been jeering the police and soldiers broke into hearty cheers.” Elsewhere, the report said, popular sentiment was “well expressed by a banner stretched outside a City Council hall at Pembroke, a suburb of the capital, which refused to address the King, declaring, ‘Welcome. We Want Home Rule.’ ”

text: JAY LENO

headline: Atom-Smasher Retires; Lab Makes Career Switch
text: When scientists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory announced last month that they might have discovered a new elementary particle or fundamental force of nature, it was likely the swan song of the lab’s Tevatron accelerator, once the most powerful atom-smasher in the world.

headline: Online Sex Videos Force Resignations of Six Members of Turkish Opposition Party
text: ISTANBUL — Just weeks before general elections in Turkey, six leading members of an opposition party were forced to resign from Parliament on Saturday after sexually explicit videos of one of them were posted on the Internet.

headline: With Withdrawal Looming, Trails Grow Cold for Americans Missing in Iraq

headline: Sunday: Fabulous Writer?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — As someone who grew up in New York City, one of my fondest memories was of childhood trips to the main branch of the New York Public Library (now known as the Stephen A. Schwartzman Building). I consider myself lucky to have walked among the majestic columns, up the stairs past the solemn, stone lions that still guard the entrance and through the great halls into the reading rooms. In a quasi-Proustian way, I can still remember the smell of the books and the card catalogs, a sense memory that I wonder if today’s children will ever have. Can you really dredge up the memory of how an e-book smelled?

headline: Students Wait as Legislators Decide Cuts
text: The Texas Legislature made a promise to the state’s financially neediest high school seniors in 1999: Money will not be a barrier to your higher education at a public college or university if you stay out of trouble, complete certain courses and graduate from high school.

headline: Tea Party Sets the Agenda, and Legislators Fall in Line
text: The ideological partnership of the raucous Tea Party movement and fiscally conservative Texas Republicans has dominated the agenda of the state lawmaking session that is sputtering to an end. Gov. Rick Perry embraced the Tea Party ideals before most knew the movement was brewing, and the conservative, anti-tax activism helped bring a supermajority of Republicans into the Texas House.

headline: Tomorrow to Pastures New
text: For the past 13 years, my horses have gazed across a gravel road toward a neighbor’s pasture, where her horses stand, gazing back. Kinship, affinity, species recognition, herd instinct, longing — I don’t know what to call this habit. But by the time you read this, my neighbor and I will have moved my horses into her pasture. She has plenty of extra grass, and my land can use a rest.

headline: The Gossip Machine, Churning Out Cash

Morse, elevated to fame and fortune by his invention of the telegraph, styled himself “an American who knows no North nor South nor East nor West, but who feels that everyone within the United States is his fellow countryman.” Lean, restless and pulsating with energy, the “Lightning Man” cherished the Union.
