text: I PICKED up my jangling cellphone one recent Saturday to hear the elated voice of Zachary, my longtime buddy and college classmate. “I just proposed to Caroline,” Zach announced, inviting me to the wedding and angling to plot logistics. “So when are you flying in?”

headline: Old Soviet Nuclear Site in Asia Has Unlikely Sentinel: The U.S.
text: KURCHATOV, Kazakhstan — Twenty years after the Soviet Union collapsed and tens of thousands of soldiers abandoned their posts at this remote site in northeastern Kazakhstan, the footprints of another great power — the United States — are increasingly visible.

headline: Need Therapy? A Good Man Is Hard to Find
text: Between unresolved family conflicts, relationship struggles and his mixed-race identity, James Puckett had enough on his mind in college that he sought professional help. But after bouncing from one therapist to another, he still felt stuck.

headline: Feeding the Gossip Machine
text: An appetite for the latest celebrity gossip fuels a growing, round-the-clock industry.

headline: Sweating at the Start, Shackleford Finishes the Right Way
text: BALTIMORE — Shackleford is a little colt, and as he skittered into the starting gate for the 136th running of the Preakness Stakes he seemed to be shrinking before everyone’s eyes. He had foam on his neck and sweat pouring down his sides and looked like a horse who had left his race in the paddock.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Freshman Democrats in the House Bond Over Policy and Egg Rolls
text: WASHINGTON — When you are a freshman Democrat in the House surrounded by scores of people whose views are antithetical to yours and who regularly pass laws you hate, you need coping strategies.

headline: Behind Grass-Roots School Advocacy, Bill Gates
text: INDIANAPOLIS — A handful of outspoken teachers helped persuade state lawmakers this spring to eliminate seniority-based layoff policies. They testified before the legislature, wrote briefing papers and published an op-ed article in The Indianapolis Star.

headline: When Grandmasters Fail to Live Up to the Title
text: There are drawn games among top players that are even more exciting than decisive victories, especially when they are riddled with errors and attacks.

headline: Annotated Excerpts of the Gates Foundation 990 Form 2009
text: Annotated excerpts of a tax form highlight how the Gates Foundation has increased its attention to education advocacy.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu
text: From Medicare to the debt ceiling, budgets deals and proposals are the main topic of conversation on the Sunday talk shows.

headline: Preakness Replay, May 21
text: A look back at Shackleford’s victory at the 136th Preakness Stakes.

headline: Leonard Kastle, Composer and Filmmaker, Dies at 82
text: Leonard Kastle, an opera composer who unexpectedly found a niche in film history as the writer and director of the low-budget 1969 crime-thriller film “The Honeymoon Killers,” died on Wednesday at his home in Westerlo, N.Y. He was 82.

headline: Yanks Feast on Mets Pitching, Belting 4 Homers Off Capuano
text: Their ballparks, 10 miles and a borough apart, were constructed at the same time, opening two years ago to breathless anticipation. For $800 million, the Mets erected a pitcher’s haven. For $1.5 billion, the Yankees built a bandbox, and it suits their team just fine.

headline: Before Turner’s Hot Start, a Few Had Faith in Him
text: Justin Turner knocked in a run Saturday for the seventh game in a row to establish a team record for rookies in the Mets’ 7-3 loss to the Yankees.

headline: The Economics of Education
text: Parents, students and teachers confront a budget shortfall that threatens to reverse hard-won gains in schools that once performed poorly.

headline: Mavericks Almost Blow a 22-Point Lead
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — The Dallas Mavericks breathed an epic sigh of relief Saturday night, which for these aging veterans has become increasingly difficult in a Western Conference finals series filled with wild emotional swings.

headline: Daniels Decides Against Republican Presidential Bid
text: Updated | 1:42 p.m.

headline: Warnings of All-Out War in Fight Over Sudan Town
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Sudanese Army invaded the flashpoint town of Abyei over the weekend, alarming Western and United Nations diplomats who warned Sunday that it was a provocative act that risked all-out war with the southern Sudanese.

headline: Charlatans and Cranks
text: Politico writes that

headline: Lottery Numbers
Baghdad Is Rocked by Blasts That Kill 20, Including 2 American Soldiers
text: BAGHDAD — A series of explosions, including one that struck a United States military patrol, shook Baghdad on Sunday, killing 20 people, including 2 American soldiers and 8 Iraqi policemen, according to an Iraqi security official.

headline: Iceland Volcano Closes Airports
text: PARIS — Iceland’s four international airports were closed to most flights on Sunday as the island nation’s most active volcano erupted for a second day, sending billows of ash 12 miles into the atmosphere, aviation and meteorological officials said.

headline: Another View of Killebrew
text: Harmon Killebrew’s death earlier this week no doubt had legions of boomers digging for a nostalgic look at the longtime Twins slugger on old baseball cards, magazines covers and photographs. One of the most appealing examples of the latter that I’ve seen is a mid-1960s image of Killebrew by the photographer Ozzie Sweet.

headline: Festival in Paris Spotlights Indie Music, Old and New
text: Normally a spot for picnickers and sunbathers, the Parc de la Villette in Paris will be getting an infusion of sound. The Villette Sonique music festival, running from May 27 to June 1, is a weeklong event in Paris’s 19th Arrondissement, spreading various musical acts — including some free shows — between the Cité de la Musique, the Géode and the green fields of the park.

headline: Uniform-Wearing Militants Kill 6 at Afghan Police Station
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Insurgents wearing police uniforms and vests laced with explosives stormed a police compound in eastern Afghanistan early Sunday morning, engaging in a firefight that lasted several hours before Afghan and NATO forces regained control of the complex, government officials said.

headline: Europeans Focus on Retaining Leadership of I.M.F.
text: PARIS — As the International Monetary Fund prepared to accept nominations Monday to replace Dominique Strauss-Kahn at its helm, European officials rallied over the weekend around Christine Lagarde, France’s finance minister, as their top choice for the post, despite fresh warnings from leaders of emerging markets and other countries that simply handing the job to another European could undermine the fund’s legitimacy.

headline: The Rail’s Scoreboard
text: How The Rail’s contributors are doing with their predictions through the first two legs of the Triple Crown (using a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show). Our guest pickers, Rick Pitino and Kevin Plank, have failed to score.

headline: Spain’s Governing Party Suffers Heavy Losses
text: MADRID — The governing Socialist Party suffered heavy losses on Sunday in regional and municipal elections, even as tens of thousands of Spaniards calling themselves the “indignant” said they would pursue their protests to force an overhaul of the country’s political system.

headline: Obama Presses Israel to Make ‘Hard Choices’
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama struck back at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday, defending his stance that talks over a Palestinian state should be focused on Israel’s pre-1967 borders, along with negotiated land swaps, and challenging Israel to “make the hard choices” necessary to bring about a stable peace.

headline: Vettel Controls Race in Spain to Win Fourth Prix in Five
text: BARCELONA – Before the race on Sunday, Formula One had high expectations that thanks to new technical rules, the Spanish Grand Prix would not be the same procession it usually is on a track where it is so difficult to overtake.

headline: Vettel Controls Race in Spain to Win Fourth Prix in Five
text: BARCELONA – Before the race on Sunday, Formula One had high expectations that thanks to new technical rules, the Spanish Grand Prix would not be the same procession it usually is on a track where it is so difficult to overtake.

headline: Schott Op-Chart: All the World’s a World Stage
text: “The purpose of foreign policy,” argued John F. Kennedy, “is not to provide an outlet for our own sentiments of hope or indignation; it is to shape real events in a real world.” And the real world is populated by other leaders, each with their own competing hopes and indignations. Click here for the actors who, since Jimmy Carter, have strutted and fretted their hour upon the world stage.

headline: Cannes Q. and A.: Driving in a Noir L.A.
text: CANNES, France— Genre movies are typically relegated to the sidelines at the world’s major film festivals, but Cannes this year has done its part to shift the balance. Alongside auteurs like the Dardenne brothers and Aki Kaurismaki, the main competition also features a few surprising Cannes first-timers, like Japan’s Takashi Miike, whose samurai drama “Hara-kiri” is the first 3-D movie to screen in competition, and Denmark’s Nicolas Winding Refn, best known for the violent “Pusher” trilogy and the stylized thug portrait “Bronson,” who is here with his Los Angeles-set noir “Drive.” (On Sunday, Mr. Refn won the festival’s best director prize.)

headline: Djokovic Hones a Masterful Winning Streak
text: PARIS — Novak Djokovic’s 39-match winning streak coming into this French Open sounds lengthy indeed, until you start thinking long-term.

headline: In City That Lost Its Team, Every Win Is a Point of Pride
text: With due deference to the millionaire superstars whose soccer skills are followed across the world, the story of English soccer’s final weekend was the rise of A.F.C. Wimbledon.

headline: Other Peoples’ Politics
text: Update: Robin’s suggestion to the Italians is, find some way to get Berlusconi into a New York hotel.

headline: Rhone Steps Down as Head of Universal Motown
text: The management shake-up at Universal Music Group continues as Sylvia Rhone, a lieutenant of the company’s former chairman and one of the most prominent women in the music business, steps down as president of Universal Motown, one of the group’s labels.

headline: A Move by City Opera Has Potential, as Well as Possible Pitfalls
text: After talking, fantasizing and plotting about it for years, New York City Opera is moving out of Lincoln Center. Immediately! Or so the company said on Friday in a stunning, if very sketchy, announcement from George Steel, the general manager and artistic director.

headline: Mideast Questions Likely to Surface in Obama’s Trip to Europe
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama left behind a week filled with the strident passions of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to fly to Europe on Sunday, where his first stop on a six-day tour is Ireland, another country once consumed by sectarian violence.

headline: Now Running for President: Mitch Daniels’s Ghost
text: Mitch Daniels’s decision to not run for president stands somewhat in contrast to Mike Huckabee’s, simply because Mr. Daniels had yet to gain significant popular support in the polls. But it also stands in contrast to Haley Barbour’s, in that Mr. Daniels had a more plausible route to the nomination, most likely by performing “well enough” in Iowa to gain significant momentum heading into New Hampshire, a state that caters to a number of his strengths.

headline: Jimmy Choo Sold to Labelux for About $800 Million
text: Labelux, a privately held luxury group, said Sunday that it had agreed to acquire the high-end shoe and accessories company Jimmy Choo from TowerBrook Capital Partners, a private equity company, and minority shareholders.

headline: Worthy Online Resource, but Global Cultural Treasure?
text: BERLIN — In its 10 years of existence, Wikipedia, the global online encyclopedia, has amassed an archive of 18 million entries in 279 languages. It is one of the 10 most popular Web sites on the Internet.

headline: Yemeni Leader’s Allies Blockade Embassy as He Refuses Peace Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Yemen’s political crisis deepened on Sunday as President Ali Abdullah Saleh once again and at the last minute scuttled an agreement that he step down, and hundreds of his armed supporters blockaded an embassy, trapping American, European and Arab diplomats for hours.

headline: Few Upsets on French Open’s First Day
text: PARIS — Samantha Stosur of Australia, last year’s runner-up, returned to the French Open on Sunday with a convincing 6-2, 6-3 victory over Iveta Benesova of the Czech Republic.

headline: Hollywood Presses Its Global Agenda
text: SINGAPORE — When “Thor,” the Marvel superhero action film directed by Kenneth Branagh, opened in theaters in North America on May 6, the $150 million 3-D film had already made more than $130 million at the international box office.

headline: Asia Society Appoints Two Leaders
text: The balance of power between the United States and Asia has shifted dramatically since 1956, when John D. Rockefeller III founded the Asia Society to promote greater understanding of Asia in the United States. In response, the Asia Society is shifting its center of gravity from New York to its outposts in Hong Kong, Mumbai, Manila and elsewhere.

headline: The Morning Line: Assessing the Preakness
text: There’s no rapture and no chance of a Triple Crown this year as the 12-1 shot Shackleford defeated the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom by a half-length to win the Preakness.

headline: Oscar Winner Facing Sex Charges an Apparent Suicide
text: An Academy Award-winning songwriter who was awaiting trial on charges of sexually assaulting about a dozen women was believed to have killed himself in an apartment on the Upper East Side, the police said.

headline: Protesters Call for the Resignation of Georgia’s President
text: MOSCOW — The police clashed with antigovernment protesters in Georgia on Sunday, at one point firing tear gas and rubber bullets, as hundreds of demonstrators gathered in the capital of the former Soviet republic to demand the ouster of President Mikheil Saakashvili.

headline: The Magic of a Courtside Seat
text: PARIS — With a relatively uneventful opening day unfolding at Roland Garros, it seemed the best way to spend part of a sunny, breezy afternoon was in my favorite press seat in sports.

headline: ‘Pirates’ Plunders the Global Box Office
text: International audiences carried “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides,” the fourth film in this series from Walt Disney Studios, to $346.4 million in worldwide ticket sales since the movie opened abroad on Wednesday.

headline: Elite South Korean University Rattled by Suicides
text: DAEJEON, South Korea — It has been a sad and gruesome semester at South Korea’s most prestigious university, and with final exams beginning Monday the school is still reeling from the recent suicides of four students and a popular professor.

headline: Talk Show Ends, and Oprah Moves On
text: Oprah Winfrey has taped more than 5,000 episodes of her daytime talk show, transforming television and trying to teach millions of viewers how to live life with purpose along the way. She has one more to go. She says she feels relieved.

headline: Union Ponders Labor Charges
text: The American Guild of Musical Artists said it would consider filing unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Board against New York City Opera after that company’s board voted on Friday to cut staffing and move from its Lincoln Center home. Alan Gordon, the union’s national executive director, said the group might also seek an injunction to keep the company from using the name New York City Opera. George Steel, the opera’s general manager and artistic director, said on Friday that the move, the layoffs and the cuts to the production schedule were required to keep the company running and to ensure “a foundation for sustainable growth.” RACHEL LEE HARRIS

headline: Media Decoder: Oprah's Final Show
text: After 25 years, the final episode of "The Oprah Winfrey Show" will air on May 25.

headline: Gates Warns Against Big Cuts in Military Spending
text: WASHINGTON — In a grim warning about financial priorities during a time of fiscal crisis, the defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, said Sunday that budget pressures must not limit Pentagon spending such that the military is unable to defend American interests in an unpredictable world.

headline: Cannes Gives Top Prize to ‘The Tree of Life’
text: CANNES, France — In a strong year that was nearly eclipsed by off-screen scandals, the top prize for the 64th Cannes Film Festival was given to “’The Tree of Life,” the long-awaited film from the American director and writer Terrence Malick. A story about transcendence that divided critics, who were alternately transported and turned off by its religious themes and elliptical storytelling, it is the first film from Mr. Malick since “The New World” (2005). The famously shy Mr. Malick did not appear to accept his award, which was introduced by Jane Fonda, who spoke in emphatic French before saying, “And maintenant, now, let’s cut to the chase.” The competition jury president, Robert De Niro, hurriedly announced the winner.

headline: Oprah’s Final Shows: What to Expect
text: After 25 years, the final episode of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” will air on May 25.

headline: On Strength of One Inning, Yankees Thwart the Mets
text: The Mets were nine outs away Sunday from evening their record at .500, from capturing a series against the Yankees, from reigning supreme in New York. Their nominal ace, Mike Pelfrey, was cruising. The bottom of the Yankees’ order was due up.

headline: Obama Addresses AIPAC
text: President Obama repeated his call for Palestinian statehood based on Israel's pre-1967 borders in a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. (Video: MSNBC)

headline: Insects Flee, and Kitty Seeks Revenge
text: Over the weekend at the West End Theater, back-to-back programs showcased new dances by a pair of diametrically opposed artists: Rebecca Stenn and Maura Nguyen Donohue. They were part of the Soaking Wet series created by Jeffrey Kazin and David Parker, who included a program note explaining that the two choreographers “show an underlying unity of purpose in their creation of eloquent work.” If that’s a little ambiguous, this isn’t: One had more purpose and eloquence than the other.

headline: Meeting, Marriage and Then Trouble
text: When you consider that opera and art song tend to reach their most unforgettable heights and depths at moments of vulnerability and tragedy, it is no surprise that the final part of the soprano Kate Royal’s concert at Weill Recital Hall on Friday was the strongest.

headline: Economic Crisis Unfurls in Hushed Suspense
text: It can’t be easy to create a financial thriller. There’s no blood, there are (usually) no bodies. How do you create excitement when most of the action consists of middle-aged white men in conservative suits talking on the phone, and the closest thing to a car chase is a stately procession of big black Town Cars? How often can you show people peering at spreadsheets and recoiling in alarm? What do you do when the scandal itself might as well be labeled “Too Complicated to Understand”? The HBO film “Too Big to Fail,” based on the book of the same name by the reporter Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, about the financial crisis of 2008, uses every cinematic trick in the book, but ultimately succeeds because we know that the danger was real.

headline: Rock and Classical Collide With Bowie and a Score by Radiohead Star
text: Wordless Music, the concert series run by Ronen Givony when he is not overseeing the classical and new-music programming at Le Poisson Rouge, is devoted to showing fans of indie rock and contemporary classical music that the two genres have a common appeal. That argument no longer requires special pleading, partly because Mr. Givony’s thoughtful juxtapositions have made the point so persuasively but also because so many young composers (and some of their elders) draw freely on both their classical and pop antecedents.

headline: In TV Pilots, Paranormal Is the New Normal
text: IT was not so long ago that commercials were filled with fantastical characters like green giants, flying maids and white knights. For the 2011-12 television season, it will be the shows, not the ads, that feature creatures out of fairy tales and ghost stories.

headline: Confederate General Buried Far From the Battlefield
text: Robert Selden Garnett, the first general killed in the Civil War, was buried in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, but his family did not want visitors to the cemetery to know it.

headline: Making a Hashtag of It
text: If you’ve been watching media debaters flip the pro-con coin about the Internet lately, you know by now that Twitter is either a noble catalyst of the Arab Spring or an atomizer of noxious moronism whose users might as well be huffing computer duster.

headline: Mystical Morocco Bursting With Tribal Rhythm
text: West African slaves, transported far from home, held on to rituals that praise saints and spirits with songs, dances, galvanizing rhythms and trance possession. That’s the story of voodoo and Santería in the Americas, and it’s also the story of Gnawa music in Morocco, made by descendants of slaves brought north from what is now Mali. As part of its World Nomads Morocco Festival, the French Institute Alliance Française brought “Master Gnaoua Musicians” to Florence Gould Hall on Saturday night.

headline: The Flight of Curiosity
text: Must one be endowed with curiosity in order to become a philosopher?

headline: With Subtlety and Power, Observing Mahler’s Moment
text: NEWARK — One hundred years ago last Wednesday, Gustav Mahler died of a heart infection. He was living in Vienna, but three months earlier he had conducted the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall in his final appearance on a podium. That February concert ended a three-year period in which he reigned in New York, first as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and then as the Philharmonic’s music director.

headline: Pop Stars Lift ‘SNL’ Ratings
text: Maybe it was the Gaga effect, or maybe it was J. T., or most likely a bit of both: with Lady Gaga performing and Justin Timberlake, together below, hosting over the weekend, “Saturday Night Live” recorded its highest ratings for a season finale in seven years. Nielsen reported that the show averaged a 7.0 rating in major local markets — meaning about 7 percent of homes with televisions watched the episode — up from a 5.8 rating for the same episode last season. NBC said that rating was high enough to match the season finale in 2004, when the Olsen twins, Mary-Kate and Ashley, were the hosts and J-Kwon was the performer. Apart from a night in January when the show was preceded by a major football game, Saturday’s episode also received a season-high rating. The episode was particularly well-received online for its revival of several past Timberlake sketches and for Lady Gaga’s appearances in several of the sketches.

headline: Nonfiction Writer Finishes Crichton Novel
text: HarperCollins plans to publish a new novel by Michael Crichton, the best-selling author of “Jurassic Park” and “The Andromeda Strain,” who died of cancer in November 2008. The book is to be released in November with assistance from the noted nonfiction author Richard Preston, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Crichton wrote about one-third of “Micro,” a technological thriller, before his death. Mr. Preston, best known for his book “The Hot Zone,” about the Ebola virus, used Mr. Crichton’s personal reference material, outline and notes to finish the novel. “When I first read Michael Crichton’s unfinished manuscript, I could practically feel his excitement filling the pages,” Mr. Preston said in a news release from the publisher. “Michael was writing at the top of his game, with a grand sense of adventure, into an eerie world that seems almost beyond imagining.” He added that he sought “to honor the work and imagination of one of our time’s most visionary and creative authors.” In 2009 HarperCollins also published “Pirate Latitudes,” which Mr. Crichton had finished.

headline: Festival for Puppets
text: St. Ann’s Warehouse in Dumbo, Brooklyn, will host Labapalooza!, an annual minifestival celebrating new puppet and object theater. Guided by the directors Matthew Acheson and Tom Lee, St. Ann’s Puppet Lab artists will present a range of works including “Interference and Collapse,” a look at the death of the R&B singer Sam Cooke, and “Senseless! A Brick Foley Adventure,” a hard-boiled tale investigating a series of murders at the Helen Keller School of Music, the theater announced. Financed by the Jim Henson Foundation, the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts, Labapalooza!, in its 13th year, will be presented in two programs running from June 2 to 5.

headline: Burdened by PBS Dues, Stations Consider Withdrawing
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Television executives who gathered here last week for PBS’s annual meeting enthusiastically embraced projects such as the five-part “Women, War and Peace” and heard the actress Anna Deavere Smith speak so passionately of PBS’s role in bringing the arts to Americans that Paula Kerger, PBS’s president and chief executive, teared up.

headline: The Parisian Experience of American Pioneers
text: “The Greater Journey” is an important-looking book by the august historian David McCullough, who has twice won the Pulitzer Prize (for “Truman” and “John Adams”) and is a regular source of Father’s Day gifts for distinction-loving dads. His latest lavishly produced volume has a handsome collection of color photographs, a stellar cast of historically important American characters and a long, impressive bibliography. What it does not have is a unifying premise.

headline: At the Game’s Highest Level, Communication Is Everything
text: The higher the level of the game, the more important bidding has become. And for getting to the correct games and, especially, slams, describing opener’s hand type as quickly as possible is a big plus. So with a balanced hand, utter the phrase “no-trump” as quickly as possible. With an unbalanced hand, show the long suits.

headline: TV Justice Thrives on Fear
text: This week, it was announced that “America’s Most Wanted,” hosted by John Walsh, the longest running perp walk in television history, would no longer be regularly broadcast on Fox. With the future of Mr. Walsh’s hunt for bad guys uncertain, who will speak for the victims of crime?

headline: Monday: 20 Questions Category
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — When I am at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, it is always interesting to see what kind of talismanic items people bring with them to help them speed up their solving. I’ve seen everything from lucky pencils to Troll dolls. Some people wear costumes. Still others, oddly enough, practice solving.

headline: Female Magazine Fans Flock to Nook Color
text: Even as the iPad remains the favorite son of the magazine business, publishers are discovering that the Barnes & Noble Nook Color is a very promising younger daughter.

headline: ‘Follies’
text: Photos from the revival at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

headline: Analysts Wary of LinkedIn’s Stock Surge
text: What are shares of LinkedIn really worth?

headline: Mourning the Loss of Yet Another Alley
text: “It’s all over with,” Marilyn Onorato said, casting a final gaze over the 32 lanes at Fairway Bowling. “Boo hoo.”

headline: Yahoo’s Emphasis Is ‘Better,’ Not ‘New’
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — In listing his biggest accomplishments as Yahoo’s product chief, Blake Irving gave an answer that speaks to the company’s painful legacy of layoffs, aimlessness and stalled growth.

headline: ‘Cronocaos’
text: A new exhibition challenges the rush to preserve sites deemed historic.

headline: Militants Attack Pakistani Naval Base in Karachi
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A team of heavily armed insurgents stormed a major Pakistani naval base in the southern city of Karachi late Sunday night, setting off a prolonged gun battle with Pakistani security forces and, by some accounts, destroying an American-made aircraft at the base.

headline: ‘The Most Northern of Southern Cities’
text: Like many Mid-Atlantic cities, Philadelphia was split between Unionist and pro-Southern sentiments. In early 1861 crowds cheered at a rally to support the seceding states, while the city’s political leaders offered Independence Hall as the site for a special convention to conciliate the secession crisis.

headline: Armstrong Teammate Describes Doping System
text: For top riders on the United States Postal Service squad, the powerhouse American cycling team led by Lance Armstrong, duplicity was simply a part of the game, one of Armstrong’s former teammates said.

headline: Lightning Fans Send a Message: We Exist
text: Assumptions about Southern fans’ interest in hockey are made at one’s own peril. The Boston Bruins’ promotions department made one about fans of the Tampa Bay Lightning, and on Sunday those fans provided a very visible rebuttal.

headline: I.M.F. Candidates, by the Numbers
text: The race to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn as managing director of the International Monetary Fund is under way. Picking the fund’s next chief will depend on personalities and politics. But what if the decision were based on the economic performance of the I.M.F.’s 187 member states? In that case, none of the current favorites would look particularly good.

headline: No Recognition Yet, but European Union Opens an Office in the Libyan Rebels’ Stronghold
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Catherine Ashton, the European Union‘s foreign policy chief, visited Benghazi on Sunday, providing support and a burst of confidence to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi‘s opponents, who said the high-profile trip was evidence of growing international recognition for their cause.

headline: Fine Print Blurs Who’s in Control of Online Photos
text: If you post a photo on the Web, it still belongs to you, right? Well, be sure to read the fine print.

headline: The Self-Rationing of Medical Care
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Objects to New Law on Clinics in Indiana
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is raising serious objections to a new Indiana law that cuts off state and federal money for Planned Parenthood clinics providing health care to low-income women on Medicaid.

headline: Somali and African Union Forces Advance in Mogadishu
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Government forces and African Union peacekeepers advanced Sunday against rebels in several Mogadishu neighborhoods, gaining ground in their campaign to take control of the Bakara market, officials and witnesses said.

headline: Ex-Leader of Honduras Signs Accord Clearing Path for Return
text: MEXICO CITY — The former president of Honduras, Manuel Zelaya, who was ousted and expelled in a 2009 coup, signed an agreement with the current president on Sunday that clears the way for him to return home after two years in exile, Honduran officials said.

headline: CNBC Takes a Hollywood Turn
text: Every few minutes in “Too Big to Fail,” the film about the darkest days of the financial crisis in 2008 that will have its premiere Monday on HBO, something happens that once seemed unbelievable. Banks collapse. Balance sheets crumble. Government officials plot extraordinary interventions to curb the free fall.

headline: Accord With Comptroller Will Help Attorney General Pursue Corruption Cases
text: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman and Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, have entered into an agreement that will grant Mr. Schneiderman powers to criminally prosecute corruption involving taxpayer money, significantly expanding the attorney general’s authority to pursue public integrity cases.

headline: Arizona’s Immigration Law: A View From the A.C.L.U.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tale of the City: Quieting the Cab Honking
text: To the Editor:

headline: As Lenders Hold Homes in Foreclosure, Sales Are Hurt
text: EL MIRAGE, Ariz. — The nation’s biggest banks and mortgage lenders have steadily amassed real estate empires, acquiring a glut of foreclosed homes that threatens to deepen the housing slump and create a further drag on the economic recovery.

headline: Daniels Is Out, in Another Jolt to G.O.P. Field
text: WASHINGTON — The announcement Sunday by Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana that he would not run for the Republican presidential nomination ended one major chapter of uncertainty in the race but ignited new debate over whether the current field contains a candidate capable of beating President Obama next year.

headline: With Triple Crown Hopes Dashed, Enthusiasm Grows for a Belmont Rivalry
text: BALTIMORE

headline: Rose Denies Comments on Performance-Enhancing Drugs
text: MIAMI — Derrick Rose denied quotations attributed to him by ESPN The Magazine on the impact of performance-enhancing drugs in the N.B.A. Rose was among a number of athletes polled by the magazine when it asked them to assess the influence of the drugs in their sport from 1 as the lowest to 10 at the highest.

headline: Don’t Tread on Golfers’ Right to Hit Ball Poorly
text: Nearly two weeks ago, I wrote an article about the Polara golf ball, a newly redesigned ball that is said to correct slices and hooks off the tee by as much as 75 percent. I tried to slice and hook the ball without much success. Then I went to a driving range, where I approached other golfers and told them I had a ball that wouldn’t slice.

headline: In Egypt, Police Officer Is Sentenced to Death
text: CAIRO — A Cairo court sentenced a rank-and-file police officer to death after trying him in absentia for the killings of unarmed protesters during the Egyptian revolution, the harshest sentence given to date as the military-led interim government grapples with calls for retribution against members of the former government.

headline: One View of the News World
text: When Xinhua, the official government news agency of China, wanted to upgrade from its old office in Queens, it sought out a space that matched its ambitions. So it leased the top floor of a skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan, one with commanding views of the headquarters for Thomson Reuters, the News Corporation, The New York Times and other leading news organizations that have offices nearby.

headline: Small Ball Produces Big Inning for Yankees
text: Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli took a big assignment with him to the batter’s box in the bottom of the seventh inning Sunday with his team trailing by two runs: drop a bunt that could move two base runners closer to home. The next thing Cervelli knew, Mike Pelfrey’s 100th pitch was headed straight for his face.

headline: The Strauss-Kahn Case: What the Housekeeper Told Police
text: As Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, was released on bail on sexual assault charges, a fuller picture of what happened at the Sofitel in Midtown on May 14 has emerged from the police.

headline: Pawlenty Announces Candidacy a Day Early

headline: Nathaniel Davis, Diplomat, Is Dead at 86
text: Nathaniel Davis, a seasoned diplomat who shepherded American interests through upheavals like the Chilean coup of 1973 and the breakout of civil war in Angola in 1975, died on May 16 in Claremont, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Behind Closed, Sequentially Numbered Doors
text: DEPENDING on traffic, it’s usually no more than a one-hour car ride from the Sofitel Hotel in Midtown Manhattan to Rikers Island, each of which Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, checked into for a time last week. But the accommodations provided are worlds apart.

headline: Free Speech on Twitter Faces Test
text: SAN FRANCISCO — What began as seamy gossip about an affair between a famous British soccer player and a reality TV star has quickly become another test over how far the rights to privacy and free speech extend online, where social media operate in countries with vastly different laws.

headline: Sealift Extends Lifeline to a Rebel City in Libya

headline: Some See Suburban Slight in the Newly Drawn State Legislative Districts
text: In drawing new legislative districts for state lawmakers last week, Democrats in Springfield said they abided by voting-rights laws and citizens’ concerns.

headline: When a Bad Golf Course Edges Into Goodness
text: There is no such thing as a really terrible golf course. If you’re playing golf on it, how awful can it be? But if some courses are indisputably better than others, then inevitably, some are worse. Quite a bit worse, in my experience. So bad that they’re worth a detour — if only because they make you grateful for the other better kind.

headline: Seeking to Disrupt Protesters, Syria Cracks Down on Social Media
text: The Syrian government is cracking down on protesters’ use of social media and the Internet to promote their rebellion just three months after allowing citizens to have open access to Facebook and YouTube, according to Syrian activists and digital privacy experts.

headline: Who Will Play Strauss-Kahn?

headline: When the Internet Thinks It Knows You
text: ONCE upon a time, the story goes, we lived in a broadcast society. In that dusty pre-Internet age, the tools for sharing information weren’t widely available. If you wanted to share your thoughts with the masses, you had to own a printing press or a chunk of the airwaves, or have access to someone who did. Controlling the flow of information was an elite class of editors, producers and media moguls who decided what people would see and hear about the world. They were the Gatekeepers.

headline: Suit Claims Cisco Helped China Pursue Falun Gong

headline: Teaching Beyond the Test, to Make Room Again for Current Events

The European team certainly hopes the 1-up win by Norway’s Suzann Pettersen over Cristie Kerr at Hamilton Farm Golf Club is also an omen portending victory after three consecutive losses to the United States.

headline: Whose Fault Is It if a Child Is Failing in School?
text: Proposals in some states would fine parents, or hold them accountable in other ways, if their children do poorly in school or are frequently absent. Do you think this is fair? What factors do you think cause children to fail in school? Who do you think most deserves the blame for a child’s academic failure — the child, the child’s parents or the teacher? Why?

headline: Pakistan’s Military Faces New Questions After Raid

Before the fighting was over, the attackers had killed at least 10 Pakistani security officers in a gun battle that lasted for hours and raised new questions about the competence of the country’s armed forces.

headline: The Early Word: Tension

Mr. Obama called his proposal the best chance Israel has to avoid growing isolation amid rising political upheaval near its borders.

headline: Seeing London’s Hidden Gardens

Called Open Squares Garden Weekend, this annual event provides a rare opportunity to see into spots like the Tate Modern Community Garden, the three gardens of artist William Morris’s London home, and the Lincoln’s Inn Gardens, which date back to 1422.

Its release coincides with that of ‘Heavy Rocks’ (not to be confused with the 2002 album of the same name) and two Japanese-only titles: another collaboration with noise master Merzbow called ‘Klatter,’ as well as ‘New Album,’ which frustratingly mixes tracks from ‘Attention Please’ and the new ‘Heavy Rocks’ with other material.”

headline: Ballerinas, Meet Bally-Rina
text: Who better to judge Bally’s new Bally-Rina collection than the real ballerinas of the New York City Ballet? The differences between the Swiss luxury-house’s flats and your run-of-the-mill ballet ones are vast according to the company’s senior corps de ballet dancers, Gretchen Smith and Marika Anderson. The women work in nude leather Bloch dance shoes both in the classroom and throughout rehearsals. And when they’re not dancing they still prefer to slip into flats. “I’m really picky when it comes to flats because I wear them to the bone,” says Anderson, who previously wore Cole Haan because of the Nike-Air instep. “We really like the Bally-Rina’s in blue,” says Smith pointing out the shoe’s ultra low vamp. Smith also likes that the sole of the shoe is comfortable and how the inside looks like an actual pointe shoe. This summer, the company heads for a slew of performances in Saratoga and both women see themselves wearing Bally-Rina flats, Smith with a flowy high-waisted skirt; Anderson with fitted jeans and a T-shirt. They’ll pair them with matching Bally-Rina bags stuffed with the tools of the trade: several pairs of pointe shoes, flat shoes, tape, scissors, glue, needles and thread, water and vitamin B. The cute but functional special Bally-Rina collection comes in shades of navy, grass green and yellow – that should be more than enough to keep more than New York City ballerinas dancing.

headline: Where Should New York City Opera Go?

The organization did indicate some parameters: three of the operas will be suitable for a larger house, and two for smaller spaces. Already, reader e-mail to The New York Times has raised the Brooklyn Academy of Music as a fine potential home. What do you think of the decision to leave Lincoln Center? Where should City Opera go?

headline: Real Estate as Backdrop for the Latest Reality TV

The models, leggy young women dressed in Nina Ricci, Proenza Schouler and Calvin Klein, had started to circulate as waiters came through with trays of canapés like smoked salmon topped with glistening orange roe. A jazz quartet kept up a steady rhythm from under the stairs as guests milled about, exclaiming over the panoramic views through four enormous, synchronized glass clocks set in the tower walls.

headline: At the CN Tower in Toronto, Leaning Over a 116-Story Deck

The CN Tower is home to a new attraction called EdgeWalk, which will allow visitors to walk around the observation deck, 1,168 feet, or 116 stories, above ground. Guided groups of six to eight walkers (who must be 13 or older) will be attached by harness to an overhead safety rail that encircles the deck, absent of any hand rails.

headline: Showtime Cancels ‘United States of Tara’ and Renews ‘Nurse Jackie’
text: With one fell swoop, Showtime has eliminated several female personalities from its lineup of original programming. On Monday it announced the cancellation of “The United States of Tara,” the comedy-drama starring Toni Collette as a housewife with dissociative identity disorder (commonly known as multiple personality disorder); the current season will be its last. “Tara,” which made its debut in 2009, came with an impressive pedigree, which included its creator, Diablo Cody, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of “Juno,” and the executive producer Steven Spielberg. And Ms. Collette was widely praised for her performance in the title role, winning an Emmy Award in 2009 and a Golden Globe in 2010. But ratings for the series have diminished, from 816,000 viewers for the premiere of Season 2 to 411,000 viewers for the debut of Season 3 in March, The Hollywood Reporter reported. By comparison, the season finale of Showtime’s historical drama “The Borgias” was watched by 810,000 viewers at 10 p.m. on Sunday, the network said.

headline: The Culturialist | Robert Irwin’s Garden Path
text: At this time of year the Central Garden at the Getty Center in Los Angeles is particularly sublime. The unorthodox collection of more than 500 plants, shrubs and trees was brought together and landscaped by the artist Robert Irwin. London plane trees line a path that traverses a stream and descends into a plaza where purple bougainvillea draped over specially constructed metal arbors form a shaded canopy. And the lower bowl is a riot of herbs, vegetables and other plants in constant rotation. Work on the garden started many years before the museum opened in 1997. And despite the fact that, in garden years, 15 is relatively young, it feels very sure of itself.

headline: The Youngest Casualties of Cancer

headline: Numberplay: Tinkering with Ladders
text: Last week’s Numberplay puzzle, presented by Gary Antonick and suggested and masterfully moderated by Joshua Zucker, had all the hallmarks of a classic. This puzzle, known as the Ducci game or 4-number game, is easy to state and understand, uses a procedure a child can carry out, and yet it unlocks the door to fabulous mathematical riches. For those who missed it I would urge you to go back and take a look at it. Here is a brief restatement, given a slightly different visual model from last week. Given any four arbitrary positive integers a, b, c and d, representing the top rung of a ladder, you construct another step below it, consisting of the positive differences between them taken cyclically: |a-b|, |b-c|, |c-d| and |d-a|. An example 2-step ladder is:1 2 5 91 3 4 8It turns out that all such ladders eventually end as all the numbers become zeroes. One challenge was to find what initial numbers gave rise to the longest ladders, and it turned out that the champion quartets had a fascinating mathematical property.

headline: A Fairy Tale, Updated Without Ambien

As in the original fairy tale, tweaked in this modern update, when she emerges from that long slumber she finds herself staring into the eyes of a love-struck swain, not groping for coffee to dispel the dim haze of an Ambien hangover.

headline: Learning Geometry Without a Protractor
text: Although many school-going youth might disagree, a new study finds that geometry is an intuitive subject that is easy to grasp even in the absence of formal training.

headline: A Season Brings New Faces and Insights to Classic Roles
text: If there were a “Harry Potter” ballet, you’d cast Janie Taylor as Luna Lovegood, that most ethereal of young wizards. Pale with a cascade of blond hair reaching her waist, she seems naturally to be in communion with other worlds. Though she well may be the weakest technician among New York City Ballet’s female principals, she brings spiritual intensity to everything she does. On Friday night she made her debut as the Sleepwalker, the title role in “La Sonnambula,” George Balanchine’s ballet. The luminous, eerie, compulsive quality she brought to the role refreshed the whole drama.

headline: Union Effort Turns Its Focus to Target
text: In the world of big-box discounters, Target enjoys a reputation as a model corporate citizen that sells the latest in cheap chic. That’s a sharp contrast to the image of Wal-Mart, the world’s largest retailer, which labor unions have pilloried for years, accusing it of providing skimpy wages and benefits and skirting various labor laws.

headline: City Opera Departure Brings Questions
text: New York City Opera’s decision to bail out of Lincoln Center raised the sounds of lamentation from company veterans and opera world officials on Monday, many of whom heard the news as a near death knell.

headline: Sacrificing the Presidency for Family?
text: “I love my country; I love my family more.” Indiana Governor Mitch Daniels in announcing why he would not be running for president.

headline: YouTube Extends Plans for Ads Before Videos
text: In the early days of online video, commercials that appeared before viewers could watch clips, known as preroll, got “thumbs down” from most computer users. That attitude seems to have softened more recently, a change of heart that Web giants have noticed.

headline: 3 Classic Novels. 22 Minutes. Why Not?
text: Elevator Repair Service has nothing to do with elevators. It’s a theatrical troupe whose main job lately has been to stage unusual readings of classic American novels. Book in hand, the actors recite the text and pretty soon start behaving in ways that indicate how they’ve been taken over by it.

headline: Before Attack, Pakistan’s Navy Boasted of Role in Fight Against Taliban
text: After Pakistan finally regained control of a naval base in Karachi on Monday, following a 16-hour gun battle with militants who killed at least 12 security officers and destroyed two American-supplied surveillance aircraft, observers were left with more questions than answers.

headline: Republican Candidate in House Race Acknowledges Missteps
text: With a closely watched special Congressional election in western New York entering its final hour, Jane L. Corwin, the Republican candidate, said on Monday that she should have done more to blunt the attacks against her campaign over her support for a Republican plan to overhaul Medicare.

headline: Peter Frelinghuysen Jr., 95, Former Congressman, Dies
text: Peter H. B. Frelinghuysen Jr., one in a long line of family members to represent New Jersey in Congress and a leader in the successful fight to block an airport proposed for the state’s Great Swamp wildlife area, died on Monday at his home in Harding Township, N.J. He was 95.

headline: Border Town Incursion Poses Big Risk for Sudan
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — With just seven weeks to go before declaring independence, a goal that has taken more than 50 years and millions of lives, southern Sudan’s leaders watched the northern Sudanese Army — their longtime nemesis — steamroll into the disputed town of Abyei over the weekend and essentially annex it overnight.

headline: Prison Ruling Raises Stakes in California Fiscal Crisis
text: LOS ANGELES — The Supreme Court’s order to California to ease overcrowding in the state’s prisons, by releasing tens of thousands of inmates if no other solution can be found, will probably aid Gov. Jerry Brown’s plan to move more inmates from state prisons to county jails.

headline: State Secrets Block Resolution of Contractors’ Suit, Justices Say
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday unanimously ruled that national security considerations made it impossible for it to take sides in a multibillion-dollar dispute between military contractors and the government.

headline: No Breakaway From Doping Charges
text: Until Sunday night, on “60 Minutes,” Lance Armstrong and Tyler Hamilton had been linked mostly by a moment of crisis — perhaps even a great gesture of sportsmanship — in the Pyrenees eight years ago, when Hamilton just might have saved Armstrong’s fifth consecutive Tour de France championship.

text: Israel said its Iron Dome antirocket missile defense system intercepted short-range rockets fired from Gaza in April.

text: Israel says its Iron Dome missile defense system intercepts short-range rockets fired from Gaza.

headline: Madoff Trustee and Mets Owners Differ on Issue of Cooperation
text: Among the points that the owners of the Mets have been most insistent about in their legal fight with the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud has been their claim to have been completely forthcoming during the trustee’s investigation of their finances.

headline: First Arrest Signals a Break in a Stadium Beating Case
text: LOS ANGELES — For seven weeks after the opening day attack on a San Francisco Giants fan outside Dodger Stadium, as the victim languished in a coma, the police struggled to find a suspect. The brutal beating had been witnessed by dozens. Billboards displaying composite sketches of the two assailants offered a grim reminder of problems at the stadium.

headline: Yandex Is Set for $1.3 Billion Stock Offering
text: Sergei Karpukhin/ReutersThe Moscow headquarters of Yandex, which is set to go public.

headline: Israel Unveils Iron Dome Missile Defense System
text: When hostilities flared last month between Palestinian militants and Israel, the headlines focused on a 16-year-old Israeli boy who was fatally wounded when an antitank missile fired from Gaza struck his school bus in southern Israel. But during those same hostilities, Israeli officials say, they scored a military success they are eager for the world to see: the country’s Iron Dome antirocket missile defense system for the first time intercepted — in seconds — short-range rockets fired from Gaza, according to the officials.

headline: Democrats Try to Woo Consumer Advocate to Run
text: WASHINGTON — Officials in the Democratic Party are wooing Elizabeth Warren to run for the Senate against the Massachusetts Republican Scott P. Brown rather than have her continue to set up the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: Evidence Said to Tie Ex-I.M.F. Chief to Housekeeper
text: Evidence from the work clothes of a hotel housekeeper matched DNA samples taken from Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund who has been charged with sexually assaulting her, a person briefed on the matter said Monday.

Granderson made it only as far as the fence, where he watched Bautista’s first-inning blast sail into the bullpen.

text: Danny O’Reilly is the singer for the Coronas, one of the bands that played before President Obama gave his speech at College Green in Dublin today. He provided the Caucus a backstage pool report. From his account, it sounded like a campaign event, just one where the crowd won’t be voting in the fall of 2012.

headline: Innovation in the Air Can Begin on the Water
text: MOST aeronautical and technological innovations in airplanes initially involve a guy like Dave Cummings in the cockpit, testing out new equipment under various conditions.

headline: The Boys & Girls Club and High Tech? They Mix
text: THE Boys & Girls Clubs of America, which traces its history back 150 years to civic-minded Connecticut women who wanted to help get impoverished boys off the streets, is turning to 21st-century social media, including Twitter, to garner support for its mission.

text: We can easily envision Fred Wilpon in the lavish confines of his Citi Field box, munching on his Shake Shack burger and complaining to Jeffrey Toobin of The New Yorker about the performance of his marquee players in relation to their reputations and remuneration.

headline: Community Banks Lobby to Limit New Regulations
text: Network television ads appearing in the Washington area feature an anxious woman who cautions that “community banks and credit unions will be squeezed” by “bad” regulation.

text: LONDON — After he cleverly obtained a court ruling forbidding the news media from reporting on his possible affair with a “Big Brother” contestant, the Manchester United soccer player Ryan Giggs must have thought he had avoided a whole lot of trouble.

headline: Tests for Pupils, but the Grades Go to Teachers
text: New York City education officials are developing more than a dozen new standardized tests, but in a sign of the times, their main purpose will be to grade teachers, not the students who take them.

headline: Despair? None Bloomberg Seems to See
text: Poor Michael Bloomberg. He possesses the third term he so desired and yet he seems not to know what to do with it.

headline: An Outcry in Chelsea Over a 12-Story Shelter
text: At an art opening in Chelsea last week, Erick Magangi stood next to the oil painting that he considered his best work. “I was trying to do an examination of the real world and the exotic world,” Mr. Magangi said, gesturing toward the work, an abstract with softly blended horizontal panels of beige and gray.

headline: Joseph Brooks, a Maker of Jingles, Songs and Films, Dies at 73
text: Before his life had tumbled into scandal and ended over the weekend in suicide at the age of 73, Joseph Brooks had carved out a glittering, idiosyncratic career as author of some of advertising’s most famous jingles, as a maker of movies and musicals and as the composer of a huge hit, “You Light Up My Life.”

headline: Edward H. Harte, Texas Newspaper Executive, Dies at 88
text: Edward H. Harte, a prominent Texas newspaper executive and an ardent conservationist who played an important role in preserving vast tracts of open space and stretches of seashore in his state, died on May 18 at a retirement home in Scarborough, Me. He was 88 and also lived in Corpus Christi, Tex.

headline: Saudis Arrest Woman Leading Right-to-Drive Campaign
text: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The government of Saudi Arabia moved swiftly to extinguish a budding protest movement of women claiming the right to drive, a campaign inspired by uprisings across the Arab world demanding new freedoms but at risk Monday of foundering.

headline: Russia: Harsh Words for Georgia
text: The Foreign Ministry rebuked authorities in Georgia on Monday for violating their citizens’ “rights to the freedom of assembly and expression of opinions” because the police dispersed an opposition protest over the weekend. The statement left out any comparison to Russia’s own treatment of opposition protesters, who are routinely arrested, but did note the police action in Georgia could be interpreted as violating a European human rights convention.

headline: Philanthropy Given Focus by Brain Cancer
text: Theodore J. Forstmann is tired.

headline: What’s Up With the Jews?
text: It’s been an interesting week or two for Jews. Mel Gibson’s new film, “The Beaver,” opens nationwide in theaters and Jews must decide whether to pay good money to see a movie starring someone whose father is a Holocaust denier, and who has himself vilified Jews in public. In Cannes, the Danish movie director Lars von Trier rambles on at a press conference about sympathizing with Hitler, being annoyed with Israel and admiring Hitler’s architect, Albert Speer. Next day he recants, but it’s too late; he’s declared persona non grata at the film festival.

headline: Home for the N.F.L. Lockout
text: While locked out from the N.F.L., Indianapolis Colts' Taj Smith trained at his former high school in Newark and talked with kids about life beyond Newark's mean streets.

headline: In ‘Food Deserts,’ Oases of Nutrition
text: Poor urban neighborhoods in America are often food deserts — places where it is difficult to find fresh food.   There are few grocery stores; people may do all their shopping at bodegas, where the only available produce and meat are canned peaches and Spam.  If they want fruits and vegetables and chicken and fish, they have to take a bus to a grocery store.   The lack of fresh food creates a vicious cycle; children grow up never seeing it or acquiring a taste for it.  It is one reason that the poor are likelier to be obese than the rich.

headline: A Slice of Afghanistan Well Secured by Afghans
text: SHINKAY, Afghanistan — Zabul Province, one of Afghanistan’s poorest, is mainly known for being a transit route for Taliban insurgents and NATO supply convoys.

headline: Visions of the Past Propel a Man Forward
text: NEWARK — Bernadine Smith raised eight children here, five boys and three girls, 13 years separating the oldest from the youngest. Her boys were inseparable, and she tried to keep them together, keep them home, with board games and cooking lessons and movie nights. “If I could have kept my kids in a bubble,” she said, “I would have.”

Now Square is trying to make wallets obsolete, too, by upending the way that consumers pay for purchases.

headline: Steady Decline in Major Crime Baffles Experts
text: The number of violent crimes in the United States dropped significantly last year, to what appeared to be the lowest rate in nearly 40 years, a development that was considered puzzling partly because it ran counter to the prevailing expectation that crime would increase during a recession.

Keeping Score: Bautista’s Stats Approach Those of the Greats
text: The leap Jose Bautista took last year was impressive. After spending four years as a fringe part-time player, he hit 54 home runs and was rewarded with a five-year, $65 million contract. But what Bautista, the Toronto Blue Jays’ new star slugger, has done so far in 2011 defies comprehension.

headline: Russian Justice
text: By the time you read this column, you may already know the fate of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky and Platon L. Lebedev. Moscow, after all, is eight hours ahead of New York, and let’s be honest here: It’s not going to take the Moscow City Court very long to conclude that the two men deserve another seven years in prison — on top of the eight they’ve already served — on laughably trumped-up charges. Chances are, the three-judge panel knew going in how it planned to rule. That’s the way it works in Russia when somebody crosses the country’s ruling plutocrats. They get sent to Siberia on phony charges.

headline: Taking Minors Off the Streets
text: In Oakland, many children are from immigrant families, and a handful of organizations, started by Asian Health Services, have developed new programs that “take into account the complex culture of foreign-born parents and their American-born children.”

headline: NATO Bombs Tripoli in Heaviest Strikes Yet
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — In the heaviest attack yet on the capital since the start of the two-month-old NATO bombing campaign, alliance aircraft struck at least 15 targets in central Tripoli early Tuesday, with most of the airstrikes concentrated on an area around Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s command compound.

headline: California’s Prison Crisis
text: Three photographs are part of Justice Anthony Kennedy’s opinion in which the Supreme Court orders California to release more than 30,000 inmates from state prisons to reduce dangerous overcrowding. Looking at the photos, there should be no doubt that the conditions violate the Constitution’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: In Oakland, Redefining Sex Trade Workers as Abuse Victims
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Dr. Kimberly Chang, a physician at a community clinic in Chinatown, will never forget the first young girl she suspected had been sold for sex.

headline: Critics of the Mayor’s Budget Put Forth Their Own Ideas
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, facing a reduction in state and federal aid and a rise in city costs, has said that balancing New York’s budget will require shuttering 20 firehouses and laying off 4,100 teachers.

headline: Catholic School in Harlem Is Closing Over Financial Woes
text: Rice High School, a Roman Catholic boys’ school in Harlem known equally for serious academics and excellent basketball players, announced on Monday that it would shut down at the end of the school year, after 73 years, because of financial difficulties.

headline: Wheelchair Access in Taxis Is Focus of U.S. Investigation
text: The United States attorney’s office in Manhattan has opened an investigation into whether the lack of wheelchair-accessible taxicabs in New York City amounts to a violation of parts of the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline: In Testimony, an Officer Admits She Fixed Tickets
text: Details of a ticket-fixing scandal involving Bronx police officers were spelled out for a jury on Monday, though they were revealed as part of an old, unrelated drunken-driving case.

headline: Keep Chilean Patagonia Wild
text: An environmental review commission in the Aysén region of southern Chile has made a potentially disastrous decision, voting to approve the construction of five hydroelectric dams, two on the Baker River and three on the Pascua. The damage these dams would do to the environment is tremendous, and their construction — in a largely unspoiled natural haven — would open the way for further development, including more dams.

headline: Bulls Plot Ways To Turn Rose Loose
text: MIAMI — To free himself of the Miami Heat’s swarming defense, Derrick Rose wants to be less crowded by his Chicago Bulls teammates. After poring over game film, Rose is hoping for more isolation plays that offer Miami less chance to double-team him Tuesday in Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Nassau’s Extremely Cynical Makeover
text: Albany isn’t the only place where lawmakers are fighting to save a protected species, the ludicrous gerrymander. In Nassau County, the Republican Party has hacked away at the legislative map in a bid to keep its 11-to-8 majority by whatever squiggly lines necessary.

headline: Thomas’s Goaltending Is Key in Bruins’ Victory

In time, this can lead to its being given full status as a championship sport. Do you consider cheerleading a sport? Why or why not?

headline: In Transit to a Home That Isn’t There
text: Rootless. Stateless. Homeless. Millions of people worldwide are in transit, a condition that has nothing to do with the morning commute and everything to do with intolerable conditions that drove them from their own homes and into perennial limbo.

headline: Volcanic Ash Forces Flight Cancellations in Europe

headline: As Contested District Votes, a Candidate Can’t

headline: Prague Fringe Festival Celebrates 10 Years
text: Over the last decade, the Prague Fringe Festival has evolved into one of Central Europe’s hottest tickets. Offering a wide assortment of stage acts, from physical theater, comedy and cabaret to spoken word and puppetry, the festival takes over the city’s tony Little Quarter for a nine-day run, starting May 27. Celebrating its 10th anniversary, the Prague Fringe is one of the few annual city events dedicated solely to English-language performing arts.

headline: Celebrated Playwright Who Resists Celebrity
text: PARIS — Yasmina Reza is one of the world’s most successful playwrights, but she wears her fame with discomfort. She can talk at length about her red leather Prada coat. She can relate stories with biting humor about her year on the road shadowing Nicolas Sarkozy in his 2007 campaign for the French presidency. But ask her about herself, and the anxiety of the writerly persona takes over.

headline: After Missouri Tornado, Grim Search for Missing
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — The sun shone for the first time in days on this devastated city on Tuesday, illuminating the full extent of the damage as rescue workers performed the grim task of searching for survivors and victims in buildings leveled by the United States’ deadliest tornado since modern record-keeping began.

headline: Glencore Sinks Below Offering Price
text: LONDON — Not all initial public offerings are receiving the same warm reception as that of LinkedIn.

headline: Nestlé to Buy Diagnostics Firm
text: Nestlé said on Tuesday that it had agreed to purchase Prometheus Laboratories, an American company specializing in gastrointestinal and cancer diagnostics, for an undisclosed sum as the Swiss food giant moved further into health care.

headline: Reading ‘Lolita.’ Forgetting Tehran.
text: In the commodities exchange of American letters, Lila Azam Zanganeh is an easy buy: She’s got that appealing balance of Near Eastern extraction, European education and Yankee ambition. Born in Paris to Iranian exiles, she studied at the prestigious École Normale Supérieure before teaching literary seminars at Harvard. Now she lives in New York and is something of a fixture at book parties and publishing events. (She was just on the cover of Thursday Styles, giving Jon-Jon Goulian, another of the season’s publishing darlings, a protracted peck.) She speaks six languages, sings opera and is quite beautiful, although even her sultry glamour is tempered a bit by a childlike innocence.

headline: Paying More to Wait Longer for the Subway
text: Let’s dispense first with a few housekeeping details: The future Lady McCartney did her duty as a board member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority by attending committee hearings on Monday. Some had wondered if she would show up. She did.

headline: El Paso Corp. to Spin Off Unit
text: 10:10 a.m. | Updated The El Paso Corporation said on Tuesday that its board had approved a plan to spin off its exploration and production business to shareholders.

text: The Times's fitness guinea pig, Karen Barrow, tries a samurai sword workout.

headline: 2 People Are Hospitalized After ‘Explosion’ on ‘Hobbit’ Film
text: An explosion on the set of Peter Jackson‘s film version of “The Hobbit” is the latest bout of bad luck to befall the project, though a publicist for the movie said no one had been seriously injured in the incident.

headline: Burkle Raises Stake in Barnes & Noble as Liberty Circles
text: With Liberty Media making an offer that values Barnes & Noble at more than $1 billion, the billionaire investor Ronald Burkle appears to be betting that the nation’s biggest bookstore chain is worth even more.

headline: In Britain, Pomp for Obama but Serious Business Too
text: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II welcomed President Obama to Britain on Tuesday with pomp and ceremony, with the Scots Guards’ band playing “The Star-Spangled Banner” and the firing of a 41-gun cannon salute that resounded across the gardens of Buckingham Palace.

headline: Getting Together
text: Last week I wrote a column citing a gradual shift in the way we think about evolution—that it’s less strictly a competitive struggle for survival among the fittest and involves a lot more cooperation and altruism. A study by Kim R. Hill, Robert Walker and others in the journal Science plays into that.

headline: Everybody Plays
text: By the way, Daniel Klein conducted an experiment for a George Mason University working paper that illustrates our hunger for cooperation. He asked groups of people in a room to sing a song together. But one person in the room was instructed not to sing unless the other people paid him some money. The question was: Do people desire complete group cohesion so much they are willing to pay to avoid having an outlier/dissident in their group. The groups decided to pay money to achieve what Klein calls “encompassment” 47.4 percent of the time.

headline: Girls and Guys Who Wear Glasses…
text: Suppose you are walking into a waiting room and you see a bunch of strangers. How close are you going to sit to one of the strangers? Well, do you wear glasses?

headline: Tuesday Reading: Midlife Fitness Can Predict Long-Term Heart Health
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: The Ryan Budget Tipping Point
text: Perhaps this is obvious, but Republican strategy on Rep. Paul Ryan’s controversial budget plan represents a classic tipping point scenario — enough so that it could be a case study for Malcolm Gladwell’s next book.

headline: Man Is Charged With Abusing Dog in East Harlem Elevator
text: A 46-year-old man who swung a pit-bull puppy by its leash against an elevator wall and also kicked the animal was charged with aggravated animal cruelty on Monday, the police said.

headline: C.E.O. of the U.S.A.
text: The job of the president is technically that of the chief executive of the United States. But I’m still fascinated by the extent to which business acumen is being emphasized by the early presidential contenders.

headline: Explaining War to Our Children
text: Explaining war to kids is always hard, but when you’re part of a military family, the task is even more difficult because it’s so personal. When my sons were little, their father was in the Navy Reserve as an intelligence officer with the Seabees, the Navy’s construction division. The boys understood what the military was in a very hazy “It must involve a ship, Daddy going away, and a large yellow bee” kind of way. But because their father wasn’t directly in harm’s way, I was able to gloss over hard questions about war and just concentrate on the fun parts of having a dad in the military from a toddler’s perspective — serving the country and wearing really cool hats.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Withnail and I’
text: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Bruce Robinson’s 1987 British comedy “Withnail and I.” The film revolves around the relationship between its two central characters (Richard E. Grant and Paul McGann), two out of work actors who spend most of their time drinking, fighting and getting very little accomplished. Mr. Scott calls the movie “charming, hilarious and ultimately heartbreaking.” Have you seen “Withnail and I?” Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Michelle Obama Meets the New Duchess
text: From the sidelines, London fashion writers pondered whether the first lady, Michelle Obama, would favor a British designer during her and President Obama’s state visit. Meanwhile, an Irish journalist observed that “all the stylists in the world couldn’t save the incredibly chic Michelle Obama” from a battle of a bad hair day in windy Dublin, where Mrs. Obama wore a dotted Marc Jacobs dress and a lightweight coat. Even the length of her eyelashes was closely observed.

headline: Chiengora
text: Yarn weaved from dog hair.  (Chien [Dog] + Angora.)

headline: A 'Spiritual Connection' With Lady Day
text: A Harlem singer who takes the name Billie Holiday Jr. tries to summon the spirit of Lady Day in the hope of being "the child she always dreamed of."

headline: As Bank Woes Ease, the F.D.I.C.’s Fund Is Building Up
text: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Gold Getter
text: I am not quite sure what to make of this magazine cover. On one hand, it is gold on the cover of a mainstream magazine. But it’s less convincing as a magazine-cover contrary indicator. Compare it to the housing-peak covers in Fortune (May 2005) or Time (June 2005). The focus here is not on the investment aspect, but rather is a profile on a gold surveyor and on gold “as the world’s most primitive form of wealth.” Hardly the gushing endorsements we typically like to see as contrary indicators.

headline: Egypt Is Moving to Try Mubarak in Fatal Protests
text: CAIRO — Former President Hosni Mubarak will be put on trial for conspiring to kill unarmed protesters, Egypt’s top prosecutor announced Tuesday, yielding to public demands for accountability and setting an example that could rattle autocrats around the region.

headline: Top Down
text: David Leonhardt’s presentation of the Pew data on religious affiliation and income in the United States (“Is Your Religion Your Financial Destiny?”) neglects the way that religious groups are distributed geographically. The groups with the highest average household incomes tend disproportionately to live where costs of living and therefore salaries are highest.

headline: The Big Thaw
text: As the first-generation daughter of an Icelandic immigrant to the United States, I was never able to tap into the psyche of my father’s native land until I read Jake Halpern’s article. The dry humor, honesty and independent spirit of the Icelanders, born from living on a rock in the middle of the north seas, were captured brilliantly. Halpern helped me understand what seemed like cavalier financial behavior and heal my embarrassment over their decisions. Thank you for helping me understand my people.

headline: Riff
text: It’s a clever line by Sam Anderson — “if novels are mirrors held up to nature, memoirs are mirrors held up to mirrors.” But most fiction actually takes the form either of biography (third-person narrative) or autobiography (first person). The relationship between these sibling genres has been complicated and competitive for at least 200 years.

headline: Talk
text: In Andrew Goldman’s interview of Larry Summers, my colleague Joseph Stiglitz is cited for saying Summers ignores arguments that he doesn’t like. I have disagreed with Summers on several issues, but I have always found him ready to debate my views, even at Columbia, when, on the celebration of my 75th birthday, he took on me, Paul Krugman and others. He shies away from shoddy arguments that are simply populist, not from debating serious differences with critics his own size. By contrast, I have never succeeded in getting a debate, on or off campus, between Stiglitz and myself.

headline: Yandex Shares Soar 55% in Market Debut

headline: British Banks Paid Bonuses Using Government Aid
text: LONDON — Some bonuses to British bankers were partly paid using government aid supplied to the beleaguered industry, John Vickers, chairman of a government-backed banking commission, said on Tuesday.

headline: Tony-Nominated Plays Reap Box-Office Benefits, and ‘Spider-Man’ Returns With a Bang
text: Do Tony Award nominees for best play sell unusually well during the weeks between the nominations (this year, May 3) and the awards ceremony (June 12)? Not always. This time last year, for instance, two of the four best-play nominees (“In the Next Room, or the Vibrator Play” and “Time Stands Still”) had already closed, while “Next Fall” earned $150,982 and “Red” earned $463,639 for performances between May 17-23.

headline: Candidates in Western New York House Race Make Final Push
text: Voters in western New York State’s 26th Congressional district went to the polls on Tuesday in the full glare of the national political spotlight, while the leading candidates crisscrossed the Buffalo area making final appeals to voters.

headline: Company Believes 3 Reactors Melted Down in Japan
text: TOKYO — In a belated acknowledgment of the severity of Japan’s nuclear disaster, the Tokyo Electric Power Company said Tuesday that three of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi plant’s reactors most likely suffered fuel meltdowns in the early days of the crisis.

headline: Watchlist: A Self-Conscious Web Experiment From CBS News
text: The live Web show “What’s Trending” at cbsnews.com, an attempt to build a news-and-chat program driven by social networking — sort of a digital “Today” — is a self-consciously experimental project. That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: “We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. It’s what you need to know to be in the now.”

text: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruling ordered that financing to Abbott districts must be made. Issued May 5, 2011.

headline: Saudi Woman’s Driving Video Preserved Online
text: As my colleague Neil MacFarquhar reports from Saudi Arabia, the Saudi government has “moved swiftly to extinguish a budding protest movement of women claiming the right to drive,” in recent days.

headline: Court Orders New Jersey to Increase Aid to Schools
text: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that a major piece of Gov. Chris Christie’s cost-cutting was unconstitutional and ordered lawmakers to raise spending for poor, urban schools by $500 million next year, despite a state budget shortfall estimated at $10 billion.
