headline: A Murderous Malkovich in Lineup for BAM’s 2011 Next Wave Festival
text: John Malkovich‘s latest turn as a psychopath, new productions of “The Threepenny Opera” and “Krapp’s Last Tape,” a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergman’s “Cries and Whispers” and the last planned appearance by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are among the eclectic events planned for BAM’s 2011 Next Wave Festival, organizers announced on Tuesday. The series, during which BAM will begin a 16-month celebration of its 150th anniversary, starts on Sept. 21 with the New York premiere of “Awakening: A Musical Meditation on the Anniversary of 9/11,” a work that will be performed by the Kronos Quartet, featuring the Brooklyn Youth Chorus.

headline: Hawk Cam | Pip Goes for a Walk
text: Updated, 4:59 p.m. |  Pip the hawk hatchling reached another milestone this morning: Sometime shortly before 10 a.m., the little one hopped out of the nest — and out of the frame of the Hawk Cam. Suddenly the camera just showed Violet’s lower body and the two inert leftover eggs in the nest.

headline: Stuff We Like That Maybe You Won’t
text: This list of recommendations was generated with a twist. Staff members were asked to identify things that differentiated their taste from that of their friends and colleagues: What do we like that others in our lives either don’t like or don’t know about? What is idiosyncratically ours? Some, you’ll see, took this occasion to reveal their particular guilty pleasures. Others showed us a side of themselves we didn’t know existed — is there really among us someone who enjoys “Alf”? And who watches shark videos? While we figure out what to do with these outliers, read the list and please add your own off-kilter picks in the comments.

headline: Netanyahu Gives No Ground in Congress Speech
text: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, broadly laying out the Israeli response to President Obama’s peace proposals, called on the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Tuesday to accept what Mr. Netanyahu framed as a tenet: that Palestinians will not get a right of return to Israel. In so doing, he made clear that he was giving no ground on the major stumbling blocks to a peace agreement.

headline: Fill-In | Alligators Everywhere
text: Fill in the blanks in the paragraphs below taken from the article, “In Florida, the Natives Are Restless.” Use your own words and phrases, or choose from a scrambled list of the words or phrases that were removed.

headline: French Connection | HI Matic
text: Social media, eco-lodging and a D.I.Y. ethic intersect at HI Matic, a new B&B-hostel hybrid in the hip Paris neighborhood of EsBas (East Bastille). The hotel takes a plugged-in approach to hospitality, eschewing full-service concierge and staff for a digitally customizable experience. Not only can guests tailor nearly every detail of their stay on touch-screens throughout the building, but they can also share information with the room next door – or, if they want, with all 42 rooms at once. The organic breakfast is served through futuristic vending machines, which also offer books, aromatherapy diffusers and other goodies. Each visitor receives a personalized list of exhibitions and shows recommended by local experts, and two electronic music stations – one mellow, one groovier – are available on every floor, courtesy of the German record label Kompakt. Matali Crasset, a Philippe Starck protégée who has opened three other hotels with the HI group (two in Nice and one in Nefta, Tunisia), created Ryokan-inspired rooms with modular furniture and floor mattresses. She chose the area for its authenticity and charm. “There are lots of bars and it’s fun, but the neighborhood is not touristy,” she says. “It has kept its local flavor, with mom-and-pop shops and cafés.” Among her favorite spots is Septime (80 rue de Charonne), a new foodie hotspot directly across the street from the hotel where the star chef Bertrand Grébaut concocts simple but sophisticated dishes that le tout Paris is raving about.

headline: No. 1 Nadal, Stretched to Five Sets by Isner, Bends but Never Buckles
text: PARIS — Rafael Nadal has made a habit of making victory look easy at Roland Garros. He arrived this time as a five-time champion with a 38-1 record. And in all those wins since 2005, the Spaniard with the steely nerve and bending shots never needed a fifth and final set.

headline: China Admits Its Technicians Were Held in Pakistan Base Attack
text: BEIJING — A day after denying that any of its citizens had been involved, China confirmed Tuesday that Chinese technicians were taken hostage during a militant attack on a Pakistani naval base.

headline: Music Executive Giving $5 Million to N.Y.U. to Expand Music Business Program
text: The music executive Clive Davis is giving an additional $5 million gift to the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, allowing the expansion of the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music into the Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, school officials announced Tuesday. The gift will make it possible for the school to recruit additional working professionals as faculty members, establish a generous scholarship fund, facilitate the recruitment of young talent from around the world and increase the number of students, university officials said in a statement. Two new programs will be created to bring in talented high school students. Future Music Moguls will be a free program for students in the New York City area, and the Summer High School Programs in Recorded Music will be open to students everywhere.

headline: Calculating the Potential Return on Your Major
text: As the cost of college climbs ever higher each year, amid a national economic forecast that remains cloudy, questions about the value of a four-year degree are being raised with increased urgency.

headline: China’s Utilities Cut Energy Production, Defying Beijing
text: YIYANG, China — It is a power struggle that is causing a power shortage — one that has begun to slow China’s mighty economic growth engine.

headline: At MoMA, Volkswagen Formula XL1 Makes U.S. Debut
text: Martin Winterkorn, the Volkswagen Group chief executive, showed off the latest XL1 Formula prototype, as well as the actress Lucy Liu, on Monday night in Manhattan. Volkswagen claims that the 1.0-liter diesel hybrid can achieve 261 m.p.g.

headline: Nowitzki’s Grand Stand
text: For a Western Conference finals without the melodrama-a-minute Lakers and formerly age-defying Spurs, the Thunder and the Mavericks are filling in the dramatic narrative nicely. It was hard to ask for much more than Dallas erasing a 15-point deficit in the final five minutes in Monday night’s latest N.B.A. epic overtime victory. Yes, this is roughly the same cast of Dallas characters that made an art form of face-planting in the playoffs over the years and yes, the hero was the same Dirk Nowitzki who habitually seems to shrink about half a foot this time of year.

headline: Pink Pork Safe to Eat, Government Says
text: Pink is back. Reversing the food safety dictates of decades, the United States Department of Agriculture has announced it is no longer necessary to cook meat (except ground meat) to an internal temperature of 160 degrees. The new magic number for pork chops and other cuts is a much juicier 145 degrees, plus a three minute resting time. This allows the internal temperature to rise slightly, but also has the culinary benefit of thickening the juices so they don’t run out when the meat is cut.

headline: Subpoena Issued to Writer in C.I.A.-Iran Leak Case
text: WASHINGTON — With the approval of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., federal prosecutors are trying to force the author of a book on the C.I.A. to testify at a criminal trial about who leaked information to him about the agency’s effort to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program at the end of the Clinton administration.

headline: Finding the Nerve to Take an Advertising Risk
text: One of the hardest things to do in business is to take a risk with your advertising. I’ve made ad campaign presentations to fiercely competitive, Type A owners and here’s what happens:

headline: Cuomo Backs Assembly Plan to Cap Property Taxes
text: ALBANY — The odds of a mandatory ceiling on property-tax increases improved significantly after the Assembly unveiled legislation Tuesday morning that was endorsed in short order by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Medicare Is on Voters’ Minds in Congressional Election
text: The special election in western New York State’s 26th Congressional District has focused on Medicare for weeks now, and as voters emerged from polling places on Tuesday, it remained the dominant topic of conversation.

headline: Chandler’s Gold Cup Absence Raises Concerns
text: No one has sought Timmy Chandler’s long-form birth certificate (yet). Nürnberg’s swift young defender, the son of an American serviceman and a German woman, has spent his entire life and professional soccer career in Germany. In March, he pulled on the jersey of the United States national team for matches against Argentina and Paraguay. He was nothing short of impressive, the apparent heir apparent to right back Steve Cherundolo.

headline: What Would You Take With You in a Disaster?
Exit Daniels
text: The world may not have ended on Saturday, but for conservatives pinning their hopes for 2012 on a Mitch Daniels presidential campaign, the weekend felt a little bit like the opening of the sixth seal in the Book of Revelation. As with any apocalyptic development, commentary is a bit superfluous: 48 hours later, there’s not much to say about Daniels’ family-driven bow-out except that it’s a big disappointment to anyone who cares about American conservatism, and that what I said about the 2012 campaign in this column still applies:

headline: Subpoena of James Risen
text: Federal prosecutors are trying to force a New York Times reporter and author to testify at a criminal trial about who leaked information to him about a C.I.A. effort to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program at the end of the Clinton administration.

headline: Chrysler Pays Back Rescue Loan
text: DETROIT — Chrysler paid back on Tuesday $7.6 billion in loans from the American and Canadian governments, paving the way for its Italian partner, Fiat, to increase its control over the Detroit carmaker.

headline: New York City Ballet Announces 2011-12 Season
text: New York City Ballet’s spring season is in full swing but there’s already much to anticipate in the months to come. The world premiere of “Ocean’s Kingdom,” a collaboration between Paul McCartney and Peter Martins, is among the highlights of the company’s 2011-12 programming. The previously announced work, which will feature costumes by Stella McCartney, will be performed at the company’s gala on Sept. 22.

text: The main pilots’ union at Air France and relatives of the 228 people who died in the Atlantic crash of Air France Flight 447 two years ago strongly condemned reports Tuesday suggesting that crucial errors by the jet’s crew might have led to the disaster.

text: Three San Francisco entrepreneurs with backgrounds in automotive advertising want to help green technology ventures get off the ground.

headline: As Wealth and Literacy Rise in India, Report Says, So Do Sex-Selective Abortions
text: NEW DELHI — India’s increasing wealth and improving literacy are apparently contributing to a national crisis of “missing girls,” with the number of sex-selective abortions up sharply among more affluent, educated families during the past two decades, according to a new study.

headline: Share Your Oprah Memories

headline: U.S. Suit Sees Manipulation of Oil Trades
text: After oil prices surged past $100 a barrel in 2008, suspicions that traders had manipulated the market led to Congressional hearings and regulatory investigations. But they produced no solid cases in the record run-up in gasoline prices.

headline: Jack of All Trades | Organic by John Patrick
text: “I’ve been creating China ink paintings pretty steadily for the eight past years,” says John Patrick, the designer of Organic by John Patrick. But they were done only as gifts, not as a way of making money. All of that changed when Alicia Lubowski-Jahn of Fair Folks & a Goat, the artsy specialty store, contacted Patrick to sign him up for an art show to promote sustainable and socially responsible designs. There were two problems. Lubowski-Jahn, who organized the show, “Leaf // Cloud: Nature Tangible and Transcendent,” loves color, but Patrick’s paintings are black and white. Also, Patrick, who is an environmentalist, did not previously use organic paint.

headline: Dell Tries Again With a Thin Laptop
text: Dell’s mixed results selling consumer products has not stopped it from trying yet again.

headline: Fiano Enjoys a Renaissance
text: FOR one of the more dramatic examples of how the world of wine has changed in the last 25 years, consider the white wines of Italy.

headline: Off the Menu
text: HOSPODA  The dramatically decorated dining room, with soaring ceilings and backlighted images of beer, food and people engraved in dark wood, is the final element of a 10-year restoration of the historic Bohemian National Hall, owned by the Czech Republic. Oldrich Sahajdak, the executive chef, who also works at the parent company’s restaurants in Prague and elsewhere, has overseen a menu of lightened dishes rooted in tradition, like butter-poached Prague ham with horseradish foam, and flatiron steak with dill sauce and barley dumplings. To the concise menu of beer snacks and smallish plates, a tasting menu will be added this summer. Marek Sada is chef de cuisine. The beer is Pilsner Urquell but is dispensed in four styles led by draught master Lukas Svoboda: 321 East 73rd Street, (212) 861-1038.

headline: Avoiding Gluten? There’s a Whole Shop for You
text: Gluten-free products have come so far in the last few years that Lynn Shuter decided she could open a whole shop devoted to them. At G-Free NYC, she sells breads, granolas, cookies and cakes as well as more commonplace snacks that people who are gluten-intolerant can enjoy, like kale chips and popcorn. Fresh baked goods from a number of sources are set out on a display table, some offered for tasting. The shelves and freezers are filled with other foods, including biscotti, pastas and frozen pita breads and boxes of small pizza crusts. Many of the products are dairy-free and some are vegan.

headline: Sixpoint Brews Are Now in Cans
text: After six years of brewing ales in more than 200 styles for bars and restaurants to sell on draught, Sixpoint Craft Ales in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is selling beer in cans. Shane Welch, the founder and brewmaster, said aluminum cans keep beer fresher than bottles: they block out light and have no air space on top. They are also lighter to ship.

headline: Satisfy That Hankering for Mixed-Vegetable Ice Cream
text: Brian Smith, the owner of Ample Hills Creamery, right, a bright shop that just opened in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is scooping salted caramel, maple-bacon, chocolate stout with pretzels, all-natural bubble gum tinted with beet juice and 19 other flavors, including chocolate and vanilla. He custom blends his bases (some with eggs, some not), so by law he needs to pasteurize his mixtures of milk and cream from local dairies on site. Homemade cones, and cakes with ice cream and blondies or brownies are also on the menu.

headline: Is This Baby a Boy or Girl?
text: When we discussed the trend toward “gender neutral parenting” on Motherlode earlier this month,we used the term to mean things like not finding out the sex of the baby before birth, allowing children to choose clothes from either department at the store, and not limiting choice of play in any way.

headline: Woods Expects to Play U.S. Open
text: Tiger Woods said Tuesday that he spent the last week wearing a protective boot on his left leg to immobilize his sore left Achilles’ tendon, and hobbled around on crutches to protect the strained medial collateral ligament in his knee and prevent further pain to his sore back. He also said he expected to be ready for the United States Open from June 16-19 at Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md.

headline: Watchlist: A Second Look at ‘What’s Trending’
text: Earlier today, Mike Hale reviewed the premiere episode of “What’s Trending,” the new Web series from CBS News. He took in the second episode this afternoon:

headline: Turning to Labor Board, N.B.A. Union Fires First
text: The legal maneuvering in the N.B.A.’s labor battle began in earnest Tuesday, when the players union filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board, accusing league officials of failing to negotiate in good faith.

headline: Parenting, Tornadoes and Surgical Boots
text: I was on the “Today” show on Monday discussing my Sunday column about “legislating parenting.” It was an interesting day to be in the studio, with news from Joplin, Mo.,  breaking all around. The everyday struggles of parenting get put in their place when you know there are parents out there who have lost everything.

headline: A Rumor From the Roundabout
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There’s an old saying here that goes “awaza sar-e chowk,” a rumor from the roundabout. If a bit of news seems hard to believe, you might hear it. Kabul residents found themselves saying it plenty on Monday when Afghan media reported the news that Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban’s reclusive, one-eyed leader, was dead. The news sprang from the National Directorate of Security, the country’s main intelligence agency. Yes, it came from unnamed sources inside the agency, which publicly would say only that Mullah Omar was missing, but it carried enough currency that Western officials, though skeptical, would not come right out and say it was wrong.

headline: Exploring Megafauna Fossil Beds
text: Patrick Widmann measuring the knee joint of a fossil, and then exposing more of the bone; he appears to be quite surprised by what he uncovers.

headline: Warren and Republicans Spar Over Bureau’s Power
text: Republican lawmakers contend the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will be able to exert too much power over Wall Street.

headline: Ivan Vasiliev to Appear With American Ballet Theater
text: American Ballet Theater has announced a replacement for the injured principal dancer Herman Cornejo. Ivan Vasiliev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, will appear with Ballet Theater as a guest artist for three performances during the company’s spring season, said Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director. Mr. Vasiliev will replace Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew from scheduled performances in “The Bright Stream” for the June 11 matinee and the evening of June 14. He will also replace Mr. Cornejo in the leading role of Franz in “Coppélia” on June 16.

headline: On Coming Out: Exploring the Stories of Gay Teenagers
text: This month we’re experimenting with a new format in which we feature a multimedia project on NYTimes.com and provide questions and activity ideas for teaching and learning with it. Today, our third such experiment, uses an audio slide show feature. Please also check out the other two, on an interactive map and a photo slide show.

headline: An Italian Painting in Kentucky, Headed Home
text: Small museums don’t often find themselves at the center of international investigations, but last year the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., did, when agents from the Department of Homeland Security tracked an altarpiece stolen in Italy in 1971 to the Speed’s store rooms. The piece, a triptych featuring a Madonna and child that may date from as long ago as the 14th century, was stolen from a villa in Goito, southwest of Verona; two years later, the museum bought it from Newhouse Galleries in New York for $38,000. Under a settlement negotiated by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and announced on Monday, the Speed will soon turn over the work to Homeland Security, which will transfer it to Italian cultural authorities. (The collector who had owned it in 1971 has since died, and the authorities will be responsible for determining who is now entitled to the work.)

headline: With a Final Taping, a Daytime Talk Era Ends
text: Before a hand-picked audience of boisterous fans, Oprah Winfrey taped the final hour of “The Oprah Winfrey Show” in Chicago on Tuesday afternoon, effectively lowering the curtain on the nation’s most popular daytime talk program.

headline: President Obama in Britain
text: The president’s two-day state visit includes some ceremony, and some serious business.

headline: Rapping About Tamales and Deportation
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: What Microsoft’s ‘Mango’ Says About Its Phone Strategy
text: Microsoft showed off the next version of its smartphone operating system, code-named Mango, at an event in downtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning.

headline: 2010 Château Pavie, a St.-Émilion Wine, Gets a Good and a Bad Review
text: From a posting by Eric Asimov on Diner’s Journal at nytimes.com/dining.

headline: Grieving Razzano Plays, Fulfilling Fiancé’s Wish
text: PARIS — Virginie Razzano could have excused herself from this French Open: maintained her distance, kept her thoughts and her pain to herself. But that was not what her fiancé, Stephane Vidal, wished for her as they spent their final days together.

headline: Where Have All The Mensches Gone?
text: I asked this question five years ago, with regard to members of the Bush administration, who seemed pathologically incapable of taking responsibility for their actions. But it’s as relevant as ever. Newt Gingrich declaring that anyone who quoted him accurately was lying; and now Tim Pawlenty, who, aside from saying a whole lot of false things while declaring himself a truthteller, pulled a Gingrich when Rush Limabaugh correctly pointed out that he wasn’t a true Tea Partier a few years ago.

headline: Sears Holdings Changes Agency Roster
text: The Sears Holdings Corporation, which has been struggling to woo shoppers to its Sears and Kmart stores, is enlisting help in the form of two additional advertising agencies.

headline: Harrison Loses to Soderling, But Confidence Never Wavers
text: PARIS -– Ryan Harrison wants to be the next great American male tennis player, but he was stuck on the outside of the French Open for two days. The 19-year-old lost in the final of last week’s qualifying tournament. He punctuated his disappointment with a toss of his racket over a fence and into a tree.

headline: Britain’s Budget Gap Widens
text: LONDON — A pullback in pay in the financial sector and the end of a bonus tax led to a bigger budget shortfall in Britain in April, according to official data released Tuesday.

headline: Democrat Wins Western New York Congressional Race
text: 10:07 p.m. | Updated Democrats scored an upset in one of New York’s most conservative congressional districts on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the national Republican Party in a race that largely turned on the party’s plan to overhaul Medicare.

headline: What Are Your Thoughts on Tests to Grade Teachers?
text: Officials at the New York City Department of Education provided some more information on Tuesday about the potential cost of the up to 16 new tests they are developing to grade teachers.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Eating to Win

headline: Artifacts | Greenbacks at the Guggenheim
text: The next time someone tells you to show him the money, head straight for the Guggenheim Museum. There, in a second-floor gallery, $100,000 in used one-dollar bills is on plain (and magnificent) view.

headline: Spain’s Mediterranean Beaches Offer a Different Kind of Paradise
text: According to the Caribbean Resort Theory of Paradise, the perfect beach is an endless stretch of powdery white sand lined with coconut palms, staffed by mojito-toting waiters and lapped by turquoise water warm enough to feel like a big salty bathtub.

headline: TimesCast | May 24, 2011
text: The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, reiterates conditions for peace; a look back at his 1996 address to Congress; and West Bank settlers refuse to compromise for a Palestinian state.

headline: Graydon Carter: Children’s Book Author
text: Some editors just edit. Others own restaurants, produce movies, write books and paint.

headline: Citing Public Interest, Judge Rules for ‘Hangover II’
text: 6:00 p.m. | Updated

headline: Risk From Spent Nuclear Reactor Fuel Is Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says
text: WASHINGTON — The threat of a catastrophic release of radioactive materials from a spent fuel pool at Japan’s Fukushima Daiichi plant is dwarfed by the risk posed by such pools in the United States, which are typically filled with far more radioactive material, according to a study released on Tuesday by a nonprofit institute.

headline: Diageo Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy José Cuervo
text: Susana Gonzalez/Bloomberg NewsDiageo has its eye on the José Cuervo brand of tequila.

headline: El Bulli Is the Greatest Restaurant in the World
text: True story: The other night I was teleported to Ferran Adria’s El Bulli with my exceedingly close friend, the actress Reese Witherspoon. One minute Reese and I were walking along the beach in Malibu with my rescue-dog Chase, and the next we were nestled into a pillow-covered king-size bed in an apartment no one knows about on top of the restaurant’s dining room, where there are eunuchs who will fetch you anything you desire. (I desired a Mountain Dew. No problem!)

headline: Huguette Clark, Reclusive Heiress, Dies at 104
text: She was almost certainly the last link to New York’s Gilded Age, reared in Beaux-Arts splendor in a 121-room Fifth Avenue mansion awash in Rembrandt, Donatello, Rubens and Degas. Her father, a copper baron who once bought himself a United States Senate seat as casually as another man might buy a pair of shoes, had been born before the Mexican War. Her six siblings died long before her, one in the 19th century.

headline: Where Do You Fall on the Income Curve?
text: The Tax Policy Center has updated its figures on the income distribution in America, which we’d previously written about in a post about why most rich people don’t feel very rich. They have now crunched income levels for every single percentile, and the numbers refer to 2011 rather than 2010. So I’ve updated my chart on this subject.

headline: There are Americans in Paris, Still Playing, Too
text: PARIS — For the American contingent, it was sure to be a little different at the French Open without Andy Roddick, and Serena and Venus Williams, all not playing because of with injuries.

headline: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from England, Washington, Missouri and Afghanistan.

headline: Keeping Score: Wilpon’s Scapegoats vs. Steinbrenner’s
text: As once-heralded New York baseball trios go, Carlos Beltran, Jose Reyes and David Wright were not the first to invoke their owner’s ire for their team’s failures.

headline: Case of Romanian Realism: Regular Guy, With Wife and Girlfriend
text: Around 40, with a soft gut, rounded shoulders and graying hair, Paul (Mimi Branescu), the middle-class Romanian who appears in virtually every frame of Radu Muntean’s “Tuesday, After Christmas,” is probably 10 years past the peak of his handsomeness. But he still has some attractive qualities, among them a low-key sense of humor, a decent work ethic and an obliging, if sometimes brusque, demeanor.

headline: President Obama in Britain
text: The president’s two-day state visit includes some ceremony, and some serious business.

headline: An Iraqi Christian Stands Firm With His Muslim Neighbors
text: BAGHDAD — Over the past several months, Iraq’s dwindling Christian population has gotten even smaller.

headline: Can a Picasso Cure You?
text: The Russian-born artist Alexander Melamid is by nature an ironist, so adept at serving as his own straight man that it’s hard to tell how seriously he means to be taken. He may not know himself.

headline: Orlando Beats N.Y.C. to 50 Million Visitors, Officials Say
text: Just as the stage appeared set for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to take bows for the achievement of one of his more audacious goals, he was upstaged on Tuesday by the mayor of the city that Mickey Mouse built.

headline: Whitney Breaks Ground for New Building
Mike Mills on ‘Beginners’
text: The director Mike Mills is considered a jack-of-all-trades in the indie world (he’s directed music videos and designed album covers for bands like Sonic Youth, Air and the Beastie Boys). So it’s no surprise that his soon-to-be-released dramedy, “Beginners,” about a young man who learns that his father is gay and has terminal cancer, is more than just a film. “I seem to need to make a lot of stuff,” he jokingly says. Collateral material includes a book of sketches, aptly titled “Mike Mills: Drawings From the Film ‘Beginners,’ ” and some animated shorts to accompany them. T caught up with Mills to talk about “Beginners” and its never-ending possibilities.

headline: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from England, Missouri, Afghanistan and Yemen.

headline: Decorum Breaks Down at House Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — A House committee hearing on Tuesday about the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau disintegrated into heated accusations of lying, with the panel’s chairman accusing Elizabeth Warren of giving misleading testimony at a hearing in March and of making up facts about her agreement to testify this week.

headline: Barnes & Noble Caught in a Wall St. Whirlwind
text: Harry Campbell

headline: Celebrating Electronics And Energy
text: New music is hardly scarce during the main part of the New York concert season, and spaces like Issue Project Room, Galapagos and the Tank specialize in it year round. But spring and summer are a virtually nonstop parade of festivals celebrating the experimental. Recent weeks have featured the MATA, Look & Listen and Keys to the Future festivals in rapid succession, and on Monday evening the Tribeca New Music Festival opened its 10th season with a tightly packed program performed by Ethel, the string quartet, and devoted almost entirely to premieres.

headline: Holding Out Hope in Missouri
text: In Joplin, Mo., rescue workers searched for survivors and victims in buildings leveled by the United States’ deadliest tornado in more than 60 years.

headline: Visitors Lift Up Their Voices to Bach and More
text: Not every musician’s Carnegie Hall debut takes place during a concert produced by Carnegie Hall. The institution’s in-house artistic administration is responsible for only a fraction of the events that take place there, admittedly including most of its starriest affairs. Still, an artistically successful debut not produced by Carnegie is no less remarkable or noteworthy an achievement — a point made by the Ottawa Bach Choir at Weill Recital Hall on Monday night.

headline: Fashioning Artistry on Wheels
text: “ALWAYS crazy here,” Ernie Wong was saying. It’s not just the constant ring-ring of the land lines. There’s the smash-bash of stainless steel resisting ball-peen hammers. The wheeeen of the polishers smoothing steel burrs. The shoooosss of the welding sparks. Not to mention Mr. Wong’s mother, Sylvia, schmoozing on the cellphone in Shanghainese while his father, Jimmy, issues production orders in Mandarin.

headline: Recently Reviewed
text: CHEF’S TABLE AT BROOKLYN FARE

headline: Tom Colicchio to Open the Lot on Tap, and Curate High Line Food Trucks
text: It’s a pop-up plaza in a vacant parking lot. It’s a food truck food court. It’s an al fresco taproom. It’s an art installation. It’s a community event space. And oh, yes — it’s a destination for hordes of future visitors to the High Line whose strolls northward on the elevated public promenade would otherwise have deposited them pretty much nowhere.

headline: Another Spin of the Musical Wheel
text: Elvis Costello came on as all jovial show business — carny barker, M.C. and musical attraction — on Monday at the Beacon Theater. It was part of a three-night stand there for his Spectacular Spinning Songbook tour with his longtime band, the Imposters.

headline: A Graphic Memoir That Earns the Designation
text: Book titles are a touchy subject for writers. It’s not rare to hear an author complain in private about one of his or hers, and ache to reach back in time to swap it for something else. A different title for a fizzled book might have meant a different life for it.

headline: Holding Out Hope in Missouri
text: In Joplin, Mo., rescue workers searched for survivors and victims in buildings leveled by the United States’ deadliest tornado in more than 60 years.

headline: Wrestling With Health Insurance Costs
text: Starting Sept. 1, double-digit increases in health insurance premiums for individuals and small businesses will be subject to a review and possible rejection by state and federal officials. The change is part of the new Affordable Care Act, and is meant to make sure that premium increases are justified.

headline: Egypt’s Literary Revolutionary
text: As protesters filled Tahrir Square in Cairo this spring, one of them turned to Alaa Al Aswany and asked him to write a novel about the revolution. Moments later the protester was dead, killed by a sniper. This would be enough to throw any writer into the spotlight, except that Al Aswany didn’t need any help getting there. What made him a household name in Egypt was his first novel, “The Yacoubian Building.” It portrayed Egypt as a corrupt society, whose public mores were belied by private sins. Considered somewhat scandalous, it nonetheless became a bestseller in the Arab world and was even made into a feature film.

headline: Obama Campaign Cultivates Clinton Donors
text: President Obama’s campaign manager, Jim Messina, met privately on Monday night with donors close to his erstwhile rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, as the campaign sought to knit together and mobilize the Democratic fund-raising elite in advance of the 2012 election.

headline: Real Prize for ‘Idol’: Rebound in Ratings
text: As the highest-rated season of Fox’s “American Idol” in several years comes to a close this week, one thing is already certain: the competition’s winner will be a country music singer.

headline: G.O.P. Lawmakers Vote to Delay Derivatives Rules
text: A House panel approved a plan on Tuesday to delay several rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market, a leading player in the financial crisis.

headline: Ballet’s Home Away From Home for International Stars in New York
text: What does American Ballet Theater do better than other companies? Does it have the world’s best selection of male principal dancers? Does it have in Alexei Ratmansky the world’s best full-time ballet choreographer of the day? About these points we can argue. But when it comes to a choice of global guest stars, all dispute fades: Ballet Theater is in a class of its own.

headline: Over the Queensboro Bridge
text: Long Island City and Astoria have become magnets for chefs and restaurateurs in search of low rents, backyard space and food-aware customers.

headline: Over the Queensboro, to Nosh
text: ALEX SCHINDLER sports a beard and a tattoo, cooks with local ingredients and wears ironic 1970s T-shirts. And yet Mr. Schindler’s restaurant, LIC Market, is not to be found in the East Village or in the hip reaches of Brooklyn.

headline: World War II and Coconut Cream Pie
text: There’s enough corn to feed an army in “The Human Comedy,” a severely dated yet wonderfully staged musical by the Astoria Performing Arts Center. The production, with 25 actors and 6 musicians, is an ambitious undertaking, met with an impressive level of skill. But time has turned this overly sincere tale into a gob of sticky sweetness.

headline: On Frederick Seidel, Radiohead, the End of the World, Pink Floyd and Weeping Sugar
text: In researching my contribution to our list of Stuff We Like That Maybe You Won’t, I’d originally intended to recommend the poetry of Frederick Seidel, which I turn to habitually for a rush of dread and pleasure, until I realized it’s quite possible you will like it, or that you already do. Which is not to say Seidel is impossible to not-love: He has been called “crass, disturbing, a name-dropping, upmarket sinner”; he has also been called “America’s greatest living poet.” In fact, he was called both in the same article (specifically, the display text to the article), when Wyatt Mason profiled him for the Times magazine back in 2009.

headline: Ahmadinejad Backs Out of Key Role at OPEC
text: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will not preside over — or even attend — next month’s OPEC meeting in Vienna as previously planned, Iran’s Foreign Ministry said Tuesday. The change in plan, reported late Monday in Iran’s state-run press, appeared to signify a retreat by the president in his power struggle with the nation’s supreme leader.

headline: Cooking Temperature for Pork Is Lowered
text: THE other pink meat?

headline: TimesCast | Benjamin Netanyahu's Speech
text: May 24, 2011 - The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, reiterates conditions for peace, and a look back at his 1996 address to Congress.

headline: TimesCast | Settlers Stand Firm
text: May 24, 2011 - West Bank settlements are a hindrance to any peace deal based on Israel's pre-1967 borders as proposed by President Obama.

headline: Treasury Gets Small Profit From Sale of A.I.G. Stock
text: 9:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Return to 'The Normal Heart'
text: Joe Mantello talks about returning to the stage in Larry Kramer’s play.

headline: On Our Radar: Brazilian Forest Advocate and Wife Slain
text: José Cláudio Ribeiro da Silva, a Brazilian rain forest activist, and his wife are shot dead near their home in Para State, in the Amazon. In a speech last year, Mr. da Silva acknowledged that his work battling illegal loggers put him in grave danger. “I will protect the forest at all costs. That is why I could get a bullet in my head at any moment — because I denounce the loggers and charcoal producers,” he said. [The Guardian]

headline: Stage Scenes: Bobby Cannavale
text: Photos of some of the actor’s past performances in New York.

headline: Clijsters Is Back on Clay, Not Yet in Form
text: PARIS — It was hardly vintage Kim Clijsters on Tuesday, but then it is difficult to remember vintage Kim Clijsters at the French Open.

headline: New Restaurants in London
text: Sam Sifton takes measure of a few new restaurants from established names in the British dining scene.

headline: In London, Stalking the New
text: LONDON

headline: A Return to Acting That’s From the Heart
text: JOE MANTELLO was a 22-year-old actor, trained in the classics and fresh to New York, when he set out for the Public Theater one snowy night in 1985 to see “The Normal Heart,” Larry Kramer’s play about the first years of AIDS. Watching the protagonist Ned Weeks — a blunt, opinionated gay man not unlike himself — Mr. Mantello understood his need to take action in the face of death and denial, he recalled recently. If others found “The Normal Heart” a statistics-laden screed, Mr. Mantello felt a visceral recognition that Molière and Sophocles had never triggered.

headline: Yankees Shut Down Soriano
text: In the latest of a series of disappointments in his first season with the Yankees, Rafael Soriano has been shut down after a throwing session in which he felt soreness in his arm.

headline: N.F.L. Will Fine Teams Whose Players Are Punished Repeatedly for Improper Hits
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The N.F.L. will begin fining teams if their players are repeatedly disciplined by the league for improper hits.

headline: Top Colleges, Largely for the Elite
text: The last four presidents of the United States each attended a highly selective college. All nine Supreme Court justices did, too, as did the chief executives of General Electric (Dartmouth), Goldman Sachs (Harvard), Wal-Mart (Georgia Tech), Exxon Mobil (Texas) and Google (Michigan).

headline: Behind the Rise in Pell Grants
text: My column this week looks at Amherst College’s impressive recent track record of recruiting low- and middle-income students. Amherst now has a much higher share of Pell Grant recipients — who tend to come from the lower-half of the income distribution — than most other elite colleges.

headline: Mrs. Obama’s American-British Day
text: Michelle Obama seems to be pleasing both sides of the Atlantic with her fashion choices during the state visit to England. She arrived in the country on Tuesday morning dressed in a royal blue outfit by Preen, a British label. Later, at Buckingham Palace, she wore a dress by the American Barbara Tfank. She then changed into a purple dress by the London designer Roksanda Ilincic for a visit to 10 Downing Street. For a white-tie dinner at the palace on Tuesday night, the first lady chose a ruched ivory georgette gown by Tom Ford, an American who has his design offices in London, where he lives part of the year. The Ford number looks super on her — flattering neckline, perfect fit, just right for all the pomp.

headline: Gates Sees Iran as a Consideration for U.S. Troops in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Tuesday that if some American troops remained in Iraq beyond the scheduled withdrawal of all United States forces by the end of the year, it would be reassuring to Persian Gulf countries, but not to Iran. “And that’s a good thing,” Mr. Gates said.

headline: Wilpon Says He Is Sorry for Remarks
text: CHICAGO — With his public-relations campaign backfiring, Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner, apologized to Jose Reyes and Carlos Beltran via speaker phone in a cramped office in the clubhouse at Wrigley Field on Tuesday.

headline: Syrian Beaten on Camera Appears on State Television
text: Among the hundreds of video clips posted online by Syrian activists in recent weeks, documenting protests and a brutal security crackdown, few are as arresting as this 75 seconds, apparently filmed last month in the village of Bayda, while members of the security forces hit and kicked a group of prisoners forced to lie face down on the pavement:

headline: Hoax Site Distressing for Victims of Shooting
text: TUCSON — Television images of the chaotic scene after the Jan. 8 shootings here do not convince them. Neither do the funerals for the deceased, the scars of the wounded or the federal prosecution of the man accused of being the gunman.

headline: A God Is Dead, but It’s Business That May Suffer Most
text: PUTTAPARTHI, India — His face adorns the yellow motorized rickshaws zipping down the streets. Billboards bear his simple motto, “Love All, Serve All.” His portrait hangs in almost every shop: a tiny man with a gravity-defying crown of curly hair regarded by millions of worldwide devotees as a god.

headline: Joe Steffy, Blocker for Stars at West Point, Dies at 85
text: Joe Steffy, a star guard who opened the way for the Heisman Trophy winners Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis to burst through opposing lines for Army’s undefeated national football champions of the mid-1940s, died Saturday in Newburgh, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: Refighting the Auto Industry Bailout Battle
Deal Reached in Albany to Cap Property Taxes
text: ALBANY — Pledging to provide relief to highly taxed suburban homeowners, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said Tuesday that they had agreed to place a 2 percent limit on property tax increases in a plan that rivals the toughest such measures in the nation.

headline: Pakistan: Chinese Held in Attack
text: A day after denying that any of its citizens had been involved, China confirmed Tuesday that Chinese technicians were taken hostage during a militant attack on a Pakistani naval base. China has been walking a careful line with Pakistan. It does not want to antagonize India, but it is eager to present itself to Pakistan as a more reliable ally than the United States.

headline: Economic Aid to Egypt and Tunisia
text: The World Bank said Tuesday that it was willing to provide up to $6 billion to support political and economic change in Egypt and Tunisia to help them weather declines in tourism and other economic activity. The money is intended to seed a broader package of international support and allow Egyptians and Tunisians to “seize the opportunities of historic change to modernize their economies and build more open and inclusive societies,” said Robert B. Zoellick, the World Bank president. Both Egypt and Tunisia have been under economic strain since the revolutions in those countries, but the bank said political reforms often produce rebounds in economic activity. Egypt and Tunisia will seek additional help this week from the Group of 8 nations.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Ending Farm Subsidies
text: To the Editor:

headline: Punishing a Yale Fraternity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Venezuela: Oil Company Sanctions
text: The United States imposed sanctions on Venezuela’s national oil company, Petróleos de Venezuela, for its deliveries of two shipments of fuel valued at $50 million to Iran. The sanctions do not directly affect the operations of Citgo, the company’s American subsidiary, or prohibit Venezuelan oil exports to the United States. But they prevent Petróleos de Venezuela from competing for United States government contracts, obtaining export licenses or receiving financing from the Export-Import Bank. The State Department also imposed sanctions on six smaller oil and shipping companies, based in the United Arab Emirates, Singapore, Israel, Britain and Monaco, for dealings with Iran.

headline: After a Silent Spring, NASA Gives Up on Spirit
text: The Spirit is dead.

headline: The Case for Gossip
text: To the Editor:

headline: Adult Attention Disorder
text: To the Editor:

headline: S.E.C. Leased Unneeded Space, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission leased $556 million worth of office space last year based on a “deeply flawed and unsound analysis” of its needs, without competitive bids and using backdated approval forms to justify its rushed attempt to rent the offices, according a report by the agency’s inspector general released Tuesday.

headline: During the Postseason, Wade Burns the Midnight Oil
text: MIAMI — Dwyane Wade is not necessarily struggling offensively in the Eastern Conference finals, but he has been sneaking out of the house and going to the gym to hoist shots — not out of frustration, but to build confidence.

headline: Drugs and Profits
text: Fredericksburg, Va.

headline: Demand for Office Condos Grows in Manhattan
text: When the Progressive Credit Union began negotiations to renew the lease for its 9,800-square-foot office near Penn Station in Manhattan, the landlord offered terms that would have more than doubled the rent, to $40 per square foot.

headline: Execution Is Sought for Mobster in Death Plot
text: As the death penalty phase began on Tuesday in the trial of a convicted murderer and former mob boss, even the prosecutor acknowledged that capital punishment was not appropriate in most cases.

headline: Cartwright Out of Contention to Lead Joint Chiefs
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. James E. Cartwright, long considered the leading candidate to be the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is out of the running for the military’s top job, government officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Infusion From China for Toledo, Ohio
text: TOLEDO, Ohio — Before it became known as the Marina District, the 128 acres of tall grass and dirt piles on the Maumee River here was home to one of the city’s most prominent eyesores, the Acme coal-fired power plant, which was decommissioned in 1994.

headline: Revolutionary Cuba Now Lays Sand Traps for the Bourgeoisie
text: MEXICO CITY — One of Fidel Castro’s first acts upon taking power was to get rid of Cuba’s golf courses, seeking to stamp out a sport he and other socialist revolutionaries saw as the epitome of bourgeois excess.

headline: Hapless but Not Hopeless, Blue Jays’ Reyes Carries On
text: Jo-Jo Reyes did everything he could. For seven innings last Sunday in Toronto, he shut out the Houston Astros and gave a 2-0 lead to the Blue Jays’ bullpen. At that point, the outcome was out of his control, and he could live with the result: a blown lead and another winless day.

headline: Taking in Some London Sights, the Obamas Display Skill at Official Travel
text: LONDON — They were shown around their rooms at Buckingham Palace by their hostess, Queen Elizabeth herself. They got to meet and have an actual conversation with one of the few couples in the world even more famous than they are: Prince William and his wife, the Duchess of Cambridge (formerly known as Kate Middleton).

headline: Chernobyl Behind Him, Student Takes on Cancer
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Yan Leyfman was born in Belarus in 1989, three years after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. His family lived only about 75 miles from the nuclear plant, and as a toddler, Mr. Leyfman had a constellation of mysterious symptoms: cysts that covered his entire body, fingernails that fell out, limbs that were swollen and skin that itched torturously.

headline: Consider Profits When Judging Initial Offerings
text: The big first-day stock market pops by Yandex, the Russian Internet search company, and LinkedIn, the online business network, show how hungry investors are for technology-related growth possibilities. That’s good news for other businesses that hope to go public. But judging them by revenue potential is risky. Profits are what matter.

headline: Hopes Rise in South as Waters Do Not

headline: Army Seeks Recruits in Social Media

At your place.” These days, the Army is getting social — if not quite that sociable — as potential recruits increasingly spend time with social media like Facebook, Flickr, Twitter and YouTube.

headline: A Legacy for a Son Whose Character, After 9/11, Was Misjudged
text: If memory serves, the police captain met me over coffee on a Wednesday night in October 2001, when the world was dizzy with menace. He passed along word of a fresh worry. A young Muslim chemist, who worked in an advanced biochemistry laboratory in Midtown, had vanished on the morning of Sept. 11. Because he had once been a member of a police cadet program, he had an ID card that gave him access to police facilities. His name was Mohammad Salman Hamdani, and the captain had just been faxed a flier about him.

headline: The G-8’s Self-Serving Math

But the word on the street is that when leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized countries meet in France this week, they will claim that wealthy countries have come close to fulfilling their 2005 promise to boost annual development aid by $50 billion by 2010. They are not even in the ballpark.

headline: A Memory Tonic for the Aging Brain

headline: After a Silent Spring, NASA Gives Up on Spirit
text: NASA said on Tuesday that it was abandoning efforts to get back in touch with the Spirit, one of the two rovers on Mars. The Spirit got stuck in a sand trap two years ago and then fell silent last year as winter arrived and its solar panels could no longer generate enough electricity. Engineers had hoped it would revive in the spring, but they never heard from it again. Its twin, Opportunity, continues to operate on the other side of the planet.

headline: Obama Will Visit Puerto Rico
text: President Obama will visit Puerto Rico on June 14, the first official visit by a sitting president since John F. Kennedy stopped there, in 1961. “Since the beginning of my administration, we have been working in close collaboration with the president and his administration to make this historic visit a reality,” Gov. Luis Fortuno, of Puerto Rico, a Republican, said in announcing the trip. President Gerald R. Ford visited in 1976, but he was there as a member of the Group of Seven economic summit, not on an official presidential visit.

headline: California: San Jose Moves to Cut Budget Gap
text: San Jose approved plans on Tuesday to work on measures that could cut city contributions to retirement plans for current employees, raise retirement ages and tighten eligibility for retirees’ health care. Mayor Chuck Reed, a Democrat, said the measures were necessary to confront a $115 million budget gap. The city eliminated 800 jobs last year and is facing “a fiscal disaster,” Mr. Reed said.

headline: Could Conjoined Twins Share a Mind?
text: It was bedtime for Krista and Tatiana Hogan, and the 4-year-old twin girls were doing what 4-year-olds everywhere do at bedtime. They were stalling, angling for more time awake. Their grandmother, Louise McKay, who lives with the girls and their parents in Vernon, a small city in British Columbia, was speaking to them in soothing tones, but the girls resorted to sleep-deferring classics of the toddler repertory. “I want one more hug!” Krista said to their grandmother, and then a few minutes later, they both called out to her, in unison, “I miss you!”

headline: Aw, Shucks | Elliott’s Oyster House

Elliott’s considers the oyster to be emblematic of the Pacific Northwest’s thriving farm-to-table — or, in this case, beach-to-bar — dining scene. Elliott’s has an expansive raw bar and many direct relationships with Northwestern oyster growers. As Spaulding puts it, shucking knife in hand and flanked by a seemingly endless battalion of shells on ice, “It’s part of that movement to get out there and create something yourself.”

text: Lisa J. Lucero, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, recently completed an expedition to central Belize to study ancient Maya underwater offerings.

headline: Who Made That Purple Heart?
text: In 1782, George Washington created the Badge of Military Merit to honor any enlisted American for, in Washington’s words, “any singularly meritorious action … not only instances of unusual gallantry, but also of extraordinary fidelity and essential service in any way.” Washington described the form of the honor as “the figure of a heart in purple cloth or silk, edged with narrow lace or binding.” Only a handful of people have been known to receive that high standing, all of which were awarded in 1783.

headline: Washington National Opera Names Glimmerglass Chief as Artistic Adviser
text: Francesca Zambello, a busy director of opera and theater and the artistic and executive director of the Glimmerglass Festival, has been appointed artistic adviser of the Washington National Opera – heralding a possible link between the institutions, officials said on Wednesday. The appointment is part of the Washington company’s reorganization as it merges with the Kennedy Center, which was a response to the Washington opera’s financial troubles. Plácido Domingo, the company’s general manager, is departing next month. Washington National Opera also announced that its chief operating officer, Michael L. Mael, had been named executive director.

headline: ‘Jerusalem’ Gets Four-Week Extension on Broadway
text: Mark Rylance had better have a healthy appetite for the concoction of milk and a raw egg that he consumes at the opening of “Jerusalem” eight shows a week, because he’s going to be swigging it down for an additional month: that Jez Butterworth play, in which Mr. Rylance stars as the manly, mangy, quasi-magical trailer denizen Johnny “Rooster” Byron, will extend its run at Broadway’s Music Box Theater by four weeks, press representatives for the production said on Wednesday. Its limited run will now end on Aug. 21, having previously been scheduled to conclude on July 24.

headline: U.N. Warns of Ethnic Cleansing in Sudan Town
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — After seizing a disputed town on the border of the breakaway region of southern Sudan on Saturday, the army of northern Sudan is now facilitating a relatively large influx of nomadic people into the area, according to new United Nations field reports.

headline: Sketching a Panda’s World
text: A look at some of the production designs for “Kung Fu Panda 2.”

headline: On the Up | GoDown Arts Centre
text: “Watch me, watch me,” says a young boy in a bright yellow T-shirt, as he juggles a set of large clubs with his small hands. He hasn’t quite gotten the moves down, but his clumsy performance is eclipsed by his giant smile. Across the lofty room, a group of young men practice balancing on two piles of rough-edged bricks — on two hands, on one hand, legs moving in all directions.

headline: Hawk Cam | The Story of Violet’s Leg Band
text: Updated, 3:41 p.m. | Bits and pieces of this story have been bouncing around the Web and the airwaves for a while now, but not yet formally reported in this space, so here goes:

headline: PeopleClaim: Taking Complaints Public Via the Web
text: Consumers are increasingly using the Web to take their gripes to the court of public opinion. A site called PeopleClaim aspires to go beyond mere venting, to assist customers in filing a complaint with the service provider in question.

headline: Favorites Have Little Trouble at French Open
text: PARIS — The French Open opened Wednesday without a cloud in the sky, and the tournament favorites in action have found clear sailing heading toward the evening.

headline: Criticism of State-Owned Air India Grows
text: NEW DELHI — When Bob Haygooni paid a midflight visit to a cockpit at his new employer, Air India, he was shocked. The pilots, he said, had completely covered the windows with newspaper to keep out the sun.

headline: Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo.
text: As Steven Pinker points out, the above is a grammatical sentence. You have to posit that there’s a kind of buffalo called a Buffalo buffalo; what the sentence then asserts is that beast of this kind, if buffaloed – that is, intimidated – by fellow members of their species, go on to do the same to other co-speciesists. Buffalo buffalo that are buffaloed by Buffalo buffalo go on to buffalo Buffalo buffalo themselves.

headline: The Best Treatment for Sinus Complaints
text: What’s the best treatment for sinus troubles that won’t go away? Ingfei Chen, health reporter, interviews Dr. Noam A. Cohen and Dr. James N. Palmer of the Rhinology Research Laboratory at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, who are exploring the role of communities of bacteria called biofilms in chronic sinusitis.

headline: Grading on a Partisan Curve
text: The divide between liberals and conservatives applies to more than just attitudes about the role of government. It appears to make a difference in university grading, too.

headline: Third Depression Watch
text: Last year I warned that we seemed to be heading into the “Third Depression” — by which I meant a prolonged period of economic weakness:

headline: Live Blogging the Ira Sohn Conference
text: Investment professionals gathered in New York today for the annual Ira Sohn Conference, a sold-out show where prominent hedge fund managers and the like showcase their best ideas.

headline: Take the Photo, Then You Can See
text: Severin Koller, 25, was born in Vienna, attended the Academy of Fine Arts Vienna and lives in the city now. He has worked for magazines and advertising agencies, shooting only black-and-white film. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald, for the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

headline: Joyce Meets Twitter: Boiling Down ‘Ulysses’
text: “Stately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of lather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed.” Seventeen characters left to complete a tweet. It just might work. What would James Joyce think of Twitter? More important, what would his handle be? It’s impossible not to imagine the inherent fun the great English-language experimentalist would find in translating his voluminous ideas onto the 140-character template, or at least the irresistible challenge.

headline: In Helsinki, an Attic Apartment With a Sea View
text: A two-bedroom attic apartment in the historic Katajanokka neighborhood of Helsinki is on the market at $1.6 million.

headline: Aerial Photographs of Joplin Before and After the Tornado
text: Aerial photographs of the area devastated by a tornado in Joplin, Mo.

headline: Hello Kitty Theme Park Planned in China
text: Hello Kitty plans to expand into China with a theme park.

headline: Pier 88, 10:22 A.M.
text: The Iwo Jima has landed. Fleet Week has begun.

headline: A Paint Job That Would Have Impressed the Man in Black
text: On Tuesday, Jalopnik featured the story of Aleksey Korzun, a 24-year-old software engineer from Brooklyn who prepped, primed and painted his BMW 5 Series in the most unlikely of places: the living room of his 579-square-foot Bay Ridge apartment. As Mike Spinelli explains, the project required more than a little ingenuity:

headline: Tahrir Square: Is It Good for the Christians?
text: After the flags were packed away, the euphoria faded and protesters swept all of the dropped signs and cigarette butts out of Tahrir Square, politicians around the world started to ask “what if?” What if the Muslim Brotherhood gains power? What if they stifle freedoms in Egypt or threaten peace with Israel? President Obama recently announced $1 billion of debt relief and $1 billion in loans for Egypt. But as David E. Sanger reported this weekend, one of Obama’s strategists said, “We think there’s a ‘Muslim Brotherhood exception’ to the aid package.”

headline: The Mets’ Bobblehead Curse Lives
text: In the latest issue of New Yorker magazine, Fred Wilpon said that the Mets were “snakebitten” because of the rash of player injuries, last-season meltdowns and financial calamities to befall the club the last few seasons.

headline: Psychic Apparently Fails to Predict Officers’ Approach
text: Sylvia Mitchell’s next available palm reading will apparently take place in a jail cell, as her own future involves a stack of police complaints that is approaching the size of a tarot deck.

headline: New Mileage Stickers Include Greenhouse Gas Data
text: WASHINGTON — The federal government unveiled new fuel economy window stickers on Wednesday, for vehicles starting with the 2013 model year, that for the first time include estimated annual fuel costs and the vehicle’s overall environmental impact.

headline: Bill Clinton: We’ve Got to Deal with Medicare
text: Former President Bill Clinton, still widely considered one of his party’s foremost politicians, said on Wednesday that Democrats should cut a “reasonable” deal with Republicans on Medicare savings rather than conclude from Tuesday’s upset in a special Congressional election that bashing Republicans on the issue is the key to a party comeback in 2012.

headline: Vain Glorious | Manstudio, South Korea’s First Apothecary for Men
text: Who: AmorePacific, one of South Korea’s oldest beauty brands.

headline: Spamalytics
text: Term used by a team of computer scientists investigating spam emails.(Spam + analytics.)

headline: Creating Kegasus
text: The Paulick Report talked with Jimmy Learned, the founder and president of the advertising agency Elevation Ltd., which created the “Get Your Preak On” and “Kegasus” campaigns for the Preakness in 2010 and 2011:

headline: American Hero in Canada
text: There are a variety of possible reactions to the Miami Heat appearing poised to crash the N.B.A. finals after Tuesday night’s victory over the Chicago Bulls: joy, grudging acceptance, pure unadulterated misery (headquarters: Cleveland) and just plain fatigue. Yes, the Big Three, above all its other attributes, is overexposed, every sigh and hangnail analyzed for social and political implications. We’ll get to today’s overexposure, but first, perhaps, a bit of an antidote.

headline: ‘Bikini-Ready’? Who’s Judging?
text: EVERY spring, as sure as cherry blossoms bloom, so does the notion that women should diet, exercise and even liposuction their way to bikini-ready bodies. Magazines like Shape and Self reinforce the idea that preparation is essential, with months-long bikini body countdowns (100-calorie snack tips included) and workout DVDs like “Bikini Ready Fast!” as if the beach reveal were a test on par with the MCAT and only a slacker would settle for a one-piece.

headline: Panda vs. Peacock: The Showdown
text: HOW hard is it to maintain a life of awesomeness? It’s not as simple as one particular panda skilled in the martial arts would like. In “Kung Fu Panda 2,” the follow-up to Dreamworks Animation’s 2008 hit, Jack Black returns as the voice of Po, the clownish panda with a laid-back vibe who becomes the Dragon Warrior, keeping order in the Valley of Peace with help from his fellow kung fu masters, the Furious Five. But when a villainous peacock, Lord Shen (Gary Oldman), emerges with a weapon that will aid him in taking over not just the valley but all of China and put an end to kung fu, Po and the Furious Five must figure out a way to defeat this dangerous fowl.

headline: House Hunting in ... Finland
text: TWO-BEDROOM CO-OP WITH A SEA VIEW IN HELSINKI

headline: Israelis See Netanyahu Trip as Diplomatic Failure
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel returned from Washington on Wednesday to a nearly unanimous assessment among Israelis that despite his forceful defense of Israel’s security interests, hopes were dashed that his visit might advance peace negotiations with the Palestinians.

headline: Fossil Extends Life Span of a Marine Predator
text: The largest animal species of the Cambrian period, a marine predator with a segmented body and a pair of grasping appendages, lived much longer than previously thought and grew to sizes much larger than previously known.

headline: A New York Debut for Textile Recycling
text: No more hauling your hand-me-downs in plastic bags and shopping carts to your nearest green market or thrift shop, New Yorkers. City officials say they have partnered with Housing Works, a group that helps homeless people infected with the H.I.V. virus, to pick up donated clothing at apartment buildings in one of the first large-scale consumer textile recycling programs in the Country.

headline: Obama’s Reference to Kenyan Roots Draws Applause in Britain
text: Unlike the American Congress, which interrupted the Israeli prime minister’s speech with 29 standing ovations on Tuesday, the British Parliament forced America’s president to stop for applause just once during his address in London on Wednesday.

headline: Battle Over Lagoon Cleanup Divides a Surfing Haven
text: MALIBU, Calif. — It was a cool weekday afternoon, but dozens of surfers were bobbing in the water, waiting for a wave. This was Malibu: the national symbol of surfing, adored by California wave riders for 50 years, near the famous stretch of coast where Annette Funicello and Frankie Avalon partied on the beach.

headline: Thomaz Bellucci’s Improving Game
text: Thomaz Bellucci advanced to the third round with a convincing straight-sets win over Andreas Seppi. Bellucci was never broken, and kept Seppi off balance by varying his lefty serve like a pitcher with masterly control. Of the 67 points Bellucci served, Seppi managed to win only 13 points, and only 5 points on Bellucci’s first serve.

headline: Don’t Stop, Stevie Fans
text: A Night of 1,000 Stevies in New York City.

headline: A Former Geek Offers Hope
text: A FEW years ago I wrote an article about Rosie O’Donnell that made her mad. She told a gossip columnist I must have been “that nerdy Jewish kid in high school who ran the A.V. club.” The columnist called me for a reaction, and I had to correct Ms. O’Donnell. Actually, I was the president of the Herpetology Society.

headline: The Crossover on Display
text: The crossover is one of the most lethal offensive moves in the N.B.A. Miami’s Dwyane Wade found inspiration for his version from players like Allen Iverson and Tim Hardaway.

headline: Miami’s Fluid Rotation Pays Off
text: For a night, Mike Miller was a star. He converted from inside and out, initiated the fast break and racked up rebounds in Game 4. His influence on the court was just as significant as that of any player on the floor; despite sharing the court with the likes of LeBron James, Derrick Rose and Dwyane Wade, Miller posted the game’s highest plus-minus rating (plus-36), a testament to his impact. He did the little things and hit the big shots, and in a game with a razor-thin margin for error, it’s not hyperbolic to say that Miller’s 12 points and team-high nine rebounds made all the difference.

headline: Detroit Symphony Orchestra Concertmaster Is Leaving
text: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, struggling to find its feet after a bitter six-month strike, has suffered another loss. Its concertmaster of 23 years, Emmanuelle Boisvert, is moving to the Dallas Symphony Orchestra as an associate concertmaster. The announcement, which came on Wednesday, was made not by the Detroit Symphony but by a committee of orchestra members that was set up during the strike and sponsored their own concerts. The orchestra’s spokeswoman, Elizabeth Weigandt, confirmed the move and said Ms. Boisvert had told the players but not yet formally informed orchestra management. “Management has the news release, and that’s what we’ve got,” she said.

headline: Rafalski Retires, Pain Trumping Money
text: In the end, Red Wings defenseman Brian Rafalski couldn’t deny the painful truth his body had been telling him all season.

headline: Rolls-Royce Photographer Channels Ecstasy, but Not in Manhattan
text: At the Milk Gallery in Manhattan’s meatpacking district on Tuesday night, hundreds of guests wandered among the photographs of a new show by Rankin, the British photographer of fashion, celebrities and titillating nudes.

headline: East 79th Street, 10:26 A.M.
text: City Councilwoman Melissa Mark-Viverito, left, joined protesters against the city’s marijuana arrest policies at demonstration half a block from the mayor’s house. More people were arrested in New York City on marijuana possession charges last year than in the entire period from 1978 to 1996. The arrests cost $75 million and disproportionately involve blacks and Hispanics, advocates say.

headline: Survival Strategies for Orchestras
text: FROM the recent string of crises at symphony orchestras you might conclude that orchestral business models are as outdated as the musicians’ Victorian attire. The Philadelphia Orchestra filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in April; the Honolulu Symphony and the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra recently folded; and musicians of the Detroit Symphony had their pay cut after a six-month strike. In a turbulent economy that has carried a wide range of organizations, including arts groups, banks and newspapers, to the brink, orchestras are being forced to re-examine their missions and structures to accommodate a changing fiscal and social landscape.

headline: Tweet on the Street
text: Most Wall Street employees can’t access sites like Facebook and Twitter, a move by banks to control the dissemination of information.

headline: On Top, Unafraid to Step Back
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: Bartoli Outlasts Govortsova to Reach Third Round
text: PARIS — Marion Bartoli’s long black hair stretches to her waist and often flies into her face during especially prolonged rallies, when she runs from sideline to sideline.

headline: Caucus | Democrat Takes G.O.P Seat
text: Megan Liberman and Carolyn Ryan discuss the upset in New York's 26th Congressional District and what it might mean for the fight over Medicare.

headline: Finding the Next Mark Zuckerberg
text: Peter Thiel University is now in session.

headline: On Bloomberg Editorials, the Comptroller, and Housekeepers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rarely misses a chance to proclaim his views at daily news conferences — on the economy, politics, philanthropy, art, traffic and, well, you get the idea.

headline: Reyes Ties Record for Consecutive Winless Starts
text: Jo-Jo Reyes didn’t take long to tie a major league record Tuesday.

headline: Ignoring ‘Typical’ Siblings
text: The cover story of The New York Times Magazine this weekend (you can read it online here) is a riveting look at two 4-year-old girls — conjoined twins — who seem able to feel each other’s sensations and read each other’s thoughts. It is fascinating science. It is also a thought-provoking parenting story.

headline: Getting Cheaper Vanguard Funds in Your 401(k)
text: In response to Ron Lieber’s column on why 401(k) plans should offer more low-cost index funds, a reader wrote asking why, as a 401(k) participant, he can’t buy a lower-expense class of Vanguard shares that are available to clients who have individual Vanguard brokerage or IRA accounts.

headline: The Morning Line: Baffert Looking to the Belmont
text: Not unexpectedly, Wednesday is fairly slow for Triple Crown news.
