headline: After Long Dry Spell, a German Revival
text: PARIS — It is early, much too early, to start talking about a full-blown German tennis renaissance.

headline: Russia Is Invited to Join O.E.C.D. Anti-Bribery Pact
text: MOSCOW — A group of nations working to outlaw bribery in international trade invited Russia to join their pact at a ceremony Wednesday in Paris, after the Russian Parliament passed a law this spring prohibiting Russian companies from bribing foreign officials.

headline: Draghi Receives Warm Welcome in Germany
text: BERLIN — Mario Draghi received a warm welcome Wednesday in his first public appearance in Germany since being officially nominated to become the next president of the European Central Bank.

headline: U.S. Government Adds Hybrids and E.V.’s to Car Fleet
text: As part of its effort to make the federal fleet greener and put a million hybrid and electric vehicles on the road by 2015, the Obama administration took a relatively small step Tuesday by purchasing 101 Chevrolet Volt plug-in hybrids, as well as 15 battery-powered E.V.’s.

headline: UBS Hires 2 From Morgan Stanley
text: UBS, which announced last that it had hired Thomas Langford from Morgan Stanley to be global head of energy investment banking, has now poached two more from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Video: Was the Special Election a Bellwether?
text: Megan Liberman talks with Carolyn Ryan, Metro editor, discuss the upset in New York’s 26th Congressional District and what it might mean for the fight over Medicare.

headline: No Rest for the Weary? Analyzing Sleep Habits
text: Overview | How much sleep does the average teenager need? How do the natural sleep rhythms of most adolescents sometimes conflict with the typical high school schedule? In this lesson, students explore their own sleep habits by keeping sleep logs. They look for patterns in the data they collect, explore current research on adolescent sleep needs and make suggestions to their local school boards regarding sleep and school schedules.

headline: CNBC Marks the Death of Anchor Mark Haines
text: Mark Haines, an anchor at CNBC who for years narrated the vicissitudes of the markets, died on Tuesday evening at his home in Marlboro, N.J., the network said Wednesday. He was 65.

headline: M.T.A. Chief Says Panhandlers Exist, but in Smaller Numbers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who proudly includes himself among the mass transit-using public (even if his is a peculiar, infrequent style of subway-going), recently caused a bit of a snit when he declared that the era of the underground beggar had all but come to an end.

headline: Havana’s Sphere of Influence
text: IN Cuba, where dancers — especially male ones — seem to grow like weeds, ballet is a noble profession. “There every taxi driver knows the names of the dancers,” Mikhail Baryshnikov said in a recent interview. “This is unheard of. Try it in New York.”

headline: Does It All Come Down to Medicare?
text: Gail Collins: David, this is going to be our last conversation until after Labor Day. I’m already nostalgic — we’ve been doing this for almost three years to the day, and this will be our first real break. I’ve been remembering all our fun times — like how plucky you were about finding ways to communicate during severe power outages — which, I must point out, seem to follow you around the country. And the night the Republicans won the Ted Kennedy Senate seat and I carried on my half of the conversation by e-mail while curled up in a fetal position under a hotel bed.

headline: Suspect in Shooting of Giffords Ruled Unfit for Trial
text: TUCSON — A federal judge ruled Wednesday that Jared L. Loughner was not mentally competent to stand trial on charges that he opened fire at a constituent event for Representative Gabrielle Giffords in January, killing six and injuring her and 12 others.

headline: Homes for $450,000
text: A log cabin in Lousiana, a 1912 bungalow in Idaho and a contemporary house in Maine.

headline: In Upset, ‘Dancing’ Tops ‘Idol’
text: In a rare ratings victory over Fox’s “American Idol,” the ABC reality show “Dancing With the Stars” drew more viewers on Tuesday night as the Pittsburgh Steelers wide receiver Hines Ward and his dancing partner, Kym Johnson, were crowned winners of the show’s 12th season.

headline: What You Get for ... $450,000
text: FOLSOM, La.

headline: After Upsetting Berdych, Robert Is Ousted
text: PARIS — The Frenchman who scored the tournament’s biggest upset so far just two days ago ran out of energy and crashed out of the tournament Wednesday, winning only three games in three straight sets.

headline: Tornadoes and Natural Gas in the Greenhouse
text: May 26, 12:28 p.m. | Updated I’m in the middle of a two-day faculty meeting on innovation in university education (with great talks on borderless learning by Gardner Campbell of Virginia Tech and Tamar Lewin of The Times). But I wanted to note some fresh coverage of a couple of issues explored here recently — the climate implications of expanded drilling for natural gas and the relationship, if any, of tornadoes to human-driven climate change.Tornadoes and warming

headline: 3 Men and a Monkey-Baby
text: The funniest, most reckless moments in “The Hangover Part II,” the largely mirthless sequel to the 2009 hit “The Hangover,” take place in the final credits, when still images flash by detailing the latest misadventures of the story’s overgrown lost boys. The outrages, most of which are once again carefully elided in the actual movie, involve a slipped knife, a tribal tattoo and Thai bar girls performing specialized party tricks. The final credits are the time when viewers meander or flee from the theater or sit in stunned or ecstatic silence or chattering communion. Here the credits just emphasize how deeply square this flick is.

headline: 2 Former Employees Accuse French Official of Sexual Assault
text: PARIS — Two women have brought sexual harassment suits against a junior minister here, with one saying explicitly that she was spurred by the accusations of sexual assault against the French economist Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the newspaper Le Parisien reported Wednesday.

headline: 9 States Get New Chance at Federal Education Aid
text: Nine states that were also-rans in last year’s Race to the Top school improvement competition will get another chance, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday, though this time $200 million will be up for grabs, compared with $4 billion awarded last year.

headline: Wells Fargo Bankers Answer Criticism of Lending Practices
text: Back in the darkest days of the economic crisis, few people had anything good to say about the nation’s biggest banks, least of all small-business owners. The big banks took federal bailout money, if in some cases reluctantly, and then faced accusations of being stingy with all of that capital. Even some business owners with longstanding banking relationships reported difficulty getting new loans. Others claimed their banks had dropped them altogether.

headline: Jon Shook in ‘Fish,’ a Film By R. J. Cutler
text: R. J. Cutler is a documentary film director who on another blog would be introduced as the guy who made “The September Issue,” about Anna Wintour and Vogue. Here at Diner’s Journal, however, Mr. Cutler is known as a food maniac — a restaurant enthusiast and scratch cook who is always game for a late dinner reservation in whatever city he visits, and who has a wood-burning pizza oven in his outdoor kitchen at his home high in the hills of Los Angeles.

headline: Maria Sharapova Extends Her Reach
text: WHEN Maria Sharapova won her first grand slam title in 2004, at age 17, she made the cover of Sports Illustrated. The issue showed Ms. Sharapova at the moment she became a household name, proudly beaming on court at Wimbledon in a body-skimming white tank dress from Nike. “Star Power,” the headline read.

headline: Poised for an Upset, Lisicki Falters and Is Carried Off the Court
text: PARIS -– The day’s most compelling match ended at dusk, with Sabine Lisicki of Germany carried away on a stretcher, sobbing.

headline: Wells Fargo Bankers Will Take Your Questions
text: Today, we’re publishing an interview The Agenda conducted with Wells Fargo’s two top executives for small-business lending, Marc Bernstein and Doug Case. Small-business owners have criticized big banks — and Wells Fargo is among the biggest — for doing little to help them through the most difficult days of the recent recession, but Mr. Bernstein and Mr. Case were resolute. Whatever the merit of the complaints against the banking industry, the officials said, the complaints were misdirected when it came to Wells Fargo.

headline: TimesCast | May 25, 2011
text: President Obama wraps up a two-day visit to Britain; the search for survivors continues in Joplin, Mo.; and Oprah Winfrey's final episode of her daily show.

headline: S.E.C. Adopts Its Revised Rules for Whistle-Blowers
text: 7:52 p.m. | Updated

headline: House Bookkeeping Criticized in Audit
text: The House had trouble keeping its own financial house in order in 2009, according to a memo sent Wednesday to members of the oversight subcommittee. The memo said an extensive audit had found deficiencies for the first time in 12 years.

headline: The Lowdown | Alec Friedman
text: Alec Friedman has the hustler mentality of the native New Yorker that he is. He is most often contextualized by the work he does as the associate creative director of the uber-hip, twice-a-year glossy Dossier Journal. Friedman, who is constantly on the move, can be found at the chicest parties world round, including the photographer Tim Barber’s late night bash during Miami Basel (see above). The ultimate consultant, he is also one of the nicest guys in fashion and publishing, a soft-spoken example of how far a smile can go in a generally cutthroat universe. Brands have begun to tap him for his creative insight, not to mention his casting skills, asking him to nominate cool kids and artists for modeling gigs and video spots. Friedman himself is something of a style icon in the downtown creative scene, and appears regularly in the pages of magazines, and lately in subway entrances via the most recent Cole Haan campaign, along with the rest of the stylish Dossier staff.

headline: Christine Lagarde's Statement on Leading the I.M.F.
text: Finance Minister Christine Lagarde of France is seen as a front-runner to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn, who resigned from the International Monetary Fund last week to fight sexual assault charges.

headline: Milestone for Yankees’ Rivera Is Tempered by a Setback for Soriano
text: The overhand throwing motion is about as unnatural an action as there is in sports, placing stress on muscles and joints and tendons, and rare is the athlete who lasts an entire career without feeling its effects.

headline: Signs Grow That Palin May Run
text: WASHINGTON — Sarah Palin is fortifying her small staff of advisers, buying a house in Arizona — where associates have said she could base a national campaign — and reviving her schedule of public appearances. The moves are the most concrete signals yet that Ms. Palin, the former governor of Alaska, is seriously weighing a Republican presidential bid.

headline: Winning Iraqi Hearts and Minds – One Camel Rescue at a Time
text: CONTINGENCY OPERATING BASE ADDER, Iraq — As the United States winds down its military operations in Iraq, American troops here in the southern part of the country are spending their days applying the gentler forms of military power.

headline: New York Harbor, 11:15 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: Fleet Week flyover.

headline: Guardian of the Pines
text: ANDREW KIRTZMAN was there alongside Rudolph W. Giuliani, marching through the dust-clogged streets of Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center collapsed. He was there alongside Michael R. Bloomberg, hunkered down in City Hall during the 2003 blackout. He was there alongside David Dinkins, on a good-will tour of Tel Aviv after the Crown Heights riots.

headline: New Works by Ballet Theater
text: The theater presented new ballets by Alexei Ratmansky, Benjamin Millepied and Christopher Wheeldon on Tuesday at the Met.

headline: On Location
text: A building, in Arbúcies, Spain, houses a family butcher business on the bottom floor and living quarters on the top three floors.

headline: Not So New, but Not Forgotten
text: WHEN 1 of a Find, a high-end vintage clothing store, arrived on Lincoln Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, during the spring of 2008, it was greeted with bland indifference.

headline: Combat in the First Person: Haruti
text: Spc. Michael Gannon guides us through a mission in Haruti by sharing the video he captured on a helmet camera.

headline: In Spain, the Modern Transformation of a Family Home
text: ARBÚCIES, Spain — In 2005, Joan Badia and Mireia Cerdà were at a crossroads in their relationship. After five years of dating, they were ready to move in together, but where they would live was another story. The couple had grown up in the picturesque Catalonian village of Arbúcies, about 50 miles northeast of Barcelona, and were content in the small town nestled in the rugged hills of the Montseny mountains. They considered building a home in the countryside, but they relished the idea of raising a family in their charming community with its pastel-colored row houses and cobblestone paths.

headline: A Magazine That Won’t Smudge
text: EVEN as the publishing rivals Condé Nast and Hearst Magazines race to one-up each other with plans to translate their old-fashioned fashion magazines for the new generation of tablets — adding features like a talking editor’s letter (Elle) or an iPad-only reality series (Glamour) — there is still the sense in some quarters that those companies haven’t yet fully embraced the digital medium.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Missouri and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Missouri, Libya, Afghanistan and Spain.

headline: Elbow to Sideline Soriano for Six to Eight Weeks
text: Yankees reliever Rafael Soriano will miss the next six to eight weeks after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed an inflamed ligament in his right elbow. Soriano was examined Wednesday by the renowned orthopedist Dr. James Andrews, who recommended rest for the next two weeks before beginning a conservative throwing program. General Manager Brian Cashman said the Yankees hope that Soriano can face hitters four to six weeks after that, which would place his potential return around the All-Star game, which is July 12.

headline: Bill Allows Military to Use High-Carbon ‘Liquid Coal’
text: An amendment to a major military spending bill before the House would rescind a 2007 federal law barring the Defense Department from using alternative fuels, like synthetic oil made from coal, that produce more climate-altering pollution than conventional fuels.

headline: Classical Recordings
text: MOMPOU:

headline: Somalis Are Told to Stop Bickering or Lose Financing
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Members of the United Nations Security Council sent an unusually blunt message to Somalia’s leaders on Wednesday to stop fighting among themselves or risk losing millions of dollars a year from Western donors.

headline: Belarus Leader May Trade Rivals’ Freedom for Aid
text: MOSCOW — Facing a deepening economic crisis in Belarus, the country’s authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, indicated on Wednesday that he might free his imprisoned political rivals, a signal that he could be ready to strike a deal with Western governments in exchange for financial support.

headline: Yahoo’s Bartz Holds Her Tongue on Alibaba
text: Carol A. Bartz, Yahoo’s outspoken chief executive, was anything but on Wednesday while being questioned about her company’s dispute with Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet giant that it partly owns.

headline: Twitter Acquires TweetDeck Software
text: After days of speculation on technology blogs, Twitter officially announced Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire TweetDeck, a service that organizes Twitter feeds to make them more useful. According to people who had been briefed on the deal who were not authorized to speak publicly, Twitter agreed to pay about $40 million.

headline: Angle Pulls Out of Nevada House Race
text: LAS VEGAS — Well, that was a short political comeback.

headline: What to Watch Thursday at the French Open
text: PARIS -– The weather at the French Open, near perfect and sunny through the first four days –- there were rumors of a cloud somewhere over Paris Wednesday, but that has not been confirmed — is expected to turn a bit cool and blustery on Thursday. But the tennis should remain plenty hot.

headline: It’s a Turban, It’s a Dress (It’s a Scarf)
text: MARIANGELA MELATO could work a scarf like Salome. In “Swept Away,” Lina Wertmüller’s 1974 screen exploration of class and gender warfare, her character, a castaway, makes do mostly with a single wardrobe item, an outsize scarf that she presses into service as a head wrap, a sultry halter dress, a lens-fogging slit-to-the-hip sarong and, when the waters get choppy, a sheltering cocoon.

headline: Tatiana and Krista’s Special Connection
text: In this week’s magazine, Susan Dominus writes about Tatiana and Krista Hogan, 4-year-old conjoined twins whose brains are linked by a neural bridge. It’s an incredible story that leads to all kinds of fascinating questions about empathy, consciousness and the nature of the self: If the girls share sensation, could they also share higher thoughts? Do they experience some kind of cross-talk in their brains that they are constantly having to filter out? Will their identities merge together over time or become more differentiated?

headline: For Public Hospital Employees, New Training on Gay Patients
text: A doctor asks a girl if she is using condoms, and a boy if he has a girlfriend. A woman has to fill out the usual medical forms, asking whether she needs birth control, and if she is married, single, divorced or widowed.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Finds a New Home
text: Updated 7:50 p.m. | Dominique Strauss-Kahn is about to be on the move again.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Missouri and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Missouri, Libya, Afghanistan and Spain.

headline: Apple Operating System Affected by Malware
text: For years Apple Mac users have boasted about the lack of malware on their computers. In comparison, Microsoft Windows owners have regularly felt the brunt of viruses and malware that can easily debilitate an entire computer system in minutes.

headline: Laurents Left Book, Play and Plan for ‘Gypsy’ Film
text: In the month before his death, on May 5, the Tony Award-winning writer and director Arthur Laurents gave his blessing to a plan for a new film version of “Gypsy,” starring Barbra Streisand, and also finished a full-length play as well as his third memoir, Laurents’s agent and several associates said this week.

headline: Less Active at Work, Americans Have Packed on Pounds
text: Looking beyond poor eating habits and a couch-potato lifestyle, a group of researchers has found a new culprit in the obesity epidemic: the American workplace.

headline: Shopping for Modernist Flatware With S. Russell Groves
text: Mr. Groves selects flatware, looking for silver pieces with an eye toward both shape and materials.

headline: TimesCast | Search Continues in Joplin
text: May 25, 2011 - The search for survivors continues in Joplin, Mo.

headline: Television Diva Gives Thanks and Signs Off
text: The surprise was that at long last there weren’t any more surprises. Oprah Winfrey took her final bow on Wednesday by holding back. “There will be no makeovers, no surprises — really, no surprises,” she told her studio audience. “You will not be getting a car or a tree. This last hour is really about me saying thank you.”

headline: Classical Recordings
text: BERLIOZ: ‘LES NUITS D’ÉTé’; HANDEL: ARIAS

headline: A Noble Panda Takes On a Nightmare Enemy
text: In “Kung Fu Panda 2” the hero, a roly-poly panda named Po, voiced by the irrepressible Jack Black, undergoes an identity crisis. Raised by a doting, dithering, noodle-shop-owning goose, Po experiences flashbacks to a traumatic infancy, including hazy recollections of his parents that look sketched by hand, in contrast to the computer-polished, 3-D images that dominate the movie.

headline: Turkey Calls for Syrian Reforms on Order of ‘Shock Therapy’
text: KONYA, Turkey — The foreign minister of Turkey said Wednesday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria must deliver reforms that would constitute “shock therapy” to his country if he had any hope of ending a nine-week crisis that was roiling the region.

text: May 25, 2011 - President Obama wraps up a two-day visit to Britain.

headline: Duck Hunting on the Internet
text: REGULAR Facebook perusers are no doubt familiar with a certain photographic expression: a pout-producing, cheekbone-enhancing pose featuring pooched-out lips and sucked-in cheeks.

headline: Exploring Biodiversity in the Philippines
text: Rich Mooi, curator of invertebrate zoology and geology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from the Philippines, where he is surveying echinoderms off the coast of Luzon Island.

headline: Pianists Embracing the New
text: Some contemporary-music festivals make a point of exploring a particular style or branch of composition. Not Keys to the Future, a festival of contemporary solo piano music, which opened its sixth mini-season on Tuesday night at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side. This embracing festival espouses no dogma.

headline: A Big House, Big Names, New Twists
text: American Ballet Theater keeps trying its damnedest to be both Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde.

headline: E-Business Is the Buzz at Book Fair
text: Authors are shrugging off publishers to self-publish their work. Publishers are advancing into retail. Barnes & Noble is getting deeper into the gadget business, and Amazon is stepping into publishing.

headline: Person-to-Person Payments Get Easier at Big Banks
text: Three of the nation’s biggest banks introduced a service that will enable their customers to move money from their checking accounts using only an e-mail address or a mobile phone number.

text: Allee Willis, songwriter, and her house, a monument to kitsch.

headline: What’s a Cortelyou? And Will the Van Wyck Get Me There?
text: You’d think there would only be so many ways to pronounce, or mispronounce, a name.

headline: Angry Parents in Japan Confront Government Over Radiation Levels
text: FUKUSHIMA CITY, Japan — The accusations flew on Wednesday at the local school board meeting, packed with parents worried and angry about radiation levels in this city at the heart of Japan’s nuclear crisis.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Boschscape of Vows, Song and Flesh
text: “I don’t want to miss my cue,” the festively dressed man sitting next to me explained as he edged his chair closer to see the left side of the tableau before us: 120 people arrayed over tiered platforms at one end of the extraordinary Skylight One Hanson, a majestic Art Deco space in the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, a towering landmark in downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Light Bulb Saving Time
text: BUNNY WILLIAMS, the no-nonsense decorator known for her lush English-style rooms, is laying in light bulbs like canned goods. Incandescent bulbs, that is — 60 and 75 watters — because she likes a double-cluster lamp with a high- and a low-watt bulb, one for reading, one for mood.

headline: The Ryan Budget’s Unforced Errors
text: Yesterday, while the backlash against the House Republican budget was helping the Democrats snap up a House seat in conservative territory, Peter Suderman discussed how the Republicans helped bring this on their own head:

headline: Bopping to Her Own Beat
text: Los Angeles

headline: Getting a Head Start on That Musical Night on the Town
text: In a rational world, you should be able to open an app wherever you are on a Friday night and have it deliver a comprehensive list of nearby concerts or weekend music festivals you would enjoy.

headline: A Library of Listening, Made by You
text: Want to know the real problem with the digital age? There’s not enough to listen to.

headline: A Lifetime of Anxiety and Lust
text: “I love my worldliness, my snobbery, my ease,” the great literary critic Alfred Kazin confided to his journal in 1959, when he was 43. He was at the apex of his powers as a writer and as a man.

headline: Rock Songs Turned Testaments of Triumphant Soul
text: To choose a song at random from the soul singer Bettye LaVette’s astounding two-hour show at the Café Carlyle on Tuesday evening, how about that jolly 1971 Ringo Starr singalong, “It Don’t Come Easy”? If you are like me, you probably never paid much attention to the lyrics of a number that’s catchy enough but no great shakes as a piece of songwriting.

headline: Spoons for Thinkers
text: EVERYTHING about S. Russell Groves is just so, from his style of dress to his choice of words; nothing is superfluous. A modernist who worked for Richard Meier and Peter Marino before starting his own architecture and design firm in 1995, Mr. Groves does not seem like the sort of person who would amass anything in quantity.

headline: Hard Times at a Factory of Legends
text: Long Beach Polytechnic High School in California is not much like the fictional East Dillon High of “Friday Night Lights” or even, for that matter, the wealthier rival Panthers across town with their championship victories. Poly, as the locals call it, exists in a realm unto its own: Sports Illustrated called it “sports school of the century.”

headline: Clouds Have Lifted, and the Hamptons Beckon
text: IS it summer already? It certainly feels that way in the Hamptons, where a post-recession lift brings new places to dine, shop and, of course, party. Mercifully, the mood has shifted from the go-go 2000s. Instead of magnums of Cristal, it’s now about communal seaplanes, hipster charities, hippie festivals, Montauk and more Montauk. Our guide:

headline: Melodramatic Sounds of Young Love
text: Verismo operas were the reality television of their time. Dispensing with the typical operatic kings and gods, they featured recognizably ordinary characters experiencing way-larger-than-life emotions. Capped by generous helpings of sex and violence, these operas made it hard to look away.

headline: Freescale Prices Its I.P.O. at $18 a Share
text: It hardly seems possible in the current environment where investors are clamoring for newly public companies like LinkedIn and Yandex.

headline: I’m Moving. And the Plants?
text: A BERRY bush may be nature’s answer to the gumball machine. There the thing stands, dispensing bits of cheer by the palmful. And a berry bush needs no coins; the currency is grab and go.

headline: Yet Again, Adele Tops the Charts
text: The old news about the latest music sales: Adele is No. 1, yet again. The new news: Thanks to an aggressive marketing campaign and some apparently unsolicited promotion by Amazon, Lady Gaga is selling even better than expected.

headline: ‘Prepare Ye the Way of the Lord': ‘Godspell’ Revival Coming to Broadway
text: “Godspell,” the parable-driven musical based on the Gospel of Matthew that ran on various New York stages from 1971 to 1977, will be revived on Broadway for the first time this fall, the producers announced on Wednesday. The revival had originally been aiming to open on Broadway in the summer of 2008, but its financing plans did not come together, largely due to the approaching economic recession. The lead producer of the upcoming production, Ken Davenport, said on Wednesday that the musical would be staged at Broadway’s only in-the-round theater, Circle in the Square. Preview performances of the open-ended run are scheduled to begin on Oct. 13, with an opening night of Nov. 7.

headline: Two Overcalls: One Worked, One Didn’t
text: In a team event, when one side gains a sizable swing, it is usually because one pair did something especially meritorious. Occasionally, though, both pairs combine well — as in the diagramed deal, Board 62 from the Bermuda Bowl world championship trial in Henderson, Nev., this month.

headline: Collegiate Living: Honeys, I’m Home
text: WE would meet in the kitchen just after sunrise each morning — he in his white terry robe, I in my black embroidered caftan. We would talk groggily while making coffee — he meticulously nursing a drip cone over a single mug, I stoking up the automatic for a tub of caffeine.

headline: Scene City: The Whitney Heads Downtown
text: The Whitney Museum tries hard to show off a younger, hipper side.

headline: Pour

headline: A Celebrity Designer in the Service of Glamour
text: The interior designer Martyn Lawrence Bullard is a favorite of Los Angeles celebrities. Since moving to the city from London 19 years ago, he has amassed a list of high-profile clients that includes Elton John, Kid Rock, Cher and Edward Norton, among other notable names.

headline: A Summer Show House on the Jersey Shore
text: Décor by the Shore, a show house to benefit the Sephardic Community Center of Brooklyn, opens Wednesday in Deal, N.J.

headline: Following a Lure to Delicate Lamps
text: “When you hold a lure in your hand, it is so delicate that you feel you could crush it like an eggshell,” said Alison Berger, explaining the inspiration for her latest piece, the Lure sconce. “The glass for the sconce is also super-delicate — you just sigh into the glass to get that shape.”

headline: My Blog Is Also Paying My Bills
text: Casting the digital equivalent of a message-in-a-bottle into the Internet’s vast sea of content, many people start Web sites or blogs hoping that they will find an appreciative audience for their precocious parrot videos, cupcake recipes or pithy commentary on everyday life. The dream, of course, is that they will develop a large and loyal following — and potentially profit from it.

headline: Cutlery and Tables to Put It On
text: Some floor model furniture, artwork, textiles and accessories are 20 to 50 percent off at Michael Hennessy Home, through June 5 (the white oak Farmhouse table, originally $3,200, is $1,600; a walnut Retro console cabinet with fossil knobs, regularly $7,995, is $5,596); 207 West 18th Street (Seventh Avenue), (646) 370-6575, mhhome.net.

headline: Ballmer Must Go, Einhorn Says
text: David Einhorn, the head of the hedge fund Greenlight Capital, called on Wednesday for the removal of Steven A. Ballmer as Microsoft‘s chief executive, telling an investor conference in New York that his leadership was the biggest overhang on the company’s stock price.

headline: Answers About Pip and Violet
text: This week, Dr. Elizabeth Bunting, a wildlife veterinarian at the Animal Health Diagnostic Center at Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine, and other experts will be responding to readers’ questions about Pip, the red-tailed hawk hatchling, or eyas, who emerged from the egg on May 6 in a nest on a 12th-floor ledge at New York University — and about Pip’s mother, Violet, about whose injured leg many of you have expressed concern.

headline: Fresh Design for an Antiques Town
text: For two years, the furniture designer Chris Lehrecke has had a 600-square-foot shop in Hudson, N.Y. Last week he opened a new space, nearly double the size, across the street. “The little store was just a tester,” Mr. Lehrecke explained. “If I put any major pieces of furniture in there, it looked ridiculous.”

headline: Honoring a Designer Who Gave Computers Their Fonts
text: If influence can be measured in the quantity of typewritten words produced, then the most powerful wordmonger in history may be Matthew Carter. The British-born designer, 73, has created typefaces for newspapers (including The New York Times), phone books and computer companies; he designed the fonts Verdana and Georgia that Microsoft added to Windows in 1996 and later distributed freely.

text: On Wednesday, Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood unveiled a new window sticker that would be required for all 2013 model-year vehicles on dealer lots. The sticker revises the current version, which provides only basic information regarding the average fuel consumption of a vehicle.

text: There were so many somebodies that nobody seemed to know who anybody was. Such was the conundrum that a phalanx of reporters and photographers faced on the red carpet at the Drama Desk Awards, held at the Hammerstein Ballroom in Midtown on Monday night.

headline: Late Pickups Help Fuel Canucks’ Run to Stanley Cup Finals
text: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Chris Higgins has this dream. It is summertime on Long Island, and he is on a beach, hoisting the Stanley Cup in front of friends and family and celebrating through the night.

text: INDIANAPOLIS — N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell did not rule out the possibility Wednesday of expanding rosters if training camps and preseason games are cut short or eliminated by the N.F.L.’s labor stalemate.

text: PARIS — The euro crisis hangs over the coming meeting of the Group of 8 industrialized countries, with Greece’s renewed problems destabilizing markets, worrying Washington and influencing the debate over who should be the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Blagojevich Did Not Seek Favors, Emanuel Testifies at Retrial
text: CHICAGO — Testifying in the retrial of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois may not have been high on the list of ways Rahm Emanuel hoped to spend his second week in office as mayor.

headline: A Statue of Pope John Paul II Brings Out the Critic in Italians
text: ROME — The backdrop may be the Termini train station, but the chatter these days evokes a Damien Hirst opening. The object of the attention is a 17-foot-tall bronze sculpture of Pope John Paul II unveiled on May 18, his birthday.

headline: Natural Court Colors Give Way to a Kaleidoscope of Shades
text: PARIS — As managing director of a company called DecoTurf, John Graham oversees the design and construction of many of the world’s best-known tennis courts. One tool he uses with increasing frequency is a color wheel.

headline: Scotty McCreery Wins ‘American Idol’
text: All the mom-baiting in the world couldn’t save Lauren Alaina, it turns out. Scotty McCreery is this year’s American Idol, his inertia too great for Lauren to overcome with one great night. Instead the title belongs to Scotty, who’s been this season’s most consistent performer, and often its most invigorating. What do you think about Scotty’s victory? Tell us below in the comments field.

headline: House Tour: Cheviot, N.Y.
text: A fully renovated Victorian house on the Hudson sits atop a gentle slope in a hamlet that dates to the 1700s.;

headline: Mexico: Man Arrested in Murder Tied to Drug Cartel
text: In a case that has galvanized a protest movement against the government’s conduct of the campaign against drug traffickers, the authorities said that they had arrested a man believed to have ordered the murder of seven people. Among the victims was Juan Francisco Sicilia, 24, the son of the poet and journalist Javier Sicilia, left, who has since led marches demanding a change in the government’s strategy. The suspect, Julio de Jesús Radilla, who was arrested Tuesday, is the leader of the South Pacific cartel in the central state of Morelos, said Luis Cárdenas Palomino, chief of regional security for the federal police. Mr. Radilla is accused of ordering the killings after two of the younger Mr. Sicilia’s friends got into an argument with members of the cartel. Juan Francisco Sicilia was found bound and fatally shot along with six friends in the city of Cuernavaca in March.

headline: China: Mongolian Students Protest Handling of Death
text: Nearly 2,000 Mongolian students on Wednesday marched on a government building in the city of Xilinhot in Inner Mongolia Province to demand that Chinese officials respect the rights of Mongolian herders, according to the Southern Mongolia Human Rights Information Center. The center, an advocacy group based in New York, posted on its Web site photographs of the protesters, the vast majority of whom were dressed in yellow or blue athletic jackets. The protest was over the way Chinese officials handled the death on May 10 of a Mongolian herder named Mergen, who was run over during a dispute by a coal truck driven by an ethnic Han, according to Mongolians in the area. The Han are the dominant ethnicity in China and make up the majority of the population in Inner Mongolia. The protest on Tuesday ended after government officials made several promises, including addressing the case of Mergen. Though many Mongolians resent the Han, the Mongolians in Inner Mongolia have rarely held large protests.

text: Paul Splittorff, a lanky left-hander who pitched more innings and won more games for the Kansas City Royals than any other pitcher, died Wednesday at his home in Blue Springs, Mo., a Kansas City suburb. He was 64.

headline: No Man's Land
text: With Spain and its neighbors facing economic turmoil, there are nearly 10,000 African migrants living in tent communities in the woods without papers or jobs and with little food and water.

headline: Voter Group Flexes Muscle in Ads Aimed at Senators
text: WASHINGTON — The League of Women Voters is typically thought of as an earnest, civic-minded organization best known for hosting sober candidate debates and distributing studious voter guides to keep the citizenry informed.

headline: FIFA Can’t Ignore Insider’s Charges of Corruption
text: Sepp Blatter has long contended that FIFA was not corrupt during his 13-year reign as president of soccer’s world governing body. But he has also promised not to ignore evidence of wrongdoing. Now we will learn if he is a man of his word.

headline: Chasing Riches From Africa to Europe and Finding Only Squalor
text: PALOS DE LA FRONTERA, Spain — Back home in Gambia, Amadou Jallow was, at 22, a lover of reggae who had just finished college and had landed a job teaching science in a high school.

headline: MSNBC Suspends Schultz Over Ingraham Remark
text: MSNBC announced what amounted to a suspension of one week without pay for its talk show host Ed Schultz Wednesday after pejorative comments he made on his syndicated radio program about the conservative commentator Laura Ingraham.

headline: Lakers Near Agreement to Hire Mike Brown as Coach
text: Mike Brown left the epicenter of the N.B.A. last summer when his Cleveland Cavaliers imploded in the playoffs against the Boston Celtics and LeBron James arrived at his long-speculated free agency.

headline: Growth in Education Spending Slowed in 2009
text: The nation’s overall education spending grew at a slower pace in 2009 than at any other time in more than a decade, amid deepening state fiscal woes and flatter tax revenues, according to new census figures released Wednesday.

headline: Squandering Medicare’s Money
text: San Francisco

headline: Complete Game Rarity for Yanks
text: Pitchers rarely throw a nine-inning complete game for the Yankees, and for one very simple reason, as C. C. Sabathia pointed out Tuesday night: Mariano Rivera. The ninth inning has been Rivera’s domain for the last 15 seasons, and his dominance has eased the workload of many a starter.

headline: Heineken Aims Its Ads at Young Digital Devotees
text: A WORLDWIDE initiative by the Dutch brewer Heineken to embrace nontraditional methods of delivering pitches to consumers has been deemed successful enough to continue.

headline: Patriot Act Battle Could Hinder Investigators
text: WASHINGTON — A dispute in the Senate over the Patriot Act that created a legislative impasse Wednesday has raised the prospect that several of the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s counterterrorism powers may temporarily lapse at the end of the week.

headline: New York Fed Investigates Goldman Loan Division
text: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has begun an investigation into the mortgage-servicing arm of Goldman Sachs, looking at whether it systematically rejected borrowers’ efforts to lower their loan payments through government programs.

headline: NATO and Afghan Forces Push Taliban Out of Seized Town
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — NATO and Afghan forces pushed back hundreds of Taliban fighters from a district center in northeastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, sending them fleeing into the rugged mountainside just hours after the fighters had seized control over a portion of that same area, Afghan officials said.

headline: State Ends a Practice of Rescoring Regents Tests
text: Responding to a suspicious spike in the number of students barely passing high school Regents exams, New York State education officials have ordered schools to end the longstanding but controversial practice of rescoring tests that fall just below the passing grade.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 25, 2011
text: United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon reiterated the urgent need for a ceasefire in Libya and for Tripoli to hold talks aimed at forming a transitional government.

headline: The Elaine’s That I Knew
text: ONE night, after I’d pulled the rolling metal gates down over the storefront of Elaine’s, the legendary restaurant on the Upper East Side, and just as I was about to put the padlocks on, I realized that I wasn’t sure if my boss, Elaine Kaufman, had left or not.

headline: An Actor Who Knows Start-Ups
text: Ashton Kutcher, a former model, rose to fame in Hollywood by playing a handsome ditz in “Dude, Where’s My Car?” and on “That 70s Show.” But in certain circles, people know that he is no dummy when it comes to technology.

headline: Egypt to Open Border With Gaza, in the Face of Israeli Objections
text: CAIRO — Egypt will permanently open its border with the Gaza Strip on Saturday despite Israeli protests, Egypt’s transitional government confirmed Wednesday, upending the dynamics of regional politics in a bid to shake up the deadlocked peace process and better respond to Egyptian public opinion.

headline: Storms Create a Scramble to Install Shelters
text: ATLANTA — Gloria Jones climbed out of a relative’s storm shelter in an Oklahoma City suburb on Wednesday night and saw only rubble where the house used to be.

headline: Ticket-Fixing Case Tests Officers on the Stand
text: In a thinly populated Bronx courtroom, a plain vanilla drunken driving case was in progress. More than four years ago, a red 1988 Oldsmobile driven by a beer-imbibing man collided with a 2002 Chevrolet Suburban on the Grand Concourse. The arresting officer was on the stand on Wednesday in State Supreme Court for defense cross-examination. But she was being asked about something quite different.

headline: Mumbai Plotter Testifies About Training
text: CHICAGO — A Pakistani-American who has confessed to helping plot the 2008 terrorist attack in Mumbai, India, testified in federal court here on Wednesday that the Drug Enforcement Administration had asked him to infiltrate Islamic extremist groups while working as an informant.

headline: Prague 1970: Music in Spring
text: I.

headline: Assistant Commissioner Who Faked Time Sheets Is Demoted
text: The Bloomberg administration demoted a high-ranking agency official on Wednesday after she admitted falsifying time sheets and collecting more than $22,000 that she had not earned.

headline: New Prosecution Team as Strauss-Kahn Moves
text: The Manhattan district attorney’s office has assigned two senior prosecutors to the sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn for what promises to be a vigorous court battle.

headline: Insider’s Claims of Corruption Put Pressure on FIFA
text: Accusations of corruption against top FIFA officials are nothing new, sadly. But the latest ones, delivered by an executive committee member, Chuck Blazer, against two other top officials, including one who is up for election to FIFA’s presidency next week, will be almost impossible to ignore. Read Jeré Longman’s analysis here, and come back to comment.

headline: Apartments Are Dedicated in Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — Senior Israeli government officials and dignitaries on Wednesday attended the dedication ceremony of a Jewish apartment complex in a hotly contested, predominantly Palestinian neighborhood of the city across the 1967 boundary.

headline: Children’s Aid Society Sells Greenwich Village Buildings
text: In Greenwich Village, Mommy and Me classes are about to make way for luxury condominiums.

headline: Democratic Happy Dance
text: Hey, did anybody notice that the Democrat won a special Congressional race in a Republican district in upstate New York? Apparently, she campaigned a lot on protecting Medicare.

headline: Winding Down the Bailouts, and Trying Not to Lose Money
text: After months of planning, the federal government has sold the first batch of shares it owns in the American International Group, the most prominent reminder of the wreckage of 2008.

headline: First Day in Monaco, Sunshine and Shadows
text: MONACO – I have never arrived in the paddock in Monaco and found it in such a state of construction before. No big deal for me, as the media can still get the job done. But the team members who have been going without sleep for 60 hours — as one said to me — really have it hard. All the time I was sleeping and writing my previews in the comfort of the trains from Barcelona to Monaco, these people were deconstructing, transporting and reconstructing the massive motor homes between the Barcelona paddock on Sunday to here today.

headline: First Day in Monaco, Sunshine and Shadows
text: MONACO – I have never arrived in the paddock in Monaco and found it in such a state of construction before. No big deal for me, as the media can still get the job done. But the team members who have been going without sleep for 60 hours — as one said to me — really have it hard. All the time I was sleeping and writing my previews in the comfort of the trains from Barcelona to Monaco, these people were deconstructing, transporting and reconstructing the massive motor homes between the Barcelona paddock on Sunday to here today.

headline: Libya Effort Is Called Violation of War Act
text: WASHINGTON — Several lawmakers from both parties on Wednesday accused President Obama of violating the War Powers Resolution by continuing American participation in NATO’s air war in Libya without Congressional authorization, but they struggled with the question of what Congress can or should do about it.

headline: Mark Haines, CNBC Host and Interviewer, Dies at 65
text: Mark Haines, a popular and often combative morning host of financial news programs on CNBC, including “Squawk on the Street,” died Tuesday at his home in Marlboro, N.J. He was 65.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Energy Pipelines Offer Market-Beating Returns
text: Oil and gas pipelines offer market-beating returns. Mostly held in so-called master limited partnerships, or M.L.P.’s, they looked expensive for a while. But the $245 billion sector again looks affordable. Many shun the complexity, but it means higher returns for those prepared to invest.

headline: Joplin Sifts Through Tornado Wreckage
text: As rescue workers continue to sift through the wreckage of Joplin, Mo., local leaders have been wrestling with the question of when to start cleaning up the destroyed area.

headline: Imagining a New Life for Women
text: Since 1996, Anne R. Elliott has been executive director of Greenhope Services for Women in East Harlem, which serves former inmates who have abused drugs or been battered, and provides an alternative to incarceration. This month, Greenhope opened Kandake House, a residence that has education, therapy and cultural programs. Dr. Elliott, a North Carolina native, is 49 and lives in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

headline: Parties See Obama’s Israel Policy as Wedge for 2012
text: WASHINGTON — Few issues in American politics are as bipartisan as support for Israel. Yet the question of whether President Obama is supportive enough is behind some of the most partisan maneuvering since the Middle East ally was born six decades ago, and that angling has potential ramifications for the 2012 elections.

headline: Housekeeper Adds Lawyers to Team
text: The hotel housekeeper who Manhattan prosecutors say was sexually assaulted by Dominique Strauss-Kahn expanded her legal team on Wednesday, adding the noted civil liberties lawyer Norman Siegel and a former assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the police officers accused of assaulting Abner Louima.

headline: Wal-Mart Security Suit Seeks Oklahoma’s Help
text: HOUSTON — It is hard to escape the long arm of Wal-Mart. Just ask Bruce O. Gabbard, a former computer security technician who was fired by the corporation in March 2007 for spying on company officials.

headline: Mets Seem to Settle on Buyer Who Will Own Less Than Half
text: The Mets appear to have settled on a buyer who will give them at least $200 million for less than 49 percent of the team and will not receive a portion of SNY, the team’s profitable cable network, a person briefed on the matter said.

headline: Ex-Mob Boss Says Deputy Sought to Kill Prosecutor
text: After making a star turn from the witness box of a Mafia murder trial last month, a former mob boss returned to the stand on Wednesday to testify again against the same man, this time in the trial’s death penalty phase.

headline: Divorce, Tennis-Style, Ends in a Second Marriage
text: PARIS –- It was a partnership that soured after seven years. Now, after nearly a decade apart, Mahesh Bhupathi, 36, and Leander Paes, 37, both of India, have forged the tennis equivalent of a remarriage in the twilight of their careers.

headline: ‘The Hangover’ and the Age of the Jokeless Comedy
text: “The Hangover Part II” arrives much like a hangover — bludgeoning, harsh and relentless — yet it’s a notable, even groundbreaking film. It represents the logical evolution of a roughly five-year trend: someone has finally dared to make a mainstream American comedy in which nothing funny happens.

headline: San Francisco’s New Pop-Up Restaurant
text: It’s not a coincidence that three of the country’s hottest destination restaurants are more or less dives — the kinds of places for which you have to put on your worst clothes. And it’s not a coincidence that they all take chances; as with television shows, the best new restaurants aren’t copycats. Two of these places — Torrisi Italian Specialties (written about in the magazine a few weeks ago) and M. Wells, a reborn diner — are in New York and have European roots.

headline: Thursday: Private Aye
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — This is an elegant puzzle, and perfect for a Thursday.

headline: A Clock Ticking to Incessant Wailing
text: Parenthood is considered from both the hypothetical and actual perspectives in “Cradle and All,” a slight but mostly satisfying comedy by Daniel Goldfarb that opened Wednesday night at City Center in a Manhattan Theater Club production. The mewling of an 11-month-old baby is sweet, seductive music to one of the two heroines in Mr. Goldfarb’s play, a torture from the depths of hell to the other. Can you guess which one is the new mom?

headline: Company Overseeing Payroll Project Fires Manager
text: Doubts about CityTime, a troubled New York City payroll automation project, grew on Wednesday as the company overseeing the project said it had fired a senior employee for misrepresenting the number of hours he had worked.

headline: Abidal, to Barcelona’s Delight, Is Ready to Go
text: Two months ago, Eric Abidal was wondering whether he would play for Barcelona again. Now he’s wondering how much he’ll play in Saturday’s Champions League final.

headline: The Crossover: Genealogy of a 'Vicious' Move
text: A look at the use and effectiveness of the crossover move in basketball.

headline: Corrections
text: NEW YORK

headline: Reject the Tax Cap
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the New York State Legislature have already adopted a state budget that drastically cuts funds to schools and local communities — cuts that were far deeper than needed to balance the budget because of Mr. Cuomo’s indefensible refusal to extend a tax surcharge on New York’s wealthiest residents. Now they want to adopt a cheap political tool — a 2 percent property tax cap — that would only further devastate communities around the state that can least afford it.

headline: Kafka Couldn’t Have Built a Better System
text: The credit reporting industry has vast reach and power. The information it gathers and sells is used to determine eligibility for credit cards, mortgages and even some jobs. Federal regulators haven’t had the authority or the means to protect consumers who have been victims of inaccurate reports. The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will have that authority. It has a big job ahead.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Vacation Apps
text: Time to start getting ready for that summer vacation! On this week’s episode of Bits: Tech Talk, Bettina Edelstein, J.D. Biersdorfer and Pedro Rafael Rosado chat about mobile apps for travel on the road, in the air and with children.

headline: The Republicans’ ChutzPAC
text: Since Watergate, federal office holders and candidates have been barred from soliciting unlimited money for partisan campaign machines. Now three members of the Republican National Committee are trying to turn the law on its head with a new Republican Super PAC.

headline: Running on Medicare the Right Way
text: After their surprise victory in a heavily Republican Congressional district of western New York, Democrats believe they have the magic formula for winning back the House next year. “Medicare, Medicare, and Medicare,” said Representative Steve Israel of Long Island, who runs the Democratic election effort in the House. There is enormous power in Mr. Israel’s new cudgel. Even Paul Ryan, the Wisconsin Republican who wrote the plan to privatize Medicare and end its guarantee to the elderly, admitted that it played a significant role in the victory by Kathy Hochul, the Democrat. Nonetheless, effective as the playbook was in one special election, Democrats cannot expect to build their entire 2012 campaign around attacking the Ryan plan. It’s a useful reminder of the vast differences between the parties, but defines only the Republicans, not the Democrats.

headline: Riot Police Break Up Protest by Opposition in Georgian Capital
text: MOSCOW — An opposition protest in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi was violently broken up by riot police officers late Wednesday, scattering about a thousand demonstrators who had occupied a viewing stand where President Mikheil Saakashvili was scheduled to preside over a military parade on Thursday.

headline: Teams Looking at Reyes, Who Remains on a Roll
text: Fred Wilpon’s recent published comments and the Mets’ financial distress paint a dreary picture for the team’s prospects of re-signing Jose Reyes. But there are other teams that have the resources and interest to land him, one of which presents a surprising possibility.

headline: A Sign Full of Symbolism Goes Too Far for Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES—Not much is sacred in Hollywood. Classics are remade; final cuts are subjected to focus groups and re-edited.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Time for Peace?
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate prospects for Israeli-Palestinian peace.

headline: City Will Pay $2 Million After an Inmate’s Death
text: New York City has agreed to pay $2 million to settle a lawsuit alleging that a postal worker died in jail because his severe alcohol withdrawal went untreated.

headline: Plane Crashes in New Delhi, Killing 10
text: NEW DELHI — A plane being used as an air ambulance crashed in a congested residential area near New Delhi on Wednesday night, killing at least 10 people, officials said.

headline: Photo Replay: May 25
text: A look at the day sports from tennis at the French Open to baseball at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Ford Focus, Honda Civic and Nissan Juke Among I.I.H.S. Top Safety Picks
text: On Thursday, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety released crash-test results for 13 small cars. Six earned top scores, bringing the total number of small cars named top safety picks by the institute to 22.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Winner Is ...‘American Idol’
text: He was a little bit country; she was a little bit country.

headline: Word of the Day | disport
text: disport •\di-ˈspȯrt\• verb

headline: Workplace Cited as a New Source of Rise in Obesity
text: Looking beyond poor eating habits and a couch-potato lifestyle, a group of researchers has found a new culprit in the obesity epidemic: the American workplace.

headline: K-Rod Wants to Stay
text: CHICAGO — Francisco Rodriguez, who has a $17.5 million option in his contract that vests if he finishes 55 games this year, could become trade bait for the Mets, although it would be difficult to move him because of that option.

headline: Married Couples Are No Longer a Majority, Census Finds
text: WASHINGTON — Married couples have dropped below half of all American households for the first time, the Census Bureau says, a milestone in the evolution of the American family toward less traditional forms.

headline: Red Sox Roll Past Indians
text: In the latest issue of The New Yorker, Fred Wilpon said that the Mets were “snakebitten” because of the rash of player injuries, late-season meltdowns and financial calamities that had afflicted the club in recent years.

headline: Nowitzki Gives Mavericks Another Shot at a Title
text: DALLAS — For years, the Dallas Mavericks have been burdened with a rap of being unable to prosper from success. Playoffs brought angst and early departures, but Wednesday night delivered the second trip to the N.B.A. finals in franchise history.

headline: Still Crazy After All These Months
text: A year ago I had some harsh words for the OECD, which inexplicably demanded sharp increases in advanced-country interest rates even though its own projections suggested that unemployment would remain high and underlying inflation low for years to come.

headline: Test Yourself | English, May 26, 2011
text: Test your editing skills with today’s question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article “A Winner’s Circle Full of Firsts.”

headline: Series of Blasts Leaves at Least 2 Dead in Southern Chinese City
text: BEIJING — At least two people were killed and six wounded by three explosions within an hour on Thursday at government office buildings in a city in southern China, according to state news media and a provincial government Web site.

text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

text: Note: All the questions below can be answered by viewing the video above, but for more on the twins, go to the related article and slide show.

headline: Riot Police Break Up Opposition Protest in Georgia
text: MOSCOW —Human rights groups sharply criticized the government of Georgia Thursday, saying the police used excessive force to disperse anti-government street protesters in the early morning hours.

headline: Maple Group Bid for TMX Goes Hostile
text: The Maple Group has announced that it would take its $3.7 billion bid for the TMX Group, the parent of the Toronto exchange, directly to shareholders even as TMX and the London Stock Exchange have set the date for a stockholder vote on their proposed merger.

headline: Letting in and Coming Out
text: 4:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Problem With Christine Lagarde
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: For Djokovic’s Streak, the End Is Near
text: Novak Djokovic pasted Victor Hanescu in the second round at Roland Garros on Wednesday for his 41st straight victory, drawing him closer to Guillermo Vilas’s record 46-match streak set in 1977. To tie the mark, Djokovic would have to win in Paris. Most of his victories over the last half year have been comfortable or blowouts, or even unprecedented: no one has ever made Rafael Nadal look so ordinary on clay.

headline: Is College Overrated?
text: A technology entrepreneur named Peter Thiel is providing seed money to create start-up companies to 24 people under 20 who agree to drop out of school, partly because he believes that higher education is generally not worth the time and expense. To you, is college essential or overrated? Would you consider applying for one of the Thiel fellowships?

headline: In Prague, a New Spot for Men to Shop
text: In a world obsessed with all the latest fashion trends and styles for the ladies, it’s nice to know there’s someone looking out for the needs of the gentlemen. Contrary to popular belief, not all men hate shopping.

headline: The Early Word: In or Out
text: Today’s Times

headline: Super Bowl 25 Revisited: Giants vs. Bills
text: (This was inspired by a post by Chase Stuart on the Pro-Football-Reference blog dated March 28 entitled “Super Bowl XXV: Correcting the Narrative.” Twenty years later, I thought it might be a good time to look back at one of the best and most interesting games in N.F.L. history.)

headline: Three Things All LinkedIn Users Should Do
text: You probably didn’t get in on LinkedIn’s initial public stock offering last week, but the company can still get you something more stable than an investment in an Internet stock— a job. But there are three things a lot of LinkedIn users don’t seem to know that can help raise your chances of being recruited.

headline: Qaddafi Reportedly Stashes Billions in Western Institutions
text: PARIS — Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has stashed billions of dollars of Libyan oil revenues with financial institutions on Wall Street and in Europe, according to a document made public Thursday by an international advocacy group.

headline: Euro Crisis Looms for Group of 8
text: PARIS — The euro crisis hangs over the meeting of the Group of 8 industrialized countries that begins on Thursday, with Greece’s renewed problems destabilizing markets, worrying Washington and influencing the debate over who should be the next managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

headline: UBS Is Said to Be Weighing Move of Investment Bank
text: LONDON — As new rules to regulate banks take shape around the world, the banks are increasingly seeking ways to soften the impact.

headline: House Tour: Cheviot, N.Y.
text: HOW MUCH $649,000. Taxes: $6,317.

headline: Partnering With Companies That Sell Alcohol, Guns and Tobacco
text: A few years ago we were approached by Nomacorc, leaders in the production of synthetic wine corks, to run a “cork brigade.” We needed millions of corks at the time to create a cork board product that Office Max was ordering from us, and we concluded that wine, as controlled vices go, is rather innocuous. In the end, there wasn’t much internal debate, so we partnered rather quickly with the alcohol industry.

headline: Serbia Says Jailed Mladic Will Face War Crimes Trial
text: Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb general held responsible for the massacre of some 8,000 Muslim men and boys at Srebrenica in 1995, was arrested on Thursday, signaling Serbia’s intention of finally escaping the isolation it brought on itself during the Balkan wars, the bloodiest in Europe since World War II.

headline: The ‘Mediscare’ Revolving Door
text: How quickly the rhetoric can turn upside down in Washington.

headline: Spirit Airlines Shares Set for Takeoff
text: The I.P.O. market is not just technology companies.

headline: At On-Air Haven for Dissent, a Dissenting Voice Is Silenced
text: For nearly 20 years, an East Village journalist named Bill Weinberg has been a familiar late-night voice on the left-leaning radio station WBAI-FM (99.5), ruminating about radical politics, global turmoil and life in New York City.

headline: Q&A: Keeping Adobe Reader Secure
text: Q.

headline: Thursday Reading: Sedentary Jobs Contribute to Obesity
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Reports of a Shake-Up in the ‘X Factor’ Cast
text: On the night that one Fox reality show, “American Idol,” was ending its season, another Fox reality show, “The X Factor,” was aswirl in tabloid-ready developments.

headline: Amazon to Try Again on Lady Gaga Album Special
text: Amazon stumbled on Monday when it offered Lady Gaga’s new album in the MP3 format at 99 cents, a surprise one-day promotion that proved so popular it stalled the company’s servers. But on Thursday it is trying the promotion again, and promises that it will be prepared.

headline: Delphi Automotive Files for an I.P.O.
text: Delphi Automotive, the auto parts maker that languished in bankruptcy for years, filed late on Wednesday for an initial public offering.

headline: Seeing Things | C’est Superba
text: New York meets L.A. in “Superba,” an exhibition at J.F. Chen’s megaspace in Los Angeles. To mark their new collaboration, Joel Chen, the driving force behind one of the largest antique and vintage furniture stores in the city, and Paul Johnson of the Johnson Trading Gallery in Manhattan, which has an outpost in Chen’s space, have brought together an eclectic roster of 14 designers to show works that range from the primitive to the futuristic. Designers from Johnson’s stable, including Max Lamb, Simon Hasan and Kwangho Lee, joined Chen’s invitees, who include the architects Greg Lynn, Eddy Sykes (who was first featured in Seeing Things in 2008) and Aranda/Lasch, and the artists Yassi Mazandi and Mary Brogger.

headline: Raptr Wants to Kill Information Overload
text: When an idea gets hot in Silicon Valley, scores of entrepreneurs come up with me-too ideas to try to get some of the money sloshing around. Why else are there so many photo-sharing apps, geolocation services and social networks?

headline: To Avoid the Death Penalty, Kill Another Killer
text: Here’s how the death penalty works — or, to be more accurate, doesn’t work — in New York. It’s usually not about the killer, but rather the victim. The case against one Vincent Basciano in Federal District Court in Brooklyn may be no exception.

headline: Clijsters Exits in Second Round
text: PARIS — After her shocking loss Thursday at the French Open, Kim Clijsters did not blame the ankle that she injured while dancing at an April wedding. She did not use her five-year absence from Roland Garros as an excuse. Instead, she surprisingly cited a sudden lack of confidence midway through a second-round match that she was controlling against the world’s 114th-ranked player.

headline: Bhupathi and Paes Advance in Doubles
text: PARIS — Mahesh Bhupathi and Leander Paes of India got off to a slow start on a gray and windy afternoon, then kicked the accelerator, coasting away from Tommy Haas and Philipp Petzschner of Germany, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2.

headline: David Einhorn in Talks for Mets Stake
text: 9:56 a.m. | Updated David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager, is in exclusive negotiations to buy a minority stake in the New York Mets baseball team for $200 million.

headline: Querrey Falls Early in French Open, Again
text: PARIS – Sam Querrey has been down this road before.

headline: Indonesia’s Success Mixes Opportunity With Growth Pains
text: JAKARTA — For a lesson in the promise and pitfalls of Indonesia’s economic resurgence, hours stuck in traffic on Jalan H. R. Rasuna Said, one of the main thoroughfares here, is as good a start as any.

headline: Déjà Vu: On ‘Jimmy Fallon,’ a Fake Neil Young Gets Some Familiar Support
text: No matter what the “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon” announcer, Steve Higgins, says at the start of this clip, that is not — we repeat, Internet, not — Neil Young covering Miley Cyrus’s “Party in the U.S.A.” on the NBC program Thursday night: that’s Mr. Fallon himself, reprising his dead-on impersonation of that ornery folk-rocker. But be sure to stick around past the one-minute mark, when Mr. Fallon receives some harmonic support from a couple of Mr. Young’s real-life collaborators, Graham Nash and David Crosby. (And if that’s not the actual Mr. Crosby, we’re very much in favor of Wilford Brimley‘s new longhair look.) Catch you next time, Stephen Stills.

headline: Filmmaker J. J. Abrams Is a Crowd Teaser
text: Soon after taking the stage at the TED conference, where specially anointed trailblazers and titans are asked to explain their inspiration, J. J. Abrams made a crack about the television sensation that branded him one of the entertainment industry’s most tenacious keepers of secrets, a purveyor of sustained ambiguity above all else.

headline: Facebook Taps Joel Kaplan to Head Washington Office
text: In an effort to expand its power base in the nation’s capital, Facebook has hired Joel Kaplan, an executive vice president at the Texas utility giant Energy Future Holdings, to head the company’s office in Washington.

headline: Pushing Colleges to Become More Diverse
text: How can top colleges be persuaded to admit more talented low- and middle-income students? My column this week laid out a strategy for making colleges more economically diverse and meritocratic, based on policies at Amherst College and the University of California. But I didn’t spent much time on the politics of getting colleges to make changes. Fortunately, several other writers have done so — some today, in response to the column, and some long before.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

headline: Investors Upbeat Despite Troubling Data
text: Stocks gained for a second day as higher-than-estimated corporate profits at companies like Tiffany overshadowed data showing that the economy grew at a slower rate than forecast and jobless claims unexpectedly rose.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Missouri Makes Progress in Identifying Missing
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — The number of people unaccounted for in this tornado-ravaged city was reduced to more than 200 on Thursday from more than 1,500 earlier this week, and officials released their names for the first time to the public.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager and Mets Near a Deal
text: The owners of the Mets, who once declared they would not surrender any piece of their team, entered exclusive negotiations on Thursday to sell a chunk of it to David Einhorn, a prominent hedge fund manager.

headline: Under an Arizona Plan, Smokers and Obese Would Pay Fee for Medicaid
text: Arizona, like many others states, says it is no longer able to adequately finance its Medicaid program. As part of a plan to cut costs, the state has proposed imposing a $50 fee on childless adults on Medicaid who are either obese or who smoke. In Arizona, almost half of all Medicaid recipients smoke; while the number of obese people is unclear, about one-in-four Arizonans is overweight, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The state’s plan must ultimately be approved by the federal government. Monica Coury, spokeswoman for Arizona’s Medicaid program, discusses.

headline: Eataly’s Beer Garden Opens to the Sky; Soon, to the Public
text: You could not have picked a better evening than last night to exhibit the allure of Birreria, the rooftop beer garden at Eataly. At a preview party  for journalists and other invited guests,  Birreria’s retractable roof, rimmed with greenery, was open on a clear warm night to a great view of the clock on the Met Life tower across Madison Square Park.

headline: A Bosnian Serb General Who Loved the Cameras Returns to the Spotlight
text: Updated | 2:45 p.m. To journalists and investigators poring over brief snatches of video shot recently in Libya or Syria for possible evidence of war crimes committed this year, it comes as something of a shock to be confronted with footage from the 1990s shot by the television cameras that accompanied Ratko Mladic, then the commander of the Bosnian Serb Army, as he entered Srebrenica in 1995.

headline: Don’t Stop, Stevie Fans
text: A night of 1,000 Stevies in New York City.

headline: Poetry Pairing | May 26, 2011
text: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

headline: Marine Celebrating Fleet Week Is Killed by Car
text: The young Marine served in Afghanistan, surviving months of perils like sniper fire, mortar rounds and improvised explosive devices before returning to the United States and taking up quarters in the comparatively tranquil precincts of Camp Lejeune, on the North Carolina coast.

headline: New Video for Royal Ballet Blends Rock and Shakespeare
text: Ballet companies are trying ever harder to promote themselves through blogs and social media, but they often struggle to strike just the right note with that much-coveted younger, hipper audience. That’s exactly what Bennet Gartside, a first soloist for the Royal Ballet, is trying to do in the first of a series of promotional videos he is creating for the company’s Web site about the troupe’s coming performances of “Romeo and Juliet” June 17-19 at the O2 Arena — an enormous dome in southeast London that can hold up to 20,000 people. (Imagine American Ballet Theater briefly relocating to Madison Square Garden. Hmmm.)

headline: Clashes in Yemen Spread to Tribes Beyond Capital
text: SANA, Yemen — Yemen degenerated further into bloody conflict on Thursday as clashes beyond the capital drew in more tribal factions and threatened to widen the fighting between government forces and opposition tribesmen.

headline: A Muse in the Machine: Click. Create.
text: It seems almost unnecessary to introduce Cory Arcangel, the digital wunderkind, artist-musician and inveterate hacker whose exhibition, “Pro Tools,” has opened at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

headline: Artifacts | Lindsay Lohan, Art Star
text: Are you ready for the next art star? Even if it happens to be Lindsay Lohan?

headline: Man Sentenced in Cat Torture Case Involving DNA
text: In the city’s first cruelty case in which an animal’s DNA was used to win a conviction, a 20-year-old Brooklyn man was sentenced Wednesday to two to six years in prison for an attack in which a cat was doused with lighter fluid and set on fire in an empty apartment.

headline: Two New York City Police Officers Acquitted of Rape
text: A jury acquitted two New York police officers on Thursday of charges that they raped a drunken woman after helping her into her apartment while on patrol.

headline: Barnes & Noble Faces Tough Choices in a Buyout Vote
text: Jin Lee/Bloomberg NewsLeonard Riggio, Barnes & Noble’s chairman and largest shareholder.

text: BRUSSELS — Serbia, which was under heavy international pressure to find the accused war criminal Ratko Mladic after a fruitless chase stretching back more than 15 years, has gone a long way toward securing a path to a European future.

text: David EinhornDavid Einhorn, Mets fan, age 7.

headline: New System Hands Reins to Complaint Board Lawyer
text: The historic significance of the moment was easy to miss: On the fourth floor of 1 Police Plaza on Tuesday, an internal administrative trial against two city police officers appeared to be just another case in the annals of alleged wrongdoing.

text: 4:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Q. and A. on the Nitrogen Cycle
text: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, studied microbes in the nitrogen cycle from off the coast of Chile. In this post, she answers readers’ questions about her recent expedition.

headline: Americans Make Presence Felt at Roland Garros
text: PARIS — Without the Williams sisters and Andy Roddick in the French Open, it may have taken some jingoistic optimism to think that three Americans would reach the third round.

headline: South Sudan Leader Tries to Calm Tempers Over Disputed Territory
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Salva Kiir Mayardit, president of the breakaway region of southern Sudan, declared on Thursday that he would not go to war over the disputed Abyei territory, which Sudanese tanks and troops seized Saturday.

headline: A Scene From 'The Tree of Life'
text: A scene from "The Tree of Life," directed by Terrence Malick with production design by Jack Fisk.

headline: The Daughter Test

headline: Pentagon Plans to Consolidate Military Health Records
text: For many years, service members who were leaving the military had to worry about whether their medical records would be properly transferred from one vast computer network in the Defense Department to another, in the Department of Veterans Affairs.

headline: Heaven, Texas and the Cosmic Whodunit
text: The Day of Judgment, prophesied for last weekend, has apparently been postponed, but moviegoers eager for rapture can find consolation — to say nothing of awe, amazement and grist for endless argument — in “The Tree of Life,” Terrence Malick’s new film, which contemplates human existence from the standpoint of eternity. Recently showered with temporal glory at the Cannes Film Festival, where it won the Palme d’Or, this movie, Mr. Malick’s fifth feature in 38 years, folds eons of cosmic and terrestrial history into less than two and a half hours. Its most provocative sequences envision the origin of the universe, the development of life on earth (including a few soulful dinosaurs) and then, more concisely and less literally, the end of time, when the dead of all the ages shall rise and walk around on a heavenly beach.
