headline: When Life Throws Those Curveballs
text: IN the wake of his frankly autobiographical new film, "Beginners," the writer and director Mike Mills has found himself frequently encountering the kindness — and the curiosity — of strangers. “It’s a very sweet and often problematic situation where people feel like they know me and they’re concerned for me,” he said by phone from Los Angeles recently. “It creates these strange little intimate moments.”

headline: You Meet the Nicest Sportbikes in the 250cc Neighborhood
text: NOBODY should be surprised to learn that Honda has the know-how to build a smooth, light, easy-to-manage motorcycle that is ideal for novice riders.

headline: In Pilsen, Beer’s Not the Only Thing on Tap
text: ON a recent, unseasonably hot spring day in Pilsen, Czech Republic, the shadowy emptiness of the city’s Great Synagogue offered a welcome cool and quiet respite from the blinding, scorching sun. Inside, a handful of tourists wandered the halls, climbing the steps to the upper level, trying to capture the spirit of the vast space of the synagogue — said to be the third largest in the world — in snapshots.

headline: Venturing Out in Pilsen, Czech Republic
text: Pilsen has cleaned itself up and opened several wonderful new attractions. The result is a worthwhile destination for visitors.

headline: McConnell Downplays Politics of Medicare
text: Senator Mitch McConnell knows one of the golden rules of politics: when your friends are down, do some punching on their behalf.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Governors Island turns into one big picnic on Sunday and Monday from noon to 5 p.m. (V.I.P. entrance is at 11 a.m.) for the Brewers’ Pic-NYC event, part of this year’s Meatopia festivities. There will be street food — including vendors like Fette Sau, Luke’s Lobster and Asia Dog — and beer sold at Colonels’ Row. Plates of food will be $2 to $10 and beer is $6. Tickets are $15 and proceeds will benefit Added Value farms.

headline: The Many Shades of Wayne
text: AS Father’s Day draws nigh, the studios traditionally shake out their libraries for films presumed to have paternal appeal — pipe-and-slippers movies, suitable for showing on big-screen TVs in wood-paneled dens.

headline: Champions League Final … Graphically Speaking
text: Saturday brings the “dream final” in what some people like to call a “massive game,” perhaps the two best teams in the world — Manchester United and Barcelona — on the verdant grass of Wembley Stadium in London.

headline: No Crumbs or Icing, Just Grapes
text: WHEN “Sex and the City” ended its run in 2004 as one of HBO’s most successful series, seemingly every network tried to recapture the show’s lighthearted, feminine formula.

headline: May 29 — June 4
text: Art

headline: Sussing Out the Other Matchups of the N.B.A. Finals
text: On the biggest stage of the N.B.A. playoffs, the spotlight will shine bright on the finals’ most riveting, star-studded matchups. How the Dallas Mavericks contend with LeBron James and Dwyane Wade, and how the Miami Heat defend against Dirk Nowitzki will go under the microscope; the highly competitive games to come will lead to an insane amount of dissection and analysis, and the magnitude of talent focused in the stars of both teams will naturally draw all attention to them.

headline: At a Protest In Cairo, One Group Is Missing
text: CAIRO — Tens of thousands of mostly liberal protesters again filled Tahrir Square on Friday to press for an assortment of demands in a demonstration billed as “The Revolution Part II, ” but perhaps most notable for the absence of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Book Review Podcast:  David McCullough and Gretchen Morgenson
text: This week the historian David McCullough talks about his new book, “The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris;” the business reporter Gretchen Morgenson, co-author of  “Reckless Endangerment,” describes the causes of the Wall Street implosion; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

headline: Robin Rusch and Thomas Heberer
text: WHETHER bartending, dishwashing or working at a foreign record label to support her world travels, Robin Dolphé Rusch had a habit of making it up as she went along. So it wasn’t surprising that she fell for someone who makes a business of improvisation.

headline: Easing Out the Gray-Haired. Or Not.
text: As the managing partner of a top Los Angeles law firm, Norman H. Levine is no stranger to what might be called the Posada problem.

headline: It’s Not the Pictures That Got Small
text: Sports Illustrated featured this striking picture across two pages last week. It’s quite winning in a couple of senses. Not only does it capture the strike, ball in midflight, that would win Manchester City its first championship (England’s F.A. Cup) in more than three decades, it is also rather charming. This tends to happen when a photographer uses a tilt-shift lens. It does funky things to a picture’s focus and turns its subjects into miniature versions of themselves — into toy figurines, really.

headline: Wawrinka Comes Back to Beat Tsonga
text: PARIS – Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland hit two aces to reach two match points but Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France refused to fold until Wawrinka slashed an inside-out forehand into a corner for a comeback five-set victory, 4-6, 6-7 (3), 7-6 (5), 6-2, 6-3, on Friday at the French Open.

headline: Investment Advice for Small Fry
text: Most of us have no business managing our own investments.

headline: The Right Model for Lower Cost Investment Management
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I take a look at Betterment and Flat Fee Portfolios. These are the latest efforts to bring investment management to the merely six-figured — the people who many fancier wealth managers no longer want to help.

headline: Band of Outsiders
text: If indeed diamonds are forever, you’ll want to make sure you don’t get stuck with a boring one. The Lucifer Vir Honestus collection of one-of-a-kind engagement rings is a subtly sparkling antidote to all those sterile solitaires. The rings are around $9,000 at Barneys New York.

headline: Perceiving the Anthropocene
text: The excellent science writer Oliver Morton has written a captivating feature for the Economist exploring the hypothesis that Earth has entered a new geological epoch of our making, the Anthropocene. It has a gem of a closing “kicker”:

headline: Accustomed to Bad News, Joplin Chaplain Takes It Personally This Time
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — In Bob Heath’s 20 years as a police chaplain, he has stood on the doorsteps of hundreds of families to deliver the worst possible news: that their loved one has died. He has tended to the frayed psyches of victims of natural disasters like the one in Gulfport, Miss., after Hurricane Katrina. He has led training seminars around the country in the delicate art of death notification.

headline: One Case as Big as It Gets, and One Now in Its Shadow
text: The comment tickled a reporter standing nearby. In the lobby of the Manhattan Criminal Courts building, a few hours before a bail hearing for Dominique Strauss-Kahn last week, a television reporter told David Bookstaver, the spokesman for the Office of Court Administration, that everyone says good things about him.

headline: Key to a Successful Fraud Defense: A Red Hanky
text: Raymond Craig Brubaker can thank his lawyer’s red hanky, and some aggressive questioning, for his freedom.

headline: Fox’s Fresh Fare a Winner as Rerun Season Begins
text: As summer repeats arrived on Thursday night for much of network television, the lone exception led the evening as 9.1 million viewers tuned in to Fox’s eighth-season premiere of “So You Think You Can Dance,” according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although technically tied with CBS’s rerun of “The Mentalist” at 10, and excluding cable ratings for TNT’s coverage of the N.B.A. playoffs, the two-hour premiere lifted Fox to No. 1 on the night among the four main television networks while attracting the series’ largest audience for the start of a season in four years.

headline: Animal Kingdom Will Run in the Belmont
text: Horse racing is halfway to a Triple Crown rubber match after the trainer of Animal Kingdom said Friday that the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom would come to New York for the Belmont Stakes.

headline: Battle For Libya | May 27, 2011
text: NATO on Friday accused forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, of placing landmines around the rebel-held city of Misrata to prevent the population from moving.

headline: A Fugitive in Their Midst? ‘Ridiculous,’ Villagers Say
text: LAZAREVO, Serbia — This village near the Romanian border is Everytown, an indistinguishable collection of tidy lawns and trimmed trees, where the local people have been rocked by the news that Ratko Mladic, one of the world’s most wanted war crimes suspects, had been found hiding out among them.

headline: Hotel Review: The nhow in Berlin
text: THE UPSHOT

headline: Restaurant Report: Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen, in San Francisco
text: A real-deal Jewish deli in San Francisco has always been as tough to come by as a California-style burrito in Manhattan. There have been a few fleeting attempts, but none have stuck. Leo Beckerman and Evan Bloom aim to change that with Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen. The pop-up restaurant, which made its debut in January, is open only on Saturdays, when they take over the Beast and the Hare restaurant.

headline: Lake Geneva as Shelley and Byron Knew It
text: SWITZERLAND is rarely thought of as a wild artistic center. Most of us recall the harsh verdict of Harry Lime, the character played by Orson Welles in “The Third Man,” who declared that the country’s most creative achievement was the cuckoo clock.

headline: Collecting Wellfleet Oysters With the Best
text: IT would be understandable if one confused a slimy, barnacle-covered rock with an unopened oyster. At least, that’s what I told myself. For the last half-hour, my husband and I had been ranging over the seabed looking for oysters on Burton Baker Beach, a quiet stretch of bay nestled in the calm of Wellfleet Harbor. But so far I had found more oyster-esque rocks than actual oysters.

headline: In Former Soviet Georgia, Two Families and the Art of Hospitality
text: FIRST the roasted eggplant arrived, topped with walnut paste and pomegranate seeds, followed by seared red peppers glistening with oil, and a salad of cucumbers and tomatoes, scattered with herbs. Then bread from a nearby kiln, a soul mate for the homemade cheese, which was akin to mozzarella with a sour kick. The two women of the house soon shuttled in with carafes of red and white wine, squeezed from grapes tended on the surrounding land and coaxed to life in cisterns out back. It was a fine finale — or so we thought — for our first lunch at a small farmstead in Georgia, the fertile backyard of the former Soviet Union.

headline: Marking the 50th Anniversary of the Berlin Wall
text: “NO one has the intention to build a wall,” Walter Ulbricht, the leader of East Germany’s ruling Socialist Unity Party, declared on June 15, 1961. Later that summer, just past midnight on Aug. 13, the Berlin Wall began to go up — so stealthily that historians still cannot agree where the first brick was laid. Twenty-nine years later, Germany reunified and the wall became a symbol lost to history.

headline: Shopping in Amsterdam’s Jordaan Section
text: In Amsterdam, the Jordaan neighborhood offers ambitious goods in small spaces.

headline: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
text: ON April 3, inspired by the essay by Paul Theroux titled “Why We Travel,” we asked readers to submit essays of their own to answer this question. Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. On May 1 we published three. Here are four more that illustrate the vast range of our readers’ experiences.

headline: Letters: Saving on Gas
text: To the Editor: Regarding “13 Ways to Save on Gas This Summer” (Practical Traveler, May 15): Save money overall by not buying a huge SUV that you use in everyday life to drive a few people a mile here or there, because you really want to make sure you have that huge SUV for your family road trip. Rent one for the road trip if it is necessary instead, and you’ll save on gas the rest of the year. I also recommend keeping track of traffic patterns. I just drove through the night 800 miles one way and, during the day, back home (another 800 miles). The night trip was much, much faster because of the lack of traffic and fewer stops for gas.

headline: Home Cooking in Georgia (Not That One)
text: In Kakheti, booming agritourism ventures offer a chance to see how private farming has revived since the end of Communism.

headline: Shores of Romance and Scandal
text: Finding the poetry and pleasures of Lake Geneva.

headline: On the Farm, After the Fall
text: A trip to the post-Soviet republic of Georgia where agritourism draws visitors eager to help out with the farm chores and reap the bounty at the dinner table.

headline: Tempting Fate and Tolkien Purists, Peter Jackson Adds Orlando Bloom to ‘The Hobbit’
text: Would you cast someone to play Anna Karenina in a film version of “War and Peace”? Bring in Tom Joad to spruce up your “Of Mice and Men” movie? Or add Jack Pumpkinhead to the roster of “The Wizard of Oz”? Probably not if you know what’s good for you, but that hasn’t discouraged Peter Jackson from risking the wrath of the literary-adaptation gods by announcing that he has added his “Lord of the Rings” star Orlando Bloom to the cast of his “Hobbit” movies, even though Mr. Bloom’s character, the elf Legolas, doesn’t appear in J. R. R. Tolkien’s original “Hobbit” novel.

headline: A Stronger Aer Lingus Says It Is Ready to Fly Solo
text: DUBLIN — Christoph Mueller, the chief executive of Aer Lingus, accompanied the Irish prime minister, Enda Kenny, and other officials on Friday on a flight aboard a restored 1936 De Havilland Dragon to observe the 75th anniversary of the airline’s first scheduled service.

headline: Rockaway Boardwalk Buffet Confirmed
text: The cornucopia of new food offerings at Rockaway Beach is finally confirmed. Mostly.

headline: Conjoined Twins: Brain Imaging
text: Several commenters responding to Susan Dominus’s story about Krista and Tatiana Hogan said that they would be interested in seeing images of the girls’ unusual neural anatomy. Here is a brain image provided to The Times by the twins’ neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Children’s Hospital. The attenuated line stretching between the two organs is what he refers to as the “thalamic bridge” that may allow them to share sensory perception.

headline: Summer Sandal: Espadrille
text: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#96", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

headline: Answers About Pip and Violet, Part 3
text: This week, Dr. Elizabeth Bunting, a wildlife veterinarian at the Animal Health Diagnostic Center at Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine, and other experts have been responding to readers’ questions about Pip, the red-tailed hawk hatchling, or eyas, who emerged from the egg on May 6 in a nest on a 12th-floor ledge at New York University — and about Pip’s mother, Violet, about whose injured leg many of you have expressed concern.

headline: Decisions, Decisions
text: The 2011 Ford Edge Sport poses a question to drivers: When it comes to technology, is there such a thing as too many options?

headline: David LaChapelle: An Unexpected Life
text: HE was hired by Andy Warhol. He fired Madonna. He photographed Pamela Anderson and Lady Gaga and also Hillary Clinton, and made a star of the transgender apparition Amanda Lepore.

headline: If You’re Keen on Quinoa
text: If you enjoy cooking with quinoa (pronounced keen-wah), then you’ll be interested to learn how to use it best. This week Martha Rose Shulman explores the proper uses of this popular grain.

headline: Officials: No Need to Protect Bluefin Tuna Under Species Act
text: The Atlantic bluefin tuna, while under pressure from intensive fishing, does not need protection under the Endangered Species Act, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has concluded.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $15,150,000
text: It was a horse race for this week’s biggest sale, with the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helú paying $15.5 million for a town house in Midtown and the prominent philanthropist Laurie M. Tisch closing on the sale of her co-op at the Brentmore on Central Park West for $15.15 million.

headline: Ferguson Upbeat for Much-Anticipated Champions League Matchup
text: LONDON – Even Sir Alex Ferguson, the Scottish coaching legend with the stellar record and droll disposition, seemed eager to see what hundreds of millions are expected to watch.

headline: Lipsky Talks Debt and I.M.F. Leadership
text: John Lipsky, the acting managing director of the International Monetary Fund, talks about how the organization is working with Greek authorities on handling that country’s debt situation, as well as the I.M.F.’s plans for picking a new head, in an interview with CNBC.

headline: Palin Releases Video Ahead of Bus Tour
text: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, released this video on the Web site of her political action committee on Friday, two days ahead of the beginning of a bus tour through the country.

headline: Fiat Plans to Buy Treasury’s Stake in Chrysler
text: From our colleagues at DealBook:

headline: Officials in Germany Support Closing 7 Nuclear Plants
text: FRANKFURT — Seven nuclear power plants in Germany that were shut down after the Fukushima disaster in Japan are likely to be closed permanently after a decision Friday by state environment ministers.

headline: For Those About to Rock (and Race), Brian Johnson Salutes You
text: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., — One thousand fans waited outside the small venue on a muggy May night, anticipating the arrival of Brian Johnson, the lead singer of AC/DC. On this night, though, Mr. Johnson would work without the scorching guitar accompaniment from the brothers Angus and Malcolm Young, or the throttling rhythm from bassist Cliff Williams and drummer Phil Rudd.

headline: It’s Meat for Beer … or Beer for Meat
text: A brewer and a butcher are teaming up as part of efforts by the beer maker to encourage consumers to think about its lager as an alternative to wine when eating beef.

headline: Death Stills Laughter of the Seaport’s Jolly Old Elf
text: Santa Claus has died.

headline: TimesCast | May 27, 2011
text: Palestinians look forward to Saturday, when Egypt plans to open its border with Gaza; and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi avoids continuous NATO bombings.

headline: Amazon Has Forecasters Rethinking Lady Gaga
text: The sales estimates for Lady Gaga’s new album keep going up and up. The latest projection: 1.15 million, according to the data-crunchers at Billboard magazine, which would make it the fastest-selling album in at least six years.

headline: Look of the Moment | Jessica Chastain
text: The Look: Ray of Light – muted green tones are enriched with a burst of neon chartreuse providing a bold, but balanced contrast.The Girl: Jessica Chastain, one of the stars of “The Tree of Life,” which won this year’s Cannes Film Festival’s Palme d’Or award, at the film’s premiere at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

headline: Jeff Conaway, Actor In ‘Taxi,’ Is Dead at 60
text: Jeff Conaway, the personable actor who won television fame on the sitcom “Taxi” and movie success in the musical “Grease” three decades ago and who later publicly struggled with drug and alcohol abuse, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

headline: The Morning Line: Waiting on Shackleford
text: The Triple Crown news focuses on the fact that Shackleford, the winner of the Preakness, seems more likely than not to run in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday June 11. Shackleford is headed for the Big Apple with the Blood-Horse writing “Shackleford is expected to ship to New York in the next couple of days and will have a workout over the Belmont track before a final decision is made about running in the June 11 Belmont Stakes.”

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Submarine'
text: Richard Ayoade, the director of "Submarine," discusses a scene from his film about an awkward teenager and his first love.

headline: This Sunday: Our Thing for Twins
text: I don’t always highlight the magazine’s cover stories because, well, they’re on the cover. Of course, we think they’re brilliant and worth every minute of your Sunday morning (or whenever). But this week’s cover story, about conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan, deserves every extra little bit of attention I can bring to it. I expect that the cover picture will make some people squeamish. But I urge those of you who feel that way to get past it and read Susan Dominus’s powerful story. It won’t make you feel bad, I promise. It’s a story about the richness and complexity of human life. There really is something miraculous about these girls, and though the challenges they face are daunting, this is the life they have to live, and it is not without joy and love.

headline: Analysis: Federer Goes On the Attack
text: Roger Federer defeated Janko Tipsarevic in straight sets, mauling the feisty Serb with pinpoint serving and aggressive all-court tennis. Tipsarevic has a penchant for scoring upsets in Grand Slams, but Federer broke serve early in the first and played with great variety and imagination to run away with an easy victory.

headline: A Tangle of Details Emerge in an Insider Trading Case
text: 6:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: Israelis Differ on ‘Defensible Borders’
text: The ongoing dispute about whether or not it is permissible for supporters of Israel to even refer to the country’s 1967 borders as one element in future negotiations with the Palestinians obscures the fact that some Israelis disagree strongly with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s view that a country with those frontiers would be “indefensible.”

headline: The Long Goodbye
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Wrenching Documentary
text: Farrah Fawcett’s documentary about her struggle with cancer was received as a seminal moment in television history when it was broadcast in May 2009.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Sudan, Spain, Somalia and Libya.

headline: Denver Crosses Lacrosse’s Great Divide
text: Denver lacrosse fans gathered on campus and at local restaurants last weekend to watch the Pioneers defeat Johns Hopkins in an N.C.A.A. tournament quarterfinal in Hempstead, N.Y. But the most emotional viewing party took place on the team’s bus ride to the airport after clinching its first berth in the semifinals.

headline: This Week’s Business News in Photos
text: Law firms’ second-tier workers, Sony’s struggles, Chinese utilities’ government defiance, the pursuit of the I.M.F.’s top job and more.

headline: Growing Funnier Each Serious Minute
text: SEVERAL years ago Harvey Weinstein came across an obscure British television comedy called “Garth Marenghi’s Darkplace” — an absurdist series that ran for just six episodes in 2004 before it was canceled. The show, set in the 1980s, was a parodic combination of gory sci-fi horror and medical soap opera, and Mr. Weinstein, who was then co-chairman of Miramax, dreamed of bringing the title to America. “I thought it was the funniest, coolest thing,” he recalled recently, on the phone from the Cannes Film Festival. “I went over to London to try and buy the show and convince the guys to do a movie of it.”

headline: Chic in Review | A Royal Coup for Tom Ford
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 27
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: A Classmate Feels the Pressure
text: THE 250cc sportbike class is a small group, but the Honda CBR250R is not its only admirable member. The Kawasaki Ninja 250R has been around since 1986, and with regular updates through the years it has long been a favorite of smaller riders, women and students in Motorcycle Safety Foundation RiderCourses.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 27
text: More Photographs

headline: Avoiding Legal Problems When Managing a Household Staff
text: HOUSEKEEPERS have been in the news lately. Look no further than former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, who recently admitted that he had a child more than 10 years ago with his former housekeeper.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Sudan, Spain, Somalia and Libya.

headline: On Our Radar: Habitat Loss and Climate Change Imperil Koala
text: Habitat loss, climate change and disease are taking a toll on Australia’s koalas, prompting a call by wildlife experts to declare the species endangered. A parliamentary committee is assessing scientific evidence on the species, which is difficult to count in the wild. “This species is supposed to be common, yet it’s slipping to extinction under our noses,” a conservationist says. [The Independent]

headline: A Reminder on How to Treat the Household Staff
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, discusses the mistakes made by people who employ household help — anyone from housekeepers and nannies to chefs, butlers and estate managers. Nor is this an issue just for the wealthy anymore, Paul writes, because many two-income couples rely on an array of workers to keep their households going.

headline: On the Street | Snow Days
text: While fashion has evolved from its rigid dictates, it’s as true today as it ever was: after Memorial Day, white rules.

headline: TimesCast | Egypt-Gaza Border to Open
text: May 27, 2011 - Palestinians look forward to Saturday, when Egypt plans to open its border with Gaza.

headline: The Youngest Kindergartners
text: Kindergarten cutoff dates in 2010 and 1975 in the United States.

headline: TimesCast | Qaddafi Remains Elusive
text: May 27, 2011 - Three days after NATO's heaviest bombing of Tripoli, Libya, Col. Muammar Qaddafi remains elusive.

headline: U.S. Declines to Protect the Overfished Bluefin Tuna
text: The Obama administration said on Friday that it had declined to grant Endangered Species Act protections to the Atlantic bluefin tuna, whose numbers have declined precipitously because of overfishing on both sides of the ocean.

headline: A Tribute to the Past, Visions of the Future
text: When a school is a training ground for a company, its performances offer an interesting opportunity to see the way technique and performance styles are forged. On Wednesday night the Alvin Ailey School presented its Spring Celebration Concert at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, and the senior students who took pride of place were remarkable for the ardent sincerity of their demeanor as well as the excellence of their dancing.

headline: New Kids: One Behaved, One, Eh
text: You can dress unruly children in Sunday clothes for church, but that doesn’t mean they won’t fidget throughout the service. Or does it? On Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall, the Tribeca New Music Festival presented two fascinating chamber ensembles built around the electric guitar: a relative newcomer to the concert-music sphere, still reluctant to curb its exuberance or disguise its roots in popular idioms. One behaved; the other, not so much.

headline: In Iowa, Romney Hears Applause, and Alarms
text: 10:06 p.m. | Updated  DES MOINES – Mitt Romney’s first Iowa campaign visit of the year was not foiled by controversial subjects on Friday afternoon, but by a bag of burned microwave popcorn.

headline: David Leonhardt on Signs of Economic Weakness; the Rise of Groupon; the Docile Bond Market
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with David Leonhardt on signs of economic weakness, Phyllis Korkki and David Streitfeld on the rise of Groupon, Tyler Cowen on prospects for driverless cars. Also, the docile bond market.

headline: Puttanesca Sauce Dressed for Spring
text: PUTTANESCA is a sauce that plies its trade all year round, heedless of the season. The ingredients — pantry staples including canned tomatoes, capers, anchovies, garlic, red pepper flakes and olives — are at the ready whenever the desire strikes.

headline: Jewelers Who Faked a Robbery Are Given Prison Time
text: The diamond dealers convicted in March of a Hollywood-worthy insurance scam in which they hired men to dress up as Hasidic Jews and stage a robbery of their store were given a prison sentence on Friday of one and two-thirds years to five years.

headline: American Arrested for Insulting Thai King
text: BANGKOK — An American citizen has been arrested in Thailand and accused of insulting the country’s monarchy in the latest in a string of cases highlighting the strict and controversial laws protecting the ailing king.

headline: Dickey May Not Miss a Start Despite Foot Injury
text: Pitcher R. A. Dickey partly tore the plantar fascia on his right foot when he ran off the mound to cover first base on Thursday, the Mets said. But Dickey, who was walking without a protective boot or crutch, said Friday that he still hoped to make his next start on Tuesday and avoid an assignment to the disabled list.

headline: A Candidate Fights a Contested Legacy in Peru
text: Keiko Fujimori, daughter of currently incarcerated former President Alberto K. Fujimori, is in a tight race for the Peruvian presidency.

headline: Rubber City Classic
text: A 1917 roadster built by Ralph Mulford, whose testimony in a patent lawsuit helped save the tire industry in Akron, has become the passion of one Ohio man.

headline: A Second Fujimori Contends for Peru’s Presidency
text: LIMA, Peru

headline: A Towering Perspective on Libya
text: The first thing people tend to notice about Bryan Denton is that he is tall — very tall. There’s a reason for mentioning this, and we’ll get back to it before long. First, let’s talk about about Bryan and his work, and the year he is having.

headline: Paying Respects, in Palace and Ghetto
text: WARSAW — For every foreign leader, a visit to Poland involves paying respects at the memorials to the country’s tragic past. It was no different for President Obama, who landed here on Friday and made his way immediately to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

headline: Metropolitan Preview: Summer 2011
text: Memorial Day already?

headline: Hungarian Tradition, African Lilt
text: The recital that the Moroccan pianist Marouan Benabdallah gave at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, his American debut, was naturally a personal milestone for this 29-year-old artist. From the demanding program he played, with nearly two hours of virtuoso works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, he seemed determined to make a strong impression.

headline: Behind the Scenes, Action and Angst
text: For decades Hollywood’s sick soul has provided cannon fodder for novelists and screenwriters. With “Cut,” a Horse Trade Theater Group and Management Theater Company production at Under St. Marks, the playwright Crystal Skillman presents a modest “Hurlyburly” for our time, taking aim at reality television, as deserving a target — with as Orwellian a name — as show business currently offers.

headline: The Art of the Videogame
text: The artwork that goes into today’s videogames can be museum-worthy. Many game scenes look completely photorealistic, created with crisp high-end graphics; others are highly stylized cartoon-like visuals. Some games even contain scenes that are beautifully painted by hand.

headline: A Dandy Defensive Coup That Few Players Would Find
text: When a tennis player is at the top of his game, he is said to be in the zone. Expert bridge players experience that also, just knowing where all of the cards are lying. Richie Coren (East) of Delray Beach, Fla., found the “zonal” play in the diagramed deal from a game in Florida this month.

headline: Waiting for the New Mobile Payments Frontier
text: The mobile phone will eventually take over your wallet, replacing your credit cards, cash and coupons. But it could be some time before this new type of transaction becomes an everyday reality.

headline: Reviewing the Ford Edge Sport
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, John R. Quain reviews the Ford Edge Sport. For 2011, the popular crossover received a revised front fascia, more robust brakes and the stout V-6 from the base-level Mustang. Ford, however, also wants to train attention on the latest version of MyFord Touch, one of the most advanced in-car computer control systems on the market.

headline: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Orphans on the Edge
text: I flew to Kinshasa in order to help a man help a boy. Scott Sherman and his family had recently adopted a four-year-old boy from an orphanage in the capital city of the Democratic Republic of Congo. When Scott’s son arrived in the States, he was severely underweight, suffering from a variety of illnesses, and indicated that he had been sexually abused at the orphanage where he’d lived. Scott’s son told his new parents that one other boy, Moise, had tried to protect him from the abuse. Scott and his family asked me if I could try and help find a better situation for Moise.

headline: French Press
text: There were a lot of shockers this week.

headline: The Week in Pictures for May 27
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a quaint antiques shop in the East Village, a dilapidated castle on the Hudson River, and a special Congressional election in upstate New York.

headline: Hawk Cam | What Is Pip Saying?
text: Caption contest!

headline: A Narrative Has Many Blanks
text: IF eons of nature and decades of culture have made anything clear, it is that all creation is more or less a collage. You know, recombinant DNA. XX times XY. Boy meets girl. “Annie” meets “Aliens.”

headline: Romanticism, Tone Paintings and Modern Takes on Folk Tunes
text: The New Amsterdam Singers have explored music ranging from 15th-century sacred works to modern secular pieces in the 40 years since Clara Longstreth founded the group, and the choir’s performances have always been spirited and finely polished. The group’s real charm, though, is its passion for contemporary American music. Having built relationships with choral composers around the country, Ms. Longstreth has made a point of building smart thematic programs around their work.

headline: Violinists, Plugged in, Bow, Pluck and Twang
text: For the final two weeks of May the programming at the Stone has been in the hands of Philip Blackburn, the director of the enterprising, polyglot record label Innova. Mr. Blackburn’s idea was to present 24 one-hour concerts by musicians who record for Innova, and on Wednesday evening he offered, as hours 13 and 14, what he called “the fiddler’s hoedown from hell”: back-to-back recitals by Ana Milosavljevic and Todd Reynolds, violinists for whom amplification and sound processing are integral to music-making.

headline: Decoding Woody Allen’s ‘Midnight in Paris’
text: Many a writer or artist has longed to travel back in time to the sizzling Paris of the 1920s, to sip absinthe with Hemingway at Les Deux Magots or dine on choucroute garnie with Picasso at La Rotonde. Imagine the conversation! What has beguiled audiences about the new Woody Allen movie, “Midnight in Paris,” is that the protagonist, Gil, a disenchanted Hollywood screenwriter played by Owen Wilson, gets to live exactly that fantasy.

headline: Youth, With Hopes and Bliss Intact
text: All over the world, teenage boys and young men are a problem. With their irrepressible energies and strengths, they are always ripe for industrial, military and other kinds of services. But when they are uneducated, unemployed and unsupervised, many of them get into trouble. They join feral gangs and terrorist groups or become freelance criminals, dissipated addicts, deadbeat fathers, suicides.

headline: Podcast: Signs of Economic Weakness, Groupon’s Rise and Driverless Cars
text: Drawing an accurate picture of an entity as complex and changeable as the modern economy is no simple matter.

headline: Sadaf & Dan
text: In this reader-submitted video, Daniel Sheffield recalls not knowing whether the business card Sadaf Jaffer gave him after dinner one night was an invitation for a date.

headline: Sadaf Jaffer and Daniel Sheffield
text: Sadaf Fatemah Jaffer and Daniel Jensen Sheffield were married Tuesday at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. Rizwan Rizvi, an imam, officiated.

headline: Movie Watching Is a Scavenger Hunt
text: Did you hear about the jeweler who opened up a shop but wouldn’t accept cash, checks or credit cards?

headline: Analysis: Who Will Fill the Void in the Women’s Game?
text: What does the ousting of the two top seeds in the women’s draw say about the state of the women’s game as we head into the second week of Roland Garros? Does the desultory showing of both Kim Clijsters and Caroline Wozniacki mean that the tour is foundering? Is the tour rudderless, adrift in a sea of mediocrity, or is this a time of exciting new players on the cusp of stardom?

headline: In the Hip-Hop World, Blogs Mean Business
text: Rick Ross has old friends, and Rick Ross has new friends.

headline: Recently Fresh Fruit, Given a Chance to Ripen
text: The best part about Keys to the Future, an unassuming but wide-ranging festival of contemporary solo piano music, isn’t hearing things for the first time. It’s hearing them again.

headline: The PT Boat Is Real, but Sham the Torpedoes
text: ABOARD PT-728, off Lower Manhattan — Capt. Tom Whyte issued only one order all morning, and there were very good reasons why that one order was not “damn the torpedoes” or “lower the depth charge,” but “Timmy, cover your ears.”

headline: Once Again, U.S. Finds China Isn’t Manipulating Its Currency
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday afternoon that China was not manipulating the value of its currency, choosing once again to avoid any escalation in the long-running trade dispute between the two countries.

headline: Ball Marks, Not Instant Replays, Are Final Word
text: PARIS — It happens in almost every match, and sometimes several times. A ball hits the court. A line judge makes a call. A player disagrees.

headline: Judge Voids Ban on Campaign Donations by Business
text: A federal judge in Virginia has declared unconstitutional a century-old law banning political contributions from corporations, a ruling that, if upheld, could have major implications for the rules governing campaign fund-raising and spending.

headline: Winner of Derby Will Run in Belmont
text: Horse racing is halfway to a Triple Crown rubber match after the trainer of Animal Kingdom, the Kentucky Derby winner, said that the colt would come to New York for the Belmont Stakes.

headline: The World This Week
text: A look at Barack Obama's European tour thus far.

headline: When Medicare Spending Is Wasteful
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Mideast Conflict: What Should the U.S. Do?
text: To the Editor:

headline: App Smart Extra: Woodstock on a App
text: Live music fans can use their mobile devices to scout out new artists locally or search for the next Woodstock, as this week’s App Smart column points out.

headline: The Arrest of Mladic
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nigeria: 70 Suspected Militants Kill Six People in Multiple Attacks
text: About 70 gunmen suspected of being Islamic militants attacked two police stations and a bank in the northeastern city of Maiduguri on Friday, killing six people, the police said. The attackers were armed with explosives and automatic rifles, which they used to attack multiple targets in the Damboa district, said Mohammed Abubakar, the police commissioner in charge of the region. Four police officers and two civilians were killed in the attack, he said. The authorities in Nigeria’s north have blamed Boko Haram, a radical Islamic sect that draws inspiration from Afghanistan’s Taliban movement, for a spate of bomb attacks and killings aimed at government officials and the security forces since last year.

headline: Gay Marriage Studies, and Coverage of Gay Issues
text: To the Editor:

headline: For Some Eighth Graders, Belated Good News
text: This time when Radcliffe Saddler got his envelope at school on Friday afternoon, it was thin and feather-light, and he sensed it was good news. It also meant the end of a painful process that weighed on his family and occupied nearly his entire eighth-grade year.

headline: A Day Off at the Monaco Grand Prix
text: MONACO – Friday is the down day in Monaco, with no track action and an almost empty paddock. Well, not quite. Today it has turned into a kind of Cannes festival Part II. Cannes ended last week, but I heard today that Leonardo DiCaprio is somewhere around here in Monaco. Kim Kardashian, the socialite and actress, and the New Jersey Nets forward Kris Humphries have also been around, and today we also had the Spanish model Esther Canadas completely sucking up the attention of all the TV cameras and photographers outside of the McLaren Mercedes motor home on the arm of Jenson Button.

headline: A Day Off at the Monaco Grand Prix
text: MONACO – Friday is the down day in Monaco, with no track action and an almost empty paddock. Well, not quite. Today it has turned into a kind of Cannes festival Part II. Cannes ended last week, but I heard today that Leonardo DiCaprio is somewhere around here in Monaco. Kim Kardashian, the socialite and actress, and the New Jersey Nets forward Kris Humphries have also been around, and today we also had the Spanish model Esther Canadas completely sucking up the attention of all the TV cameras and photographers outside of the McLaren Mercedes motor home on the arm of Jenson Button.

headline: This Time, Wade Knows How Hard It Is to Win a Title
text: In June 2006, Dwyane Wade was a buoyant, boyish 24-year-old with an armful of shiny trophies and a perfectly naïve vision of the future. The Miami Heat had just claimed the N.B.A. championship, with Wade as the most valuable player. And Wade was certain — absolutely certain — that he was on the precipice of something great and enduring.

headline: The Church of Oprah Winfrey and a Theology of Suffering
text: “The Oprah Winfrey Show” ended Wednesday, bringing despair to booksellers who relied on her book club, television programmers who needed her ratings, and religion scholars who for a decade have tried explaining how this child of poverty became the leader of a worldwide cult. They have worked just as hard to define that cult, which is at once Christian and pantheistic, African-American in origin but global in reach.

headline: Texas Governor Hints at G.O.P. Run for White House
text: HOUSTON — The ritual of reporters asking Gov. Rick Perry if he is running for president and getting a firm no has become so entrenched in Texas that jaws dropped Friday afternoon when Mr. Perry abruptly changed his tune — slightly — and hinted that he might run after all.

headline: Barack vs. Bibi
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Gershom Gorenberg of The American Prospect debate the Obama-Netanyahu relationship.

headline: Ignoring Homes, Thieves Make Off With Just the Gates Guarding Them
text: Hers was the hand of a little girl, smooth and quick, when she first learned to open that little iron gate. That was half a century ago, and while the hand aged — deeper wrinkles, better nails — the gate remained constant, its creak sounding the arrival of visitors like a doorbell and as much a part of the home on Vanderbilt Avenue as the brownstone walls themselves.

headline: Reacting to Police Rape Case With Anger, but Little Surprise
text: It was a trial that bared some anxieties that run just below the city’s surface: the weakness of a drunken memory; the vulnerability of ordinary residents to abuse from the powerful, especially in a police uniform. For nearly two months, New Yorkers followed a courtroom drama that held all the fascination of a television crime series, with intimate sexual detail and a haunting void at its center into which they could project their own fears or anger.

headline: For First Time, Unicef Reveals Differences in Prices It Pays Drug Companies for Vaccines
text: The United Nations Children’s Fund on Friday publicly listed for the first time the price it pays for vaccines.

headline: Goodbye Food Pyramid, Hello Dinner Plate
text: Whatever you do, don’t call it a pie chart.

headline: Giving to Charity by Managing Your E-Mail
text: Send an e-mail, make a charitable donation. Delete an e-mail, make a charitable donation.

headline: The Coyote Candidate
text: Today, we are going to discuss Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

headline: Sotomayor Got $1.175 Million for Memoir, Forms Reveal
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor received a $1.175 million advance last year to write a memoir, according to financial disclosure forms released on Friday for the nine Supreme Court justices.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug to Treat Hospital Scourge
text: As a young infectious disease researcher in 1971, Dr. Sherwood L. Gorbach received an urgent call for help from a drug company. Some patients treated with the company’s antibiotic in New Zealand had developed severe cases of diarrhea and bowel inflammation, and some had died.

headline: Senate Gadfly Who Isn’t Shy About Buzzing
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky did not come to this town to be quiet.

headline: Endangered Ryan-os
text: It’s hard to overstate just how profoundly Republicans underestimated the public’s distaste for their draconian Medicare proposal.

headline: Lasting Choice in a Sport of Split-Second Decisions
text: INDIANAPOLIS — A week after her racecar broke during a practice run, hit a wall and flipped, catching fire and dousing her with fuel, Simona de Silvestro still had her burned hands swathed in white gauze. She smiled when she called them her “Mickey Mouse hands.”

headline: Don’t Scorn Paul Ryan
text: I hadn’t realized until I met him on Tuesday that Paul Ryan had been a protégé of Jack Kemp. But the minute I heard him talking about his late mentor, everything suddenly made sense.

headline: Fracking Raises Hope for an Onshore Oil Rush
text: Advocates of extracting oil from tightly packed rock say it could increase the nation’s oil output by 25 percent.

headline: Adding Thrills When Flying Upside Down Just Isn’t Enough
text: Air show pilots have a tough assignment. They must pull off extraordinary feats of aeronautical airmanship, sure, but the bigger challenge is keeping the attention of an audience that already receives regular doses of adrenaline from various forms of entertainment.

headline: Wilpon’s Sudden Silence Speaks Volumes About His Style
text: Fred Wilpon has called his team lousy and snakebitten. He has mocked Carlos Beltran, dismissed Jose Reyes’s earning power and said that his most marketable player, David Wright, is not a superstar. He has acknowledged that his Mets are bleeding cash. Yet his dreary portrait of the product was not enough to deter David Einhorn from giving Wilpon $200 million for a piece of it.

headline: Arrest Follows Serbia’s Uneven Path to Break With Its Past
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — The tall building that served as the headquarters for the late Slobodan Milosevic’s political party, bombed by an American cruise missile in the 1999 Kosovo war, has been privatized and rebuilt, covered now in blue-green glass. Before 1990, it was home to the Communist Party Central Committee; now it houses offices, including Western banks, and a modish shopping center.

headline: A New Flood, Some Old Truths
text: The thousands of people forced to abandon their homes in recent weeks to floodwaters are victims not just of nature but of human error as well. Years of mismanagement of the vast Mississippi River ecosystem — the relentless and often inadvisable construction of levees and navigation channels, the paving over of wetlands, the commercial development of flood plains — have made the damage worse than it might otherwise have been.

headline: The Not-So-Simple Case for Taking Herman Cain Seriously
text: I’ve been taking some heat for yesterday’s article, “The Simple Case for Taking Herman Cain Seriously.”

headline: Shale Boom in Texas Could Increase U.S. Oil Output
text: CATARINA, Tex. — Until last year, the 17-mile stretch of road between this forsaken South Texas village and the county seat of Carrizo Springs was a patchwork of derelict gasoline stations and rusting warehouses.

headline: Another War in Sudan?
text: The world breathed a sigh of relief in January when southern Sudanese voted overwhelming to secede and the government in northern Sudan accepted the results. But with the July 9 independence date approaching, north and south Sudan are on the brink of war over the oil-rich border region of Abyei. The United States, the United Nations and the African Union will have to press hard to get the two sides to back down.

headline: Data Breach at Security Firm Linked to Attack on Lockheed
text: Lockheed Martin, the nation’s largest military contractor, has battled disruptions in its computer networks this week that might be tied to a hacking attack on a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to millions of users, security officials said on Friday.

headline: Margo Dydek, Towering Women’s Basketball Center, Dies at 37
text: Margo Dydek, the 7-foot-2 Polish center who was the W.N.B.A.’s No. 1 draft pick in 1998 and went on to become its leading career shot blocker, died on Friday in Brisbane, Australia. She was 37.

headline: At Fragrance Awards, Sniffing Celebrity Wrists
text: We caught a whiff of Halle Berry, a sniff of Paz de la Huerta and a deep breath of Padma Lakshmi. At the Fragrance Foundation’s FiFi Awards, billed as the Oscars of the perfume industry, our correspondent came face to face with a sea of celebrity wrists on Wednesday night. All around us, scented arms, flung into the faces of others, were sniffed with the solemnity of a sommelier.

headline: Tom West Dies at 71; Was the Computer Engineer Incarnate
text: Tom West, a shy computer engineer who became an unlikely symbol of high tech to multitudes of general-interest readers as leader of the engineering team portrayed in Tracy Kidder’s book “The Soul of a New Machine,” died on May 19 at his home in Westport, Mass. He was 71.

headline: Steve Rutt, an Inventor Behind Early Video Animation, Dies at 66
text: Steve Rutt, an engineer, inventor and artist whose early video animation system made images expand and contract and leap and dance, and in so doing helped propel the video-art revolution of the 1970s, died on May 20 in Manhattan. He was 66.

headline: CVS Wins $3 Billion Pharmacy Contract
text: The CVS Caremark Corporation won a $3 billion contract to provide pharmacy benefits to federal employees, easing concern that the company is losing business to rivals. Medco Health Solutions, which had held the contract, disclosed Friday that Blue Cross Blue Shield Association planned to switch to another provider by 2012. CVS said the new agreement, which starts Jan. 1, will run through 2014. Stock in CVS, which is based in Woonsocket, R.I., rose 65 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $38.80 a share. Stock in Medco, which is based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., fell $5.78, or 9 percent, to $58.66 a share.

headline: Dodd-Frank in Limbo
text: Congressional Republicans could not be clearer about their intent to undermine the Dodd-Frank financial reform law. They’re not helping consumers, so we have to assume that their goal is to protect the bankers.

headline: Albany Needs Ethics Reform — Now
text: The first item on Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s post-inauguration to-do list was ethics reform. He’s been in office five months, and we’re still waiting for the bill.

headline: Oprah, I Hardly Knew You
text: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

headline: Lottery Numbers
2010 Was Big-Spending Year Even by Mayor’s Standards, Documents Suggest
text: He gave away a Jeep Grand Cherokee that retailed for $26,000. He forgave a personal loan worth at least $500,000. He poured at least half a million dollars into a trust fund for his ex-wife. And he cast off a set of unwanted cabinets valued at more than $40,000.

headline: Public Services for Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Studying Housing Through Distorted Indexes
text: THE American housing market seems to be getting worse as time passes.

headline: Minority-Stake Sale Could Stabilize Mets’ Finances Through Next Year
text: When the Mets said Thursday that they were in exclusive negotiations to sell the hedge fund mogul David Einhorn a minority stake in the team for $200 million, they moved one step closer to securing a much-needed financial lifeline.

headline: For the Women of the Service, a Tamer Type of Fleet Week
text: When the U.S.S. Iwo Jima docked on Manhattan’s West Side this week, a gaggle of sailors of a different sort stood ready to greet the ship.

headline: Saturday: Advancement Aid
text: Administrivial Alert-From-the-Future! There will be a Notepad on Sunday’s puzzle that says “The grid represents a maze. Enter the room at the upper left and exit at the lower right, following a path that will become apparent as you solve the crossword. When the puzzle is done, read the circled letters in the order in which the rooms are visited to spell a quote by 153 Across.”

headline: With Arrest, Criticism for Payroll Project Grows
text: As federal investigators arrested another central figure in their widening inquiry into the city’s troubled automated payroll project, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday leveled his harshest criticism yet against the project’s main contractor, suggesting there was “widespread fraud and gross negligence” in the company.

headline: Newark Officer Is Killed in a Drive-By Shooting
text: NEWARK — The night before he was to give his younger daughter a birthday party, Police Officer William C. Johnson went out for pizza and never came home. He died early Friday, apparently a random victim of a drive-by shooting.

headline: Swisher’s Batting Average Is Still Far Below His Spirits
text: SEATTLE — On the first day of the Yankees’ last visit here, Nick Swisher was overjoyed to learn that fans had voted him onto the 2010 American League All-Star team, his reward for a splendid three months. When Swisher returned to Safeco Field on Friday, he was merely trying to maintain his regular spot in the lineup. It has been a disappointing season for Swisher, the team’s lone everyday player yet to embark on a hot streak.

headline: Carter Brain Tumor Appears Malignant
text: A tumor on Gary Carter’s brain is most likely malignant, according to preliminary results from a biopsy that was performed Friday morning. A statement from Carter’s physicians said that once the final pathology report became available in several days, treatment options would be discussed with Carter and his family.

headline: Corrections
text: NATIONAL

headline: Wright Is Magnanimous; Bullpen Is Too Generous
text: The sting of hearing that his team’s owner does not think of him as a superstar was soothed for David Wright by that most reliable and ever-faithful of sources.

headline: Mets’ Partner Was Critical of Carelessness on Madoff
text: In January 2009, roughly a month after Bernard L. Madoff’s arrest, David Einhorn wrote an opinion article with Michael Lewis, the author who was then working on a book about the financial collapse of Wall Street. It was headlined “The End of the Financial World as We Know It.”

headline: F.D.I.C. Closes 44th Bank This Year
text: WASHINGTON (AP) — Regulators on Friday shut a bank in Washington State, pushing to 44 the number of United States bank failures this year.

headline: Panoramas of Joplin Before and After the Tornado
text: Interactive panoramas of devastation in two locations in Joplin, Mo., compared to images of the same locations before the storm.

headline: Africa to Pittsburgh, Slave Ship to 1904
text: You have to start somewhere, and you have to end somewhere. August Wilson’s wondrous cycle of 10 dramas depicting the black experience in 20th-century America starts with “Gem of the Ocean”; but the production now at Hartford Stage also serves as the final offering of Michael Wilson’s tenure as artistic director. As it turns out, this conjunction of Wilsons has a certain aptness: With its many comings and goings, the Pittsburgh parlor of the play’s mystical Aunt Ester provides both an essential destination and an ideal point of departure.

headline: Broadway Rhythm Reappears in ‘My One and Only’
text: What could possibly bring together a hick aviator from Texas, a comely swimmer from England, an entrepreneurial prince from Russia and an all-knowing barber from Harlem?

headline: You Call This a Golden Age? 1950s TV, via Neil Simon
text: There’s something about New York City in the 1950s. It was a horrible time in crucial ways (sexism, racism, the Communist witch hunts). But on the surface, it was lovely. Americans dressed up for the office, took three-hour lunches and seemed to smoke and drink blithely with little thought of the consequences. All that postwar confidence!

headline: I’m an Angel, and I’m Here to Help
text: We couldn’t actually see theater without them, but lighting designers are rarely on our minds as we watch plays. It’s a little different with Tom Dudzick’s 1990 comedy “Greetings!” He’s made the lights a crucial part of his story. And Martin E. Vreeland, the designer of the lighting effects in the production at Penguin Rep Theater in Stony Point, in Rockland County, has gotten them all just right.

headline: A Republican Stays Connected in Democratic Massachusetts
text: BOSTON — When Scott P. Brown won an upset victory in last year’s special election for the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat, it seemed his tenure could be brief. Massachusetts is a left-leaning state, after all, where larger-than-life Democrats have run for president or become Washington power players.

headline: Year One of Festival: 65 Films in 5 Days
text: WHEN Regina Keller Gil began to shape the Gold Coast International Film Festival — it opens Wednesday and runs for five days in five North Shore communities — she was already well aware of the power of movies to bring out a crowd. As the executive director of the Great Neck Arts Center, whose offerings include film, “I can fill an auditorium at a multiplex on a Thursday night, every week,” she said recently.

headline: Beguiled by Humble Objects Like Peppers and Toilets
text: Is it too much to say that the history of 20th-century art can be read through its attitude toward toilets? Perhaps. But evidence that toilets played at least a cameo role is on view in “Edward Weston: Life Work” at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, N.Y.

headline: Arizona Man Looks to Law in Bid to Retrieve Ranch
text: PHOENIX — An Arizona border activist is seeking to take advantage of a new state law restricting court awards to illegal immigrants to avoid paying nearly a million dollars that a Texas judge ruled he owes two Salvadoran migrants he detained in 2003.

headline: A Weekend in Port
text: On the town with women of the Navy during Fleet Week.

headline: Brunch and TV, but Still a Workday
text: When you are a writer, even Sunday is a workday. J. Courtney Sullivan, 29, whose second novel, “Maine,” due out next month from Knopf, is expected to be one of the major beach reads of the summer, usually goes to the Brooklyn Writers Space at some point during the day. Still, she makes time for walks with her puppy, for breakfasts fit for a lumberjack and for lazing around the apartment in Park Slope that she shares with her boyfriend, Kevin Johannesen, 34, owner of a company that manages advertising sales for Internet start-ups.  JULIE BOSMAN

headline: City Critic: The New Coney Island
text: Neil Genzlinger rides the four new attractions at Scream Zone located in Coney Island's Luna Park.

headline: Coney Island Gets 4 New Thrill Rides
text: Last weekend, right about the time the rapture was supposed to be happening, I was ascending. Man, was I ever ascending. I believe I even shouted a few phrases invoking divine beings. It may have been the best 0.57 seconds of my life.

headline: Justices’ Arizona Ruling on Illegal Immigration May Embolden States
text: The decision by the Supreme Court this week upholding an Arizona law punishing employers for hiring illegal immigrants was an energy boost for state lawmakers across the country who have proposed bills this year to curb illegal immigration. As if they needed it.

headline: Ailing Megachurch Is Selling Its Property
text: LOS ANGELES — Crystal Cathedral Ministries, known for the towering Orange County megachurch where “Hour of Power” is taped, has agreed to sell its campus to a real estate investment group as part of a plan to emerge from bankruptcy.

headline: By Smallest of Margins, Bruins Seal Finals Spot
text: BOSTON — On Friday, before Game 7 of the Eastern Conference finals, Bruins goalie Tim Thomas had a dream.

headline: Sports Photo Replay — May 27
text: The day in sports, from the French Open to rhythmic gymnastics.

headline: ‘Friday Night Lights’ Watch: Heavily Involved Parents
text: We are covering the final season of “Friday Night Lights” according to the NBC schedule. We ask that readers who have already seen the season on DirecTV or on DVD to please refrain from giving away future plot points in the comments section. For analysis of previous episodes, click here.

headline: Making Legislative History, With Nod From Obama and Stroke of an Autopen
text: WASHINGTON — Generations of children learned the basics of the American legislative process from a “Schoolhouse Rock” cartoon, in which “Bill” sings, “If he signs me, then I’ll be a law.”

headline: Israeli Troops Move Into Gaza
text: Israel opens a ground war against Hamas after a week of intense airstrikes.

headline: A Troubled Life and a Mysterious Case
text: A look at the investigation into the 2001 anthrax attacks reveals lingering uncertainty over the perpetrator’s true identity.

headline: A 911 Call That Can Help Save a Sirloin, and the Griller’s Ego
text: SCHAUMBURG, Ill. — Man. Meat. Fire.

headline: Champions League Preview: Talking Tactics
text: Hyperbole is rarely in short supply on the eve of a major soccer final, but Manchester United Coach Alex Ferguson might have been on to something on Friday. In his final news conference before United faces Barcelona in Saturday’s UEFA Champions League final, Ferguson predicted the matchup would produce the best game of the past 10 years.

headline: Yankees Start Trip With Loss in Seattle
text: SEATTLE — For the Yankees, the western sojourn that began Friday night is not just a nine-game trip. It is a test of their mettle, measuring the efficiency of their offense, in three spacious ballparks, against starting pitchers who excel at their craft. Runs will be precious. So will victories.

headline: Budget Disinformation, Part 1 Million
text: I’m late in getting to Glenn Hubbard’s debt column, but it still needs further bashing. Here’s what Hubbard says about the Obama administration:

headline: The Weekend Word: Brash
text: Today’s Times

headline: 2010 Chargers: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: Classic Ad: Volkswagen’s Blue-Sky Beetle
text: It’s Memorial Day weekend, a time to rise from the cubicle, hop in the car, put the top down and take to the open road.

headline: Egypt Lifts Blockade, Along With the Gazans’ Hopes
text: RAFAH BORDER CROSSING, Egypt — Hundreds of Palestinian residents of the Gaza Strip arrived here by the busload on Saturday to pass through the reopened border into Egypt, taking the first tangible steps out of a four-year Israeli blockade.

headline: 8 Die in Bombing of Pakistan Restaurant
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least eight people were killed on Saturday when a bomb ripped through a restaurant in the restive northwestern tribal region of Bajaur, officials said.

headline: Newt Gingrich, Small-Business Owner
text: Last Sunday, Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker and current Republican presidential candidate, told America that he was a small-business owner. The revelation came on CBS’s “Face the Nation,” as the candidate tried to deflect questions (PDF) from Bob Schieffer, the host, about his recently revealed debts to Tiffany and Company.

headline: Medicare and the “Disaffected” Vote
text: In the wake of the NY-26 election, both Henry Olson and Jonathan Chait pointed out that the constituency most resistant to Paul Ryan’s Medicare reforms seems to be conservative-leaning blue collar voters — what the Pew Research Center, in a recent report, calls the “Disaffecteds.” (This is a cohort that I mentioned in my column on Mike Huckabee’s appeal, and it overlaps to some degree with the “Sam’s Club Republicans” that Reihan Salam and I spent a whole book talking about.) Chait calls this “the demographic group that should terrify Republicans,” because they’re a crucial constituency for the right-of-center coalition, but they’re also more resistant to cutting Medicare and Social Security than most Democratic-leaning groups.

headline: Del Potro Returns to Competitive Form
text: I watched the first two sets of the Djokovic-Del Potro match searching for any sign of weakness in the tall Argentine’s game. I found none, and in fact felt that he had Djokovic on the defensive when the match was called in the waning light on Friday night. Despite a year’s absence from the tour, and a comeback interrupted by a slight tear high in the quadricep that put his return to Roland Garros in doubt, Del Potro served well, hit out with authority on his ground strokes, and competed fearlessly against the tour’s dominant player. Having Del Potro back in the mix in a Grand Slam adds excitement to the men’s game, and Saturday’s continuation of the match has tennis fans buzzing over the high quality of the first two sets.

headline: Nadal Advances to the Fourth Round
text: PARIS – Rafael Nadal of Spain used his potent forehand and a strong-arm backhand service return to move easily into the fourth round of the French Open Saturday. He defeated Antonio Veic of Croatia, the world’s 227th ranked player, 6-1, 6-3, 6-0.

headline: Obama Cites Poland as Model for Arab Shift
text: WARSAW — President Obama held up Poland on Saturday as a model for Arab nations undergoing political change, saying its peaceful overthrow of Communism held lessons for Tunisia and other Arab countries grappling with the chaotic aftermath of popular revolts.

headline: Murray Rolls On Despite Injury
text: PARIS -– Andy Murray rolled on the red clay, his face a portrait in pain, after injuring his right ankle Saturday in his third round French Open match against Michael Berrer of Germany.

headline: Success and Scandal Can Leave Everyone Weary
text: With scandal looming, soccer did the best it could in the Champions League final on Saturday — sending out the most creative team of its generation, temporarily taking everybody’s mind off intrigue at the home office.

headline: Murder of Activists Raises Questions of Justice in Amazon
text: Early last Tuesday, José Cláudio Ribeiro da Silva, a forest activist and tree nut harvester, and his wife, Maria do Espirito Santo, drove a motorcycle through Brazil’s northern Para State, in the Amazon rain forest. As they crossed a river bridge, gunmen lying in wait opened fire with a pistol and shotgun, killing them.

headline: Inflation and Debt (Wonkish)
text: As I mentioned in an earlier post, the latest OECD Economic Outlook is a remarkable document — and I mean that in the worst way. I’ve already pointed to the report’s insistence that we must raise interest rates, because foofa grrzt bumble shazam — OK, that’s not quite what the report says, but it makes at least as much sense as the justification the report does offer.

headline: Gil Scott-Heron, Voice of Black Protest Culture, Dies at 62
text: Gil Scott-Heron, the poet and recording artist whose syncopated spoken style and mordant critiques of politics, racism and mass media in pieces like “The Revolution Will Not Be Televised” made him a notable voice of black protest culture in the 1970s and an important early influence on hip-hop, died on Friday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 62 and had been a longtime resident of Harlem.

headline: Urban Forager | Spring Sprucing
text: Some weeks ago, I started noticing nascent light-green buds on the branches of every city conifer I encountered from Central Park down to Staten Island. Unlike mature pine needle tea — a resiny, survivalist food at best — fresh, young evergreen tips are a citrusy surprise to the palate, and I couldn’t help nibbling on a choice few. At the College of Staten Island, I discovered a midsize, classic Christmas-tree-looking conifer, which friends at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden identified as a Colorado blue spruce. It had very lemony-tasting tips.

headline: Bhupathi and Paes Are Eliminated

headline: Bodies Found Near Site of Protests in Georgia

headline: Who You Gonna Bet On? An Update
text: It’s not quite a year yet since Business Week ran a piece ridiculing my concerns about prolonged economic weakness, comparing it to the wisdom of John Paulson, who saw a boom — particularly in housing — just around the corner. Still, it seems worth revisiting.

headline: Diamondbacks Revamp Bullpen Without Costly Additions
text: In a six-game stretch from late April to mid-May, Joaquin Benoit of the Detroit Tigers allowed 12 earned runs, three more than he did all of last season for the Tampa Bay Rays. That short stretch of shaky pitching showed just how volatile a reliever’s results can be from year to year.

headline: Variety: A Very Romantic Diagramless
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Once you’ve solved this puzzle, you might think that Patrick Blindauer is a tad obsessed with the letter “H,” but in reading between the lines on this one, I’m wondering if it also serves as a love letter to his fiancee. Each of the theme entries is a phrase that has that double “H” going for it, and most of them are fairly romantic. Or maybe it’s a love letter to Henry Hook, what do I know?

headline: Have an Enjoyable Memorial Day Weekend
text: Wheels will be taking a short break in observance of Memorial Day, but we’ll return on Tuesday, May 31, with our regular coverage. Whatever mode of transport conveys you to your destination, the editors and contributors at Wheels wish you safe and happy travels this holiday weekend.

headline: When Play in Paris Resumes, So Does Djokovic’s Undefeated Streak
text: PARIS — Best of three. Best of five. Darkness. Daylight. Delays. Resumptions. Italian clay. French clay. None of it has affected the bottom line for Novak Djokovic in 2011. He remains unbeatable, or more to the point, undefeated.

headline: When Warnings Don’t Work

headline: When Everything Is Gone, Including a Sense of Direction

headline: Spoelstra Raised to Be in N.B.A., and Rising to Challenge
text: Watson Spoelstra covered sports in Detroit during the middle of the last century. It was another era, another world. There were no computers, just typewriters. Reporters traveled with teams and inevitably became close with some of the players they wrote about. They might even bail a player out of jail, as Spoelstra once did for the Detroit Lions’ Bobby Layne.

headline: Taliban Bomber Infiltrates Afghan-NATO Meeting, Killing Police Official and Others

Daoud Daoud, Afghan officials said.

headline: In Florida, Criminals Pose as Police More Frequently and for More Violent Ends
text: MIAMI — A black BMW flashing red and blue lights suddenly filled Alexandria Armeley’s rearview mirror one evening last month. At a stoplight, the BMW’s driver pulled up next to her, waved a gold badge and told her “I’m a cop.”

headline: Agencies’ Lack of Coordination Hindered Supply of Crucial Gas, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The United States is running out of a rare gas that is crucial for detecting smuggled nuclear weapons materials because one arm of the Energy Department was selling the gas six times as fast as another arm could accumulate it, and the two sides failed to communicate for years, according to a new Congressional audit.

headline: Dana Brand, Who Blogged of Mets Fans’ Delight and Despair, Dies at 56
text: He was 7 ½ years old, sitting in his room, riveted to his family’s portable radio and wearing his little plastic baseball glove. It was 1962, and Dana Brand was listening to the Mets’ inaugural game, and so began a love affair that would last until his death on Wednesday at 56.

headline: Buzz Is Back for Centennial at the Brickyard

headline: Carl Edwards Forgoes Feuds and Leads Standings
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Carl Edwards wanted a celebration to remember when he won the annual Nascar All-Star race May 21 at Charlotte Motor Speedway. So he turned his car onto the grass along the front stretch of the racetrack for what he hoped would be a spectacular spin.

headline: Brown Ushers in New Era for the Lakers
text: Widespread approval greeted the news last week that the Los Angeles Lakers had chosen Mike Brown to replace the retiring legend Phil Jackson. And why not?

headline: Egypt Opens Border
text: Egypt lifted a four-year-old blockade on the Gaza Strip’s main link to the outside world Saturday, bringing relief to the crowded territory’s 1.5 million Palestinians but deepening a rift with Israel since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak earlier this year.

headline: For Columbia Class of ’41, It Is Always the Day After
text: Lou Gehrig, Columbia’s most eminent sports figure, died June 2, 1941. The next day, I received my bachelor’s degree from the university.

headline: A Splintered Landscape
text: The tornado that carved through southwestern Missouri last Sunday leveled parts of Joplin so completely — taking landmarks, street signs, everything — that the community’s inner GPS remains out of whack.

headline: Troubled Veterans and Early Deaths After Iraq
text: This month, the Department of Veterans Affairs informed the parents of William Hamilton, an Iraq war veteran, that it was not responsible for his death.

headline: U.S. Has Binged. Soon It’ll Be Time to Pay the Tab.
text: SAY this about all the bickering over the federal debt ceiling: at least people are talking openly about our nation’s growing debt load. This $14.3 trillion issue is front and center — exactly where it should be.

headline: For Kyle Drabek, It’s No. 4, the One and Only
text: For a pitcher with only a few months in the major leagues, Toronto’s Kyle Drabek is easy to identify. He is the son of Doug Drabek, the 1990 National League Cy Young Award winner; he was the Blue Jays’ centerpiece in the trade that sent Roy Halladay to Philadelphia; and he is the only pitcher in the majors with a single-digit uniform number.

headline: Playing Through Pain Is a Playoff Ritual
text: One of the most celebrated aspects of Stanley Cup play is the pain players endure to make a contribution during the postseason. It is a point of professional pride that hockey players will dress for games with injuries that would sideline most other athletes.

headline: French System Tints View of the Strauss-Kahn Case
text: PARIS — The sexual assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, which continues to crowd out much other news here, is becoming something of a civics lesson in American justice — one that has inspired both biting criticism and some respect.

headline: The Trouble With the Echo Chamber Online
text: ON the Web, we often see what we like, and like what we see. Whether we know it or not, the Internet creates personalized e-comfort zones for each one of us.

headline: War Crimes Suspect Could Be Extradited Tuesday
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — Serbian officials vowed on Saturday to track down all those who had helped hide Ratko Mladic and other fugitives accused of war crimes, but their prime interest now is to get the former Bosnian Serb general packed off to the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, which could happen as early as Tuesday.

headline: A Psychological Twister

headline: Consumer Complaints Made Easy. Maybe Too Easy.
text: PHONE trees that lead nowhere. Customer service drones chained to a script. The modern corporation has invented a thousand ways to tell customers with a grievance: You’re out of luck. And, no, contrary to our dulcet recording, your call is not important to us.

headline: Why Are Investors Still Lining Up for Bonds?
text: THERE is nothing more intimidating than the bond market, once it starts flexing its muscles. So said James Carville, the Democratic political strategist, after finding himself on the losing side of some bruising budget battles in the 1990s.

headline: Mentoring Program Is in Peril
text: On Tuesday, 14-year-old Delvon Morgan carefully removed one of his pastel pythons from a plastic tub in his Oakland bedroom. “This one,” he said, “he’s a proven breeder.”

headline: Can I See Your License, Registration and C.P.U.?
text: MOST of us don’t trust computers completely, and for good reason. Our smartphones freeze and our hard drives crash with disconcerting regularity. Yet we frequently place our lives in the hands of computers, which are embedded in our cars, operate airplane navigation systems and even help conduct robot-guided laser surgery.

headline: Tenderloin National Forest
text: Nestled between a cluster of residential buildings and hotels in San Francisco’s Tenderloin district is a surprising outcropping of green — the so-called Tenderloin National Forest. Formerly known as Cohen Alley, the small urban enclave is not really a national forest but a former  dumping ground for hypodermic needles and garbage.

headline: A Venture Born in the Kitchen
text: WHEN I was 3, my dad called a family meeting and told us he was sick of shoveling snow in Minneapolis. We were moving to Scottsdale, Ariz., he announced.

headline: East Bay Professor’s Political Odyssey Leads to His Arrest in Nigeria
text: On Thanksgiving last year, Steve Torkuma Ugbah gathered with his extended family at his sister’s home in Elk Grove, outside Sacramento.

headline: Retired, but Doing the Work You Love
From Russia, a Motorcycle Built for Two
text: Like so many other post-Communist enterprises, the Irbit motorcycle factory seemed to be sputtering into the sunset in the 1990s, but it found a new market for its sidecar bikes in the United States.

headline: 30 Seconds With Steve Nash
text: Steve Nash, the Phoenix Suns’ star point guard and noted soccer enthusiast, is hosting the fourth annual Showdown in Chinatown, a charity soccer match, on June 22 on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Tony Parker, Grant Hill and Brandon Jennings are among the N.B.A. stars playing in the match, which is free and open to the public. Proceeds from an after-hours event will benefit the Steve Nash Foundation. Nash, who lives in Manhattan in the off-season, has recently become an advocate for gay rights and recently lent his voice to a same-sex marriage initiative in New York State.

headline: Sony and Epsilon Agree to Testify Before Congress
text: Sony has finally agreed to testify before a Congressional hearing that will be held by Representative Mary Bono Mack, the chairwoman of the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade.

text: WASHINGTON
