text: WHEN crowds flock to the Williamsburg Waterfront concert series this summer, most will pass the home of Genya Wolowacz on North Eighth Street, where she has lived since 1957. She will watch them as if eyeing 6,500 barbarian invaders.

headline: A Generation of Slackers? Not So Much
text: YOU’D think there would be a little sympathy. This month, college graduates are jumping into the job market, only to land on their parents’ couches: the unemployment rate for 16- to 24-year-olds is a whopping 17.6 percent.

headline: Nicholas V. Riasanovsky Dies at 87; Set Standard for Russian History
text: Nicholas V. Riasanovsky, a Russian émigré who came to the United States at 14, served in the Army during World War II and became one of the country’s leading scholars of Russian history, writing a college textbook that served as the American standard for teaching Russian history during the cold war, died on May 14 in Oakland, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Boy, 4, Is Mauled to Death by Dog in Brooklyn Home
text: A 4-year-old boy was mauled to death by a family dog as he and his two brothers played in a bedroom of their apartment in Brooklyn, the authorities said on Saturday.

headline: The Office: Sedentary No More
text: News item: Less physical activity at work may be a major but overlooked culprit in rising American obesity, researchers reported last week.

headline: Ahead of the Class
text: DON’T HAVE THE GRADES to get into Oxford? It might not be a problem if you’ve got the cash. The British education minister has proposed letting wealthy students pay for spots at top universities even though they failed to get in through the regular admissions process. “Rage and confusion have been the immediate results,” The Boston Globe reports. Admission to British universities is based on meritocratic competition; once students get in, they pay a low flat fee. At Oxford, it is about $6,000 a year, The Globe says. Supporters of the idea say the extra cash will bolster the educational system. Less affluent students would not lose out, they say, because these new spots would be “extra” ones. Critics say the two-tier idea is profoundly unfair. “The proposals are likely to be criticized as a means for the wealthiest to ‘buy places’ at a time when the government is to cut 10,000 publicly funded places,” The Guardian reported.

headline: In Texas, Budget Held Sway for 20 Weeks
text: The 82nd Texas Legislature’s regular session ends as it started, with lawmakers arguing about a shrunken state budget and redistricting.

headline: Prime Number
text: 48: THE PERCENTAGE OF American households represented by married couples in 2010, the first time that figure has dropped below 50 percent, the Census Bureau reports. That is down from 78 percent in 1950. “The days of Ozzie and Harriet have faded into the past,” said William Frey, a demographer at the Brookings Institution who analyzed the census figures. Just a fifth of households were traditional families — married couples with children. The overwhelming majority of Americans still eventually marry, though increasingly working-class people do not stay married.

headline: Fighting Words
text: Congress agreed last week to reauthorize the Patriot Act just before the terrorist surveillance law was set to expire. Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, helped lead the opposition, to the consternation of many fellow Republicans.

headline: Considered: Screen Grab
text: IT WAS JULY 12, 1995, and a cameraman from Bosnian Serb television was there, in the town of Srebrenica. United Nations forces had made it a safe haven for Bosnian Muslims, but Bosnian Serb forces had wrested it from them.

headline: Back Then: 1984
text: PRESIDENT OBAMA IS HARDLY the first president to travel to Ireland in search of his roots — and of Irish Catholic votes back home. In June 1984, Ronald Reagan traveled to the green hills of County Tipperary, where his great-grandfather was baptized. The Times’s Steven R. Weisman went along:

headline: Laugh Lines
text: JAY LENO

headline: Liking Is for Cowards. Go for What Hurts.
text: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I replaced my three-year-old BlackBerry Pearl with a much more powerful BlackBerry Bold. Needless to say, I was impressed with how far the technology had advanced in three years. Even when I didn’t have anybody to call or text or e-mail, I wanted to keep fondling my new Bold and experiencing the marvelous clarity of its screen, the silky action of its track pad, the shocking speed of its responses, the beguiling elegance of its graphics.

headline: Kevin Long’s Winding Road
text: Part of Kevin Long’s job as the hitting coach for the Yankees is to build trust, to get his players to buy what he is selling. He has been far more successful doing that than he was at an off-season job in the minors, when he tried to sell Yugos in Phoenix.

headline: After Combat, the Unexpected Perils of Coming Home
text: Pvt. Johnnie Stevenson cleaned his truck one last time, scraping off the barnacle-like mud and pulling crushed water bottles from under seats. But deployment to Afghanistan was almost over, and his thoughts drifted elsewhere. Was his pregnant fiancée ready to be a mother? Facebook provided so few clues. Nor could it answer him this: Was he ready to be a father?

headline: Battle for Libya | May 28, 2011
text: NATO warplanes struck Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s compound in Tripoli on Saturday, as the new rebel administration warned it was fast running out of money because countries that promised financial aid have not come through.

headline: Tony Horton Demonstrates a Push-Up
text: The fitness guru Tony Horton says exercisers should focus on engaging their core muscles.

headline: The Fitness Revolution Will Be Televised (After Leno)

headline: Obama Expected to Name Army’s Leader to Head Joint Chiefs
text: WASHINGTON — Gen. Martin E. Dempsey’s peers call him a “pentathlete,” the kind of post-Sept. 11 commander who not only knows the art of combat but is also adept at marshaling the power of diplomacy, money, allied cooperation and information.

headline: From Scott Crow's F.B.I. File
text: These documents are among 440 pages that Scott Crow, an Austin, Tex., activist, received under the Freedom of Information Act. The Federal Bureau of Investigation wielded an impressive array of tools, the documents show, to monitor Mr. Crow, who has been arrested a dozen times during demonstrations but never convicted of anything more serious than trespassing.

headline: The Morning Line: All About Animal Kingdom
text: Animal Kingdom is the story today. The Kentucky Derby winner’s trainer, Graham Motion, announced, as definitely as one can two weeks before the race, that Animal Kingdom is headed for the Belmont Stakes. Motion was quoted by The Associated Press as sayng, “He bounced out of the Preakness very well and we are looking forward to running in the Belmont Stakes.”

headline: For Office Civility, Cherchez La Femme
text: PARIS

headline: Disguised as Breakfast, Dessert Served for Lunch
text: As spring rapidly becomes summer, the lines have been growing longer at the city’s food trucks, an ever-expanding collection of mobile options — food court meets convoy — that neatly satisfies the New York demand for convenience and variety. The taxicab-yellow Wafels and Dinges truck, which has trolled the streets since 2007, has become a mainstay. Offering a variety of Belgian waffles with sweet or savory toppings, the truck — its owners also have four carts and opened their first stationary outpost on Friday in Seaside Heights, N.J. — attracts a mix of repeat customers and passers-by intrigued by the novelty. On Wednesday, along Hanover Square near Water Street in the financial district, as a group of men ogled passing women and talked on cellphones, two co-workers asked for recommendations and discussed the notion of breakfast at lunch.

headline: F.Y.I.
text: Q. Who invented the ice-cream sandwich?

headline: Mixing the Sacred and the Secular
text: MSGR. MARCO FRISINA and the 47 members of the Choir of the Pope’s Diocese of Rome whom he will lead in a concert on June 4 in Trenton are not all newcomers to the United States, but they will be performing here as a group for the first time.

headline: ‘Alive and Well,’ and Also Aging, Alone and Desperate
text: Early in the second act of “Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris,” Rona Figueroa sings “Ne Me Quitte Pas” (“Don’t Leave Me”) in French, with Andy Kelso, upstage right, softly contributing a few words of translation. Listening to it at a recent matinee, I thought: Maybe they should be doing the whole thing in French.

headline: Pay Attention
text: Cairo

headline: Kilowatts vs. Gallons
text: Comparing the costs of driving a battery-powered Nissan Leaf versus that of a similarly sized, conventionally powered Nissan Altima.

headline: The Great Kilowatt vs. Gallon Face-Off
text: WITH Memorial Day upon us, and with it a summer driving season marked by high prices at the gas pump, it seems a fitting time to look at the electric car. How do the fuel and environmental costs of running one compare with the costs of a conventional car, or even the electricity to run appliances in your home? (Such details are on the minds of federal officials, who last week unveiled new fuel-economy stickers for vehicles, starting with the 2013 model year.)

headline: In Evidence: a Terrorist’s To-Do List
text: CHICAGO — When the authorities arrested David C. Headley, the man who has since confessed to helping plot the 2008 terrorist attacks on Mumbai, India, they confiscated two items essential to the plans for his next plot: a book titled “How to Pray Like a Jew” and a lemon-yellow notepad.

headline: Slums Into Malls
text: KOLKATA, India

headline: Threats and Arrests at a Gay Rights Rally in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — Amid shouts from gangs of men and threats of beatings, police officers arrested more than a dozen gay rights activists, including a few foreigners, who attempted to hold a rally in Moscow on Saturday.

headline: Another Forest Defender Falls in the Amazon
text: John Collins Rudolf has posted a thorough overview of the latest murder on the eroding perimeter of the Amazon rain forest in Brazil. There’s been enormous progress in efforts to bring governance to forest frontiers in Brazil since the late 1980s, when I spent months in the western Amazon reporting on the life and assassination of Chico Mendes for “The Burning Season,” my first book. But pistols and shotguns still sometimes blaze.

headline: Passive in the Senate
text: Republican leaders in the Senate have spent weeks gleefully deriding the Democrats who run the chamber for not producing a budget proposal in more than two years. It is a classic tactic, designed to deflect attention from their party’s toxic plan to privatize Medicare. The truth, though, is that the Republicans also have a point.

headline: Readers Comment on the Rise of India
text: My Sunday column argues that India is turning around and that its takeoff is gaining traction around the country, even in places like Bihar and West Bengal. I’ve been a bit wary of India in the past, previously noting that the tech sector accomplishments are real but have tiny employment and that solid chunks of India remain abysmally undeveloped. That’s still true, but my latest trip leaves me more optimistic. India is steadily evolving in the right direction — while in China there’s reason for more caution. Under President Hu Jintao, China’s evolution has paused, and there probably won’t be more movement until after the Communist Party Congress in late 2012 installs Xi Jinping as Hu’s successor. I still would never bet against China, but I think India may be able to narrow the gap in the coming years.

headline: Tornado Losses in 2011 Worst Since 1950
text: The federal Storm Prediction Center has released its latest tally of tornadoes and deaths for 2011, with the current count of 523 now making this the worst year since 1950.. [May 30, 11:45 p.m. | Updated  This line and the headline have been adjusted to eliminate an error explained at the end of this post.]

headline: Gender and Therapists
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Libyan Rebel Capital, Shouts of Thanks to America and the West
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — Frustrated by the gridlocked traffic, the young man in fatigues was leaning on the horn of his old Chevrolet Impala, the one with the front and rear windshields shot out. The shrillness of the pointless noise made a foreigner in the car next to him wince.

headline: Sunday: Is For You?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we get started today, I just want to take a moment to applaud my fellow constructors, particularly today’s, for their creativity and the ingenious lengths they go to in order to entertain us. I did most of the puzzle today with my mouth hanging open and I sincerely hope that when you discovered the gimmick, you were just as pleasantly surprised.

headline: A Further Overreach on Political Money
text: The spree of big-money political campaigning — and the corruption that comes with it — seemed guaranteed to worsen Thursday when a federal judge in Virginia ruled that corporations are now free to make direct donations to federal candidates.

headline: The Smartphone as Tour Guide for Central Park
text: APP Central Park

headline: Old-School Italian in a Spruced-Up Space
text: AFTER almost a year of serious remodeling, Alba’s doors reopened last September onto a spiffy space with an upscale yet homey look. Done tastefully in muted tones with white architectural detailing, the large dining room is defined subtly by the varied shapes of large Oriental-style rugs that add softness and a touch of luxury.

headline: Amid a Bit of Railroad History
text: Whether you roll in from the Putnam County Trailway bike path or stroll in from the nearby Putnam Music Center, the laid-back Freight House Cafe is a nifty place to unwind or rewind — a charming piece of history set well back from the busy traffic of Route 6.

headline: Boutique Wines on Parade
text: Brooklyn Uncorked, a wine-and-food showcase at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this month, offered a chance to sample recent wines of Long Island boutique producers who have kept a low profile. Many of the wines were made by contract vintners from the vintners’ own or from bought grapes.

headline: Steak and Seafood, and Views of a Bay
text: FORGET June 21. Summer starts this weekend, and on Long Island, summer is synonymous with water — including water views. One of the best places around to enjoy them while dining out is Lombardi’s on the Bay in Patchogue.

headline: Spammers and Their Bankers
text: In early 2004 Bill Gates claimed that “two years from now, spam will be solved.” Today it amounts to 70 percent of all e-mail. Yet there may be a chance to cut it back.

headline: Final Goodbye to a Mars Explorer
text: After a final attempt last week, NASA has stopped trying to make contact with the Mars rover called Spirit, which was last heard from in March 2010 as the Martian winter was setting in. Hopes of hearing more from Spirit were slim even then, but there is a difference between not hearing and no longer listening.

headline: Why Medical School Should Be Free
text: DOCTORS are among the most richly rewarded professionals in the country. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that of the 15 highest-paid professions in the United States, all but two are in medicine or dentistry.

headline: Southwestern Fare, Inspired and Varied
text: CLOSE by the beaches of Sandy Hook, Atlantic Highlands has a fairly lively eating scene, with fancy and family-style restaurants alike along the lower end of First Avenue, steps away from the town marina and Raritan Bay. If you’re not paying attention, though, you might walk right past one of the best: There is no sign outside the Copper Canyon Restaurant, just a rust-colored horseshoe logo above the door.

headline: Animal-Free and Sermon-Free
text: Gail Doherty believes in healthy eating, but she isn’t preachy about it. At Good Karma Cafe, the Red Bank restaurant and juice bar she owns with Tiffany Betts, vegan food is served with an easygoing air.

headline: In a Darkened Alcove, Plenty of Bright Spots
text: IT’S all very casual at the Suburban, in downtown Branford. Waiters and waitresses are clad in plaid shirts, neatly folded dish towels serve as napkins, and an extended bookshelf endows the main dining room with the feel of a home library — although not one conducive to reading.

headline: The Weak Foundations of Arab Democracy
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 29
text: On this Memorial Day weekend, CNN’s “State of the Union” and TV One’s “Washington Watch” are recognizing the holiday by exploring the challenges facing military personnel and veterans.

headline: Novelist and His Hero Wonder, Will It Last?
text: To research his latest work of historical fiction, the post-World War I novel “Remember Ben Clayton,” the novelist and screenwriter Stephen Harrigan traveled to France twice so he could faithfully describe the town of Saint-Étienne and the battle that took place there in 1918. In Austin, where he lives, he spent hours poring over newspaper microfiche so he could write about what movies were playing at the time and what brands of chewing gum were being advertised.

headline: A Verb for Our Frantic Times
text: Sandisfield, Mass.

headline: Remembering Officer Slain in Case of Mistaken Identity
text: Exactly two years after Omar J. Edwards, a New York police officer, was fatally shot in East Harlem by another officer, officials gathered on Saturday to rename the street outside his old station house in his honor.

headline: A Movable Canvas
text: For some yoga practitioners, the body represents a blank, movable canvas.

headline: With Scattershot Comments, Blagojevich Wagers All
text: After sitting in the witness box for a few minutes at his federal corruption trial last week, Rod R. Blagojevich shared with jurors a bit of personal insight about himself.

headline: Loitering on the Fringes
text: THE culture is headed for the curb, and The New York Times is on the story.

headline: Exhibit Shows the Impact of War, Through the Artists and the Soldiers
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Promise and Peril in Utilities’ Smart Grid
text: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Hot City, a Guide
text: Some may think that in summer, the city gets quiet, the traffic starts to die down a bit, and the brisk pace of the business suits slows to a saunter in a sundress. Some would be wrong. That’s when the city gets rowdy with music festivals, parades, celebrations of art and food, and most of it at small cost.

headline: Administration Opposes Challenges to Medicaid Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — Medicaid recipients and health care providers cannot sue state officials to challenge cuts in Medicaid payments, even if such cuts compromise access to health care for poor people, the Obama administration has told the Supreme Court.

headline: Return of Islamic College Raises New Questions
text: The American Islamic College, closed since 2004 when the state revoked its operating authority, is expected early next month to win approval to reopen.

headline: For Anarchist, Details of Life as F.B.I. Target
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A fat sheaf of F.B.I. reports meticulously details the surveillance that counterterrorism agents directed at the one-story house in East Austin. For at least three years, they traced the license plates of cars parked out front, recorded the comings and goings of residents and guests and, in one case, speculated about a suspicious flat object spread out across the driveway.

headline: Shooting in Bronx Injures Three People
text: A day after a 5-year-old girl was wounded by a stray bullet, detectives on Saturday were searching for whoever had opened fire on a crowded Bronx street, hitting the girl and two others, the police said.

headline: For the Yankees’ Nunez, Growth Comes With the Pains of Mistakes
text: SEATTLE — Eduardo Nunez had appeared in 23 games for the Yankees, and what happened to him in the eighth inning Friday night was his season writ small.

headline: Dickey Is Willing, but the Mets Want to Be Sure He Is Able
text: With their recent history of trying to rush players back from injuries or attempting to hide the exact nature of injuries, it would seem imprudent for the Mets to allow R. A. Dickey to make his next start if there is any chance he is unfit, or unable to perform all his duties.

headline: More Room to Roam on the High Line
text: This summer, the second section of the High Line, the elevated railway turned city park, will open to eager visitors.

headline: High Line: the Sequel
text: IT promises to be the summer’s biggest sequel: the High Line, Section 2.

headline: Prized Possession for Barcelona: Champions League Title
text: LONDON — With the fans at one end of Wembley Stadium singing and dancing, and those at the other sulking and leaving, the public-address announcer made the most obvious of proclamations: Barcelona was the winner of the Champions League.

text: Correctional Colony 13 houses law enforcement officials who have committed abuses of power such as accepting bribes or beating detainees.

headline: In Russia, Prisons for Police Thrive
text: NIZHNY TAIGIL, Russia — Like a scene from a felon’s daydream, all the inmates at a prison compound here in western Russia — some 2,000 of them — are former policemen, prosecutors, tax inspectors, customs agents and judges.

text: In this homemade video, Lauren Larusso and Matt Drago tell of their first encounter as they prepare to wed on May 29.

headline: An Unlikely Power Duo Emerges in the Global Fight Against Climate Change
text: WASHINGTON — Bill Clinton and Michael R. Bloomberg have circled each other warily for a decade, ever since Mr. Clinton landed in Harlem after leaving the White House and Mr. Bloomberg ascended from a hugely successful business career to become the mayor of New York City. They have appeared together at a few civic functions, dined out a couple of times a year and hacked at golf balls on the same course.

headline: Bridget & Mani

headline: Ayoola Kellar, Nathan Carleton
text: Ayoola Bejide Kellar and Nathan Lee Carleton were married Saturday at the Carlton Savannah Hotel in Port of Spain, Trinidad and Tobago. Bishop Andrew John of the Covenant House of Praise, a Pentecostal church in Diego Martin, Trinidad and Tobago, officiated.

headline: Retro Russian Import Lures Older Riders
text: IRBIT, Russia — This is the story of how a dying Soviet-era industry and an aging biker population in the United States met and found happiness together on the streets and highways of America.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Christie & Steve
text: In this homemade video, Steve Gersh recounts how instant messaging helped him grow closer to Christie Franklin while they worked for the same company on opposite coasts.

headline: Christina Franklin, Steven Gersh
text: Christina Lee Franklin, a daughter of Joy W. Hire of Granville, Ohio, and George A. Franklin of Kalamazoo, Mich., is to be married Sunday evening to Steven Philip Gersh, the son of Susan Gersh and David Gersh of Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Karen Chakoian, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate, and Cantor Danny Maseng is to assist at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

headline: The Funnywoman, Alive and Well
text: THE stars of “Bridesmaids” — Kristen Wiig and Maya Rudolph, principally, with Ellie Kemper, Rose Byrne, Wendi McLendon-Covey and especially Melissa McCarthy in support — are very funny. This is not just my opinion, and it should not come as news, if the raucous laughter at a sold-out theater last weekend in Brooklyn is any indication. “Funny,” apart from being a subjective judgment, is also a commercial imperative, and it is one that “Bridesmaids” has fulfilled.

headline: Republican Legislators Push to Tighten Voting Rules
text: MIAMI — Less than 18 months before the next presidential election, Republican-controlled statehouses around the country are rewriting voting laws to require photo identification at the polls, reduce the number of days of early voting or tighten registration rules.

headline: As Potential Investor Watches, Bullpen Displays Little Security
text: In the moments after another dispiriting loss to a division rival, Fred Wilpon, the Mets’ principal owner, who has endured a week of bad publicity and sobering business decisions, walked slowly and quietly down a tunnel underneath Citi Field toward his waiting car.

headline: License Plate Scanners Locate Vehicle Sought After Hit and Run
text: A car that was believed to have been used in a hit-and-run accident that left a traffic officer injured earlier this month was tracked down on Friday through the use of the Police Department’s growing web of license-plate-reading cameras, the authorities said.

Raval is to perform the Hindu ceremony at the Aashirwad Palace, a banquet hall in Randolph, N.J., with his father, Pandit Vinod R. Raval, also a Hindu priest, taking part.
