text: Dr. Luciana Alves Vieira and Stephen White Grambling are to be married Sunday evening at the Evergreen Museum in Baltimore. The Rev. Marco A. Negráo, a minister of the Izunome Association U.S.A., is to officiate.

headline: Patricia Maloney, Alastair Hamilton
text: Patricia Ann Maloney and Alastair Ethan Hamilton were married Saturday in New Haven. The Rev. Bret B. Hays, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Battell Chapel at Yale.

headline: Jamie Schiff, Jason Sperling
text: Jamie Rose Schiff, the daughter of Judith B. Schiff and David A. Schiff of Portland, Ore., is to be married there Sunday to Jason Maxwell Sperling, the son of Rebecca W. Sperling and Louis J. Sperling of East Greenwich, R.I. Rabbi Michael Z. Cahana is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Beth Israel, with Rabbi Emanuel Rose assisting.

headline: Leslie Kim, Peter Lu
text: Dr. Leslie Rhan Kim, a daughter of Jung Hee Kim of Syosset, N.Y., and Jeong Doo Kim of College Point, Queens, was married Friday night to Dr. Peter Long-Shyang Lu, the son of Mei June Lu and Cheng Yi Lu of West Hills, Calif. The Rev. Chong Kim, a United Methodist minister, officiated at the de Seversky Mansion, a party and conference center on the campus of the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y.

headline: Olivia Ma, Sean Kelly
text: Olivia Otey Ma, the daughter of Nathalie Preston Gilfoyle and Christopher Ma of Washington, is to be married Sunday at her parents’ house to Sean Uberoi Kelly, the son of Narindar U. Kelly and Michael J. Kelly of Baltimore. Judge Diana Gribbon Motz of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Baltimore is to officiate.

headline: Lisa Nguyen, Shawn Anthony
text: Dr. Lisa Pham Nguyen, a daughter of Huong Lien Nguyen and Lam Thanh Nguyen Sr. of New Orleans, is to be married Sunday to Dr. Shawn Garrett Anthony, a son of Joyce A. Anthony and Larry E. Anthony of State College, Pa. The Rev. Michael E. Drea, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Discretionary Truthiness
text: I keep hearing Republicans say that Obama has increased nondefense discretionary spending by 80 percent; it’s one of those “facts” that apparently everyone on the right knows. So where does that come from?

headline: Reserve Currency Mysticism
text: Oh, my. Even though it was a personal attack on me, I didn’t get around to reading Steil and Hinds on why we must be totally freaked about the role of the dollar. But Brad DeLong did; and it turns out that it’s quite a piece of work.

headline: Seattle Solves Rivera and Yankees in 12th
text: SEATTLE — If there is one guideline in baseball that managers follow almost uniformly, it is this: on the road, their closer pitches only with a lead. Manager Joe Girardi strayed from that line of thinking Saturday night because he was left with little other choice. Mariano Rivera entered with the score tied in the 12th inning, and he surprisingly emerged as the weak link in the Yankees’ bullpen chain. Rivera gave up the winning run in the Mariners’ 5-4 victory on a bases-loaded blooper to Adam Kennedy, who ignited their go-ahead rally on Friday.

headline: 2010 Chiefs: What the Film Revealed
text: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This is the final installment of the series.

headline: Gagosian Hosts Peyton’s First Solo Show in Paris
text: The American painter Elizabeth Peyton is enjoying her first solo show in Paris at the Gagosian Gallery, spotlighting new paintings and drawings, through July 28. The gallery’s polished, high-ceilinged space (4 rue Ponthieu; 33-1-45-63-98-06; www.gagosian.com) may seem like an odd fit with Ms. Peyton’s small-scale, tightly framed portraits, but the power of her intimate style holds up in the gallery.

headline: Policy Adviser Tapped to Become U.S. Ambassador to Russia
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has decided to send the architect of his so-called Russia reset policy to Moscow as the next United States ambassador there, seeking to further bolster an improved relationship as both countries head into a potentially volatile election season.

headline: At Mission’s End — Joy, Relief and Unexpected Perils
text: In the final installment of A Year at War, his project that chronicled the yearlong deployment of the First Battalion, 87th Infantry Regiment that was based in Kunduz Province, Afghanistan, Jim Dao reports on the new difficulties that soldiers face on their return home from the battlefield.

headline: At Rolling Thunder, Waiting for Palin
text: WASHINGTON — Thousands of Harley-riding bikers from across the country began assembling in the Pentagon’s North Parking Lot on Sunday morning for the annual Rolling Thunder rally — and the start  of Sarah Palin’s “One Nation” bus tour.

headline: Civilians Are Killed in Airstrike by NATO
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan officials said Sunday that a NATO airstrike had killed 14 civilians, most of them women and children, in the southern province of Helmand on Saturday night.

headline: Vettel Dodges All Obstacles to Win Again
text: MONACO — The Monaco Grand Prix was a wild race from start to finish, with multiple accidents, two safety-car periods, a half-hour red flag break just six laps before the end and a fight to the end among three drivers separated by less than a second.

headline: Vettel Dodges All Obstacles to Win Again
text: MONACO — The Monaco Grand Prix was a wild race from start to finish, with multiple accidents, two safety-car periods, a half-hour red flag break just six laps before the end and a fight to the end among three drivers separated by less than a second.

headline: Federer Defeats Wawrinka to Reach Quarterfinals
text: PARIS — Roger Federer took 106 minutes to dispatch his countryman, Stanislas Wawrinka, at Roland Garros on Sunday for what could have been the Swiss national tennis championship. The final score: 6-3, 6-2, 7-5.

headline: A Quarterfinals Record Worth Noting
text: PARIS – As Novak Djokovic and his 40-0 record this year took the court under the watchful eyes of tennis historians and French fans (he was playing Richard Gasquet), Roger Federer was in the interview room, having already advanced.

headline: Reaction to Barcelona’s Victory
text: Postgame comments from some of the principals in Saturday’s Champions League final:

headline: Afghan Bank Commission Absolves President’s Brother in Fraud Case
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A commission appointed by President Hamid Karzai to assess responsibility for the massive fraud at Kabul Bank issued its report on Sunday, absolving the president’s brother of any blame.

headline: Islamists Seize a Yemeni City, Stoking Fears
text: SANA, Yemen — Islamist militants consolidated control over a second city in southern Yemen on Sunday, seizing banks, government offices and the security headquarters as government forces responded with mortar fire.

headline: For Palin, a Short Ride With Lots of Rumbling
text: Sarah Palin made a grand entrance at the Rolling Thunder biker rally on Sunday, wearing a black Harley-Davidson helmet and visibly enjoying herself as a crush of reporters and bikers swarmed her motorcycle.

headline: Dickey Says He Is Ready to Start, but Collins Isn’t So Sure
text: R.A. Dickey threw a full bullpen session before Sunday’s game against the Phillies and said he was prepared to make his next scheduled start on Tuesday. Terry Collins, his manager, isn’t so convinced.

headline: Djokovic Wins 41st Straight This Year
text: PARIS – Novak Djokovic, tennis’s most successful all-surface professional player of the moment and for many years, added a 41st consecutive victory to this year’s list and wove a competent straight-set victory over Richard Gasquet of France, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2. on Sunday at the French Open.

headline: Badminton Group Kills Controversial Dress Code Rule
text: Facing mounting criticism, the Badminton World Federation announced Sunday that it was scrapping a rule that would have forced women to wear skirts or dresses in elite competition.

headline: Sudan Threatens to Occupy 2 More Disputed Regions
text: JUBA, Sudan — The northern Sudanese Army is threatening to seize two more areas along the combustible north-south border, risking war just weeks before southern Sudan is due to split off as a new country, Western and Sudanese officials said Sunday.

headline: Changeovers Offer Glimpse Into Players’ Souls
text: PARIS — There was once not much of a changeover in tennis. Chairs were not used at Wimbledon until 1975, and until the demands of television had to be met, players stayed on their feet and quickly made their way to the opposite side of the court, taking a swig of water or perhaps something stronger along the way.

headline: After Zvonareva’s Loss, Schiavone Moves Into Role of Favorite
text: PARIS – Francesca Schiavone, a stunning French Open winner a year ago, is headed to this year’s quarterfinals suddenly cast as the tournament favorite.

headline: Skee-Ball, Played for Fun and Money
text: Dressed in an orange Tony the Tiger vest and clashing red-on-black striped pants, and proudly sporting a mullet hairdo, Joe Mucha grasped ball after ball, achieving a score that reflected his years of training in the art of Skee-Ball.

headline: Corruption Inquiry Leads FIFA to Bar Two More Officials
text: World soccer’s corruption scandal continued to widen Sunday with the suspension of two more powerful officials from the executive committee of FIFA, the sport’s governing body.

headline: A New Radio Home for Alternative Music
text: New York City’s alternative music scene will get a lift starting Wednesday, June 1, when WNYE-FM, the city-owned noncommercial station at 91.5 on the dial, begins broadcasting the indie music service “The Alternate Side” from 6 a.m. to noon. The program, started in 2008 by Fordham University’s public station WFUV-FM with support from the New York State Music Fund, has showcased artists like the Strokes and TV on the Radio as well as newer local groups like Freelance Whales.

headline: 3-D Starts to Fizzle, and Hollywood Frets
text: LOS ANGELES — Has the 3-D boom already gone bust? It’s starting to look that way — at least for American moviegoers — even as Hollywood prepares to release a glut of the gimmicky pictures.

headline: Visiting Joplin, Obama Offers Message of Comfort
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — A week ago the Missouri Southern State University campus here was rich with celebration and smiles as the graduating seniors of the public high school paraded across stage to grasp their diplomas. Within hours, a third of the town was destroyed — including Joplin High School — and scores of residents were dead, at least one of the newly minted graduates among them.

headline: Mets End Rocky Week by Thumping Phillies
text: After enduring one of the stranger and more stressful weeks in the team’s 49-year history, the Mets were eager to turn the page Sunday.

headline: The Morning Line: 12 Appear Ready for Belmont
text: Jerry Bossert in The Daily News reviewed the field for the Belmont Stakes to be run on June 11 and found that “a field of 12 appears set.” Mike Veitch in the Saratogian reviewed and rated the cast of 3-year-olds in the United States. His top four rated in order were Animal Kingdom, Shackleford, Nehro and Toby’s Corner.

headline: American Songbook as Fountain of Youth
text: “As many of you know, I’ve had three husbands and one meaningful love affair,” the singer Marilyn Maye remarked. “And now that I’m too old to be humble, the good news is that none of ’em worked. This is what I love.”

headline: Music to Echo Nature’s Sounds and Voices
text: One hundred years after Mahler’s death his work remains a vital influence, at least when it comes to talking animals. In a revealing recital Thursday evening at the Austrian Cultural Forum the soprano Ursula Langmayr sang two sets of Mahler songs about nature and beasts, using them to frame pieces on the same themes by three more recent, less famous Austrian composers.

headline: Ranking Baseball’s Best Ballparks
text: I’m working on an article about the New York Mets — but that subject is perhaps too depressing for a beautiful Memorial Day weekend.

headline: Winning Pair With Plenty of Experience
text: The world’s most successful single-session charity bridge tournament, the UJA-Federation of New York’s Women’s Philanthropy pro-am, was played Tuesday at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan. The winners with a huge 81 percent game were Jacqui Mitchell and Selma Schlechter of New York. Melih Ozdil and Sharon Goldman of New York finished second.

headline: The Trouble With E-Mail
text: Among Internet users with secrets, including bankers, lawyers, hackers and people who visit porn sites or confide in friends — so that would be all of us — there’s a widespread apprehension that the Web is no longer a safe place to spill them.

headline: Are There Natural Human Rights?
text: This has been a year of uprisings. The series of popular revolts, struggles and crackdowns by governments, which continue to this day, began in Tunisia when protesters demanded the removal of president Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali.  The claims of the protesters were about the right to eat (the cost of food), political corruption, freedom of speech and basic political rights.  Then came Egypt, as thousands flocked to Tahrir Square in Cairo and elsewhere.  Their demands were similar to those in Tunisia. Both sets of protesters were successful: the leaders of both countries fled.  This was the first wave.  It was largely peaceful.

headline: Schiavone Advances by Keeping Her Cool
text: The stakes were high late in the third set Sunday between Jelena Jankovic and the French Open defending champion, Francesca Schiavone. Both players had squandered opportunities to run away with the match, and neither was playing their best tennis. Schiavone had won converted just 4 of 19 break-point chances. Time and again, Schiavone set up the point, only to hit the final shot into the top of the net or just wide. For her part, Jankovic allowed her emotions to run away, especially at several critical junctures late in the match.

headline: The Dances of Africa, as Filtered Through the Americas
text: There’s nothing like a DanceAfrica performance to send you straight to summer. It has its own flow, and you can’t fight it, no matter how chaotic, raucous and hazily dull it becomes. Chuck Davis, the group’s artistic director, loves to speechify, and during the nearly two-and-a-half hour program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night — it was so long he had to cut the finale — there were two award presentations and a memorial service to honor those once connected to DanceAfrica.

headline: Focus Groups That Look Like Play Groups
text: The dozen women worked in meditative silence, gingerly pasting Barbie dolls, large colorful lollipops and pieces of feather boas on black poster board panels.

headline: The New Focus Group
text: An analysis of a type of market research that uses collages to learn about consumer feelings towards a brand or product.

headline: DanceAfrica 2011
text: Photos of the program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Monday: Himalayan Beast
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — All in all, this is a very straightforward Monday puzzle, with some nice entries making their first appearance today, like POLAR BEAR and AFTER GLOW, thankfully clued as a “Sunset remnant.”

headline: Five Poets Seasoned by Life
text: One of the great pleasures of poetry is catching a good poet in midcareer. Reading a savvy verse veteran is like watching Sandy Koufax paint a 1-0 shutout in his prime — some pure high heat here, a paralyzing curve there, then a little deliberate deception way down in the dirt. Any one of the following books by midcareer poets would be a bracing warm-weather antidote to the clankety-clank-clank of Stieg Larsson’s alleged thrillers, or the kohl-smeared smirks that make up the “Pirates of the Caribbean” movies.

headline: Demonstrators Rally Against Mladic Extradition
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — Groups of youths throwing stones and bottles clashed with riot police officers on Sunday evening in Belgrade, after thousands of Serbian nationalists rallied outside Parliament against the arrest and extradition of Ratko Mladic, the former Serbian military commander facing war crimes charges in The Hague for atrocities committed during the 1990s Balkans conflict.

headline: Sex and the City (Atlanta), With Racial Politics
text: Even if you’ve never sweated through a Dolce & Gabbana bustier on a neon-lighted dance floor somewhere deep into a fifth or sixth shot of Grey Goose, you have surely, by virtue of living, absorbed the message of Beyoncé’s revenge-as-empowerment anthem, “Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It).” If not, let me boil it down for you: Most men are toddlers who get bored with their toys, dump them into the sandbox and then get ticked off when someone else on the playground dares to use them.

headline: City College to Support New Theater Uptown
text: In a bid to broaden its theater program and to bring additional polished, diverse theater uptown, City College of New York is lending critical support to an effort to open a new professional theater in residence uptown at Aaron Davis Hall.

headline: A Striking, Gentle Portrait of a Shaker Community
text: It must be nice when “I passed the meeting house without saying a prayer” is the worst sin you can recall committing.

headline: Two Top Giselles, Back to Back
text: Behind the story of “Giselle” lie the still dismaying, well-attested historical accounts of dance mania that caused deaths in the Rhineland in the late medieval and early Renaissance eras. Onstage love, death and dance all come together in an engrossingly beautiful vortex. Other ballets have greater music and greater choreography, yet this one still takes us deep into the classically Romantic heart of what ballet itself is all about.

headline: CBS Radio Reminds D.J.’s to Identify Songs: ‘When You Play It, Say It’
text: It would seem one of the basic tasks of any disk jockey: tell listeners the name of the song they just heard. But last week the head of a major radio company felt compelled to instruct its programmers to start identifying more of the songs played on the air, by title and artist name.

headline: Modern Dance Has an iPhone App
text: Modern dance now has a new performance space, the iPhone, with a free app called Dances for an iPhone, created by the choreographer and videographer Richard Daniels. It features six short films with performances by the dancers Carmen de Lavallade, Deborah Jowitt, Regina Larkin, Christine Redpath and Megan Williams, with biographical information for each performer. Mr. Daniels said this was the first installment in a planned series meant to bring the world of dance to a digital audience. Mr. Daniels is an artist in residence at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in New York, where an update for the app, featuring seven new performances, is in production.

headline: Jewish Prize for Brooklyn Author
text: Austin Ratner has won the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature, the Jewish Book Council has announced. Mr. Ratner, who lives in Brooklyn, will receive the $100,000 award, presented each year to an emerging Jewish writer, for his novel, “The Jump Artist” (Bellevue Literary Press, 2009). Joseph Skibell, the second-place winner, will receive the Jewish Literature Choice Award of $25,000, for his novel “A Curable Romantic” (Algonquin Books, 2010). Both awards will be presented on Tuesday at the Center for Jewish History in New York.

headline: Selections for Next Link Project
text: The New York Musical Theater Festival has selected musicals for its 2011 Next Link Project, a program that provides visibility, financial support, training and networking for rising talent with previously unproduced work. Twelve of the festival’s fully staged slots will go to Next Link Project productions, including “The Brain That Wouldn’t Die! In 3-D!!!,” with book and lyrics by T. Sivak and E. Gelman, and “Jack Perry Is Alive (and Dating),” with book and lyrics by Harrison David Rivers and Daniella Shoshan and music by Julia Meinwald. Selections were chosen by a jury of industry professionals.  The festival will run from Sept. 26 to Oct. 16.

headline: At I.M.F., a Strict Ethics Code Doesn’t Apply to Top Officials
text: At the International Monetary Fund, there is one set of ethics guidelines for the rank-and-file staff and another for the 24 elite executive directors who oversee the powerful organization.

headline: Debbie Reynolds Auctions Costume Collection
text: Ever wanted to dress up as Judy Garland in “The Wizard of Oz” or as Marilyn Monroe in “The Seven Year Itch”? Profiles in History, a California auction house, is offering enthusiasts an opportunity actually to do so when it puts the famous dresses from those movies and other famous costume pieces worn by classic film stars up for auction on June 18 in Beverly Hills, Reuters reported. The 3,500-piece collection, which is owned by Debbie Reynolds, will include a bowler worn by Charlie Chaplin, the gold velvet gown worn by Barbra Streisand in “Hello, Dolly!,” right, the Ascot dress worn by Audrey Hepburn in “My Fair Lady,” left, and several costumes for Julie Andrews in “The Sound of Music.” Ms. Reynolds said that she was sad to break up the collection but that recent attempts to open a museum to showcase the items had fallen through. “I’ve reached such a difficult time with the economic situation,” Ms. Reynolds told Reuters. “To keep them stored another 50 years didn’t make sense. I hope in the end they all find happy homes, that they will be shown, and that they might even land in museums.”

headline: Pop Goes the BB Gun, in Tune
text: “A Christmas Story,” the holiday film classic about a boy and his Red Ryder BB gun, will find new life on the stage as “A Christmas Story, the Musical!,” the producers announced. The production features a score by the composer-lyricist team Benj Pasek and Justin Paul (“Roald Dahl’s James and the Giant Peach” ) and a book by Joseph Robinette (“Charlotte’s Web”) based on the writings of the radio humorist Jean Shepherd and the 1983 “Christmas Story” film. The prime mover behind the project is Warren Carlyle, choreographer of the Kennedy Center’s current production of “Follies” in Washington. “A Christmas Story, the Musical!” will begin a five-city tour on Nov. 8 in Hershey, Pa.; it ends with a three-week run at the Chicago Theater. Peter Billingsley, who starred in the film, above, as the boy who was warned about the perils of playing with the gun, has signed on as a producer.

headline: ‘Giselle’
text: Diana Vishneva and Alina Cojocaru danced for American Ballet Theater.

headline: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Parenthood Plays
text: Two male playwrights consider the perks and perils of parenthood in new shows that recently opened in New York. Daniel Goldfarb’s “Cradle and All,” from the Manhattan Theater Club, is about two couples living in Brooklyn Heights, one considering having a baby and the other wondering whether or not to let their baby cry herself to sleep. In Jonathan Marc Sherman’s “Knickerbocker,” which closed on Sunday at the Public Theater, a 40-year-old man comes to terms with being a father for the first time.

headline: Japan Appears Dispensable as a Supplier
text: Maybe Japan is not as crucial to the global supply chain as those first weeks after the earthquake made it seem.

headline: Palin at Rolling Thunder
text: Sarah Palin and her family participated in a motorcycle ride honoring veterans.

headline: Palin’s Path May Be Unclear, but Her Ride Is Revved Up
text: WASHINGTON — For sheer mastery of celebrity theater, Sarah Palin cannot be beat.

headline: FIFA Clears Blatter and Suspends Two Others
text: A FIFA ethics panel on Sunday suspended two of the organization’s most powerful figures, Mohamed bin Hammam of Qatar and Jack Warner of Trinidad and Tobago, after they were accused of corruption. But the panel found no wrongdoing by the FIFA president, Sepp Blatter, clearing him to run unopposed for a fourth term as president. The vote is scheduled for Wednesday. Read Jeré Longman’s article here, and a news analysis by Rob Hughes on what the ruling says about Blatter, then come back to comment.

headline: Bill Gates and the School Reform Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bullpen Rests as Sabathia Helps Yankees Avoid a Sweep
text: SEATTLE — If nothing about their first two games at Safeco Field qualified as relaxing for the Yankees, then Sunday allowed Manager Joe Girardi to sit in his figurative Adirondack chair, sip a tall glass of iced tea and just watch and enjoy.

headline: How to Explain the Decrease in Major Crime?
text: To the Editor:

headline: An Outsider Making Waves in Hollywood
text: Los Angeles

headline: Rookie Loses Indy 500 With Crash on Last Turn
text: INDIANAPOLIS — J. R. Hildebrand, a 23-year-old rookie, had much more on his mind around midafternoon Sunday than just completing one smooth turn that would have won the Indianapolis 500. He was low on fuel. He was swooping in on lapped traffic. And Dan Wheldon was closing fast.

headline: Fearing Alzheimer’s
text: To the Editor:

headline: As PC Markets Slow, Nvidia Aims at Tablets
text: Jen-Hsun Huang has rallied his engineers and developers before around his grand plans for Nvidia, the computer chipmaker he helped found nearly 20 years ago.

headline: Mugabe Ally Escalates Push to Control Anglican Church
text: HARARE, Zimbabwe — Religion, like politics, is often a dangerous business in this country.

headline: Forgetting Why We Remember
text: MOST Americans know that Memorial Day is about honoring the nation’s war dead. It is also a holiday devoted to department store sales, half-marathons, picnics, baseball and auto racing. But where did it begin, who created it, and why?

headline: Teacher of the Hour, 14 Times Daily
text: Calling Allan Renz a golf teacher with a lot of students is like calling Manhattan an island with a lot of buildings.

headline: YouTube's Next Stars
text: The winners of YouTube’s talent search contest spent a week in video training boot camp at Google’s headquarters in New York to elevate their production skills. Here are the contestants’ entries and pitches in their own words.

headline: French Official Resigns Amid Harassment Suits
text: PARIS — A junior government minister resigned Sunday after two women filed sexual harassment suits against him last week, becoming the first clear political casualty here of the fallout from the arrest of the French economist Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

headline: At YouTube Boot Camp, Future Stars Polish Their Acts
text: Vanessa Wilson was back in class last week for the first time since law school. Only this time, she said, she wasn’t bored.

headline: Last Man Standing (Barely) Will Face Djokovic, if He Can Recover
text: PARIS — Shallow on star power but deep on compelling plot, the fourth-round marathon between Fabio Fognini and Alberto Montañés was one of the wilder rides in memory at Roland Garros.

headline: Retailers Offer Apps With a Catalog Feel
text: Mia Sara, 43, a Manhattan transplant in Los Angeles, misses window shopping in New York, but has found a replacement — shopping on her iPad.

headline: Some Faint Praise for Mr. Ballmer
text: Microsoft has missed too many opportunities under Steve Ballmer’s stewardship. It’s a fair criticism reignited last week by the hedge fund boss, David Einhorn, who called for the software giant’s chief executive to step down. But that doesn’t necessarily mean Mr. Ballmer will go. Based on total return to shareholders, other long-time company bosses, including Jeff Immelt at General Electric, have fared worse.

headline: Against Learned Helplessness
text: Unemployment is a terrible scourge across much of the Western world. Almost 14 million Americans are jobless, and millions more are stuck with part-time work or jobs that fail to use their skills. Some European countries have it even worse: 21 percent of Spanish workers are unemployed.

headline: For French, Arrest Forces Some Questions of Identity
text: Anne Cottavoz is of two minds about the Dominique Strauss-Kahn affair, her American mind and her French mind, though she concedes that after living in the United States for 27 years, there may be some blurring of the two.

headline: Riding the Rails to the Circus Ring
text: P.T. Barnum first took to the rails with his self-proclaimed “greatest show on earth” in 1872, and trains still keep the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus on the move.

headline: Florida Governor Vetoes PBS Funding
text: Just as a deal came together late last week to keep PBS programming on the air in Orlando, Florida’s public broadcasters suffered a financial blow when Gov. Rick Scott vetoed the state’s nearly $4.8 million appropriation for public broadcasting.

headline: Northwestern Wins 6th Title in 7 Years
text: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Since losing in last year’s national championship game, the Northwestern lacrosse players Brianne LoManto and Shannon Smith had been contemplating the day they might return to this stage. That this year’s final would be played on Long Island — minutes from where LoManto, the Wildcats’ goalkeeper, and Smith, an attacker, grew up — made the opportunity that much more special.

headline: Honors for War Service, Long Unacknowledged
text: It was a family mystery. Everyone knew that Milton Rein had served in the United States Army during World War II. Everyone suspected that he had seen combat.

headline: Skull Found in Backyard of Old Home in Brooklyn
text: Bright sun and heat beckoned many New Yorkers who had remained in the city over the Memorial Day weekend into their backyards.

headline: Trust but E-Verify
text: The Arizona immigration law was controversial from the beginning. Critics said it was ripe for abuse, implicitly discriminatory and probably unconstitutional as well. Business groups and liberal activists joined forces to oppose it.

headline: Horton Is Bruins’ Finishing Touch
text: BOSTON — For a seven-year N.H.L. veteran who had never played in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Nathan Horton certainly knows what to do there.

headline: Among Bodies Discarded on a Beach, One That Doesn’t Fit
text: The little girl had lived, at most, 730 days or so. Someone had hidden her body in the thicket of branches and poison ivy off Ocean Parkway on the South Shore of Long Island. By the time the police discovered her on April 4, the remains had turned skeletal.

headline: Man and Woman Killed at Brooklyn Housing Project
text: A man and a woman were killed and another man was wounded in a shooting early Sunday morning in a courtyard of a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

headline: Inching Closer to States’ Rights
text: Chief Justice John Roberts is one vote short of moving the Supreme Court to a position so conservative on states’ rights that it would be to the right of the Tea Party’s idea of limited government. That chilling possibility was evident in the court’s recent ruling in the case of Virginia v. Stewart.

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Kindnesses of New Yorkers
text: DEAR Diary:

headline: Rep. Ryan’s Dubious Sales Pitch
text: Representative Paul Ryan is rebutting critics of his plan to turn Medicare into a “premium support” program, pointing to two existing programs that he says prove his approach would be better for beneficiaries. Don’t believe it.

headline: Detroit’s Rebound Is Built on Smaller Cars
text: DETROIT — After years of being outgunned by Japanese rivals, the American auto industry has made small cars a central part of its strategy, seeking to capitalize on a fundamental shift in the preferences of consumers in an era of fast-rising gas prices.

headline: Hudson Power Cable Still Has Critics in 2 States
text: New York City officials are not completely sold on it, some state lawmakers are dead-set against it and now regulators in New Jersey are trying to stop it. But New York’s governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, wants it, so a cable that would carry electricity from New Jersey to Manhattan appears to be about to make its way across the Hudson River.

headline: Her Inheritance: An Eagerness to Serve
text: A few months before Kathy Hochul was born, her family was living in a 31-by-8-foot trailer not far from the hulking Bethlehem Steel plant near Buffalo. When things got a little better, they moved to the second-floor flat of a home in working-class Woodlawn.

headline: Millions Need Not Apply
text: Millions of Americans who lost their jobs to the recession and fell behind in payments to creditors are being penalized again, this time by companies that use credit records to screen job applicants. Five states have limited the use of credit histories by potential employers and about 20 are considering similar measures that deserve to become law.

headline: Among the Graves This Memorial Day
text: Today, there are families knotted in mourning for a soldier recently lost in Iraq or Afghanistan. There are families for which mourning has become an absence more persistently felt than they could ever have imagined.

headline: Corrections
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Shouts of ‘Pull Him Back!’ Then Rescuers Do Just That.
text: A man who was dangling from the Brooklyn Bridge was pulled to safety by police officers Sunday afternoon as scores of people watched from the pedestrian walkway, from the street below and from cars on the bridge that had been halted during the rescue.

headline: Of Monsters, Men — And Topic Modeling
text: “The blood of the first Martyr has flowed,” the Richmond Daily Dispatch announced on May 27, 1861. Three days earlier Confederate partisan James Jackson had been killed in Alexandria, Va., by a Union soldier after Jackson shot and killed Union Col. Elmer Ellsworth, who had charged into Jackson’s inn to remove a Confederate flag atop the building. Arguably the first casualties of the war, Jackson and Ellsworth became celebrated martyrs for the respective Confederate and Union causes.

headline: Public Services for Memorial Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Lockheed Strengthens Network Security After Hacker Attack
text: Lockheed Martin said on Sunday that it had stepped up its investigation into a sophisticated hacking attack on its computer networks and bolstered security measures for gaining remote access to its systems.

headline: An Ark Built for Today
text: A man in Dordrecht, the Netherlands built an ark to teach others about the bible.

headline: A Biblical Blueprint Meets the Fire Code and the Neighbors
text: DORDRECHT, the Netherlands — If Noah had run into the modern nanny state, or nimby, or a few of the other obstacles that Johan Huibers has been facing, the animal kingdom might look a lot different today.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for March, the Chicago purchasing managers index for May and consumer confidence for May (Tuesday); the ADP employment report and the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for May, construction spending for April and North American auto sales for May (Wednesday); same-store sales for May, revised first-quarter productivity and factory orders for April (Thursday); and unemployment and the I.S.M. service index for May (Friday).

headline: Harvard Business Review Reinvention Is Paying Off
text: Shortly after editors at the Harvard Business Review tore up their magazine in 2009, adding pictures to the cover, reader comments to their signature case studies and colorful illustrations — the horror! — cranky reader comments started coming in.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Tuesday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Stories of Bad Golf Courses, Landfills and Kangaroos
text: Charles McGrath’s On Par essay last week extolling the beauty of bad golf courses elicited a long list of reader tributes to the ugly ducklings of the game, including courses with abandoned cars, moose droppings and kangaroos.

headline: Serb Fugitive Slowly Starved of Friends and Cash
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — The arrest of war crimes fugitive Ratko Mladic, found hiding inside a darkened house in a Serbian village last week, came from methodically pressuring his waning network of supporters and draining his financial lifeline so thoroughly that his most bitter complaint when captured was a demand for his frozen military pension of 140 euros a month, according to investigators in Serbia.

headline: For Ex-Officer’s Wife, Anger at His Accuser and Tears at an Upended Life
text: Kenneth Moreno, the former police officer acquitted of rape last week, gazed toward the pavement, choosing his words carefully, thinking of a measured way to describe his feelings about the woman who had accused him.

headline: Young and Bored, Behind the Wheel
text: BENGHAZI, Libya — The battered white sedan plunged forward, its engine whining and tires screaming, across the long, tiled plaza in a practiced routine of skids and slides. With a quick yank of the wheel, the driver narrowly missed other snaking cars, and with a tug of the hand brake jerked to a halt inches shy of a crowd of cheering spectators.

headline: The Battle for Libya | May 29, 2011
text: Rebel recruits graduate and frontline fire gets heavier.

headline: Outbreak of Infections Kills 10 in Germany
text: BERLIN — With 10 people dead of infection and 400 cases reported, the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control said Sunday that a bacterial outbreak in northern Germany was one of the largest of its kind ever reported worldwide.

headline: Looking Like His Old Self, Watson Adds Another Major Title
text: Great players don’t forget how to do great things. When a defining moment comes, and a golfer like Tom Watson has an opportunity to win a major championship as he did on Sunday it’s just a matter of whether the body will do what the old head tells it to do.

headline: Syrian Forces Struck Northern Villages, Activists Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government deployed the military and security forces to four villages and towns on Sunday, killing at least eight people and wounding many others, in the latest attempt to crush a two-month-old uprising against the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad, human rights groups and activists said.

headline: Nepal Averts Crisis Over Constitution Deadline
text: KATMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s political parties averted a crisis on Sunday by reaching a last-minute deal that extended the deadline for a new constitution. Prime Minister Jhalanath Khanal agreed to step down as part of the deal.

headline: Feud in Kazakh President’s Family Spills Into U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Kazakhstan’s foreign minister summoned the United States ambassador to a meeting in Astana, the capital of his oil-rich nation, to warn that a family squabble between the country’s president and his son-in-law — two of the country’s most powerful men — had boiled over.

headline: A Crackdown on Employing Illegal Workers
text: TUCSON — Obama administration officials are sharpening their crackdown on the hiring of illegal immigrants by focusing increasingly tough criminal charges on employers while moving away from criminal arrests of the workers themselves.

headline: Changes in Oregon Law Put Faith-Healing Parents on Trial
text: OREGON CITY, Ore. — At the Clackamas County courthouse here, Timothy and Rebecca Wyland sat next to each other — ramrod straight, their shoulders barely touching — as they watched images of their daughter flash on the screen.

headline: Seeing the Advantage in Delaying a Solution
text: WASHINGTON — Soon enough, Democrats will have to identify new Medicare cuts they can support.

headline: An Unclear Course on Emissions Policy
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Opposition to cap and trade, a regulatory tool for curbing greenhouse gas emissions, normally comes from the right end of the political spectrum, where it is derided as “cap and tax.”

headline: Missouri, Baylor and Cal Advance to World Series
text: Missouri, Baylor and California won super-regional finals to complete the field for the Women’s College World Series. The eight-team tournament begins Thursday in Oklahoma City.

headline: Congressman Says Hacker Sent Lewd Photo Using His Name
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, one of the most prolific users of social media among politicians, said his Twitter account was hacked this weekend when someone sent out a lewd photograph under his name to a young woman in Seattle.

headline: Finding Voice in the Pain of a Family and Its Fall
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — When Victoria Ford was a little girl growing up in Memphis, her family was so widely known, strangers would see her at the grocery store, notice a resemblance and ask, “Are you a Ford?”

headline: The Landscape in the Backyard Is Hydroelectric
text: Ron and Melodie Koe were cruising sunny Eastern Washington in search of a retirement home three years ago when they happened down Columbia Avenue here. The houses, cottages built in the 1930s, were adorable. Old maples lined the sidewalks. Everything was immaculate.

headline: Utah Law Makes Coins Worth Their Weight in Gold (or Silver)
text: FARR WEST, Utah — Most people who amass the pure gold and silver coins produced by the United States Mint do so for collections or investments, not to buy Slurpees at 7-Eleven.

headline: Earnhardt Out of Fuel; Harvick Wins
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Only a driver as beloved as Dale Earnhardt Jr. could deliver such exquisite agony to his long suffering fans.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,581 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: NYT: Front Page for 05/30/2011
text: NYT: Front Page for 05/30/2011

headline: Chinese Try to Appease Mongolians
text: HOHHOT, Inner Mongolia — Chinese authorities publicly acknowledged for the first time on Sunday the depth of anger among ethnic Mongolians over the hit-and-run killing of a herder by a Han Chinese truck driver nearly three weeks ago, which became a catalyst for days of street protests and led to fears among officials here of an outbreak in anti-Han violence.

headline: Paul J. Wiedorfer, Hero of the Battle of the Bulge, Dies at 90
text: Paul J. Wiedorfer, who earned the Medal of Honor for charging across an icy field in Belgium in 1944 and eliminating two German machine-gun nests that had pinned down his platoon, died on Wednesday in Baltimore. He was 90.

headline: Sergei Bagapsh, Abkhazia’s Leader, Dies at 62
text: MOSCOW — Sergei V. Bagapsh, who led the Black Sea enclave of Abkhazia through a tumultuous effort to gain independence from Georgia without being absorbed by Russia, died Sunday in Moscow. He was 62.

headline: Photo Replay: May 29
text: A view of the day in sports, from the courts of Paris to the crashes in Indianapolis.

headline: ‘To a Restless Little Brother Calling for Mama in His Sleep’
text: You may not understand this now, but she isn’t coming back. Not tonight. Not tomorrow. Day after that. And no, she hasn’t left anything behind — a sticky note on the refrigerator door or a quick message for the answering machine, her voice a distant echo calling your name and mine. Nothing. I’m sorry because I know you get scared when the wind blows hard like this at night, when the shadows on your ceiling shuffle as if they’ve been alive all this time. But I’m right here. And the sun will not rise for another few hours and the birds outside are still sleeping —remember Johnjohn, your favorite cardinals nestled in the Sweet Gum tree down by the mailbox? The babies wrapped in small, ruby feathers. That’s how you should be right now. Dreaming and resting and not worrying.

headline: As Physicians’ Jobs Change, So Do Their Politics
text: AUGUSTA, Me. — With Republicans in complete control of Maine’s state government for the first time since 1962, State Senator Lois A. Snowe-Mello offered a bill in February to limit doctors’ liability that she was sure the powerful doctors’ lobby would cheer. Instead, it asked her to shelve the measure.

headline: Hackers Disrupt PBS Web Site and Post a Fake Report About a Rap Artist
text: The PBS Web site briefly carried a fake article claiming that the famed rapper Tupac Shakur was alive and living in New Zealand after a group of hackers took over the organization’s computer systems on Saturday night.

headline: Germany, in Reversal, Will Close Nuclear Plants by 2022
text: BERLIN — The German government on Monday announced plans to shut all of the nation’s nuclear power plants within the next 11 years, a sharp reversal for Chancellor Angela Merkel after the Japanese disaster at Fukushima caused an electoral backlash by voters opposed to reliance on nuclear energy.

headline: Latino Artists on Display at London Fair
text: Latin American exuberance will pervade the Pinta Latin American Art Fair, from June 7 to 9 at the Earls Court Exhibition Center. Featuring both established and emerging artists, the exhibition (Brompton Hall, Warwick Road, Earls Court; www.eco.co.uk) will bring together works from 50 American and European galleries all in one inviting setting.

headline: The Case for Ken Anderson’s Place in the Hall of Fame
text: Kerry J. Byrne of the Cold, Hard Football Facts has been making the case for Ken Anderson’s enshrinement into the Hall of Fame, based on three sets of qualifications:

headline: Shared Capitalism
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

headline: The Early Word: Commemorations
text: Today’s Times

headline: Chasing Win Record, Djokovic Faces Tough Finale
text: PARIS – Fabio Fognini, citing a muscle tear in his leg, pulled out of the French Open on Monday, altering the arc of Novak Djokovic’s winning streak.

headline: Air India Faces Hurdles in Joining Alliance
text: NEW DELHI — Air India, the troubled state-owned airline, risks being rejected by the Star Alliance network of airlines because of delays in fulfilling membership conditions, an executive from Star Alliance said Monday, putting in jeopardy a key element of its turnaround plan.

headline: Suspended in Space, 103 Stories Over Chicago
text: CHICAGO — The view looking down through the glass floor toward South Wacker Drive is just what you’d expect if you were balanced on top of 6,960 boxes of this city’s deep-dish pizza — or, as the exhibition at the Willis Tower also tells us, standing atop 313 Oprah Winfreys or 283 Barack Obamas.

headline: Complaint Box | Pre-Ponderance
text: Every day, it seems, I am preapproved, prequalified or precertified for yet another credit card or home equity loan that I don’t want. I already have enough credit cards, thank you, so that I can prepay my daughter’s college tuition, allowing her to preregister for courses (pre-med? pre-law?). I can use those cards to pile up air miles so that I can preboard a plane at the airport (after pre-check-in, of course). I can even preorder items during the annual presale event at a major department store.

headline: Tempted to Speed? Consider Your Auto Insurance
text: Steep prices at the gasoline pump aren’t the only thing drivers need to worry about this summer travel season. Speeding tickets and other moving violations can increase your automobile insurance rates by double digits, a recent analysis shows.

headline: Yemeni Military Battles Opponents on Two Fronts
text: SANA, Yemen — The government pounded a major coastal city on Monday with airstrikes to dislodge Islamic militants and, to the west, smashed the country’s largest antigovernment demonstration in overnight clashes that killed at least 20 protesters, according to witnesses reached by phone.

headline: Heading the IMF
text: I suspect that an endorsement from me may be the kiss of death — but anyway, Stan Fischer really would be the best choice.

headline: Godwin’s Law, Monetary Edition
text: Any mention of the advantages of a higher inflation target will evoke, almost immediately, claims that you’re trying to turn America into the Weimar Republic and/or Zimbabwe.

headline: The Unkillable Yield Curve Fallacy (Wonkish)
text: Bad ideas in economics never die; they just wait a few months, then resurface, once again touted as wisdom.

headline: Qaddafi and Zuma Meet but Reach No Agreement
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Talks between President Jacob Zuma of South Africa and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi ended Monday with no sign of the breakthrough Libyan officials had said they hoped for ahead of the visit. The outcome appeared to leave the Tripoli government and its rebel foes still mired in the stalemate that has settled over the conflict, and NATO with the prospect of an extended campaign of airstrikes in its bid to topple the Libyan leader.

headline: Taliban Attack in Herat, Far From Their Usual Areas
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban launched an unusual attack on targets in the western Afghan city of Herat on Monday, including a NATO base, and the police said at least 4 people had been killed and 38 wounded.

headline: Monday Reading: Bargain Trips in the Mountains or the Desert
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Carnegie’s Ousted Residents Agree: Film Has Sad Ending
text: It was not billed as a three-hankie movie — it was a documentary, after all. But Editta Sherman started sobbing a few minutes after the lights went down, and not because of the way she looked on the screen.

headline: Palin Family Tours Washington ‘Incognito’
text: Sarah Palin and her family sneaked out in Washington on Sunday night for what she called an “incognito” tour of the national monuments, having successfully created a media frenzy and then ditched the press.

headline: Li Fires Husband as Coach, Advances to Quarterfinals
text: PARIS – At the Australian Open earlier this year, the surging Li Na reached her first Grand Slam final. She gave credit to her husband and coach, Jiang Shan, saying she would love her husband even if he were “fat and ugly.”

headline: Capturing Moments of Naval History in New York
New Data on High Unemployment Among Recent Veterans
text: Much has been said about the high unemployment rate among veterans from the post-9/11 wars, but a new Congressional study offers some fresh insights into the nature of the problem, which does not appear to be going away anytime soon.

headline: Djokovic-Gasquet: the Mental Mismatch
text: Most matches are decided before the players take the court. Each player, according to this theory, knows who will win, and the loser spends a lot of energy playing just well enough to have a respectable showing, but without truly believing victory is possible.

headline: In a Flash, Bryans Advance in Doubles
text: PARIS -– Workmanlike is the word that describes Bob and Mike Bryan of the United States, the world’s top-ranked team, as they move through the men’s doubles draw at the French Open.

headline: The Facts Have A Liberal Bias, Again
text: Steve Benen watches an entire panel on Meet the Press condemn Democrats for accurately describing the Ryan plan:

headline: Tressel Quits as N.C.A.A. Investigates Ohio State
text: Jim Tressel resigned as the football coach at Ohio State on Monday, an abrupt move in a long but escalating scandal that has ensnared the university in an N.C.A.A. investigation and sullied Tressel’s reputation.

headline: Animal Kingdom Sharp in First Gallop Since Preakness
text: On a day when the Kentucky Derby runner-up, Nehro, put in a smashing work at Churchill Downs (6 furlongs in 1:12.2), Animal Kingdom put in his first gallop since his second-place finish in the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Fortis to Buy Vermont Utility for $470.3 Million
text: Fortis Incorporated, a Canadian power company, said on Monday that it would expand its presence in the United States by buying Central Vermont Public Service for $470.3 million in cash. It will also assume the company’s $230 million in debt.

headline: Copenhagen Interpretation Finance
text: Also, it’s both a recession and a recovery, depending on the observer.

headline: Nadal Cruises Past Ljubicic into Quarters
text: PARIS – Ivan Ljubicic wore a worried expression on his tanned face. It was only 1-1 in the first set against Rafael Nadal, the French Open’s top seed, but Ljubicic was already struggling with his serve.

headline: The Changing Politics of Doctors
text: Doctors were once overwhelmingly male and conservative. But today the politics of the medical profession are changing, as more doctors abandon independent practice for salaried jobs and more women are graduating from medical school, reports Gardiner Harris in the latest installment of his Doctors, Inc. series.

headline: Numberplay: A Triplet of Time Puzzles
text: Neil Bickford recently calculated the first 458 million terms for the continued fraction of pi. That’s a record. He cranked out the giant calculation several months ago to celebrate his 13th birthday. Holy cats! you might say: 458 million terms! It’s true. Here’s Mr. Bickford’s account of the adventure, including a link to a complete list of the terms.

headline: Dempsey Appointed as Chairman of Joint Chiefs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday nominated Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the Army chief, to help steer the American armed forces through the three present conflicts in Muslim countries as the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

headline: Monfils Delights Crowd With Five-Set Victory Over Ferrer
text: PARIS -– If Gael Monfils, the flamboyant French dynamo, picked a favorite shot from his 6-4, 2-6, 7-5, 1-6, 8-6 victory over David Ferrer of Spain, it might be an inside-out forehand that split Court Suzanne Lenghlen into two sharp angles and bounded onward for a winner. It was seven games into the fifth set and it put Monfils ahead, 5-2.

headline: Blatter Defiant During News Conference
text: 1:10 p.m. | Updated  Sepp Blatter’s news conference in Zurich, which was scheduled to begin at 12 p.m., Eastern, did not start until 12:35 p.m. What follows is a transcript of the news conference that was streamed live at FIFA.com.

headline: Anger Over Protesters’ Deaths Leads to Intensified Demonstrations by Mongolians
text: HOHHOT, China — Ethnic Mongolians seething over the killings of two Mongolians by Han Chinese drivers took their anger to the streets of this capital of Inner Mongolia on Monday in a rare expression of antigovernment sentiment here.

headline: Justice Stevens Is Off the Bench but Not Out of Opinions
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Palins Continue Roll Through Washington
text: Day 2 of the Sarah Palin bus tour started Monday morning with a visit to the National Archives in Washington, where she and her family took a private moment to look at the Constitution.

headline: Rollins, Fearless Forecaster, Makes Call on N.B.A. Finals, Too
text: When it comes to baseball, Jimmy Rollins has been exceptionally accurate in the forecasting business. He predicted that the Phillies would win 100 games in 2008; they won 103 and captured the World Series. In 2009, he predicted that the Phillies would meet the Yankees in the World Series; they did. (He also said that Philadelphia would win; well, can’t win ’em all.)

headline: 30 Years In, We Are Still Learning From AIDS
text: At first it seemed an oddity: a scattering of reports in the spring and early summer of 1981 that young gay men in New York and California were ill with forms of pneumonia and cancer usually seen only in people with severely weakened immune systems.

headline: At City Ballet, the Big Boss Plays the ‘Big Boss’
text: A mild tremor of excitement ran through the New York City Ballet audience on Sunday afternoon as the cast of George Balanchine’s “Slaughter on Tenth Avenue” took a bow. The dark-suited and hatted dancer who had played the “Big Boss” in the delightful tale of murder and mayhem at the ballet, had just popped out of the wings, performed a quick, modest salute, and popped back in. It took a moment to realize that the Big Boss was in fact the Big Boss. Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of the company, had stepped in for an injured Ask la Cour the previous night, and reappeared at the matinee with no fanfare or announcement of the change in cast.

headline: Exercise and Olives
text: I’m spending a lot of time alone this summer, and though I’m a pretty good companion for myself (I think that all my jokes are hilarious), there’s always room for more ways to stay entertained.

headline: Two New York Hotels Allow You to Sleep Under the Stars
text: In years past, hotel rooms offering outdoor showers in Manhattan were all the rage. This year, the latest in urban en plein air living is the outdoor bedroom.

headline: China’s Economy Slows, but Inflation Still Looms
text: CHANGSHA, China — China’s economy is starting to slow, after two years of torrid growth achieved following the global downturn.

headline: Soderling Squashes Simon’s French Dream
text: PARIS -– For the crowd at Roland Garros, the prize would have been two Frenchmen stepping into the final eight of their country’s international championship, the French Open. First, Gael Monfils made half of that prize come true. Then, Gilles Simon had a chance to join him.

headline: Surprise Victory in New York Invigorates Democrats Looking to 2012
text: WASHINGTON — Sal Pace, the Democratic leader of the State House in Colorado, was already preparing to run for Congress in a district captured by Republicans last year, but his party’s special election victory last week in a conservative district in upstate New York made the decision all the easier.

headline: Police Investigator Is Cleared in Death of Russian Awaiting Trial
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s Investigative Committee said Monday that prosecutors had cleared a police investigator of any wrongdoing in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, whose death in pre-trial detention is viewed as a test of country’s law enforcement and judicial systems.

headline: Does Money Grow on Art Market Trees? Not for Everyone
text: As all the talk of record prices demonstrates, contemporary art has soared in value over the last 10 years, outperforming stocks as an investment and drawing attention to possible bonanzas to be found in the market.

headline: Seeds of Promise
text: A few years ago, we began to hear a lot about flaxseeds. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, these seeds also are loaded with vitamin E, B vitamins and certain important minerals (manganese, potassium, calcium, iron, magnesium, zinc and selenium). Impressed, I’d buy flaxseeds from time to time and add them to breads, muffins or granola. But to be honest, I never much liked the taste.

headline: Mladic Appeals Extradition on Health Grounds
text: BELGRADE, Serbia — The lawyer for the war crimes suspect Ratko Mladic mailed an appeal of his extradition order on health grounds Monday, a tactic likely to result in a short delay in the ex-general’s departure from Serbia for trial before the special tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague.

headline: The Difference-Maker: Monfils’s Backhand
text: Gael Monfils won the first set over David Ferrer with remarkably consistent play off the backhand side. It was clear from the outset that Ferrer was going to work over the Monfils backhand, trying to break down the shot with a relentless assault. Monfils was ready, however, and played patiently with a high shot tolerance to thwart the Spaniard’s opening tactics.

headline: Box Office Welcomes Another ‘Hangover’
text: “The Hangover Part II” has sold about $137.4 million in tickets since opening in North American theaters on Thursday, according to results compiled by Hollywood.com. That performance — the biggest debut for a live-action comedy and the strongest opening for an R-rated comedy — helped drive robust business for the Memorial Day weekend.Audiences for the top 12 films over the four-day weekend spent about $272.8 million on tickets, up 48 percent from the same period last year. (The figures were not adjusted for inflation or to account for 3-D and Imax ticket prices.)

headline: Blatter Sidesteps Tough Questions
text: Sepp Blatter, the embattled president of FIFA, endured more than 30 minutes of questions, many of which he deflected, during an often contentious news conference Monday in Zurich.

headline: Charges for Opposition Protest in Georgia
text: MOSCOW — Authorities in Georgia on Monday charged the husband of a prominent opposition leader with organizing attacks on police, using paramilitary groups during violent anti-government protests last week.

headline: More Blows to Berlusconi Coalition
text: ROME — Italy’s ruling center-right coalition was resoundingly beaten in runoff administrative elections on Monday, a defeat that further weakened Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has been besieged by growing dissent within his razor-thin majority and faces criminal charges in court.

headline: The Morning Line: As Horses Arrive at Belmont, Alternation Is Out
text: Alternation, the winner of the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park on May 12, will not race in the Belmont. According to the Daily Racing Form, Alternation will concentrate on major stakes events over the summer. Alternation’s trainer Donnie Van Hemel said, “We looked things over and decided to take a breather. … The horse is fine. We just decided to point for races like the Jim Dandy and the Travers. He’s had four or five races early in the year. We want to give him a little breather now, then make some noise later.”

headline: The Squeaky Joint
text: Q. Is there research on whether fish oil supplements help ease joint pain?

headline: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, 11:55 a.m.
text: A Memorial Day parade on Third Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

headline: Childbirth: Every Week in Utero Counts, Study Says
text: Pregnancies lasting at least 37 weeks are regarded as safely full-term, but new research finds that babies born in the 37th or 38th week of pregnancy have a higher risk of dying before their first birthdays than those born after 39 weeks of gestation.

headline: Patterns: Seniors Fare Better Where Doctors Are
text: Older adults who live in areas with high concentrations of primary care doctors are less likely than those in areas with fewer such doctors to be hospitalized for illnesses that can be managed outside a hospital, like asthma and diabetes, a new study has found.

headline: Risks: Hypertension Lurking in Young Adults
text: A new study finds that nearly one in five young adults has high blood pressure, a startling estimate much higher than any previously reported.

headline: A Resolute Sharapova Holds Off Radwanska
text: PARIS — Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland, her left leg heavily bandaged, managed to jump ahead of Maria Sharapova of Russia, 3-0, in a fourth-round match Monday at the French Open. For awhile, she didn’t dare look back.

headline: A Good Night’s Sleep Isn’t a Luxury; It’s a Necessity
text: In my younger years, I regarded sleep as a necessary evil, nature’s way of thwarting my desire to cram as many activities into a 24-hour day as possible. I frequently flew the red-eye from California, for instance, sailing (or so I thought) through the next day on less than four hours of uncomfortable sleep.

headline: Drug Trade Flourishes in Spanish Port Town
text: BARBATE, SPAIN — In the police station of Barbate, a port town in the southern region of Andalusia, officers have pinned a poster to the wall that reads “they owe us April,” referring to the late payment of their salaries.

headline: The Claim: A Diet High in Protein Is Bad for Your Kidneys
text: THE FACTS

headline: Dissident Plans a More Active Role in Myanmar
text: HONG KONG — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the most high-profile dissident in Myanmar, signaled on Monday that she would be seeking to broaden her audience in her country since being released from house arrest.

headline: Dispatching the Worn Narrative of the 2006 Finals
text: When the Dallas Mavericks and Miami Heat crystallized their date to meet in the N.B.A. Finals, media dreams of rehashed narratives came true. Dirk Nowitzki will finally be given his shot at revenge and redemption, or so say the series taglines. Yet depicting these N.B.A. Finals as a rematch or even a re-imagining doesn’t do the matchup justice; these teams aren’t two shadows of their 2006 counterparts, but unique and successful basketball machines. Sport doesn’t pack the same punch without the underlying story, but is it really necessary to dig up ancient history?

headline: Young Russians in Brooklyn Find Love, the Wonder Wheel and Then Life
text: There comes a point in almost every relationship when you discuss the future. Where is this heading? Do you want to get married? Do you want to get married? Vaclav and Lena have had this talk. It has gone well. Vaclav and Lena are 10.

headline: Gaining Perspective, Small and Large, With Dolls
text: In the movie “Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,” an inventor accidently miniaturizes his children, making the world appear enormous to them. Now, scientists have simulated the sensation of feeling tiny using cameras and a doll.

headline: Housing Index Is Expected to Show a New Low in Prices
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The desire to own your own home, long a bedrock of the American Dream, is fast becoming a casualty of the worst housing downturn since the Great Depression.

headline: In I.P.O. Price Debate, an Investment Giant Weighs In
text: You might recall that about a week ago, my colleague Joe Nocera wrote an intriguing column about LinkedIn‘s initial public offering, in which he said that the bankers who underwrote the deal “scammed” the social network company by pricing it too low, lining the pockets of its investor clients.

headline: The Bilingual Advantage
text: A cognitive neuroscientist, Ellen Bialystok has spent almost 40 years learning about how bilingualism sharpens the mind. Her good news: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms. Dr. Bialystok, 62, a distinguished research professor of psychology at York University in Toronto, was awarded a $100,000 Killam Prize last year for her contributions to social science. We spoke for two hours in a Washington hotel room in February and again, more recently, by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

headline: Darkness Delays Fifth Set of Murray-Troicki
text: PARIS -– Victor Troicki of Serbia jumped out to a 5-0 lead in the first set of his match with Andy Murray of Britain at the French Open Monday.

headline: Pharmaceutical Giant to Give $5.7 Million Toward Health Programs in Poor Countries
text: Fulfilling a promise made several years ago, the pharmaceutical giant GlaxoSmithKline, based in London, will use 20 percent of the profits it made in the world’s poorest countries to finance health care initiatives, the company announced last week.

headline: Shoulda Coulda Woulda
text: Jared Bernstein has a thoughtful response to today’s column; oh, and by the way, people should be reading his blog.

headline: ‘Bali: Art, Ritual Performance’
text: Images from the exhibition in San Francisco.

headline: A Storied Paradise, Tempered by Reality
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On a recent nothing-special weekday afternoon, I walked into the Asian Art Museum here and found a Balinese gamelan concert in progress: clanging gongs, pulsing drums, jazzy flutes, the whole real heavenly thing, with musicians settled cross-legged on a fabric-draped platform and a rapt crowd of museumgoers, many quite young, on benches, folding chairs and the floor.

headline: New Evidence on Iran’s Nuclear Aspirations
text: In a report by the International Atomic Energy Agency, seven categories of technology are cited as possible evidence that Tehran’s nuclear program aims to build an implosion nuclear device.

headline: Wal-Mart Is Being Pressed to Disclose How Global Suppliers Treat Workers
text: Wal-Mart is facing new pressure to monitor and disclose how its international suppliers treat their workers.

headline: Bubble-debt Denialism
text: For a project I’m working on, I went back to the famous 2004 speech in which Alan Greenspan not only denied that there was a national housing bubble, but denied that it was even possible to have a national housing bubble.

headline: Inspectors Pierce Iran’s Cloak of Nuclear Secrecy
text: The International Atomic Energy Agency last week presented a report to its board that laid out new information on what it calls “possible military dimensions” of Iran’s nuclear program, clarifying the central issue in the long clash between Tehran and the West over nuclear technology.

headline: She’s Married to a Gunman and Willing to Sing About It
text: There’s a lot of pretty good in the first act of “I Married Wyatt Earp,” a musical at 59E59 Theaters. The story? Pretty good. Songs? Pretty good. Acting, singing, jokes? Same, same, same. Yet as it wanders into an aimless second act, that pretty goodness wanes, and you long for the show to race toward a bigger finish or to stop and explore a smaller moment.

headline: Groundwater Depletion Is Detected From Space
text: IRVINE, Calif. — Scientists have been using small variations in the Earth’s gravity to identify trouble spots around the globe where people are making unsustainable demands on groundwater, one of the planet’s main sources of fresh water.

headline: The Not-as-Hot Art Market for Formerly Hot Artists
text: The contemporary art market has boomed in the last 10 years, characterized by the steep ascent of artists like Gerhard Richter. But the work of some contemporary artists has not appreciated at the same rate.

headline: Timescast | Protest in Inner Mongolia
text: May 30, 2011 - The Chinese police disbursed demonstrators in Hohhot, China, who were protesting the deaths five days ago of two ethnic Mongolians, caused by Han Chinese drivers.

headline: On the Road, More or Less, With Palin
text: Here’s an update for those of you following the whereabouts of Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska.

headline: Brooding Now Laced With Hope
text: DEATH CAB FOR CUTIE

headline: Summerworks Plays Are Announced
text: Clubbed Thumb, the Obie Award-winning New York theater company that commissions, develops and produces provocative plays, has announced titles for the 16th annual Summerworks festival, from Sunday through June 25, at Here Arts Center in Manhattan. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, will feature three new plays, according to  Maria Striar, Clubbed Thumb’s producing artistic director. They are  Tanya Saracho’s “Enfrascada,” directed by  Jerry Ruiz, from Thursday through June 11;  Kristin Newbom and  W. David Hancock’s “Our Lot,” directed by  May Adrales, from June 12 through 18; and  Jason Grote’s “Civilization (All You Can Eat),” directed by  Seth Bockley, from June 19 through 25.

headline: Sean Kingston Remains in Hospital After Crash
text: The pop star Sean Kingston who was hospitalized in Miami after an accident involving a personal watercraft on Sunday, was listed in stable condition on Monday, Billboard.com reported. The publicist Joseph Carozza issued a statement saying that Mr. Kingston, 21, had been moved to intensive care from the trauma unit. “Sean’s family thanks everyone for their prayers and support during this time,” Mr. Carozza said. Mr. Kingston, whose real name is Kisean Anderson, was taken to Jackson Memorial Hospital after he and a female passenger aboard his watercraft crashed into a bridge around 6 p.m. A boater rescued them from the water, and crews took them to the hospital. No details regarding the injuries have been released. Since breaking out with his debut single, “Beautiful Girls,” in 2007, Mr. Kingston has scored hits like “Take You There,” “Fire Burning” and “Eenie Meenie” with Justin Bieber, whom he joined on tour last year. Mr. Kingston received an outpouring of support by his fans and his peers on Twitter, including Mr. Bieber, Rihanna, Nicki Minaj and Chris Brown.

headline: Artists Remember Gil Scott-Heron
text: Tributes have been pouring in from around the world from musicians and friends of the poet and music pioneer Gil Scott-Heron, who died on Friday at 62. Eminem,  Talib Kweli and Snoop Dogg were among the rappers who acknowledged Mr. Scott-Heron’s early influence on hip-hop and black protest culture after hearing the news, according to BBC News. The cause of death was not immediately known, though The Associated Press reported that Mr. Scott-Heron had become ill after returning from a trip to Europe. Chuck D of Public Enemy posted on Twitter, “We do what we do and how we do because of you.” Wu-Tang Clan’s Ghostface Killah wrote: “Salute Gil Scott-Heron for his wisdom and poetry! May he rest in paradise.” Eminem wrote on Twitter: “RIP Gil Scott-Heron. He influenced all of hip-hop.” Cee Lo Green recognized “the god Gil Scott,” while Talib Kweli said he “completely influenced me as an artist.” The politically outspoken rapper Michael Franti said Mr. Scott-Heron’s talent was his ability to “make us think about the world in a different way.”  Richard Russell, who produced and released Mr. Scott-Heron’s final album, “I’m New Here in 2010,” described him as “a master lyricist, singer, orator and keyboard player.”  Lemn Sissay, a friend of Mr. Scott-Heron’s who produced a documentary on his work, told the BBC that he was “a polymath” who “spoke crucially of the issues of his people.”

headline: Royal Love Story Heads to Hallmark
text: You saw the wedding. You followed the postnuptials gossip. Now a film about the romance of Prince William and Kate Middleton is expected to be released in August on the Hallmark Channel, The Associated Press reported. “William & Kate: A Royal Love Story” is a mixture of fact and fiction, according to the director, Linda Yellen, who took some time out from filming at MediaPro Studios in Romania to talk with The A.P. about her project. Ms. Yellen was the producer of CBS’s film “The Royal Romance of Charles and Diana” (1982), which drew a huge audience. “William & Kate” is more than a romance; it’s also “a psychological story of the memory of the mother, in this case Princess Diana, and her legacy,” Ms. Yellen said. The film shows how William “has to choose to live his life with her memory and with the decisions he has to make,” including the decision of whom to marry. The couple were married on April 29 in a lavish ceremony at Westminster Abbey. Filming for the movie, which imagines some scenes from the couple’s romance, began in early May. Ms. Yellen, who met Princess Diana, described the project as “a very personal story.” She added, “In a way, it’s my tribute to her as well as a tribute to the young couple.”

headline: Morning Feast on the Bolshoi (Popcorn, Too)
text: On Sunday morning, in a live transmission of the Bolshoi Ballet’s production of the three-act “Coppélia,” the extraordinary ballerina Natalia Osipova bounded with her characteristic élan onto a New York cinema screen. The camera — though only employing close-ups for acting passages — often followed her full-frame, so that we had only a blurry sense of the space around her: disorienting but exciting. In the intimate cinema, people kept starting to applaud.

headline: Despite Advances, Tornado Forecasts Show Limits
text: It was a warm, damp day in central Nebraska, heavy and still. The tornado arrived at the Madsen farm just before 3 p.m. Mads Madsen, 63, his wife Minnie, 59, three of their children and five of their grandchildren were in the parlor eating Sunday dinner. Twenty minutes later all 10 of them were dead.

headline: From Elegiac Appalachian Hollers to New Terrain
text: Making Romulus Linney’s “Tennessee” the centerpiece of Series A of the Ensemble Studio Theater’s 33rd annual festival of one-acts was a fine idea.

headline: Viral Outbreaks in Dogs Yield Clues on Origins of Hepatitis C
text: Hepatitis C is, in some ways, a high-profile disease. Worldwide, an estimated 200 million people are infected with the virus. Some of them will suffer cirrhosis, liver cancer and even death. Celebrities like Steven Tyler of Aerosmith and “American Idol” have spoken publicly of their infections.

headline: To Rest Easy, Forget the Sheep
text: Scientists know that many people inadvertently undermine their ability to fall asleep and stay asleep for a full night. Here are some frequent suggestions:

headline: Tracking Economy, CO2 Emissions Hit New High
text: The International Energy Agency has reported that global emissions of carbon dioxide from energy use, tracking the recovering world economy,  hit a new high of 30.6 billion metric tons of the gas last year. (Emissions from deforestation and activities like cement manufacturing are not included.) That’s 5 percent above the previous peak, measured in 2008.

headline: With Their Fingers Crossed, Fans in Boston Embrace the Bruins
text: BOSTON — It has been a long time since so many Bostonians cared so much about the Bruins.

headline: Broad Brushstrokes Obscure a View of Brain Trauma
text: On a fall afternoon in 1988, Jon Sarkin, a 35-year-old Massachusetts chiropractor, was happily playing the eighth hole on a local golf course when he felt something “twist” in his brain. Three days later he began to hear a high-pitched screech, a siren that only grew louder with the passing weeks. Doctors shrugged; a brain scan suggested a vague abnormality near a nerve at the base of the brain that controls hearing and balance.

headline: Reyes Placed on Bereavement List
text: Jose Reyes left the Mets on Monday after the death of his grandmother and may be gone as long as a week on bereavement leave. That means a team already battered by injuries will now be without its best everyday player this season.

headline: PBS Plans Promotional Breaks Within Programs
text: FOR decades, the uninterrupted programming on PBS has been one of its most distinctive selling points to audiences and philanthropic and corporate supporters alike.

headline: A Source of Strength to Help Conquer Addiction
text: “First off,” the counselor began, her lips pursed in disdain, “it’s important you understand that I don’t have a nickel in the dime” — an addiction therapist’s way of saying this was my fight, not hers.

headline: Translation Matters in Choices on Data
text: If your doctor tells you that highly reliable studies have shown that taking a certain pill will cut your risk of getting a serious disease in half, would you take it?

headline: In Japan, a Culture That Promotes Nuclear Dependency
text: KASHIMA, Japan — When the Shimane nuclear plant was first proposed here more than 40 years ago, this rural port town put up such fierce resistance that the plant’s would-be operator, Chugoku Electric, almost scrapped the project. Angry fishermen vowed to defend areas where they had fished and harvested seaweed for generations.
