headline: Nadal Keeps Laboring, but He Keeps Winning
text: PARIS — It has often looked like work this year for Rafael Nadal at his favorite playground. He needed five sets in the first round of the French Open to disarm the unconventional weapons of the towering John Isner, and although Nadal has yet to lose another set on his well-worn path to the quarterfinals, there has been grinding and grumbling in unusual quantities.

headline: Former Pakistani Navy Commando Arrested in Sweep for Attack Suspects
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A former Pakistan Navy commando has been arrested in a sweep by Pakistani intelligence agents in connection with the audacious attack last week on the naval base in the southern port city of Karachi that apparently was planned with inside information about the facility, security officials said Monday.

headline: Union Man
text: On May 31, 1861, Joseph Holt spoke out on behalf of the Union. The man who had been Secretary of War in early 1861 (and who has a role played by Danny Huston in Robert Redford’s current film, “The Conspirator”) saw that his native state of Kentucky dangled precariously in the balance. Its leading men had just resolved upon “strict neutrality” between the Federal government and the Confederacy. Holt would have none of it. Neutrality, he insisted, was a delusion. He would as soon think “of being neutral in a contest between an officer of justice and an incendiary arrested in an attempt to fire the dwelling over my head.”

headline: With Shutout, Colon Continues to Be a Surprise
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Since Bartolo Colon last pitched here in September 2007 — a time before elbow surgery, before retirement was considered, before a rejuvenating medical treatment — the stadium has changed names twice, but its features have remained the same. The roomy dimensions and acres of foul territory reward pitchers unafraid of contact, encouraging them to throw strikes. And one thing Colon can do, has done, is throw strikes.

headline: Sudan’s Peaceful Partition, at Risk

headline: Keeping Score: Which Team Has the Right Stuff to Win the Cup?
text: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championship characteristics in our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.” Based on similar research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might predict the winner of the Stanley Cup finals, which start Wednesday in Vancouver. Focusing on concepts of sports psychology, we looked at factors such as big-game experience, leadership on the ice and consistency. So important are these concepts to winning championships that they have proven to be common themes across all sports we have studied.

headline: Einhorn Says Deal With Mets Is a ‘Win-Win’

The hedge fund mogul, who met reporters during batting practice before the Mets played the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field on Monday, said that the deal being negotiating with the Wilpon family was a “win-win” agreement that he hopes will be completed by the end of June.

headline: Instead of Student Loans, Investing in Futures
text: As the global economy has become more knowledge-based, the importance of a university education has risen dramatically. However, only 7 percent of the world’s population currently has a college degree. There are many reasons why people fail to reach college, including, of course, lack of access to quality primary and secondary schooling. But for millions of students who could succeed in college, the limiting factor is money.

headline: 2 Americans Are Indicted in Iraq Contract Bribery
text: BAGHDAD — Two American businessmen have been charged with giving Army officers airline tickets, spa vacations and more than $1 million in bribes to secure multimillion-dollar contracts to supply the American military and help rebuild Iraq, according to court documents.

headline: Analysis: How Murray Rallied to Tie Troicki
text: Viktor Troicki started fast in Monday’s match against Andy Murray, serving bombs and testing Murray’s injured right ankle as he swept to a two-set lead. When he broke Murray’s serve at 1-1 in the third set, the Scotsman looked dispirited. But he broke right back and began to find rhythm with his footwork and movement.

headline: The Good Banker
text: Not long ago, as I was leaving a business lunch, my luncheon companion handed me a thin manila envelope. He didn’t tell me what was in it or why he had given it to me, but as soon as I opened it up, I immediately understood.

headline: While Virginia Celebrates Another Title, Relief Combines With Elation
text: BALTIMORE — At the end of his strangest season in 29 years of coaching lacrosse, Virginia’s Dom Starsia looked exhausted, weary, worn. He entered his news conference Monday night drenched in sweat, absent a smile or any outward signs of celebration, yet with his fourth and most unlikely national title already secured.

headline: Trees Felled By Joplin Tornado Leaves Broken Landscape
text: Stripped bare by the swirling wind — as if ravaged by wildfire — the skeletons of oak, elm, and hickory stand sentinel over a wasteland.

headline: Once-Stately Trees Tell a Tale of Destruction in Joplin
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — The tornado’s destruction two Sundays ago was so absolute in some areas of this city that the sweep of the landscape is now broken only by the thick skeletons of oak, elm and hickory.

headline: It’s Not About You
text: Over the past few weeks, America’s colleges have sent another class of graduates off into the world. These graduates possess something of inestimable value. Nearly every sensible middle-aged person would give away all their money to be able to go back to age 22 and begin adulthood anew.

headline: Accusations Are Replaced by Anger at FIFA
text: The American official who blew the whistle on the latest charges of corruption in FIFA, soccer’s world governing body, said Monday that he had not seen concrete evidence of vote-buying in his two decades as a high-ranking executive in the regional confederation in which the United States plays.

headline: Abdias do Nascimento, Rights Voice, Dies at 97
text: Abdias do Nascimento, a Brazilian writer, painter, politician and scholar who was an outspoken civil rights leader on behalf of black Brazilians, has died in Rio de Janeiro. He was 97.

headline: The Numbers Are Grim

headline: U.S. Engages With an Iron Leader in Equatorial Guinea

headline: Gov. Christie Abandons a Good Idea
text: Running for governor in 2009, Chris Christie vowed to become “New Jersey’s No. 1 clean-energy advocate.” That was a hollow promise. As governor, Mr. Christie proceeded to cut all the money for the Office of Climate and Energy. He raided $158 million from the clean energy fund, meant for alternative energy investments, and spent it on general programs. He withdrew the state from an important lawsuit against electric utilities to reduce emissions.

headline: Video of Tortured Boy’s Corpse Deepens Anger in Syria

Nothing was known of him for a month before his mutilated corpse was returned to his family on the condition, according to activists, that they never speak of his brutal end.

headline: Under an Arizona Plan, Smokers and the Obese Would Pay Medicaid Fee
text: Arizona, like many other states, says it is no longer able to finance its Medicaid program adequately. As part of a plan to cut costs, the state has proposed imposing a $50 fee on childless adults on Medicaid who are either obese or who smoke. In Arizona, almost half of all Medicaid recipients smoke; while the number of obese people is unclear, about one in four Arizonans is overweight, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The state’s plan must ultimately be approved by the federal government. Monica Coury, spokeswoman for Arizona’s Medicaid program, discusses.

headline: E. Coli Death Toll Grows in Europe
text: The authorities in Europe stepped up efforts on Monday to halt a deadly E. coli outbreak, and Spain and Germany argued over the source of the bacteria. Officials in Germany said the death toll had climbed to 13 in one of the largest outbreaks ever reported. Hundreds of Europeans have suffered from diarrhea, cramps and other symptoms, and vegetables have been pulled from shelves in a number of countries. Germany said Spanish cucumbers could be a source, an announcement that Spain called “an irresponsibility and an atrocity.” A crucial question was whether the disease could have developed on delivery routes between Spain and Germany, or in storage areas.

headline: Fantasy Focus: Moving the Needle
text: It’s hard for a first-round pick to move up significantly, but aside from Jose Bautista, Ryan Braun is probably the top hitter in fantasy baseball this year. While Braun’s 12 home runs and .588 slugging percentage through Sunday are improvements over last year’s rates, the number that jumps out most is his 13 steals in 14 attempts. Milwaukee’s new manager, Ron Roenicke, is more aggressive on the basepaths than his predecessor, Ken Macha: the Brewers are 14th in the majors in stolen bases this year, as opposed to 21st last year, and Braun in particular is getting the green light. At this pace, a 35-35 season is within reach, and with Braun, you’re virtually assured a good batting average. Only Carlos Gonzalez and maybe Matt Kemp offer the same speed-power-average upside, and Gonzalez is struggling this year.Jacoby Ellsbury’s 2010 was a lost season because of rib injuries, but as he is 27, his value has never been higher. The 19 stolen bases through Sunday put him on pace for close to 60 steals, and that’s not accounting for chilly early-season conditions that often slow the running game. Ellsbury also has 6 home runs and 16 doubles and is posting a .298/.368/.462 line in 208 at-bats while hitting leadoff in one of the league’s best lineups. In short, he’s what the Red Sox hoped Carl Crawford would be when they gave him $142 million. Crawford was a late first-round pick in most leagues, and Ellsbury must be considered similarly at this point.

headline: Kapoor’s ‘Leviathan’ Fills Grand Palais in Paris
text: Invited for the fourth edition of the Grand Palais’s annual Monumenta exhibition, the artist Anish Kapoor chose to take the title of the event literally. His creation, titled “Leviathan,” fills the large-scale venue with a giant sculpture — measuring about 775,000 square feet — that seems to push the walls of the building and, within its interior, drenches the viewer with a blood-red hue.

headline: Keeping Score: Championship Characteristics in the N.B.A. Finals
text: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, “Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method.” Based on this research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might help predict the winner of the N.B.A. finals, which start Tuesday night in Miami. Last year’s analysis highlighted leadership factors and correctly predicted that the Lakers would win the championship.

headline: The Changing (Communication) Climate
text: One of my mantras these days is that traditional media are a shrinking wedge of an explosively growing pie of communication options. I make the point frequently in encouraging scientists and their institutions to recognize that the old model of drafting a press release and waiting for the phone to ring is not the path to efficacy and impact.

headline: Ristretto | Stumptown Stubbies
text: Give Stumptown Coffee Roasters points for style. The small-batch roaster just started selling cold-brewed coffee in dark amber glass bottles — stubbies — that look as if they belong in a cooler on the porch.

headline: Echoes of Barber, Literally
text: There is probably no piece of classical music written in the 20th century that is better known or more associated with grief than Barber’s Adagio for Strings — it was played at the funerals of John F. Kennedy and Franklin D. Roosevelt, popularized by Oliver Stone’s 1986 Vietnam War film, “Platoon,” and remixed by numerous D.J.s and pop singers.

headline: Tuesday Reading: New Ways to Answer Hospital Patients’ Calls
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Driver Arrested After Fatal Bus Crash in Virginia; Carrier Has Record of Violations
text: Virginia authorities arrested the driver of a commercial bus that rolled over in Virginia on Tuesday, killing four people, and charged him with reckless driving. The accident was the latest of several for the bus operator, which has been cited for dozens of violations including driver fatigue, a factor the police believe caused this crash.

headline: Prospect Park Condom Crew Picks Up After Others Cavort
text: Marie Viljoen padded through the woods in Prospect Park one recent morning like a Brooklyn-chic bushwhacker in cargo pants, tall leather boots and a shock of red lipstick. She stepped delicately over damp logs and poison-ivy patches, a metal trash-grabber in one hand, a black trash bag in the other.

headline: Venice Biennale: Up the Canal Without a Water Bus
text: VENICE — The weather may be picture-perfect, but the stars were not all aligned for the first day the giant Biennale was open to the art press and V.I.P.’s. A one-day water-bus strike has crippled this shimmering city. When asked the reason for the walkout, a concierge at the chic Hotel Danieli, shrugged and replied, “Money, madame,’’ like everywhere else.

headline: Tanner Foust Soars 332 Feet to Set Record at Indy 500
text: INDIANAPOLIS — As race fans trickled in to Indianapolis Motor Speedway for Sunday’s 100th anniversary Indianapolis 500, a purpose-built off-road truck was being winched slowly up a steep orange track, backwards.

headline: China: Tiananmen Payment Discussed, Activists Say
text: A group of mothers demanding justice for the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 4, 1989, said Tuesday that police officials in Beijing had contacted one family in April to discuss giving compensation for the death in that family. It was a rare instance in which officials had mentioned compensation in relation to the killings. However, the group said in a letter circulated on the Internet that the police officials did not talk about revealing the truth of the killings, legal redress or the possibility of addressing each case. Instead, “they simply raised the issue of how much money should be given and stressed that this is for individuals, not the group as a whole,” said the letter, which had 127 signatures. The group said: “The bottom line is this: the souls of those killed during June 4 shall not be defiled; their families shall not be dishonored.”

headline: Palin Ditches Press and Tours Battlefield
text: GETTYSBURG, Pa. — Sarah Palin took a brief tour of the Gettysburg battlefield and cemetery Tuesday morning as she and her family continued their “One Nation” tour of historical sites.

headline: More Words We Love Too Much
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: One Last Note on Barcelona’s Midfield Mastery
text: John Kennedy is a Goal blog reader and a video producer whose credits include the Purple States series that ran on nytimes.com in 2008. He’s also a former college soccer player who wrote in with an interesting take on Barcelona’s success in the Champions League final.

headline: Using Public Relations to Drive Demand
text: Jill Cartwright hatched the idea for Go GaGa, an online retailer of bags used to tote everything from baby gear to camera equipment, while earning her M.B.A. at Babson. She graduated and started the company in 2007. That fall, she attended trade shows ABC Kids Expo, ENK Children’s Club, and New York International Gift Fair. She emerged with pre-orders and began producing her products, which she says are differentiated by an ergonomically safe strap, in January, 2008.

headline: Expressive Attraction
text: Every day Kevin Lewis, who covers the social sciences for National Affairs and the Boston Globe, blasts out an email of wonky goodness—a collection of 10 to 20 study abstracts. Last Saturday’s was particularly rich. He sent out the abstract of a study by Jessica Tracy and Alex Beall from a forthcoming issue of Emotion.

headline: Iraq: Arrest in Killing of Anti-Baathist Politician
text: A former member of Saddam Hussein’s intelligence service was arrested in the assassination of Ali Faisal al-Lami, left, a politician who oversaw efforts to purge scores of candidates from national ballots because of ties to the former government, the Iraqi police announced Tuesday. They said the suspect was arrested in the Taji area north of Baghdad but did not release his name or provide any evidence tying him to the killing. Mr. Lami, a Shiite Muslim, was gunned down Thursday night as he drove through Baghdad, becoming one of the most prominent victims of an assassination campaign aimed at security forces and government officials. As the head of Iraq’s Accountability and Justice Commission, Mr. Lami played a central role in last year’s politically divisive attempt to bar a number of candidates, many of them Sunnis, from parliamentary elections.

headline: Should Medical School Be Free?
text: Can free medical school help fix the American health care system? In this weekend’s opinion section, two physicians, Dr. Peter B. Bach and Dr. Robert Kocher, propose that it can.

headline: Schiavone Recovers and Outlasts Pavlyuchenkova
text: PARIS — It took Francesca Schiavone of Italy 21 minutes to get on the scoreboard at Roland Garros, almost enough time for Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova of Russia to run away with the match – but not quite.

headline: Forged Painting Was Once in Collection of Steve Martin, German Police Say

headline: Makeshift Effort Rising to Oppose Cuts
text: There was a rally on May 12, when seasoned protesters convened by the thousands near City Hall to stake their claim against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s budget. There were gatherings at subway stations organized by the city’s public advocate, Bill de Blasio, at which hundreds of parents recorded messages and signed petitions  against cuts to their children’s schools.

headline: Face Time | Lela Rose
text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist, who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: The End-of-School-Year Scramble
text: In the conversation on Motherlode last week about how some parenting norms differ by neighborhood, many of you mentioned relationships with teachers. In some school districts, it is expected that parents will be present for all school activities; at others a parent who shows up too often is seen as pushy. In some places showering the teacher with end of year gifts is expected; elsewhere, is it frowned upon.

headline: A New York Dog Makes Its Hollywood Debut
text: HOLLYWOOD — It is tucked in a storefront a block from the Walk of Fame, walking distance from the annual Academy Awards ceremonies, and steps from the hubbub of tourists, hucksters and celebrity hunters that is Hollywood: a Papaya King hot dog stand, in all its garish yellow and orange glory, selling hot dogs imported straight from the Bronx.

headline: Housing’s Rise and Fall in 20 Cities
text: Not seasonally-adjusted Case-Shiller house prices for 20 U.S. metro-areas.

headline: Obama Nominates Bryson for Commerce Secretary
text: 2:43 p.m. | Updated President Obama named a California utility and energy executive, John E. Bryson, as his second secretary of commerce at the White House on Tuesday afternoon, ending a search for an executive to add a business outlook to his economic team.

headline: Suspect Held in ’06 Killing of Journalist in Moscow
text: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities on Tuesday arrested the man they suspect of shooting the journalist Anna Politkovskaya, whose apparent contract killing in 2006 sent a chilling message about the hazards of challenging the powerful in contemporary Russia.

headline: Kamoinge Photographers Convey Black Experience
text: Kamoinge, a group of mostly New York photographers who strive to capture the black experience, are creating an archive of their work. The group first assembled in 1963 and now has 24 members, with some focusing on documentary work, others on fine art. They are all driven by a similar passion: honest portrayal. “What we’re documenting isn’t just black history,” said Russell Frederick, one of Kamoinge’s newer members. “It’s American history; it’s global history. It’s something that everybody needs to see.” Read and see more on the Lens blog.

headline: Trichet to Leave a Difficult Legacy at Central Bank
text: FRANKFURT — Since Europe’s debt crisis became acute last year, the European Central Bank has gone beyond its role as arbiter of monetary policy to become in effect the adult supervision for quarreling heads of government.

headline: In Twist, Federer Can Play Spoiler Against Djokovic
text: PARIS — Now it is Roger Federer’s turn to be the spoiler, and there is much to spoil.

headline: Zuma’s Office Says Qaddafi Intent on Staying in Libya
text: JOHANNESBURG — In talks with South Africa President Jacob Zuma, the Libya leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi “emphasized” that he will not leave Libya despite air attacks and international pressure, according to a statement released Tuesday by Mr. Zuma’s office.

headline: The Morning Line: Shackleford Settles In at Belmont
text: Shackleford, the winner of the Preakness, arrived at Belmont Park Monday morning. He arrived after an overnight 15-hour van ride from Churchill Downs. The New York Daily News reported that “the 3-year-old colt is expected to gallop over Belmont’s main oval Wednesday, before having an official workout over the strip Saturday.” The Associated Press said that the trainer Dale Romans “wants to make sure the 3-year-old colt is in top condition before committing to the Belmont.”

headline: Video Game Decides Canucks Will Win Stanley Cup
text: Don’t mess with the video game simulation, as it appears to know all, at least when it comes to hockey.

headline: The Twins’ Connection: Other Theories
text: As I wrote in Sunday’s cover story, 4-year-old conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan seem — based on casual observation and (as yet unpublished) scientific research — to share some sensory perception. Their neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Children’s Hospital, believes that a neural bridge that links the thalamus of one girl to that of the other could explain why, for example, Tatiana would be able to see the stuffed animal Krista is holding, even when Tatiana’s eyes are closed.

headline: Hospital call buttons, 30 years on the AIDS watch and the World Science Festival.
text: This week: When you push that hospital call button, is anybody listening? Thirty years on the AIDS watch. And a science fair to remember.

headline: Homecoming for a Veteran of the ‘Secret War’ in Southeast Asia
text: Thousands of people in the quiet towns of Concord and Kannapolis, N.C., will remember the weekend of April 30 and May 1 for a long time.

headline: How Rising Stock Prices Can Fool You
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

headline: In Novel by Mayor’s Daughter, Hints of Family Life
text: Those who inhabit the rarefied world of Michael R. Bloomberg, with all its perquisites and payouts, have long adhered to a strict code of silence about his personal life: jaunts to Bermuda are cloaked in secrecy, tax returns are heavily redacted and even his golf handicap is off limits.

headline: Headed Back to Court, N.F.L. May Gain Clarity
text: At the N.F.L. owners meeting last week, John Mara, the president of the Giants, was asked if the Super Bowl, scheduled for February in Indianapolis, would be played. Yes, he told a reporter, he was confident Indianapolis would have its Super Bowl.

headline: As China’s Workers Get a Raise, Companies Fret
text: HONG KONG — Wages are surging this year in China and among its main low-wage Asian rivals, benefiting workers across the region. But the increases confront trading companies and Western retailers with cost increases and are making higher prices likely for American and European consumers.

headline: Crises at FIFA and Ohio State
text: Memorial Day is normally a placid day in sports that allows us to remember what we’re supposed to be remembering, and no, not just how long to grill the burgers. But on Monday the whole metaphorical barbecue flared so badly that all our eyebrows got singed: Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel felt the flames lapping at his sweater vest and quit amid a deepening N.C.A.A. scandal, and Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, called a nonsensical news conference to proclaim there is no scandal in his organization because he says so and because he is FIFA’s president, “You cannot question me.” Feel free to imagine him shaking a spatula at you.

headline: A Saudi Activist, in Her Own Words
text: As Arab News reported, a Saudi woman who was detained for more than a week for defying Saudi Arabia’s ban on female drivers was released on Monday.

headline: Standing When the First Lady Pays a Call
text: On Memorial Day, Michelle Obama made an unannounced trip to visit the wounded at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Joao Silva of The New York Times was among those on whom she paid a call. “She came across as a kind and attentive person,” Mr. Silva said. She asked about the progress of his recovery and gave yo-yos, Frisbees and White House candies to his children, Isabel, 6, and Gabriel, 5.

headline: Why Did Apple Pre-Announce Its Announcement?
text: New product announcements by Apple usually take place with the secrecy of a clandestine military operation.

headline: Off the Beaten Path in Greece
text: Q.

headline: The Vogue Intern | Katie Ermilio
text: It’s a well-known fact that Vogue assistants often move on to become designers: Irini Arakas of Prova, Aimee Cho of Gryphon and Eviana Hartman of Bodkin. But who knew that Vogue interns also graduate from the 12th floor right into their own fashion labels? In fairness, Katie Ermilio, who interned at Vogue, had a stint at Teen Vogue before leaving to devote herself full time to making clothes. “I grew up in the business,” says Ermilio, whose dad owns Ermilio Clothiers, a bespoke men’s-wear shop in Philadelphia. “But I always thought I was going to be a fashion editor — I had no interest in becoming a designer at all.”

headline: Historical Society Snags a Founding Father’s Notebooks
text: The New-York Historical Society, already the repository of several sets of original notes by delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1787, received yet another last week: the notebooks of John Lansing Jr. of New York, who recorded many of the convention’s debates.

headline: Eamon Dolan to Leave Penguin Press
text: Eamon Dolan, a prominent editor at the Penguin Press who lost one of his titles in a recent shake-up at the publisher, will leave to run his own imprint for a competitor, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

headline: Nokia Lowers Second-Quarter Forecast and Abandons 2011 Profit Goals
text: Nokia, the cellphone giant battling to maintain its position in the face of competition from the iPhone and Android, said Tuesday that it was abandoning its 2011 profit targets after an unexpectedly poor second-quarter showing.

headline: What ‘Hobbit’ Curse? Jackson’s Movies Get Star-Crossed Release Dates
text: As if to prove that there are no supernatural forces working against Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit” movies, for which that director has already contended with a labor dispute, the occasional explosion and emergency ulcer surgery, the studios have settled on some interesting release dates for the two-part fantasy epic. New Line Cinema, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said in a joint statement reported by The Associated Press that the first “Hobbit” movie would open on Dec. 14, 2012, when some scholars say is the 509th anniversary of the birth of Nostradamus, the French astrologer and soothsayer. (Historical spoilsports say he was born on Dec. 21.) And the concluding “Hobbit” film will be released on Dec. 13, 2013, a date that not only has two 13s but is also, wouldn’t you know it, Friday the 13th.

headline: Pakistani Journalist Who Covered Security and Terrorism Is Found Dead
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A well-known Pakistani journalist has been found dead after being abducted over the weekend in an upscale neighborhood here and receiving repeated threats from Pakistan’s premier intelligence agency.

text: The award-winning actress and author Betty White shares stories from her seven-decade career with New York Times national correspondent Frank Bruni.

headline: Chile Military File Suggests Allende May Not Have Killed Himself
text: SANTIAGO, Chile – A newly disclosed military legal file has cast fresh doubt on whether former President Salvador Allende, who died during the September 11, 1973 military coup, committed suicide, as the official version and his own family have always claimed.

headline: Bartoli Bounds Past Kuznetsova Into Semifinals
text: PARIS — Marion Bartoli of France likes to bounce up and down as she stands at the baseline preparing to serve. There was extra bounce in the 23rd minute of her quarterfinal match Tuesday at the French Open.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
text: Ad Store, New York, is opening a satellite office, in Kabul, Afghanistan, to be led by Massoud Etemadi, an Afghan native who is the creative director of the Ad Store Washington office. Mr. Etemadi will be president of Ad Store Kabul, which will operate under the direction of Ad Store D.C.

headline: Reaction to Dempsey Appointment
text: Our colleagues Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker report on President Obama’s nomination of Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the Army chief, to succeed Adm. Mike Mullen as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In a brief Rose Garden announcement in the midst of Memorial Day observances, Mr. Obama highlighted the dual roles that General Dempsey, who, as chairman, will be the country’s highest-ranking military officer, must fill as the United States brings its troops home from Iraq, begins withdrawing from Afghanistan and takes part in the NATO operation in Libya. General Dempsey, the president said, understands that “military gains and political progress must go hand in hand.”

headline: Strange Creatures Promote Montreal’s Festivals
text: There’s a scene in the musical “Bells Are Ringing” in which a character gets so excited about meeting a “fabulous creature” that he joyously breaks into song. Imagine what he would have done if he had come across a new campaign with a menagerie of marvelous beasts.

headline: Peace Without Partners
text: It seems like months ago, rather than a week, that President Obama tried to move the Mideast ball down the field a bit, and Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, came to Washington. The applause in Congress for Netanyahu’s speech last Tuesday — the adjective universally used was “rapturous” — found an odd counterpoint in the negative reaction among most commentators. Fareed Zakaria simply ruled Netanyahu out of history.

headline: Monfils’s Magic Evaporates as Federer Advances
text: PARIS — France’s newest favorite tennis son, Gael Monfils, broke Roger Federer’s serve early in the first set, took 2-1 lead in their quarterfinal match on Tuesday at the French Open and made it look like it wasn’t much of an obstacle.

headline: On Our Radar: South Korea Investigates Dumping of Agent Orange
text: The South Korean authorities look into allegations by retired American soldiers that large amounts of the toxic defoliant Agent Orange, used extensively during the Vietnam War, were clandestinely buried at a onetime United States military base in the country. [Reuters]

headline: India and Pakistan Fail to Resolve Glacier Dispute at Talks
text: NEW DELHI — The slow, uncertain efforts to normalize relations between India and Pakistan apparently made little progress on Tuesday, after defense secretaries from both countries failed to deliver a breakthrough on demilitarizing a Himalayan glacier considered the world’s highest battlefield.

headline: Atlanta Loses Thrashers as N.H.L. Returns to Winnipeg
text: After 15 years, the N.H.L. is returning to Winnipeg.

headline: The Moon’s Tide
text: A study by Jeffry Rudski, Lauren Bernstein and Joy Mitchell in the Archives of Sexual Behavior studied the link between the menstrual cycle and perception. Female research subjects were asked to react to various Georgia O’Keeffe paintings. Nearly a third of the women in the first half of their monthly cycle discerned sexual themes in her paintings, while only 6 percent of the women in the second half of their cycle did. Women who were taking oral contraceptives saw the paintings the same way throughout the month.

headline: North and South Sudan Tentatively Agree to Demilitarize Disputed Border
text: JUBA, Sudan — Northern and southern Sudanese officials have agreed to a preliminary arrangement on demilitarizing the border between them, the African Union said Tuesday, though some officials from both sides immediately expressed skepticism of the deal, particularly its ability to resolve the dispute over the contested Abyei area.

headline: Race and Dating
text: Internet dating is fertile territory for people who study social patterns. Belinda Robnett and Cynthia Feliciano studied racial exclusion patterns in the Journal Social Forces. They looked at over 6000 internet dating profiles and found that whites are least open to dating outside their group, with Asians and Latinos close behind. Asian males and black females are more highly excluded than their opposite sex counterparts.

headline: New Rescue Package for Greece Takes Shape
text: LONDON — A new rescue package for Greece is taking shape, one that would offer billions of euros in new loans in return for accelerated privatization and tougher tax collection measures on the part of the beleaguered Greek government, European officials said on Tuesday.

headline: To Much Skepticism, Syria Issues Amnesty
text: As nationwide protests in Syria entered their 12th week, President Bashar al-Assad issued a general amnesty on Tuesday, Syrian state media reported.

headline: How Ashland Won International Specialty
text: For Ashland, the roots of its second-largest acquisition, International Specialty Products, lie in its biggest deal.

headline: Andy Robustelli, Giants’ Hall of Fame Defensive End, Dies at 85
text: Andy Robustelli, the Giants’ Hall of Fame defensive end in their glory years of the late 1950s and early ’60s, when shouts of “DEE-fense” rang from the stands at Yankee Stadium, died on Tuesday in Stamford, Conn., his hometown. He was 85.

headline: A Touch of Broadway in a New Ticketing App
text: Has standing in line for tickets to “The Book of Mormon” become too much of a mission? A new app could make getting tickets to Broadway shows as easy as a tap of the finger.

headline: Mount Street: A Haven of Luxury Shopping

headline: Fast Cars, Medieval Villages
text: 9:51 a.m. | Updated Ear plugs in, my friend Tom and I watched in awe from our seats three rows above the Monaco Grand Prix course as famous Formula One pilots I’d never heard of lurched around the sharp turn in front of us, their engines turning at up to 18,000 r.p.m.’s, making the noise of 18 million high-speed hornets. Just across the track, Champagne-sippers watched from their yachts in the bay.

headline: Former Buckeye Nicklaus Weighs In on Tressel’s Resignation
text: DUBLIN, Ohio -– Like anyone with any connection to Ohio State University athletics in this central-Ohio suburb of Columbus, Jack Nicklaus had opinions about the resignation of the Buckeyes’ highly successful football coach Jim Tressel this week.

headline: Photo Replay: May 31
text: The day in sports from quarterfinal matches at the French Open to the N.B.A. finals in Miami.

headline: Taking Stock of Goldman

headline: There Is No Sheep at the Table: What Exactly Is a Jokeless Comedy?
text: In this weekend’s Riff, I made the case that “jokeless comedies” — specifically, the films of Judd Apatow and Todd Phillips (and their lesser imitators) — have effectively ended the long run of gag-heavy comedies like “Ace Ventura: Pet Detective” and “Zoolander” (to pick two at random).

headline: Year-End Roundup | Social Studies, History, Geography and Civics
text: The school year is drawing to a close, and our lesson plans have already gone on summer vacation. So this week we’re looking back at the 2010-11 school year and collecting the year’s teaching materials by subject matter, starting today with social studies, American history and civics, global history, economics and geography.

headline: A Day in the Unelectrified Life, by Renault
text: Carlos Tavares, the former Nissan Americas head, recently was named the new chief operating officer at Renault. Along with Renault-Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn, Mr. Tavares has been an outspoken proponent of electric vehicles, appearing at various conferences to tout the Nissan Leaf E.V. and sound the trumpet for strengthening private and public outlays for E.V. infrastructure.

headline: Medicare Doublethink

headline: France Marshals G-20 to Combat Rising Food Costs

headline: Politics and the Stock Bubble
text: I’ve been getting some comments along the lines that I failed to see the Internet bubble, with the implication that I only see bad things when Republicans are in office.

headline: After Sex Attack, Stringer Warns Upper East Siders
text: The day after a man sexually assaulted and robbed an 85-year-old woman on the Upper East Side, Scott M. Stringer, the Manhattan borough president, is embarking on an effort to help catch the culprit and warn other elderly citizens that the suspect remains at large.

headline: Gaining Viewers While Losing Weight
text: Opposite mostly Memorial Day repeats, the premiere of ABC’s new reality show, “Extreme Makeover: Weight Loss Edition,” earned the highest ratings on Monday night in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49 while tying ABC’s two-hour installment of “The Bachelorette” as the night’s most-watched show.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Yemen, Serbia, Turkey and India.

headline: TimesCast | May 31, 2011
text: A cease-fire breaks down in Yemen; a look at the one banker on Wall Street sued by the S.E.C. for helping to sell a mortgage-securities investment; and FIFA’s scandal on the eve of elections.

headline: Three Americans Gain Women’s Doubles Semifinals
text: PARIS — Three Americans have reached the women’s doubles semifinals of the French Open championships, to be played on Wednesday at Roland Garros.

headline: Primary Global Shuts Offices, but Says It’s Still Open

headline: The Hidden Price of Drugs
text: Pharmaceutical companies are happy to tout the benefits of their newest drugs. But sometimes they seem far less willing to let the public know the price of the product.

headline: Justices Block Suit Over Use of Material Witness Law Against Detainee
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court unanimously ruled Tuesday that a man detained after the Sept. 11 attacks may not sue John D. Ashcroft, the former attorney general, for asserted misuse of the federal material witness law.

headline: The Laziest Generation(s)
text: Over the weekend I had an article on whether Generation Y — loosely defined as people born between the mid-’70s and the early ’00s — deserved its reputation as the laziest generation ever (a topic I also blogged about last week).

headline: Video: Rhoden on Nowitzki’s Quest for a Title
text: William C. Rhoden says what may be more intriguing than Dirk Nowitzki’s quest for his first N.B.A. title is how the news media will choose to cover it and whether race will play a role.

headline: The Fatty Crew Comes to the Battery
text: After some delay, the first kiosk of Fatty at the Battery, as Zakary Pelaccio’s Fatty Crew company is calling their new stands in Battery Park near Castle Clinton, will open Wednesday Thursday (they had to delay it a day) from noon to 7 p.m., selling hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches. (After that it will be open 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily.) Called Fatty ‘Cue, it’s to the left of a planted area called the Battery Bosque, in what had been Will Goldfarb’s Picnick stands. Fatty Snack, with pastries and ice cream will follow in about a week, once the ice cream machine is installed, and it will be farther the castle. There is some seating around the kiosks. For Kevin Pomplun, one of the chefs, it’s a reprise: he worked at Picnick.

headline: Cellphone Radiation May Cause Cancer, Advisory Panel Says
text: A World Health Organization panel has concluded that cellphones are “possibly carcinogenic,’’ putting the popular devices in the same category as certain dry cleaning chemicals and pesticides, as a potential threat to human health.

text: NBC, perhaps confirming its conviction that “The Voice” represents its best shot at a breakout hit in many years, announced Tuesday that it would offer a special edition of the singing competition on one of the best platforms in television — the hour after the conclusion of next season’s Super Bowl.

headline: Darkness Postpones Bryans’ Match in Final Set

headline: At Ballet Theater, Popping the Question After the Plié
text: Perhaps it’s the influence of all those story ballets, where love mostly triumphs (at least when no-one is dying young and becoming a Wili). American Ballet Theater seems to be experiencing an unusual rush of real romance, with three engagements over the last two weeks. On the opening night of the season, Ethan Stiefel proposed to his longtime girlfriend Gillian Murphy on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, moments after she and her partner David Hallberg had taken their curtain calls for the “Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux.” A few days later, the about-to-retire Cuban star Jose Manuel Carreño and corps de ballet dancer Melanie Hamrick announced their engagement. And on Friday, which happened to be the 30th birthday of the Royal Ballet guest artist Alina Cojocaru, her longtime on-and-offstage partner Johan Kobborg (who had arrived unexpectedly to fill in for the injured Maxim Beloserkovsky at the Saturday matinee of “Giselle”) popped the question.  Perhaps Alexei Ratmansky will choreograph a wedding dance.

headline: Analysis: Schiavone’s Comeback
text: As I watched Francesca Schiavone claw her way back into the second set against Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova, I remembered a story I’d heard about Allen Fox, the legendary coach and tennis guru who helped develop Brad Gilbert at Pepperdine. Fox would tell his players to persevere when they were struggling in a match, and to believe that if they just kept battling, their level of play would almost certainly rise.

headline: A Date for the Prom: ‘Carrie’ Sets Key Casting and First Performance Off Broadway
text: After a year of work, MCC Theater’s stab at salvaging the musical “Carrie” from the Broadway flop hall of shame is far enough along that the company announced on Tuesday that it will produce the show next season, with preview performances set to begin Off Broadway on Jan. 31, 2012.

headline: City Is Faulted on Enforcement of Window Guards

headline: Enhancing the Image of Feminist Art
text: Can you name three female artists? The people asked that question outside the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art can’t get much beyond Frida You-Know-Who-I-Mean. That’s old, sad news to Lynn Hershman Leeson, the director of “!Women Art Revolution” — “!W.A.R.” — a documentary history of the feminist art movement.

headline: Intact Financial to Buy AXA’s Canadian Unit
text: The Intact Financial Corporation, the big Toronto-based insurer, said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the Canadian insurance operation of the AXA Group of Paris for 2.6 billion Canadian dollars in cash ($2.68 billion).

headline: Met Museum to Add Hours, Charge $50 to Accommodate McQueen Show Crowds
text: High fashion and money have always gone together, and for the next few weeks, they will do so in the museum world as well as on the racks. The Metropolitan Museum of Art said Tuesday that its Alexander McQueen show, which it recently extended by a week to accommodate the overflow crowds, will be opened during special viewing hours on Mondays, when the Met is usually closed, for patrons willing to buy $50 tickets.

headline: How to Succeed in (Show) Business: Broadway Season Box Office Up Nearly 6 Percent
text: Broadway had another billion-dollar season between late May 2010 and Sunday, with shows grossing $1.08 billion — 5.9 percent more than the total for the 2009-10 season — and playing to more than 12.5 million people, according to the Broadway League, the trade group for theater owners and producers. That 2010-11 season attendance figure also reflects an increase of 5.4 percent over the previous season.

headline: Lunar Expedition
text: “We first met in Toronto, friends of friends, met on the scene, you know?” says the designer Jeremy Laing, referring to the artist Scott Treleaven. Laing is no stranger to the artist collaboration — in past seasons he worked with Karen Azoulay and also the band Grizzly Bear. For his fall collection (hitting stores this month), he and Trevleavan generated two different prints — a flaming hand and a moon — that will come in the form of silk jersey T-shirt and a slinky silk crepe dress. “Jeremy was in a mood of luminance and transformation, which coincided perfectly,” says Treleaven. “We were both seeing these circle patterns and lunar imagery.” The rest of the collection is a more subtle riff on the theme with crater-etched sweaters, voluminous wide-leg trousers and a black velvet sheath dress – albeit in the same pagan, slightly macabre spirit. “I really appreciate the collaborative process; it’s a great way to keep engaged and grasp onto someone else’s creativity,” Laing says.

headline: In a Bentley, Trying to Catch the Spotlight Again

headline: Tenpenny
text: YOU may hardly believe it, walking in through the narrow, undistinguished lobby of the Gotham Hotel on East 46th Street to enter Tenpenny at the end of the hall. It looks like a half-finished Bennigan’s in there, all brick face and wood and half-filled bookshelves, with room on the walls for flair. A skylight in the rear of the dining room offers a view up the backsides of surrounding skyscrapers: it is the view from the bottom of a well.

headline: New Hampshire Is Not Unique

Someone may point out, accurately, that New Hampshire had the highest primary-voter turnout of any state in 2008 — 53.6 percent, according to the United States Elections Project at George Mason University. (Iowa, a caucus state, had a turnout of only 16.1 percent.)

headline: A Bit of Hollywood, Minus the Tinsel
text: People who take things into their own hands and try to operate outside the institutional grid deserve our gratitude. So hats off to the organizers of “Greater LA,” a sprawling survey of recent art from Los Angeles arrayed in an immense, unrepentantly raw SoHo loft. It represents a tremendous effort on the part of three temporarily allied art professionals: Benjamin Godsill, a curator moonlighting from the New Museum; Joel Mesler, a partner in Untitled, an art gallery on the Lower East Side who began his art-dealing career in Los Angeles; and Eleanor Cayre, a New York collector and consultant who organized “The Station,” a large group show in Miami during the Basel Miami art fair in 2008.

headline: A Chef Has a Way With French Pastry
text: The name of Olivier Dessyn’s new pastry shop in Greenwich Village, Mille-feuille, is a term for what Americans call a napoleon. The ones he makes, with cream and praline fillings, are first-rate indulgences. So are his beautifully burnished croissants (modest in size but flaky and practically oozing butter), his pains au chocolat and his almond croissants. Another specialty of this French pastry chef are fine macarons in many flavors. And no wonder: he worked in Paris with the chef Pierre Hermé, who probably did more for the macaron than Proust did for the madeleine. Brownies (some with praline filling), cookies, madeleines and loaf cakes are also turned out by the busy bakers in the open kitchen. Soon, Mr. Dessyn promises summer fruit tartlets, éclairs and other classics, as well as some sandwiches and salads to enjoy at the cafe tables that are coming for sidewalk snacks.

headline: At Long Last, Tacos in Paris

headline: Seafood: Read All About It, and How to Cook It
text: “Seafood: How to Buy, Prepare and Cook the Best Sustainable Fish and Seafood From Around the World” has lavish color photography on each of its 400 pages. And even if you don’t try any of the 300 recipes that take up more than half the book, there is plenty to read and to learn. And there is a wealth of good dishes to try. Sesame prawn toasts (call them shrimp toast), smoked fish mousses, crostini and lots of breaded and fried little seafood balls for hors d’oeuvres are suitable for summer cocktails. These are followed by soups, salads, pastas, one-pot stews, fish pies and tarts, an intriguing collections of curry recipes from various Asian sources, and dishes grouped by technique: frying, baking, roasting, poaching, broiling and grilling.

headline: Pink and Green and Just to Cut Watermelon
text: You do not need a special knife for watermelon, but this one, with a watermelon-pink blade and a green handle, is as functional as it is fun. The blade is long (11 inches) and serrated to cut through the rind and the fruit. The little perforations that look like seeds and the blade’s bright silicone coating make slicing effortless. The knife comes in a matching sheath.

headline: The Manly Art of Cooking Has Its Bards
text: Not so long ago, most food-world workers — brewers, fishmongers, butchers — had jobs you’d describe as blue collar. This is changing. These days the guy downtown who makes pickles and collects artisanal tattoos on his forearms probably went to Brown and has a failed novella on his laptop. We need a new term for these humans. Bleu collar?

headline: ‘Frozen Conflict’ Between Azerbaijan and Armenia Begins to Boil
text: BAKU, Azerbaijan — In a mostly empty Soviet-era building here on a recent morning, a 29-year-old woman pressed her eye against the scope of a sniper rifle, brown hair spilling over her shoulder, and took aim at virtual commandos darting between virtual trees.
